translated: Because the restriction to being a part is not a reason.

analyzed: yat uktam pakṣa dharma tvam sapakṣe sattvam vipakṣa advaya āvṛttiḥ abādhita viṣaya tvam asat pratipakṣa tvam iti pañca rūpa upapannam anumānam iti
translated: As for what was said, that inference has five aspects: the property of the subject, presence in similar instances, absence in dissimilar instances, unobstructed object, and absence of counter-argument.

analyzed: yathā āha
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: anumeyena sambaddham prasiddham ca caśabda saṅgṛhītam iti
translated: And what is related to the inferable object and well-known, along with what is included by the word 'ca' (and).

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: kevala anvayinaḥ vipakṣa advaya āvṛtti abhāvena kevala vyatirekiṇaḥ ca sapakṣe sattā bhāvena avyāpaka tvāt
translated: Because the only positive example is not pervasive due to the absence of exclusion from the dissimilar example, and the only negative example is not pervasive due to the absence of existence in the similar example.

analyzed: kvacid catur rūpa upapanna tvam kvacid pañca rūpa upapanna tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in some cases it has four forms and in some cases it has five forms, that is not so.

analyzed: eka prayojaka alābhāt  vyāpti pakṣa dhama ṛta aupayika tvena eṣām grahaṇam
translated: Because there is no gain of a single cause.🔽These are grasped as being useful for the pervasion and the property of the subject.

analyzed: vastutas tu te eva anumāna aṅgam iti ced na
translated: But if it is argued that in reality they are only the components of inference, that is not so.

analyzed: pakṣa dharma tāyāḥ api aprayojaka tvāt  tathāca vyāptiḥ eva prayojikā iti vaktavyam
translated: Because the property of the subject is also not a cause.🔽And thus it must be said that only the pervasion is the cause.

analyzed: kim anena jalpitena iti āha vyāptiḥ eva iti
translated: What is the use of this talk? He says: The pervasion alone, etc.

analyzed: avinābhāvaḥ vyāptiḥ
translated: The invariable concomitance is the pervasion.

analyzed: sā dvividhā
translated: It is of two kinds.

analyzed: anvaya vyatireka bhedāt  sādhyena sādhanasya vyāptiḥ anvayaḥ
translated: Due to the difference of positive and negative concomitance.🔽The pervasion of the reason by the probandum is the positive concomitance.

analyzed: sādhana abhāvena sādhya abhāvasya vyāptiḥ vyatirekaḥ iti kecid ācakṣate
translated: The pervasion of the absence of the probandum by the absence of the reason is the negative concomitance. Some say this.

analyzed: tat dvaividhyam tuśabdena vyavacchinatti
translated: But that twofold division is excluded by the word 'tu' (but).

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Because it is like this.

original: yo 'gnimānna bhavati sa dhūmavānna bhavatīti vyatirekavyāptiḥ kiṃ dhūmenāgnisādhane upayujyate kiṃvāgnyabhāvena dhūmābhāvasādhane /
analyzed: yaḥ gnimān na bhavati sa dhūmavān na bhavati iti vyatireka vyāptiḥ kim dhūmena agni sādhane upayujyate kiṃvā agni abhāvena dhūma abhāva sādhane
translated: The negative pervasion is: What does not have fire does not have smoke. What use is it in proving fire by smoke, or in proving the absence of smoke by the absence of fire?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: yaḥ dhūmavān asau agnimān iti anvayavyāptyā eva tad siddheḥ  anyathā kevala anvayavato sādhaka tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that is established by the positive pervasion alone, that what has smoke has fire.🔽Otherwise, it would follow that what has only a positive pervasion is not a proof.

analyzed: kiñca atra abhāvayoḥ vyāpya vyāpaka bhāvaḥ
translated: Moreover, here there is the relation of the pervaded and pervader between the absences.

analyzed: bhāvena bhāva sādhanam iti subhāṣitam
translated: It is well said that by the positive [pervasion] one proves the positive.

analyzed: anya gatayā vyāptyā anyasya sādhaka tve tiprasaṅgāt
translated: If by the pervasion belonging to another one proves another, there would be an overextension.

original: yadabhāvayorvyāpyavyāpakabhāvastayoreva sādhyasādhanabhāva ityabhyupagame nātiprasaṅga iti cenna /
analyzed: yad abhāvayoḥ vyāpya vyāpaka bhāvaḥ tayoḥ eva sādhya sādhana bhāvaḥ iti abhyupagame na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is accepted that the relation of the pervaded and pervader between the absences is the relation of the probandum and probans between them, there is no overextension. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā api vyāpyam liṅgam iti asya avyāpti prasakteḥ
translated: Even so, there is the contingence of the overextension of the definition of the logical mark as the pervaded.

original: yadabhāvayorvyāpyavyāpakabhāvastayoreva sādhyasādhanabhāva ityabhyupagame nātiprasaṅga iti cenna /
analyzed: yad abhāvayoḥ vyāpya vyāpaka bhāvaḥ tayoḥ eva sādhya sādhana bhāvaḥ iti abhyupagame na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is accepted that the relation of the pervaded and pervader between the absences is the relation of the probandum and probans between them, there is no overextension. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā api vyāpyam liṅgam iti asya avyapti prasakteḥ
translated: Even so, there is the contingence of the overextension of the definition of the logical mark as the pervaded.

original: yadabhāvo yadabhāvasya vyāpakaḥ sa tasya vyāpya iti niyamādadoṣa iti cetna /
analyzed: yad abhāvaḥ yad abhāvasya vyāpakaḥ sa tasya vyāpyaḥ iti niyamāt adoṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is no fault because of the rule that whatever absence is the pervader of another absence is the pervaded of that, it is not so.

analyzed: tarhi na vyatirekavyāptiḥ prakṛta sādhya siddhay upayoginī
translated: If it be said that there is no fallacy, because it is a rule that the absence of one thing is the pervasion of the absence of another, then (we reply that) in that case the pervasion by difference is not useful for the proof of the conclusion in question.

analyzed: kinnāma prakṛta sādhana vyāpti sādhana upayoginī
translated: What then? The pervasion of the probans in question is useful for the proof of the probandum.

analyzed: tatra ca anvayi rūpa tā eva tasyāḥ
translated: And in that case it is of the nature of the pervasion by identity.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tu iṣyate eva
translated: But the second (kind of pervasion) is admitted.

original: kinnāma sāpyanvayarūpaiveti na sarvathā vyāptidvaividhyaṃ sambhavatīti / /
analyzed: kinnāma sā api anvaya rūpā evā iti na sarvathā vyāpti dvaividhyam sambhavati iti
translated: What then? That also is of the nature of the pervasion by identity. Thus the twofold division of pervasion is not possible in every case.

analyzed: etena anumānasya kevala anvayi kevala vyatireki anvaya vyatireki bhedena traividhyam api parāstam
translated: By this (argument) the threefold division of inference into (1) that which has only identity, (2) that which has only difference, and (3) that which has both identity and difference is also refuted.

analyzed: vyatireka vyāpteḥ anumāna anaṅga tvāt
translated: Because the pervasion by difference is not a part of inference.

analyzed: sadbhāva mātreṇa vyutpādanasya atiprasaṅgi tvāt
translated: Because the explanation by mere existence leads to absurdity.

analyzed: katham tarhi kevala vyatirekiṇaḥ gamaka tvam iti ced
translated: If it be asked how then there is the power of conveying the meaning in the case of that which has only difference,

analyzed: kaḥ yam kevala vyatirekī nāma
translated: what is that which is called that which has only difference?

analyzed: kevalaḥ vyatirekaḥ eva yasya asau iti ced
translated: If it be said that it is that of which difference alone is the only (pervasion),

analyzed: tarhi katham atyanta asatoḥ sādhyasādhana tā syāt
translated: then how can there be the relation of probandum and probans between two absolutely non-existent things?

analyzed: dṛśyate tāvat iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is seen, we reply: No.

analyzed: yatas tasya anyā eva gatiḥ
translated: Because it has a different course.

analyzed: prāṇa ādimat tvasya sātmaka tvena vyāptiḥ jīvat śarīre eva gṛhītā
translated: The pervasion of having life, etc. by having a self is grasped only in a living body.

analyzed: atas tatra eva vipratipattau na sā upadarśayitum śakyā abhūt
translated: Therefore, when there is a dispute there, it could not be shown.

original: vyāptimātramevānumānāṅgaṃ na punaḥ sapakṣe tadupadarśanamapītyato vyatirekayorvyāptyā tadupapādanaṃ kriyate /
analyzed: vyāpti mātram eva anumāna aṅgam na punar sapakṣe tad upadarśanam api iti atas vyatirekayoḥ vyāptyā tad upapādanam kriyate
translated: Only the pervasion is a part of inference, and the demonstration of it in a similar instance is not a part. Therefore, the establishment of that by the pervasion of the two negative concomitances is done.

analyzed: ayam atra prayoga kramaḥ
translated: This is the sequence of reasoning here.

original: jīvaccharīraṃ sātmakaṃ prāṇādimattvāt yatprāṇādimattatsātmakaṃ prāṇādimaccedaṃ tasmātsātmakamiti prayukte dhūmasyāgninevāsya na vyāptirdṛśyate
analyzed: jīvat śarīram sātmakam prāṇa ādimat tvāt yat prāṇa ādimat tat sātmakam prāṇa ādimat ca idam tasmāt sātmakam iti prayukte dhūmasya agninā iva asya na vyāptiḥ dṛśyate
translated: A living body has a self because it has life, etc. What has life, etc. has a self. This has life, etc. Therefore, it has a self. When this is employed, the pervasion of this by life, etc. is not seen, like smoke by fire.

analyzed: tat katham iti ākāṅkṣāyām prayoga antaram pravartate
translated: When there is a desire to know how this is, another application proceeds.
Having life, etc. is pervaded by having a self because of being the absence that pervades the absence of that.

analyzed: yaḥ yad abhāva vyāpaka abhāvaḥ
translated: That which is the absence that pervades the absence of something

analyzed: sa tad vayāptaḥ yathā dhūmaḥ gninā iti
translated: is pervaded by that, like smoke by fire.

original: tadetāvati vaktavye yadanyathā prayujyate tadvivekināṃ sphuṭapratītikatayā saṅgraharucitayā veti /
analyzed: tat etāvati vaktavye yat anyathā prayujyate tat vivekinām sphuṭa pratītika tayā saṅgraha ruci tayā vā iti
translated: When this much is to be said, that which is employed otherwise is either because of the clear cognition of the discerning or because of the desire to include.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said.

original: vyāpyaṃ cedanumānaṃ tadā dhūmaḥ śabdānityatve 'pyanumānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: vyāpyam ced anumānam tadā dhūmaḥ śabda anitya tve pi anumānam syāt
translated: If what is pervaded is inference, then smoke would be an inference even for the impermanence of sound.

analyzed: vyāptaḥ hi saḥ pi agninā iti
translated: For that [smoke] is also pervaded by fire.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: vyāpyam ityasya sambandhi śabda tvāt
translated: Because the word pervaded is a relative term.

original: tathāca yo yena vyāpyaḥ sa tasminnanumānamityuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca yaḥ yena vyāpyaḥ sa tasmin anumānam iti uktam syāt
translated: And thus it would be said that what is pervaded by something is an inference of that.

analyzed: na ca evam atiprasaṅgaḥ sti
translated: And there is no such overextension.

analyzed: dvividhāḥ hi dharmāḥ bhavanti
translated: For there are two kinds of properties.

analyzed: kecid paraspara parihāreṇa eva vatarmānāḥ
translated: Some exist only by mutually excluding each other.

analyzed: yathā kṛtaka tva nitya tve
translated: Like being produced and being eternal.

analyzed: svātantrya pāratantrye ca iti evamādayaḥ
translated: And like being independent and being dependent, and so on.

analyzed: kecid samāviṣyāḥ
translated: Some are mixed.

analyzed: te pi trividhāḥ
translated: They are also of three kinds.

analyzed: kecid saṅkīrṇāḥ
translated: Some are mixed.

analyzed: paraspara parihāreṇa eva vartamānayoḥ ekatra samāveśaḥ saṅkaraḥ
translated: The mixing of two things that exist only by mutually excluding each other in one place is a mixture.

analyzed: yathā bhūta tva mūrta tve
translated: Like being an element and being corporeal.

analyzed: puruṣa tva pācaka tve ca iti evamādayaḥ
translated: And like being a person and being a cook, and so on.

analyzed: kecid para apara bhāva avasthitāḥ  yathā sattva dravya tve
translated: Some exist in a higher and lower state.🔽Like being a substance and being a substance.

analyzed: dhūmavat tva agnimat tve ca iti evamādayaḥ
translated: And like having smoke and having fire, and so on.

analyzed: kecid tulya vṛttayaḥ
translated: Some have the same function.

analyzed: yathā kṛtaka tva anitya tve
translated: Like being produced and being impermanent.

analyzed: guru tva rasavat tve ca itya ati evamādayaḥ
translated: And like being heavy and having taste, and so on.

analyzed: tatra ādyānām paraspara sambandhaḥ eva na asti iti na anumāna anumeya bhāvaḥ
translated: Of these, the first two have no mutual connection at all, so there is no relation of probans and probandum.

analyzed: viruddha samākhyayā te bhidhīyante
translated: They are called contradictory by name.

analyzed: dvitīyānām api sati api sambandhe paraspara vyabhicāreṇa vyāpya vyāpaka bhāva abhāvāt na anumāna anumeya tā
translated: Even of the second two, although there is a connection, there is no relation of probans and probandum due to mutual deviation, because of the absence of the relation of pervaded and pervader.

analyzed: kintu parasparam anaikāntika tayā abhidhīyate
translated: But they are said to be mutually inconclusive.

analyzed: tṛtīyeṣu apareṣām vyāpya tayā apareṣām vyāpaka tayā asti anumāna anumeya tvam
translated: Of the third two, some are the probans for others, and some are the probandum for others, so there is the relation of probans and probandum.

analyzed: pare tu avyāpya tayā na apareṣu anumāna tām aśnute
translated: But others, because they are not pervaded, do not become the probans for others.

analyzed: kinnāma anaikāntikāḥ eva
translated: What are they? They are only inconclusive.

original: caturthāstu parasparaṃ vyāpyavyāpakabhāvādanyonyamanumānatāmarhantaḥ prasiddhayaprasiddhibhyāṃ viśiṣṭanta iti saṅkṣepaḥ / /
analyzed: caturthāḥ tu parasparam vyāpya vyāpaka bhāvāt anyonyam anumāna tām arhantaḥ prasiddhaya prasiddhibhyām viśiṣṭantaḥ iti saṅkṣepaḥ
translated: But the fourth two, because of the relation of pervaded and pervader, deserve to be the probans and probandum for each other, so they are distinguished by being well-known or not well-known. This is the summary.

original: nanvevamapi dhūmenāgnijñānaṃ sarveṣāṃ syādityata uktaṃ smṛteti /
analyzed: nanu evam api dhūmena agni jñānam sarveṣām syāt iti atas uktam smṛtā iti
translated: Even so, the knowledge of fire by smoke would be for all, so it is said that the pervasion is remembered.

analyzed: pramita tvasya upalakṣaṇam etat  smṛtā vyāptiḥ eva pramitam eva vyāpyam anumā
translated: This is a metaphor for being known.🔽An inference is only that which has a remembered pervasion and a known pervaded.

analyzed: na tu indriya vat sattā mātreṇa pramā karaṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: It is not a means of knowing by mere existence like a sense faculty. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu tathā api nārikeladvīpa vāsinaḥ dhūma darśanāt agni anumiti prasaktiḥ
translated: But even so, there is the contingence of the inhabitants of the Narikela island inferring fire from the perception of smoke.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: vyāpya svarūpa pramiti vat vayāpti pramiteḥ api apekṣita tvāt  tathā api gṛhīta vismṛ
translated: Because the knowledge of the pervasion is required just as the knowledge of the form of the pervaded.

analyzed: tā smṛta vyāpteḥ tad avasthaḥ prasaṅgaḥ iti atas uktam smṛta iti
translated: Even so, there is the contingence of the forgotten pervasion being remembered. To avoid this, it is said 'remembered'.

analyzed: smṛtā vyāptiḥ eva sā anumā upayoginī iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that only the remembered pervasion is useful for inference.

analyzed: tathā ca vyāpti smaraṇa sa vyapekṣam vyāpya jñānam anumānam iti uktam bhavati
translated: And thus it is said that inference is the knowledge of the pervaded, which requires the memory of the pervasion.

analyzed: liṅga parāmarśaḥ numānam parāmarśaḥ ca anusandhāna ātmakam tṛtīyam jñānam iti kaścid
translated: Some say that inference is the ascertainment of the mark, and ascertainment is the third cognition in the form of recollection.

analyzed: tathā hi  mahānasa ādau dhūmasya agninā vyāpti grahaṇa samaye yat jñānam tat prathamam
translated: To explain:🔽When the pervasion of smoke by fire is grasped in a kitchen, that is the first cognition.

analyzed: gṛhīta vyāptikasya parvata ādau yat dhūma jñānam tat dvitīyam
translated: The cognition of smoke in a mountain, etc., by one who has grasped the pervasion, is the second.

analyzed: tatas
translated: Then, from the recollection caused by the impression produced by the perception of the related object,

original: sya yo dhūmavānasāvagnimāniti vyāptismaraṇasyānantaramayaṃ cāgnivyāptadhūmavāniti pratisandhānātmakaṃ yaddhūmajñānaṃ tattṛtīyamanumānamiti
analyzed: yaḥ dhūmavān asau agnimān iti vyāpti smaraṇasya anantaram ayam ca agni vyāpta dhūmavān iti pratisandhāna ātmakam yat dhūma jñānam tat tṛtīyam anumānam iti
translated: The cognition of smoke as pervaded by fire, which is the synthesis that immediately follows the recollection of the pervasion, that cognition of smoke is the third inference.

analyzed: tat etat anyaḥ na manyate  vyāpti smaraṇam pakṣa dharma tā jñānam iti etāvat eva hi anumāna sāmarthyam
translated: Others do not think so.🔽For this much is the capacity of inference: the recollection of the pervasion and the knowledge of the property of the subject.

analyzed: tatra ananubhūtāyāḥ vyāpteḥ smartum aśakya tvāt prathamam jñānam iṣyate
translated: Since the unperceived pervasion cannot be remembered, the first cognition is accepted.

analyzed: dvitīya jñāna
translated: The second cognition

analyzed: pakṣa dharmatā viṣaya tvāt aṅgīkriyate
translated: is also accepted because it has the property of the subject as its object.

original: tato vyāptismṛtau satyāṃ kimaparamavaśiṣyate yadarthaṃ tṛtīyaṃ jñānameṣyavyamiti /
analyzed: tatas vyāpti smṛtau satyām kim aparam avaśiṣyate yat artham tṛtīyam jñānam eṣyavyam iti
translated: Then, when the pervasion is remembered, what else remains to be done for which a third cognition would be needed?

analyzed: sa sthūla dṛśvā iti ādyaḥ
translated: The first view is that the self is a gross observer.

analyzed: na khalu sahakāri tā anupapatteḥ
translated: Not because of the impossibility of cooperation,

analyzed: kintu saṅkalite
translated: but because of the combination.

original: naca tatsaṅkalitatvaṃ vinā tṛtīyajñānāditi kathaṃ tannaiṣyavyam /
analyzed: na ca tad saṅkalita tvam vinā tṛtīya jñānāt iti katham tat na eṣyavyam
translated: And that combination cannot be without the third cognition. So how can that not be accepted?

analyzed: ātmā saṅkalayati iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the self combines,

analyzed: satyam
translated: it is true.

analyzed: vṛttyā hi asau saṅkalayet na tu svarūpeṇa eva
translated: For it combines by superimposition, not by its own nature.

analyzed: na ca evam tat eva astu iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that that itself should be so.

analyzed: pūrveṇa vinā tad anupapatteḥ iti
translated: Because without the former, that [inference] is not possible.

analyzed: vayam tu brūmaḥ
translated: But we say:

analyzed: yatra liṅga darśanāt eva vyāpti smṛtiḥ astu tatra ukta prakāraḥ
translated: Where the recollection of the pervasion is from seeing the inferential mark alone, let it be as stated.

original: yadā tu gṛhītavyāptervināpi liṅgadarśanādvacanādinaiva vyāptismṛtirāvirasti yadā dvitīyameva liṅgadarśanaṃ pratisandhānātmakamudeṣyatīti nāvaśyambhāvinīyaṃ 🔽prakriyā /
analyzed: yadā tu gṛhīta vyāpteḥ vinā api liṅga darśanāt vacana ādinā eva vyāpti smṛtiḥ āvirasti yadā dvitīyam eva liṅga darśanam pratisandhāna ātmakam udeṣyati iti na avaśyambhāvinī iyam  prakriyā
translated: But when for one who has grasped the pervasion, the recollection of the pervasion arises from mere statement etc. without even seeing the inferential mark, and when the second seeing of the inferential mark in the form of recollection will arise, this procedure is not necessarily to be followed.

original: yathā khalu saṃskārasāhitye satīndriyasannikarṣādeva so 'yamiti pratyabhijñā jāyate tathethātrāpī
analyzed: yathā khalu saṃskāra sāhitye sati indriya sannikarṣāt eva saḥ yam iti pratyabhijñā jāyate tathā itha atrāpī
translated: Just as recognition arises from the mere contact of the sense organ with the object when accompanied by the impression, this is that, similarly it is so here also.

original: tyaṅgīkāre na kaścidvirodha iti / /🔽nanu vyāptireva kena pramāṇena grāhyā /
analyzed: ti aṅgīkāre na kaścid virodhaḥ iti  nanu vyāptiḥ eva kena pramāṇena grāhyā
translated: If this is accepted, there is no contradiction at all.🔽But by what means is the pervasion to be grasped?

analyzed: yathāyatham pratyakṣa anumāna āgamaiḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that it is by perception, inference and verbal testimony as appropriate.

analyzed: yathā ca etat tathā vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And how this is so will be explained.

analyzed: dvividham anumānam sva artham para artham ca iti  tatra yat para upadeśān upekṣya
translated: Inference is of two kinds: for one's own sake and for the sake of others.

analyzed: vyāpti smṛtimat vayāpya darśanam tat svārtham
translated: Among them, that which, without regard to the instruction of another, is the seeing of the pervaded object by one who possesses the recollection of the pervasion, is for one's own sake.

analyzed: para upadeśa apekṣam tu para artham
translated: But that which depends on the instruction of another is for the sake of others.

analyzed: sa sāmarthya liṅga pratīti janakam vākyam para upadeśaḥ
translated: An instruction by another is a sentence that produces the understanding of an inferential mark along with its capability.

analyzed: tat ca pratijñā hetu udāharaṇa upanaya nigamanaiḥ pañcabhiḥ avayavaiḥ upetam iti eke
translated: And some say that it is endowed with five parts: proposition, reason, example, application, and conclusion.

original: tamimaṃ niyamamarocayamāna āha ukteti //🔽uktā vyāptireva sānumā /
analyzed: tam imam niyamam arocayamānaḥ āha uktā iti  uktā vyāptiḥ eva sā anumā
translated: Not approving of this rule, he says stated and so on.🔽The statement of the pervasion itself is the inference.

analyzed: vyāpti uktiḥ eva para upadeśaḥ iti yāvat
translated: The statement of the pervasion is the instruction by another, that is the meaning.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ niyama nirākaraṇa paraḥ na punar pakṣa antara nivṛtti arthaḥ
translated: The word only is meant to negate the rule, not to exclude another position.

analyzed: pakṣa antarasya svayam eva vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because another position will be stated by himself.

original: nanu yo dhūmavānso 'gnimāniti vyāptyuktiḥ kathaṃ pratyāyanāṅgam /
analyzed: nanu yaḥ dhūmavān saḥ gnimān iti vyāpti uktiḥ katham pratyāyana aṅgam
translated: But how is the statement of the pervasion, That which has smoke has fire, a means of understanding?

analyzed: vādi prativādinoḥ anyonyasmin anāśvāsāt iti atas uktam smṛtā iti
translated: Because the proponent and the opponent do not have mutual confidence, therefore it is said remembered.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ caśabda arthaḥ jijñāsitā iti samuccinoti
translated: And the word only has the meaning of also and connects with to be known.

analyzed: gṛhīta vyāpteḥ tad uktiḥ smaraṇa hetuḥ agṛhīta vyāpteḥ tu jijñāsā janikā iti ucyate  na tu āgama tayā upayujyate iti āśayaḥ
translated: The statement of that is the cause of remembering for one who has grasped the pervasion. But for one who has not grasped the pervasion, it is said to be the cause of inquiry.🔽The idea is that it is not useful like scripture.

analyzed: nanu ca vyāpti uktiḥ eva para upadeśaḥ iti ayuktam
translated: But it is not proper to say that the statement of the pervasion itself is the instruction by another.

original: prathamata eva vyāptyukterasaṅgatatvādityāśaṅkāṃ pariharanuktā vyāptireva sā' /🔽iti pratijñātamupapādayati pratijñāteti //
analyzed: prathamatas eva vyāpti ukteḥ asaṅga tatvāt iti āśaṅkām pariharan uktā vyāptiḥ eva sā  iti pratijñātam upapādayati pratijñātā iti
translated: To remove the doubt that this is irrelevant because the pervasion is stated at the very beginning, he says: That itself is the stated pervasion.🔽He explains what was promised with For the sake of establishing the stated meaning.

analyzed: pratijñāta artha siddhaya artham vyāptiḥ eva yadā uditā
translated: When the pervasion is stated for the sake of establishing the stated meaning,

analyzed: avaśiṣyam kim atra asti
translated: what remains to be said here?

analyzed: pratijñāta artha siddhayartham iti asaṅgateḥ parihāraḥ
translated: For the sake of establishing the stated meaning is the answer to the irrelevance.

analyzed: tadā iti adhyaha ayarm
translated: That is the pronoun.

analyzed: kim ākṣepe
translated: What is used for asking.

analyzed: atra vaktavye
translated: Here means in what is to be said.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

original: yo hi parvatamagnimantaṃ pratipadyamānaḥ pareṇa niragnikaṃ manyamānena kiṃ parvatasyāgnimatve mānamityanuyujyate /
analyzed: yaḥ hi parvatam agnimantam pratipadyamānaḥ pareṇa niragnikam manyamānena kim parvatasya agnima tve mānam iti anuyujyate
translated: When one who is cognizing the mountain as having fire is questioned by another who thinks it is without fire, What is the valid cognition of the mountain having fire?

original: sa yadi yo dhūmavānasāvagnimāniti vyāptimātraṃ paraṃ prati
analyzed: sa yadi yaḥ dhūmavān asau agnimān iti vyāpti mātram param prati
translated: If he were to state to the other only the pervasion That which has smoke has fire,

analyzed: sva pratipanna artha siddhayartham brūyāt tadā kā nāma asaṅgatiḥ
translated: for the sake of establishing his own understood meaning, then what is irrelevant about that?

analyzed: para pṛṣṭa pramāṇasya upanyasyamāna tvāt  kiṃvā kiñcā
translated: Because the stated valid cognition is being presented.🔽Or, what else?

original: paraṃ vaktavyamavaśiṣyaṃ yadarthaṃ śabdāntaramavaśiṣyaṃ🔽raṃ vaktavyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: param vaktavyam avaśiṣyam yad artham śabda antaram avaśiṣyam 🔽raṃ vaktavyam syāt
translated: What remains to be said to the other for the sake of which another word would remain to be said?

analyzed: atas vyāpti vacanam eva para upadeśaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the statement of the pervasion itself is the instruction to others.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: vyāptipakṣadharmatopetatayā liṅgānusandhānaṃ khalvanumānam /🔽pakṣadharmatāmanaṅgaṃ manyamānairapi liṅgasya sattā tāvadavaśyama
analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā upeta tayā liṅga anusandhānam khalu anumānam  pakṣa dharma tām anaṅgam manyamānaiḥ api liṅgasya sattā tāvat avaśyam
translated: Indeed, inference is the connection of the inferential mark with the property of the subject, along with the pervasion.

analyzed: ṅgīkaraṇīyā
translated: Even those who consider the property of the subject to be a non-essential must necessarily accept the existence of the inferential mark.

analyzed: anyathā vyāpti aṅgīkāra vyāghātāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be a contradiction in accepting the pervasion.

analyzed: sā ca na avivakṣita sthānā
translated: And that is not without a specified location.

analyzed: tathā sati yasya kasyacid dhūmavat tva ādinā sarva parvata
translated: If that were so, then because of having smoke, etc., anywhere, all mountains

analyzed: syā api agnimat tva ādi prasaṅgāt
translated: would have to be accepted as having fire, etc.

analyzed: atas vyāpti anusāreṇa niyata deśa dharmatā api aṅgīkaraṇīyā eva
translated: Therefore, in accordance with the pervasion, the property of a limited location must also be accepted.

original: vyadhikaraṇo 'pi hi kṛttikāgata evodayo rohiṇyudayāsattiṃ gamayati /
analyzed: vyadhikaraṇaḥ pi hi kṛttikā gataḥ eva udayaḥ rohiṇī udaya āsattim gamayati
translated: For even a different locus, the rising of the Kṛttikā constellation itself establishes the proximity of the rising of the Rohiṇī constellation,

analyzed: na tu yatra tatratyaḥ
translated: but not just anywhere.

original: tatastāvadanena vaktavyaṃ yāvatā vyāptivivakṣitasthaladharmatopetatayā liṅgasyānusandhānaṃ syāt tadapyākāṅkṣākrameṇābhidhātavyamiti sthite /
analyzed: tatas tāvat anena vaktavyam yāvatā vyāpti vivakṣita sthala dharma tā upeta tayā liṅgasya anusandhānam syāt tat api ākāṅkṣā krameṇa abhidhātavyam iti sthite
translated: Therefore, this much should be stated by him: as much as is necessary for the connection of the inferential mark with the property of the specified location of the pervasion, that should also be stated in the order of expectancy. This being the case,

original: nirāśrayasya pramāṇasyābhidhātumaśakyatvāt pramāṇajijñāsotthāpanāya viṣayopakṣeparūpaṃ parvato 'gnimāniti pratijñāvākyaṃ vaktavyam /🔽tataḥ kasmādidaṃ pramāṇātpratipattavyamityākāṅkṣāyāṃ parāṅgatāpannaliṅgasvarūpamātrapratipādakaṃ dhūmavattvāditi hetuvacanam /
analyzed: nirāśrayasya pramāṇasya abhidhātum aśakya tvāt pramāṇa jijñāsā utthāpanāya viṣaya upakṣepa rūpam parvataḥ gnimān iti pratijñā vākyam vaktavyam  tatas kasmāt idam pramāṇāt pratipattavyam iti ākāṅkṣāyām para aṅga tā āpanna liṅga svarūpa mātra pratipādakam dhūmavat tvāt iti hetu vacanam
translated: Because a means of knowledge without a basis cannot be stated, in order to arouse the desire to know the means of knowledge, the propositional statement the mountain is fiery in the form of a presentation of the object should be stated.🔽Then, when there is a desire to know from what this should be understood through the means of knowledge, the statement of the reason because it has smoke is stated, which presents only the form of the reason that has become a subordinate factor.

analyzed: sāmarthya jijñāsāyām vyāpti pratipādanāyāḥ yaḥ dhūmavān asau agnimān iti udāharaṇa vākyam
translated: Then, when there is a desire to know its capability, the example statement whatever has smoke has fire is stated in order to present the pervasion.

analyzed: pakṣa ādi vivakṣita sthala dharmatā pratipādana artham dhūmavān ca ayam iti upanayaḥ
translated: The application and this has smoke is stated in order to present the property of the locus that is intended to be the subject and so on.

analyzed: tatas sarvasya buddhayā ārohāya ekavākya tām āpādayitum tasmāt agnimān eva iti nigamanam
translated: Then, in order to bring everything to a single sentence for the sake of understanding, the conclusion therefore it has fire is stated.

analyzed: atas eva pratijñā hetubhyām upanaya nigamanayoḥ gatārtha tām manyamānāḥ nirastāḥ bhavanti
translated: For this very reason, those who consider the application and conclusion to be stated by the proposition and reason are refuted.

original: tadevametāvati vaktavye kathaṃ vyāptimātramuktvā kṛtī syāditi / /
analyzed: tat evam etāvati vaktavye katham vyāpti mātram uktvā kṛtī syāt iti
translated: So, when this much needs to be stated, how could one be satisfied by merely stating the pervasion?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: yat tāvat pratijñā vaśyambhāve kāraṇam uktam tat asat
translated: That which has been stated as the reason for the necessity of the conclusion is not correct.

analyzed: vivādena eva viṣaya upakṣepasya siddha tayā ākāṅkṣā udayasya samarthita tvāt
translated: Because the statement of the topic by means of the dispute has been established, and the arising of the requirement has been supported.

original: tathāpyākāṅkṣitatvālliṅgasvarūpasya tatpakṣadharmatāyāśca pratipādanāya hetūpanayau vaktavyāviti cenna /
analyzed: tathā api ākāṅkṣita tvāt liṅga sva rūpasya tad pakṣa dharma tāyāḥ ca pratipādanāya hetu upanayau vaktavyau iti ced na
translated: Even so, if it is argued that the form of the probans and its presence in the subject being required, the reason and the application should be stated for their understanding, it is not so.

analyzed: vikalpa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because of the impossibility of option.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

original: kiṃ yena dhūmavattvaṃ parvatavṛttitayāvagataṃ taṃ prati hetūpanayau vaktavyau /
analyzed: kim yena dhūmavat tvam parvata vṛtti tayā avagatam tam prati hetu upanayau vaktavyau
translated: That is, for whom the presence of smoke is known as occurring in the mountain, for him the reason and the application should be stated.

analyzed: uta viparītam prati
translated: Or for one who is the opposite?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati liṅgam iti
translated: He criticizes the first by saying the probans etc.

analyzed: liṅgam tatra vijānataḥ
translated: The probans there for one who knows...

analyzed: tatra vivakṣite sthale
translated: There, in the intended place.

analyzed: avaśiṣyam kim asti iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: What remains? The connection is with the previous.

analyzed: liṅga svarūpa tadīya pakṣa dharjña tā vijñāpanāya hi hetu upayana upayogaḥ
translated: For the purpose of making known the form of the probans and its presence in the subject, the reason and the application are useful.

original: taccedvijñānaṃ parasya svatassiddhaṃ tadā kiṃ hetūpanayābhyāmiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tat ced vijñānam parasya svatas siddham tadā kim hetu upanayābhyām iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If that knowledge is established by itself for the other, then what is the use of the reason and the application? This is the idea.

analyzed: dvitīyam anūdya dūṣayati yadi iti
translated: He raises the second and criticizes it by saying if etc.

original: yadi liṅgamasiddhaṃ syāt kuta evāsya mānatā // / / //
analyzed: yadi liṅgam asiddham syāt kutas eva asya māna tā
translated: If the probans were not established, from where could it have validity?🔽...

analyzed: tatra iti anuvartate
translated: The word there is to be supplied.

analyzed: a siddham pareṇa a prasiddham
translated: Unestablished means not well known to the opponent.

analyzed: tadā asya liṅgasya svarūpa asiddhasya māna tā eva kutas
translated: How can that inferential mark, which is of the nature of non-establishment, be a means of valid knowledge?

analyzed: na asti iti yāvat
translated: The meaning is: it does not exist.

analyzed: dūre vaktavyatā iti eva śabda arthaḥ
translated: The word 'even' means that it is far from being stated.

original: nanvevaṃ sati vyāptirapi na vaktavyā /🔽sāpi yadi viditavyāptikaṃ pratyucyate tadābhidhānavaiyarthyam /
analyzed: nanu evam sati vyāptiḥ api na vaktavyā  sā api yadi vidita vyāptikam pratyucyate tadā abhidhāna vaiyarthyam
translated: If that is so, then the pervasion should also not be stated.🔽If that is also stated to one who knows the pervasion, then the statement is pointless.

original: viparatītasya tu vyāpyatvāsiddhayā tatpramāṇameva na bhavati iti
analyzed: viparatītasya tu vyāpya tva asiddhayā tat pramāṇam eva na bhavati iti
translated: But for one who is mistaken, it is not a means of valid knowledge due to the non-establishment of the pervaded. So

analyzed: kutas vyāpti abhidhānam iti tatra api vaktum śakya tvāt
translated: how can the statement of the pervasion be made? Because it can be said in that case also.

analyzed: tathāca vādi prativādinoḥ maunam eva āpatitam iti
translated: And thus, there would be only silence on the part of the proponent and the opponent.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: ubhayathā api adoṣāt
translated: Because there is no fault in either case.

analyzed: vyāptiḥ hi na svarūpeṇa upayoginī
translated: For pervasion is not useful by its own nature.

analyzed: na api jñāta tā mātreṇa
translated: Nor is it by mere knowledge.

analyzed: api tarhi smaryamāṇā
translated: But rather by being remembered.

analyzed: tathā ca gṛhīta vyāptikam prati tad smāraka tvena tayā
translated: And thus, for one who has grasped the pervasion, it is as a reminder. By that

analyzed: agṛhīta vyāptikam prati tu tadā eva
translated: for one who has not grasped the pervasion, it is at that very time

analyzed: tad jijñāsā janaka tayā vyāpti vacanam upayujyate iti uktam eva
translated: it is useful as a statement of the pervasion that generates the desire to know it. This has already been stated.

analyzed: evam tarhi hetu upanayau api na anupayuktau
translated: If that is so, then the statement of the reason and the conclusion are also not useless.

analyzed: nahi pakṣa dharma upetam liṅgam sva rūpeṇa upayuktam
translated: For the probans, which is possessed of the property of the subject, is not useful by its own form.

analyzed: na api vidita tva mātreṇa
translated: Nor merely by being known.

analyzed: kintu jñāta caram
translated: But rather by being known as a fact.

analyzed: smaryamāṇa tayā jñāyamānam api na vṛkṣa ādi sādhāraṇyena
translated: Even if known as being remembered, it is not by a generality common to trees and so on.

analyzed: kintarhi liṅga tayā
translated: But rather as a probans.

original: tathāca viditaliṅgasvarūpapakṣadharmatvaṃ prati tatsmārakatvena liṅgatayānusandhāyakatvenetaraṃ prati tajjijñāsājanakatvena hetūpanayayoḥ sārthakyamevetyāśaṅkayāha
analyzed: tathā ca vidita liṅga svarūpa pakṣa dharma tvam prati tad smāraka tvena liṅgatayā anusandhāyaka tvena itaram prati tad jijñāsā janaka tvena hetu upanayayoḥ sārthakyam eva iti āśaṅkayā āha
translated: And thus, for the one [party] in regard to the known form of the probans and the property of the subject, it is meaningful for the reason and application to be the cause of generating the desire to know by means of being a reminder of that and by means of being a connector as a probans. Fearing this, he says

analyzed: yadi iti
translated: If and so on.

analyzed: yadi smāraka mātram syāt smartuḥ na atra prayojanam
translated: If it were merely a reminder, the rememberer would have no purpose here.

analyzed: smāraka tvam uktasya sarvasya upalakṣaṇam  mātra grahaṇena pratyāyaka tvam vyāvartayati  hetu ādikam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The word merely excludes the meaning of being an indicator.🔽The remainder is reason and so on.

analyzed: pakṣa dharma tormo
translated: The property of the subject.

analyzed: petasya liṅgasya iti ca
translated: And of the probans.

analyzed: syāt iti atas param tat na yatas iti adhyāhāryam
translated: Would be should be supplied after it.

analyzed: smartuḥ iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: The rememberer is a synecdoche.

analyzed: atra vyāpti vacane  nimitta saptamīyam
translated: Here, in the statement of the pervasion.🔽It is a locative of reason.

analyzed: hetu ādau iti ca
translated: And in the reason and so on.

original: tataśca vyāptivacanavaddhetvādikamapi pakṣadharmatormo🔽petasya liṅgasya smaraṇānusandhānajijñāsājanakaṃ syāditi yadyucyate tanna /
analyzed: tatas ca vyāpti vacana vat hetu ādikam api pakṣa dharma toḥ mo  syāt iti yadi ucyate tat na
translated: And then, like the statement of the pervasion, the reason etc. would also cause the recollection, connection, and desire to know of the inferential mark that is related to the property of the subject. If this is said, it is not so.

original: yato vyāptivacanenaiva tatsmaraṇādimatastasya hetvādinā prayojanaṃ nāstīti yojanā /
analyzed: yatas vyāpti vacanena eva tad smaraṇa ādimataḥ tasya hetu ādinā prayojanam nā asti iti yojanā
translated: Because by the statement of the pervasion itself, there is no purpose for that [inferential mark] which has recollection etc., by the reason etc. This is the construction.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: yadi hi hetvādikaṃ vākyatayā pratyāyakaṃ syāttadā samārthyacintopayujyate /
analyzed: yadi hi hetu ādikam vākya tayā pratyāyakam syāt tadā samārthya cintā upayujyate
translated: For if the reason etc. were to be the conveyor as a sentence, then the consideration of its effectiveness would be useful.

original: yadā tu tatsmārakatvādinaivopayuktaṃ tadā saṃskārodbodhopayuktaṃ sādṛśyasambandhādikaṃ kimapyanvepyeṣyavyam /
analyzed: yadā tu tad smāraka tva ādinā evā upayuktam tadā saṃskāra udbodha upayuktam sādṛśya sambandha ādikam kim api anvepya iṣyavyam
translated: But when it is useful only by way of reminding etc., then some similarity, relation etc. that is useful for awakening the impression must be sought after.

analyzed: tad vayāpti vacane pi samānam
translated: The same applies to the statement of the pervasion.

original: yo dhūmavānasāvagnimānityabhihite khalvanumānamudrāvit atra dhūmavattvaṃ vyāpyamityavabudhyata eva /
analyzed: yaḥ dhūmavān asau agnimān iti abhihite khalu anumāna mudrā vid atra dhūmavat tvam vyāpyam iti avabudhyate eva
translated: When it is said Whatever is smoky is fiery, the one who knows the seal of inference understands here that being smoky is the pervaded.

analyzed: tatas tadīya pakṣa dharmatā ādi smṛti ādimān api katham na bhavet iti
translated: Then how could he not have the recollection etc. of its property of the subject etc.?

analyzed: yat vā para upadeśasya pañca avayava tā niyatim vadan praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Or, one who says that the five-memberedness is not necessary for the other's instruction should be asked.

analyzed: kim etat pañca avayavam vākyam āgama tayā vyāpti pakṣa dharma toḥ mo
translated: Is this five-membered statement to be taken as an inference, or as a statement of the reason and the subject?

analyzed: petasya liṅgasya pratyāyakam
translated: Is this five-membered statement a means of knowledge in the sense of being a statement that conveys the inferential mark along with the pervasion and the property of the subject?

analyzed: uta smāraka ādi mātram
translated: Or is it merely a reminder and so on?

analyzed: ādye tu syāt eva idam
translated: In the first case, this would indeed be so.
The size of the statement is explained by others.

analyzed: vākyam pramāṇam kathañcid
translated: The statement is a means of knowledge in some way.

analyzed: na ca asau yujyate  vādi prata vādinoḥ itaretarasmin anāśvāsāt
translated: And that is not proper.🔽Because the proponent and the opponent do not have confidence in each other.

analyzed: āśvāse vā pratijñā mātreṇa artha siddhau hetu ādi abhidhāna vaiyarthyāt
translated: Or if there is confidence, then the matter is established merely by the thesis, and the statement of the reason and so on is pointless.

analyzed: dvitīye tu āha yadi iti
translated: In the second case, he says if and so on.

original: parepadeśaṃ vākyaṃ yadi smaraṇādimātrakāraṇamaṅgīkriyate tadātra vyāptivacane satyeva smarturvyāptivacanādeva smaraṇādyutpatteriti yāvat /
analyzed: vākyam yadi smaraṇa ādi mātra kāraṇam aṅgīkriyate tadā atra vyāpti vacane sati eva smartuḥ vyāpti vacanāt eva smaraṇa ādi utpatteḥ iti yāvat
translated: If it is accepted that the statement of others is merely the cause of memory and so on, then in this case, when the statement of the pervasion is present, the memory arises from the statement of the pervasion itself, that is, memory arises from the statement of the pervasion alone.

original: atra vyāptivacanātirikte śabde prayojanaṃ nāstīti nāsāvavaśyaṃ vaktavyaḥ /
analyzed: atra vyāpti vacana atirikte śabde prayojanam na asti iti na asau avaśyam vaktavyaḥ
translated: Here, there is no purpose in the word other than the statement of the pervasion, so that should not necessarily be stated.

analyzed: dṛśyate khalu loke pada eka deśāt itas pi padārtha smaraṇa ādikam
translated: In the world, the meaning of a word and so on is indeed seen to be remembered even from a part of a word.

analyzed: śāstre pi ca vākya eka deśa prayogaḥ
translated: And in the scriptures too, a part of a sentence is used.

original: tatra vakturāptatvāvadhāraṇādanusaraṇaṃ prativādini tu tannāstīti cenmā bhūt /
analyzed: tatra vaktuḥ āpta tva avadhāraṇāt anusaraṇam prativādini tu tat na asti iti ced mā bhūt
translated: If it be said that in the case of the speaker there is a determination of his being a trustworthy person and hence the opponent follows him, but in the case of the opponent there is no such determination and hence he is not followed, let it be so.

analyzed: na hi etat āgama tayā pratyāyakam iti aktam
translated: For it has been said that this is not to be known as a means of valid knowledge by way of scripture.

analyzed: anyathā sāṃvyāvahārikaḥ kevala vyatireki prayogaḥ na anusaraṇīyaḥ
translated: Otherwise, even the purely negative argument in worldly usage should not be followed.

analyzed: vāstava prayoga parimāṇa anyathātvasya upapādita tvāt
translated: Because it has been shown that the actual extent of the argument is otherwise.

analyzed: prativādini api anusaraṇe nigrahasthāna udbhāvanam na syāt iti ced
translated: If it be said that even when the opponent is followed, there should be no statement of the ground of defeat,

analyzed: laukika śāstrīya saṃvyavahāra atikrame tad avakāśāt
translated: because there is scope for that when there is transgression of worldly and scriptural usage.

analyzed: anyathā prakaraṇa ādi āpannasya a saṅkīrtanam api nigraha hetuḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, even the non-mention of what is included in the context would be a ground of defeat.

original: kiṃ prakaraṇādyāpannatayāyaṃ na vadatyutāpratipannatvādineti sandehasya prakṛte 'pi tulyatvāditi / /
analyzed: kim prakaraṇa ādi āpanna tayā ayam na vadati uta apratipanna tva ādinā iti sandehasya prakṛte pi tulya tvāt iti
translated: Because the doubt as to whether this is not stated because it is included in the context or because of non-understanding, etc., is equally present in the present case also.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha  prameya avadhāraṇa artham hi pramāṇa upanyāsaḥ
translated: Another says:🔽For the purpose of determining the object of knowledge, the means of valid knowledge is stated.
And the determination of the object of knowledge is the non-disputed cognition of that.

analyzed: na ca sā pramāṇa svarūpa mātra upadarśanena bhavati
translated: And that does not occur merely by showing the form of the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: kinnāma tad ābhāsa uddhāreṇa api
translated: But rather by the removal of its semblance.

analyzed: anyathā tad prāmāṇyasya eva anavasthānāt
translated: Otherwise, the validity of that [inference] would not be established.

original: tathāca pratijñāvākyena viṣayamupakṣipya tatra hetunā pramāṇasvarūpamupadarśya tasyodāharaṇavākyena viruddhānadhyavasitānaikāntikatvanirāsaḥ
analyzed: tathā ca pratijñā vākyena viṣayam upakṣipya tatra hetunā pramāṇa svarūpam upadarśya tasya udāharaṇa vākyena viruddha anadhyavasita anaikāntika tva nirāsaḥ
translated: And thus, having introduced the topic by the propositional statement, having shown the nature of the means of valid knowledge there by the reason, the exclusion of contradictory, inconclusive, and uncertain [reasons]

analyzed: kriyate
translated: is done by the example statement.

analyzed: upanayena asiddhiḥ apāsyate
translated: By the application, the unestablished [reason] is excluded.

analyzed: nigamanena api hetu anuvādena tasmāt eva na anyasmāt iti siddhasādhana tā apakṣipyate
translated: By the conclusion also, by the repetition of the reason, it is implied that the proof is established by that alone, not by anything else.

analyzed: sādhya anuvādena tu
translated: But by the repetition of the probandum,

original: agnimāneva na tu niragnika iti bādhapratipakṣapratikṣepaḥ kriyate /
analyzed: agnimān eva na tu niragnikaḥ iti bādha pratipakṣa pratikṣepaḥ kriyate
translated: the exclusion of the contradicted [reason] is done by saying it is only with fire, not without fire.

analyzed: tat evam vidhūta vivāda sādhya pratipattaye pañcāvayava vākyam āvaśyakam iti
translated: Thus, for the attainment of the probandum which has been cleared of objections, the five-membered sentence is necessary.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: evam vadatā hi
translated: For even by one who speaks thus,

analyzed: yāvatā vivāda avasānam tāvān para upadeśaḥ iti uktam syāt
translated: it would be said that the other's instruction extends only as far as the end of the dispute.

analyzed: tathā ca pañca avayavam vākyam para upadeśaḥ iti ayuktam
translated: And thus, it is not correct that the five-membered sentence is the other's instruction.

analyzed: pañca avayava uktau api vivāda avasiteḥ abhāvāt
translated: Because even when the five members are stated, the dispute does not end.

analyzed: kintu ākathā parisamāpteḥ para upadeśaḥ iti vaktavyam iti āśayavān āha na iti
translated: But it should be said that the other's instruction is until the end of the discourse. With this intention, he says no.

analyzed: na pañca avayoktau ca vivāda avasitiḥ bhavet
translated: And in the absence of the five members, there would be no conclusion to the dispute.
The conclusion of a dispute is the cognition of the probandum accompanied by the end of the dispute.

analyzed: nanu etat ayuktam
translated: But this is not correct.

analyzed: udāharaṇa ādi avayava trayeṇa ābhāsa uddhārasya kṛta tvāt
translated: Because the removal of fallacies has been done by the three members such as the example.

original: nirastasamastābhāsapramāṇopanyāse 'pi vivādānavasāne sarvadā🔽thāpi tatprasaṅgādityata āha dṛṣṭānteti // /
analyzed: nirasta samasta ābhāsa pramāṇa upanyāse vivāda anavasāne sarvadā  thā api tad prasaṅgāt iti atas āha dṛṣṭānta iti
translated: Even when all fallacies have been refuted and valid means of knowledge have been stated, if the dispute is not concluded at all times,🔽then there would be the undesirable consequence of that. Therefore he says in the example and so on.

original: dṛṣṭāntādiṣu caivaṃ syāt sādhanaṃ punareva hi // / / //🔽dṛṣṭāntapadenodāharaṇārthamupalakṣayati /
analyzed: dṛṣṭānta ādiṣu ca evam syāt sādhanam punar eva hi  dṛṣṭānta padena udāharaṇa artham upalakṣayati
translated: And in the example and so on, the proof would indeed be again.🔽By the word example, he indicates the meaning of the illustration.

analyzed: ādi padena upanaya nigamana artha grahaṇam
translated: By the word and so on, he includes the meaning of the application and conclusion.

analyzed: viṣaya saptamīyam
translated: The locative case is with respect to the object.

analyzed: evam yathā pratijñā atīta arthe
translated: In the same way, as in the case of the proposition that has passed beyond.

analyzed: sādhanam vaktavyam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that the proof should be stated.

analyzed: syāt eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that it would indeed be.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ yasmāt iti arthe
translated: The word but has the meaning of because.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: satyam uddhṛta ābhāsāt pramāṇāt prameya avadhāraṇam bhavati iti
translated: It is true that the ascertainment of the object of knowledge occurs from the means of knowledge from which fallacies have been removed.

analyzed: kintu pañcabhiḥ api avayavaiḥ tādṛśa pramāṇa pratītiḥ eva na bhavati iti brūmaḥ
translated: But we say that such a cognition of the means of knowledge does not occur even with all five members.

analyzed: ābhāsa uddhāra para udāharaṇa ādi artha vipratipattau tad sādhanasya api vaktavya tvāt
translated: Because when there is a dispute regarding the meaning of the example and so on, the proof of that also has to be stated.

analyzed: na ca tatra vipratipattiḥ na kartavyā
translated: And there should not be no dispute there.

analyzed: nā api vāc mātreṇa tad nivṛttiḥ
translated: Nor is that removed merely by words.

analyzed: pratijñā artha samāna yogakṣema tvāt
translated: Because it has the same fate as the proposition.

analyzed: na ca udāharaṇa ādiṣu eva sarva śaṅkā uddhāra kāraṇam asti
translated: And there is no cause for removing all doubts in the example and so on.

analyzed: anupalambhāt
translated: Because it is not perceived.

analyzed: pañca avayava prayogaḥ eva kathā pudraṇa āpātāt
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of the entire discussion being a mere five-membered argument.

analyzed: atas prameya niṇarya avadhi tve numāna prayogasya na pañca avayava tva niyamaḥ yujyate
translated: Therefore, when inference is limited to the ascertainment of the object to be proved, the restriction to five members is not appropriate.

analyzed: api tu katha parisamāpti avadhika tvam eva aṅgīkāryam iti
translated: But it should be accepted that it is limited only to the completion of the discussion.

analyzed: satyam niḥśeṣataḥ vivāda nivṛttiḥ na pañca avayava prayoge bhavati iti
translated: It is true that the complete cessation of dispute does not occur even in the five-membered argument.

original: tathāpyavāntarākāṅkṣānivartakatvena pañcāvayavamevāvāntaravākyaṃ parisamāpyata ityata āha liṅgeti //
analyzed: tathā api avāntara ākāṅkṣā nivartaka tvena pañca avayavam eva avāntara vākyam parisamāpyate iti atas āha liṅga iti
translated: Nevertheless, since it satisfies the intermediate expectancy, the intermediate sentence consisting of five members is completed. Therefore he says liṅga (indicative).

analyzed: liṅga uktau api ca evam syāt anumā avasitiḥ dhruvā
translated: Even when the indicative is stated, the conclusion of inference would certainly be firm.

analyzed: caḥ hetu arthe
translated: Ca (and) is for the purpose of stating a reason.

analyzed: anumā iti tad sambandhi vākyam upalakṣyate
translated: Anumeya (what is to be inferred) is used to refer to the sentence related to it.

original: evaṃ sati kimatra pramāṇamityavāntarākāṅkṣānivṛttihetau dhūmatvamiti liṅgoktau kṛtāyāmapi avāntaravākyaparyavasānamavaśyaṃ bhavatīti tanmātrameva
analyzed: evam sati kim atra pramāṇam iti avāntara ākāṅkṣā nivṛtti hetau dhūma tvam iti liṅga uktau kṛtāyām api avāntara vākya paryavasānam avaśyam bhavati iti tad mātram eva
translated: If this is so, then even when the probans, 'being smoky', has been stated, which is the cause for removing the intermediate expectancy as to what the evidence is in this case, there must necessarily be an end to the intermediate sentence. Therefore, that alone

analyzed: vākyam aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: should be accepted as the sentence.

analyzed: na tu pañca avayava tva niyatiḥ iti
translated: But there is no restriction that it must have five parts.

original: yaduktaṃ smaraṇādimātrahetutvena vākyasyopayogastacca vyāptivacanamātreṇa bhavatīti vyāptireva vaktavyeti tadayuktam /
analyzed: yat uktam smaraṇa ādi mātra hetu tvena vākyasya upayogaḥ tat ca vyāpti vacana mātreṇa bhavati iti vyāptiḥ eva vaktavyā iti tat ayuktam
translated: What was said, that the use of the sentence is as the cause for mere recollection etc., and that is accomplished merely by stating the pervasion, so only the pervasion should be stated, that is not correct.

analyzed: tathā sati liṅga mātra vacanasya api prayoktavya tva āpātāt
translated: Because in that case, it would follow that the statement of the probans alone should also be employed.

analyzed: sambhavati hi tasya api vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā smaraṇa ādi hetu tvam ite
translated: For that too can be the cause for the recollection of the pervasion and the property of the subject.

analyzed: ti ukta abhiprāyam a jānānasya codyam vā pariharati liṅga iti
translated: And the objection is raised by one who does not understand the intention stated thus, or it is answered by the word 'probans'.

analyzed: yathā vyāpti uktau evam liṅga uktau api anumā avasitiḥ dhruvā syāt
translated: Just as there is certainty of inference when the pervasion is stated, so too it would certainly be when the probans is stated.

analyzed: iṣyā āpādanam etat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this is an undesirable consequence.
The word 'ca' (and) is for including the other view stated earlier, that the proposition is only the thesis and the reason.

analyzed: na ca evam sati vyāptiḥ eva iti avadhāraṇa anupapattiḥ
translated: And if this is so, there is no inconsistency in the restriction 'only the pervasion'.

analyzed: yena yena prakāreṇa vyāpti ādi smaraṇa ādikam bhavati
translated: By whatever means, such as pervasion, recollection, etc.

analyzed: yaḥ ca sāṃvyāvahārikaḥ tam tam upādāya niyama nirākaraṇasya tatra iṣṭa tvāt iti abhisandhiḥ
translated: And because the denial of restriction is accepted there in relation to that which is conventional, such is the intention.

analyzed: etena pratijñā hetubhyām upanaya nigamanayoḥ gatārtha tā api samarthitā veditavyā iti
translated: By this, it should be understood that the statement of conclusion and the final summary are also established as having the same meaning as the thesis and reason.

analyzed: iti anumāna lakṣaṇa nirūpaṇam
translated: Thus, the definition of inference is completed.

analyzed: nirdoṣa tām antarbhāvya yuktiḥ anumā iti aktam
translated: Having included the absence of faults, it is said that reasoning is inference.

original: doṣaparijñāna eva tadviyuktā yuktiḥ sujñānetyato yuktidoṣo nirūpaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: doṣa parijñāne eva tad viyuktā yuktiḥ su jñānā iti atas yukti doṣaḥ nirūpaṇīyaḥ
translated: Since the well-known reasoning devoid of those faults is known only when the faults are well known, the faults of reasoning should be determined.

analyzed: dhūma ādeḥ agni ādi pramiti janaka tve pi
translated: Even though smoke etc. generate the cognition of fire etc.,

analyzed: yad nimittam kaścid arthaḥ rtha antara jñānam na janayati
translated: the reason for which a certain object does not generate the cognition of another object,

analyzed: saṃśaya viparyayau vā karoti
translated: or causes doubt or error,

analyzed: sa yukti doṣaḥ
translated: that is a fault of reasoning.

analyzed: sa dvividhaḥ
translated: It is of two kinds:

original: sākṣādvācanikaśca /🔽tatrādyaṃ vibhāgenoddiśati virodha iti //🔽virodho 'saṅgatiścaiva sākṣād yuktestu dūṣaṇam // / / // /
analyzed: sākṣādvācanikaḥ ca  tatra ādyam vibhāgena uddiśati virodhaḥ iti  virodhaḥ saṅgatiḥ ca eva sākṣāt yukteḥ tu dūṣaṇam
translated: direct and verbal.🔽Among them, he first mentions the first kind by division: contradiction.🔽Contradiction and irrelevance are the direct faults of reasoning.

analyzed: prāyeṇa anumāna doṣaḥ virodhe eva antarbhavantī
translated: The faults of inference are mostly included in contradiction itself.

analyzed: ti iti prādhānyāt prathamam tad uddeśaḥ
translated: The word first is used because of the importance of the topic.

analyzed: eva iti para parisaṅkhayā ātam ādhikyam nirākaroti  doṣāṇām satām atra eva antarbhāvāt
translated: The word only excludes the possibility of there being more than that.🔽Because the existing faults are included here itself.

analyzed: anantarbhūtānām ca doṣa tva nirāsāt
translated: And because those that are not included are shown to be not faults.

analyzed: sākṣāt iti  vacana upadhānena vinā artha niṣṭham uktam  ukta yukteḥ sāmarthyam
translated: The word directly means🔽without the mediation of words, it is said to be based on meaning.🔽The power of the argument is stated.

analyzed: dūṣaṇam tu iti tuśabda sambandhaḥ
translated: The word but is connected with refutation.

analyzed: sākṣātu iti vā
translated: Or with directly.

analyzed: yukteḥ yukti tva abhimatasya arthasya
translated: Of the meaning that is considered to be an argument.

analyzed: sādhana abhimatasya arthasya sādhya abhimatena arthena sambhāvita pratītikasya api sādhya sādhana bhāvasya
translated: Even though the relation of probans and probandum is possible for the meaning considered to be a proof and the meaning considered to be the probandum,

original: bādhalakṣaṇamayogyatvaṃ virodha iti śiṣyairevohyatāmityāśayavānasaṅgatiṃ nirūpayati pratijñāyāmiti //
analyzed: bādha lakṣaṇam ayogya tvam virodhaḥ iti śiṣyaiḥ eva uhyatām iti āśayavān asaṅgatim nirūpayati pratijñāyām iti
translated: the incompatibility in the form of unsuitability characterized by contradiction should be understood by the students themselves. With this intention, he defines irrelevance as follows:

analyzed: pratijñāyām asambandhaḥ yukteḥ uktā hi asaṅgatiḥ
translated: Irrelevance is stated to be the lack of connection of the reason with the proposition.

analyzed: pratijñā padena tad arthaḥ lakṣyate
translated: By the word proposition, its meaning is indicated.

analyzed: viṣaya saptamīyam
translated: The locative case is in reference to the object.

analyzed: asambandhaḥ tra ākāṅkṣā lakṣaṇa sambandha virahaḥ
translated: The lack of connection here is the absence of the relation characterized by expectancy.

analyzed: atra api yukteḥ iti gauṇaḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: Here also, the word reason is used in a secondary sense.

original: asambandho 'saṅgatiriti paryāyāvityato vyavahārasādhyatāsūcanāyoktetyuktam /🔽virodhāsaṅgatisvarūpasya sphuṭatvādanyairupadarśitatvācca kimatrodāharaṇopadarśaneneti hiśabdenāha / /
analyzed: asambandhaḥ saṅgatiḥ iti paryāyau iti atas vyavahāra sādhya tā sūcanāya uktā iti uktam  virodha asaṅgati svarūpasya sphuṭa tvāt anyaiḥ upadarśita tvāt ca kim atra udāharaṇa upadarśanena iti hi śabdena āha
translated: Non-connection is a synonym for inconsistency. Therefore, it is said that it is stated to indicate the achievability of usage.🔽Since the nature of contradiction and inconsistency is clear and has been shown by others, the word indeed states that there is no need to give an example here.

original: nanu kathaṃ dve evānumānadūṣaṇe paraparigaṇitānāmasiddhatvādīnāṃ bahūnāṃ sattvādityatasteṣāmatrāntarbhāvaṃ vibhāvayitu virodhavibhāgamāha 🔽virodho 'pīti //
analyzed: nanu katham dve eva anumāna dūṣaṇe para parigaṇitānām asiddha tva ādīnām bahūnām sattvāt iti atas teṣām atra antarbhāvam vibhāvayitu virodha vibhāgam āha  virodhaḥ pi iti
translated: But how can there be only two fallacies of inference, since there are many others like unproven accepted by others? To show that they are included here, he states the division of contradiction:

analyzed: virodhaḥ pi tridhā eva syāt
translated: Contradiction is also threefold...

analyzed: sāmānya vibhāgena saha viśeṣa vibhāgasya samuccaye api śabdaḥ
translated: The word also in the compound sāmānyaviśeṣaviśleṣa indicates that the division of particulars is combined with the general division.

original: asaṅgatirapyanekavidheti vā tridhaiva na tvekavidhaiva yenāsiddhayādīnāmantarbhāvo durghaṭaḥ syāt /🔽yadvā yāvanto 'numānābhāsāḥ paraparigaṇitāstāvadbhedatāṃ nirākartu
analyzed: asaṅgatiḥ api anekavidhā iti vā tridhā eva na tu ekavidhā eva yena asiddhayā ādīnām antarbhāvaḥ durghaṭaḥ syāt  yat vā yāvantaḥ numāna ābhāsāḥ para parigaṇitāḥ tāvat bheda tām nirākartu
translated: Inconsistency is also of many kinds means it is threefold, not just one kind, so that the inclusion of unproven and others would not be difficult.🔽Or, the word eva is used to show that all the fallacies of inference accepted by others have that many varieties.

analyzed: vataryitum eva śabdaḥ
translated: To show that.

analyzed: sarveṣām atra eva antarbhāvāt
translated: Because all of them are included here.

analyzed: traividhyam darśayati pratijñā artha iti
translated: He shows the threefold nature with the meaning of the proposition...

analyzed: liṅga rāhityam avyāptiḥ
translated: Contradiction with the proposition.🔽Absence of the probans, over-extension,

analyzed: sādhya dharma viśiṣṭaḥ dharmī pratijñā arthaḥ
translated: The proposition is the subject qualified by the property to be proved.

analyzed: tasya prati spardhi sadbhāvaḥ viruddha tā
translated: The presence of something that competes with it is contradiction.

original: yatrārthe liṅgapramitiḥ sādhyasiddhayupayoginī tatra tadabhāvo liṅgarāhityam /
analyzed: yatra arthe liṅga pramitiḥ sādhya siddhayupayoginī tatra tad abhāvaḥ liṅga rāhityam
translated: Where the ascertainment of the probans is useful for establishing the probandum, the absence of that there is absence of the probans.

analyzed: vyāpteḥ abhāvaḥ vyāptiḥ
translated: The absence of pervasion is over-extension.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ dhyāhāryaḥ  sādhya sādhana bhāva sambandha yogyatā virahaḥ hi sādhya sādhana abhimatayoḥ tad bhāva asambhave bhavati
translated: The word iti should be supplied.🔽For the absence of the relation of the relation of the property to be proved and the property to be established occurs when the existence of that is not possible in what are supposed to be the property to be proved and the property to be established.

original: naca sādhanasya tadbhāve 'pi viruddhasya sādhyatā sambhavati /
analyzed: na ca sādhanasya tad bhāve viruddhasya sādhya tā sambhavati
translated: And even when the property to be established exists, it is not possible for the contradictory to be the property to be proved.

analyzed: niśita tve pi paraśoḥ ākāśasya chedya tā bhāvāt
translated: Even when the axe is sharp, there is no cuttability of space.

analyzed: nā api sādhyasya tathātva sambhave pi asamarthasya
translated: Nor is it possible for the property to be established to be the means of establishment even when it is possible,

analyzed: sādhana tā upapadyate
translated: because it is not capable.

original: chedyatve 'pi kāṣṭhasya kuṇṭhakuṭhārasya chedanakatvābhāvāt /🔽ataḥ pratijñārthaviruddhatādīnāṃ yuktaṃ virodhitvam /
analyzed: chedya tve pi kāṣṭhasya kuṇṭha kuṭhārasya chedanaka tva abhāvāt  atas pratijñā artha viruddha tā ādīnām yuktam virodhi tvam
translated: Even when the wood is cuttable, the crippled axe does not have the nature of cutting.🔽Therefore, it is proper for contradiction with the proposition and others to be contradictions.

analyzed: astu liṅga rāhitya avyāptyoḥ yukti doṣa tvam
translated: Let the absence of the probans and over-extension be faults of reasoning.

analyzed: pratijñā artha viruddha tā tu katham tad doṣaḥ
translated: But how is contradiction of the proposition a fault in that?

analyzed: sādhya sambandhi tvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it is because it is related to the probandum, that is not so.

original: sādhyābhimatasya tadbhāvāsambhave sādhanābhimatasyāviṣayavṛttitvāt /🔽nanvevaṃ sati siddhasādhanatāpi virodha eva syāt /
analyzed: sādhya abhimatasya tad bhāva asambhave sādhana abhimatasya aviṣaya vṛtti tvāt  nanu evam sati siddha sādhana tā api virodhaḥ eva syāt
translated: Because the probandum cannot exist in that [reason], the probans cannot operate on what is not its domain.🔽If that is so, then the contradiction of the probandum being the probans would also be a contradiction.

analyzed: nahi siddhasya sādhya tā sambhavati
translated: For the probandum cannot possibly be the probans.

analyzed: na ca astu iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said to exist.

analyzed: ukta prakāra traya anantarbhāvāt
translated: Because it is not included in the three types mentioned.

analyzed: siddha sādhakaḥ saṅgataḥ iti sva vacana virodhāt ca iti
translated: And because it contradicts one's own statement that the probans of what is established is irrelevant.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: sati sākāṅkṣa tve nvaya ayogya tvam virodhaḥ
translated: If there is a need, then the incompatibility of connection is a contradiction.

original: naca siddhasādhanasya sākāṅkṣatā astīti nāsau virodhe 'ntarbhavati /
analyzed: na ca siddha sādhanasya sākāṅkṣa tā asti iti na asau virodhe ntarbhavati
translated: And the probans of what is established does not have a need, therefore it is not included in contradiction.

original: nanu cānyatra trividho virodha ityādinā liṅgarāhityāvyāptyorekatāmupādāya sādhyasya sādhanasya vānugamo dṛṣṭāntavirodhastṛtīyatayā parigṛhītaḥ
analyzed: nanu ca anyatra trividhaḥ virodhaḥ ityādinā liṅga rāhitya avyāptyoḥ ekatām upādāya sādhyasya sādhanasya vā anugamaḥ dṛṣṭānta virodhaḥ tṛtīya tayā parigṛhītaḥ
translated: But elsewhere, by taking the identity of the absence of a probans and over-extension, the non-universality of the probandum or probans is included as the third type of contradiction of the example.

analyzed: atra api sādhya sādhana vaikalyam dṛṣṭāntasya iti vakṣyati
translated: Here also, it will say that the example lacks the probandum and probans.

analyzed: tat katham etat
translated: How is this so?

analyzed: na ca atra api tad adhyāhāreṇa tathā eva vyākhyānam yuktam
translated: And here also it is not proper to explain it in the same way by supplying that [i.e., the example].

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta doṣasya anumāna doṣa tā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the fault of the example does not logically follow from the fault of the inference.

analyzed: nahi dṛṣṭāntaḥ numānam  tathā api anumāna aṅga vyāpti dūṣaka tayā anumāna doṣa tvam astu
translated: For the example is not the inference.🔽Nevertheless, let it be a fault of the inference because it is a fault of the pervasion which is a part of the inference.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vaikalye sādhanasya sādhya parityāgāt
translated: Because when the example lacks the probandum, the probans abandons the probandum.

analyzed: sādhana vaikalye tu vyāpteḥ anupadarśanāt iti ced na
translated: But if the probans lacks, it is because the pervasion is not shown. If you say this, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā satya vyāptyā eva saṅgṛhīta tvena tṛtīya tva anupapatteḥ iti
translated: Because it is not logically possible for it to be the third [fault] when it is included by the pervasion itself.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: svārthānumāne hi dṛṣṭavyāptikasya liṅgasya vivakṣitasthale siddhimātreṇa sādhyapramitirutpadyata
analyzed: svārtha anumāne hi dṛṣṭa vyāptikasya liṅgasya vivakṣita sthale siddhi mātreṇa sādhya pramitiḥ utpadyata
translated: For in an inference for oneself, the cognition of the probandum arises merely by the establishment of the logical mark whose pervasion has been seen in the intended locus.

analyzed: iti tad paripanthinām doṣa tvam abhipretya pratijñā artha viruddha tā liṅga rāhitya avyāptīnām atra grahaṇam
translated: Thus, intending that the faults are those which obstruct that [cognition of the probandum], the contradiction with the proposition, the absence of the logical mark, and the non-pervasion are mentioned here.

analyzed: para artha anumāne ipya
translated: Even in an inference for another,

original: tvavyāptyaupayikasyāpi dṛṣṭāntadoṣasya tadāśrayatayā pratītatvena tathaivodbhavanīyatājñāpanāya tena saha trividhatvamanyatroktamiti na virodhaḥ
analyzed: tu avyāpti aupayikasya api dṛṣṭānta doṣasya tad āśraya tayā pratīta tvena tathā evā udbhavanīya tā jñāpanāya tena saha trividha tvam anyatra uktam iti na virodhaḥ
translated: The fault of the example, which is also useful for non-pervasion, is considered to be the basis of that [non-pervasion], and in order to indicate that it should be stated in the same way, the threefold nature is stated elsewhere along with that [fault of the example]. Thus there is no contradiction.

analyzed: yat vā sādhya sādhana ubhaya āśraya hīna sādhya sādhana ubhaya vyāvṛtta āśraya hīnān aṣṭau dṛṣṭānta doṣān eke bhāṣante
translated: Or, some speak of eight faults of the example: the fault of the example being devoid of both the probandum and the probans, the fault of the example being devoid of both the probandum and the probans, the fault of the example being devoid of both the probandum and the probans, and the fault of the example being devoid of both the probandum and the probans.

analyzed: tad nirāsāya dṛṣṭānta doṣasya pṛthak upādānam
translated: In order to refute that, the fault of the example is mentioned separately.

analyzed: tathā hi ubhaya vikalaḥ tāvat na parisaṅkhayeyaḥ  anyatara vaikalyena eva dṛṣṭānta  duṣyatā siddhau ādhikya prasaṅgāt
translated: To explain: First, one who is devoid of both [the probandum and the probans] should not be enumerated.🔽Because if the example is faulty due to being deficient in either [the probandum or the probans], it is established that there is an excess [of faults].

analyzed: anyathā ekaika vikala parisaṅkhaya anā anupapatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, it would be impossible to enumerate each deficiency individually.

analyzed: katham tarhi anvaya vyatireki iti ced
translated: If it is asked how then [the example] is one that has concomitance and non-concomitance,

analyzed: na kathañcid iti uktam eva
translated: it has been said that it is not [a fault] in any way.

original: sādhyādyavyāptistu dṛṣṭāntasya guṇa eva na doṣaḥ /
analyzed: sādhya ādi avyāptiḥ tu dṛṣṭāntasya guṇaḥ eva na doṣaḥ
translated: But the non-pervasion of the example by the probandum and so on is a virtue of the example, not a fault.

original: sato hi satā vyāptiṃ pradarśayituṃ dṛṣṭānto 'nveṣyavyaḥ /🔽vaidharmyadṛṣṭāntasyāyaṃ doṣa iti cetsa eva kimarthaḥ /
analyzed: sataḥ hi satā vyāptim pradarśayitum dṛṣṭāntaḥ nveṣyavyaḥ  vaidharmya dṛṣṭāntasya ayam doṣaḥ iti ced saḥ eva kimarthaḥ
translated: For an example should be sought to demonstrate the pervasion of an existent by an existent.🔽If it is said that this is a fault of the example of dissimilar nature, what is the purpose of that [example]?

analyzed: vyatireka vyāpti bodhayā iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it is for the purpose of understanding the pervasion by the negative concomitance, no.

analyzed: tasyāḥ sākṣāt anupayogāt
translated: Because it is not directly useful.

original: pāramparyeṇopayogo tu sādharmyadṛṣṭānta evāsāviti kiṃ pṛthagupādānena /
analyzed: tu sādharmya dṛṣṭāntaḥ eva asau iti kim pṛthak upādānena
translated: But if it is useful indirectly, then it is just the similar example, so what is the use of mentioning it separately?

analyzed: ubhaya avyāvṛttaḥ ca ādhikyāt nikya nirastaḥ
translated: And one that is excluded from both is refuted by the excess.

analyzed: āśraya hīnaḥ tu āśraya asiddhi samāna yogakṣemaḥ iti dvau eva dṛṣṭānta doṣau
translated: But one that lacks a basis is of the same nature as the unestablished basis, so there are only two faults of the example.

original: asārvatrikaśca dṛṣṭāntadoṣaḥ /🔽nahi sarvatra dṛṣṭānta eva vyāptirupadarśanīyetyasti niyamaḥ /
analyzed: asārvatrikaḥ ca dṛṣṭānta doṣaḥ  nahi sarvatra dṛṣṭānte eva vyāptiḥ upadarśanīyā iti asti niyamaḥ
translated: And the fault of the example is not universal.🔽For there is no rule that the pervasion must be shown only through an example everywhere.

analyzed: ānumānika āgamika vyāpteḥ tad anapekṣaṇāt
translated: Because the pervasion that is inferred or known from scripture does not require that.

analyzed: syāt etat  pratijñā artha viruddha tayā hi kāla atīta prakaraṇasamau saṅgṛhītau
translated: This may be so.🔽For the inconclusive and the contradictory are included as contradicting the meaning of the proposition.

analyzed: liṅga rāhityam iti asiddhiḥ
translated: The absence of the reason is the unestablished.

analyzed: avyāptiḥ ca trividhā bhavati
translated: And the non-pervasion is of three kinds.

analyzed: sādhanasya sādhyena sambandha abhāvaḥ
translated: The absence of a relation between the proof and the probandum.

analyzed: sati api sambandhe tad abhāvena api sambandhaḥ
translated: Even when there is a relation, the relation with that absence.

analyzed: sādhya abhāva vyāpta pya tā ca iti
translated: And the pervasion by the absence of the probandum.

analyzed: tat etat trayam krameṇa anadhyavasitā na aikāntika viruddha saṃjñām labhate
translated: And these three in order get the names inconclusive, contradictory, and unestablished.

analyzed: tathā ca para nirūpita prastārasya samasanam eva anena kṛtam syāt
translated: And thus he would have merely composed a samasana (a summary) of the prasthāna (the basic text) as determined by others.

analyzed: na ca anena kim api prayojanam
translated: And this has no purpose at all.

analyzed: anyathā puruṣa mati vaiśvarūpyeṇa prakriyā antarasya api sāvakāśa tvāt
translated: Otherwise, due to the diversity of human intellect, another method would also have an occasion.

analyzed: na ca brahmatarka ādi tarka śāstram anusṛtya ittham vyutpādanam iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that this explanation is based on the logic treatises such as the Brahmatarka.

analyzed: prayojana abhāve ndha paramparā patteḥ iti
translated: Because if there is no purpose, it would lead to a blind succession.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: asti prakriyā antara karaṇasya prayojanam
translated: There is a purpose for making another method.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus:

analyzed: pratijñā artha viruddha tayā hi sva vākya virodhasya api saṅgraham vakṣyati
translated: He will say that self-contradiction is also included as contradicting the meaning of the thesis.

analyzed: na ca kāla atīta tva ādinā sa labhyate
translated: And that is not obtained by being beyond time, etc.

analyzed: api ca vyavahāraḥ pi pratijñā artha viruddha tayā upapadyate
translated: Moreover, usage is also possible by contradicting the meaning of the thesis.

analyzed: na kāla atīta tva ādinā  vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt
translated: Not by being beyond time, etc.

analyzed: asādhakam idam kāla atīta tvāt
translated: Because it would lead to the fault of being useless.🔽This is not a proof because it is beyond time.

analyzed: sat pratipakṣa tvāt iti asya prabala sama bala pramāṇa viruddha tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of this is that it is contradicted by strong and equal evidence.

analyzed: na ca atra viśeṣaṇasya kim api prayojanam asti
translated: And there is no purpose at all for the qualification in this.

analyzed: hīna balasya pramāṇa padena eva nirasta tvāt
translated: Because one of weak power has been refuted by the very statement of the measure.

original: pramāṇatadābhāsāviveka eva hi pramāṇaśabdaprayogo na tvaprāmāṇyaniścaye /
analyzed: pramāṇa tad ābhāsa aviveke eva hi pramāṇa śabda prayogaḥ na tu aprāmāṇya niścaye
translated: For the use of the word 'means of valid knowledge' is just the non-discrimination of the means of valid knowledge and its semblance, not the ascertainment of invalidity.

original: ahīnabalatayā vā viśeṣaṇe sambhavati tadavāntarabhedopādānaṃ niratharkameva /
analyzed: ahīna bala tayā vā viśeṣaṇe sambhavati tat avāntarabheda upādānam niratharkam eva
translated: Or, when the qualification of not being of weak power is possible, the mention of its subdivisions is pointless.

analyzed: tathā ca ekam eva idam dūṣaṇam syāt
translated: And thus this would be just one fault.

original: liṅgarāhityagrahaṇena cādūṣaṇānāmapi dūṣaṇatayā paraparigaṇitānāmāśrayavyadhikaraṇasādhyānyathāsiddhīnāṃ nirāso labhyate anyathāsiddherdūṣaṇatve
analyzed: liṅga rāhitya grahaṇena ca adūṣaṇānām api dūṣaṇa tayā para parigaṇitānām āśraya vyadhikaraṇa sādhya anyathāsiddhīnām nirāsaḥ labhyate anyathāsiddheḥ dūṣaṇa tve
translated: And by mentioning the absence of the logical mark, the refutation of the other's enumerated faults such as the subject being not established, the reason being not established, the probandum being not established, and the reason being contradictory, which are not faults, is obtained. Even if the non-establishment of the probandum were a fault,

analyzed: pi prakāra antasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: another type will be stated.

original: anadhyavasitatvādibhedo 'pi kiṃ vyāptyabhāve sambhavatītyetāvatā parisaṅkhayeyo vyavahāropayogitvādvā /
analyzed: anadhyavasita tva ādi bhedaḥ pi kim vyāpti abhāve sambhavati iti etāvatā parisaṅkhayeyaḥ vyavahāra upayogi tvāt vā
translated: Should the distinction of being undetermined, etc. be included just because it is possible in the absence of pervasion, or because it is useful for usage?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: vyartha vyutpādanasya atiprasaṅgi tvāt
translated: Because the postulation of what is useless is too wide.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.
