translated: But for rivals also, it is preceded by the questioning of the assembly and the assembly.🔽Debate itself...

analyzed: vādaḥ eva
translated: It is only a dispute. . . .🔽. . . .

analyzed: praśna śabdāt karoti iti arthe īkak pratyayaḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: From the word 'question', the affix 'ik' should be used in the sense of 'doing'.

analyzed: spardhinām iti jātau bahuvacanam  eva ityasya yujyate iti adhyāhṛtena anvayaḥ
translated: The plural in 'spardhinām' is in the general sense.🔽The word 'eva' is connected with the understood 'yujyate'.

original: yataḥ sabhādipūrvastataḥ spardhināmapi vādo yujyata eveti /
analyzed: yatas sabhā ādi pūrvaḥ tatas spardhinām api vādaḥ yujyate evā iti
translated: Because it is preceded by the assembly etc., therefore the debate of the competitors is also proper.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ hetvarthaḥ
translated: The word 'tu' has the sense of reason.

analyzed: sabhā sabhā pati prāśnikaiḥ niyatayoḥ asat sādhana ādi prayoga varjana sambhavāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is possible to avoid the use of false means of proof etc. for those whose debate is determined by the assembly, the president of the assembly, and the judges.

analyzed: yat uktam tad siddhau vyartha tā anyayoḥ
translated: What was said - In the establishment of that, the other two are useless -

analyzed: iti tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: vādena tattva nirṇaya siddhau api artha ādi asiddheḥ
translated: Even if the determination of truth is established by debate, the desired meaning etc. are not established.

analyzed: tathā ca abhilaṣitam na siddham
translated: And thus, what is desired is not established.

analyzed: siddham ca anabhilaṣitam iti tatra āha ubhaya iti
translated: And what is established is not desired. There, he says 'ubhayartha' etc.
It would be for both purposes, for bringing about determination and victory.

analyzed: vādaḥ iti anuvartate
translated: The word 'vāda' is continued.

analyzed: asya eva vivaraṇam
translated: The explanation of this itself is 'nirṇīti' etc.

analyzed: na kevalam nirṇīti kārakaḥ kintu jaya kārakaḥ ca
translated: It is not only the cause of determination, but also the cause of victory.

analyzed: jaya śabdena tad sādhyam arthya ādikam upalakṣyate
translated: By the word 'jaya', what is to be accomplished by it, such as meaning etc., is indicated.

original: vidyāparīkṣārthe vāde jayino 'rthādikamapi sabhāpatinā sampādanīyamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vidyā parīkṣā arthe vāde jayinaḥ rtha ādikam api sabhāpatinā sampādanīyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in a debate for the purpose of testing knowledge, the presiding officer of the assembly should arrange for the winner to obtain wealth etc. as well.

analyzed: evam tarhi na kadāpi jalpa vitaṇḍā pravṛttiḥ vyartha rata anyayoḥ
translated: If that is so, then there can never be the practice of wrangling and caviling, because of the uselessness of the two.

analyzed: iti yukteḥ sama māna tvāt
translated: Because of the equality of the reason.

analyzed: yathā hi vidyā vaiṣamya nirṇaye jitavataḥ rtha ādi lābhaḥ
translated: For just as there is gain of wealth etc. for the victor when the difference in knowledge is determined,

original: tathā tatsāmye dvayorapi arthādilābhaḥ sambhavatyeva /🔽naca phalāntaramasti yena punarjalpavitaṇḍārambhaḥ syādityata āha tattvāprakāśa eveti // /
analyzed: tathā tad sāmye dvayoḥ api artha ādi lābhaḥ sambhavati eva  na ca phala antaram asti yena punar jalpa vitaṇḍā ārambhaḥ syāt iti atas āha tattva aprakāśe eva iti
translated: in the same way, when it is equal, the gain of wealth etc. is possible for both.🔽And there is no other result by which the commencement of wrangling and caviling would be possible. Therefore he says: The non-illumination of truth alone is the result of wrangling and caviling.

analyzed: tattva aprakāśaḥ eva ekaḥ vitaṇḍā jalpayoḥ phalam
translated: The non-illumination of truth alone is the result of wrangling and caviling.

analyzed: tattva aprakāśaḥ iti para vañcana sāmarthyam ucyate
translated: The non-illumination of truth is said to be the ability to deceive others.

analyzed: tena tad sādhyaḥ rtha ādi lābhaḥ lakṣyate
translated: By that, the gain of wealth etc. which is accomplished by that is indicated.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: yadi api vidyā sāmya vaiṣamyayoḥ nirṇīti jayau syātām tathā api tāttvika kathā phala rūpau eva
translated: Even if there were determination and victory in the equality and inequality of knowledge, they would still be the true results of the discussion.

analyzed: para ācchādana cāturya prayukta artha ādi lābha artham samāna vidyayoḥ punar jalpa vitaṇḍā pravṛttiḥ iti
translated: The practice of wrangling and caviling again by those of equal knowledge is for the sake of the gain of wealth etc. brought about by the skill in concealing from the opponent.

analyzed: na ca evam viṣama vidyayoḥ api tad pravṛttiḥ
translated: And thus, even in the case of unequal knowledge, there is no application of those (debate, etc.).

analyzed: upaplava prasaṅgasya ukta tvāt iti
translated: Because the possibility of error has been stated.

analyzed: yat vā tattva nirṇaya phalaḥ vādaḥ artha ādi phale jalpa vitaṇḍe
translated: Or, debate has the result of determining truth, while disputation and cavil have the result of wealth, etc.

analyzed: iti phala bhedena kathā bhedaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Thus, the difference in discussions is stated on the basis of the difference in results.

original: so 'nupapannaḥ /🔽tathā satyarthādīnāṃ bhedena kathā'nantyaprasaṅgādityata āha tattveti //
analyzed: saḥ nu papannaḥ  tathā sati artha ādīnām bhedena kathā ānantya prasaṅgāt iti atas āha tattva iti
translated: That is not correct.🔽Because if that were so, there would be the undesirable consequence of the infinite number of discussions due to the difference in wealth, etc. To this, he says tattve (in reality).

original: yadyapi arthādayo 'vāntarabhedabhinnāstathāpi tattvāprakāśa eka eva vitaṇḍājalpayoḥ phalam /🔽tattvanirṇayetaratvarūpeṇārthādīnāmekatvānnoktadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api artha ādayaḥ vāntara bheda bhinnāḥ tathā api tattva aprakāśaḥ ekaḥ eva vitaṇḍā jalpayoḥ phalam  tattva nirṇaya itaratva rūpeṇa artha ādīnām ekatvāt na ukta doṣaḥ
translated: Even though wealth, etc. are different due to the difference in sub-varieties, still the non-illumination of truth is the only result of disputation and cavil.🔽Because wealth, etc. are one in the form of being other than the determination of truth, there is no fault as stated.

analyzed: tad avāntarabheda vivakṣā tu vyarthā evā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The intention to state the difference in their sub-varieties is itself pointless. This is the idea.

analyzed: evam kathayā vidyā parīkṣaṇam iti pakṣaḥ samarthitaḥ
translated: Thus, the view that the examination of knowledge is through discussion is supported.

analyzed: idānīm anyathā iti pakṣam api samarthayamānaḥ āha vinā iti
translated: Now, supporting the view that it is otherwise, he says vina (without).

original: vinā vādena vidyāyā yadi śakyaṃ parīkṣaṇam /
analyzed: vinā vādena vidyāyāḥ yadi śakyam parīkṣaṇam
translated: If the examination of knowledge is possible without discussion,

analyzed: syāt jalpa ādiḥ api kvāpi
translated: then disputation, etc. may also be somewhere.

analyzed: avigīta vidvas prasiddha yādinā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is by what is not contradicted by the well-known of the learned, etc.

analyzed: kvāpi iti asya pūrva ardhena anvayaḥ
translated: The word 'kvacit' is to be construed with the first half.

original: tadā samavidyayoḥ prathamamapi jalpādiḥ kathāviśeṣaḥ kāryaḥ syādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tadā sama vidyayoḥ prathamam api jalpa ādiḥ kathā viśeṣaḥ kāryaḥ syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that then, even at the beginning, a special kind of discussion like Jalpa etc. should be undertaken between the two parties having equal knowledge.

original: tarhi vidyāparīkṣaṇaṃ vādenaivetyuktivirodha ityata āha vā eveti //
analyzed: tarhi vidyā parīkṣaṇam vādena eva iti ukti virodhaḥ iti atas āha vā eva iti
translated: If that is so, then there is contradiction with the statement that the examination of knowledge should be done only by Vada. To this he says 'Vada eva' etc.

analyzed: vādaḥ eva anyathā bhavet
translated: Vada alone would be otherwise.

original: vāda eva prathamaṃ kartavyo bhavediti yaduktaṃ tadanyathā vādena vinā vidyāparīkṣaṇasya kartumaśakyatva evāto na virodha iti /
analyzed: vādaḥ eva prathamam kartavyaḥ bhavet iti yat uktam tad anyathā vādena vinā vidyā parīkṣaṇasya kartum aśakya tve eva atas na virodhaḥ iti
translated: What was said that Vada alone should be done first, that is otherwise, because without Vada the examination of knowledge cannot be done, therefore there is no contradiction.

analyzed: astu evam upāya antara virahe kathaya eva vidyā parīkṣaṇam
translated: Let it be so, that the examination of knowledge is done by discussion alone in the absence of other means.

analyzed: sā tu vādaḥ iti kutas
translated: But how is that Vada?

analyzed: tattva nirṇaya arthinoḥ adhikāri tvāt tad phala tvāt ca iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is so because the two parties seeking to ascertain the truth are entitled to it and it is the result of that, it is not so.

analyzed: evam
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tarhi vijigīṣāvatoḥ adhikāri tvāt artha ādi phala tvāt sabhā ādi aṅga upeta tvāt jalpaḥ pi syāt iti
translated: Then, because the two parties desirous of victory are entitled to it and it is the result of wealth etc., and because it is accompanied by the limbs like the assembly etc., Jalpa also would be so.

analyzed: kim atra jalpa śabda vācya tā mātram āpadyate
translated: What happens here? Is it merely the state of being denoted by the word Jalpa?

analyzed: kiṃvā vāda śabda vācya tā bhāvaḥ
translated: Or is it the absence of being denoted by the word Vada?

original: athavā samāhārarūpaṃ kathāntaraṃ yadvā nimittadvayasamāveśe vādaśabdasyaiva vyavahārānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: athavā samāhāra rūpam kathā antaram yat vā nimitta dvaya samāveśe vāda śabdasya eva vyavahāra anupapattiḥ
translated: Or, the form of a combination is a different kind of discussion. Or, when two reasons are combined, the word 'vāda' itself is not applicable.

analyzed: sarvatra api uttaram āha jalpaḥ iti
translated: In all cases, the answer is given by 'jalpa'.

original: jalpa ityapi nāma syād vādasyaitādṛśasya tu // / / //
analyzed: jalpaḥ iti api nāma syāt vādasya etādṛśasya tu
translated: Even the name 'jalpa' would be for such a kind of vāda.

original: etādṛśasya nimittadvayopetasyātra jalpa iti nāma syādityabhyupagamenādyo nirastaḥ /
analyzed: etādṛśasya nimitta dvaya upetasya atra jalpaḥ iti nāma syāt iti abhyupagamena ādyaḥ nirastaḥ
translated: For such a kind endowed with two reasons, the name 'jalpa' would be accepted, thus refuting the first [objection].

analyzed: apiśabdena vāda śabda vācya tām pratijñāyai tādṛśasya iti anena hetuḥ uktaḥ
translated: By the word 'api' (even), having promised to be denoted by the word 'vāda', by the word 'tādṛśasya' (such), the reason is stated.

analyzed: tena dvitīyaḥ pi nirākṛtaḥ
translated: Therefore, the second [objection] is also refuted.

analyzed: nahi nimitta sadbhāve vācaka apravṛttiḥ iti yuktam
translated: For, when the reason exists, it is not proper that the denotator should not function.

analyzed: jalpa śabde pi sāmyāt
translated: Because of similarity even in the word 'jalpa'.

analyzed: atas tulāyām pramāṇāt itas vidhā antaravatī syāt
translated: Therefore, it would have a different rule from the standard of balance.

original: vādasya jalpa ityapi nāma syāditi vādasaṃjñā tu mukhyā jalpasaṃjñā tvamukhyeti sūcitam /
analyzed: vādasya jalpaḥ iti api nāma syāt iti vāda saṃjñā tu mukhyā jalpa saṃjñā tu amukhyā iti sūcitam
translated: Even the name 'jalpa' would be for vāda. But the designation 'vāda' is primary, while the designation 'jalpa' is secondary, thus it is indicated.

analyzed: tena caturthaḥ pi nirastaḥ
translated: And by that, the fourth [objection] is also refuted.

analyzed: tatra hetu viśeṣa sadbhāvam tuśabdena dyotayati
translated: There, the existence of a special reason is indicated by the word 'tu'.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

original: yadyapi kathakāvādito vijigīṣū tathāpi sabhyādibhivirjigīṣāṃ paribhāvyotpāditā tattvanirṇayārthitaiva kathopayoginī /
analyzed: yadi api kathaka avāditaḥ vijigīṣū tathā api sabhya ādibhiḥ jigīṣām paribhāvya utpāditā tattva nirṇaya arthitā eva kathā upayoginī
translated: Although the disputants are desirous of victory from the beginning, it is only the desire for the ascertainment of truth produced by the consideration of victory by the audience etc. that is useful for the debate.

original: arthādilābhaścāntarā prāpto na tvādita evoddiṣya ityamukhya eva /
analyzed: artha ādi lābhaḥ ca antarā prāptaḥ na tu āditas eva uddiṣyaḥ iti amukhyaḥ eva
translated: And the gain of wealth etc. is obtained incidentally, not as the primary objective, so it is only secondary.

original: ata eva pūrva ubhayārthaḥ syādityukte sāmyapratītiprasaktau nirṇītijayakāraka iti tattvanirṇīteḥ prādhānyapradarśanārthaṃ vivaraṇaṃ kṛtam /
analyzed: atas eva pūrvaḥ ubhaya arthaḥ syāt iti ukte sāmya pratīti prasaktau nirṇīti jaya kārakaḥ iti tattva nirṇīteḥ prādhānya pradarśana artham vivaraṇam kṛtam
translated: For this very reason, when it was said that it may be for both, and the possibility of understanding it as equal was raised, the commentary was written to show the primacy of the ascertainment of truth by saying the cause of the ascertainment and victory.

analyzed: anyathā kathā phala dvayasya evā ubhaya śabdena pratīteḥ vivaraṇam vyartham syāt
translated: Otherwise, the commentary would be pointless, as the two fruits of the debate would be understood by the word both itself.

analyzed: alpa a c taram iti lakṣaṇasya vyabhicāram kurvāṇena api etat eva sūcitam
translated: Even by one who points out the deviation of the definition with few words, this same [fact] is indicated.

analyzed: anyathā jaya nirṇīti kārakaḥ iti avakṣyat
translated: Otherwise, he would have said the cause of victory and ascertainment.

analyzed: sabhya ādi saṃvaraṇam ca vijigīṣu tā paribhava artham iti vāda tā prādhānyam eva upodbalayati iti
translated: And the concealment by the audience etc. is for the purpose of humiliating the desirous of victory, thus it only emphasizes the primacy of debate.

analyzed: api ca adhikāri bheda ādikam bahis aṅga tayā eva kathā bhedakam
translated: Moreover, the difference in the qualifications etc. is the differentiator of the debate only as an external factor.

analyzed: antaraṅgam tu pravṛtti prakāraḥ eva
translated: But the internal factor is only the mode of engagement.

original: sa ca vādasambandhyevāsyāṃ kathāyāmastītyato vādatvameva mukhyamityāśayavānāha pratijñeti //
analyzed: sa ca vāda sambandhī eva asyām kathāyām asti iti atas vāda tvam eva mukhyam iti āśayavān āha pratijñā iti
translated: And that is only connected with debate in this story, therefore debate itself is primary. With this intention, he says promise etc.

analyzed: pratijñā mātra sādhya tvam api syāt yājñavalkya vat
translated: Even the state of being to be established by mere promise would be like Yajnavalkya.

original: vidyāparīkṣārthāyāṃ kathāyāṃ kvāpi prameye pratijñāmātreṇa pramāṇopanyāsarahitena vacanena sādhyatvaṃ prajñāpanīyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: vidyā parīkṣā arthāyām kathāyām kvāpi prameye pratijñā mātreṇa pramāṇa upanyāsa rahitena vacanena sādhya tvam prajñāpanīyam syāt
translated: In a story for the purpose of examining knowledge, in some object of knowledge, the state of being to be established would be indicated by a statement lacking the presentation of a means of knowledge, by mere promise.

analyzed: kutas etat
translated: Why is this?

analyzed: kati eva devāḥ yājñavalkya iti śākalyena pṛṣṭe
translated: When asked by Śākalya, How many gods are there, Yājñavalkya?,

analyzed: yājñavalkyena
translated: by Yājñavalkya

original: trayastriṃśaditi vacanamātreṇa prajñāpanasya kṛtatvāt /🔽sā ca vidyāparīkṣārthā kathetyupakramaparyālocanayā siddham /
analyzed: trayastriṃśat iti vacana mātreṇa prajñāpanasya kṛta tvāt  sā ca vidyā parīkṣā arthā kathā iti upakrama paryālocanayā siddham
translated: the state of being to be established was done by the mere statement thirty-three.🔽And that is established by examining the introductory section that the story is for the purpose of examining knowledge.

analyzed: yājñavalkya śabdena tad kathā upalakṣyate
translated: The word Yājñavalkya indicates that story.

analyzed: saptamī arthe vatiḥ
translated: The suffix vati has the sense of the locative case.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha saṃvādaḥ iti
translated: What then? Therefore he says agreement etc.

analyzed: saṃvāde vādinoḥ kvāpi
translated: In an agreement between the two disputants, in some place...

original: evambhāvo hi vādiprativādinoḥ saṃvāde 'nyonyāptatā'śvāse satyeva syāt tadāśvāso hi vāda eva sambhavati na jalpe /
analyzed: evambhāvaḥ hi vādi prativādinoḥ saṃvāde nyonya āpta tā āśvāse sati eva syāt tad āśvāsaḥ hi vāde eva sambhavati na jalpe
translated: For this state of affairs would only be in an agreement between the disputants, when there is mutual confidence and trust. Then that confidence is possible only in debate, not in disputation.

original: vijigīṣuṇāpasiddhāntādiparihāreṇa sarvathā pramāṇapraśnasya kartavyatvāt /🔽tenāyaṃ vāda eveti prati
analyzed: vijigīṣuṇā apasiddhānta ādi parihāreṇa sarvathā pramāṇa praśnasya kartavya tvāt  tena ayam vādaḥ eva iti prati
translated: Because the question of pramāṇa must be undertaken in every way by one who is victorious, by avoiding the fallacy of contradiction, etc.

analyzed: jñāyate iti
translated: Therefore, this is recognized as a debate.

analyzed: nanu evam tarhi na vidyā parīkṣā sambhavati
translated: But if so, then the examination of knowledge is not possible.

analyzed: pramāṇa upanyāse hi tad samarthana upālambhābhyām sā syāt
translated: For that would be by supporting and refuting the statement of pramāṇa,

analyzed: na tu praśna pratijñā abhyupagama mātreṇa iti atas āha vivādaḥ iti
translated: but not merely by the question, assertion, and acceptance. To this he says: dispute etc.

analyzed: vivāde hetuḥ iṣyate
translated: A reason is accepted in a dispute.

analyzed: hetuḥ iti pramāṇa mātra upalakṣaṇam
translated: Reason is a mere indication of pramāṇa.

analyzed: pramā hetuḥ iti vā
translated: Or, the cause of valid knowledge.

original: na hyekatrāptaḥ sarvatrāpta eveti niyamo 'stīti bhāvaḥ /🔽yājñavalkyenāpi tatra tatra pramāṇopanyāsaḥ kṛta eveti sakalamanākulam / /
analyzed: na hi ekatra āptaḥ sarvatra āptaḥ eva iti niyamaḥ asti iti bhāvaḥ  yājñavalkyena api tatra tatra pramāṇa upanyāsaḥ kṛtaḥ evā iti sakalam an ākulam
translated: For there is no rule that one who is authoritative in one place is authoritative everywhere. This is the idea.🔽Yājñavalkya himself has stated the pramāṇas here and there. Thus everything is clear.

analyzed: prakṛtānām sabhya sabhāpati prāśnikānām svarūpa jijñāsāyām āha sabhā iti
translated: When there is a desire to know the nature of the topics under discussion, the members of the assembly, the president of the assembly, and the judges, he says assembly etc.

analyzed: sabhā sabhāpatiḥ ca eva prāśnikāḥ ca eva vaiṣṇavāḥ
translated: The assembly, the president of the assembly, and the judges are all devotees of Viṣṇu.

analyzed: rāga dveṣa vihīnāḥ ca  dvau caśabdau sa bhābhyā
translated: Free from attachment and aversion.

analyzed: dīnām anyonya samuccaye
translated: The two words ca (and) are for mutual combination of the assembly and others.

analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ viśeṣaṇa samuccaye
translated: The third is for the combination of qualifications.

original: evaśabdau tu vaiṣṇavā eva rāgadveṣavihīnā eveti sambaddhayete /
analyzed: eva śabdau tu vaiṣṇavāḥ eva rāga dveṣa vihīnāḥ eva iti
translated: The words eva (only) are connected to mean that only the devotees of Vishnu are free from attachment and aversion.

analyzed: anyathā kathā anupapatti sūcanam tad prayojanam  syuḥ iti vakṣyamāṇam iha apim atra api
translated: The purpose of that is to indicate the impossibility of the story otherwise.

analyzed: sambaddhayate
translated: The word syuḥ (may be) which will be mentioned later is also connected here.

analyzed: sabhyānām prāśnikānām ca viśeṣaṇa antaram āha syuḥ iti
translated: He states another qualification of the members of the assembly and the judges.

analyzed: syuḥ sabhyāḥ sarva vedinaḥ
translated: The members of the assembly may be omniscient.

analyzed: prāśnikāḥ
translated: The judges may be omniscient.

analyzed: sarva śabdena vādi prativādi darśanasya kathā upayuktasya vyākaraṇa ādeḥ ca saṅgrahaḥ
translated: By the word sarva (all), the knowledge of the disputants and the opponent, and the grammar etc. useful for the story are included.

analyzed: punar sabhya prāśnika grahaṇam sabhāpati vyavaccheda artham
translated: The repetition of the words sabhyāḥ (members of the assembly) and prāśnikāḥ (judges) is for the purpose of excluding the president of the assembly.

analyzed: tad sārvajñasya kathā upayoga abhāvāt
translated: Because his omniscience is not useful for the story.

analyzed: sabhyāḥ prāśnikāḥ ca sarva vedinaḥ syuḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The construction is that the members of the assembly and the judges may be omniscient.

analyzed: nanu prāśnikānām kva upayogaḥ
translated: But where is the use of the judges?

analyzed: vivadamānayoḥ guṇa doṣa avadhāraṇa ādau iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say that it is for determining the merits and demerits of the disputants.

original: evaṃ tarhi tairevālaṃ kiṃ sabhyairityata āha etaditi //
analyzed: evam tarhi taiḥ eva alam kim sabhyaiḥ iti atas āha etat iti
translated: If so, then what is the use of the members of the assembly? To this he says this.

analyzed: ca etat ajñāne sabhyāḥ ca
translated: And in the absence of this knowledge, the members of the assembly may be omniscient.

analyzed: anantara uktān prāśnikān etad śabdena parāmṛśati
translated: He refers to the judges mentioned just before by the word etat (this).

original: kvacitsūkṣme prameye eteṣāṃ prāśnikānāṃ kāraṇāntaradvājñāne sati vādinorguṇadoṣanirṇayāya sabhyāśca pramāṇaṃ syuriti vakṣyamāṇenānvayaḥ /
analyzed: kvacid sūkṣme prameye eteṣām prāśnikānām kāraṇa antara dvār jñāne sati vādinoḥ guṇa doṣa nirṇayāya sabhyāḥ ca pramāṇam syuḥ iti vakṣyamāṇena anvayaḥ
translated: In some cases, when these judges have ignorance about the cause of the matter to be examined, the members of the assembly would also be the means of knowledge for determining the merits and demerits of the disputants. This is connected with what is going to be said.

analyzed: yadi evam prāśnikeṣu ajñāna śaṅkayā sabhyānām varaṇam
translated: The means of knowledge is figuratively applied to those who are the basis of the means of knowledge.🔽If so, the members of the assembly are chosen due to doubt about ignorance among the judges.

analyzed: tadā teṣu api ajñāna śaṅkayā anye varaṇīyāḥ
translated: Then others should also be chosen due to doubt about ignorance among them.
Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the futility of the debate due to the absence of a decision.

analyzed: teṣu api evam iti atas āha eṣām ca iti
translated: Since it is the same for them, he says and of these etc.

analyzed: eṣām ca dūra gāḥ
translated: And of these, the distant ones

analyzed: pramāṇam nirṇayāya syuḥ
translated: would be the means of knowledge for the decision.

original: eṣāṃ sabhyānāṃ cājñāne sati dūragā deśāntarasthāḥ /
analyzed: eṣām sabhyānām ca ajñāne sati dūra gāḥ deśa antara sthāḥ
translated: When there is ignorance among the members of the assembly, the distant ones, those in other countries,

analyzed: na ca evam sabhya saṃvaraṇam api anarthakam
translated: And thus the selection of the members of the assembly is not useless.

analyzed: tatas param prāyeṇa ajñāna śaṅkā anudayāt
translated: Because after that, doubt about ignorance generally does not arise.

analyzed: laukikaḥ ca ayam arthaḥ iti
translated: And this is a worldly matter.

analyzed: dūragān nirṇāyaka tva sambhavāya viśinaṣṭi pakṣa iti
translated: In order to make it possible for the distant ones to be the determiners, he distinguishes them with the word party etc.

analyzed: pakṣapāta vivarjitāḥ
translated: Free from partiality.

analyzed: eka deśa utkīrtanena yathoktam sabhya ādi lakṣaṇam atidiśati
translated: By mentioning one part, he indicates the characteristics of the members of the assembly and others as stated.

analyzed: a prakāśya sva siddhāntam iti vitaṇḍā lakṣaṇam uktam
translated: The definition of wrangling has been stated as not revealing one's own doctrine.

original: tatkathaṃ vādajalpābhyāṃ vyāvartakamityata āha ubhābhyāmiti // /🔽ubhābhyāṃ sādhanaṃ caiva dūṣaṇaṃ vādajalpayoḥ // / / //
analyzed: tat katham vāda jalpābhyām vyāvartakam iti atas āha ubhābhyām iti  ubhābhyām sādhanam ca eva dūṣaṇam vāda jalpayoḥ
translated: How does it differ from debate and disputation? To this he says by both (in the next verse).🔽In debate and disputation, the proof and refutation are by both.

analyzed: vāda jalpayoḥ ubhābhyām eva sva pakṣa sādhanam para pakṣa dūṣaṇam kartavyam
translated: In debate and disputation, the proof of one's own position and the refutation of the opponent's position should be done by both.

analyzed: na tu prativādinaḥ parapakṣa dūṣaṇa mātreṇa kṛtārtha tā iti
translated: But the opponent is not satisfied merely by the refutation of the opponent's position.

analyzed: satām eva iti sārdhaślokasya atra sanniveśe tu
translated: If the half-verse by the two who are honest is inserted here,

analyzed: lakṣitau vāda jalpau
translated: then debate and disputation are defined.

original: idānīṃ tu vitaṇḍāyā lakṣaṇadvayaṃ vivakṣustāvadupayuktamāha ubhābhyāmiti //
analyzed: idānīm tu vitaṇḍāyāḥ lakṣaṇa dvayam vivakṣuḥ tāvat upayuktam āha ubhābhyām iti
translated: Now, wishing to state the two definitions of wrangling, he first says by both (in the next verse).

analyzed: kathā vāda jalpa lakṣaṇā
translated: A discussion is characterized by debate and disputation.

analyzed: etena jalpaḥ rtha ādi vyapekṣayā iti uktasya vitaṇḍāyām ativyāptiḥ api parihṛtā
translated: By this, the over-extension of wrangling to a discussion that depends on the object, etc. is also avoided.

analyzed: ubhaya sādhanavat tvena sat eka ādhikārika tvena vā rtha ādi vyapekṣa kathāyāḥ viśeṣita tvāt
translated: Because it is distinguished by being a discussion that has both proofs and is governed by the honest, or by depending on the object, etc.

analyzed: yad artham satām eva iti uktam tat vitaṇḍā lakṣaṇam āha vitaṇḍā tu iti
translated: The definition of wrangling, for which by the two who are honest was stated, is stated as wrangling, however (in the next verse).

analyzed: kathā iti anuvartate
translated: Discussion is continued.

analyzed: ubhābhyām iti yad artham uktam tad lakṣaṇa antaram āha aprakāśya iti
translated: The characteristic of what is said by both is stated as not to be revealed etc.

analyzed: ukte taiḥ iti pūrvavat iti
translated: By them etc. is as before.

analyzed: ubhābhyām sādhanam ityādi uktam
translated: By both etc. has been stated.

analyzed: tatra sādhanāya kim pramāṇam prayoktavyam
translated: What means of knowledge should be employed for that?

original: yatra yadasti tatra tadeva kiṃ vaktavyam /
analyzed: yatra yat asti tatra tat eva kim vaktavyam
translated: Should only what exists there be stated?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: pramāṇa samplave tu katham
translated: But how in the case of a combination of means of knowledge?

analyzed: kim sarvam evā uta ekam eva tatra api kim iti apekṣāyām āha sadbhiḥ iti
translated: What should be employed there? Should all be employed or only one? To this question, he says by the good etc.

analyzed: sadbhiḥ āgamaḥ eva ekaḥ prayojyaḥ bhīṣya sādhakaḥ
translated: Only one authoritative statement should be employed by the good, which accomplishes the desired goal.

analyzed: ekaḥ eva na tu sambhavat sarvam ādhikya prasaṅgāt
translated: Only one, not all that is possible, because of the possibility of excess.

analyzed: sa ca āgamaḥ eva iti yojyam
translated: And that is an authoritative statement, this should be connected.

analyzed: yat vā eka śabdaḥ mukhya arthaḥ
translated: Or, the word one has its primary meaning.

original: īśvarādiprameye mukhyo vedādirāgama eva vaktavyaḥ tasya svātantryeṇa sādhyasiddhayaṅgatvāt
analyzed: īśvara ādi prameye mukhyaḥ veda ādiḥ āgamaḥ eva vaktavyaḥ tasya svātantryeṇa sādhya siddhayaṅga tvāt
translated: In the case of the object of knowledge such as God, only the authoritative statement such as the Veda should be stated, because that is the means of accomplishing what is to be done independently,

analyzed: na anumānam iti
translated: not inference.

analyzed: nanu avaidikasya veda ādi āgama upādāne syāt iti atas uktam sadbhiḥ iti
translated: If the non-Vedic is included in the authoritative statement such as the Veda, there would be a contradiction of one's own doctrine. To this, it is said by the good.

analyzed: kutas veda ādi prayoga niyamaḥ iti atas āha abhīṣya iti
translated: From where is the restriction on the employment of the Veda etc.? To this, he says which accomplishes the desired goal.

analyzed: yatas iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is:

analyzed: anumānam khalu na svātantryeṇa īśvara ādi sādhanasya iṣye
translated: Inference, indeed, is not accepted as independently establishing the existence of God and so on.

analyzed: sarvatra upādhi pratipakṣayoḥ sambhavāt
translated: Because in every case, a limiting adjunct and an opposing factor are possible.

analyzed: tad artham antatas pi āgamaḥ nusaraṇīyaḥ
translated: For that purpose, even in the end, scripture must be followed.

analyzed: tatas varam prathamam eva āgamaḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is better to state scripture first.

analyzed: tasya svātantryeṇa sādhya siddhayaṅga tvāt
translated: Because it is an independent means of establishing what is to be proven.

analyzed: nanu avaidikam prati katham
translated: But how is it for one who is not Vedic?

analyzed: āgamam prayujya tad prāmāṇyam sādhanīyam iti
translated: Having employed scripture, its validity must be established.

analyzed: nanu asadbhiḥ kim vaktavyam  na tāvat pratyakṣam
translated: But what is to be said by the non-existent?🔽Not perception first of all.

analyzed: atīndriye tad ayogāt
translated: Because it is not applicable to the supersensible.

analyzed: na ca āgamaḥ
translated: Nor scripture.

analyzed: sva para āgamayoḥ anyonyam prāmāṇya asammateḥ
translated: Because the validity of one's own and others' scriptures is not mutually accepted.

analyzed: na api anumānam
translated: Nor inference.

analyzed: prayoga parimāṇa asammateḥ
translated: Because of disagreement about the form of the argument.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus,

original: saugato yadi dvayavayavaprayogaṃ kuryāttadā naiyāyikena nyūnena nigṛhyeta /
analyzed: saugataḥ yadi dvaya avayava prayogam kuryāt tadā naiyāyikena nyūnena nigṛhyeta
translated: if the Buddhist makes a two-membered argument, then he would be refuted by the Naiyāyika with a shorter one.

analyzed: anigrahe vā prativādī paryanuyojyam upekṣeta
translated: Or, if there is no refutation, the opponent would ignore what is to be examined.

analyzed: pañca avayava prayoge tu adhikena nigṛhyeta
translated: But if he makes a five-membered argument, he would be refuted by the Naiyāyika with a longer one.

analyzed: tathā svīkāre ca apasiddhāntena
translated: And if he accepts that, then by the doctrine of the unwanted consequence.

original: tathāca niyatāvayavādivyatirekeṇa vitaṇḍaiva na syādityata āha svasiddhānteti //
analyzed: tathāca niyata avayava ādi vyatirekeṇa vitaṇḍā eva na syāt iti atas āha sva siddhānta iti
translated: And thus, except for the fixed number of parts etc., there would be no debate at all. To this he says 'in accordance with one's own established doctrine' etc.

analyzed: sva siddhānta anusāreṇa hi asadbhiḥ anumocyate
translated: For one is released by the bad [arguments] in accordance with one's own established doctrine.

analyzed: yathāsiddhāntam vaktavyam iti prāk niyamāt sva siddhānta nirṇīta prayoga avayava parimāṇa apekṣayā eva nyūna ādi avatārāt anyathākathā
translated: Because it has been previously determined that one should speak in accordance with one's own doctrine, the entry of the deficient etc. is only in relation to the number of parts of the argument determined by one's own established doctrine. Otherwise the story

analyzed: nupapatteḥ iti
translated: is not possible.

analyzed: hi śabda atharḥ
translated: The word 'hi' has this meaning.

analyzed: sadbhiḥ āgamaḥ vaktavyaḥ iti naḥ iti ayuktam
translated: It is not correct to say that the scripture should be stated by the good.

original: vaidikasya prativādinastaddūṣaṇe 'pasiddhāntāt /🔽adūṣaṇe tu parapakṣādūṣaṇena kathābhāvaprasaṅgādityata āha pratyakṣeti /
analyzed: vaidikasya prativādinaḥ tad dūṣaṇe  a dūṣaṇe tu para pakṣa a dūṣaṇena kathā bhāva prasaṅgāt iti atas āha pratyakṣa iti
translated: Because for the Vedic opponent, there would be a contradiction in refuting it.🔽But if it is not to be refuted, then there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of debate due to the non-refutation of the opponent's position. To this he says 'perception' etc.

analyzed: pratyakṣa āgama vairūpyam āśritya anya artha tā eva tu
translated: But the other meaning should be shown based on the discrepancy between perception and scripture.

analyzed: āgame doṣaḥ liṅga viloma tā
translated: The fault of the contradiction of the inferential mark should be shown in the scripture.

original: āgame tu vādinā prayukte prativādinā vaidikena tasyānyārthataiva daśarnīyā /
analyzed: āgame tu vādinā prayukte prativādinā vaidikena tasya anya artha tā eva
translated: But when the scripture is used by the proponent, the Vedic opponent should show that it has another meaning.

analyzed: na anumānasya iva aprāmāṇyam  yena apasiddhāntaḥ syāt
translated: Not that it is not a valid means of knowledge, like an inference.🔽By which there would be a contradiction in one's own doctrine.

analyzed: tatas eva kṛta para pakṣa dūṣaṇaḥ bhavet
translated: And from that alone, he would also have refuted the opponent's position.

analyzed: anya artha tām darśitavatā āgamasya para abhimata arthāt pracyāvita tvāt
translated: Because the scripture, which has shown the other meaning, has been rejected from the intended meaning accepted by others.

analyzed: na hi apekṣita artha asādhaka tavāt anyat pramāṇa dūṣaṇam asti iti
translated: For there is no fault of a means of valid knowledge other than not establishing the intended meaning.

analyzed: nanu evam sati katham kathā paryavasānam
translated: If that is so, then how is there an end to the discussion?

analyzed: sva sva abhimata artha agraha parityājana upāya abhāvāt iti atas uktam pratyakṣa ityādi
translated: Because there is no means of abandoning the grasping of one's own intended meaning, therefore it is said by perception and so on.

analyzed: atra para abhimate rthe pratyakṣa āgama virodham āśritya
translated: Here, relying on the contradiction of perception and scripture in the meaning accepted by others.

analyzed: na kevalam etāvat
translated: Not only this much.

analyzed: atra upakrama ādi liṅga viloma tā doṣaḥ darśanīyaḥ  atra anyatama ra
translated: Here, the fault of being contrary to the indications such as the introduction should also be shown.

analyzed: mātre tātparyam
translated: Here, the intention is towards just one of them.

analyzed: anyathā ādhikya prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the consequence of excess.

analyzed: nanu etāvatā api na kathā samāptiḥ
translated: Even with this much, the discussion is not concluded.

analyzed: para abhimata artha anupapatti mātreṇa sva abhimata artha asiddheḥ iti atas satyam iti āha liṅga iti
translated: Because the non-establishment of one's own intended meaning is merely due to the non-establishment of the meaning accepted by others, therefore it is said truly and so on.

analyzed: liṅga ānukūlyam sva arthasya śruti ādīnām anugrahaḥ
translated: The conformity with the indication is the favor of one's own meaning by the scriptures and so on.

analyzed: darśanīya padam anuvartate
translated: The word should be shown continues.

original: śrutyādīnāṃ vedādīnāṃ śrutirliṅgaṃ samākhyā cetyuktānāṃ liṅgagrahaṇenaiva gṛhītatvāt /
analyzed: śruti ādīnām veda ādīnām śrutiḥ liṅgam samākhyā ca iti uktānām liṅga grahaṇena eva gṛhīta tvāt
translated: Because the scriptures and so on, the Vedas and so on, which are mentioned as scripture, indication, and designation, are already included by the mention of indication alone.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an illustration.

original: parārthe pramāṇānukūlyasya svārthe tatprātikūlyasya ca nirāso darśanīya ityapi draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: para arthe pramāṇa ānukūlyasya sva arthe tad prātikūlyasya ca nirāsaḥ darśanīyaḥ iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen that the denial of the conformity of the means of knowledge in the case of the other's purpose and the non-conformity of that in one's own case should be shown.

analyzed: sva siddhānta prayoga parimāṇa anatikrameṇa parārtha anumāna vākya prayogaḥ kartavyaḥ
translated: The use of the statement of inference for the sake of another should be made without exceeding the measure of one's own established doctrine.

analyzed: tathātve ca na nyūna ādi avatāraḥ
translated: And in that case, there is no entry of deficiency, etc.

analyzed: tad atikramaḥ eva tad avakāśaḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the opportunity for that is only when it is exceeded.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha
translated: Another says:

analyzed: yathāvastu prayoktavyam
translated: It should be used according to the thing.

original: naca vastutattva eva vādināṃ vipratipatteravaśyaṃ nyūnādyavatārasambhavenāprayogaprāptiriti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca vastu tattve eva vādinām vipratipatteḥ avaśyam nyūna ādi avatāra sambhavena aprayoga prāptiḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that there is no possibility of use due to the necessary entry of deficiency, etc., because of the disagreement of the disputants on the truth of the thing.

original: tayasya yatra tāttvikatvābhimānastena tatprayogānantaraṃ pareṇa nyūnādāvudbhāvite tathārūpatāyāḥ sādhanīyatvātnāt /
analyzed: yatra tāttvika tva abhimānaḥ tena tad prayoga anantaram pareṇa nyūna ādau udbhāvite tathārūpa tāyāḥ
translated: Because for one who has the conceit of reality in a certain thing, after the use of that, when the other points out deficiency, etc., in that form, it has to be established, not so.

analyzed: na ca evam artha antara āpātaḥ
translated: And in this way, there is no intrusion of something else.

analyzed: hetoḥ anyatara asiddhay udbhāvane tad siddhi vyutpādana vat prakṛta upayoga sadbhāvāt iti
translated: Because there is the presence of usefulness in the present case, like the explanation of the establishment of that when the other points out the non-establishment of one or the other of the reason.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: dvi tri pañca avayava ādi pakṣāṇām sarveṣām api tāttvika tāyāḥ samarthita tvāt
translated: Because all the positions of two, three, five parts, etc. have been established as being real.

original: svasvaniyamasyaiva tātvikatvamupetya tadanatikrameṇaiva prayogāṅgīkāre tu sarvathā kathocchedāpatteḥ /🔽tattāttvikatāyāṃ prativādinā vipratipadyamānenāvaśyaṃ nyūnāderudbhāvanāt /
analyzed: sva sva niyamasya eva tātvika tvam upetya tad anatikrameṇa eva prayoga aṅgīkāre tu sarvathā kathā uccheda āpatteḥ  tad tāttvika tāyām prativādinā vipratipadyamānena avaśyam nyūna ādeḥ udbhāvanāt
translated: But if one accepts the reality of one's own rules and accepts the use of inference without transgressing them, then there would be a complete end to the discussion,🔽because when the opponent is disagreeing about the reality of that, he would necessarily have to point out the deficiency and so on.

analyzed: nanu uktam atra sva sva avayava kalpanā param prati samarthanīyā iti
translated: But it has been said here that one's own parts should be established for the opponent.

analyzed: duruktam tat
translated: That is badly said.

analyzed: tad samarthanasya aśakya tvāt iti āha tri pañca iti  tri pañca avayavām eva yugma avayavinīm api
translated: Because establishing that is impossible, he says three and five and so on.🔽Even if one necessarily states an inference with three or five parts, or with an even number of parts,

original: niyamād yo 'numāṃ brūyād taṃ brūyād yadi tādṛśī /
analyzed: niyamāt yaḥ nu mām brūyāt tam brūyāt yadi tādṛśī
translated: if one says that is not an inference when it is like that,

analyzed: na anumā iti tadā kena sādhya avayava kalpanā
translated: then how can the part of the conclusion be imagined?

analyzed: trayaḥ pratijñā hetu udāharaṇāni
translated: There are three parts: the thesis, reason, and example.

analyzed: udāharaṇa upanaya nigamanāni vā
translated: Or the example, application, and conclusion.

original: pañca pratijñāhetūdāhaṇopanayanigamanāni vāvayavā yasyāḥ sā tripañcāvayavā /
analyzed: pañca pratijñā hetu udāhaṇa upanaya nigamanāni vā avayavāḥ yasyāḥ sā tri pañca avayavā
translated: That which has three or five parts, or the thesis, reason, example, application, and conclusion, is called having three or five parts.

analyzed: eva śabdena pakṣa dvaya niyamam āha
translated: The word even indicates the rule for both sides.

analyzed: yugmau dvau udāharaṇa upanaya avayavau yasyāḥ sā yugmāvayavinī
translated: That which has two even parts, the example and application, is called having even parts.

analyzed: niyamāt iti sannihitena eva sambaddhayate
translated: The word 'necessarily' is connected only with what is proximate.

analyzed: anumā iti tādarthyāt prayogaḥ ucyate
translated: The word 'infer' is used in the sense of 'to argue'.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika ādīnām tatra eva vyavahārāt
translated: Because the Vaiśeṣikas and others use it in that sense.

analyzed: tam brūyāt yadi paraḥ niyata vādī iti śeṣaḥ
translated: One should say that if the opponent is one who does not accept the rule, this is the remainder.

original: yadvā yo mīmāṃsakastārkikādiśca tripañcāvayavāmevānumāṃ brūyāt /🔽taṃ prati yaḥ saugato niyamādyugmāvayavinīṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: yat vā yaḥ mīmāṃsakaḥ tārkika ādiḥ ca tri pañca avayavām eva anumām brūyāt  tam prati yaḥ saugataḥ niyamāt yugma avayavinīm brūyāt
translated: Or, one may connect it thus: One who is a Mīmāṃsaka or a logician, who would argue only with three or five members,🔽to him, if a Buddhist argues with two or five members necessarily,

original: sa yadi tādṛśī tryavayavā pañcāvayavā ca nānumeti brūyāditi yojyam /
analyzed: sa yadi tādṛśī tri avayavā pañca avayavā ca na anumā iti brūyāt iti yojyam
translated: if he says that such a three-membered or five-membered argument is not an inference, it should be connected thus.

analyzed: evam viparivartena api
translated: In the same way, it should be connected by reversing the order.

analyzed: tādṛśī na anumā iti asya pramāṇa abhāvāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: because there is no valid means of knowing that such an argument is not an inference.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

original: naiyāyikena saugataṃ prati pañcāvayavaprayoge vihite saugato 'dhikamiti nigṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: naiyāyikena saugatam prati pañca avayava prayoge vihite saugataḥ dhikam iti nigṛhṇīyāt
translated: When the Naiyāyika has stated the five-membered argument to the Buddhist, the Buddhist would censure it as redundant.

analyzed: tatas naiyāyikena pañca avayava prayogasya eva tāttvika tvāt na evam iti vaktavyam
translated: Then the Naiyāyika should say that the five-membered argument itself is true, not so.

analyzed: tatas saugataḥ na idam tattvam apramāṇika tvāt iti vadet eva
translated: Then the Buddhist would say that this is not true, because it is not based on a valid means of knowledge.

original: atha naiyāyikenāprāmāṇikatvamasiddhamiti vadatā kathamiti saugate pṛṣṭavati sati
analyzed: atha naiyāyikena aprāmāṇika tvam asiddham iti vadatā katham iti saugate pṛṣṭavati sati
translated: Then, when the Naiyāyika, saying that the lack of authoritativeness is not established, asks the Buddhist how it is,

analyzed: kena pramāṇena svīyā pañca avayava kalpanā sādhyā
translated: by what means of knowledge is one's own five-membered argument to be established?

analyzed: tad agocara tvāt
translated: Because it is not the object of that.

analyzed: nahi kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ kvāpi pratyakṣasya viṣayaḥ
translated: For the relation of cause and effect is nowhere the object of perception.

analyzed: na ca āgamena
translated: Nor by scripture.

analyzed: tad abhāvāt
translated: Because it does not exist.

original: pañcāvayavayuktasya vākyasya guṇadoṣavit' /🔽iti bhāratādivākyamastīti cennasaukṣmyaṃ saṅkhayākramaścaiva nirṇayaśca prayojanam' /
analyzed: pañca avayava yuktasya vākyasya guṇa doṣa vid  iti bhārata ādi vākyam asti iti ced na saukṣmyam saṅkhaya ākramaḥ ca eva nirṇayaḥ ca prayojanam
translated: One who knows the merits and faults of a statement consisting of five members,

analyzed: ityādinā tatra eva anyathā vyākhyāta tvāt
translated: if it is said that there is a statement by Bhārata and others, it is not so, because it is explained differently there itself by subtlety, number, sequence, and determination are the purpose, etc.

analyzed: na api upamāna abhāvābhyām
translated: Nor by analogy and non-existence.

analyzed: niyata viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because they have limited objects.

analyzed: na ca arthāpattyā
translated: Nor by presumption.

analyzed: tad abhāvāt
translated: Because it does not exist.

analyzed: anupāna anatirekāt ca iti
translated: And because it does not exceed the absence of a means.

analyzed: mā bhūt pratyakṣa ādinā avayava kalpanā siddhiḥ
translated: Let the establishment of the five-membered argument by perception, etc. not be.

analyzed: anumānena tu bhaviṣyati
translated: But it will be by inference.

analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā upeta liṅga pratīteḥ pañca avayava vākya śravaṇa anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyi tvāt iti ced
translated: Because the understanding of the reason endowed with pervasion and the property of the subject follows the concomitance and non-concomitance of hearing a statement consisting of five members, if it is said so.

original: na tāvadidamanumānaṃ tvaccetasi parivartamānaṃ paraṃ pratyāyanāṅgam /
analyzed: na tāvat idam anumānam tvad cetasi parivartamānam param pratyāyana aṅgam
translated: This inference, revolving in your mind, is not a means of conveying knowledge to another.

analyzed: kinnāma prayujyamānam
translated: But rather when employed.

analyzed: tatra kim vidhāsyate
translated: There, will its employment be prescribed as having five parts?

analyzed: atha dvayavayavaḥ
translated: Or as having two parts?

analyzed: na ubhau api iti āha niyata iti
translated: He says neither of these, because of the impossibility of fixed parts.

analyzed: note jump in vese numbering

analyzed: naḥ lacunaḥ in text
translated: No lacuna in text.

analyzed: niyata avayava asiddhau
translated: Because of the impossibility of fixed parts...

analyzed: niyata avayavasya pañca avayavasya dvayavayavasya ca
translated: Of the fixed parts, of five parts and of two parts.

analyzed: yathāsaṅkhayam saugata naiyāyikayoḥ bodha aupayika tva asiddhau  na anumānena api avayava kalpanā siddhiḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: As appropriate, the impossibility of being a means of knowledge for the Buddhist and the Naiyāyika.🔽The remainder is that the assumption of parts is not established even by inference.

analyzed: yat vā uttara vākye niyata avayava asiddhau iti anuvādaḥ yam
translated: Or, in the subsequent statement, this is a restatement of the impossibility of fixed parts.

analyzed: tatas niyata avayava asiddheḥ iti siddhayati
translated: Therefore, it is established that because of the impossibility of fixed parts.

analyzed: pañca avayava prayoge pareṇa ādhikya udbhāvanāt
translated: Because in the employment of five parts, the opponent raises the issue of excess.

analyzed: dvaya avayava prayoge nyatara nyūna tva apasiddhāntayoḥ udbhāvanāt iti arthaḥ
translated: In the employment of two parts, the issue of deficiency in one or the other and the contradiction of one's own doctrine is raised. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha vyāpti iti
translated: What then? Therefore, he says by the mere pervasion, the proof.

analyzed: vyāpti mātreṇa sādhanam
translated: By the mere pervasion, the proof.

analyzed: kartavyam eva tena syāt
translated: That should be done by him.

analyzed: yatas evam na upāya antaram tena kāraṇena
translated: For this reason, since there is no other means,

analyzed: tena naiyāyikena vyāpti mātreṇa tat tat kāryam ityādi vyāpti vacana mātreṇa eva
translated: by that Naiyāyika, if by mere pervasion, if something conforms to the absence of another, then that is the effect of that, etc., by the mere statement of pervasion.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a mere indication.

analyzed: liṅga uktau ityādi prāk vyutpādita prakāreṣu anyatamena iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: In the statement of the reason, etc., it should be seen that it is by one of the previously explained types.

analyzed: sādhanam pañca avayava niyamasya
translated: The means of establishing the necessity of five members.

analyzed: kartavyam syāt
translated: Should be done.

analyzed: saugatena api tat anusaraṇīyam
translated: Even by the Buddhist, that should be followed.

analyzed: itarathā tasya api prayoga anupapatti prasaṅgāt iti
translated: Otherwise, for him also, the use would be logically impossible, it follows.

analyzed: tatas pi kim iti atas āha tasmāt iti
translated: What then of that? Therefore, he says:

analyzed: tasmāt sā eva anumā matā
translated: Therefore, that alone is accepted as inference.

original: yasmātprayogeyattāsādhanaṃ vādiprativādibhyāmanyatareṇa vā svamataparityāgenānyamatābhyupagame kṛta evopapadyate nānyathā /
analyzed: yasmāt prayoga iyattā sādhanam vādi prativādibhyām anyatareṇa vā sva mata parityāgena anya mata abhyupagame kṛte evā upapadyate na anyathā
translated: Because the means of establishing the limit of the argument is logically possible only when the acceptance of another's opinion by abandoning one's own opinion is done by either the proponent or the opponent, not otherwise.

analyzed: tasmāt sā eva anumā matā
translated: Therefore, that alone is accepted as inference.

analyzed: vyāpti vacana ādikam eva para artha prayoga tvena sarvatra mantavyam
translated: The statement of pervasion, etc., should be understood everywhere as the use for the sake of others.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

analyzed: yadā naiyāyikaḥ dvaya avayavena pañca avayava niyamam sādhayati
translated: When a Naiyāyika proves the rule of five members by two members,

original: tadā dvayavayavasya tāttvikatvaṃ svayaṃ manyate na vā /
analyzed: tadā dvaya avayavasya tāttvika tvam svayam manyate na vā
translated: then does he himself consider the two members to be real or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe pratārakaḥ syāt
translated: If not, he would be a deceiver.

analyzed: ādye nyatra api katham tattatvam na syāt
translated: If the first, how could it not be real elsewhere too?

original: evaṃ kathābhāvaprasaṅgabhīruḥ saugato 'pi pañcāvayavena dvayavayavasyāvaśyakatāṃ pratipadyamānastattvaṃ manyate na vā /
analyzed: evam kathā bhāva prasaṅga bhīruḥ saugataḥ pi pañca avayavena dvayavayavasya āvaśyaka tām pratipadyamānaḥ tattvam manyate na vā
translated: In the same way, the Buddhist, fearing the consequence of the non-existence of debate, when accepting the necessity of the two members by the five members, considers it to be real or not.

analyzed: dvitīye katham tatas pratipadyeta
translated: In the second case, how could he understand it from that?

analyzed: ādye nyatra api kutas tat na tattvam
translated: In the first, how could it not be real elsewhere too?

analyzed: atas tra sarva siddhānta prakārāṇām tāttvika tva āt yuktam sva siddhānta anusāreṇa iti
translated: Therefore, since all the methods of the established conclusion are real here, it is proper according to one's own established conclusion.

original: asmādeva saṅkaṭādbibhyadudayano yathāvastu vaktavyamityuktvā yathāsiddhāntaṃ vā vaktavyamiti samayaṃ baddhvā pravṛttāyāṃ kathāyāṃ na nyūnādyavatāra
analyzed: asmāt eva saṅkaṭāt bibhyat udayanaḥ yathāvastu vaktavyam iti uktvā yathāsiddhāntam vā vaktavyam iti samayam baddhvā pravṛttāyām kathāyām na nyūna ādi avatāra
translated: Fearing this very difficulty, Udayana, having said that it should be stated according to the object, having made the rule that it should be stated according to the established conclusion, when the debate has begun, he does not allow the entry of deficiency etc.

analyzed: iti pakṣa antaram avādīt iti
translated: He has stated another position.

analyzed: avasitam anumānam
translated: Inference is finished.

analyzed: nirdoṣam vākyam āgamaḥ
translated: A faultless statement is scripture.

analyzed: sa dvividhaḥ
translated: It is of two kinds.

analyzed: pauruṣeyaḥ pauruṣeyaḥ ca
translated: [There are two kinds of statements:] those made by a person and those not made by a person.

analyzed: tatra apauruṣeyaḥ vedaḥ
translated: Among them, the Veda is not made by a person.

analyzed: anyaḥ tu pauruṣeyaḥ iti su prasiddha tvāt na uktam
translated: But the other [i.e., the statement of the opponent] is made by a person. This is well-known, so it is not stated.

analyzed: kecid vākyam vākya arthe numānam iti bruvate
translated: Some say that a statement is an inference regarding the meaning of the statement.

analyzed: tat anupapannam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: vākya vākya arthayoḥ deśataḥ kālataḥ vā anvaya vyatireka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no positive or negative concomitance between a statement and the meaning of the statement in terms of place or time.

analyzed: atha idam vākyam vākya atharvat vākya tvāt iti sādhyate
translated: If it is argued that this statement is like the meaning of the statement because it is a statement,

original: tatra kiṃ vākyārthamātraṃ sādhyate tadviśeṣo vā /
analyzed: tatra kim vākya artha mātram sādhyate tad viśeṣaḥ vā
translated: then is just the meaning of the statement to be proven, or a particular of that?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: viśeṣa pramiteḥ nirnibandhana tva āpatteḥ
translated: Because the ascertainment of a particular would be baseless.

original: dvitīye sa viśeṣaḥ pratīto na vā /
analyzed: dvitīye sa viśeṣaḥ pratītaḥ na vā
translated: In the second case, is that particular known or not?

analyzed: ādye vākya vaiyarthyam
translated: In the first case, the statement is useless.

analyzed: dvitīye prasiddha viśeṣaṇa tā
translated: In the second case, there is the fault of an unknown particular.

analyzed: viśeṣasya anyatra abhāvāt anaikāntyam ca
translated: And there is inconclusiveness because the particular is absent elsewhere.

analyzed: matupa arthaḥ ca kim pratipādya pratipādaka bhāvaḥ  sambandha antaram vā
translated: And what is the meaning of the suffix matup? Is it the relation of the expounder and the expounded,🔽or some other relation?

analyzed: ādye sākṣāt liṅga tayā vā
translated: In the first case, is it directly or by implication?

analyzed: na prathamaḥ  anumāna vaiyarthyāt
translated: Not the first.🔽Because inference would be useless.

analyzed: apasiddhāntāt ca
translated: And because of the fallacy of unestablished conclusion.

original: dvitīye tu nedaṃ vākyārthānumānaṃ kintu siddhe 'rthe vākyasya liṅgatānumānameva /
analyzed: dvitīye tu nā idam vākya artha anumānam kintu siddhe rthe vākyasya liṅga tā anumānam eva
translated: But in the second case, this is not an inference of the meaning of the sentence, but rather an inference of the sentence itself as the mark in regard to the established meaning.

analyzed: tatra ca dṛṣṭāntaḥ nyatara sādhya vikalaḥ
translated: And in that case, the example is defective in regard to one of the things to be established.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: tad abhāvena bādhāt
translated: Because it is contradicted by the absence of that.

analyzed: atha evam prayujyate
translated: Now, if this is used:

analyzed: vivāda adhyasitāni padāni sva smārita artha anvaya pramiti pūrvakāṇi ākāṅkṣā ādimat pada kadambaka tvāt iti
translated: The words that are the subject of dispute are preceded by the cognition of the relation of the remembered meanings, because they are a collection of words having expectancy etc.,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: vinā api anvaya pramitim daivāt prayukteṣu ākāṅkṣā ādimatsu padeṣu anaikāntyāt
translated: Because it is inconclusive in the case of words having expectancy etc. that are used by chance even without the cognition of the relation.

analyzed: āpta prayukta tvena hetu viśeṣaṇe sādhya arthasya hetvarthe praveśa āpatteḥ
translated: Because if the reason is qualified by being used by a trustworthy person, then the meaning of the conclusion is included in the meaning of the reason.

analyzed: puruṣa viśeṣa prayukta tvasya adhyāpaka prayukteṣu vyabhicārāt
translated: Because being used by a particular person is deviant in the case of those used by a teacher.

analyzed: mūla pramā anumāne pi vedeṣu anupapatteḥ
translated: And because it is not established in the Vedas even in the inference of the original valid cognition.

analyzed: tad apauruṣeya tvasya sādhita tvāt
translated: Because the non-human authorship of that has been established.

analyzed: apare tu apauruṣeyasya āgama tvam upagamya pauruṣeyasya anumāna tvam abhyupagacchanti
translated: But others, accepting that what is not human is scripture, accept that what is human is inference.

analyzed: teṣām tu sphuṭaḥ vede vyabhicāraḥ
translated: But their deviation in the Veda is clear.

analyzed: kiñca padānām anvita abhidhāne śaktiḥ
translated: Moreover, the power of words is to denote the related meaning.

analyzed: padāni eva ca vākyam
translated: And the sentence is nothing but the words themselves.

analyzed: na ca vaidika padebhyaḥ nyāni eva laukikāni padāni
translated: And the worldly words are not different from the Vedic words.

original: vaktā tu padajñāna evopayujyate /🔽tatkathaṃ lokavedayoḥ prakārabhedaḥ syāt /
analyzed: vaktā tu pada jñāne eva upayujyate  tat katham loka vedayoḥ prakāra bhedaḥ syāt
translated: But the speaker is useful only in the knowledge of the words.🔽So how can there be a difference in the form between the worldly and Vedic sentences?

original: api ca vedānusāreṇa paṭhyamāneṣu laukikavākyeṣu katham /
analyzed: api ca veda anusāreṇa paṭhyamāneṣu laukika vākyeṣu katham
translated: Moreover, when worldly sentences are recited in accordance with the Vedas,

analyzed: anvaya pratītiḥ utpadyate eva
translated: how is it that the understanding of the related meaning does not arise?

analyzed: kinnāma punar pauruṣeya tva jñānāt apanīyate iti
translated: What is it that is removed by the knowledge of being composed by a person?

analyzed: evam tarhi vākyāt eva vākya athar jñānam
translated: Thus then, the meaning of a sentence is known only from the sentence itself.

analyzed: tad prāmāṇya niścayāya tu vaktra ādi anusaraṇam iti āyātam iti āstām
translated: But for the ascertainment of its validity, the speaker etc. are to be resorted to. Let this suffice.

analyzed: tat evam sāmānyatas viśeṣataḥ ca pramāṇāni lakṣitāni
translated: Thus, the means of valid knowledge have been defined in general and in particular.

analyzed: tatra svīya sāmānya lakṣaṇa samarthanena arthādvādi antara ukta sāmānya lakṣaṇāni nirastāni eva
translated: There, by establishing its own general definition, the general definitions stated by other logicians are implicitly refuted.

analyzed: tathā api smṛti viṣaye
translated: Nevertheless, in the case of memory, the object to be stated

analyzed: śeṣasya vidyamāna tvāt prābhākara lakṣaṇam viśeṣataḥ nirākaroti anubhūtiḥ iti
translated: existing, he refutes the definition of Prabhākara in particular, with the words Anubhūti (experience).

analyzed: anubhūtiḥ pramāṇam ced kena smṛtiḥ apodyate
translated: If experience is the means of valid knowledge, by what is memory refuted?

original: tadā vaktavyaṃ smṛtiḥ pramā na vā /
analyzed: tadā vaktavyam smṛtiḥ pramā na vā
translated: Then it should be said whether memory is valid knowledge or not.

analyzed: ādye iti śeṣaḥ
translated: If the first, there is a contradiction of one's own doctrine.🔽This is the remainder.

analyzed: dvitīye tu āha kena iti
translated: If the second, he says by what.

original: yadi smṛtirna pramā tadā smṛtiḥ lakṣaṇena vyāvartanīyā /
analyzed: yadi smṛtiḥ na pramā tadā smṛtiḥ lakṣaṇena vyāvartanīyā
translated: If memory is not valid knowledge, then memory should be excluded by the definition.

original: anyathātivyāpteḥ /🔽tatkena tatkutaḥ smṛtirapodyate vyāvartyate /🔽smṛtirvyāvartakaṃ na kimapi /
analyzed: anyathā ativyāpteḥ  tat kena tat kutas smṛtiḥ apodyate vyāvartyate  smṛtiḥ vyāvartakam na kim api
translated: Otherwise, there would be over-extension.🔽By what is memory refuted, excluded?🔽There is nothing in the definition that excludes memory.

analyzed: lakṣaṇe sti iti yāvat  nanu anubhūtiḥ iti uktaḥ eva smṛtau aprasaṅgaḥ
translated: That is, memory is not excluded by the definition.🔽Isn't the occurrence of memory excluded by the very statement 'experience'?

analyzed: smṛti vyatiriktam jñānam anubhūtiḥ iti abhidhānāt
translated: Because it is said that experience is knowledge other than memory.

analyzed: nahi smṛtiḥ smṛti vyatiriktā bhavati iti
translated: For memory does not become other than memory.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: smṛteḥ api smṛti antara vyatirikta tva sambhavena a vyavacchedaka tvāt
translated: Because memory cannot exclude, since memory is also possible as other than another memory.

analyzed: smṛti tva anadhikaraṇam jñānam anubhūtiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is said that experience is knowledge that is not the locus of memory,

analyzed: kim idam smṛti tvam
translated: what is this memory?

analyzed: na tāvat jātiḥ
translated: First of all, it is not a universal.

analyzed: guṇeṣu jāteḥ an aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because a universal is not accepted among qualities.

analyzed: saṃskāra mātra janya jñāna tvam tu na sambhavati
translated: But being knowledge produced only from impressions is not possible.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa ādi janya tvāt
translated: Because it is produced from unseen things and so on.

analyzed: asādhāraṇa kāraṇa vivakṣāyām api tathā
translated: Even if the uncommon cause is meant, it is so.

analyzed: smṛteḥ mānasa tvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because memory is mental is going to be stated.

analyzed: etena niyamena pratyutpanna asādhāraṇa kāraṇaka pratyagra tvam anubhūti tvam iti api avacchedakam draṣṭavyam
translated: By this rule, the distinguishing feature should be seen as being the freshness produced by the present uncommon cause.

analyzed: smṛteḥ api mānasa pratyakṣa janyāyāḥ tathātvāt
translated: Because even memory produced by mental perception is so.

original: saṃskārasya kāraṇatve 'pi nāsau sattāmātreṇa smṛtiṃ janayati kinnāmodbuddha eva /
analyzed: saṃskārasya kāraṇa tve pi nā asau sattā mātreṇa smṛtim janayati kinnāma udbuddhaḥ eva
translated: Even though the impression is a cause, it does not produce memory merely by its existence, but only when awakened.

analyzed: tathā ca katham na pratyutpanna asādhāraṇa kāraṇa janya tvam  anyathā indriya ādi māyamā
translated: And how then is it not produced by the present uncommon cause?

analyzed: tram upādāya anubhūteḥ api tat nirākuryāt
translated: Otherwise, it would deny even the experience produced by the present senses etc.

analyzed: kiñca smṛtiḥ api kācid pratyutpanna saṃskāra janyā sambhavati eva
translated: Moreover, some memory is indeed produced by the present impression.

original: nacāvacchedakena vinā niyamo jñātuṃ śakyata iti / /
analyzed: na ca avacchedakena vinā niyamaḥ jñātum śakyate iti
translated: And without a distinguishing feature, the rule cannot be known.

original: yadvā anubhūtiḥ pramāṇaṃ cettadā smṛtāvavyāptiriti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā anubhūtiḥ pramāṇam ced tadā smṛtau avyāptiḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Or, if experience is a means of valid knowledge, then there is over-extension to memory - this is the remainder.

analyzed: nanu smṛtiḥ pramāṇam eva na bhavati
translated: But memory is not a means of valid knowledge at all.

analyzed: tat katham tatra avyāpti doṣaḥ iti atas āha kena iti
translated: Then how can there be the fault of over-extension in that? To this he says by what, etc.

original: smṛtiḥ kena nimittenāpodyate pramāṇādbahiḥ kriyate na kenāpītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: smṛtiḥ kena nimittena apodyate pramāṇāt bahis kriyate na kena api iti arthaḥ
translated: By what proof is memory set aside, is made to be outside of the means of valid knowledge? The meaning is: by none at all.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: kim ayathārtha tvāt
translated: Is it because it is not in accordance with reality?

analyzed: yāthārthye pi ananubhūti tvāt vā aprāmāṇye bādhaka abhāvāt vā prāmāṇye sādhaka abhāvāt bādhaka sadbhāvāt vā
translated: Or because it is not an experience even though it is in accordance with reality, or because there is no proof of its invalidity, or because there is no proof of its validity, or because there is a proof of its invalidity?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati kena iti
translated: He refutes the first by saying by what.

analyzed: smṛtiḥ kena prabalena pramāṇena apodyate bādhyate
translated: By what powerful means of valid knowledge is memory set aside, contradicted,

analyzed: yena yathārthā na syāt
translated: by which it would not be in accordance with reality?

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt na ayathārtha tvam vācyam iti
translated: It cannot be said to be not in accordance with reality because there is no proof of its invalidity.

analyzed: dvitīyam nirākaroti kena iti
translated: He refutes the second by saying by what.

analyzed: kim anubhūti tvam pramāṇa lakṣaṇam iti kṛtvā ananubhūti tvāt smṛtiḥ apramāṇam iti ucyate kim vā ghaṭa ādi dṛṣṭānta avaṣṭambhena
translated: Is it said that memory is not a means of valid knowledge because it is not an experience, taking the fact that it is not an experience to be the defining characteristic of a means of valid knowledge, or because of the example of a pot, etc.?
In the first case, there is mutual dependence.

analyzed: tathā ca kena smṛtiḥ apodyate
translated: And so, by what is memory set aside?

analyzed: dvitīye pi smṛtiḥ eva kena apodyate
translated: In the second case also, by what is memory itself set aside?

analyzed: asmṛti tvena anubhūtiḥ kutas nā apodyate viśeṣa abhāvāt iti
translated: If it is not an experience, why is an experience not set aside as well, because there is no difference?

analyzed: tṛtīyam apākaroti pūrvā iti
translated: He refutes the third by saying previously.

analyzed: pūrva anubhūte kim mānam iti ukte syāt kim uttaram
translated: What would be the answer if it were asked what is the means of valid knowledge of what was previously experienced?

original: yadi smṛtirapramāṇaṃ syāttadā pūrvānubhūte kiṃ mānamiti praśno niruttaraḥ syāt /🔽smṛtivyatiriktasya
analyzed: yadi smṛtiḥ apramāṇam syāt tadā pūrva anubhūte kim mānam iti praśnaḥ niruttaraḥ syāt  smṛti vyatiriktasya
translated: If memory were not a means of valid knowledge, then the question What is the means of valid knowledge regarding what was experienced before? would be unanswerable.

analyzed: tad pramāṇasya abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no means of valid knowledge other than memory.

analyzed: tathā ca sākṣi ādi lokavyavahāraḥ lupyeta
translated: And thus the worldly usage of witnesses and others would be destroyed.

analyzed: smṛtiḥ eva pramāṇam kintu liṅgatayā iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that memory itself is the means of valid knowledge, but only as an inferential mark, that is not so.

analyzed: tathā anubhava abhāvāt  anyathā sākṣātkāreṇa kāryeṇa karma kāraka tayā
translated: Because there is no such experience.

analyzed: numānam iti api syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would be argued that a pot, etc. are inferred by the effect in the form of direct perception.

analyzed: caturtham pratyāha pūrvā iti
translated: In response to the fourth objection, he says before (in the verse).

analyzed: smṛtiḥ iti eva hi vaktavyam
translated: For it should be said simply memory.

analyzed: vacanāt ca anubhavaḥ numīyate iti lokavyavahāraḥ eva atra pramāṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: And from the statement, experience is inferred. Thus, worldly usage is the means of valid knowledge here. This is the meaning.

original: nanu yadi smṛtiḥ pramā syāttadā tatkāraṇasya saṃskārasyānupramāṇatvaṃ prasajyeta /
analyzed: nanu yadi smṛtiḥ pramā syāt tadā tad kāraṇasya saṃskārasya anupramāṇa tvam prasajyeta
translated: If memory were a valid cognition, then the impression, which is its cause, would be an additional means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: tathā ca anupramāṇa tri tvam bhajyeta
translated: And thus, the number of additional means of valid knowledge would be reduced to three.

analyzed: na hi saṃskāraḥ pratyakṣa ādiṣu antarbhavati
translated: For an impression is not included among perception and the others.

analyzed: an indriya sannikarṣa tvāt ajñāta karaṇa tvāt ca iti pañcamam apākaroti mānasam iti
translated: Because it is not a contact of the senses, and because it is not a known instrument. In response to the fifth objection, he says mental (in the verse).

analyzed: mānasam tat hi vijñānam
translated: For that is a cognition.

original: hi yasmāttatsmaraṇaṃ mānasaṃ manaḥpratyakṣajaṃ na saṃskārakaraṇakaṃ tato noktadoṣa iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: hi yasmāt tat smaraṇam mānasam manaḥ pratyakṣa jam na saṃskāra karaṇakam tatas na ukta doṣaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Because that remembrance is mental, born from mental perception, not caused by impressions, therefore there is no fault stated, the rest.

analyzed: a sākṣātkāra rūpa tvāt na pratyakṣa phala tvam iti atas uktam vijñānam iti
translated: It is not the fruit of perception because it is not of the nature of direct knowledge. Therefore it is said: knowledge.

analyzed: sākṣātkāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is direct knowledge.

original: smaraṇasya mānasatvaṃ sākṣātkāratvaṃ ca kuta ityata āha tacceti //🔽tacca sākṣipramāṇakam // / / //
analyzed: smaraṇasya mānasa tvam sākṣātkāra tvam ca kutas iti atas āha tat ca iti  tat ca sākṣi pramāṇakam
translated: How is remembrance mental and direct knowledge? Therefore it is said: that and so on.🔽And that is known by the means of valid knowledge called the witness.

analyzed: tat iti mānasa tvam
translated: The word that refers to being mental.

analyzed: caśabdāt sākṣātkāra tvam ca
translated: By the word and is meant being direct knowledge.

analyzed: yat vā dvayam api tad śabdena parāmṛśyate
translated: Or both are referred to by the word that.

analyzed: prakṛta anusandhāna arthaḥ caśabdaḥ
translated: The word and is for connecting with the subject matter.

original: nanvindriyāṇāṃ prāpyakāritvaniyamādatītena ca manasaḥ prāpterayogātkathaṃ smṛtermānasapratyakṣajatvamityata āha atīteti //
analyzed: nanu indriyāṇām prāpyakāri tva niyamāt atītena ca manasaḥ prāpteḥ ayogāt katham smṛteḥ mānasa pratyakṣa ja tvam iti atas āha atīta iti
translated: But since the senses are restricted to operate only on the present, and since the mind cannot apprehend the past, how can memory be born from mental perception? To this he says: the past and so on.

analyzed: atīta anāgatam yadvat yogibhiḥ dṛśyate ñjasā
translated: Just as the past and future are directly perceived by yogis,

analyzed: evam pūrva anubhūtam ca manasā eva avagamyate
translated: in the same way the previously experienced is understood by the mind alone.

analyzed: santi tāvat yoginaḥ ṇima ādi siddhi sampannāḥ atīta anāgata darśinaḥ śruti smṛti itihāsa purāṇa prasiddhāḥ
translated: There are certainly yogins endowed with the powers of aṇimā, etc., who perceive the past and future, as is well known from the Vedas, Smṛtis, Itihāsas, and Purāṇas.

analyzed: śruti ādeḥ siddhārthe prāmāṇyasya sādhita tvāt
translated: Because the authoritativeness of the Vedas, etc. with regard to established matters has been proved.

analyzed: karma vidhi samāna yogakṣema tvāt ca yoga vidhīnām
translated: And because the injunctions of yoga are of the same nature as the injunctions of ritual.

analyzed: na ca tat jñānam asākṣātkāraḥ
translated: And the knowledge of that is not non-perception.

analyzed: śruti ādinā sākṣātkāra tva pratīteḥ
translated: Because the Vedas, etc. convey the idea of perception.

original: tathāhi śrutiḥapaśyamapyaye māyayā viśvakarmaṇyado jagannihitaṃ śubhracakṣuḥ' / iti /
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ apaśyam apyaye māyayā viśvakarmaṇi adaḥ jagat nihitam śubhra cakṣuḥ iti
translated: For instance, the Vedas declare: I saw with my divine eye the universe hidden in the dissolution by the illusion of Viśvakarman, O Śubha-eyed one.

original: purāṇaṃ canārāyaṇaprasādena' / ityādi /🔽itihāso 'pidivyaṃ dadāmi te cakṣuḥ' / ityādi /
analyzed: purāṇam ca nārāyaṇa prasādena ityādi  dadāmi te cakṣuḥ ityādi
translated: And the Purāṇa says: By the grace of Nārāyaṇa, etc.🔽And the Itihāsa also says: I give you the divine eye, etc.

analyzed: tat idam uktam añjasā iti
translated: This is what is meant by the words to the eye.

analyzed: sākṣāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is directly.

original: evañca yathā yogināmindriyeṇaivātītānāgatātharsākṣātkārastathātītamapi manasā smaryata iti ko doṣaḥ /
analyzed: evam ca yathā yoginām indriyeṇa eva atīta anāgata athar sākṣātkāraḥ tathā atītam api manasā smaryate iti kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: And thus, just as yogins perceive the past and future objects directly by the sense organs, similarly, the past is also remembered by the mind. What is the fault in that?

original: nanvindriyasyārthaprāptirnāma na saṃyogaḥ samavāyo veti niyamaḥ /
analyzed: nanu indriyasya artha prāptiḥ nāma na saṃyogaḥ samavāyaḥ vā iti niyamaḥ
translated: But it is not the case that the sense organ's contact with the object is either conjunction or inherence.

analyzed: kintu pratyāsatti mātram
translated: Rather, it is mere proximity.

analyzed: asti ca tad yogi indriyāṇām
translated: And that exists for the sense organs of the yogin.

analyzed: tad tad upadarśaka yoga ja dharma sahakṛta tva lakṣaṇam iti ced
translated: If it be said that it is the fact of being accompanied by the dharma born of yoga which reveals each of these,

original: evaṃ tarhi manaso 'pi pūrvānubhavajanitasaṃskārasācivyalakṣaṇāstyatītārthena pratyāsattirityāśayavatoktam pūrvānubhūtaṃ ceti // /
analyzed: evam tarhi pūrva anubhava janita saṃskāra sācivya lakṣaṇā asti atīta arthena pratyāsattiḥ iti āśayavatā uktam pūrva anubhūtam ca iti
translated: then, in that case, the mind also has proximity to the past object in the form of the aid in the shape of the impressions born of the previous experience. With this intention it is said: “And what is experienced before” (is remembered).

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati /🔽yadi prāptiḥ saṃyogādilakṣaṇā vivakṣitā tadā tadabhāvo 'naikāntikaḥ /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  yadi prāptiḥ saṃyoga ādi lakṣaṇā vivakṣitā tadā tad abhāvaḥ na aikāntikaḥ
translated: This is what is meant.🔽If the proximity in the form of conjunction etc. is intended, then its absence is inconclusive.

analyzed: pratyāsatti mātra vivakṣāyām tu asiddhiḥ iti
translated: But if mere proximity is intended, then it is not established.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta kathanam tu pratyāsatti mātrasya sākṣātkāra hetutām sambhāvayitum
translated: The statement of the example is to suggest the possibility of mere proximity being the cause of the direct perception.

original: kāryadarśanavaśācceyaṃ kalpanāsau nātiprasaṅga iti darśayituṃ ca /🔽etena mānasaṃ cetsmaraṇaṃ syānna saṃskārajaṃ tadānanubhūte 'pyuvyu
analyzed: kārya darśana vaśāt ca iyam kalpanā asau na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti darśayitum ca  etena mānasam ced smaraṇam syāt na saṃskāra jam tadā ananubhūte
translated: And to show that this assumption is based on the observation of the effect, and that there is no over-extension.

analyzed: tpadyeta iti parāstam
translated: By this, the objection that if memory were mental, it would not be born of impressions, then it would arise even with regard to what is not experienced, is refuted.

analyzed: saṃskārasya sannikarṣa sthānīya tayā aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because the impression is accepted as being like a proximity.

analyzed: yat smṛteḥ mānasa tvam sākṣi siddham iti uktam tat abhinayena darśayati vijñātam iti
translated: What was said that the mental nature of memory is established by the witness, that is shown in detail by saying “What is known” etc.

analyzed: vijñātam manasā pūrvam mayā etat kṛtam iti api
translated: This has been known by me before, and this has been done by me.

analyzed: sākṣāt anubhavāt siddham
translated: This is established by direct experience.

original: etanmayā pūrvaṃ kṛtamityetanmayā manasā vijñātaṃ smṛtamapīti smaraṇasya mānasatvaṃ sākṣādanubhavātsākṣyanubhavena siddhamiti /
analyzed: etat mayā pūrvam kṛtam iti etat mayā manasā vijñātam smṛtam api iti smaraṇasya mānasa tvam sākṣāt anubhavāt sākṣi anubhavena siddham iti
translated: This has been known by me before, and this has been done by me, this has been remembered by me mentally. Thus, the mental nature of memory is established by direct experience, by the experience of the witness.

original: yaduktaṃ paraiḥ pūrvānubhavāvacchinnārthagocarā smṛtistadyāthārthyādikamanuvidadhānā na svayaṃ yathārtheti /
analyzed: yat uktam paraiḥ pūrva anubhava avacchinna artha gocarā smṛtiḥ tad yāthārthya ādikam anuvidadhānā na svayam yathārthā iti
translated: What has been said by others - memory has as its object the thing delimited by previous experience, and it conforms to that as being true, etc., but itself is not true -

analyzed: tat asat
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: anubhava vat śuddhārtha viṣaya tvasya api sākṣi siddha tvāt iti darśayitum mayā etat kṛtam iti api iti uktam
translated: Because the fact that it has as its object a pure thing like the experience is also established by the witness. To show this, this has been done by me is said.

original: nanu manaso 'pratyakṣatvātkathaṃ smaraṇasya mānasatā sākṣipratyakṣagamyeti cenna /
analyzed: nanu manasaḥ pratyakṣa tvāt katham smaraṇasya mānasa tā sākṣi pratyakṣa gamyā iti ced na
translated: If it is asked how, since the mind is not directly perceived, the mental nature of memory is to be known by the direct perception of the witness, it is not so.

analyzed: tasya sākṣi vedya tāyāḥ vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because its knowability by the witness will be stated.

original: tathāpi kāryakāraṇabhāvo na pratyakṣa iti cedanvayavyatirekasacivasya sākṣiṇastatra prāmāṇyābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: tathā api kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ na pratyakṣaḥ iti ced anvaya vyatireka sacivasya sākṣiṇaḥ tatra prāmāṇya abhyupagamāt
translated: If it is said that even so, the relation of cause and effect is not directly perceived, it is accepted that the witness, aided by positive and negative concomitance, is authoritative in that matter.

analyzed: jñānam nitya anumeyam iti ced na
