translated: If it is said that knowledge is always to be inferred, it is not so.

analyzed: jñāta tāyāḥ nirākariṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because the existence of the known object is going to be refuted.

analyzed: sva prakāśam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is self-luminous, no (says the siddhāntin);

analyzed: anātva tvāt ghaṭa vat
translated: because it is not eternal, like a jar.

analyzed: mānasa vedya tā tu nirasiṣyate iti āśayavān āha katham evā iti
translated: But the cognition of the mental state is going to be refuted. With this intention he says: How can it be refuted?

analyzed: katham eva hi apodyate
translated: How can it be refuted?

analyzed: yāthārthyam eva ityādinā uktasya prakṛta upayogam āha evam iti
translated: The author of the commentary says that the purpose of what was said beginning with being in accordance with reality is this.

analyzed: evam lakṣaṇake māna traye brahma ādi vastuṣu
translated: Thus, in the three means of valid knowledge characterized in this way, with regard to Brahman and other things,

analyzed: pramāṇam vedaḥ eva ekaḥ
translated: the Veda alone is the means of valid knowledge.

original: yasmānmānatrayamevaṃlakṣaṇakaṃ tasmādbrahmādivastuṣu veda eva pramāṇaṃ na yuktyādestatrāvakāśaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt māna trayam evaṃlakṣaṇakam tasmāt brahma ādi vastuṣu vedaḥ eva pramāṇam na yukti ādeḥ tatra avakāśaḥ
translated: Since the three means of valid knowledge are characterized in this way, therefore, with regard to Brahman and other things, the Veda alone is the means of valid knowledge, and reasoning etc. have no scope there.

analyzed: indriyam hi rūpa ādimati eva dravye pravatarte
translated: For the sense organ operates only with regard to a substance possessing form etc.

analyzed: na ca brahma ādikam tathā
translated: And Brahman etc. are not like that.

analyzed: anumānam ca vyāpti sāpekṣam
translated: And inference depends on the relation of universal concomitance.

analyzed: na ca veda nirapekṣasya tasya brahma ādau sañcāraḥ sti
translated: And there is no operation of it, independent of the Veda, with regard to Brahman etc.

analyzed: upādhi pratipakṣayoḥ tu sarvatra sambhavena vyāpti aniścayāt
translated: But in the case of the counter-correlate and the limiting adjunct, the relation of universal concomitance is not ascertained, because they are possible everywhere.

analyzed: veda anusaraṇe tu sādhya avyāpaka tva bādhita viṣaya tvayoḥ āvaśyaka tvāt
translated: But if it follows the Veda, then the subject-matter is necessarily either not included in the conclusion or is contradicted.

analyzed: pauruṣeya āgamaḥ tu paratantraḥ eva iti
translated: But the human scripture is dependent on another.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha tad prāmāṇyam ca iti
translated: What then? To this he says: And the validity of that has been established.

analyzed: tad prāmāṇyam ca sādhitam
translated: And the validity of that has been established.

original: yatasmādvedaviṣaye na yukteravakāśastato virodho 'pi sa evokta ityupapannam /
analyzed: yatasmāt veda viṣaye na yukteḥ avakāśaḥ tatas saḥ eva uktaḥ iti upapannam
translated: Since there is no scope for reasoning in the case of the Veda, therefore the contradiction also has been stated to be the same. This is reasonable.

analyzed: tathā ca vedasya pramāṇa virodha abhāvāt tad prāmāṇyam ca sādhitam
translated: And thus, because there is no contradiction of valid cognition in the case of the Veda, the validity of that has been established.

analyzed: yat uktam prāk tasmāt veda prāmāṇyam iṣyate
translated: What was said earlier - The validity of the Veda is accepted -

analyzed: iti tat siddham iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that that is established.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām na vilakṣaṇa tva adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Adhikarana on the non-difference of the Veda in the glorious Nyaya Sudha.
III. The Adhikarana on the Over-esteeming of the Vedas.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām caturthaḥ bhāgaḥ abhimāni adhikaraṇam
translated: Now begins the fourth part of the glorious Nyaya Sudha, the Adhikarana on the Over-esteeming of the Vedas.

analyzed: om abhimāni vyapadeśaḥ tu viśeṣa anugatibhyām om
translated: Om. But the declaration of the over-esteeming is due to the conformity of the particulars.

analyzed: yukti antara virodham vedasya parihartum idam ārabhyate
translated: This is begun to remove the contradiction of the Veda with another reason.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: yukti virodhāḥ kim pratyekam pariharaṇīyāḥ  uta upalakṣaṇayā
translated: Should the contradictions with reason be removed individually?🔽Or by synecdoche?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ  nirasanīya yukti ābhāsa ānantyena śāstra aparyavasāna prasaṅgāt
translated: Not the first.🔽Because of the infinite number of refutable fallacious reasons, there is the contingence of the impossibility of the treatise.

analyzed: sūtra tva vyāghātāt ca
translated: And because of the contradiction with the sutra nature.

analyzed: dvitīye tu anārambhe eva asya adhikaraṇasya
translated: In the second, this section is not even begun.

analyzed: nirantara atīta adhikaraṇena eva upalakṣaṇayā sakala yukti virodhānām parihṛta tvāt iti
translated: Because all contradictions with reasoning are removed by the immediately preceding section itself, through indication.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: abhyadhika śaṅkā sadbhāvena tad upapatteḥ iti āśayavān pūrvapakṣam tāvat āha tathā api iti
translated: With the idea that it is appropriate because of the presence of an additional doubt, he first presents the prima facie view, saying Thus also...

analyzed: abhimāni vyapadeśaḥ tu viśeṣa anugatibhyām
translated: But the designation of the Veda as a personal author is due to the particularity and conformity.

analyzed: tathā api mṛd jala ādīnām buddhi vāc ādi vācakaḥ
translated: Even so, the designation of clay, water, etc. as cognition, speech, etc.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa vyāpti viruddha tvāt tatra mānam katham bhavet
translated: How can it be authoritative there, being contrary to what has a well-known pervasion?

analyzed: yadi api phala vyabhicāra ādi virodhaḥ vedasya parihṛtaḥ tathā api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even though the contradiction of the Veda due to the deviation of the result, etc. has been removed.

analyzed: mṛd jala ādīnām iti ādi padena tejaḥ prabhṛtīnām grahaṇam
translated: By the word etc. in clay, water, etc. fire and so on are included.

analyzed: buddhiḥ jñānam
translated: Cognition is knowledge.

analyzed: vāc vaktṛ tvac
translated: Speech is the state of being a speaker.

analyzed: ādi grahaṇena śrotṛ tva ādikam
translated: By the word etc. listening and so on are included.

analyzed: vedaḥ iti anuvartate
translated: Veda is continued.

original: dṛṣṭā pramitā vyāptiryasyā yukteḥ sā tathoktā /
analyzed: dṛṣṭā pramitā vyāptiḥ yasyāḥ yukteḥ sā tathā uktā
translated: That reasoning which has a well-known pervasion is called that way.

analyzed: vyāpti grahaṇam pakṣa dharma tāyāḥ api upalakṣaṇam
translated: The mention of pervasion is a specification of the property of the subject.

analyzed: kvacid tad niyama anabhyupagamāt sva śabdena asaṅkīrtanam
translated: In some cases, because the restriction is not accepted, it is not mentioned by its own word.

analyzed: tayā viruddha tvāt
translated: Because it is contradicted by that.

analyzed: tatra mṛd jala ādīnām buddhi vāc ādau
translated: There, the cognition, speech, etc. of clay, water, etc.

analyzed: katham iti ākṣepe
translated: How? In the form of a question.

analyzed: pratipādya antaram tu na asti apratīteḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: But there is no other subject matter, because it is not understood, is the remainder.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  mṛdabravīt
translated: This is what is said.🔽Clay spoke.

analyzed: āpaḥ bruvan  tat tejaḥ aikṣata
translated: The waters spoke.🔽That fire contemplated.

analyzed: tāḥ āpaḥ aikṣanta  ṛṇota grāvāṇaḥ
translated: Those waters contemplated.🔽The pressing stones are born.

analyzed: viduṣaḥ nu prāṇāḥ  aham śreyasi vyūdire
translated: The breaths follow the wise.🔽I am engaged in what is better.

analyzed: āpaḥ vai akāmayanta  iti ādi vedaḥ tāvat na pramāṇam
translated: The waters indeed desired.🔽Such Vedic statements are not valid.

analyzed: yukti viruddha artha abhidhāyi tvāt
translated: Because they express meanings that are contrary to reason.

analyzed: nīlam nabhaḥ itivat  mṛd jala ādīnām buddhi vāc ādimat tvam khalu asya arthaḥ
translated: Like The sky is blue.🔽Its meaning is that clay, water, etc. have cognition, speech, etc.

analyzed: sa ca vimatā mṛd na vaktrī mṛd tvāt sampratipanna mṛd vat ityādi yukti viruddhaḥ
translated: And that is contrary to reason, like The clay under dispute is not a speaker because of being clay, like clay generally accepted.

analyzed: tathā ca veda vākya antare pi aprāmāṇyam anumāsyate  nanu na vilakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: And thus, in another Vedic statement also, invalidity will be inferred.

analyzed: iti anena eva nyāyena ayam api virodhaḥ pariharaṇīyaḥ
translated: But this contradiction should be avoided by the very same reasoning as because of being different.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.
Because it is not the subject of other reasonings.

analyzed: tatra hi yathā ukta anuṣṭhāne pi phala vyabhicāraḥ ced hetuḥ tat āpātataḥ tāvat sandigdha viśeṣaṇa asiddhiḥ
translated: For, if the reason is the non-occurrence of the result even when the prescribed action is performed as stated, then at first there is doubt about the qualification being unestablished.

analyzed: kartṛ ādi vaiguṇyasya api sambhavāt
translated: Because the fault of the agent and so on is also possible.

original: nityatvena vedaprāmāṇyasya sthitau tu viśeṣaṇāsiddhiniścaya eva /
analyzed: nitya tvena veda prāmāṇyasya sthitau tu viśeṣaṇa asiddhi niścayaḥ eva
translated: But when the authoritativeness of the Veda is established by its eternality, there is certainty that the qualification is unestablished.

original: phalavyabhicāramātrasya hetutve tu anaikāntikatvamityevaṃ vyāptipakṣadharmatāvirahavyutpādanena yuktivirodhaḥ parihṛtaḥ /
analyzed: phala vyabhicāra mātrasya hetu tve tu anaikāntika tvam iti evam vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā viraha vyutpādanena yukti virodhaḥ parihṛtaḥ
translated: But if the mere non-occurrence of the result is the reason, then it is inconclusive. Thus, by explaining the absence of pervasion and the property of the subject, the contradiction with reasoning is avoided.

analyzed: na ca asyāḥ yukteḥ vyāpti ādi aṅga vaikalyam sambaddham
translated: And this reasoning is not connected with the deficiency of the components such as pervasion and so on.

analyzed: prasiddha mṛd ādau tathā upalambhāt
translated: Because it is observed to be so in well-known clay and so on.

analyzed: na ca tatra api buddhayādi sadbhāvaḥ
translated: And there is no existence of intellect and so on there.

analyzed: kadāpi
translated: Because the effect of that is never seen.

analyzed: na api sambaddham api vyabhicīrṇam
translated: Nor is it contradicted even though connected.

analyzed: vyabhicāra anupalambhāt
translated: Because the contradiction is not observed.

analyzed: na ca anupalambha māna vyabhicāram api sa upādhikam
translated: And even though the contradiction is not observed, it is not qualified by a limiting condition.

analyzed: upādheḥ anirūpaṇāt
translated: Because the limiting condition is not determined.

analyzed: buddhayādimattve ca mṛd ādīnām śarīra indriyavat tā api syāt
translated: And if clay and so on have intellect and so on, they would also have a body and sense organs.

analyzed: akaraṇaka kriyā darśanāt
translated: Because action without an instrument is seen.

analyzed: na ca tat yuktam indriya ādīnām api vaktṛ tva ādi vat adarśanāt
translated: And that is not proper, because of the non-perception of the speaker-ness etc. of the sense-organs etc.

original: tato 'nukūlatarkasanāthenopādhivyabhicārānupalambhasahakṛtena sahabhāgagrāhakeṇa pramāṇena siddhā mṛttvādīnāmavaktṛtvādinā vyāptiḥ /🔽naca mṛdādiṣu mṛdāditvaṃmṛttvādikaṃ
analyzed: tatas nukūla tarka sanāthena upādhi vyabhicāra anupalambha sahakṛtena saha bhāga grāhakeṇa pramāṇena siddhā mṛd tva ādīnām avaktṛ tva ādinā vyāptiḥ  na ca mṛd ādiṣu mṛd ādi tvam mṛd tva ādikam
translated: Therefore, the pervasion of earth-ness etc. by non-speaker-ness etc. is established by the valid cognition that grasps the common property, assisted by the non-perception of the counter-pervasion, supported by the favorable reasoning.

analyzed: na asti iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to say that earth-ness etc. do not exist in earth etc.

analyzed: vyāghātāt
translated: Because of contradiction.

analyzed: mṛd abravīt ityādi prayogāt ca
translated: And because of the usage earth spoke etc.

analyzed: tatas pakṣa dharmatā api siddhā evā iti
translated: Therefore, the property of being the subject is also established.

original: nanu ca nityatayā vedasya prāmāṇye vyavasthite tadviruddhāyā yukterevāprāmāṇyamucitamiti /
analyzed: nanu ca nitya tayā vedasya prāmāṇye vyavasthite tad viruddhāyāḥ yukteḥ eva aprāmāṇyam ucitam iti
translated: But when the authoritativeness of the Veda is established by its eternality, it is proper that reasoning, which is contrary to it, should be unauthoritative.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

original: vyāptipakṣadharmatopetāyā yukterapi niravakāśatvāt /🔽tataśca satpratipakṣatayā niścāyakatvābhāvenāprāmāṇyaṃ vedasya /
analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā upetāyāḥ yukteḥ api niravakāśa tvāt  tatas ca sat pratipakṣa tayā niścāyaka tva abhāvena aprāmāṇyam vedasya
translated: Because even reasoning, which is endowed with pervasion and the property of being the subject, is not conclusive.🔽And therefore, because of having a counter-argument, there is lack of certainty, and the Veda is unauthoritative.

analyzed: nanu prasiddha mṛd ādi pakṣīkāre siddha sādhana tā
translated: But if one accepts as the subject the well-known earth etc., there is the fault of proving what is already established.

analyzed: pakṣa sapakṣa bheda abhāvaḥ ca
translated: And there is no difference between the subject and the similar instance.
If another similar instance is accepted, then earth-ness etc. do not exist there.

analyzed: jaḍa tvasya hetu ukaraṇe tu asiddhiḥ syāt
translated: But if inertness is made the reason, there would be non-establishment.

analyzed: tasmāt ādi kālīnam mṛd ādikam pakṣayitavyam
translated: Therefore, the clay etc. from the beginning of time should be considered.

analyzed: na ca tat pratyakṣa ādi siddham iti vedaḥ eva upajīvyaḥ
translated: And that is not established by perception etc., therefore the Veda alone is to be relied upon.

analyzed: tathā ca dharmi grāhaka pramāṇa virodhāt aprāmāṇyam yukteḥ iti ced na
translated: And thus, because of contradiction with the means of knowing the subject, it is proper that reasoning is not authoritative. But that is not so.

analyzed: vyāpti ādimatyāḥ tad asambhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible for that which has pervasion etc.

analyzed: ādi kālīna mṛd ādi sva rūpa para vākya antareṇa paridṛśyamāna kārya liṅgena dharmi graha upapatteḥ
translated: Because the apprehension of the subject is possible by the statement of another person about the nature of clay etc. from the beginning of time, and by the inference of the effect that is being seen.

original: etena vaidike 'rthe yukteravakāśābhāvānna tadvirodhakatvamityapāstam /🔽tadevaṃ mṛdabravīdityādivedavākyānāṃ yuktiviruddhatvenāprāmāṇye vedatvātyato vā imāni bhūtāni
analyzed: etena vaidike rthe yukteḥ avakāśa abhāvāt na tad virodhaka tvam iti apāstam  tat evam mṛd abravīt ityādi veda vākyānām yukti viruddha tvena aprāmāṇye veda tva atyatas vai imāni bhūtāni
translated: By this, the argument that there is no contradiction with the Veda because there is no scope for reasoning in the Vedic sense is refuted.

analyzed: ityādi vākyānām api aprāmāṇyāt na veda samanvayena brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatva siddhiḥ iti
translated: Thus, when the Vedic statements such as the clay said etc. are not authoritative because of contradiction with reasoning, and because of being the Veda, the statements such as from that these beings etc. are also not authoritative. Therefore, Brahman is not established as the cause of the world by the agreement of the Veda.

analyzed: siddhāntam āha tatas iti
translated: He states the conclusion with tataḥ.

analyzed: tatas tad nāmakaḥ kaścid pumān anyaḥ bhavet iti
translated: Therefore, some person named that would be different.

analyzed: yukta yāgama avirodhena prāptam atra abhidhīyate
translated: What is obtained by the non-contradiction of reasoning and scripture is stated here.

original: vedasya yukteśca niravakāśatvaṃ tata iti parāmṛśati /
analyzed: vedasya yukteḥ ca niravakāśa tvam tatas iti parāmṛśati
translated: He refers to the non-scope of the Veda and reasoning with tataḥ.

analyzed: tad nāmakaḥ mṛd ādi nāmakaḥ kaścid iti asmat ādi atīndriya tvam abhipraiti
translated: He intends that some person named after clay etc. is beyond the senses of us etc.

original: pumāṃścetano 'nyo 'smadādivilakṣaṇo 'ntardhānādiśaktimānbhavet /🔽asyāṃ śrutau vaktṛtvādinā pratipādyata iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: pumān cetanaḥ smat ādi vilakṣaṇaḥ ntardhāna ādi śaktimān bhavet  asyām śrutau vaktṛ tva ādinā pratipādyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: And there may be another conscious being, different from us etc., possessing the power of invisibility etc.🔽The meaning is that he is taught by the speaker etc. in this Vedic text.

analyzed: iti śabdasya prāptam iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: The word iti is connected with the word prāptam (obtained).

analyzed: prāptam pramitam
translated: Obtained means known.

analyzed: yukti āgama virodhena iti arthāpattim sūcayati
translated: By the contradiction of reasoning and scripture, he indicates presumption.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam arthaḥ
translated: And from that, this is the meaning.

analyzed: na mṛd abravīt ityādi vākyānām yukti virodhena aprāmāṇyam vaktavyam
translated: It should not be said that the statements beginning with clay did not speak are invalid due to contradiction with reasoning.

analyzed: atra mṛd ādi śabdasya cetana viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because the word clay etc. refers to conscious beings.

analyzed: tathāca tad pakṣīkāre hetoḥ asiddheḥ
translated: And thus, if that is accepted, the reason is unestablished.

analyzed: śabda mātreṇa hetu tve atiprasaṅgāt
translated: If mere words are the reason, there is over-extension.

analyzed: acetana mṛd ādi pakṣīkāre ca prakṛta avirodhāt
translated: And if the unconscious clay etc. is accepted, there is no contradiction with the present context.

analyzed: nanu katham cetaneṣu mṛd ādi śabda pravṛttiḥ
translated: But how can the word clay etc. be used for conscious beings?

analyzed: abhidhāna śaktyā iti brūmaḥ  mṛd ādi abhimāni tvāt
translated: We say it is due to the power of designation.🔽Because they are the conceivers of clay etc.
The word clay etc. is used for earth etc. because they are considered to be that.

analyzed: nanu ete bhimāninaḥ kim abhimata artha vyāpinaḥ tad eka deśa vṛttayaḥ vā
translated: Are these conceited beings all-pervading like the desired object, or do they exist only in part of it?

analyzed: ādye api sa dehāḥ videhāḥ vā
translated: Even in the first case, are they embodied or disembodied?

analyzed: ādye tad upalambha prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the first case, they would be perceived.

analyzed: dvitīye teṣām indriya abhāvena vaktṛ tva ādi anupapattau punar yukti virodha tādavasthyam
translated: In the second case, their speech and other activities would be impossible due to the absence of sense organs, so the contradiction with reasoning remains as before.

analyzed: tṛtīye tad vaiyarthyam tad anadhiṣṭhita pradeśa vat pradeśa antara pravṛtti sambhavāt iti
translated: In the third case, that (concealment) would be useless, as their activities in other places would be possible without the concealed places.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: vyāpakānām sa dehānām api piśāca ādi vat antardhāna śakti yogāt adṛśya tva upapatteḥ
translated: Even for all-pervading embodied beings, invisibility is possible due to their possession of the power of invisibility like ghosts and others.

analyzed: nanu evam sati kalpanā gauravam āpadyeta
translated: If that is so, then there would be the fault of excessive imagination.

original: keṣāñciccetanānāṃ mṛdādyabhimānitvaṃ tatastacchabdānāṃ teṣu vṛvirvyāpakatvaṃ sadehatvamantardhānaśaktistatparatā ca śruterityanekasya kalpyamānatvāt
analyzed: keṣāñcid cetanānām mṛd ādi abhimāni tvam tatas tad śabdānām teṣu vṛviḥ vyāpaka tvam sa deha tvam antardhāna śaktiḥ tatpara tā ca śruteḥ iti anekasya kalpyamāna tvāt
translated: For some conscious beings, there would be the status of being conceited as earth etc., then the application of the word that to them, all-pervasiveness, embodiment, the power of invisibility, and the purport of the scripture - all this would have to be imagined.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: arthāpattitaḥ sarvasya asya siddha tvāt
translated: Because all this is established by presumption.

analyzed: śrutiḥ hi mṛd ādīnām vaktṛ tva ādikam pratipādayati
translated: For the scripture teaches the speech and other activities of earth etc.,

analyzed: yuktiḥ ca tad abhāvam
translated: and reasoning shows their absence.

analyzed: na ca vāstavaḥ virodhaḥ sambhavati
translated: And there is no real contradiction possible.

analyzed: vastu vikalpa āpatteḥ
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of the reality of alternatives.

original: nacāyaṃ virodho vinaitatkalpanayā śāmyati /🔽jaḍasvīkāre yuktivirodhāt /🔽anabhimānisvīkāre ca pṛthak śabdaśaktau pramāṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: na ca ayam virodhaḥ vinā etad kalpanayā śāmyati  jaḍa svīkāre yukti virodhāt  anabhimāni svīkāre ca pṛthak śabda śaktau pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: And this contradiction cannot be removed without this assumption.🔽Because if the inert [matter] is accepted, it would contradict reason.

analyzed: avyāpaka tva ādi aṅgīkāre ca ukta anupapatteḥ
translated: And if the acceptance of the non-conceited [matter] is accepted, there is no evidence for the separate power of words.🔽And if the acceptance of non-pervasiveness, etc. is accepted, the stated impossibility [of the Sāṃkhya doctrine] would follow.

analyzed: na ca śruti yuktyoḥ anyatara aprāmāṇyena api upapadyate etat iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that this is possible even by the non-authoritativeness of either scripture or reason.

analyzed: ukta rītyā dvayoḥ api niravakāśa tvāt
translated: Because, as stated, both are without scope.

analyzed: nahi pareṇa api vidveṣeṇa eva āgama a prāmāṇyam abhidhātum yuktam
translated: For it is not proper for the opponent also to declare the non-authoritativeness of the scriptures merely out of hatred.

analyzed: kinnāma upapattim āśritya eva
translated: But rather by relying on reason.

original: tathāca kathaṃ vedaprāmāṇye 'pi na dīyate dṛṣṭiḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca katham veda prāmāṇye na dīyate dṛṣṭiḥ
translated: And so, how is sight not given even in the authoritativeness of the Veda?

analyzed: tat evam yukti āgama virodhena asya arthasya prāpta tvāt na kiñcid kalpanā gauravam iti
translated: Thus, since this matter is established by contradiction with reason and scripture, there is no heaviness in the assumption of anything.

analyzed: nanu etat utsūtritam katham ucyate iti atas āha atra iti
translated: But this is not stated in the sūtra, how is it said? To this he says here [in the Bhāṣya].

analyzed: iti uktam etat sarvam atra abhimāni vyapadeśaḥ tu viśeṣa anugatibhyām iti
translated: All this has been stated here in the sūtra But the designation of the conceited [matter] is by the conformity of the particulars.

analyzed: sūtre bhidhīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is stated in the sūtra.

analyzed: yat vā atra abhidhīyate iti siddhānta upakrama vākyam
translated: Or, the sentence beginning with yasminn is the statement of the conclusion.

analyzed: tasya evam prāpte sūtrakṛtā samādhānam abhidhīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when this is the case, the author of the aphorisms states the solution.

analyzed: evam sūtram avatārya tatas ityādinā vyākhyātam iti
translated: Thus, having introduced the aphorism, it is explained by the words tataḥ etc.

analyzed: yat uktam tad nāmakaḥ iti mṛd ādi śabda vācya tvam devatāyāḥ tat anupapannam
translated: What has been said - that the deity is denoted by words like mṛda etc. - is not correct.

analyzed: ayogāt anuyogāt ca
translated: Because it is not proper and because it is open to objection.

analyzed: mṛd ādi śabdāḥ khalu acetaneṣu eva rūḍhāḥ
translated: Words like mṛda are well-known only in relation to insentient things.

analyzed: na devatāyām
translated: Not in relation to the deity.

analyzed: lakṣaṇa āśrayaṇena api śruti yukti virodha śāntiḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Even by resorting to secondary signification, the contradiction with scripture and reasoning will be removed.

analyzed: na api vacana vṛttim sūtrakṛt āha iti atas āha bāla rūḍhim iti
translated: And the author of the aphorisms does not state the literal meaning. Therefore, he says bāla-rūḍhi.

analyzed: bāla rūḍhim vinā evā api vidvas rūḍhi samāśrayāt
translated: Even without the well-known usage of children, by relying on the well-known usage of the learned,

analyzed: tad tad nāmānaḥ eva ete tad tad vastu abhimāninaḥ
translated: these are indeed the names of those who conceive of those and those entities.

analyzed: santi  ete pṛthivī varuṇa ādayaḥ tad tad nāmānaḥ eva santi
translated: They exist.🔽These - Earth, Varuṇa, etc. - are indeed the names of those and those.

original: tāni tāni mṛdādīni nāmāni vācakāni yeṣāṃ te tathoktāḥ /
analyzed: tāni tāni mṛd ādīni nāmāni vācakāni yeṣām te tathā uktāḥ
translated: Those for whom those and those names like mṛda are denotative are said to be so.

analyzed: na tu tāni lakṣakāṇi iti eva śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word eva is that they are not merely indicative.

analyzed: santi bhavanti
translated: They exist.

analyzed: ayoga parihārāya uktam bāla iti
translated: In order to avoid the objection of impossibility, it is said that it is in the ignorant.

analyzed: a vidvat rūḍhi abhāve pi vidvat rūḍhi sadbhāvāt
translated: Even in the absence of the usage of the ignorant, the usage of the learned exists.

analyzed: mṛd ādi śabdāḥ tāvat devatā viṣayāḥ iti arthāpatti siddham
translated: It is established by presumption that words like 'mṛda' (clay) refer to deities.

analyzed: mukhya asambhave eva ca jaghanya vṛttiḥ āśrayaṇīyā
translated: And in the absence of the primary meaning, the secondary meaning must be accepted.

analyzed: na ca atra bādhakam asti iti vaidika prayogāt eva bādhaka abhāva sahitāt vidvat rūḍhiḥ avagamyate
translated: And there is no contradiction here. Therefore, from the Vedic usage itself, along with the absence of contradiction, the usage of the learned is understood.

original: yaccoktaṃ vacanavṛttyaṅgīkāraḥ prakṛtānupayogīti tatparihārāyoktaṃ tattanmṛdādivastvabhimānina iti /
analyzed: yat ca uktam vacana vṛtti aṅgīkāraḥ prakṛta anupayogī iti tad parihārāya uktam tat tat mṛd ādi vastu abhimāninaḥ iti
translated: And what was said that accepting the etymological meaning is not useful for the present topic, to avoid that it is said 'for one who identifies with those things like clay, etc.'

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: mṛdādiśabdānāṃ cetanaviṣayatāmātreṇa prakṛtavirodhaśāntāvapi vastusthitiṃ vijijñāpayiṣatā sūtrakāreṇa vyapadeśastviti tuśabdena mukhyavṛttiḥ 🔽sūcitā /
analyzed: mṛd ādi śabdānām cetana viṣaya tā mātreṇa prakṛta virodha śāntau api vastu sthitim vijijñāpayiṣatā sūtrakāreṇa vyapadeśaḥ tu iti tuśabdena mukhya vṛttiḥ  sūcitā
translated: Even though the contradiction with the present topic is removed by the words 'mṛda' (clay) etc. merely referring to conscious beings, the author of the aphorisms, wishing to make known the true state of things, uses the word 'tu' (but) in the statement 'the designation, however' to indicate the primary meaning.

analyzed: tatra upapatti jñāpanāya abhimānī iti ca uktam
translated: There, in order to show the reason, he says 'identification'.

analyzed: anyathā cenana vyapadeśaḥ iti avakṣyat
translated: Otherwise, he would have said 'the designation would not be otherwise'.

analyzed: abhimānī khalu abhimatasya sattā ādeḥ prayojakaḥ
translated: For one who identifies is the cause of the existence, etc. of what is desired.

original: tataśca tadadhīnatvāditi nyāyena sa eva tanmu
analyzed: tatas ca tad adhīna tvāt iti nyāyena saḥ eva tad mu
translated: And therefore, by the principle 'because it depends on that', he alone is the cause of the designation.

analyzed: mukhya arthaḥ iti
translated: The primary meaning.

analyzed: tat etat asmābhiḥ sūtram vyākurvadbhiḥ abhihitam iti
translated: This has been stated by us who are commenting on the aphorism.

original: nanvatra tannāmaka ityekavacanaṃ prakramya tattannāmāna iti bahuvacanaprayoge kinnimittam /
analyzed: nanu atra tad nāmakaḥ iti ekavacanam prakramya tad tad nāmānaḥ iti bahuvacana prayoge kinnimittam
translated: But here, having begun with the singular that named, why is the plural those named used?

analyzed: tathā bhāṣye pi abhimāni devatā tatra vyapadiśyate
translated: And in the commentary also, the deity of identification is indicated there.

analyzed: tāsām ca ityādi
translated: And of those, etc.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said.

analyzed: atra abhimāni vyapadeśaḥ iti abhimāni śabdaḥ hi ekavacana antaḥ samastaḥ
translated: Here the indication is of the identifying deity. For the word identifying deity is a compound ending in the singular.

analyzed: vyapadeśa śabdasya ekavacana anta tvāt
translated: Because the word indication ends in the singular.

analyzed: nahi bahūnām ekaḥ vyapadeśaḥ iti sambhavati
translated: For it is not possible that many have one indication.

analyzed: uttara sūtre ca ekavacanam eva
translated: And in the subsequent aphorism, there is the singular itself.

original: ato yathāsūtraṃ prathamaṃ vyākhyātam /🔽athedānīṃ prāpramā🔽ṇasaṃvādighaṭanāya jātāvidamekavacanamityāśayavatā bahuvacanaṃ prayuktamiti / /
analyzed: atas yathāsūtram prathamam vyākhyātam  atha idānīm prāpramā  ṇa saṃvādi ghaṭanāya jātau idam ekavacanam iti āśayavatā bahuvacanam prayuktam iti
translated: Therefore, it has been explained first according to the aphorism.🔽Now, for the purpose of establishing what is in agreement with valid means of knowledge, this singular has been used by one who has the intention that it has arisen thus. Thus, the plural is used.

analyzed: abhimāninām prādeśika tva videha tvayoḥ vaiyarthya vaktṛ tva ādi anupapattī
translated: For the identifying deities, the locality and the absence of a body are purposeless, and speech, etc. are not possible.

original: vyāptānāṃ sadehatve 'nupalambhabādha ityetatparihārāya viśeṣānugatibhyāmiti sūtrakhaṇḍaṃ kaścidanya iti tātparyato vyākhyātam /
analyzed: vyāptānām sa deha tve nupalambha bādhaḥ iti etad parihārāya viśeṣa anugatibhyām iti sūtrakhaṇḍam kaścid anyaḥ iti tātparyataḥ vyākhyātam
translated: To avoid the objection that if the all-pervading souls have bodies, they would be perceptible, the phrase by the particular and the relation in the sutra is explained by someone as meaning by some other.

analyzed: tat prapañcayati teṣām iti
translated: He elaborates on that with of those.

analyzed: teṣām viśeṣeṇa śaktiḥ anyebhyaḥ ucyate
translated: The power of those is said to be particular from others.

analyzed: viśeṣeṇa atiśayena
translated: Particular means superior.

analyzed: anyebhyaḥ smat ādibhyaḥ
translated: From others means from us and others.

analyzed: vyāptiḥ ca ucyate iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The relation is that pervasion is also said.

analyzed: dehavat tvasya api upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is also a metaphor for having a body.

analyzed: yadi api etat sarvam arthāpattyā eva labdham
translated: Although all this is obtained by presumption itself,

analyzed: anyathā virodha śānteḥ eva apayarvasānāt
translated: because otherwise the contradiction would not be resolved even by the Vedas,

analyzed: tathā api ucyate iti pṛthivī ādi abhimāninyaḥ iti āgamam api atra saṃvādayati
translated: still it is said. He also cites the scripture here with of those who preside over Earth etc.

analyzed: dinam darśayati  yadi api atra ākāṅkṣā anusāreṇa vyāptim ādau uktvā śakti viśeṣaḥ nantaram abhidhātavyaḥ
translated: He shows the day.🔽Although here, in accordance with the requirement, pervasion should be stated first and the particular power should be mentioned afterwards,

original: tathāpyalpāctarasya pūrvanipātamanusṛtya pravṛttaṃ sūtramanugacchatā kramo bhagnaḥ / /
analyzed: tathā api alpa a c tarasya pūrva nipātam anusṛtya pravṛttam sūtram anugacchatā kramaḥ bhagnaḥ  /
translated: nevertheless, following the rule of the prior placement of the shorter word, the order is broken by one who follows the sutra which has been composed.

original: nanu ca pṛthivyādyabhimāninya iti vākyaṃ kathamupādeyam 'ātmani caivaṃ vicitrāśca hi' /
analyzed: nanu ca pṛthivī ādi abhimāninyaḥ iti vākyam katham upādeyam ātmani ca evam vicitrāḥ ca hi
translated: But how can the statement they are the conceivers of earth etc. be accepted, since it contradicts the statement and thus various in the self in the next sutra?🔽To this he says in accordance with what is stated.

analyzed: utkrānti gati āgatīnām ityādi āgāmi sūtreṇa acintya śakteḥ sarvagata tvasya ca viruddha tvāt iti atas āha ukta anusāreṇa iti  vyāptiḥ ca ukta anusāreṇa
translated: And the pervasion is stated in accordance with what is stated.

analyzed: ātmani ca evam ityādi ukta anusāreṇa śaktiḥ vyāptiḥ ca ucyate iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that power and pervasion are stated in accordance with what is stated in the next sutra beginning with and thus various in the self.

analyzed: syāt ayam virodhaḥ yadi śaktiḥ vyāptiḥ ca niravadhikā atrā ucyate
translated: This contradiction would arise if unlimited power and pervasion were stated here.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: pramāṇa antara anusāreṇa antardhāna ādi śakteḥ abhimata artha vyāpteḥ ca pratipādya tā aṅgīkārāt iti
translated: Because it is accepted that the power of disappearance etc. and the pervasion of the intended meaning are taught in accordance with other means of knowledge.

analyzed: evam asmat ādi apekṣayā abhimāninām anupalambham aṅgīkṛtya tad bādhaḥ parihṛtaḥ
translated: Thus, accepting the non-apprehension of the conceivers from the point of view of us and others, their contradiction is refuted.

analyzed: idānīm asiddhaḥ ca asau iti āha dṛśyante ca iti
translated: Now, he says that they are also unestablished, saying and they are seen.

analyzed: dṛśyante ca adhikāribhiḥ
translated: And they are seen by those qualified.

analyzed: adhikāribhiḥ antarhita artha darśana samarthaiḥ yogibhiḥ
translated: By yogis capable of seeing hidden objects.

analyzed: etat ca bhāṣyā udā
translated: And this is stated in the commentary.

analyzed: udāhṛta smṛti siddham
translated: It is established by the cited smrti.

analyzed: etena dṛśyate ca
translated: And it is seen is also by this.

analyzed: iti sūtram vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: Thus the Sūtra is explained.

original: ye tu mīmāṃsakaṃmanyā vigrahavatī devatāṃ na sahante te 'pyanenaiva nirastā bhavanti /🔽arthāpattyā pratyakṣeṇa ca tatsiddheḥ /
analyzed: ye tu mīmāṃsakaṃmanyāḥ vigrahavatī devatām na sahante te pi anena eva nirastāḥ bhavanti  arthāpattyā pratyakṣeṇa ca tad siddheḥ
translated: But those who, considering themselves Mīmāṃsakas, do not accept the deity with form, they also are refuted by this very [argument].🔽Because it is established by presumption and perception.

analyzed: samarthitam ca āgamānām siddhārthe prāmāṇyam
translated: And the validity of the scriptures with regard to established things has been proved.

original: anupalambhaḥ anekatra yugapatsannidhānaṃ ca śaktiviśeṣādupapadyate piśācādivat /
analyzed: anupalambhaḥ anekatra yugapad sannidhānam ca śakti viśeṣāt upapadyate piśāca ādi vat
translated: Non-apprehension and being present in many places simultaneously are possible by a special power, like in the case of ghosts and so on.

analyzed: na ca piśāca ādayaḥ na santi
translated: And ghosts and so on are not non-existent.

analyzed: mantra auṣadha ādinā asmat ādibhiḥ api upalabhyamāna tvāt
translated: Because they are perceived even by us through mantras, herbs, and so on.

analyzed: arthakriyayā saṃvādena ca prāmāṇya upapatteḥ
translated: And because validity is possible through agreement with successful action.

analyzed: vakṣyati ca sūtrakāraḥ udeva ādi vat
translated: And the author of the aphorisms will say, Like gods and so on.

original: ityuktvā tatrāpi vipratipannaṃ pratiapi lokaḥ' / iti /
analyzed: iti uktvā tatra api vipratipannam prati api lokaḥ iti
translated: Having said this, even there, with regard to one who disagrees, [he says], Even the world.

analyzed: kiñca indra agni varuṇa ādi padam kasyacid vācakam pada tvāt go pada vat
translated: Moreover, the word Indra, Agni, Varuṇa, etc. is denotative of something, because it is a word, like the word cow.

analyzed: na ca acetana mātre tad prayogaḥ sti
translated: And that usage does not exist for mere insentient things.

original: naca cetano muktaḥ pralīno vā tadvācyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca cetanaḥ muktaḥ pralīnaḥ vā tad vācyaḥ
translated: And a liberated or dissolved sentient being is not denoted by that,

analyzed: jagat vayāpāra sambandhini api prayogāt
translated: because the usage is connected with one related to the activity of the world.

analyzed: na ca asau vigraha vidhuraḥ sambhavati iti alam
translated: And it is not possible that it is devoid of a body. Thus far.

analyzed: nanu tathā api mṛd abravīt ityādi vedasya abodhaka tva lakṣaṇam aprāmāṇyam durnivāram
translated: But even so, the Veda's lack of authoritativeness, characterized by its inability to instruct, is difficult to avoid, as in Earth spoke.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: yadi api vākya tā āpannāni padāni vākya artham padārthānām anyonya saṃsarga viśeṣa rūpam apūrvam eva avagamayanti
translated: Even though the words that form a sentence make one understand the meaning of the sentence, which is a new form of mutual connection among the meanings of the words,

analyzed: tathā api padārthaiḥ vācya vācaka bhāva rūpa sambandha pratipatti lakṣaṇām vyutpattim apekṣante anvaya vyatirekābhyām tathā avadhāraṇāt
translated: they still depend on the acquisition of knowledge characterized by the understanding of the relation in the form of the relation between the denoted and the denotator, by the positive and negative concomitance, because it is ascertained thus.

analyzed: na ca mṛd ādi śabdānām pṛthivī ādiṣu devatāsu vyutpattiḥ sambhavati  sambandha jñāna
translated: And the acquisition of knowledge of the relation of the words earth etc. with the deities such as Earth etc. is not possible.

analyzed: sya sambandhi jñāna sāpekṣa tvāt
translated: Because the knowledge of the relation depends on the knowledge of the relata.

analyzed: pratisambandhi rūpāyāḥ ca devatāyāḥ pratyakṣeṇa duradhigama tvāt
translated: And the deity, which is the relatum, is difficult to be understood by perception.

analyzed: liṅga abhāvena anumāna ayogāt
translated: And inference is not possible due to the absence of an inferential mark.

analyzed: na ca śabdataḥ tad avagamaḥ
translated: And it cannot be understood from a word.

analyzed: satyām vyutpattau śabdataḥ devatā āgamaḥ
translated: The understanding of the deity is from a word when there is acquisition of knowledge.

analyzed: sati ca tasmin vyutpattiḥ iti paraspara āśraya tvāt
translated: And when that exists, there is acquisition of knowledge. Thus it is a case of mutual dependence.

analyzed: naca śabda viśeṣasya agṛhīta saṅgatikasya eva bodhaka tvam
translated: And a particular word, whose connection has not been grasped, does not convey the meaning.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa kalpanā prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the assumption of something not seen.

analyzed: yadi api dṛśyate ca iti uktam
translated: Although it is said that it is seen,

analyzed: tathā api asmat ādīnām vyutpati anupapattiḥ eva  devatā darśanam tu ca
translated: nevertheless, for us and others, the derivation of meaning is impossible.

analyzed: yoginām veda artha jñāna uttara bhāvanā janyam aṅgīkriyate iti na vyutpatti hetuḥ
translated: But the vision of the deity is accepted as arising from meditation born after the knowledge of the meaning of the Veda by the yogis, and hence it is not the cause of derivation of meaning.

analyzed: lakṣaṇā api vācyārtha darśanam vinā anupapannā evā iti atas āha śāstra uktā iti
translated: Even the indication is impossible without the perception of the denoted meaning. Therefore he says:

analyzed: śāstra ukta vastunaḥ ca eva vyutpattiḥ śāstra liṅgataḥ
translated: And the derivation of the object mentioned in the scriptures is from the indication of the scriptures.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pyarthaḥ  evaśabdaḥ sāmarthyāt śāstra śabdena sambandhanīyaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the sense of api (also).🔽The word eva (only) should be connected by implication with the word śāstra (scriptures).

analyzed: śāstra eka samadhigamya vastunaḥ iti
translated: Of the object knowable only through the scriptures means

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi agamyāyāḥ api devatāyāḥ iti yāvat
translated: even of the deity, which is not knowable through perception etc.

analyzed: vastunaḥ vyutpattiḥ ati mṛd ādi śabdasya tad sambandhi vācaka tva pratipattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The derivation of the object means the understanding that the words mṛda etc. denote that which is related to it. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yujyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Is possible is the remainder.

analyzed: anena ca eva śabdasya sambandhaḥ
translated: And by this, the connection of the word eva (only) is made.

analyzed: śāstra liṅgataḥ tad jñāna sambhavāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: From the indication of the scriptures, because the knowledge of that is possible is the remainder.

original: yadvā śāstroktavastuno 'pi śāstraliṅgato 'dhigatisambhavāttatra śabdasya vyutpattiryujyata iti yojanā /
analyzed: yat vā śāstra ukta vastunaḥ śāstra liṅgataḥ dhi gati sambhavāt tatra śabdasya vyutpattiḥ yujyate iti yojanā
translated: Or the construction is: because the nature of the object taught in the scriptures can be understood from the indication of the scriptures, the derivation of the word is proper in that case.

analyzed: devatāyāḥ
translated: With regard to the deity,

analyzed: iti vaktavye śāstra ukta vastunaḥ ca iti vacanam śaṅkā anuvāda rūpam
translated: where it should be said of the deity, the statement of the object taught in the scriptures is in the form of stating the doubt.

analyzed: śāstram eva liṅgam śāstra liṅgam
translated: The indication of the scriptures is the indication of the scriptures.

analyzed: mṛd abravīt ityādi śāstrāt eva upapatti virodha sahitāt mṛd ādi śabda vācyatayā eva devatā svarūpam avagamyate iti
translated: From the scriptures themselves, such as Earth spoke, the nature of the deities is understood only as the denotation of the words Earth and so on, along with the contradiction of logic.

original: yadvā śāstraṃ taistaiḥ praṇītaṃ tatsadbhāve liṅgam /
analyzed: yat vā śāstram taiḥ taiḥ praṇītam tad sadbhāve liṅgam
translated: Or the scriptures composed by them are the indication of their existence.

analyzed: nahi vedāt anyat vākyam vaktāram antareṇa upapadyate
translated: For no statement other than the Veda is possible without a speaker.

original: tataśca vacanaliṅgānumite vaktari vṛddhairanyānprati mṛdādiśabdāḥ śakyavyutpādanāḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca vacana liṅga anumite vaktari vṛddhaiḥ anyān prati mṛd ādi śabdāḥ śakya vyutpādanāḥ
translated: And from that, the speaker inferred from the indication of the statement, the elders are able to teach others the words Earth and so on.

analyzed: yat vā śāstram śāsanam
translated: Or the scriptures are the teaching.

analyzed: varṣaṇa ādi upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is an illustration of raining and so on.

analyzed: nahi varṣaṇa ādi kriyā vikartṛkā sambhavati
translated: For the action of raining and so on is not possible without an agent.

analyzed: tathā ca tayā anumite katarri śakyata
translated: And in that way, the agent inferred from that is able🔽by the elders to teach the words

analyzed: ntaḥ eva vṛddhaiḥ śabdo 🔽bdāḥ vyutpādayitum
translated: The elders themselves have taught the word🔽to teach the word.

analyzed: athavā śāstra uktam liṅgam avyabhicaritaḥ dharmaḥ śāstra liṅgam
translated: Or, the mark mentioned in the scriptures is the invariable property, the mark of the scriptures.

original: pāśahastatvasahasrākṣatvādiśāstroktatattaddevatālakṣaṇānyupādāya vyutpādanaṃ śakyameva /🔽yathā khalu loke yathā mudgastathā mudgaparṇī /🔽yathā māṣastathā māṣaparṇī /
analyzed: pāśahasta tva sahasrākṣa tva ādi śāstra ukta tad tad devatā lakṣaṇāni upādāya vyutpādanam śakyam eva  yathā khalu loke yathā mudgaḥ tathā mudgaparṇī  yathā māṣaḥ tathā māṣaparṇī
translated: It is indeed possible to explain the words 'deva' etc. on the basis of the characteristics of those deities mentioned in the scriptures, such as having a noose in hand, having a thousand eyes, and so on.🔽Just as in the world, the word 'mudgaparni' is explained on the basis of the characteristics of having a long neck etc. of the animal 'usha',

original: dīrghagrīvādimānpaśuruṣṣa iti lakṣaṇānyupādāya mudgaparṇītyārṇyā🔽diśabdā vyutpādyante /🔽tathā yaḥ pāśahastatvādimānso 'bādiśabdārtha iti vyutpādanaṃ suvacanakarameva /
analyzed: dīrgha grīvā ādimān paśuḥ uṣṣaḥ iti lakṣaṇāni upādāya mudgaparṇī iti ārṇyā  diśabdāḥ vyutpādyante  tathā yaḥ pāśa hasta tva ādimān saḥ ba ādi śabda arthaḥ iti vyutpādanam suvacana karam eva
translated: similarly, the words 'deva' etc. are explained as meaning 'he who has a noose in hand' etc.

analyzed: pāśa ādi śabdāḥ tu lokataḥ eva gṛhīta saṅgatayaḥ
translated: The words 'pasa' etc. have their connection understood from the world itself.

analyzed: samāsasya vākya tvena vyutpatti anapekṣa tvam iti na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: And since a compound is a sentence, it does not require explanation. So there is no contradiction at all.

analyzed: na kevalam mṛd ādi śabdānām ayam vyutpatti prakāraḥ
translated: This is not only the way to explain the words 'mṛda' etc.

analyzed: kin nāma atīndriye dharma ādau api
translated: But also in the case of the supersensible dharma etc.

original: tataścaivaṃ vedaprāmāṇyamākṣipato 'tīndriyātharvyavahāramātravilayaprasaṅga iti sūcayituṃ śāstroktavastunaśceti sāmānyenoktam / /
analyzed: tatas ca evam veda prāmāṇyam ākṣipataḥ tīndriya athar vyavahāra mātra vilaya prasaṅgaḥ iti sūcayitum śāstra ukta vastunaḥ ca iti sāmānyena uktam
translated: And therefore, in order to indicate that one who thus questions the authoritativeness of the Veda incurs the undesirable consequence of the destruction of the mere usage regarding the transcendent Atharva Veda, the general statement and of the matter stated in the scriptures is made.

analyzed: evam tarhi kuṭilikā iyam vyutpattiḥ dubarlā
translated: If it is so, then this derivation is crooked and weak.

original: sākṣātkṛte tu mṛdādāveva prabalā tataśca devatānāṃ mukhyapratipādyatvamityayuktam /
analyzed: sākṣātkṛte tu mṛd ādau eva prabalā tatas ca devatānām mukhya pratipādya tvam iti ayuktam
translated: But when it is directly perceived, it is strong only in clay etc. Therefore, it is not proper that the deities are the primary subject matter.

analyzed: kintu mṛd ādīnām eva
translated: Rather, it is only of clay etc.

analyzed: vyutpatti anusāri tvāt pratipādanasya iti atas āha vyutpattiḥ iti
translated: Because the presentation follows the derivation. Therefore, he says The derivation...

original: vyutpattiḥ sā balavatī mūrkhavyutpattitā hi yat // / / //
analyzed: vyutpattiḥ sā balavatī mūrkha vyutpatti tā hi yat
translated: That derivation is strong, for it is the derivation by the ignorant.

analyzed: sā iti  yā vidita śabda śaktibhiḥ vṛddhaiḥ śāstra liṅgataḥ sampāditā
translated: That refers to🔽that which is accomplished by the elders who know the power of words from the indications of the scriptures.

analyzed: mūrkhaiḥ avidita śaktibhiḥ vyutpāditā
translated: That which is derived by the ignorant who do not know the power.

analyzed: vyutpattiḥ mūrkha vyutpattiḥ
translated: The derivation is the derivation by the ignorant.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetu sūcakaḥ
translated: The word hi indicates a reason.

original: nahi vyutpattiviṣayasya parokṣatvamaparokṣatvaṃ ca vyutpatterdairbalye prābalye ca kāraṇam /🔽api tarhi vyutpādakasya śabda
analyzed: nahi vyutpatti viṣayasya parokṣa tvam aparokṣa tvam ca vyutpatteḥ dairbalye prābalye ca kāraṇam  api tarhi vyutpādakasya śabda
translated: For the transcendence or immanence of the object of derivation is not the cause of the weakness or strength of the derivation.
Rather, it is the knowledge of the truth of the power of the word by the one who derives it.

analyzed: tad anusāreṇa vyutpādanam prābalye
translated: The explanation according to that is stronger.

analyzed: anyat tu daurbalye
translated: But the other is weaker.

analyzed: anyathā aikhaṇḍe sākṣātkṛte candana śabdasya vyutpattiḥ prabalā
translated: Otherwise, when the whole is directly perceived, the explanation of the word 'sandalwood' is stronger.

analyzed: liṅgataḥ pi jñāpite candane syāt
translated: If sandalwood is indicated even by the gender, it would be weaker.

analyzed: asti ca idam kāraṇam prakṛte
translated: And this is the reason in the present case.

analyzed: iti iyam eva prabalā na itarā iti
translated: Therefore, this alone is stronger, not the others.

analyzed: yat yasmāt evam
translated: This is because of what.

original: vaitat tasmāttattannāmāna evaita iti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ / /
analyzed: vā etat tasmāt tad tad nāmānaḥ eva ete iti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, they are named after that. This is the connection with the previous.

analyzed: nanu etat ayuktam
translated: But this is not correct.

analyzed: yadi ukti virodhena vedasya svārthāt pracyāvanam
translated: If the Veda is removed from its own meaning due to contradiction with reasoning,

analyzed: tasya sakala pramāṇa apekṣayā ca prābalyam
translated: and it is stronger than all other means of knowledge,

analyzed: yat kvacid svārthāt pracyāvanam tat upajīvya virodhaḥ eva
translated: and if it is removed from its own meaning somewhere, then it is only in contradiction with what is relied upon.

analyzed: na ca atra tathā iti atas āha dṛḍha iti
translated: And it is not so here. Therefore he says 'firm'.

analyzed: dṛḍha yukti virodhe tu sarvatra nyāyaḥ īdṛśaḥ
translated: But when there is contradiction with firm reasoning, the rule is always like this.

analyzed: virodhe vedasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: There is contradiction with the Veda, this is the remainder.

analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ  śruteḥ artha pracyāvanasya ayukta tām vadataḥ kaḥ bhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the idea.🔽What is the intention of one who says that it is not proper to remove the meaning of the Veda?

analyzed: kim viruddhayoḥ eva aprāmāṇyam uta āgama viruddhāyāḥ yukteḥ aprāmāṇyam
translated: Is it that both contradictory [means of knowledge] are not valid, or is reasoning that contradicts scripture not valid?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: vastu vikalpa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of the option of the object.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: vyāpti pakṣa dharma tā upetāyāḥ tad ayogāt
translated: Because that is not possible for what is pervaded and has the property of the subject.

analyzed: katham tarhi upajīvya virodhe tu ityādi uktam iti ced
translated: If it is asked how then was it said that in the case of contradiction with what is relied upon, etc.,

analyzed: upalakṣaṇa tvena iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say that it is by way of indication.

analyzed: upajīvyam khalu na upajīvyam iti eva bādhakam
translated: For what is relied upon is not a refuter merely because it is relied upon.

analyzed: kintu prabala tvena
translated: But because it is strong.

original: tadyadi yuktyantarasyāpi syāttadā kuto na bādhakateti /
analyzed: tat yadi yukti antarasya api syāt tadā kutas na bādhaka tā iti
translated: If that were to be the case for another reason also, then how could it not be a refutation?

analyzed: yat vā adhikaraṇa upādhim anena āha
translated: Or by this he states the topic of the section.

analyzed: na kevalam atra udāharaṇe
translated: Not only in this example,

original: kintu sarvatrāpi vedavākye pramitavyāptipakṣadharmatāvadyaktivirodhe satīdṛśa evānyathārthasvīkāreṇa virodhaparihāro nyāyaḥ prakāro draṣṭavya
analyzed: kintu sarvatra api veda vākye pramita vyāpti pakṣa dharmatāvat yakti virodhe sati īdṛśaḥ eva anyathā artha svīkāreṇa virodha parihāraḥ nyāyaḥ prakāraḥ
translated: but everywhere in the Vedic sentence, when there is contradiction with a reason having a known pervasion and property of the subject, this same method of resolving the contradiction by accepting a different meaning should be seen.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.
Section on the non-existence of God.

analyzed: om asat iti ced na pratiṣedha mātra tvāt om
translated: If it is argued that it is non-existent, no, because it is mere negation.

analyzed: nanu ca ca an ārambhaṇīyam eva idam adhikaraṇam na vilakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: But this section is not to be begun at all, because it is different.

analyzed: iti anena eva vedasya sakala yukti virodhānām
translated: Because by this alone, the contradiction of the Veda with all reasoning has been removed.

analyzed: dṛḍha yukti virodha parihārasya ca abhimāni adhikaraṇa nyāya siddha tvāt
translated: And because the avoidance of contradiction with firm reasoning has been established by the reasoning of the section on the presumptuous.

analyzed: iti atas gatārtha tām pariharan adhikaraṇasya upādhi māpyā
translated: Therefore, avoiding redundancy, the topic of the section is stated:

analyzed: ha alpa vākyā iti
translated: It is said: 'In a small number of statements...'.

analyzed: asat iti ced na pratiṣedha mātra tvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is non-existent, it is not so, because it is mere negation.

analyzed: alpa vākya yutā yuktiḥ bahulā eva virodhinī
translated: The reasoning, even if accompanied by a small number of statements, is contradicted by many.

analyzed: yatra tatra katham vastu nirṇayaḥ syāt iti īrite
translated: When it is asked how the determination of a thing can be made there and then,

analyzed: virodhi yukti bāhulyāt iti nyāyaḥ viniścitaḥ
translated: the settled conclusion is that it is by the preponderance of contradictory reasonings.

original: yatra yadā vedasya vākyayutā yuktirvirodhinī syāt /
analyzed: yatra yadā vedasya vākya yutā yuktiḥ virodhinī syāt
translated: When and where the reasoning accompanied by the statements of the Veda would be contradicted,

analyzed: tatra tadā
translated: there and then.

original: vastunirṇayaḥ kathaṃ syāt iti pūrvapakṣiṇerite sati tadvirodhiyuktīnāṃ bāhulyāt prābalyāt vastunirṇayo bhavediti siddhāntaḥ /
analyzed: vastu nirṇayaḥ katham syāt iti pūrvapakṣiṇā īrite sati tad virodhi yuktīnām bāhulyāt prābalyāt vastu nirṇayaḥ bhavet iti siddhāntaḥ
translated: When it is asked by the one who holds the prima facie view how the determination of a thing can be made, the conclusion is that the determination of a thing can be made by the preponderance of the contradictory reasonings.

analyzed: iti eṣa u tra adhikaraṇe nyāyaḥ viniścitaḥ
translated: This is the settled conclusion of reasoning in this section.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: pūrva adhikaraṇe pratyakṣa ādi gṛhīta vyāpti ādimattvena dṛḍhayā yuktyā viruddha tvāt veda ekadeśasya aprāmāṇye
translated: In the previous section, due to the contradiction with the firm reasoning having the pervasion etc. grasped by perception etc., the invalidity of a part of the Veda,

original: sati taddṛṣṭāntena brahmaṇo jagatkāraṇatvābhidhāyakasyāpi vedasya vedatvādaprāmāṇye
analyzed: sati tad dṛṣṭāntena brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatva abhidhāyakasya api vedasya veda tvāt aprāmāṇye
translated: If, by the example of that, the Veda which declares Brahman to be the cause of the world is also unauthoritative because it is Veda,

analyzed: tad asiddhiḥ iti pūrvaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: then that is unestablished. This is the prima facie view.

original: siddhāntastu yuktivadvedasyāpyapauruṣeyatvena dṛḍhatvāt vāstavavirodhasyānupapatteḥ aviruddhātharkalpanopapatteḥ nāprāmāṇyamiti / /🔽iha punarvedavākyāntarasaṃvādena sudṛḍhayā yuktyā viruddhatvādbrahmaṇo jagatkāraṇatvābhidhātrīṇāṃ
analyzed: siddhāntaḥ tu yukti vat vedasya api apauruṣeya tvena dṛḍha tvāt vāstava virodhasya anupapatteḥ aviruddha athar kalpanā upapatteḥ na aprāmāṇyam iti  iha punar veda vākya antara saṃvādena su dṛḍhayā yuktyā viruddha tvāt brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatva abhidhātrīṇām
translated: The conclusion is: Since the Veda, like reasoning, is firm due to being non-human, real contradiction is not possible. Since the assumption of non-contradiction is possible, it is not unauthoritative.🔽Here again, due to contradiction by very firm reasoning in agreement with other Vedic statements,

original: śrutīnāmeva tatra prāmāṇyānupapattau prathamādhyāyoktavastunirṇayo na bhavediti pūrvaḥ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: śrutīnām eva tatra prāmāṇya anupapattau prathama adhyāya ukta vastu nirṇayaḥ na bhavet iti pūrvaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: the authoritativeness of the Vedic statements declaring Brahman to be the cause of the world is not possible. If that is not established, the determination of the topic stated in the first chapter would not be possible. This is the prima facie view.

analyzed: siddhāntaḥ tu
translated: The conclusion is:

analyzed: pūrvapakṣiṇā utprekṣitābhyaḥ śruti sahita yuktibhyaḥ pi prabalānām tad virodhi yuktīnām sadbhāvāt tad viruddhānām pūrvapakṣa śruti yuktīnām aprāmāṇyāt upapannataraḥ
translated: Since there are present reasonings contradicting them, which are stronger than the reasonings along with the Vedic statements imagined by the opponent, and since the reasonings and Vedic statements of the opponent, which are contradicted by them, are not authoritative,

analyzed: prāk uktaḥ rthaḥ iti
translated: the previously stated meaning is more reasonable.

analyzed: atas pūrva uttarapakṣa nyāyayoḥ agata tvena yuktaḥ dhikaraṇa ārambhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, since the reasoning of the prima facie view and the conclusion has not yet come, it is proper to begin the section.

analyzed: etat ca anupadam eva udāharaṇena prapañcayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: And this we shall explain at length by an example immediately after this.

original: nanvevaṃ sati śrutīnāṃ śrutiyuktivirodhaparihāro 'syādhikaraṇasyārtha ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: nanu evam sati śrutīnām śruti yukti virodha parihāraḥ syāt adhikaraṇasya arthaḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: If this be so, then it is said that the purpose of this section is to remove the contradiction of the Śrutis with the Śrutis and reasonings.

analyzed: saḥ yam caturtha pāda arthe eva iti tatra eva asya adhikaraṇasya upanibandhanam ucitam
translated: And this is the very subject-matter of the fourth section; so it is proper to connect this section with that only.

analyzed: na atra iti atas vailakṣaṇyam darśayitum uktam alpa iti
translated: Not here. Hence it is said 'alpa' (small) in order to show its difference even from that.

analyzed: bahulā iti ca
translated: And 'bahula' (abundant).

analyzed: atra alpa tvam upasajarna tvam
translated: Here 'alpa' (small) means subordinate,

analyzed: bahula tvam ca
translated: and 'bahula' (abundant)

analyzed: pradhāna tvam iti jñātavyam
translated: means principal. This should be understood.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ tu guṇa pradhāna bhāva vyatyāsaḥ caturtha pāde iva iti arthe
translated: The word 'eva' (only) is for the purpose of reversing the relation of subordinate and principal, as in the fourth section.

original: nanu śrutiyuktibhyāṃ pūrvapakṣite kathaṃ prabalayuktimātrāśrayeṇa siddhāntaḥ /
analyzed: nanu śruti yuktibhyām pūrvapakṣite katham prabala yukti mātra āśrayeṇa siddhāntaḥ
translated: If it is argued that when the prima facie view is presented by the Śrutis and reasonings, how can the conclusion be based on only the abundant reasonings?

original: kathañcitpratipakṣatāmātrasambhavādityata uktaṃ vivṛṇvannāha yuktestviti //🔽yuktestu yuktibāhulyamāgamādāgamasya ca /
analyzed: kathañcid pratipakṣatā mātra sambhavāt iti atas uktam vivṛṇvan āha yukteḥ tu iti  yukteḥ tu yukti bāhulyam āgamāt āgamasya ca
translated: Because the possibility of being a counter-argument is somehow present, to explain this it is said 'tu' (but).

analyzed: katham na nirṇayam kuryāt
translated: But how can one not come to a conclusion regarding the abundance of reasonings from reasonings and of scriptures from scriptures?
In comparison with the arguments for the prima facie view, the arguments against it are more numerous.

original: tathā pūrvapakṣāgamāpekṣayā virodhyāgamasya ca bāhulyaṃ kathaṃ nirṇayaṃ na kuryāt /
analyzed: tathā pūrvapakṣa āgama apekṣayā virodhi āgamasya ca bāhulyam katham nirṇayam na kuryāt
translated: Similarly, in comparison with the scriptures for the prima facie view, the scriptures against it are more numerous. How could one not make a decision?

original: pūrvapakṣyutprekṣitayuktyāgamābhyāṃ prabalau virodhiyuktyāgamau tadbādhayā vastuvyavasthāṃ kuruta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvapakṣi utprekṣita yukti āgamābhyām prabalau virodhi yukti āgamau tad bādhayā vastu vyavasthām kurutaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the strong arguments and scriptures against it, imagined by the prima facie view, establish the nature of reality by refuting those [imagined arguments and scriptures].

analyzed: kuryāt iti pratyekam sambandhaḥ
translated: The word could is connected with each [of the two].

analyzed: na kevalam siddhānte prabala yukti mātram
translated: Not only is there strong reasoning in the established conclusion,

analyzed: kinnāma prabala āgamaḥ api asti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: but there is also a strong scripture, this is the idea.

analyzed: iti atas adhikaraṇa ārambhaḥ sambhavati iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Thus - this is the remainder, that the beginning of the topic is possible.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa upādhi vyutpādana samāpti dyotakaḥ vā iti śabdaḥ
translated: Or the word iti (thus) indicates the completion of the explanation of the topic and its basis.

original: tadidamudāharaṇaniṣṭhaṃ vyutpādayituṃ pūrvapakṣamanuvadati sūtrakāraḥ asaditi cediti //
analyzed: tat idam udāharaṇa niṣṭham vyutpādayitum pūrvapakṣam anuvadati sūtrakāraḥ asat iti ced iti
translated: In order to explain this, which is based on examples, the author of the aphorisms repeats the prima facie view in the words If it be said that it is non-existent.

analyzed: ayam asya arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of this [verse].

analyzed: na brahmaṇaḥ jagatkartṛ tvam yuktam
translated: It is not proper for Brahman to be the creator of the world.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence.

analyzed: sat eva somya idam agre āsīt tat tejaḥ sṛjata
translated: In the beginning, O Somya, this was Being only. It sent forth fire.

analyzed: ityādi śrutiḥ asti iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there are such Vedic statements, it is not so.

analyzed: tasyāḥ yukti viruddha tvena bhavat abhimata arthe prāmāṇya abhāvāt
translated: Because that (scripture) is contradicted by reasoning, and so is not authoritative for the matter you accept.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: mahāpralaye tāvat utpatsyamāna kārya prāgabhāvaḥ vaśyam aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: First of all, the prior non-existence of the effect that will be produced at the time of the great dissolution must certainly be accepted.

analyzed: anyathā sarga ādau
translated: Otherwise, at the beginning of creation,

analyzed: kārya utpāda ayogāt
translated: the production of the effect would be impossible.

analyzed: na ca asya anyatra caritārtha tā upalabhyate
translated: And its having a purpose elsewhere is not perceived.

analyzed: tatas ca saḥ eva sakala kārya kāraṇam bhaviṣyati
translated: Therefore, that alone will be the cause of all effects.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: mahāpralaya vartī kārya prāgabhāvaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: The prior non-existence of the effect that exists at the time of the great dissolution is fit to be the cause of the effect beginning with Mahat.

original: anyatrānupakṣīṇatve sati niyamena tatpūrvabhāvitvāt /🔽yo 'nyatrānupakṣīṇatve sati niyamena yataḥ
analyzed: anyatra anupakṣīṇa tve sati niyamena tad pūrva bhāvi tvāt  yaḥ nyatra anupakṣīṇa tve sati niyamena yatas
translated: Because it necessarily precedes it, while not being excluded by anything else.

analyzed: t pūrva bhāvī
translated: That which necessarily precedes something, while not being excluded by anything else,

analyzed: sa tasya kāraṇam
translated: is the cause of that.

analyzed: yathā kuvindaḥ paṭasya iti
translated: Like a weaver is of a cloth.

analyzed: mahat ādikam vā prāgabhāva kāryam ananyathā asiddha niyata paścādbhāvi tvāt
translated: Or, Mahat and so on are the effects of the prior non-existence, because they necessarily exist later without any other means.

analyzed: yat yat ananyathāsiddha niyata paścāt bhāvi tat tat kāyarm
translated: That which necessarily exists later without any other means is the effect of that.

analyzed: yathā paṭaḥ kuvindasya iti
translated: Like a cloth is of a weaver.

analyzed: nanu atra jagat prāgabhāvasya jagat kāraṇatva mātram vā sādhyam
translated: But here, is it the mere fact of the prior non-existence of the world being the cause of the world that is to be proved?

analyzed: anya yoga vyavacchedena vā
translated: Or is it that it is the cause, excluding any other cause?

analyzed: ādye rtha antara tā
translated: In the first case, there is irrelevance.
Even if prior non-existence is the cause, Brahman can still be the cause.

analyzed: dvitīye vyāpti abhāvaḥ
translated: In the second case, there is absence of pervasion.🔽For there is no rule that

analyzed: na hiyaḥ yad apekṣayā pūrva bhāvī
translated: only that which exists prior to something else

analyzed: saḥ eva tat kāraṇam
translated: is its cause,

analyzed: na anyaḥ iti niyamaḥ sti
translated: and not something else.

analyzed: tatas prāgabhāvasya jagat kāraṇa tve pi tad samāna nyāyānām īśvara ādīnām api tad kāraṇatvam aṅgīkāryam iti
translated: Therefore, even if prior non-existence is the cause of the world, the same logic applies to God and others, and their status as causes must be accepted.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: syāt etat evam yadi īśvara ādīnām pralaye sattvam eva syāt
translated: This would be so if the existence of God and others were established even in the state of dissolution.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: siddhāntinā kāraṇa tvena āśāsyamānam īśvara ādikam pralaye sat bhavitum arhati bhāva tvāt mahat ādi kārya vat iti yukti viruddha tva tā trodhaḥ
translated: The opponent's argument is contradicted by logic, as the Siddhantin (proponent of the established view) would have to accept that God and others, who are sought to be established as causes, cannot be non-existent in the state of dissolution, because they are effects like the great elements and others.

analyzed: evañcañcedī
translated: And if this is so,

original: īśvarādīnāṃ pralaye 'sattvasiddhau prāgabhāvasya kāraṇatvamātrasādhane 'pi tasyaiva kāraṇatvamiti siddhayati /
analyzed: īśvara ādīnām pralaye sattva siddhau prāgabhāvasya kāraṇa tva mātra sādhane tasya eva kāraṇa tvam iti siddhayati
translated: even if the mere fact of prior non-existence being the cause of the world is established, it is established that it alone is the cause.

original: nanu ca yatkāryaṃ tatsakartṛkamiti niyamānmahadādikartṛtveneśvaro 'vaśyamaṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ / na /🔽pralaye tatsattāttvā
analyzed: nanu ca yat kāryam tat sa kartṛkam iti niyamāt mahat ādi kartṛ tvena īśvaraḥ vaśyam aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ na  pralaye
translated: But surely, since it is a rule that what is an effect must have a maker, God must be admitted as the maker of Mahat and the rest. No.🔽Because of the cognition of non-existence at the time of dissolution,

analyzed: bhāvasya pramita tvena prāgabhāvasya eva jagat kartṛ tva upapatteḥ
translated: the prior non-existence itself is logically possible as the maker of the world.

analyzed: na ca etat anumāna jātam udāhṛta śruti viruddha tvena aprāmāṇyam iti sāmpratam
translated: And it is not right to say that these inferences are not valid because they are contradicted by the quoted Vedic texts.

analyzed: asat eva idam agre āsīt
translated: For it is said in the Vedic texts: This universe was non-existent in the beginning.

analyzed: tat asat eva sat manaḥ kuruta
translated: That non-existent became the existent mind.

analyzed: asataḥ sat ajāyata  ityādi śruti saṃvādi tvena śruti mātrataḥ prābalyāt
translated: From the non-existent, the existent was born.🔽 Because they are stronger than mere Vedic texts by being in agreement with such Vedic texts,

analyzed: prabala yukti viruddhāyāḥ ca śruteḥ sva artha parityāgasya atīta adhikaraṇe sthita tvāt
translated: and because it has been established in a previous section that a Vedic text contradicted by strong reasoning must abandon its own meaning.

analyzed: prāgabhāvasya api sva rūpa sattva ādinā sat eva ityādi prayoga viṣaya tad vā upapatteḥ
translated: And because the prior non-existence is the subject of such expressions as existent alone by being existent in its own nature, etc.

analyzed: nanu etena sarve
translated: By this, all [the passages] beginning with 'asat' (non-existent) are explained.

analyzed: iti asat ādi śabdānām brahma artha tvam uktam  tat kim śabdānām anyatra śaktiḥ eva nā asti
translated: It has been said that the words 'asat' (non-existent) and so on refer to Brahman.🔽Then, do these words have no power to denote anything else?

analyzed: kim vā śruteḥ tatra tātparya abhāvaḥ
translated: Or is there no intention in the Vedic text to refer to that [Brahman]?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: samākarṣa aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because the inclusion [of Brahman under the word 'asat'] is accepted.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: yukti upatāyāḥ tatra tātparya upapatteḥ
translated: Because the purpose of the statement is established by reason.

original: tathāpi prāgabhāvasyaiva kāraṇatvaṃ kartṛtvaṃ ca na kvāpyupalabdhamiti cenna /
analyzed: tathā api prāgabhāvasya eva kāraṇa tvam kartṛ tvam ca na kvāpi upalabdham iti ced na
translated: If it be said that nowhere is the mere prior non-existence of a thing found to be the cause or the agent, we say no.

analyzed: alaukika arthasya yathāgamam grāhya tvāt
translated: Because what is not of the nature of the world must be accepted as it is taught in the scriptures.

analyzed: santata utpatti prasaṅgaḥ tu brahma vādinaḥ samānaḥ
translated: The objection that there would be a constant production is equally applicable to the doctrine of Brahman also.

analyzed: icchā ādi kāraṇānām kādācitkatvena tad samādhānam mama api samānam
translated: The solution of that difficulty by the assertion that the causes, will, etc., are occasional, is equally available for us also.

analyzed: atas eva śrutiḥ āha tat manaḥ kurute iti
translated: For this very reason the Śruti says, 'It made the mind' (Tai. Up. 2. 1).

analyzed: tat tasmāt tad tad prāgabhāvasya eva tad tad kartṛ tvāt uktam ayuktam iti
translated: 'Tat' (therefore), because the prior non-existence of each thing is the agent of each thing, it is said that the objection is not applicable.

analyzed: tat idam uktam asat iti
translated: This is what is said by the word 'asat'.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ śrutyā jagat kartṛ tvena ucyate
translated: Non-existence is declared by the Śruti to be the agent of the world.

analyzed: anumīyate ca tathā
translated: And it is inferred as such.

analyzed: tasmāt saḥ eva jagatkartā iti
translated: Therefore, it alone is the agent of the world.

analyzed: atra asat śabdaḥ bhāva sādhanaḥ śruti anugama artham abhāve prayuktaḥ
translated: Here the word 'asat' (non-existent) is used in the sense of non-existence for the sake of conformity with the Śruti, though it is a word denoting an existent.

analyzed: aparā api vṛttiḥ
translated: There is another interpretation also.

analyzed: bhāva tva hetunā kārya vat īśvara ādikam api pralaye sat anumīyate iti
translated: By the reason of existence, even God, etc., which are effects, are inferred to be non-existent at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: atra asat śabdaḥ kartṛ sādhanaḥ
translated: Here the word 'asat' (non-existent) is used in the sense of an agent.

original: iha prathamāṃ vṛttimabhipretya neti siddhāntāṃśaṃ vyācaṣṭevyākhyāti asaditi //
analyzed: iha prathamām vṛttim abhipretya na iti siddhānta aṃśam vyācaṣṭe vyākhyāti asat iti
translated: Here, with reference to the first interpretation, he explains the part of the conclusion beginning with 'not' as 'explains'.

analyzed: iti asat kāraṇam na hi
translated: Thus, the non-existent is not the cause.

analyzed: śruti arthaḥ bhavati
translated: The meaning of the Vedic text becomes.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is 'non-existence'.

analyzed: kāraṇam iti tad viśeṣaḥ kartā ucyate
translated: The word 'cause' specifically refers to the agent.

analyzed: hi iti anena idam āha
translated: By the word 'not', this is said.

analyzed: upapatti viruddhaḥ tāvat na veda atharḥ sambhavati
translated: A meaning of the Veda that contradicts reason is not possible.

analyzed: tad aviruddhe rthe sambhavati iti uktam
translated: It has been said that it is possible in a meaning that is not contrary to reason.

analyzed: prakṛtaḥ ca upapatti viruddhaḥ
translated: And the present case contradicts reason.

analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyāmaḥ iti
translated: And we will explain it thus.

analyzed: śruti arthaḥ na bhavati iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: The meaning of the Vedic text is not so, this is a metaphor.

analyzed: anumāna prameyam api idam na bhavati upapatti viruddha tvāt iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: This should also be seen as not being an object of inference, because it contradicts reason.

analyzed: kiñca sambhāvitaḥ eva śruti arthaḥ vaktavyaḥ numātavyaḥ ca
translated: Moreover, the meaning of the Vedic text should be stated and inferred only if it is possible.

analyzed: na ca evam prakṛtaḥ
translated: And the present case is not so.

analyzed: kvāpi abhāvasya kartṛ tva anupalambhāt iti āha kvāpi iti
translated: Because the agency of non-existence is not observed anywhere, he says 'kvacit'.

analyzed: kvāpi
translated: Anywhere.

analyzed: asat kāraṇam na hi anupalabdham iti anuvartate
translated: The non-existent is not the cause, because it is not perceived, this continues.

analyzed: caturtha pādasya adhikaraṇasya vailakṣaṇyam darśayitum alpa ityādi uktam
translated: In order to show the difference of the fourth section, 'alpa' etc. is stated.

analyzed: tat aviśadam
translated: That is indistinct.

analyzed: vailakṣaṇya jñānasya ubhaya svarūpa jñāna adhīna tvāt
translated: Because the knowledge of difference depends on the knowledge of the nature of both.

analyzed: atas caturtha pāda artham darśayati śruti iti
translated: And therefore he shows the meaning of the fourth quarter with the words the scriptures.

analyzed: śruti prāya upapattibhiḥ
translated: With the scriptures and the majority of arguments.

analyzed: śrutīnām prāyas bāhulyam
translated: The scriptures are the majority.

analyzed: tad sahitābhiḥ upapattibhiḥ
translated: Along with those arguments.

analyzed: śruti pradhānaka upapattibhiḥ iti yāvat
translated: It means with arguments that are mainly based on the scriptures.

analyzed: avirodhaḥ virodha abhāvaḥ
translated: Non-contradiction is the absence of contradiction.

analyzed: śrutīnām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The scriptures are understood.

analyzed: yat vā śruti prāya śabdena śruti kalpa tvam ucyate
translated: Or, by the word majority of scriptures, it is said to be like the scriptures.

analyzed: śruti gṛhītābhiḥ upapattibhiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: It means with arguments accepted by the scriptures.

analyzed: atra tu svatantrābhiḥ iti sphuṭam eva
translated: But here it is clear that they are independent.

analyzed: athavā atrā ukta arthasya eva tatra prapañcanāt na doṣaḥ
translated: Or, since the same matter is elaborated there, there is no fault.

analyzed: yathā prathama pāda artha prapañcanāt dvitīya pādasya iti āśayena uktam samyak iti
translated: With the intention that it is like the second quarter because it elaborates the meaning of the first quarter, it is said correctly.

analyzed: yat vā kvāpi iti atra sambaddhayate
translated: Or, in some places is connected here.

analyzed: tena kvāpi adhyātma lakṣaṇe viṣaye
translated: Therefore, in some places, in the subject matter characterized by the internal.

analyzed: atra tu anyatra iti bhedaḥ sūcitaḥ bhavati
translated: But here, elsewhere is indicated as the difference.

analyzed: yadi api etat prāk eva vaktavyam tathā api asatkāryam ityādeḥ vakṣyamāṇasya
translated: Although this should have been stated earlier, it is not, because of what is to be stated beginning with non-existent effect.

analyzed: sūtrasya vyākhyāna antara tva dyotanāya vyavadhānena uktam
translated: In order to indicate the difference of interpretation of the Sūtra, it is stated by an interruption.

analyzed: anyathā pūrvam eva vyākhyānam
translated: Otherwise, the previous explanation itself.

original: idaṃ tu tadupapādanāyopayogīti vijñāyeta / /🔽atha dvitīyāṃ vṛttimabhipretyaasaditi cenna' /
analyzed: idam tu tad upapādanāya upayogi iti vijñāyeta  atha dvitīyām vṛttim abhipretya asat iti ced na
translated: But this would be understood as useful for the elucidation of that.

original: ityetāvatsūtraṃ vyācaṣṭe asaditi //🔽asat kāryaṃ yathā dṛṣṭaṃ vastutvāt kāraṇaṃ tathā /
analyzed: iti etāvat sūtram vyācaṣṭe asat iti  asat kāryam yathā dṛṣṭam vastu tvāt kāraṇam tathā
translated: Now, with reference to the second interpretation, he explains the Sūtra up to it is not so, because of the existence of the effect.🔽He explains it is not so up to it is not so, because of the existence of the effect.

analyzed: iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the effect is non-existent, like what is seen, the cause is existent, because of being an entity, it is not so.

analyzed: kāryam mahat ādikam
translated: The effect is the great one, etc.

original: yathā pralaye 'sat pramitaṃ tathā vastutvādbhāvatvātkāraṇaṃ kāraṇatvena siddhāntināṅgīkṛtamīśvarādikamapimiti
analyzed: yathā pralaye sat pramitam tathā vastu tvāt bhāva tvāt kāraṇam kāraṇa tvena siddhāntinā aṅgīkṛtam īśvara ādikam api miti
translated: Just as it is known to be non-existent at the time of dissolution, in the same way, the cause, which is accepted by the Siddhāntin as the cause, such as God, etc., also.

analyzed: pralaye sat bhavitum arhati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it should be non-existent at the time of dissolution.
