original: kuto neti cet /🔽na tāvadasmādevānumānādabhāvasya viśvakartṛtvasiddhiḥ /🔽kintvanena pralayāvasthāyāmīśvarādyabhāvasiddhau kāryasya sakartṛkatvaniyame sthite
analyzed: kutas na iti ced  na tāvat asmāt eva anumānāt abhāvasya viśva kartṛ tva siddhiḥ  kintu anena pralaya avasthāyām īśvara ādi abhāva siddhau kāryasya sa kartṛka tva niyame sthite
translated: If it is asked why not,🔽first of all, the non-existence of the universe cannot be established as the creator by this inference alone.🔽But when the non-existence of God, etc. is established by this in the state of dissolution, and the rule that the effect must have a creator is established,

original: prāgabhāvasya niyatapūrvabhāvitvena viśvakāraṇatvaṃ siddhayan kartṛtayaiva setsyatīti vaktavyam /
analyzed: prāgabhāvasya niyata pūrva bhāvi tvena viśva kāraṇatvam siddhayan kartṛtayā eva setsyati iti vaktavyam
translated: it must be said that the prior non-existence, being necessarily antecedent, being established as the cause of the universe, will be accomplished only by the state of being the creator.

original: tadidaṃ pratyanumānaparāhatamityāśayavān pratiṣedhamātratvaditi sautraṃ hetuṃ vyākuvarn sādhyamadhyāharati niṣedheti //
analyzed: tat idam pratyanumāna parāhatam iti āśayavān pratiṣedha mātra tvat iti sautram hetum vyākuvarn sādhyam adhyāharati niṣedha iti
translated: The author, intending to show that this (view of the opponent) is refuted by a counter-inference, explains the reason stated in the aphorism because it is mere negation by supplying the probandum (in the form of the word not).

analyzed: niṣedha eka svarūpasya na kartṛ tā
translated: The nature of an absolute negation is not that of an agent, etc.

analyzed: niṣedha eka svarūpasya iti hetu garbha viśeṣaṇam
translated: The nature of an absolute negation is a qualifying word containing the reason.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: The argument here is as follows:

original: vipratipanno 'bhāvo na kartā pratiṣedhamātratvāt niṣedhaikasvarūpatvāt sampratipannaghaṭābhāvavaditi /
analyzed: vipratipannaḥ bhāvaḥ na kartā pratiṣedha mātra tvāt niṣedha eka svarūpa tvāt sampratipanna ghaṭa abhāva vat iti
translated: The disputed absence is not an agent, because it is mere negation, because it is of the nature of absolute negation, like the generally accepted absence of a pot.

analyzed: kartṛ tva mātrasya abhāve viśvakartṛ tvam dūra utsāritam
translated: When mere agency is denied, the (view of the opponent that it is) the agent of the universe is far removed.

analyzed: na ca dṛṣṭāntaḥ sādhya vikalaḥ
translated: And the example is not devoid of the probandum.

original: anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ kulālādeḥ kartṛtvaniścaye tu abhāvasya tatkalpakābhāvāt / /
analyzed: anvaya vyatirekābhyām kulāla ādeḥ kartṛ tva niścaye tu abhāvasya tad kalpaka abhāvāt
translated: For when the potter and others are ascertained to be agents by positive and negative concomitance, there is no ground for supposing that absence (to be the agent).

analyzed: nanu astu niṣedha eka svarūpa tvam
translated: Well then, let it be that (absence) is of the nature of absolute negation.

analyzed: kartṛ tvam ca kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: And what is the contradiction in its being an agent?

original: tathāca ghaṭādyabhāvasyākartṛtve 'pi pralayakālīno 'bhāvaḥ kartā bhaviṣyatītyataḥ kartṛtvaniṣedhaikasvarūpatvayovirredhaṃ sphorayituṃ kartṛtvasvarūpamāha
analyzed: tathā ca ghaṭa ādi abhāvasya akartṛ tve pi pralaya kālīnaḥ bhāvaḥ kartā bhaviṣyati iti atas kartṛ tva niṣedha eka svarūpa tvayoḥ virredham sphorayitum kartṛ tva svarūpam āha
translated: And thus, even if the absence of a pot and other things is not an agent, the absence at the time of dissolution will be the agent. To show the contradiction between being an agent and being of the nature of absolute negation, the nature of an agent is stated:

analyzed: buddhi iti
translated: 'Buddhi' (means)

analyzed: buddhi pūrva pravṛttiḥ hi kartṛ tvam iha niścitam
translated: For, in this world, it is certain that the state of being an agent is preceded by cognition.
'Activity' means desire, effort, etc.

analyzed: niścitam sarvaiḥ api parīkṣakaiḥ
translated: It is certain for all who examine.

original: vṛkṣeṇa sthīyata ityādau kartṛtvaṃ pāribhāṣikaṃ na tu svābhāvikamiti hi sarve 'pi pratipannāḥ /
analyzed: vṛkṣeṇa sthīyate ityādau kartṛ tvam pāribhāṣikam na tu svābhāvikam iti hi sarve pratipannāḥ
translated: For all agree that in statements like 'The tree stands', the state of being an agent is conventional, not natural.

analyzed: atra buddhi pūrva pravṛttiḥ iti etat buddhayā vivicya vyākhyeyam
translated: Here, the phrase 'preceded by cognition' should be analyzed and explained with the word 'cognition'.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: syāt kartṛ niṣedha eka svarūpa tvayoḥ avirodhaḥ
translated: There would be no contradiction between the state of being an agent and the state of being solely characterized by negation,

analyzed: yadi tṛtīya ādi viṣaya tvam eva kartṛ tvam syāt
translated: if the state of being an agent were only the state of being the object of the third case ending.

analyzed: na ca etat asti  api tarhi icchā prayatna ādi rūpā pravṛttiḥ eva
translated: But this is not the case.🔽Rather, it is activity in the form of desire, effort, etc.

analyzed: sarvaiḥ api parīkṣakaiḥ tasyāḥ eva kartṛ tvena niścita tvāt
translated: For all who examine have ascertained that only that is the state of being an agent.

analyzed: prakaraṇāt ca etat eva niścitam
translated: And this is ascertained from the context itself.

analyzed: atra eva hi vipratipattiḥ na anyatra
translated: For there is disagreement only here, not elsewhere.

analyzed: sā ca iyam pravṛttiḥ buddhi pūrvā buddhi vyāptā
translated: And this activity is preceded by cognition, pervaded by cognition.

analyzed: kāryāyāḥ pravṛtteḥ buddhi kāraṇaka tvāt
translated: Because activity, which is an effect, has cognition as its cause.

analyzed: akāryāyāḥ ca buddhi vyabhicārāt yat aśarnāt
translated: And because non-activity is not seen to deviate from cognition.

analyzed: na ca kartṛ tva apara paryāyāyāḥ pravṛtteḥ vyāpikā buddhiḥ abhāve sambhavati
translated: And the absence of the cognition, which is the pervader of activity, which is synonymous with agency, is not possible.

original: tato vyāpyaṃ kartṛtvamapi na sambhavatyeveti kathaṃ kartṛtvaniṣedhaikasvarūpatvayorna virodha iti /
analyzed: tatas vyāpyam kartṛ tvam api na sambhavati evā iti katham kartṛ tva niṣedha eka svarūpa tvayoḥ na virodhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the pervaded, namely, agency, is also not possible. How then is there no contradiction between the nature of mere negation of agency and the nature of being an effect?

analyzed: atra kartṛ tva anuvādena buddhi pūrva pravṛttiḥ iti vyākhyānāt niścitam iti napuṃsaka upapattiḥ
translated: Here, because of the explanation that activity preceded by cognition is stated by way of reiteration of agency, the use of the neuter form niścitam is appropriate.

analyzed: bhāve vā kta pratyayaḥ iti
translated: Or, the suffix kta is used to denote existence.

analyzed: nanu mā bhūt aprayojaka tvam hetoḥ
translated: Now, let the reason not be unestablished.

analyzed: tathā api vaiyarthyam a parihāyarm
translated: Even so, it cannot avoid being useless.

analyzed: abhāva paryāyaḥ hi pratiṣedha śabdaḥ
translated: For the word negation is synonymous with absence.

analyzed: kartṛ tvam ca kārya utpatti anukūla icchā ādi yogaḥ iti uktam
translated: And agency is said to be the possession of will etc. favorable to the production of an effect.

analyzed: na ca pratiṣedha tvam kartari vartate
translated: And negation does not apply to an agent.

analyzed: yena a kartṛkam vyabhicaret
translated: By which it would be deviant with respect to a non-agent.

analyzed: tad nirāsa artham ca viśeṣaṇam sārthakam syāt
translated: And the qualification would be meaningful for the purpose of refuting that.

original: ataḥ pratiṣedhatvādityetāvatākartṛtvavyabhicārābhāvātsūtre mātragrahaṇaṃ vyākhyāne 'pyekagrahaṇaṃ vyarthamityata āha pratiṣedheti //
analyzed: atas pratiṣedha tvāt iti etāvatā akartṛ tva vyabhicāra abhāvāt sūtre mātra grahaṇam vyākhyāne pi eka grahaṇam vyartham iti atas āha pratiṣedha iti
translated: Therefore, since there is no deviation from non-agency by just because of being a negation, the use of mātra in the sutra and the use of eva in the explanation are useless. To this he says pratiṣedhe etc.

analyzed: pratiṣedha ātmaka tvam tu bhāvasya
translated: But the existence of an entity has the nature of negation.

analyzed: bhāvasya api kulāla ādeḥ kartuḥ pratiṣedha ātmaka tvam vidyate
translated: The existence of a potter and other agents also has the nature of negation.

analyzed: atas pratiṣedha tvāt iti utya iva
translated: Therefore, when it is said because of being negation,

analyzed: kte kulāla ādau
translated: the potter and others are mentioned.

analyzed: akartṛ tvena hetoḥ
translated: Due to the reason of not being an agent,

analyzed: vyabhicāraḥ syāt
translated: there would be a fallacy.

analyzed: tad parihāra artham mātra grahaṇam
translated: To avoid that, the word only is used.

analyzed: tad vayākhyāne ca
translated: And in the explanation of that,

analyzed: eka grahaṇam ca sārthakam iti
translated: the word only is also meaningful.

original: nanu kulālāderbhāvasya kathaṃ pratiṣedhātmakatvamityata āha abhāveti //
analyzed: nanu kulāla ādeḥ bhāvasya katham pratiṣedha ātmaka tvam iti atas āha abhāva iti
translated: But how can the existence of a potter and others have the nature of negation? To this he says because of the property of non-existence.

analyzed: abhāva dharmataḥ
translated: Because of the property of non-existence.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ tra anyonya abhāvaḥ vivakṣitaḥ
translated: Here, non-existence is intended as mutual non-existence.

analyzed: sa
translated: That is its property, so it has the property of non-existence.

analyzed: tasya bhāvaḥ tattvam
translated: Its existence is its nature.

original: tata iti bhāvapradhāno nirdeśaḥ /🔽asti khalu kulālāderbhāvasya bhedāparaparyāyaḥ
analyzed: tatas iti bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ  asti khalu kulāla ādeḥ bhāvasya bheda apara paryāyaḥ
translated: From that is an expression with the primary meaning of existence.🔽Indeed, for the existence of a potter and others, which is synonymous with difference,

analyzed: pratiṣedha ātmakaḥ anyonya abhāvaḥ dharmaḥ iti
translated: there is a property in the form of mutual non-existence, which has the nature of negation.

analyzed: nanu idam asaṅgatam
translated: But this is irrelevant.

original: yaḥ kartā dharmī kulālādiḥ na tasya pratiṣedhātmakatvam /
analyzed: yaḥ kartā dharmī kulāla ādiḥ na tasya pratiṣedha ātmaka tvam
translated: The subject that is an agent, such as a potter, does not have the nature of negation.

original: yaśca pratiṣedhātmako 'nyonyābhāvo na tasya kartṛtvamittaya āha dharmeti //
analyzed: yaḥ ca pratiṣedha ātmakaḥ nyonya abhāvaḥ na tasya kartṛ tva mittaye āha dharma iti
translated: And that which is of the nature of negation, mutual absence, does not have the nature of an agent, he says 'dharma' etc.

analyzed: dharma dharma aikyataḥ ca eva
translated: And also from the oneness of the property and the possessor of the property...

analyzed: dharma dharmiṇoḥ kulāla anyonya abhāvoḥ eka tvataḥ
translated: The mutual absence of the potter and the possessor of the property is from the oneness of the two.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ hetu samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for the purpose of including the reason.

analyzed: abhāva dharmataḥ dharma dharmya aikyataḥ ca pratiṣedha ātmaka tvam bhāvasya asti iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the existence of the nature of negation belongs to the entity from the oneness of the property and the possessor of the property, which have the nature of negation.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ bheda vyudāsa arthaḥ  anyonya abhāvaḥ hi dharmiṇā atyanta abhinnaḥ bhyupeyate
translated: The word 'eva' (only) is for the purpose of excluding difference.🔽For mutual absence is accepted as absolutely non-different from the possessor of the property.

analyzed: na tvayā avaddravyabhāvī dharmaḥ iva bhinna abhinnaḥ
translated: But it is not like a property that exists as long as the substance exists, which is both different and non-different.

original: astvevaṃ pratiṣedhatvasya kulālādau vyabhicārastathāpi kathaṃ mātragrahaṇasya sārthakyam /
analyzed: astu evam pratiṣedha tvasya kulāla ādau vyabhicāraḥ tathā api katham mātra grahaṇasya sārthakyam
translated: Let it be so that the nature of negation is deviant in the potter and so on. Even then, how is the inclusion of 'only' meaningful?

analyzed: na hi aviśiṣṭa vyabhicāraḥ eva viśeṣaṇam prayojayati
translated: For a deviant [reason] that is not distinguished does not justify a distinction.
If it were so, the restriction of the distinction would be impossible.

analyzed: kinnāma viśeṣaṇasya vyabhicāra nirāsa aupayika tve sati
translated: But rather, when the distinction is conducive to the exclusion of deviation.

analyzed: tat atra katham iti atas āha na tu iti
translated: Here, how is it so? Therefore he says 'not' etc.🔽But that would not be mere...

analyzed: na tu tanmātra tā bhavet
translated: But it would not be mere that.

analyzed: kulāla ādeḥ kartuḥ bhāvasya pratiṣedha tve pidhā ātmaka tve pi
translated: Even though the existence of the potter and other agents is negated, it is not merely negation.

original: tanmātratā pratiṣedhamātratā na bhavet /🔽ato 'sti mātragrahaṇasya vyabhicāraparihāraupayikatvam /
analyzed: tad mātra tā pratiṣedha mātra tā na bhavet  atas sti mātra grahaṇasya vyabhicāra parihāra aupayika tvam
translated: That is, it is not mere negation.🔽Therefore, the use of the word merely is useful for avoiding the fallacy of inconclusive evidence.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ sandigdha vyabhicāra parihāra arthaḥ  nanu evam ekam sandhitsataḥ nyat
translated: The word but is for determination and for avoiding the fallacy of inconclusive evidence.🔽If one tries to establish one thing, another

analyzed: param pracyavate
translated: falls away.

analyzed: yatas vyartha viśeṣaṇa tā parihāre svarūpa asiddhiḥ āpannā
translated: Because in order to avoid the fault of having a useless qualifier, the non-establishment of the nature [of the reason] is incurred.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

original: pakṣīkṛte abhāve prameyatvādidharmāḥ santi na vā /🔽neti pakṣe 'pramitāśrayatvādikaṃ hetoḥ /
analyzed: pakṣīkṛte abhāve prameya tva ādi dharmāḥ santi na vā  na iti pakṣe pramita āśraya tva ādikam hetoḥ
translated: In the absence, which is the subject, are there properties such as being an object of knowledge or not?🔽If the answer is no, then the reason is not established because it has an unestablished basis, and so on.

analyzed: ādye na tāvat te pi abhāvāḥ vidhi pratyaya viṣaya tvāt
translated: If the answer is yes, then those [properties] are not absences, because they are the objects of affirmative cognition,

analyzed: pratiyogi a nirūpya tvāt ca
translated: and because they are not dependent on a counter-correlate.

analyzed: ṣaṣ padārtha atirikta tvam abhāva tvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that absence means being different from the six categories, that is not so.

analyzed: sva icchā parikalpanāyāḥ anupādeya tvāt
translated: Because it is not acceptable to imagine [properties] according to one's own will.

original: anyathā pañcaiva bhāvāstadatirikto 'bhāva iti kalpanāyāṃ samavāyāderapi bhāvatvaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: anyathā pañca eva bhāvāḥ tad atiriktaḥ bhāvaḥ iti kalpanāyām samavāya ādeḥ api bhāva tvam na syāt
translated: Otherwise, if one imagines that there are only five existents and that what is different from them is non-existent, even inherence and so on would not be existents.

analyzed: te ca na abhāvāt dharmiṇaḥ bhinnāḥ
translated: And those [properties] are not different from the substratum, which is absence.

analyzed: anyonya abhāva samāna nyāya tvāt
translated: Because the non-existence of each other is of the same principle.

original: tathāca yathā kulālādervipakṣasya vidhiniṣedhātmakatvena pratiṣedhamātratvābhāvastathā pakṣīkṛthābhāvasyāpi dharmadvārā vidhirūpasya
analyzed: tathā ca yathā kulāla ādeḥ vipakṣasya vidhi niṣedha ātmaka tvena pratiṣedha mātra tva abhāvaḥ tathā pakṣīkṛthā bhāvasya api dharma dvārā vidhi rūpasya
translated: And thus, just as the potter and others, which are the counter-examples, are not mere negations by being of the nature of affirmation and negation, in the same way, the absence which is the subject, which is of the nature of affirmation through the property,

analyzed: pratiṣedha mātra tva abhāvāt svarūpa asiddhaḥ hetuḥ syāt
translated: is not a mere negation, so the reason would be unestablished in its own nature.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntaḥ ca sādhana vikalaḥ
translated: And the example is deficient in the proof.

original: ghaṭābhāvasyāpi dharmadvārā vidhirūpasya pratiṣedhamātratvābhāvādityata āha abhāvasya ceti //
analyzed: ghaṭa abhāvasya api dharma dvārā vidhi rūpasya pratiṣedha mātra tva abhāvāt iti atas āha abhāvasya ca iti
translated: Because even the absence of the pot, which is of the nature of affirmation through the property, is not a mere negation. Therefore he says and of the absence etc.

analyzed: abhāvasya ca bhāvaḥ
translated: And of the absence, existence is also a property, although...

analyzed: prathama api śabdāt pūrvam yadi iti adhyāhāryam
translated: Before the first api (also), yadi (if) should be supplied.

original: yadyapyabhāvasya pakṣīkṛtasya dṛṣṭāntīkṛtasya ca bhāvaḥ prameyatvādidharmo 'sti /
analyzed: yadi api abhāvasya pakṣīkṛtasya dṛṣṭāntīkṛtasya ca bhāvaḥ prameya tva ādi dharmaḥ sti
translated: Although for the absence which is the subject and the absence which is the example, there is the property such as being an object of knowledge,

analyzed: caśabdāt dharmiṇā abhinnaḥ ca
translated: and by the word ca (and), it is also non-different from the subject,

analyzed: bhāvasya abhāva dharmaḥ iva iti vā
translated: or like the property of non-existence for existence.

analyzed: atha api na svarūpa asiddhayā ādi doṣaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Although, there is no fault of being unestablished in its own nature etc. is the remainder.

analyzed: katham iti atas āha hi dharmiṇaḥ iti
translated: How is it so? Therefore he says for the subject etc.

analyzed: hi dharmiṇaḥ
translated: For the subject.🔽Suchness, mere-ness, is said to be just this here...

analyzed: tādṛś tavam mātratā iha uktā
translated: Such is the measure stated here...🔽...

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word hi (in fact) is for a reason.

analyzed: tādṛktvam pratiṣedha ātmaka tvam
translated: That nature is the nature of negation.

analyzed: mātra tā pratiṣedha mātra tā
translated: Mere means mere negation.

analyzed: iha sūtre
translated: In this sutra.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: syādayaṃ svarūpāsiddhayādidoṣo yadyatra pratiṣedhamātraśabdena kevalapratiṣedhatvaṃ vivakṣitaṃ syāt /
analyzed: syāt ayam svarūpa asiddhayā ādi doṣaḥ yadi atra pratiṣedha mātra śabdena kevala pratiṣedha tvam vivakṣitam syāt
translated: This fault of being unestablished in its own nature and so on would be [admitted] if mere negation were intended by the word mere negation here.

original: nacaivam /🔽kintu dharmadvāramantareṇa dhamirṇa eva pratiṣedhatvam /🔽tacca pakṣadṛṣṭāntayerastyeva /
analyzed: na ca evam  kintu dharma dvāram antareṇa eva pratiṣedha tvam  tat ca pakṣa dṛṣṭāntayeḥ asti eva
translated: But it is not so.🔽Rather, negation is of the substratum itself without the door of a property.🔽And that does exist in the subject and example.

analyzed: tayoḥ dharrma dvāreṇa vidhi tve pi dharmiṇoḥ pratiṣedha tvasya ubhaya siddha tvāt
translated: Even though there is affirmation through the door of that property, the negation of the substratum is established for both.

analyzed: vyāvṛttam ca vipakṣāt kulāla ādeḥ
translated: And it is distinguished from the opposite, such as a potter.

analyzed: tasya dharmataḥ niṣedha tve pi dharmiṇaḥ  vidhitvā
translated: Although that is negation by way of the property, the substratum🔽is not a negation.

analyzed: ṇaḥ niṣedha tvāt iti
translated: It is not a negation.

analyzed: nanu katham etat labhyate
translated: But how is this understood?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: mātra śabdaḥ hi sākalye vartate
translated: The word mere is used for totality.

analyzed: na ca tat kvāpi sambhavati
translated: And that is not possible anywhere.

analyzed: pratiṣedhe vidhi sadbhāvasya pareṇa eva ukta tvāt
translated: Because the existence of affirmation even in negation has been stated by the opponent himself.

analyzed: tatas pratiṣedha mātra śabdaḥ vidheḥ aprādhānyam lakṣayati
translated: Therefore, the word mere negation indicates the non-primary nature of affirmation.

analyzed: anna mātram bhuktam iti yathā
translated: Just as when it is said that only food is eaten.

analyzed: dharma dharmiṇoḥ ca
translated: And of the property and the possessor of the property.

analyzed: a prādhānyam dharmasya
translated: The property is not primary.

analyzed: prādhānyam dharmiṇaḥ
translated: The possessor of the property is primary.

analyzed: tena dharmiṇaḥ pratiṣedha tvam pratiṣedha mātra tvam iti siddhayati
translated: Therefore, it is established that the negation is of the possessor of the property, that it is mere negation.

original: icchāprayatnādirūpāyāḥ pravṛtteḥ kartṛtāparanāmikāyāḥ vyāpikā buddhiḥ abhāvādvayāvṛttā tāmapi vyāvartayatītyuktam /
analyzed: icchā prayatna ādi rūpāyāḥ pravṛtteḥ kartṛ tā apara nāmikāyāḥ vyāpikā buddhiḥ abhāvāt vayāvṛttā tām api vyāvartayati iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the absence of the intellect, which is the pervader of activity, which is synonymous with agency, is excluded due to non-existence, and that it also excludes that.

original: tatrābhāvādbuddhivyāvṛttireva kuta ityata āha buddhīti //🔽buddhirāhityameva tat // / / //
analyzed: tatra abhāvāt buddhi vyāvṛttiḥ eva kutas iti atas āha buddhi iti  buddhi rāhityam eva tat
translated: In that case, how is there exclusion of the intellect due to non-existence? To this he says buddhi etc.🔽That is the absence of the intellect itself.

analyzed: tat tasmāt pratiṣedha mātra tvāt eva buddhi rāhityam abhāvasya ghaṭa abhāva vat siddhayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: from mere negation, the absence of the intellect is established, just like the absence of a pot.

original: dvividhaṃ hi prameyam svatantraṃ paratantraṃ ca /
analyzed: dvividham hi prameyam svatantram paratantram ca
translated: For the object of knowledge is of two kinds: independent and dependent on another.

analyzed: paratantram api dvividham bhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ ca
translated: The dependent on another is also of two kinds: existent and non-existent.

analyzed: dvedhā cetanaḥ cetanaḥ ca
translated: The existent is also of two kinds: conscious and unconscious.

analyzed: evañca yadā bhāvasya api kasyacid na caitanyam
translated: And when even some existent is not conscious,

analyzed: kā vārtā tad abhāve caitanyasya
translated: then what to speak of non-existence being conscious?

analyzed: kaścid abhāvaḥ buddhimān kin na syāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that some non-existence may not be conscious, that is not so.

analyzed: nirupādhika sambandham an ādṛtya nirnimittāyāḥ śaṅkāyāḥ atiprasaṅgi tvāt
translated: Because, disregarding the relation without qualification, the suspicion of groundlessness would lead to an absurdity.

analyzed: tat manaḥ kuruta
translated: They made that mind.

analyzed: iti śruteḥ iti ced na
translated: If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: anyathā asiddha tvāt
translated: Because it is established otherwise.

analyzed: atha pratiṣedha mātra tvam api pakṣe na abhyupeyāt
translated: If even the mere negation is not accepted in the proposition,

analyzed: tat āsat iti brahma iti ca saṃjñā bheda mātram
translated: then the difference in names, 'that' and 'Brahman', is merely nominal.

analyzed: aneka tva ādeḥ pareṇa api tyājya tvāt
translated: Because multiplicity etc. should be abandoned by the opponent also.

analyzed: aneka svātantrye kārya udaya ayogāt
translated: Because if there were many independent [Brahmans], the arising of effects would be illogical.

analyzed: nanu idam tatra eva vaktavyam
translated: But this should be stated right there.

analyzed: satyam  pratiṣedha tva
translated: True.

analyzed: mātra tve vidite tatas buddhi rāhitya pratīteḥ saulabhyāt iha uktam
translated: When mere negation is known, the understanding of the absence of intellect is easily obtained, so it is stated here.

original: ṭīkākārastu prameyatvādibhāvadharmāṅgīkāre buddhirapi tathā kinna syāditi śaṅkāvakāśādihoktamityāhuḥ / /
analyzed: ṭīkākāraḥ tu prameya tva ādi bhāva dharma aṅgīkāre buddhiḥ api tathā kin na syāt iti śaṅkā avakāśāt iha uktam iti āhuḥ
translated: But the commentator says it is stated here because there is room for doubt that if the property of being an object of knowledge etc. is accepted, why should not the intellect also be so.

analyzed: bhāvasya abhāvaḥ dharmaḥ
translated: The absence is a property of existence.

original: abhāvasya ca bhāvo 'pi dharma ityanupapannam bhāvasyābhāvadharmatā /🔽abhāvasya ca bhāvadharmatetyanupapannam /
analyzed: abhāvasya ca dharmaḥ iti anupapannam bhāvasya abhāva dharma tā  abhāvasya ca bhāva dharma tā iti anupapannam
translated: And the existence is also a property of non-existence. This is illogical. The absence is a property of existence.🔽And the existence is also a property of non-existence. This is illogical.

analyzed: bhāva abhāvayoḥ abhāva bhāva dharmi tve pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence for the absence and existence being the properties of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: sambandha abhāvāt ca
translated: And because there is no relation.

analyzed: sambaddhayoḥ eva hi śauklaya paṭayoḥ dharma dharmi bhāvaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ na asambaddhayoḥ maru mandarayoḥ
translated: For the relation of property and possessor is seen only between connected things, like a cloth and whiteness, not between unconnected things like a mirage and Mount Mandara.

analyzed: na ca bhāva abhāvayoḥ sambandhaḥ sti
translated: And there is no relation between existence and non-existence.

analyzed: saṃyoga samavāyayoḥ bhāva niyata tvāt
translated: Because conjunction and inherence are restricted to existent things.

analyzed: viruddha svabhāva tvāt ca  yau aviruddha svabhāvau guṇa guṇinau tau eva hi dharma dharmiṇau upalabdhau
translated: And because they have contradictory natures.🔽For only those that have non-contradictory natures are seen to be property and possessor, like a cloth and whiteness.

analyzed: na viruddha svabhāvau aśva mahiṣau
translated: But a horse and a buffalo have contradictory natures.

analyzed: viruddha svabhāvau ca bhāva abhāvau  vidhi niṣedha rūpa tvāt
translated: And existence and non-existence have contradictory natures.

analyzed: abhedāt ca
translated: Because they have the form of affirmation and negation.🔽And because they are not different.

original: nahi ghaṭaḥ svayaṃ svasyaiva dharmo bhavati /🔽uktaṃ ca dharmadharmyaikyamityata āha viśeṣyataiveti //
analyzed: nahi ghaṭaḥ svayam svasya eva dharmaḥ bhavati  uktam ca dharma dharmya aikyam iti atas āha viśeṣya tā eva iti
translated: For a pot is not itself the property of itself.

analyzed: viśeṣyatā eva dharmi tvam
translated: And it has been said that property and possessor are one. Therefore he says: The very state of being the qualified is the state of being the possessor of the property.🔽The very state of being the qualified is the state of being the possessor of the property.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa tā eva ca dharma tvam iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: And it should be seen that the very state of being the qualifier is the state of being the property.

original: yo hi viśiṣṭate vyavacchidyate sa tasya dharmī /
analyzed: yaḥ hi viśiṣṭate vyavacchidyate sa tasya dharmī
translated: For that which is distinguished and determined is the possessor of the property.

analyzed: dharmaḥ ca aparaḥ
translated: And the other is the property.

analyzed: prakāra antarasya nirvaktum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because another mode cannot be stated.

analyzed: pratīyate ca viśeṣya viśeṣaṇa bhāvaḥ bhāva abhāvayoḥ
translated: And the relation of qualified and qualifier is perceived between existence and non-existence.

original: anyathā ghaṭaḥ paṭo na bhavatītyabhāvaḥ prameya iti ca vyavahārānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: anyathā ghaṭaḥ paṭaḥ na bhavati iti abhāvaḥ prameyaḥ iti ca vyavahāra anupapatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, the usage the pot is not the cloth and non-existence is an object of knowledge would be impossible.

analyzed: tat katham bhāva abhāvayoḥ na dharma dharmi bhāvaḥ
translated: So how can there be no relation of qualifier and qualified between existence and non-existence?

analyzed: paṭa śoklayayoḥ ca na sambandha prayuktaḥ dharmi dharma bhāvaḥ
translated: And the relation of qualifier and qualified between cloth and shokla is not based on relation.

analyzed: nā api meru mandarayoḥ tad abhāvaḥ sambandha abhāva prayuktaḥ
translated: Nor is the absence of that in Meru and Mandara based on the absence of relation.

analyzed: kintu svabhāvāt eva viśeṣya viśeṣaṇa tvāt abhāva rūpaḥ
translated: But it is just by nature that the form of qualifier and qualified, and absence of that, is based on the distinction between the qualified and the qualifier.

analyzed: sambaddhayoḥ api ghaṭa paṭayoḥ tad abhāva vat
translated: Even when the pot and cloth are related, there is absence of that [in the cloth].

analyzed: bhū tala ghaṭa abhāvayoḥ tad bhāvāt ca
translated: And because there is existence of that in the absence of the pot on the ground.

analyzed: evam eva virodhi svabhāva abhedau api para a nirastau
translated: In the same way, the two differences based on contradictory nature and non-difference are refuted by others.

original: saguṇanirguṇatvena nityānityatvena vā viruddhasvabhāvayorapi guṇaguṇinordharmyāditvasya darśanāt /
analyzed: sa guṇa nirguṇa tvena nitya anitya tvena vā viruddha svabhāvayoḥ api guṇa guṇinoḥ dharmi ādi tvasya darśanāt
translated: Even for quality and substance, which have contradictory natures by being with qualities and without qualities, or by being eternal and non-eternal, the relation of qualified and qualifier, etc. is seen.

analyzed: adarśanāt ca paṭa tva śauklayayoḥ
translated: And it is not seen in cloth and whiteness.

analyzed: dṛśyate ca abhede tad bhāvaḥ
translated: And even in non-difference, that existence is seen.

analyzed: astitva abhidheya tva ādīnām dharmāṇām paraiḥ dharmya bhedasya aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because existence, being expressible, and other properties are accepted by others as non-different from the qualified.

analyzed: bhinnānām api tad bhāvaḥ na upalabhyate
translated: And the existence of that is not perceived in different [things].

original: tadevamasambaddhayorapi vilakṣaṇasvabhāvayorapi bhāvābhāvayorabhede 'pi viśeṣaśaktyā viśeṣyaviśeṣaṇatālakṣaṇo dharmidharmabhāvo yukta eveti
analyzed: tat evam asambaddhayoḥ api vilakṣaṇa svabhāvayoḥ api bhāva abhāvayoḥ abhede pi viśeṣa śaktyā viśeṣya viśeṣaṇa tā lakṣaṇaḥ dharmi dharma bhāvaḥ yuktaḥ eva iti
translated: Thus, even in the case of unrelated, different things, even in the non-difference of existence and non-existence, the relation of qualifier and qualified, characterized and characteristic, is proper, based on the power of distinction.

analyzed: yadi evam bhāva abhāvayoḥ abhāva bhāva dharmi tvam dharma dharmiṇoḥ ca abhedaḥ syāt
translated: If so, there would be the state of characterized and characteristic of existence and non-existence, and non-difference of the characterized and characteristic.

analyzed: tadā bhāvasya api abhāva tvena abhāvasya ca bhāva tvena
translated: Then, due to the existence being non-existence and the non-existence being existence,

analyzed: ghaṭa ādīnām bhāva tvam eva prāk pradhvaṃsa atyanta abhāvānām abhāva tvam eva iti niyamaḥ nirnibandhanaḥ syāt
translated: the rule that pots etc. are only existent and prior to destruction, and absolute non-existences are only non-existent would be groundless.

analyzed: na ca evam astu iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said to be so,

analyzed: sakala loka siddhasya tathābhāva anarha tvāt iti atas āha prathama iti
translated: because what is well-known to all people does not deserve to be so. Therefore he says 'in the first' etc.

analyzed: prathama pratipattiṣu
translated: In the first cognitions,

analyzed: niṣedha vidhi rūpa tvam bhāva abhāva tvam atra hi
translated: the form of negation and affirmation is existence and non-existence here.

analyzed: rūpa śabdaḥ dharmi vacanaḥ
translated: The word 'rūpa' (form) means the characterized.

analyzed: bhāva abhāva tvam iti yathāyogam sambandhaḥ
translated: The relation is 'existence and non-existence' as appropriate.

analyzed: atra evam sati api
translated: Here, even though this is so,

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ prasiddhau
translated: the word 'hi' (in fact) is for well-known fact.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: kim bhāva abhāva nibandhanam prameya rūpam anviṣyate pramāṇam vā
translated: Is the form of the object based on existence and non-existence being sought, or the means of knowledge?

analyzed: ādyasya uttara ardham uttaram
translated: The second half of the first [verse] is the answer.

analyzed: yadi api bhāva abhāva ātmakāḥ ghaṭa ādayaḥ prāgabhāva ādayaḥ ca
translated: Although pots and so on, and prior non-existence and so on, have the nature of existence and non-existence,

original: tathāpyatra padārthasārthe yaḥ piṇḍo vidhidharmiko ghaṭādiḥ sa bhāvo /
analyzed: tathā api atra padārtha sārthe yaḥ piṇḍaḥ vidhi dharmikaḥ ghaṭa ādiḥ sa
translated: nevertheless, in this collection of terms, the individual which is the subject of affirmation, such as a pot, is an existent.

original: yastu niṣedhadharmikaḥ prāgabhāvādiḥ so 'bhāva iti vyavasthopapadyate /
analyzed: yaḥ tu niṣedha dharmikaḥ prāgabhāva ādiḥ saḥ bhāvaḥ iti vyavasthā upapadyate
translated: But that which is the subject of negation, such as prior non-existence and so on, is a non-existent. Thus the distinction is logically possible.

analyzed: abhede pi dhamaḥ dharmi bhāvaḥ viśeṣa śaktyā saṅgacchate iti uktam eva
translated: Even in the absence of difference, the relation of attribute and possessor of attribute is accounted for by a special power, as already stated.

analyzed: dvitīyasya uttaram prathama pratipattiṣu iti
translated: The answer to the second [verse] is in the first cognitions.

original: yaḥ prathamaṃ vidhitayā parapratikṣeparūpatāṃ vinā pratīyate sa ghaṭādirbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ prathamam vidhi tayā para pratikṣepa rūpa tām vinā pratīyate sa ghaṭa ādiḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: That which is first cognized by affirmation, without the form of negating another, is an existent such as a pot.

original: yastu niṣedhatayā parapratikṣepeṇa pratīyate prāgabhāvādiḥ so 'bhāva ityuttarārdhenaikavākyatayā yojyam / /
analyzed: yaḥ tu niṣedha tayā para pratikṣepeṇa pratīyate prāgabhāva ādiḥ saḥ bhāvaḥ iti uttara ardhena ekavākyatayā yojyam
translated: But that which is cognized by negation, through the negation of another, such as prior non-existence and so on, is a non-existent. This should be connected as a single sentence with the second half.

original: ghaṭo hi prathamaṃ vidhitvena dharmirūpeṇa pratīto 'nantaraṃ paṭo na bhavatīti paṭaniṣedhātmatayā pratīyate /🔽prāgabhāvādirapi
analyzed: ghaṭaḥ hi prathamam vidhi tvena dharmi rūpeṇa pratītaḥ nantaram paṭaḥ na bhavati iti paṭa niṣedha ātma tayā pratīyate 🔽prāgabhāva ādiḥ api
translated: For a pot, which is first cognized as the possessor of the attribute in the form of affirmation, is subsequently cognized as having the nature of the negation of a cloth, it is not a cloth.🔽Prior non-existence and so on are also cognized as the possessor of the attribute in the form of negation, it is not a pot.

original: prathamaṃ niṣedhatvena dharmisvarūpeṇāvagato 'nantaraṃ prameya iti vidhitayā pratīyata iti sakalapratipattṛsiddhamiti bahuvacanahiśabdābhyāṃ 🔽dyotayati /
analyzed: prathamam niṣedha tvena dharmi svarūpeṇa avagataḥ nantaram prameyaḥ iti vidhitayā pratīyate iti sakala pratipattṛ siddham iti bahuvacana hi śabdābhyām  dyotayati
translated: First, being understood as the nature of the subject through negation, it is subsequently cognized as an object through affirmation. Thus, it is established for all cognizers. This is indicated by the plural particle hi.

analyzed: viṣayi viṣayayoḥ ādhāra ādheya bhāvam abhipretya saptamī prayogaḥ
translated: He uses the locative case with the intention of the relation of container and contained between the subject and object.

analyzed: kārakeṣu gauṇa mukhya tva vivakṣā bhāvasya sthita tvāt iti
translated: Since it is established that there is no distinction between primary and secondary in the case endings.

analyzed: evam pūrvapakṣi utprekṣita pramāṇa samudāya labdhasya arthasya pramāṇa virodhaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: Thus, the contradiction of the object obtained by the collection of means of knowledge imagined by the opponent is shown.

original: idānīmasatkāryaṃ yathā dṛṣṭamityanumānaṃ viśeṣato nirācikīrṣustatprastāvanāya asūtrayatsūtrakāraḥ oṃ apītau tadvatprasaṅgādasamañjasamiti /
analyzed: idānīm asatkāryam yathā dṛṣṭam iti anumānam viśeṣataḥ nirācikīrṣuḥ tad prastāvanāya asūtrayat sūtrakāraḥ om apītau tadvat prasaṅgāt asamañjasam iti
translated: Now, wishing to refute in particular the inference asat-kārya as seen, in order to introduce it, the author of the aphorisms formulated the aphorism: In dissolution, the consequence of its being so is incoherent.

analyzed: asamañjasam etat viśvasya abhāva kartṛkatva matam
translated: This doctrine of the universe being produced by non-existence is incoherent.🔽Why?

analyzed: kutas  abhāvasya eva
translated: Because,

analyzed: jagat kartṛ tva aṅgīkāre pītau pralaye tadvat prasaṅgāt abhāvavat tva prasaṅgāt  īśvara ādeḥ sarvasya api a
translated: even if the non-existence is accepted as the creator of the world, in dissolution, the consequence of its being so, the consequence of its being non-existent,🔽the consequence of accepting everything, including God, as

analyzed: bhāva abhyupagama prasaṅgāt iti yāvat
translated: existent. This is the meaning.

original: na hīśvarādau sati tatparityāgenābhāvasya jagatkartṛtvamavadhārayituṃ śakyamiti /
analyzed: na hi īśvara ādau sati tad parityāgena abhāvasya jagat kartṛ tvam avadhārayitum śakyam iti
translated: For, when God and so on exist, it is not possible to determine that non-existence is the cause of the world by abandoning that.

analyzed: nanu nā idam aniṣyam īśvara ādikam pralaye sat bhavitum arhati
translated: But this is not undesirable - God and so on should not become non-existent at the time of dissolution.

original: bhāvatvāt ghaṭavadityanumāneneśvarādeḥ sarvasya pralaye 'bhāvābhyupagamādityatroktaṃ sūtrakṛtāna tu dṛṣṭāntabhāvāt' / iti /
analyzed: bhāva tvāt ghaṭa vat iti anumānena īśvara ādeḥ sarvasya pralaye bhāva abhyupagamāt iti atra uktam sūtrakṛtā na tu dṛṣṭānta bhāvāt iti
translated: Because of the existence of an example, it is said in the sutra that all, including God, are not accepted as non-existent at the time of dissolution by the inference that they are existent like a pot.

analyzed: nā eva pralaye sarvasya asattvam aṅgīkartum ucitam
translated: It is not proper to accept the non-existence of everything at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: kasmāt dṛṣṭānta bhāvāt
translated: Why? Because of the existence of an example.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntaḥ iti tatra avadhārita vyāpti mūlam anumānam ucyate
translated: There, an inference based on a determined pervasion is called an example.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta mātrasya sādhana bādhana anaṅga tvāt  tathā ca pralaye parameśvara ādi sadbhāvasya
translated: Because mere examples are not a part of proof or refutation.

analyzed: sādhaka anumāna sambhavāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, because of the possibility of an inference proving the existence of the Supreme Lord and so on at the time of dissolution, that is the meaning.

analyzed: kim tat anumānam iti atas āha bhāṣyakāraḥ sarva nāśeṣu api iti
translated: What is that inference? For that reason, the author of the commentary says even in the destruction of all.

analyzed: apītau tadvat prasaṅgāt asamañjasam  /
translated: Because of the undesirable consequence of its existence even in dissolution, it is not reasonable.

original: sarvanāśeṣvapi sadā śiṣṭatvād yasya kasya nuḥ /
analyzed: sarva nāśeṣu api sadā śiṣṭa tvāt yasya kasya nuḥ
translated: Because of the existence of some unknown entity even in the destruction of all.

analyzed: nāśaḥ yam syāt nāśa tvāt kartṛ śeṣavān
translated: This destruction, though disputed, would also have a remainder of an agent, because of being a destruction.

analyzed: apiḥ abhivyāptau
translated: The word 'api' (also) is for including.

analyzed: sarva śabdaḥ vartamāna mātra vivakṣayā api syāt iti atas sadā iti uktam
translated: The word 'sarva' (all) might be used even with the intention of expressing only the present, therefore 'sat' (existing) is said.

analyzed: tat idam vyabhicāra parihārāya abhihitam
translated: This is stated for the purpose of avoiding fallacy.

analyzed: naḥ puruṣasya
translated: 'Naḥ' (of us).

original: ayamityasyaiva vivaraṇaṃ vimata iti /🔽atra pūrvārdhena vyāptiruktā /
analyzed: ayam iti asya eva vivaraṇam vimataḥ iti  atra pūrva ardhena vyāptiḥ uktā
translated: The explanation of 'ayam' (this) is 'vimata' (disputed).🔽Here, the pervasion is stated in the first half.

analyzed: uttara ardhena pratijñā hetū
translated: In the second half, the thesis and reason are stated.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: mahāpralaya lakṣaṇaḥ nāśaḥ puruṣa śeṣavān bhavitum arhati nāśa tvāt sampratipanna sammata
translated: Destruction characterized by the great dissolution should have a remainder of the soul, because of being a destruction, like the destruction that is commonly accepted.

analyzed: nāśa vat iti
translated: Like a known destruction.

analyzed: atra puruṣa avaśeṣa mātram sādhyam
translated: Here, only the mere remainder of the soul is to be proved.

analyzed: na tu nāśa kartuḥ puruṣasya avaśiṣya tā
translated: But not the remaining of the soul, the agent of destruction.

analyzed: atas eva uktam yasya kasya iti
translated: For this very reason, it is said 'of anyone'.

analyzed: nāśasya kartuḥ akartuḥ vā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: of the agent or non-agent of destruction.

analyzed: tathā api kartṛ śeṣavān iti vadatā idam abhipretam
translated: Nevertheless, by saying 'having a remainder of an agent', this is intended:

analyzed: pralaye puruṣa sadbhāva mātra sādhane sati bhagnam tāvat parasya anumānam
translated: When only the existence of the soul at the time of dissolution is being proved, the opponent's inference is refuted.

analyzed: yat api parasya abhāva kartṛkatvam jagataḥ bhimatam
translated: Even what is accepted by the opponent as the non-existence of an agent of the world,

analyzed: tat api atas eva apāstam  avaśiṣyasya puruṣa viśeṣa
translated: That also is refuted by the same argument.

analyzed: sya eva viśvakartṛ tva sambhave bhāvasya tad kalpanā anavakāśāt
translated: For when it is possible for a particular person alone to be the creator of the universe, there is no scope for postulating non-existence.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa anusāriṇī hi kalpanā
translated: For postulation follows what is seen.

original: nahi loke prāgutpatteḥ kulālābhāvayoḥ satorabhāvo ghaṭasya kartā dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: nahi loke prāk utpatteḥ kulāla abhāvayoḥ satoḥ abhāvaḥ ghaṭasya kartā dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: For in the world, prior to origination, the non-existence of the potter and the lump of clay, which exist, is not seen to be the maker of the pot.

analyzed: kinnāma kulālaḥ eva iti
translated: Rather, it is the potter alone.

original: abhiprāyamajānānaḥ kartṛśeṣavānityuktvā vibhrāntaścodayatiyatra sundopasundanyāyenāśeṣā api puruṣā naṣṭāstatra nāśatvahetoranaikāntikatā' /
analyzed: abhiprāyam a jānānaḥ kartṛ śeṣavān iti uktvā vibhrāntaḥ codayati yatra sunda upasunda nyāyena aśeṣāḥ api puruṣāḥ naṣṭāḥ tatra nāśa tva hetoḥ anaikāntika tā
translated: Not knowing the intention, having said that the remainder is the agent, and being confused, he objects that where all the men are destroyed by the Sundopasunda principle, there is non-exclusiveness of the reason of destruction.

analyzed: tatra āha na ca iti
translated: There he says not and so on.

analyzed: na ca aśeṣa nṛ nāśaḥ tu dṛṣṭaḥ dṛśyaḥ sti vā kvacid
translated: And the destruction of all men is not seen, is not seen, or does not exist anywhere.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word and is for determination.

original: aśeṣanṛnāśastu naiva kvaciddṛṣṭa ityatītaniṣedho /🔽dṛśyo vā naivetyanāgatasya /
analyzed: aśeṣa nṛ nāśaḥ tu nā eva kvacid dṛṣṭaḥ iti atīta niṣedhaḥ  dṛśyaḥ vā na eva iti anāgatasya
translated: The destruction of all men is not seen anywhere at all. This is the prohibition of the past.🔽Or it is not seen. This is of the future.

analyzed: na eva asti vā dṛśyamānaḥ iti vartamānasya
translated: Or it does not exist at all, being seen. This is of the present.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: anaikāntikatvaṃ hi pramite vipakṣe hetuvṛttau satyāṃhetuvṛttyā vaktavyam /
analyzed: anaikāntika tvam hi pramite vipakṣe hetu vṛttau satyām hetu vṛttyā vaktavyam
translated: For non-exclusiveness is to be stated when the presence of the reason is known in a contradictory example.

analyzed: na apramite
translated: Not when it is unknown.

analyzed: tathā sati anamina mātra uccheda prasaṅgāt
translated: And because, if that were so, there would be the undesirable consequence of the mere destruction of the non-bending (soul).

original: nacāśeṣapuruṣanāśaḥ kālatraye 'pi pramitaḥ /🔽yena nāśatvasya tatra vyabhicāraḥ syāt /
analyzed: na ca aśeṣa puruṣa nāśaḥ kāla traye pramitaḥ  yena nāśa tvasya tatra vyabhicāraḥ syāt
translated: And the destruction of all souls is not known to exist in the three times,🔽by which there would be a deviation of the nature of destruction in that (case).

analyzed: pramita tva aṅgīkāre ca pramātuḥ evā urvarita tvena vyāghātaḥ ca syāt
translated: And if existence is accepted, there would be a contradiction because only the knower would remain.

analyzed: naca nāśa kartuḥ puruṣasya avaśiṣya tā sādhya tvena iṣyā
translated: And the remaining of the soul, which is the agent of destruction, is not intended to be proved,

analyzed: yena sunda upasunda ādi nāśaḥ pratyudāhriyeta  kintu puruṣa vi
translated: by which the destruction of Sunda, Upasunda, etc. could be given as a counter-example.

analyzed: śeṣavat tva mātram iti
translated: But only the mere possession of a special quality of the soul.

analyzed: anena pralaya kālaḥ puruṣavān kāla tvāt idānīntana kāla vat iti api anumānam sūcitam
translated: By this, an inference is also indicated: The time of dissolution has a soul, because it is time, like the present time.

analyzed: na ca tadā kāla abhāvāt āśraya asiddhiḥ
translated: And it is not the case that the substratum is not established because time does not exist at that time,

analyzed: tathā sati tadā iti eva vaktum aśakya tvāt
translated: because if that were so, it would be impossible to speak of it as then.

analyzed: parakīya anumāne ca pralaya viśeṣaṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: And in the inference of others, the qualification of dissolution is not possible.

analyzed: yadi api atrakālaḥ ṅgīkriyate na vā
translated: Even though time is accepted here or not,

analyzed: ādye tatra eva bhāva tva hetoḥ vyabhicāraḥ
translated: in the first case, there is a deviation of the reason being an existent in that (time),

analyzed: dvitīye pralaya viśeṣaṇa anupapattiḥ
translated: in the second, the qualification of dissolution is not possible,

analyzed: sakala kārya vināśa viśiṣṭa kālasya pralaya tvāt
translated: because dissolution is the time qualified by the destruction of all effects.

original: atha kāryavināśa eva pralayastathāpīśvarābhāvasya tena sambandhābhāvādīśvarādikaṃ pralaye 'saditi pratijñārthānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: atha kārya vināśaḥ eva pralayaḥ tathā api īśvara abhāvasya tena sambandha abhāvāt īśvara ādikam pralaye sat iti pratijñā artha anupapattiḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, dissolution means the destruction of effects, then, since there is no connection between that and the non-existence of God, the proposition that God and so on do not exist at the time of dissolution is not established.

analyzed: deśa ādi dvārā sambandha abhyupagame tatra eva bhāva tvasya vyabhicāraḥ
translated: If a connection through space and so on is accepted, then existence is seen to be absent there.

analyzed: pralaya viśeṣaṇa parityāge tat śiṣyaiḥ eva uhyatām iti na sūtra bhāṣyakārābhyām abhihitam
translated: When the qualification of dissolution is abandoned, it should be inferred by the disciples themselves, so it has not been stated by the author of the aphorisms and the commentary.

analyzed: sūcitam ca api itau iti sūtrakṛtā
translated: And it is also indicated in the aphorism by the author.

analyzed: laye mānam ca kim bhavet
translated: And what could be the proof of dissolution?

analyzed: iti bhāṣyakṛtā api  tat idam jīva īśvara sādhāraṇam anumānam uktam
translated: Thus it has been stated by the author of the commentary also.🔽This inference is stated as common to the individual soul and God.

analyzed: idānīm pralaye jīva sadbhāva sādhakam anumānam āha dharma iti
translated: Now, the author states an inference proving the existence of the individual soul at the time of dissolution, with the words Dharma and so on.

analyzed: dharma adharma āśraya tvena svīkāryaḥ pi naraḥ laye
translated: The individual soul should be accepted as the substratum of dharma and adharma at the time of dissolution,

analyzed: na kevalam ukta anumānena
translated: not only by the previously stated inference,

analyzed: kinnāma dharma adharma śraya tvena api iti sambandhaḥ
translated: but also as the substratum of dharma and adharma, this is the connection.

analyzed: naraḥ jīva ātmā
translated: The individual soul is the soul of the individual.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:
The dharma that exists at the time of dissolution has a substratum, because it is dharma, like the dharma that exists now.

analyzed: evam adharmam api pakṣīkṛtya prayoktavyam
translated: In the same way, taking non-existence as the probandum, it should be employed.

analyzed: na ca dharma adharma āśrayaḥ jīvātmanaḥ sambhavati
translated: And the soul cannot be other than the substratum of dharma and adharma.

analyzed: evam ca pralaye jīvātma sadbhāvāt bhāva mātrā sattva sādhanam anupapannam iti
translated: And thus, since the individual soul exists at the time of dissolution, the proof that mere existence does not exist is not proper.

analyzed: yatra īśvara sadbhāva sādhanam idam
translated: And this is the proof of the existence of God.

analyzed: āśraya śabdasya adhiṣṭhātṛ para tvāt
translated: Because the word 'substratum' refers to the controller.

analyzed: tatra evam prayogaḥ
translated: There, the argument is as follows:

analyzed: pralaya kāla vartinau dharma adharmau kenacid adhiṣṭhitau
translated: Dharma and adharma existing at the time of dissolution are controlled by someone.

analyzed: kāraṇa tve sati acetana tvāt
translated: Because they are causes and non-sentient.

analyzed: vāśi ādi vat iti
translated: Like a rope, etc.

analyzed: na ca atīndriyayoḥ dharma adharmayoḥ adhiṣṭhātṛ tvam īśvarāt anyasya upapadyate
translated: And the control over dharma and adharma, which are beyond the senses, is not possible for anyone other than God.

original: ato dharmādharmādhiṣṭhātṛtvenāpi naraḥ paramapuruṣo laye svīkārya iti / /
analyzed: atas dharma adharma adhiṣṭhātṛ tvena api naraḥ paramapuruṣaḥ laye svīkāryaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, even as the controller of dharma and adharma, the Supreme Person should be accepted at the time of dissolution.

original: nanu pralaye bhāvamātrasyāsattvamabhyupagacchato mama tadā dharmādharmāvapi na sta evetyāśrayāsiddhiriti /
analyzed: nanu pralaye bhāva mātrasya asattvam abhyupagacchataḥ mama tadā dharma adharmau api na staḥ eva iti āśraya asiddhiḥ iti
translated: But if you accept the non-existence of mere existence at the time of dissolution, then dharma and adharma also do not exist at that time, so the substratum is not established.

analyzed: idam iha vaktavyam
translated: This should be stated here:

original: kiṃ dharmādharmasaṃjñitamadṛṣṭamasti kāryamātrasya kāraṇaṃ ca bhavatītyabhyupagamya pralaye tadabhāvo 'bhīdhīyate /
analyzed: kim dharma adharma saṃjñitam adṛṣṭam asti kārya mātrasya kāraṇam ca bhavati iti abhyupagamya pralaye tad abhāvaḥ bhīdhīyate
translated: Is it that, accepting that there is an unseen [entity] called Dharma and Adharma which is the cause of mere effects, it is said that it does not exist at the time of dissolution?🔽Or, accepting that it exists, [is it said that] it is not a cause?

analyzed: uta sat api tat akāraṇam iti abhyupetya  atha tat eva na asti iti aṅgīkṛtya
translated: Or, accepting that it does not exist at all, [is it said that] it is not a cause?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati anādi tvam iti
translated: He refutes the first [view] with [the verse beginning with] Without beginninglessness.

original: anāditvaṃ vinādṛṣṭaṃ kathaṃ syāt kāraṇaṃ kvacit // / / //
analyzed: anādi tvam vinā adṛṣṭam katham syāt kāraṇam kvacid
translated: How could the unseen be a cause anywhere without beginninglessness?

analyzed: anādi tvam iva anādi tvam pralaye sattvam iti arthaḥ
translated: Without beginninglessness means existing at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: kvacid iti sṛṣṭi kāle
translated: Anywhere means at the time of creation.

original: yadyadṛṣṭaṃ pralaye na syāttadā'dikālīnasya kāryasya kāraṇaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: yadi adṛṣṭam pralaye na syāt tad ādi kālīnasya kāryasya kāraṇam na syāt
translated: If the unseen did not exist at the time of dissolution, it could not be the cause of the effect that existed at the beginning of time.

analyzed: asataḥ kāraṇa tva ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for a non-existent to be a cause.

analyzed: tathā ca sarva utpattimatām nimittam iti abhyupagamaḥ bhagnaḥ iti atharḥ
translated: And thus the acceptance that it is the cause of all that is produced is destroyed - this is the meaning.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: adhunātana kāryam adṛṣṭa kāraṇakam na tu ādi kālīnam iti mama abhyupagamaḥ
translated: I accept that the present effect has an unseen cause, but not the one that existed at the beginning of time.

analyzed: tat kim adṛṣṭasya pralaye sadbhāvena iti atas āha anādi tvam iti
translated: Then, what is the point of saying that the unseen exists at the time of dissolution? Therefore [the author] says Without beginninglessness.

original: anāditvaṃ vinā tata evādikālīnakāyarkāraṇatvaṃ ca vinādṛṣṭaṃ kvacidadhunātane 'pi kārye kāraṇaṃ kathaṃ syāt /
analyzed: anādi tvam vinā tatas eva ādi kālīna ca vinā adṛṣṭam kvacid adhunātane kārye kāraṇam katham syāt
translated: Without beginning, and without being the cause of the primordial effects, how could it be the cause of any present effect, without being seen?

analyzed: na kathañcid
translated: In no way.

analyzed: adhunātanam kāryam adṛṣṭa kāraṇakam na
translated: The present effect is not one whose cause is not seen.

analyzed: kārya tvāt ādi kālīna kārya vat iti anumāna sambhavāt
translated: Because the inference is possible that it is an effect because it is an effect like the primordial effect.

analyzed: na ced idam iva tat api adṛṣṭa kāryam eva aṅgīkāryam iti
translated: And if this is not so, then that also must be accepted as an effect whose cause is not seen.

analyzed: yat vā mā bhūt ādi kālīnasya kāryasya adṛṣṭam kāraṇam
translated: Or, let the cause of the primordial effect not be unseen.

analyzed: tathā api pralaye tad bhāvaḥ ṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: Even so, its existence at the time of dissolution must be accepted.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: anādi tvam pralaye sattvam
translated: Beginninglessness and existence at the time of dissolution.

original: vinādṛṣṭaṃ kvacididānīntane 'pi kārye kāraṇaṃ kathaṃ syāt /
analyzed: vinā adṛṣṭam kvacid idānīntane pi kārye kāraṇam katham syāt
translated: Without being seen, how could it be the cause of any present effect, without being seen?

analyzed: antarāle eva adṛṣṭa utpatti ayogāt iti yojyam
translated: It should be connected as follows: because it is impossible for the unseen to arise in the interval.

analyzed: nanu adṛṣṭasya sarva utpattimat nimitta tve pi na pralaye sadbhāvaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: Even if the unseen is the cause of everything that arises, its existence at the time of dissolution need not be accepted.

analyzed: ādi kāle eva utpannasya api mahat ādi kāraṇa tva upapatteḥ iti
translated: Because it is possible that even what arises at the beginning of time is the cause of Mahat and so on.

analyzed: idam atra vaktavyam
translated: This should be stated here.

original: tadādikāle janimadadṛṣṭaṃ tataḥ pūrvādṛṣṭādutpadyate na veti /
analyzed: tad ādi kāle janimat adṛṣṭam tatas pūrva adṛṣṭāt utpadyate na vā iti
translated: Whether that unseen force at the beginning of creation is produced from a prior unseen force or not.

analyzed: ādyam upādatte pūrvā iti
translated: He accepts the first view with from a prior.

analyzed: pūrva adṛṣṭāt para adṛṣṭam yadi na eva uttaram kutas
translated: If the subsequent unseen force is not produced from a prior unseen force, then how can it arise?

analyzed: jāyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is is produced.

analyzed: pariharati na eva iti
translated: He replies with not at all.

original: evaṃ tarhi taduttaramādikāle janimadadṛṣṭaṃ naivāsmābhiḥ pakṣīkriyate /
analyzed: evam tarhi tat uttaram ādi kāle janimat adṛṣṭam na eva asmābhiḥ pakṣīkriyate
translated: In that case, we do not accept that unseen force at the beginning of creation, which is produced later, as our thesis.

original: kintu tatkāraṇaṃ pralayakālīnaṃ pūrvādṛṣṭameveti kuta āśrayāsiddhiriti /
analyzed: kintu tad kāraṇam pralaya kālīnam pūrva adṛṣṭam eva iti kutas āśraya asiddhiḥ iti
translated: But its cause is the prior unseen force at the time of dissolution. So how can there be an unestablished basis?

analyzed: dvitīyam upādatte pūrvā iti
translated: He accepts the second view with prior.

analyzed: na eva utpadyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is is not produced at all.

analyzed: dūṣayati uttaram iti
translated: He criticizes with subsequent.

analyzed: tarhi tat uttaram ādi kālīnam adṛṣṭam kutas jāyate
translated: In that case, how is that subsequent unseen force at the beginning of creation produced?

analyzed: na kutaścid
translated: From nothing.

analyzed: sarva utpattimat nimittasya adṛṣṭasya abhāvāt ādi kālīna adṛṣṭa utpattiḥ eva na syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the production of the primordial unseen force itself would not occur due to the absence of an unseen cause for all that is produced.

analyzed: na brūmaḥ vayam sarvam kāryam adṛṣṭa janyam iti
translated: We do not say that all effects are produced by unseen forces.

original: kiṃ tarhyādikāle janimato mahadādikāraṇādadṛṣṭādanyadevāto noktadoṣa ityāśaṅkāmutthāpya dūṣayati pūrveti //
analyzed: kim tarhi ādi kāle janimataḥ mahat ādi kāraṇāt adṛṣṭāt anyat eva atas na ukta doṣaḥ iti āśaṅkām utthāpya dūṣayati pūrva iti
translated: Then what? From the unseen force that is the cause of Mahat etc. at the beginning of creation, there is something else. So the stated fault does not apply to us. Raising this doubt, he refutes it with prior.

analyzed: yadi para adṛṣṭam sṛṣṭay upakrame janimat pūrva adṛṣṭāt na eva utpadyate  api tu adṛṣṭa nirapekṣam eva
translated: If what is seen is not produced from a prior unseen [cause], but is produced only independently of an unseen [cause],

analyzed: tarhi kutas dṛṣṭāt utpadyate iti aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: then why should the subsequent body of Mahat and so on be accepted as produced from an unseen [cause]?

analyzed: adṛṣṭa vat tasya api adṛṣṭi nirapekṣa tva sambhavāt
translated: Because it is possible that it too is independent of an unseen [cause], like the unseen [cause].

analyzed: anyathā kārya tvāt adṛṣṭasya api adṛṣṭa apekṣā aṅgīkāryā iti
translated: Otherwise, because it is an effect, the unseen [cause] would have to be accepted as dependent on an unseen [cause].

original: astu tarhyadṛṣṭaṃ kāraṇameva na bhavatīti dvitīyaḥ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: astu tarhi adṛṣṭam kāraṇam eva na bhavati iti dvitīyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: Well then, let the second alternative be that the unseen [cause] is not a cause at all.

analyzed: adṛṣṭam eva na asti iti tṛtīyaḥ vā
translated: Or let the third alternative be that the unseen [cause] itself does not exist.

analyzed: ubhayasya api anupalambhāt
translated: Because both are not perceived.

analyzed: tathā ca āśraya asiddhiḥ aparihāryā iti āśaṅkayā āha adṛṣṭam iti
translated: And thus, the non-establishment of the substratum cannot be avoided. With this doubt in mind, he says the unseen [cause]

original: adṛṣṭaṃ kāraṇaṃ no cellaye mānaṃ ca kiṃ bhavet // / / //
analyzed: adṛṣṭam kāraṇam no ced laye mānam ca kim bhavet
translated: If the unseen [cause] is not a cause, then what would be the evidence for dissolution?

analyzed: yadi pratyakṣeṇa anupalambhāt adṛṣṭam na syāt
translated: If the unseen [cause] would not exist due to non-perception by direct perception,

analyzed: sat api vā kāraṇam na syāt
translated: or if it would not be a cause even though it exists,

original: tadā laye ca kiṃ mānaṃ bhavet /🔽pralayo 'pyaprāmāṇikatvānna syāt /
analyzed: tadā laye ca kim mānam bhavet  pralayaḥ pi aprāmāṇika tvāt na syāt
translated: then what would be the evidence for dissolution?🔽Dissolution too would not exist due to lack of evidence.

analyzed: na hi asau api pratyakṣeṇa upalabhyate
translated: For that too is not perceived by direct perception.

analyzed: tathā ca īśvara ādikam pralaye sat bhavitum arhati iti aprasiddha viśeṣaṇaḥ pakṣaḥ parasya api syāt
translated: And so, the proposition of the opponent also would have an unknown qualifier, since God and so on would have to become non-existent at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: atha matam  kāla viprakarṣāt an upalabhabhya
translated: Now, if it is thought:

analyzed: pralayaḥ numāna siddha tvāt aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: Even though dissolution is not perceived due to the lapse of time, it should be accepted because it is established by inference.

analyzed: tathā hi  viśva santānaḥ yam dṛśya santāna śūnyaiḥ
translated: To explain:

analyzed: bhiḥ ārabdhaḥ santāna tvāt āraṇeya santāna vat
translated: This continuum of the universe is produced by the inhering causes that are devoid of the continuum of the visible, because it is a continuum, like the continuum of the son of a barren woman.

original: vartamānabrahmāṇḍaparamāṇavaḥ pūrvamutpāditasajātīyasantānāntarāḥ nityatve sati tadārambhakatvāt pradīpaparamāṇuvat /
analyzed: vartamāna brahmāṇḍa paramāṇavaḥ pūrvam utpādita sajātīya santāna antarāḥ nitya tve sati tad ārambhaka tvāt pradīpa paramāṇu vat
translated: The present atoms of the universe have produced other homogeneous continua before, because they are eternal and are the cause of that, like the atoms of a lamp.

analyzed: sarve santānāḥ kadācid saha ucchidyante santāna tvāt pradīpa santāna vat
translated: All continua are sometimes destroyed together, because they are continua, like the continuum of a lamp.

original: sarva eva paramāṇavaḥ kadācitsamagropādeyaprabandhaśūnyāḥ ārambhakatvāt naṣṭapavanārambhakaparamāṇuvat /
analyzed: sarve eva paramāṇavaḥ kadācid samagra upādeya prabandha śūnyāḥ ārambhaka tvāt naṣṭa pavana ārambhaka paramāṇu vat
translated: All atoms are sometimes devoid of the series that are to be taken together, because they are causes, like the atoms that are the cause of the destroyed wind.

analyzed: bhū golaka santānaḥ kadācid sākalyena ucchidyate santāna tvāt dīpa santāna vat
translated: The continuum of the earth-globe is sometimes destroyed completely, because it is a continuum, like the continuum of a lamp.

original: iyaṃ kriyā svānyāvayayikālīnatvānadhikaraṇakiñcitkālīnakriyānyā kriyātvādanyakriyāvaditi /🔽evaṃ tarhi dharmādharmāvapi svarūpato viprakṛṣṭatvādanupalabhyamānāvapi devadattaśarīrādikaṃ
analyzed: iyam kriyā sva anya avayayi kālīna tva anadhikaraṇa kiñcid kālīna kriyā anyā kriyā tvāt anya kriyā vat iti  evam tarhi dharma adharmau api svarūpataḥ viprakṛṣṭa tvāt anupalabhyamānau api devadatta śarīra ādikam
translated: This action is different from another action which is not related to any time other than its own parts, because it is an action, like another action.🔽If so, then virtue and vice, though imperceptible due to being remote in nature, are also to be accepted as established by inference,🔽by the non-apprehension of the effect of the body of Devadatta,

analyzed: devadatta viśeṣa guṇa janyam kārya tve sati devadatta bhoga hetu tvāt devadatta prayatna janya sraj ādi vat ityādi anumānena
translated: by the non-apprehension of the effect of virtue and vice,

original: vicitrakāryānyathānupapattyā /🔽jyotiṣyomena svargakāmo yajeta' /🔽yo brāhmaṇāyāvagurettaṃ śatena yātayāye
analyzed: vicitra kārya anyathā anupapattyā  jyotiṣyomena svarga kāmaḥ yajeta  yaḥ brāhmaṇāya avaguret tam śatena yātayāye
translated: by the non-apprehension of the effect of the sacrifice,🔽by the non-apprehension of the effect of the Vedic injunction One desiring heaven should sacrifice with the Jyotiṣṭoma,🔽by the non-apprehension of the effect of the Vedic injunction One who insults a Brahmin should be fined one hundred,

analyzed: ityādi śruta sādhya sādhana bhāva anyathā anupapattyā vā siddha tvāt abhyupagantavyau iti samam samādhānam
translated: and so on.

analyzed: atha manyase
translated: If you think:

analyzed: na anumāna ādinā dharma ādi siddhiḥ
translated: Virtue and vice are not established by inference, etc.

analyzed: tasya ābhāsa tvāt
translated: Because that is fallacious.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus:

analyzed: devadatta śarīra ādeḥ devadatta viśeṣa guṇa janya tvam kim sākṣāt sādhyam uta paramparayā
translated: Is the fact that the body of Devadatta is produced by the special qualities of Devadatta to be directly inferred or indirectly?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: dharma adharmayoḥ api ārambhaka preraṇa ādi rūpeṇa eva upayoga aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because it is accepted that even Dharma and Adharma are useful only in the form of instigating the beginning of actions.

analyzed: devadatta śarīram na sākṣāt devadatta viśeṣa guṇa janyam śarīra tvāt yajñadatta śarīra vat iti sat pratipakṣa tvāt ca
translated: And because there is a counter-argument: Devadatta's body is not directly produced by Devadatta's specific qualities, because it is a body, like Yajnadatta's body.

analyzed: dvitīye tu janma antarīya prayatna ārādhita devatā dvāreṇa upapatteḥ artha antara tā
translated: But in the second case, because it is possible through the door of the deity worshipped by effort in a previous birth, it is a different matter.

original: devadattaviśeṣaguṇajanyatayā vināpi ākāśāderiveśvarecchayā devadattasya bhogahetutā sambhavatītyaprayojakatā ca /
analyzed: devadatta viśeṣa guṇa janyatayā vinā api ākāśa ādeḥ iva īśvara icchayā devadattasya bhoga hetutā sambhavati iti aprayojaka tā ca
translated: And because even without being produced by Devadatta's specific qualities, like space etc., Devadatta's status as the cause of enjoyment is possible by the will of God, it is not a conclusive reason.

analyzed: kārya vaicitryam ca dṛṣṭa kāraṇa vaicitryāt eva upapadyate
translated: And the variety of effects is possible only from the variety of seen causes.

analyzed: ādi kālīnam ca tad tad prāgabhāvaḥ eva vaicitrya aṅgīkāreṇa
translated: And in the case of accepting the variety of the prior non-existence of each thing in the beginningless time.

analyzed: sva gar yāga ādeḥ sādhya sādhana bhāva śravaṇam tu asiddham eva yogyatā virahāt
translated: But the statement of the relation between means and end in the case of one's own heaven etc. is itself unestablished, due to the absence of fitness.

analyzed: anyathā khyātim āśritya abhyupagame
translated: If it is accepted by resorting to misapprehension, it is not established in another way.

analyzed: yāga ādi ārādhita avajñāta devatā dvāreṇa svarga ādi upapatteḥ iti 🔽evam tarhi pralaya sādhaka anumānānām api a
translated: Because heaven etc. is possible through the door of the deity worshipped by sacrifice etc.

analyzed: bhāsa tvāt na taiḥ tad siddhiḥ iti tulyam uttaram
translated: The reply is the same, that it is not established by them because of the existence of light.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Indeed,

analyzed: vimataḥ kālaḥ vaya viyuktaḥ kāla tvāt idānīntana kāla vat
translated: the disputed time is devoid of parts, because it is time, like the present time.

original: vimato brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇapūrvako brāhmaṇatvātsammatavadityādinā satpratipakṣaṃ tāvaduktānumānajātam /
analyzed: vimataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ brāhmaṇa pūrvakaḥ brāhmaṇa tvāt sammata vat ityādinā sat pratipakṣam tāvat ukta anumāna jātam
translated: The disputed Brahmin is preceded by a Brahmin, because he is a Brahmin, like a recognized one. Thus, the class of inferences stated is first of all opposed by a counter-argument.

analyzed: nanu pralaya kāla pakṣīkṛtau āśraya asiddhiḥ
translated: But if the time of dissolution is taken as the subject, there is non-establishment of the substratum.

analyzed: anyathā siddha sādhanam
translated: Otherwise, it is a futile rejoinder.

analyzed: evam ādya brāhmaṇa pakṣīkāre nyathā ca doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: Similarly, if the first Brahmin is taken as the subject, there is a fault in the other case. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: parvataḥ gnimān ityādau api agnimat anagnimat pakṣa dūṣaṇa sambhavena sarva anumāna uccheda prasaṅgāt
translated: Because even if the mountain is fiery, etc., and the subject is faulty, there is the contingence of the destruction of all inference.

analyzed: nanu agnimat tva divi arirekeṇa api asti parvata ādeḥ svarūpam
translated: But apart from being fiery, etc., there is a form of the mountain, etc.

analyzed: śakyam ca viśeṣa antareṇa avadhārayitum
translated: And it is possible to determine it by another attribute.

analyzed: tat katham doṣa avakāśaḥ iti ced
translated: If this is said, how is there room for a fault?

analyzed: tat kim avayavi sambandha asambandhau vihāya kāla viśeṣasya svarūpam eva nā asti
translated: Then, apart from the connection and non-connection with the whole, is there no form of the particular time at all?

analyzed: brāhmaṇa vyakteḥ vādya tva anādya tve vihāya
translated: Or, apart from the first and non-firstness of the Brahmin individual?

analyzed: avadhāraṇam ca kāla ādeḥ hiraṇyagarbha apavarga uttararga anantara
translated: And the determination of time etc. is after the liberation of Hiranyagarbha, immediately after.

analyzed: bhāvi tva ādinā bhaviṣyati
translated: And the determination of time, etc., will be by the fact of their existence after the liberation of Hiranyagarbha and others.

original: kiñca prathamaprayoge viśvaśabdena kiṃ brahmāṇḍamabhipreyate sakalakāryāṇi vā /
analyzed: kiñca prathama prayoge viśva śabdena kim brahmāṇḍam abhipreyate sakala kāryāṇi vā
translated: Moreover, in the first argument, does the word universe refer to the cosmic egg or to all effects?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ  aśraya asiddheḥ
translated: Not the first.🔽Because of the non-establishment of the substratum.

analyzed: pralayam an abhyupagacchatā brahmāṇḍasya an aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because one who does not accept dissolution does not accept the existence of the cosmic egg.

analyzed: brahmāṇḍa abhāve pi kārya antara avasthiti sambhavena pralaya asiddheḥ ca
translated: And because dissolution is not established by the possibility of the existence of other effects even in the absence of the cosmic egg.

analyzed: kapi kapola antargata audumbara udara varti maśaka śarīra ādi vat kārya antara avasthānam asambhāvitam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the existence of other effects is not possible, like the body of a cricket inside the belly of a fig fruit inside the cheek of a monkey, that is not so.

analyzed: kuṇḍa badara vat upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is logically possible like a fig fruit.
Because the process of Kālāgni Rudra, etc. is not established.

analyzed: dvitīye pi na pralaya siddhiḥ
translated: In the second case also, dissolution is not established.

original: yathā hīdānīntanānāṃ dahanapavanasantānānāṃ krameṇāstamaye 'pi na pralayastathā tarugiriśarīrādisantānānāmapi kramārambhasiddhāvapyavayaviśūnyasamayā 🔽siddheḥ /
analyzed: yathā hi idānīntanānām dahana pavana santānānām krameṇa astamaye na pralayaḥ tathā taru giri śarīra ādi santānānām api krama ārambha siddhau api avayavi śūnya samayā 🔽siddheḥ
translated: Just as there is no dissolution even when the series of fire and wind of the present time gradually disappear, similarly, even when the gradual beginning of the series of trees, mountain bodies, etc. is established, there is no establishment of a time devoid of wholes.

original: athaikadaiveti viśeṣaṇamupādīyeta tadā kramārabdhadahanapavanādisantānairvyabhicāraḥ syāt /🔽ekadarambhakahetusākalye satīti hetuviśeṣaṇe viśeṣaṇāsiddhiḥ /
analyzed: atha ekadā eva iti viśeṣaṇam upādīyeta tadā krama ārabdha dahana pavana ādi santānaiḥ vyabhicāraḥ syāt  eka darambhaka hetu sākalye sati iti hetu viśeṣaṇe viśeṣaṇa asiddhiḥ
translated: If the qualification 'at one time' is added, then there would be invalidation by the series of fire, wind, etc. started at one time.🔽If the reason is qualified as 'when there is completeness of the cause that brings about one', then the qualification is unestablished.

analyzed: dvayaṇuka ādi krameṇa ārambha svīkāreṇa bādhā ādi prasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: And there would be the undesirable consequence of invalidation, etc., by accepting the creation through the series of dyads and so on.

analyzed: etena dvitīya anumānam api nirastam
translated: By this, the second inference is also refuted.

analyzed: brahmāṇḍa an abhyupagamāt  abhyupagame pi avayavānām āvāpa uddhārābhyām eva utpāda vināśayoḥ upapatteḥ
translated: Because the universe is not accepted.🔽Even if it is accepted, creation and destruction are possible only through the addition and subtraction of parts.

analyzed: kārya antara avasthāna upapatteḥ ca
translated: And because the existence of other effects is possible.

analyzed: tṛtīye pi apasiddhāntaḥ
translated: In the third [reason], there is the fallacy of contradicting one's own doctrine.

analyzed: krameṇa ucchedasya abhyupagama atatvāt
translated: Because the destruction through the series is accepted as a fact.

analyzed: caturthe pi paṭa ādibhyaḥ pūrva vinaṣṭaiḥ tantu ādibhiḥ vyarbhicāraḥ
translated: In the fourth [reason], there is invalidation by the previously destroyed threads, etc. from cloth, etc.

analyzed: paramāṇu tvena hetu viśeṣaṇe pi dvayaṇuka ādi avasthāna sambhavena dṛṣṭāntasya sandigdha sādhya tā
translated: Even if the reason is qualified as 'being an atom', the example has a doubtful probandum, because the state of dyads and so on is possible.

original: pañcame 'pi kiṃ bhūgolakā eva santānaśabdenocyante tadatirikto vā kaścit /
analyzed: pañcame pi kim bhū golakāḥ eva santāna śabdena ucyante tad atiriktaḥ vā kaścid
translated: In the fifth [reason], are only the earth-spheres referred to by the word 'series', or is something else than that?

analyzed: ādye siddhasādhanam
translated: In the first case, [the reason] is the establishment of what is already established.

analyzed: avayavānām āvāpa uddhārābhyām santata utpatti vināśa siddheḥ
translated: Because the production and destruction of the parts is established by the addition and subtraction of the parts.

analyzed: dvitīye tu āśraya asiddhiḥ
translated: But in the second case, there is non-establishment of the substratum.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭham tu ābhāsa samāna yogakṣema tvāt upekṣaṇīyam iti
translated: But the sixth [reason] is to be disregarded because it has the same fate as the fallacious [reason].

analyzed: atha mā bhūt anumānaiḥ pralaya siddhiḥ
translated: Now, let there be no establishment of dissolution by inference.

analyzed: tathā api āgamaiḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Even so, it will be by scriptures.

analyzed: teṣām siddhārthe pi prāmāṇyasya sādhita tvāt
translated: Because the validity of those [scriptures] has been established even with regard to established meanings.

analyzed: tatas na aprasiddha viśeṣaṇa tā iti brūṣe
translated: Therefore, you say that there is no fallacy of the reason being not established.

analyzed: tarhi asmākam api dharma ādi siddhiḥ āgamāt bhaviṣyati iti katham āśraya asiddhiḥ iti
translated: Then, for us also, the establishment of dharma, etc. will be from scripture. So how is there non-establishment of the substratum?

original: evaṃ pralaye jīveśvarasadbhāvaṃ sādhayatā dharmādisattvamapi sādhitamiti na pralaye bhāvamātrāsattvasādhanaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: evam pralaye jīveśvara sadbhāvam sādhayatā dharma ādi sattvam api sādhitam iti na pralaye bhāva mātra asattva sādhanam yuktam
translated: Thus, one who establishes the existence of the individual soul and God at the time of dissolution has also established the existence of dharma, etc. So it is not proper to establish the non-existence of mere existence at the time of dissolution.

original: evam ādikāryaṃ pakṣīkṛtya sopādānatvasādhane prakṛtyādisiddhirapi draṣṭavyeti / /
analyzed: evam ādikāryam pakṣīkṛtya sopādānatva sādhane prakṛti ādi siddhiḥ api draṣṭavyā iti
translated: Similarly, when proving that the primordial matter, etc. exist, it should be seen that the primordial matter, etc. are established even when proving that the primordial matter, etc. are the material cause by taking the primordial effect as the subject.

analyzed: prathama sūtre bhāvasya kartṛ tva nirāsāya anumānam uktam
translated: In the first aphorism, an inference was stated to refute the agency of non-existence.

analyzed: idānīm itas na abhāva kartṛkam jagat
translated: Now, the world is not created by non-existence.

analyzed: cetana kartṛkatve idṛṣṭānta bhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of an example for being created by an intelligent agent.

original: iti sūtrasya vṛttyantaramabhipretya cetanakartṛkatve anumānamāha utpattīti //
analyzed: iti sūtrasya vṛtti antaram abhipretya cetana kartṛkatve anumānam āha utpatti iti
translated: Having in mind another interpretation of the Sūtra, he states an inference in favor of the existence of an intelligent cause, in the words, The producer of origination and destruction is seen to be intelligent in some cases.

analyzed: utpatti nāśa kārī hi buddhimān dṛśyate kvacid
translated: The producer of origination and destruction is seen to be intelligent in some cases.

analyzed: tad dṛṣṭāntena sarvatra kartā kim nā anumīyate
translated: By that example, why is not the cause inferred in all cases?

analyzed: buddhimān utpatti nāśa kārī iti buddhi pūrvam tad kartā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the intelligent one is the producer of origination and destruction, he is the cause of that with intelligence.

analyzed: kvacid paṭa ādau
translated: In some cases, in a cloth, etc.

analyzed: sarvatra vipratipanne kārye
translated: In all cases, in the disputed effect.
