analyzed: mahat ādi kārye iti eva ukte ṅkura ādau vyabhicāraḥ śaṅkayeta
translated: If it is said only in the effect beginning with Mahat, it may be suspected that there is deviation in the sprout, etc.

analyzed: tad artham tasya api pakṣa nikṣepa artham sarvatra iti uktam
translated: For the purpose of including that also in the subject, in all cases is said.

analyzed: kartā buddhimān iti śeṣaḥ  anyathābhāva kartṛ tva vādinam
translated: The rest is the cause is intelligent.

analyzed: prati siddha sādhana tā prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the contingence of the establishment of what is already established against one who maintains the existence of a cause that is not an intelligent being.

analyzed: kim ākṣepe
translated: Why? is used for a question.

analyzed: ananumāne na kim api kāraṇam
translated: In the absence of inference, there is no reason at all.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta abhāvena pratipakṣa asambhavāt iti arthaḥ  etena sva pakṣa doṣāt ca
translated: The meaning is that the counter-argument is not possible due to the absence of an example.🔽By this, the Sūtra And because of the fault in one's own position

analyzed: iti sūtram api vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: is also explained.

analyzed: ayam atra prayoga kramaḥ
translated: Here is the sequence of reasoning:

analyzed: vimatam kāryam cetanā utpādyam kārya tvāt ghaṭa vat
translated: The disputed effect is produced by an intelligent being, because it is an effect, like a pot.

original: cetanavināśyaṃ ca tata eva tadvadeva /🔽vimatotpattiścetanakartṛkā utpattitvātpaṭotpattivat /
analyzed: cetana vināśyam ca tatas eva tadvat eva  vimata utpattiḥ cetana kartṛkā utpatti tvāt paṭa utpatti vat
translated: And it is to be destroyed by an intelligent being, for the same reason, like that [pot].🔽The production of the disputed [entity] is by an intelligent agent, because it is a production, like the production of a cloth.

analyzed: vimataḥ vināśaḥ cetana kartṛkaḥ vināśa tvāt sammata vat iti
translated: The destruction of the disputed [entity] is by an intelligent agent, because it is a destruction, like what is agreed upon.

analyzed: atra vināśasya cetana kartṛka tva sādhanam prāsaṅgikam
translated: Here, the proof that destruction is caused by an intelligent being is incidental.

original: yadvā kecitkāraṇasya bījādeḥ pradhvaṃsenāṅkurādeḥ janmadarśanāttantvādināśena paṭādināśadaśarnācca pradhvaṃsābhāvasyaiva jagajjanmavināśakartṛtvamāsthitāḥ
analyzed: yat vā kecid kāraṇasya bīja ādeḥ pradhvaṃsena aṅkura ādeḥ janma darśanāt tantu ādi nāśena paṭa ādi nāśa daśarnāt ca pradhvaṃsa abhāvasya eva jagat janma vināśa kartṛ tvam āsthitāḥ
translated: Or, some, seeing the birth of a sprout etc. from the destruction of a seed etc., which is a cause, and seeing the destruction of a cloth etc. from the destruction of threads etc., maintain that only the absence of destruction is the cause of the birth and destruction of the world.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: na an upamṛdya prādurbhāvāt iti
translated: Because of the appearance without destruction.

analyzed: tad matam vā atra asat ityādi sūtraiḥ nirākṛtam iti jñāpana artham
translated: Or, the view that this is not so is to be understood as being refuted by the aphorisms beginning with atīndriyāṇi.

analyzed: dṛṣṭānta abhāvaḥ tu svayam ūhanīyaḥ
translated: The absence of an example should be understood by oneself.

analyzed: nanu idam anumānena īśvarasya jagatkartṛtva sādhanam sūtrakārasya ukta viruddham
translated: But this proof of the creator-ship of God by inference is contradictory to what the author of the aphorisms has said,

analyzed: śāstra yoni tvāt iti īśvare numāna prāmāṇyasya svayam eva nirākṛta tvāt iti atas āha āgama iti
translated: because he himself has refuted the validity of inference with regard to God in the aphorism because of being the source of scripture. In response to this, he says but when supported by scripture, it is valid.

analyzed: āgama anugṛhītā tu mānam
translated: But when supported by scripture, it is valid.

analyzed: anumā iti vakṣyamāṇam atra api sambaddhayate
translated: The word 'anumāna' (inference) which is going to be mentioned is connected here also.

analyzed: na sarvathā api īśvare numānasya prāmāṇyam sūtrakṛtā nirākṛtam
translated: The author of the aphorisms has not denied the validity of inference in every way with regard to God.

analyzed: kinnāma āgama an anugṛhītasya
translated: But of that which is not supported by scripture.

analyzed: āgama anugṛhītā tu anumā īśvare mānam eva abhimatā
translated: But inference supported by scripture is indeed accepted as a means of knowledge regarding God.

original: anyathā vedavākyārthe yuktyanusandhānarūpajijñāsā nārabheteti /🔽kimato yadyevamityata āha eṣeti //
analyzed: anyathā veda vākya arthe yukti anusandhāna rūpa jijñāsā na ārabheta iti  kim atas yadi evam iti atas āha eṣā iti
translated: Otherwise, inquiry in the form of investigation by reasoning regarding the meaning of the Vedic statements would not be undertaken.🔽What follows from this if it is so? To this he says 'this' (inference).

analyzed: eṣā anumāpi tu
translated: This inference is to be inferred.

analyzed: āgama anugṛhītā iti anuvartate
translated: 'Supported by scripture' is continued.

analyzed: mānam iti ca
translated: And 'means of knowledge'.

analyzed: eṣā sampratyupanyastā api anumāyataḥ vai imāni bhūtāni
translated: This inference is also presented now: 'From that, indeed, these beings have been born.'

analyzed: iti āgama anugṛhītā
translated: This is supported by scripture.

original: tato bhavatīśvare mānamiti na kaścidvirodha iti / /
analyzed: tatas bhavati īśvare mānam iti na kaścid virodhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it becomes a means of knowledge regarding God. There is no contradiction at all.

analyzed: evam anumānena abhāva kartṛkatvam viśvasya āśaṅkayā anumānena eva īśvara kartṛkatvam samarthitam
translated: Thus, having raised the doubt that the universe is created by a non-existent being through inference, the author has established that it is created by God through inference itself.

original: tadetanmatāntareṇākṣipya samādadhatsūtram oṃ tarkāpratiṣṭhānādapyanyathānumeyamiti cedevamapyanirmokṣaprasaṅgaḥ oṃ iti //
analyzed: tat etat mata antareṇa ākṣipya samādadhat sūtram om tarka apratiṣṭhānāt api anyathā anumeyam iti ced evam api anirmokṣa prasaṅgaḥ om iti
translated: To this, another view raises an objection and upholds it with the aphorism: 'If it is argued that inference is not established, therefore it is to be inferred otherwise, even so there is the undesirable consequence of no liberation.'

analyzed: tatra ākṣepasya ayam arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the objection there is this:

original: nāyamanumānāvaṣṭambhena pūvarpakṣaḥ pramāṇena ca siddhānto bhavati /
analyzed: na ayam anumāna avaṣṭambhena pūvarpakṣaḥ pramāṇena ca siddhāntaḥ bhavati
translated: This is not a prima facie view based on inference, and the conclusion is established by a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: na ca anumānam nāma pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no means of valid knowledge called inference.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: anyathā api anumeyam
translated: Because what is to be inferred can be inferred otherwise.

analyzed: asat pratipakṣa tvam hi anumāna prāmāṇya vādibhiḥ anumāna aṅgam aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: For those who maintain the validity of inference must accept that the absence of a contradictory [reason] is a part of inference.

analyzed: pratiruddhasya karaṇasya kvāpi kriyā niṣpādaka tva adarśanāt
translated: Because a contradicted means of knowledge is never seen to produce any result.

analyzed: anumāna pratipannam ca anyathā api anumeyam anumātum śakyam
translated: And what is inferred by inference can be inferred otherwise, it can be inferred differently.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: tarka apratiṣṭhānām
translated: Because reasoning is not established.

analyzed: evam eva anumātavyam
translated: It should be inferred in this way.

analyzed: na punar anyathā
translated: It should not be inferred otherwise.

analyzed: iti tarkasya vyavasthā bhāvāt
translated: Because reasoning is not established.

analyzed: tathā ca uktam
translated: And it is said:

original: upādhipratipakṣau tu kva nāmātīva durvacau' / iti /🔽nanvidaṃ vyadhikaraṇaṃ /
analyzed: upādhi pratipakṣau tu kva nāma atīva durvacau iti  nanu idam vyadhikaraṇam
translated: But the reason and the counter-reason are indeed very difficult to state.🔽But this is a different topic.

analyzed: tarkasya apratiṣṭhita tvāt anyathā anumeyam iti
translated: Because reasoning is not established, what is to be inferred can be inferred otherwise.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: etat anena jñāpayati sūtrakāraḥ
translated: The author of the aphorisms makes this known by this:

analyzed: na tarkaḥ numānāt bhidyate iti
translated: Reasoning is not different from inference.

analyzed: athavā tarkasya anumānasya apratiṣṭhānāt apramāṇa tvāt na anumānena pūrva uttarapakṣau yuktau
translated: Or else, because reasoning, i.e., inference, is not established, i.e., is not a means of valid knowledge, the prima facie and conclusive views are not proper by inference.

analyzed: katham apramāṇa tvāt
translated: How is it not a valid means of knowledge?

original: yato 'nyathānumeyamiti yojanā /🔽tatra samādhānasūtraṃ saṅgamayitumutsūtrameva bhāṣyakārastāvaduttaramāha āgameti //
analyzed: yatas nyathā anumeyam iti yojanā  tatra samādhāna sūtram saṅgamayitum utsūtram eva bhāṣyakāraḥ tāvat uttaram āha āgama iti
translated: The construction is: because it is to be inferred in another way.

original: tarkāpratiṣṭhānād apy anyathānumeyam iti ced evam apy anirmokṣaprasaṅgaḥ / / / /
analyzed: tarka apratiṣṭhānāt api anyathā anumeyam iti ced evam api anirmokṣa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: To connect the sutra on the solution, the commentator first says, independently of the sutra, that the answer is If it is argued that it is to be inferred in another way because reasoning is not established, then there would be the undesirable consequence of no liberation.

analyzed: āgama anugraha abhāve na tarkaḥ syāt pratiṣṭhitaḥ
translated: If there is no support from scripture, reasoning would not be established.

analyzed: āgama grahaṇam pramāṇa mātra upalakṣaṇam
translated: The mention of scripture is to indicate all means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: atas eva uttara ardhe kṣajam api saṅgṛhītam
translated: For this very reason, in the latter half, what is produced from the senses is also included.

analyzed: pramāṇa anugraha pramāṇa mūla tva śabdābhyām pratiṣṭhita prāmāṇya pramāṇa antara avadhṛta pakṣa liṅga vyāptimat tvam tad saṃvādi tvam ca ucyate
translated: By the words supported by valid knowledge and having valid knowledge as its basis, the possession of a subject, reason, and pervasion ascertained by another means of valid knowledge whose validity is established, and the agreement with that, are stated.

original: tatrādyayojanāyāmasyāyamarthaḥ /🔽yaduktamanumānasyāvyavasthitatvena sarvatra pratyanumānasambhava iti tadanupapannam /🔽yataḥ pramāṇānugrahābhāve tarko na pratiṣṭhitaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tatra ādya yojanāyām asya ayam arthaḥ  yat uktam anumānasya avyavasthita tvena sarvatra pratyanumāna sambhavaḥ iti tat anupapannam  yatas pramāṇa anugraha abhāve tarkaḥ na pratiṣṭhitaḥ syāt
translated: Here is the meaning of this in the first interpretation.🔽What was said, that inference is not fixed and therefore an inference can be made in every case, is not correct.🔽Because reasoning would not be established if there were no support from a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: kintu pramāṇa mūlasya eva asya pratiṣṭhitiḥ syāt
translated: But its establishment would be only if it has a means of valid knowledge as its basis.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: pratyanumānam bhavat kim pramāṇa anugraha rahitam syāt
translated: Is your counter-inference devoid of the support of valid means of knowledge?

analyzed: uta tat mūlam
translated: Or does it have that as its basis?

original: ādyaṃ tu kathaṃ svayamadṛḍhabhūmikaṃ paraṃ pratirundhyāt /
analyzed: ādyam tu katham svayam adṛḍha bhūmikam param pratirundhyāt
translated: But how can the first, which is not firmly grounded itself, refute the other?

analyzed: nahi bhavati tarakṣoḥ pratipakṣaḥ hariṇa śāvaḥ
translated: For a young deer is not the counteragent of a tiger.

analyzed: kintu ādyena eva pramāṇa mūlena bādhyate
translated: But rather it is refuted by the first itself, which has valid means of knowledge as its basis.

analyzed: dvitīyam tu syāt eva pramāṇam
translated: But the second would indeed be a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: ādyam ca apabādheta
translated: And it would refute the first.

analyzed: ubhayathā api na sarva anumāna aprāmāṇyam
translated: In both cases, not all inferences are invalid.

original: yada tūbhayoḥ api pramāṇamūlatvasandehaḥ tadāstu pratirodhaḥ /
analyzed: tu ubhayoḥ api pramāṇa mūla tva sandehaḥ tadā astu pratirodhaḥ
translated: But where there is doubt about the basis of valid means of knowledge for both, let there be contradiction.

analyzed: kintu na evam sarvatra
translated: But it is not so in all cases.

analyzed: avadhāraṇāyām tu pūrvā eva gatiḥ iti
translated: But in the case of restriction, the former course is to be followed.

analyzed: dvitīya yojanāyām tu praṣṭavyam
translated: But in the second formulation, it should be asked:

analyzed: kim pramāṇa anugraha rahitam anumānam pratyanumāna parāhata tvāt apramāṇam
translated: Is an inference devoid of the support of valid means of knowledge invalid because it is refuted by a counter-inference?

analyzed: uta tat mūlam
translated: Or does it have that as its basis?

analyzed: ādye sampratipattim uttaram āha āgama iti
translated: In the first case, he gives the answer beginning with in the case of scriptures.

analyzed: tathā api na evam sarvatra iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even so, it is not so in all cases.

analyzed: pratiṣṭhitaḥ pramāṇa bhūtaḥ
translated: Established means based on valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: dvitīye tu āha akṣa ja iti
translated: In the second case, he says in the case of the senses, etc.

analyzed: akṣaja āgama mūlasya syāt eva asya pratiṣṭhitiḥ
translated: This [inference] would indeed have a basis in the scriptures of the dice-born [Vyāsa].

analyzed: pratiṣṭhitaḥ prāmāṇyam
translated: [The inference] is established as a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tena eva pratiprayogasya bādhita tvāt
translated: Because the counter-argument is contradicted by that very [inference].

analyzed: ubhayoḥ vāstava pramāṇa mūla tva asambhavāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is impossible for both to have a real valid means of knowledge as their basis.

original: yastvetāṃ vyavasthāmanabhyupagamya sarvatrāpi pratipakṣasyāstyavakāśa iti sarvamanumānamapramāṇamiti ca manyate tasya sūtrārūḍhamuttaramāha
analyzed: yaḥ tu etām vyavasthām an abhyupagamya sarvatra api pratipakṣasya asti avakāśaḥ iti sarvam anumānam apramāṇam iti ca manyate tasya sūtra ārūḍham uttaram āha
translated: However, one who, not accepting this arrangement, thinks that there is room for a counter-argument everywhere, and that therefore all inference is not a valid means of knowledge, for him the reply is stated in the sūtra

analyzed: anyathā iti
translated: Otherwise, etc.

analyzed: anyathā asya apratiṣṭhā ca sva vācā vyāhatā eva hi
translated: Otherwise, this [inference] would indeed be unestablished, contradicted by one's own words.

original: etenaivamupapādite 'pi yo naivaṃ manyate tasya svavacanavyāghātādanirmokṣaprasaṅga iti sūtrayojanā sūcitā /
analyzed: etena evam upapādite pi yaḥ nā evam manyate tasya sva vacana vyāghātāt anirmokṣa prasaṅgaḥ iti sūtra yojanā sūcitā
translated: Even though it has been explained in this way, the arrangement of the sūtra is indicated as follows: for one who does not think in this way, there is the consequence of being unable to escape due to contradicting one's own words.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

original: sarvamanumānapramāṇaṃ pratipakṣapratihatatvāditi tvadīyamanumānaṃ pratipakṣaparāhataṃ cāpramāṇaṃ ca bhavati na vā /
analyzed: sarvam anumāna pramāṇam pratipakṣa pratihata tvāt iti tvadīyam anumānam pratipakṣa parāhatam ca apramāṇam ca bhavati na vā
translated: Your inference that all inference is not a valid means of knowledge because it is countered by a counter-argument is either countered by a counter-argument and not a valid means of knowledge, or not.

analyzed: ādye na anena sarvasya a prāmāṇya siddhiḥ
translated: In the first case, its invalidity cannot be established by this [inference].

analyzed: dvitīye tu atra eva bādhāt iti
translated: In the second case, there is contradiction right here [in your inference].

analyzed: anyathā ukta vyavasthām vihāya
translated: Otherwise, abandoning the arrangement stated above.

original: asya sarvasyāpyanumānasya apratiṣṭhā apramāṇatā /🔽svavācaiva vyāhatā hīti / /🔽apare tuna vilakṣaṇatvāt' /
analyzed: asya sarvasya api anumānasya apratiṣṭhā apramāṇa tā  sva vācā eva vyāhatāḥ hi iti  apare tu vilakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: The unreliability of all this inference is due to the fact that it is contradicted by the Veda itself.🔽The other party, however, say that the world cannot have originated from Brahman, because it is different from him.

analyzed: ityādīni sūtrāṇi brahmaṇaḥ jagat upādāna tva ākṣepa samādhāna arthatayā vyācakṣate
translated: Other commentators explain the aphorisms beginning with this one as aiming at the refutation and establishment of the doctrine that Brahman is the material cause of the world.

analyzed: tad prakṛti adhikaraṇe eva nirākṛtam
translated: This has been refuted in the chapter on Prakṛti.

original: yaccātra sūtre tarkāpratiṣṭhānāditi vākyaṃ bhittvā siddhāntatayaiva varṇayanti /
analyzed: yat ca atra sūtre tarka apratiṣṭhānāt iti vākyam bhittvā siddhānta tayā eva varṇayanti
translated: And the passage in this aphorism, “because inference is not established,” they explain as the conclusion, in accordance with their own view.

original: tadvā anena sārdhena ślokena nirācaṣṭe /🔽tathāhi tarkasyāpratiṣṭhāṃ vadanvaktavyaḥ /
analyzed: tat vai anena sa ardhena ślokena nirācaṣṭe  tathā hi tarkasya apratiṣṭhām vadan vaktavyaḥ
translated: This is refuted by the next half of the verse.

analyzed: kim pramāṇa anugraha rahitasya uta tad mūlasya
translated: For he who speaks of the unreliability of inference must say whether he means of inference devoid of the support of the scriptures or of that which has its root in the scriptures.

analyzed: ādye gūḍha abhisandhiḥ uttaram āha āgama iti  ayam āśayaḥ
translated: If the former, the author, concealing his real intention, replies, “Because it is not supported by the scriptures,” etc.🔽The meaning is as follows.

analyzed: satyam etat
translated: This is true.

analyzed: tathā api na sāṅkhayaḥ sva tarkasya āgama ādi anugraha abhāvam manyate
translated: Nevertheless, the Sāṅkhya does not consider his own inference to be devoid of the support of the scriptures, etc.

analyzed: sva matena idam ucyate ced paunaruktyam
translated: If it is said that this is stated according to his own view, there is repetition.

analyzed: śāstra yoni tvāt
translated: Because it has the scriptures for its womb.

analyzed: īkṣateḥ na a śabdam
translated: Because of the word “not” in “not from an unseen cause.”

analyzed: ānumānikam ityadinā asya arthasya ukta tvāt iti
translated: Because this meaning has been stated by “from inference,” etc.

analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati akṣa ja iti
translated: He refutes the second by “because it is not produced by the senses,” etc.

original: nahi jñānakaraṇasya pramāṇagṛhītavyāptyādimattvenāprāmāṇyakāraṇavyabhicārādiśaṅkākalaṅkavikalasya prāmāṇyaṃ nāstīti yuktamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nahi jñāna karaṇasya pramāṇa gṛhīta vyāpti ādimattvena aprāmāṇya kāraṇa vyabhicāra ādi śaṅkā kalaṅka vikalasya prāmāṇyam nā asti iti yuktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is not proper to say that when the instrument of knowledge is devoid of the stain of doubt regarding the invalidity of inference, such as the presence of the reason in the dissimilar instances, its validity does not exist.

analyzed: vipakṣe bādhakam ca āha anyathā iti
translated: He states the sublation in the case of the contrary in the words 'anyathā' (otherwise).

original: anyathoktānabhyupagamenāsya pramāṇamūlasyāpyanumānasyāpratiṣṭhā svavācā vyāhataiva sūtrakṛtaḥ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā ukta anabhyupagamena asya pramāṇa mūlasya api anumānasya apratiṣṭhā sva vācā vyāhatā eva sūtrakṛtaḥ syāt
translated: If the author of the aphorisms does not accept the statement made in another way, then even this inference based on valid means of knowledge would be unestablished, and he would contradict himself.

original: svayameva hi yuktyanusandhānarūpāṃ brahmamīmāṃsāmārabhya pramāṇamūlasyāpi tarkasyāprāmāṇyamabhidadhānaḥ sūtrakāro na vyāhatabhāṣī kathaṃ syāt🔽yadapi vṛttikārairuktamekena tārkikeṇotprekṣitaṃ tarkamaparo dūṣayati /
analyzed: svayam eva hi yukti anusandhāna rūpām brahmamīmāṃsām ārabhya pramāṇa mūlasya api tarkasya aprāmāṇyam abhidadhānaḥ sūtrakāraḥ na vyāhata bhāṣī katham syāt  yat api vṛtti kāraiḥ uktam ekena tārkikeṇa utprekṣitam tarkam aparaḥ dūṣayati
translated: For how could the author of the aphorisms, who has himself begun the investigation of Brahman in the form of the inquiry into reason, and who declares the invalidity of reasoning even when based on valid means of knowledge, be one who speaks in a contradictory manner?🔽What the commentators have said, that one logician imagines a reasoning and another refutes it,

analyzed: tena utprekṣitam api aparaḥ
translated: and another imagines it,🔽and another,

analyzed: iti atas puruṣa mati vaiśvarūpya janmā tarkaḥ syāt apratiṣṭhitaḥ iti
translated: therefore reasoning would be unestablished, born of the diversity of human intellect.

analyzed: tat ca ayuktam
translated: And that is improper.

original: yato 'syāpi tarkasya prāmāṇye 'prāmāṇye vā asyāpratiṣṭhā ca svavācā
analyzed: yatas syā api tarkasya prāmāṇye prāmāṇye vā asya apratiṣṭhā ca sva vācā
translated: Because, whether this reasoning is valid or invalid, this unestablishedness of it is by his own words.

original: vyāhataiveti nāyaṃ vākyabhedo yukta ityukta eva sūtrārthaḥ /
analyzed: vyāhatā eva iti na ayam vākya bhedaḥ yuktaḥ iti uktaḥ eva sūtra arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the aphorism is stated to be that this is a contradiction, and therefore this is not a proper case of split-of-the-sentence.

original: atra sūtram oṃ etena śiṣyā aparigrahā api vyākhyātā iti /
analyzed: atra sūtram om etena śiṣyāḥ aparigrahāḥ api vyākhyātāḥ iti
translated: Here is the aphorism: By this, the doctrines of the disciples, even those not accepted, are explained.

analyzed: tat kecid vayācakṣate
translated: Some explain this as follows.

analyzed: etena na vilakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: By this, because of being unlike.

original: ityādinā prakṛtena śiṣyaiḥ kenacidaṃśena parigṛhītasya pradhānakāraṇavādasya nirākaraṇena
analyzed: ityādinā prakṛtena śiṣyaiḥ kenacid aṃśena parigṛhītasya pradhāna kāraṇa vādasya nirākaraṇena
translated: By this, which is the subject matter, by refuting the doctrine of Pradhana as the cause, accepted by some part by the disciples,

analyzed: śiṣyaiḥ manuvyāsa prabhṛtibhiḥ kenacid api aṃśena a parigṛhītāḥ ye ṇu ādi kāraṇavādāḥ te pi
translated: even those doctrines of the cause being an atom and so on, not accepted by any part by the disciples such as Manu, Vyasa and so on,

analyzed: vyākhyātāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ iti
translated: should be seen as explained.

analyzed: tat idam dūṣayati na ca iti
translated: This is criticized as follows: And this is not...

analyzed: etena śiṣṭa a parigrahāḥ api vyākhyātāḥ
translated: By this, even those not accepted by the learned are explained.🔽And the doctrine of the Lord is not accepted by the disciples.

analyzed: na ca śiṣya agṛhīta tvam nirīśa ādīśavādinaḥ  āstām tāvat abhyadhika āśaṅkā prakāraḥ
translated: Let alone the mode of additional doubt.

analyzed: parihāra atideśa prakāraḥ ca
translated: And the mode of extension of the solution.

analyzed: yat tāvat uktam sāṅkhayāt api vaiśeṣika ādeḥ atiśayena śiṣya agṛhīta tvam
translated: As for what was said, The Vaiśeṣika and others have a doctrine more accepted by the disciples than even the Sāṃkhya,

analyzed: tat ati tīva viruddham
translated: that is extremely contradictory.

analyzed: sāṅkhayasya nirīśvara tvāt
translated: Because the Sāṃkhya is non-theistic.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika ādeḥ tu sa īśvara tvāt
translated: But the Vaiśeṣika and others are theistic.

analyzed: vaiparītyasya eva ucita tvāt
translated: because the opposite is proper.

original: iha hi brahmaṇo jagatkāraṇatve vipratipattayo nirasyante /
analyzed: iha hi brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatve vipratipattayaḥ nirasyante
translated: For here, the misconceptions regarding Brahman being the cause of the world are being refuted.

analyzed: tatra sāṅkhayaḥ brahma eva na abhyupaiti
translated: Among them, the Sāṃkhya does not even accept Brahman.

analyzed: kutas tadīyam jagat kāraṇatvam iti atiśayena vedānta vāda virodhi tvāt śiṣya aparigṛhītaḥ
translated: How then can there be the cause of the world belonging to it? Being extremely opposed to the Vedānta doctrine, it is not accepted by the disciples.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika ādiḥ tu
translated: But the Vaiśeṣika and others,

original: brahma tasya jagannimittatvaṃ cāṅgīkṛtyopādānatāmātraṃ nāṅgīkuruta itīṣadvirodhitvāt īṣacchiṣyāparigṛhīta iti yuktam /
analyzed: brahma tasya jagat nimitta tvam ca aṅgīkṛtya upādānatā mātram na aṅgīkurute iti īṣat virodhi tvāt īṣat śiṣya aparigṛhītaḥ iti yuktam
translated: accepting Brahman and its being the cause of the world, do not accept mere being the material cause. Thus, being slightly opposed, it is proper to say it is slightly not accepted by the disciples.

analyzed: satkārya vādi tva ādikam tu prakṛta asaṅgatam eva
translated: But the doctrine of satkāryavāda and so on is irrelevant to the present context.

analyzed: anyathā yāgīya hiṃsā niṣedha ādinā viparivartaḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be a contradiction with the prohibition of sacrifice-related violence and so on.

analyzed: atha veda saṃvāda bāhulya a bāhulya prayuktam idam
translated: Or, this is based on the abundance or lack of agreement with the Vedas.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: tat na
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: tattvānām pratipādyānām a parisaṅkhayā āta tvāt iti
translated: Because the principles to be taught are innumerable, it is said.

original: kiṃ tarhyasya sūtrasyābhidheyamityata āha ata iti //
analyzed: kim tarhi asya sūtrasya abhidheyam iti atas āha atas iti
translated: Then what is the subject matter of this aphorism? To this he says ataḥ (therefore).

analyzed: artha avaśiṣṭa jīva ādi kartṛ tā atra niṣidhyate
translated: Here, the agency of the soul etc. which remains as the meaning is being negated.

analyzed: artha antarasya nirākṛta tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because another meaning has been refuted.

analyzed: apavyākhyāna nirākaraṇasya sva vyākhyāna dārḍhya athartvāt na asaṅgatam iti sūcayitum atas iti uktam
translated: The word 'thus' is used to indicate that the refutation of misinterpretations serves the purpose of strengthening one's own interpretation, and is not irrelevant.

analyzed: avaśiṣyāḥ nirākṛtāyāḥ abhāva kartṛ tāyāḥ  jīva ādi kartṛ tā
translated: The remaining [view] is the view that the world is created by the individual soul, etc.

analyzed: jagataḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The world is the remainder.

original: anena nirākṛtādavaśiṣyā vedāparigṛhītā jīvapradhānāsatkālasvabhāvādivādā nirākṛtā iti vyākhyātaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: anena nirākṛtāt avaśiṣyāḥ veda a parigṛhītāḥ jīva pradhāna asat kāla svabhāva ādi vādāḥ nirākṛtāḥ iti vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: By this, it is explained that the remaining views not refuted, such as the view that the world is created by the individual soul, etc., which are not accepted by the Vedas, are refuted.

analyzed: tatra śiṣyāḥ iti eva ukte prāpnoti
translated: If only 'the disciples' were mentioned, the view that Brahman is the cause would also be included.

analyzed: tad artham aparigrahāḥ iti uktam  tad mātre tu ukte gṛhyeta
translated: To exclude that, 'not accepted' is said.🔽But if only that much were mentioned, the view that non-existence is the creator would also be included.

analyzed: tathā ca punaruktiḥ atideśa anupapattiḥ ca syāt
translated: And thus there would be repetition and the impossibility of extending the argument.

analyzed: atas śiṣyāḥ iti uktam
translated: Therefore, 'the disciples' is said.

original: abhyadhikāśaṅkāsadbhāvasūcanena sūtrārambhopapādanārthaṃ ca śiṣyāḥ śiṣyatayā pratītāḥ /
analyzed: abhyadhika āśaṅkā sadbhāva sūcanena sūtra ārambha upapādana artham ca śiṣyāḥ śiṣya tayā pratītāḥ
translated: The disciples are mentioned to show that there is a greater doubt, and to justify the beginning of the sutra.

analyzed: na tu tatas eva nirākṛta tayā iti
translated: But they are not refuted just because of that.

analyzed: nanu
translated: But if 'the individual soul, etc.' is mentioned, the view that non-existence is the creator is included.

analyzed: tasya asat iti ced
translated: If it is argued that non-existence is mentioned,🔽then the view that non-existence is the creator is included.

original: ityādinā nirastatvena paunaruktyādiprasaṅgādityata āha tanmana iti //
analyzed: ityādinā nirasta tvena paunaruktya ādi prasaṅgāt iti atas āha tat manaḥ iti
translated: Because it has been refuted by statements like this, there is the problem of redundancy and so on. Therefore, he says that mind and so on.

original: tanmano 'kurutetyāderasato manaso janiḥ /🔽nivāritā tu pūrvatra hyakasmāditi tadvinā // / / //
analyzed: tat mano kuruta ityādeḥ asataḥ manasaḥ janiḥ  nivāritā tu pūrvatra hi akasmāt iti tat vinā
translated: The birth of the non-existent mind from that mind and so on,🔽Is indeed refuted before, because without it, there is no sudden [birth].

analyzed: asataḥ viśva jananam āśaṅkayā atra
translated: The birth of the universe from the non-existent is suspected here and is refuted.

analyzed: ityādeḥ pramāṇāt
translated: From this evidence.

analyzed: āśaṅkitā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is suspected.

analyzed: ādi padena ukta yuktiḥ gṛhyate
translated: By the word and so on, the stated reasoning is included.

analyzed: asataḥ abhāvasya
translated: Of the non-existent, of non-being.

analyzed: manasaḥ iti
translated: Of the mind.

analyzed: jñāna icchā prayatnebhyaḥ janiḥ
translated: The birth from knowledge, desire, and effort.

analyzed: jagataḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Of the universe, is the remainder.

analyzed: pūrvatra tu iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is before.

analyzed: tat ca pratiṣedha mātra tvāt ityādinā sphuṭam avagamyate iti hi śabdaḥ
translated: And that is clearly understood by because it is mere negation and so on. Therefore, the word indeed.

analyzed: akasmāt hi idam āvirāsīt ityādi śrutyā
translated: By the scripture this world appeared suddenly and so on.

analyzed: tat manaḥ vinā
translated: That mind, without it.

analyzed: asataḥ śūnyāt
translated: From the non-existent, from emptiness.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: nirākṛtam idānīm tu śūnyasya
translated: The universe's being the cause of prior existence has been refuted. Now, however, emptiness [is refuted].

original: kiñca pūrvaṃ kartṛtvenādhunā kartṛtāṃ vinaiveti na paunaruktyādīti /
analyzed: kiñca pūrvam kartṛ tvena adhunā kartṛtām vinā evā iti na paunaruktya ādi iti
translated: Moreover, before [it was refuted] as the agent, now [it is refuted] without agency. Therefore, there is no redundancy and so on.

original: yadvā bhāṣyadiśā niṣkāraṇaivātra jagajjanirāśaṅkiteti na paunaruktyādikam /
analyzed: yat vā bhāṣya diśā niṣkāraṇā eva atra jagat janiḥ āśaṅkitā iti na paunaruktya ādikam
translated: Or, according to the direction of the Bhāṣya, since the origin of the world is suspected here even without a cause, there is no repetition, etc.

analyzed: atra śaṅkā prāpaka pramāṇa upanyāsaḥ tu asya eva prameya bhedasya upapādana artham
translated: Here, the statement of the means of valid knowledge that brings about suspicion is for the purpose of establishing this very difference of the object of knowledge.

analyzed: etena abhyadhikā śaṅkā api sūcitā
translated: By this, the additional suspicion is also indicated.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus it is.

analyzed: mā bhūt abhāva kartṛkam jagat
translated: Let there be no world made by non-existence.

analyzed: tathā api jīva ādibhyaḥ janimat bhaviṣyati
translated: Even so, it will have origination from the soul and others.

analyzed: jīvāt bhavanti bhūtāni
translated: From the soul, beings originate.

analyzed: pradhānāt idam utpannam
translated: This has originated from Pradhāna and others.

analyzed: akasmāt hi idam āvirāsīt
translated: This has appeared suddenly.

analyzed: ityādi śruti anugṛhītebhyaḥ ghaṭa dadhi kaṇṭa taikṣṇa ādi dṛṣṭāntebhyaḥ
translated: From these examples such as the sharpness of a pot, curd, and a thorn, which are supported by such Vedic statements, etc.

analyzed: nahi jīva ādīnām pratiṣedha mātra tvam asti
translated: For the soul and others are not mere negations.

analyzed: yena ukta yukti virodhaḥ syāt
translated: By which there would be a contradiction with the stated reasoning.

analyzed: asattva acetana tva ādeḥ upalakṣaṇam etat iti ced
translated: If it is said that this is a specification of non-existence, non-intelligence, etc.,

analyzed: kim atra asat ādeḥ kāraṇatva mātram na iti ucyate
translated: is it said here that the mere causality of non-existence, etc. is not?

analyzed: kiṃvā kartṛ tvam
translated: Or is it agency?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: ukta dṛṣṭānteṣu vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of inconstancy in the stated examples.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: kartṛ tvasya asmābhiḥ an aṅgīkṛta tvāt iti
translated: Because we do not accept agency.

original: ata evātra sarvatra kartṛśabdaḥ kāraṇatvamātraparo draṣṭavyaḥ / /
analyzed: atas eva atra sarvatra kartṛ śabdaḥ kāraṇatva mātra paraḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, in all these (passages), the word 'agent' should be seen as referring to the mere cause.

analyzed: nanu atra jīva ādeḥ viśva kāraṇa tva mātram śaṅkayate
translated: But here, is it only the cause of the universe that is suspected to be the individual soul, etc.?

analyzed: tasya eva vā
translated: Or is it that very (individual soul, etc.)?

analyzed: ādye na siddhānta virodhaḥ
translated: In the first case, there is no contradiction with the established conclusion.

analyzed: jīvasya hi adṛṣṭa ādhāra tayā nimitta tvam pradhānasya ca upādāna tvam aṅgīkṛtam eva
translated: For the individual soul is accepted as the instrumental cause by being the substratum of unseen (merit and demerit), and the primordial matter as the material cause.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second (alternative) is not (correct).

analyzed: prāpaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no proof (for it).

analyzed: kāryasya sa kartṛka tva niyama darśanāt ca iti atas āha prāpakam iti
translated: And because it is seen that every effect has a cause. To this (the author) says:

analyzed: prāpakam vākya mātram tu
translated: But the proof is merely the statement (of the Veda).

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ eva āśaṅkayate
translated: The second (alternative) alone is suspected.

analyzed: tasya ca prāpakam na jīvāt kāraṇam param
translated: And the proof for that (is the statement of the Veda): 'The individual soul is not the highest cause.'

analyzed: na hi anyat kāraṇam matam
translated: 'For there is no other cause accepted.'

analyzed: ityādi vākyam
translated: And so on.

analyzed: na ca loka virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with the world.

original: vākyamātrasiddhe 'rthe tatpratipannameva gṛhyate natu loko 'nugamyata iti pūrvapakṣī manyata iti /
analyzed: vākya mātra siddhe rthe tat pratipannam eva gṛhyate na tu lokaḥ nugamyate iti pūrvapakṣī manyate iti
translated: The opponent thinks that in a matter established by mere statement, only what is accepted by that (Veda) is taken, but the world is not followed.

analyzed: nanu ca pradhāna kāraṇa tva ādi matāni dvitīya pāde nirākariṣyate
translated: But the doctrines of the primordial matter being the cause, etc., will be refuted in the second chapter.

original: teṣāmatrāpi nirākaraṇe punaruktidoṣaḥ syādityato vā'ha prāpakamiti //
analyzed: teṣām atra api nirākaraṇe punarukti doṣaḥ syāt iti atas vā āha prāpakam iti
translated: If they are refuted here also, there would be the fault of repetition. Therefore, he says the means of knowing [in the verse].

original: atra śaṅkāprāpakaṃ vākyamātraṃ natu samaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atra śaṅkā prāpakam vākya mātram na tu samayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that here [in the Vedānta texts] only a statement that raises doubts is [used], not a convention [of the Sāṃkhya and other systems].

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: atra śruti anugṛhītābhiḥ yuktibhiḥ prāptam pradhāna ādi kāraṇa tvam nirākriyate
translated: Here, the being the cause of primordial matter and so on, which is established by reasonings supported by scripture, is refuted.

analyzed: uttaraṃratra
translated: But in the following [verse],

analyzed: tu tu sāṅkhaya ādi samaya prāptam
translated: [the being the cause of primordial matter and so on] is established by the conventions of the Sāṃkhya and other [systems].

analyzed: na ukta doṣaḥ iti  nanu evam tarhi etena iti atideśaḥ katham
translated: Therefore, the stated fault does not apply [to the Vedānta texts].🔽If that is so, then how is there a transference [of the fault] by [the words] thus [in the Sāṃkhyakārikā]?

original: uktaparihārasya pūrvapakṣiṇā parihṛtatvādityata āha parihāra iti //
analyzed: ukta parihārasya pūrvapakṣiṇā parihṛta tvāt iti atas āha parihāraḥ iti
translated: Because the opponent has refuted the stated answer, therefore he says the answer [in the commentary].

analyzed: parihāraḥ viśeṣitaḥ
translated: The answer is specified.

analyzed: yadi api pratiṣedha mātra tvam pradhāna ādiṣu asiddham
translated: Even though the mere negation [of the existence of primordial matter and so on] is not established with regard to primordial matter and so on,

analyzed: acetana tva ādikam ca kāraṇatva mātra vāde anaikāntikam
translated: and the being insentient and so on is inconclusive in the doctrine of mere causality,

original: tathāpi pūrvapakṣāṇāṃ yuktiviruddhatvaṃ yatpratiṣedhamātratvāt dṛṣṭāntabhāvāditi sāmānyataḥ sūcitam /
analyzed: tathā api pūrvapakṣāṇām yukti viruddha tvam yat pratiṣedha mātra tvāt dṛṣṭānta bhāvāt iti sāmānyatas sūcitam
translated: nevertheless, the reasonings of the opponents are contradictory, as indicated in general by the mere negation [of the existence of primordial matter and so on] and by the example [of the potter and so on].

analyzed: yat ca sva pakṣa doṣāt ca iti aprāmāṇika tvam
translated: And the lack of being authoritative due to the fault in one's own position [is also a reason for refuting the Sāṃkhya and other systems].

analyzed: sa parihāraḥ samānaḥ
translated: That answer is also the same here, without distinction.

analyzed: iti atideśaḥ yujyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that such a transference is proper.

original: nanu kathaṃ jagato jīvakartṛtvādivādasya yuktiviruddhatvamityata āha kvaciditi //
analyzed: nanu katham jagataḥ jīva kartṛ tva ādi vādasya yukti viruddha tvam iti atas āha kvacid iti
translated: But how is the doctrine of the world being created by the individual soul etc. contrary to reason? To this he says 'in some cases'.

analyzed: kvacid jīva akṛtam dṛṣṭvā cetanāt eva ca akṛtam
translated: Having seen that which is not done by the individual soul, and that which is not done by an intelligent being,

analyzed: tadvat evā anumānī atra vastu tvāt kriyate śruteḥ  kvacid deśa ādau
translated: in the same way, by inference, it is done in other cases, because of being an entity, even though contrary to the scriptures.🔽In some cases, in space etc.

analyzed: yat vā kvacid jīva ādau
translated: Or, in some cases, in the individual soul etc.

analyzed: a kṛtam iti ca bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: And the statement 'not done' is in the nature of a substantive.

analyzed: kāraṇa tva mātram atra pūrvapakṣaḥ na kartṛ tvam iti atas cetanāt iti pañcamī prayogaḥ
translated: Here, the prima facie view is only about causality, not about being the agent. Therefore, the use of the instrumental case 'from an insentient being' is made.

analyzed: acetanāt akṛtam ca dṛṣṭvā
translated: And having seen that which is not done by an insentient being.

analyzed: evaśabdena dṛṣṭāntānām asandigdha sādhya tām āha
translated: The word 'eva' (only) states that the examples have an undoubted probandum.

analyzed: anumā anumitiḥ
translated: Anumitiḥ (inference) is anumāna (inference).

analyzed: anyathā vastu tvasya eva anumāna tvāt pañcamī na syāt
translated: Otherwise, since only being an entity would be the inference, the instrumental case would not be used.

analyzed: jīva akṛta tva ādeḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is 'of being done by the individual soul etc.'

analyzed: anyatra mahat ādau
translated: In other cases, in Mahat etc.

analyzed: atra ete prayogāḥ
translated: Here are the arguments:

original: mahadādikāryaṃ na jīvakṛtaṃ vastutvājjīvavat /🔽vimataṃ na pradhānakāryaṃ vastutvātpradhānavat /
analyzed: mahat ādi kāryam na jīva kṛtam vastu tvāt jīva vat  vimatam na pradhāna kāryam vastu tvāt pradhāna vat
translated: The effect such as Mahat is not done by the individual soul, because it is an entity, like the individual soul.🔽The disputed [effect] is not the effect of Prakriti, because it is an entity, like Prakriti.

analyzed: vimatam na asat kāryam vastu tvāt ghaṭa vat iti
translated: The disputed [effect] is not the effect of non-existence, because it is an entity, like a pot.

original: yadyapi jīvasya nimittatvena pradhānasyopādānatvena jagatkāraṇatvamaṅgīkṛtameva tathāpi svātantryābhāvābhiprāyeṇedaṃ vacanamiti na virodhaḥ
analyzed: yadi api jīvasya nimitta tvena pradhānasya upādāna tvena jagat kāraṇatvam aṅgīkṛtam eva tathā api svātantrya abhāva abhiprāyeṇa idam vacanam iti na virodhaḥ
translated: Although the Jiva is accepted as the cause and the Pradhana as the material cause of the world, this statement is made with the intention of denying their independence, so there is no contradiction.

analyzed: nanu evam sati atiprasaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: If that is so, there would be over-extension.

original: vimatamaśvarakṛtaṃ na bhavati vastutvādīśvaravat ityapi prayoktuṃ śakyatvādityata āha śruteriti //
analyzed: vimatam aśvara kṛtam na bhavati vastu tvāt īśvara vat iti api prayoktum śakya tvāt iti atas āha śruteḥ iti
translated: It can be argued that the object of doubt is not created by God, because it is a thing, like God. To this he says because of the Vedic text.

analyzed: saḥ idam sarvam asṛjata
translated: He created all this.

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ mahat ādeḥ īśvara kṛta tva avadhāraṇāt atiprasaṅga anumānasya bādhita tvena aprāmāṇyam iti
translated: Because of this and other Vedic texts, the inference of over-extension is invalid because it is contradicted by the determination that the great elements etc. are created by God.

analyzed: samam tarhi idam bhavat anumāneṣu
translated: Then this is the same in your inferences.

analyzed: jīvāt bhavanti bhūtāni ityādi śruteḥ iti atas āha śruteḥ iti
translated: Because of the Vedic text the elements etc. originate from the Jiva etc. To this he says because of the Vedic text.

analyzed: bhāva pradhānaḥ nirdeśaḥ
translated: The statement is predominant in meaning.

analyzed: jīva ādi śabdānām brahma śruti tvāt brahma nāma tvāt na śruti virodhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The words Jiva etc. are Vedic texts about Brahman, and are names of Brahman, so there is no contradiction with the Vedic text, this is the meaning.

analyzed: tat kutas iti atas āha śruteḥ iti
translated: How is that? To this he says because of the Vedic text.

analyzed: nāmāni sarvāṇi yam āviśanti
translated: All names enter into Him.

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ
translated: Because of this and other Vedic texts.

analyzed: śeṣam bhāṣye
translated: The rest is in the commentary.

analyzed: nanu jīva ādi kāraṇaka
translated: But the world originates from the Jiva etc.

analyzed: tve pi ghaṭa ādi dṛṣṭānta avaṣṭambhena anumāna sambhavāt katham aprāmāṇika tvam iti atas āha śruteḥ iti
translated: Even in your case, since inference is possible based on the example of pot etc., how can it be unauthoritative? To this he says because of the contradiction of the Veda.

analyzed: na anyaḥ taḥ sti kartā
translated: There is no other agent than He.

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ bādhita viṣaya tvāt dṛṣṭāntānām sādhya vaikalyāt ca na anumānānām prāmāṇyam
translated: Because the examples are contradicted by this and other Vedic statements, and because the conclusion is defective, the inferences are not authoritative.

analyzed: etena asmad anumāne kāryatvam upādhiḥ iti api nirastaḥ  svātantryeṇa
translated: By this, the objection that non-being is a fallacy in our inference is also refuted.

analyzed: jīva ādi akṛte pi ghaṭa ādau akārya tva abhāvāt
translated: Because even in a pot etc. which are not made by the individual etc. independently, there is no non-being.

analyzed: pratipakṣe bādhā ādi doṣa anuṣaṅgāt ca iti sarvam sustham
translated: And because the counter-argument would entail the fallacies of contradiction etc., all is well.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām asat adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Asat-Adhikarana in the Sri-Naya-Sudha.
VI. Bhoktva-Adhikarana.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām bhoktṛ adhikaraṇam  om bhoktṛ āpatteḥ avibhāgaḥ ced syāt loka vat om
translated: Now begins the Bhoktva-Adhikarana in the Sri-Naya-Sudha.🔽Om. If it is argued that there is no division because of the attainment of the experiencer, it would be like in the world.

original: atītādhikaraṇe brahmaṇo jagajjanmādikāraṇatve śrutisaṃvāditvena prabalayā yuktyā virodhaḥ parihṛtaḥ /🔽idānīṃ tu śrutisiddhaliṅga
analyzed: atīta adhikaraṇe brahmaṇaḥ jagat janma ādi kāraṇatve śruti saṃvādi tvena prabalayā yuktyā virodhaḥ parihṛtaḥ  idānīm tu śruti siddha liṅga
translated: In the previous chapter, the contradiction with the strong reasoning of being in agreement with the Vedas in Brahman being the cause of the creation etc. of the world was refuted.

analyzed: tvena prabalayā yuktyā virodhaḥ parihriyate
translated: Now, the contradiction with the strong reasoning of being a strong inferential mark established by the Vedas is being refuted.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus indeed.

analyzed: na brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇa tvam vāstavam sambhavati
translated: The real cause of the world is not Brahman.
Because the liberated soul, which is not the cause of all,

analyzed: na atyanta abhinna tvāt
translated: is not absolutely non-different from Brahman.

original: nahi yo yenātyantābhinnaḥ sa tadviruddhasvabhāvo vastuta iti kvacidupalabdham /
analyzed: nahi yaḥ yena atyanta abhinnaḥ sa tad viruddha svabhāvaḥ vastutas iti kvacid upalabdham
translated: For it is not found anywhere that one who is absolutely non-different from another is of a nature contradictory to him in reality.

analyzed: na ca muktasya a sarva kāraṇa tvam asiddham
translated: And it is not unestablished that the liberated soul is not the cause of all.

analyzed: sarva kāraṇa tvasya
translated: Because the state of being the cause of all

analyzed: saṃsāre n upalambhāt
translated: is not perceived in the world.

original: saṃsāre pratīyamānasya kasyacidākārasyaivāpagamo hi mokṣo natu apūrvākārotpādaḥ /
analyzed: saṃsāre pratīyamānasya kasyacid ākārasya eva apagamaḥ hi mokṣaḥ na tu apūrva ākāra utpādaḥ
translated: For liberation is the removal of some form that is perceived in the world, not the production of a new form.

analyzed: anitya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would lead to the undesirable consequence of impermanence.

analyzed: na ca ānanda ādeḥ iva vidyamānasya eva avidyayā tirohita tvāt sarva kāraṇatvasya anupalambhaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the state of being the cause of all is not perceived because it exists like bliss etc., but is obscured by ignorance.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence for that.

analyzed: ānanda ādeḥ parama prema āspada tva ādinā īṣat upalabdheḥ ca
translated: And because bliss etc. are slightly perceived as the basis of supreme love etc.

original: naca brahmaṇo jagatkāraṇatvaśravaṇātsavarthānupalabhyamānamapi jagatkāraṇatvaṃ saṃsāre kalpyamiti yuktam /
analyzed: na ca brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatva śravaṇāt savartha anupalabhyamānam api jagat kāraṇatvam saṃsāre kalpyam iti yuktam
translated: And it is not right to assume that the world, which is not perceived to have a meaning, is the cause of the world in the world, just because the Veda declares Brahman to be the cause of the world.

analyzed: śruteḥ kālpanika jagat kāraṇatva anuvādi tvena api sāvakāśa tvāt
translated: Because the Veda can be explained as referring to the assumed cause of the world, even though it is not perceived.

analyzed: na ca tathābhūtam eva lakṣaṇam astu iti vācyam
translated: Nor can it be said that the definition should be just as it is.

analyzed: anaṅgīkārāt
translated: Because it is not accepted.

analyzed: kālpanikasya jagat kāraṇa tvasya pradhāna ādiṣu api sambhavena atiprasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because there would be the fallacy of over-extension, since the being the cause of the world by way of imagination is possible even in regard to primordial matter etc.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: muktasya brahmaṇā aikyam eva asiddham iti
translated: The identity of the liberated one with Brahman itself is not established.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

original: karmāṇi vijñānamayaśca ātmā pare 'vyaye sarva ekībhavanti' /🔽ityādiśrutisiddhatvāditi /
analyzed: karmāṇi vijñāna mayaḥ ca ātmā pare vyaye sarve ekībhavanti  ityādi śruti siddha tvāt iti
translated: For it is said in the Upanisads: Actions, and the Self consisting of knowledge, all become one in the supreme imperishable one.

original: tadidamuktaṃ sūtrakṛtā bhokturjīvasya mokṣe brahmatvāpattiśravaṇāttayoravibhāgo bhedābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tat idam uktam sūtrakṛtā bhoktuḥ jīvasya mokṣe brahma tva āpatti śravaṇāt tayoḥ avibhāgaḥ bheda abhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the author of the aphorisms has said this: The non-division, i.e. non-difference, of the two, i.e. of the enjoyer, the individual soul, and Brahman, is due to the declaration of the attainment of Brahmanhood by the liberated soul.

original: tataśca na brahmaṇo jagatkāraṇatvaṃ vāstavaṃ yuktamiti / /
analyzed: tatas ca na brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatvam vāstavam yuktam iti
translated: And therefore, the real being the cause of the world is not proper for Brahman.

analyzed: evam prāpte siddhāntitam
translated: When this has been reached, the conclusion is stated:

original: bhavedetadakhilaṃ yadi muktasya brahmaṇābheda eva prāmāṇikaḥ syāt /
analyzed: bhavet etat akhilam yadi muktasya brahmaṇā abhedaḥ eva prāmāṇikaḥ syāt
translated: All this would be so if the non-difference of the liberated one with Brahman were indeed authoritative.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: śrautaḥ tu ekībhāva prayogaḥ syāt loka vat
translated: The use of the term 'identity' in the scriptures would be like in the world.

analyzed: yathā loke udake udakasya ekībhāva vyavahāraḥ sthāna aikya nibandhanaḥ
translated: Just as in the world, the usage of the identity of water with water is based on the identity of place,

original: yathā vā prāgvibhinnā brāhmaṇāḥ sāmpratamekībhūtā iti matyaikyanibandhanaḥ /
analyzed: yathā vā prāc vibhinnāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ sāmpratam ekībhūtāḥ iti mati aikya nibandhanaḥ
translated: Or, like the Brahmins who were previously divided but are now united, the unity of opinion is based on the unity of the mind.

original: tathā prāgvibhinnasthānā bhinnamatayaśca jīvā muktau brahmaṇā ekībhavanti /
analyzed: tathā prāc vibhinna sthānāḥ bhinnamatayaḥ ca jīvāḥ muktau brahmaṇā ekībhavanti
translated: Or, as for instance, the Brahmanas, though formerly divided, are now united, so the individual souls, though formerly in different places and of different opinions, become united with Brahman in liberation.

analyzed: eka sthānāḥ ekamatayaḥ ca bhavanti iti upapadyate
translated: And it is proper that they become of one place and of one opinion.

analyzed: tasmāt asiddhena asiddha sādhanam etat iti
translated: Therefore this is the establishment of the unestablished by the unestablished.

analyzed: tat etat ayuktam
translated: This is not proper.

analyzed: mukhya arthe bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction in the primary meaning.

analyzed: vinā bādhakena jaghanya vṛtti āśrayaṇe ca atiprasaṅgāt
translated: And because if one resorts to the secondary meaning without contradiction, there would be an overextension.

original: ityato mukhyārthe bādhakayuktivyutpādanaparatvenāpi syāllokavaditi sūtrakhaṇḍaṃ vyācaṣṭe nānyaditi //
analyzed: iti atas mukhya arthe bādhaka yukti vyutpādana paratvena api syāt loka vat iti sūtrakhaṇḍam vyācaṣṭe na anyat iti
translated: Therefore, even as explaining the portion of the sutra syallaokavat as having the purpose of bringing out the reasons for contradiction in the primary meaning, he explains na anyat (no other).

analyzed: bhoktṛ āpatteḥ avibhāgaḥ ced syāt loka vat
translated: If it be said that there is no distinction because of the attainment of the experiencer, it would be like in the world.

analyzed: na anyat anyatvam āpannam kvacid dṛṣṭam kathañcana
translated: Nowhere has anything ever been seen to attain another nature.

original: ato jīvasya na brahmabhāvaḥ syāddhi kadācana // / / // /
analyzed: atas jīvasya na brahma bhāvaḥ syāt hi kadācana
translated: Therefore, the individual soul could never become one with Brahman.

analyzed: atra mukhyam eva artham aṅgīkurvāṇaḥ praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Here, one who accepts the primary meaning itself should be asked:

analyzed: kim prāk abhinnasya eva jīvasya muktau brahmaṇā aikyam anena ucyate
translated: Is it said by this that the individual soul, which is non-different before, becomes one with Brahman in liberation?

analyzed: uta bhinnasya athavā
translated: Or of the different. Or

analyzed: bhinna abhinnasya
translated: of the different and non-different.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ abhūta tad bhāva arthasya ekībhavanti iti cvi pratyayasya eva anupapatteḥ
translated: The first is not so, because the suffix 'cvi' (in 'ekibhavanti') which means 'becoming one' is itself not proper for one who was not so before.

analyzed: atas eva na tṛtīyaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the third is not so.

analyzed: aikyasya prāk siddha tvāt
translated: Because oneness is already established.

analyzed: bheda nivṛtti artha tve tu gauṇa artha tva āpatteḥ
translated: But if it were for the purpose of removing difference, it would lead to the fault of having a secondary meaning.

analyzed: dvitīya nirākaraṇena nirasta tvāt ca
translated: And because it has been refuted by the refutation of the second.

analyzed: dvitīye tu idam upatiṣṭhate na anyat iti
translated: In the second, this is presented: 'not different'.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word 'hi' (in fact) is a reason.

analyzed: yatas loke anyat vastu
translated: Because in the world, one thing

analyzed: anya tvam vastu antareṇa abhedam āpannam
translated: is never seen to attain non-difference with another thing,🔽at some time,

analyzed: kvacid kāle  kathañcana upāyena na dṛṣṭam
translated: by some means.

original: atastaddṛṣṭāntena jīvasyāpi kadācana muktāvapi brahmabhāvo brahmatvaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: atas tad dṛṣṭāntena jīvasya api kadācana muktau api brahma bhāvaḥ brahmatvam na syāt
translated: Therefore, by that example, even the individual soul would not become Brahman, even in liberation at some time.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: jīvaḥ na kāla antare brahmaṇā aikyam āpatsyate
translated: The individual soul will not attain oneness with Brahman even at a later time,

analyzed: prāk tyanta bhinna tvāt
translated: because it is absolutely different from that before.

analyzed: yaḥ kadācid yatas u tyantam bhidyate na asau kadācid tad aikyam āpadyate
translated: One who is at some time absolutely different from another never attains oneness with that,

analyzed: yathā ghaṭaḥ paṭena iti
translated: like a pot with a cloth.

analyzed: athavā jīva brahmaṇoḥ bhedaḥ
translated: Or, the difference between the individual soul and Brahman,

analyzed: satoḥ bhedinoḥ na nivṛttimān
translated: There is no cessation of the difference between the existent and the non-existent.

analyzed: bheda tvāt stambha kumbha ādi bheda vat iti
translated: Because of being different, like the difference between a pillar and a pot, etc.

analyzed: āgama bādhitam etat iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that this is contradicted by scripture, it is not so.

analyzed: āgamānām mukhya artha tā sambhave numāna bādhaka tvam
translated: For scriptures are a means of valid knowledge only when their meaning is primary.

analyzed: bādhite ca anumāne teṣām mukhya artha tā iti paraspara āśraya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: And when inference is contradicted, their meaning is secondary. Thus there is the fallacy of mutual dependence.

analyzed: sat pratipakṣa tvāt ca
translated: And because there is a counter-argument.

analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ  yathā udakam ityādikā
translated: Thus the scripture says:🔽As water in water, ghee in ghee, space in space, so the Self in the Self.

analyzed: pralhādaḥ pi parama ātma ātmanoḥ yogaḥ parama arthaḥ iti iṣyatetām
translated: And Prahlada says: The union of the supreme Self and the individual Self is accepted as the highest truth.

original: mithyaitadanyaddravyaṃ hi naiti taddravyatāṃ yataḥ' / iti / /
analyzed: mithyā etat anyat dravyam hi nā eti tad dravya tām yatas iti
translated: This is false, because another substance does not attain the nature of that substance.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is argued:

analyzed: na ayam asti yukti virodhaḥ
translated: This is not a contradiction with reasoning.

analyzed: prāk api abhinnaḥ eva brahmaṇā jīvaḥ iti aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because it is accepted that even before, the individual self is non-different from Brahman.

analyzed: na ca cvi pratyaya anupapattiḥ
translated: And the suffix 'kvip' is not ungrammatical.

analyzed: pratīti apekṣayā tad upapatteḥ  prāk vibhinna tayā dṛṣṭaḥ yam jīvaḥ brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Because it is appropriate in relation to the cognition.🔽This individual self, which was seen before as different from Brahman,

analyzed: atha idānīm muktā avabhinna tayā dṛśyate
translated: is now seen as non-different from Brahman in liberation.

analyzed: iti atas ekībhavanti iti ucyate iti
translated: Therefore it is said to become one.

analyzed: atra idam vaktavyam
translated: Here this should be said:

analyzed: kim prāktanī jīva brahmaṇoḥ bheda dṛṣṭiḥ bhrāntiḥ uta pramā iti
translated: Is the previous perception of difference between the individual soul and Brahman an error or valid knowledge?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no sublating cognition.

analyzed: śrutayaḥ tu adya api avyavasthita arthāḥ na bādhaka tām aśnuvate
translated: The scriptures, whose meaning is not yet settled, do not attain the status of sublators.

analyzed: dvitīye tu āha kvacid iti
translated: In the second case, he says 'where' etc.

analyzed: kvacid bhinna tayā dṛṣṭam tat abhinna tayā katham
translated: How can that which is seen as different somewhere be seen as non-different from that?

original: dṛśyenno dṛṣṭapūrvaṃ hi tādṛśaṃ na ca dṛśyate // / / //
analyzed: dṛśyet no dṛṣṭa pūrvam hi tādṛśam na ca dṛśyate
translated: For what was not seen before in that way is not seen now.

original: kvacitkāle yadvastu yato bhinnatayā pramitaṃ tat kālāntare 'pi kathaṃ tadabhinnatayā pratīmī
analyzed: kvacid kāle yat vastu yatas bhinna tayā pramitam tat kāla antare pi katham tad abhinna tayā pratīmī
translated: At some time, an object which is cognized as different from something, how can it be cognized as non-different from that at a later time?

analyzed: na kathañcid iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: in no way.

original: kuta ityata āha no dṛṣṭapūrvaṃ hīti //
analyzed: kutas iti atas āha no dṛṣṭa pūrvam hi iti
translated: Why is it so? For that reason, he says 'for what was not seen before in that way' etc.

analyzed: tādṛśam prāk bhinna tayā pramitam kāla antare bhinna tayā pramīyamāṇam
translated: That which was cognized as different before is being cognized as non-different at a later time.

analyzed: ayam iha prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: jīvaḥ na kadācid brahma abhinna tayā pramā viṣayaḥ
translated: The individual soul is never the object of valid knowledge as non-different from Brahman.

analyzed: tyanta bhinna tayā pramita tvāt
translated: Because it is cognized as absolutely different from that.

analyzed: yat evam tat evam yathā ghaṭaḥ paṭāt bhinna tayā iti
translated: What is so is so, like a pot as different from a cloth.

analyzed: yaḥ tu kvacid api bheda pramām na manyate
translated: But one who does not consider difference to be cognized anywhere,

analyzed: tam pratyāropita bhedam ekam vastu vyatireka udāharaṇam vācyam
translated: The example of a negative inference is a thing which is one but is superimposed as different from that.

analyzed: evam ca pratītim upādāya api na cvi pratyaya upapattiḥ
translated: And thus, even on the basis of cognition, the non-apprehension of the negative particle is not justified.

analyzed: etad artha tvena api syāt loka vat iti yojyam
translated: Even for the purpose of this, it should be connected as it may be like in the world.

analyzed: tat evam grāvaplavana ādi śruti vat upapatti viruddha tvena śruteḥ mukhya artha asambhavāt amukhya artha
translated: Thus, just as in the case of the Vedic injunction to float on a stone, due to the impossibility of the primary meaning of the Vedic text in contradiction with reasoning, the primary meaning

original: eva svīkaraṇīye parakīyahetorasiddhatvānna brahmaṇo jagatkāraṇatve yuktivirodha iti siddham / /
analyzed: eva svīkaraṇīye parakīya hetoḥ asiddha tvāt na brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatve yukti virodhaḥ iti siddham
translated: should be accepted as secondary. Since the opponent's reason is unestablished, it is established that there is no contradiction with reasoning in Brahman being the cause of the world.

analyzed: kecid idam sūtram anyathā vyācakṣate
translated: Some explain this sutra differently.

original: pūrvaṃ kila cetanācetanātmakasya prapañcasya brahmopādanatvena brahmānanyatvamuktam /
analyzed: pūrvam kila cetana acetana ātmakasya prapañcasya brahma upādana tvena brahma ananyatvam uktam
translated: It is said that earlier, the non-difference of the universe consisting of the conscious and the unconscious from Brahman was stated by Brahman being the material cause of the universe.

analyzed: tat ākṣipya samādhātum idam sūtram
translated: This sutra is to raise objections and resolve them.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

original: yadi cetanācetanātmakasya jagato brahmānanyatvaṃ syāttadā cetano bhoktā bhogyaścācetanā viṣayā ityayaṃ vibhāgo na syāt /
analyzed: yadi cetana acetana ātmakasya jagataḥ brahma ananya tvam syāt tadā cetanaḥ bhoktā bhogyaḥ ca acetanāḥ viṣayāḥ iti ayam vibhāgaḥ na syāt
translated: If the universe consisting of the conscious and the unconscious were non-different from Brahman, then this distinction would not exist - the conscious being is the enjoyer and the unconscious objects are the objects of enjoyment.

analyzed: kutas  bhogyasya api bhoktṛ tva āpatteḥ
translated: Why?🔽Because the object of enjoyment would also become the enjoyer.

analyzed: bhoktuḥ api bhogya tva āpatteḥ
translated: And because the enjoyer would also become the object of enjoyment.

analyzed: bhavitavyam ca anena vibhāgena
translated: And it must be by this division.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi siddha tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is because it is established by perception and other means of knowledge,

analyzed: syāt loka vat
translated: it could be like in the world.

original: yathā loke samudrātmanāmapi phenataraṅgādīnāṃ netaretarabhāvāpattyā vibhāgabhaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: yathā loke samudra ātmanām api phena taraṅga ādīnām na itaretarabhāva āpattyā vibhāga bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Just as in the world, even the foam, waves, etc. of the ocean do not have mutual identity, and there is no division or destruction,

analyzed: yathā vā mahākāśa ātmanām api ghaṭa maṭha ādi ākāśānām
translated: or just as the spaces in pots, huts, etc. are all of the nature of the great space,

analyzed: tathā prakṛte pi syāt iti  tat idam dūṣayati bhoktṛ tva iti
translated: so it could be in the present case as well.

original: bhoktṛtvāpattita iti yanmataṃ tat kuto hariḥ /
analyzed: bhoktṛ tva āpattitaḥ iti yat matam tat kutas hariḥ
translated: He refutes this as follows: If it is argued that it is because of the attainment of the state of an enjoyer, how is Hari (the author of the sutra)?

analyzed: bhoktṛ āpatteḥ iti prāha
translated: He says that it is because of the attainment of the state of an enjoyer.

original: yat yadi bhoktrāpatterityatra bhoktratvāpatteriti vyākhyānaṃ sūtrakārasyāpibhi
analyzed: yat yadi bhoktṛ āpatteḥ iti atra bhoktṛ atva āpatteḥ iti vyākhyānam
translated: If the explanation here in because of the attainment of the state of an enjoyer is that the author of the sutra also

original: mataṃ syāt tat tarhi kuto hariḥ sūtrakṛt bhoktrāpatteriti praāha /
analyzed: matam syāt tat tarhi kutas hariḥ sūtrakṛt bhoktṛ āpatteḥ iti praāha
translated: would have the view of because of the attainment of the state of an enjoyer, then how is Hari, the author of the sutra,

analyzed: bhoktṛ tva āpatteḥ iti eva brūyāt
translated: he would say because of the attainment of the state of an enjoyer.

analyzed: na ca evam abravīt
translated: But he did not say this.

analyzed: tatas na ayam abhiprāyaḥ sūtrakārasya iti  yadi api atra pareṣām asmākam ca adhyāhāra sāmyam
translated: Therefore, this is not the intention of the author of the sutra.🔽Even though here there is equality in the insertion of words by others and by us,

analyzed: tathā api bhāva pratyaya abhāvaḥ parasya adhikaḥ
translated: nevertheless, the absence of the suffix tva is an additional fault for the opponent.

original: ye tu vyācakṣatecidacidvastuśarīratve brahmaṇo jīvavatsukhaduḥkhādibhoktṛtvāpatterjīvabrahmasvabhāvavibhāgo na syāditi cenna /🔽yathā kāntāre nipatitasyasyāpi
analyzed: ye tu vyācakṣate cit acit vastu śarīra tve brahmaṇaḥ jīva vat sukha duḥkha ādi bhoktṛ tva āpatteḥ jīva brahma svabhāva vibhāgaḥ na syāt iti ced na  yathā kāntāre
translated: But those who explain (the Sūtra) thus, (say that) if Brahman has the body of the existent and non-existent things, then, like the individual soul, it would be the enjoyer of pleasure, pain, etc., and there would be no distinction of the nature of the individual soul and Brahman. This is not so.

analyzed: nṛpasya na daṃśa maśaka ādi upadravaḥ tathā atra api syāt iti
translated: Just as a king fallen in a desert is not troubled by mosquitoes, flies, etc., so it would be here also.

analyzed: teṣām api ayam śabda doṣaḥ samānaḥ
translated: For them also this fault of the word is the same.

analyzed: nanu bhāva pradhānāḥ nirdeśāḥ tatra tatra bahulam upalabhyante
translated: But in many places the directions are found to be predominant in the existent.

analyzed: tat katham ayam doṣaḥ bhidhīyate
translated: How then is this fault stated?

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ bhāṣyakārasya
translated: This is the intention of the author of the Bhāṣya.

analyzed: pratipādye vyavasthite tad balāt śābdī gauṇa tā kathañcid anusartavyā
translated: When the subject matter is established, the secondary meaning based on the word should somehow be followed by its power.

analyzed: na ca asya sūtrasya idam pratipādyam vyavasthitam  jagat upādāna tvasya prāk anukta tvena anukta upālambha prasaṅgāt
translated: And this is not the established subject matter of this Sūtra.🔽Because the non-stated is stated, since the being the material cause of the world is not stated before.

original: jagaccharīratvasyāntaryāmyadhikaraṇe prasakte 'pi sambhogaprāptirityanenaiva parihṛtatvāt /🔽tatra jīvaśarīragatatvena prasaktaṃ
analyzed: jagat śarīra tvasya antaryāmi adhikaraṇe sambhoga prāptiḥ iti anena eva parihṛta tvāt  tatra jīva śarīra gata tvena prasaktam
translated: And the being the body of the world, although relevant in the Adhikaraṇa on the Inner Controller, is refuted by this alone, saying the attainment of enjoyment.
There, the being the enjoyer, which is relevant as being related to the body of the individual soul, is refuted.

analyzed: atra tu jagat śarīra tvena iti ced na
translated: If it be said that here (in the present case) the meaning is that the world is the body of Brahman, (we reply that) this is not so.

analyzed: pūrva uttarapakṣayoḥ nyāya aviśeṣe sūtra ārambha anupapatteḥ
translated: For, in the former and the latter discussion, there being no difference in the reasoning, it is not proper to begin a new aphorism.

analyzed: atas nirnimittaḥ śābda doṣaḥ na anusaraṇa arhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, even a verbal fault without a reason is not to be pursued.

original: yadvaitadarthapratipādanāya kathaṃ cetyādyuttaravākyamatrāpi saṃyojya vyākhyeyamityukta eva sūtrārtha iti /
analyzed: yadvā etad artha pratipādanāya katham ca ityādi uttara vākyam atra api saṃyojya vyākhyeyam iti uktaḥ eva sūtra arthaḥ iti
translated: And in order to explain this meaning, the subsequent sentence beginning with how should be connected here also and explained. Thus the meaning of the aphorism is stated.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām bhoktṛ adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Adhikaraṇa on the enjoyer in the auspicious Nyāyasudhā.
VI. The Adhikaraṇa on the beginning (of the world).

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām ārambhaṇa adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the auspicious Nyāyasudhā, the Adhikaraṇa on the beginning (of the world).

original: oṃ tadananyatvamārambhaṇaśabdādibhyaḥ oṃ //🔽prāk pramāṇamūlatvatatsaṃvāditvābhyāṃ prabalayā yuktyā uktektārthe
analyzed: om tad ananya tvam ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ om  prāk pramāṇa mūla tva tad saṃvādi tvābhyām prabalayā yuktyā ukta ikta arthe
translated: Om. Their non-difference is from the word arambhana (beginning) and others.

analyzed: virodhaḥ
translated: Earlier, the contradiction of the repeatedly stated meaning by strong reasoning based on the authority of the means of knowledge and its agreement with other means of knowledge has been removed.

analyzed: bāhulya lakṣaṇa balavat yukti virodha parihārāya idam adhikaraṇam ārabhyate
translated: The removal of the contradiction with the strong reasoning characterized by preponderance is begun in this section.

analyzed: tat idam brahma pariṇāma vādī vyācaṣṭe anantara adhikaraṇe bhogya vargasya pariṇāmataḥ siddha prātisvika rūpa bheda anapahnavena
translated: The proponent of Brahman's transformation explains this as follows: In the immediately preceding section, the worldly established

analyzed: kāraṇā bhedam aṅgīkṛtya sāṅkhaya siddhāntena śāstrataḥ bhoktṛ vargasya svābhāvika rūpa brahma avibhāge
translated: Having accepted the non-difference of cause, the non-difference of the class of enjoyers from the natural form of Brahman is shown by the Sankhya doctrine from the scriptures.

original: bhogyasyāpi brahmaikyavadbhoktṛtvāpattimāśaṅkaya anaikāntikatvena nirāsovi'bhihitaḥ /🔽samprati vaiśeṣikādimatena svarūpakāryavyapadeśādibhedena kāryasya kāraṇātmaka
analyzed: bhogyasya api brahma aikya vat bhoktṛ tva āpattim āśaṅkaya anaikāntika tvena  samprati vaiśeṣika ādi matena svarūpa kārya vyapadeśa ādi bhedena kāryasya kāraṇa ātmaka
translated: The objection that the object of enjoyment would also become an enjoyer like Brahman is refuted by showing its inconclusiveness.

analyzed: tva asiddhayā prapañcasya brahma advaitam ākṣipya samādhīyate
translated: Now, the non-dualism of Brahman and the world is questioned by the Vaisheshika and other doctrines, which establish the identity of effect with cause by the difference of form, effect, designation, etc., and is answered.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus:

analyzed: tad ananyatvam tena brahmaṇā ananya tvam kāryasya
translated: The non-difference from that, from Brahman, of the effect.

original: kutaḥ / ārambhaṇaśabdādibhyaḥyathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena vijñātena sarvaṃ mṛṇmayaṃ vijñātaṃ syāt /
analyzed: kutas ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ yathā somya ekena mṛd piṇḍena vijñātena sarvam mṛṇmayam vijñātam syāt
translated: Why? From the words arambhaṇa and so on. Just as, my dear, by knowing one clod of earth, all that is made of earth would be known,

analyzed: vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam
translated: name is a mere verbal designation, clay alone is real.

analyzed: iti adi śabdāt
translated: From such words.

analyzed: ādi grahaṇāt aitadātmyam idam sarvam
translated: By the word ādi (etc.), the Upanishadic texts that teach identity are included, such as All this has that Self,

analyzed: yat ayam ātmā
translated: This Self is to be known,

analyzed: sarvam khalu idam brahma 🔽ityādi tādātmya āvedaka śruti parigrahaḥ iti
translated: All this is indeed Brahman.

original: vivartavādī tu vyākhyātiabhyupagamya cemaṃ vyāvahārikaṃ bhoktṛbhogyalakṣaṇaṃ vibhāgam /
analyzed: vivarta vādī tu vyākhyāti abhyupagamya ca imam vyāvahārikam bhoktṛ bhogya lakṣaṇam vibhāgam
translated: But the advocate of the doctrine of evolution explains: Having accepted this division characterized by enjoyer and objects in the conventional sense,

analyzed: syāt loka vat
translated: it may be like in the world.

analyzed: iti parihāraḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: This answer has been stated.

analyzed: na tu ayam vibhāgaḥ pāramārthikaḥ sti
translated: But this division does not exist ultimately.

original: yasmāt tadananyatvaṃ kāraṇādbrahmaṇaḥ kāryasyākāśādeḥ paramārthato 'nanyatvaṃ vyatirekeṇābhāvaḥ /🔽avagamyate /
analyzed: yasmāt tad ananyatvam kāraṇāt brahmaṇaḥ kāryasya ākāśa ādeḥ paramārthataḥ vyatirekeṇa abhāvaḥ  avagamyate
translated: Because the non-difference of the effect, such as space, from Brahman, the cause, is known to be real non-difference, absence of difference.

analyzed: kutas ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ iti
translated: How is it known? From the words arising, etc.

analyzed: tatra ādyam vyākhyānam tāvat nirākaroti katham ca iti
translated: Among them, he first refutes the first explanation, saying And how?

analyzed: tad ananya tvam ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ
translated: The non-difference from that is due to the words arising, etc.

analyzed: katham ca tad ananyatā
translated: And how is that non-difference?

analyzed: katham iti ākṣepe
translated: And how is a question.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pūrva sūtra apavyākhyāna ākṣepeṇa asya samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of including this with the refutation of the previous explanation of the aphorism.

analyzed: jagataḥ iti vakṣyamāṇam atra api sambaddhayate
translated: Of the world is to be connected here also.

analyzed: atra pratipādyā syāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: This would be taught is the remainder.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ
translated: This is the idea:

original: yo hi brahmopādānatāṃ jagato 'bhyupagamyāpi tadanyatāṃ manyate so 'tra pūrvapakṣīkaraṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ hi brahma upādānatām jagataḥ abhyupagamya api tad anya tām manyate saḥ tra pūrvapakṣīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: One who, even while accepting the world's dependence on Brahman, thinks it to be different from that, should be made the opponent here.

analyzed: na ca vaiśeṣika ādiḥ tathā iti prāpti abhāvāt na tad ananyatva ukteḥ avasaraḥ sti
translated: And since the Vaiśeṣika and others do not accept this, there is no occasion for the statement of non-difference due to the absence of attainment.

analyzed: brahma upādānatām an aṅgīkurvāṇam prati tu sā eva samarthanīyā
translated: But for one who does not accept Brahman as the material cause, that very [non-difference] should be established.

analyzed: na tu tad ananyatā
translated: But not the non-difference from that.

analyzed: tad adhīna siddhi tvāt asyāḥ
translated: Because this [non-difference] depends on that [material cause].

original: atha brahmopādānatāpyatra samarthyata iti cet / na /
analyzed: atha brahma upādāna tā api atra samarthyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even the status of Brahman as the material cause is being established here, [we say] no.

analyzed: tathā sati prakṛti adhikaraṇa vaiyarthya āpatteḥ  prakṛti adhikaraṇa nyāyena uyaḥ  papāditam
translated: Because in that case the Purva Mimamsa section would be pointless.

original: tamabhyupetyāpi tadanyatāṃ manyamāno 'tra pūrvapakṣīti cet / na /
analyzed: tam abhyupetya api tad anya tām manyamānaḥ tra pūrvapakṣī iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the opponent here [in the Purva Mimamsa section] thinks that even though Brahman is established by the reasoning of the Purva Mimamsa section, it is different from that, [we say] no.

analyzed: kim idam brahma upādāna tvam brahma samavāyi tvam vā
translated: What is this status of Brahman as the material cause? Is it the inherence in Brahman,

analyzed: brahma pariṇāma tvam vā
translated: or the transformation of Brahman,

analyzed: yat pareṇa aṅgīkāritam
translated: which the opponent accepts?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ kalpaḥ  tasya ananyatva virodhāt
translated: The first alternative is not correct.🔽Because it is contradictory to non-difference.

analyzed: samavāyasya nirākariṣyamāṇa tvāt ca
translated: And because inherence will be refuted.

analyzed: dvitīye prayatna vaiyarthyam eva
translated: In the second case, the effort is pointless.

analyzed: nahi kaḥ pi pariṇāma vādam aṅgīkṛtya atyanta bhedam aṅgīkurute
translated: For no one, accepting the doctrine of transformation, accepts absolute difference between cause and effect.

analyzed: yam prati idam ārabhyeta iti
translated: For which [opponent] this [argument] would be begun.

original: yadvā kathaṃ ca tadananyatā jagato vaktuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: yat vā katham ca tad ananyatā jagataḥ vaktum śakyate
translated: Or, how can it be said that the world is not different from that?

analyzed: ananya tvam hi bheda abhāvaḥ
translated: For non-difference means absence of difference,

analyzed: atyanta abhedaḥ iti yāvat
translated: that is, absolute non-difference.

analyzed: bheda abhedau ca pareṇa aṅgīkṛtau
translated: And difference and non-difference are accepted by the opponent.

analyzed: atas tādātmyam iti vaktavyam syāt
translated: Therefore, it should be said that it is identity.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ  yāvatā kāryasya kāraṇena abhedaḥ eva
translated: This is not a fault.🔽For the effect is indeed non-different from the cause.

analyzed: kāraṇasya tu kāryāt bhedaḥ eva
translated: But the cause is indeed different from the effect.

analyzed: iti evam bheda abhedau aṅgīkṛtau iti ced na
translated: Thus, difference and non-difference are accepted. If this is said, it is not so.
