original: yadi brahma jagato 'nyadeva tadā kathaṃ ca tadananyatvaṃtā🔽jagataḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi brahma jagataḥ tadā katham ca  jagataḥ syāt
translated: If Brahman is indeed different from the world, then how can the world be non-different from that?

analyzed: nahi yat yatas tyanta bhinnam tat tena atyanta abhinnam iti sambhavati
translated: For it is not possible that what is absolutely different from something is absolutely non-different from it.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt iti
translated: Because of the absurdity of over-extension.

original: athavā kathaṃ ca tadananyatā pratijñātuṃ yuktā /
analyzed: athavā katham ca tad ananyatā pratijñātum yuktā
translated: Or else, how can it be proper to assert that it is not different from that?

original: pramāṇābhāvāditi śeṣaḥ /🔽nanu cārambhaṇaśabdādibhya ityuktatvātkathaṃ pramāṇābhāva iti cet /
analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt iti śeṣaḥ  nanu ca ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ iti ukta tvāt katham pramāṇa abhāvaḥ iti ced
translated: The remainder is: because there is no means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: atra vaktavyam
translated: But since it has been said that it is due to words such as 'arambhaṇa', how can there be no means of valid knowledge? If this is said, it should be stated here.

analyzed: ārambhaṇa śabdaḥ tāvat kim sākṣāt jagataḥ brahma ananyatvam ācakṣīta
translated: To begin with, does the word 'arambhaṇa' directly declare that the world is not different from Brahman?

analyzed: uta vikārasya vikāri ananya tvam
translated: Or does it declare that the modification is not different from the modified?

original: ādye kathaṃ ca tadananyatā jagatosyārthaḥ syāt /
analyzed: ādye katham ca tad ananyatā jagataḥ asya arthaḥ syāt
translated: In the first case, how can the meaning of this be the non-difference of the world from that?

analyzed: yathā somya iti mṛd piṇḍa ādeḥ prakṛta tvāt iti uttaram
translated: The answer is: because a lump of clay etc. is the subject matter.

analyzed: dvitīye bhavatu nāma vikārasya vikāri ananyatvam
translated: In the second case, let there be the non-difference of the modification from the modified.

analyzed: jagataḥ tu katham tad ananyatā iti
translated: But how can there be the non-difference of the world from that?

original: nanu vikārasya vikāryananyatve tenokte 'pi jagato brahmānanyatvaṃ siddhayatyeva /
analyzed: nanu vikārasya vikāri ananyatve tena ukte jagataḥ brahma ananyatvam
translated: But when the non-difference of the modification from the modified is stated, the non-difference of the world from Brahman is established even then,

analyzed: tasya api tad vikāra tvāt iti atas āha jagataḥ tu iti
translated: because that (world) is also its modification. To this he says:

analyzed: jagataḥ tu avikāra tve ukta nyāyena sādhite
translated: When the non-modification of the world is established by the stated reasoning,
in the non-modification, i.e., in the absence of being a modification of Brahman,

analyzed: ukta nyāyena na ca prakṛtiḥ
translated: by the stated reasoning, i.e., by the statement the modification is not the cause etc.

analyzed: ityādinā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: This is the remainder.

analyzed: sādhite sati katham ca tad ananyatā iti anvayaḥ
translated: When that is established, how can there be the non-difference from that? This is the connection.

analyzed: yat vā jagataḥ iti pūrveṇa eva sambaddhayate
translated: Or, the world is connected with the previous (statement).

analyzed: avikāra tve brahmaṇaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: in the non-modification of Brahman.

analyzed: na vidyate vikāraḥ yasya iti avikāram
translated: That which has no modification is non-modification.

analyzed: tasya bhāvaḥ tattvam tasmin
translated: The state of that is the truth. In that.

analyzed: nanu atra ārambhaṇa śabda śa 🔽bdena ota tam ādeśam aprākṣi akṣaḥ
translated: But here, by the word arambhana (beginning),🔽one would ask that teacher,

analyzed: ityādyā śrutiḥ upalakṣyate
translated: The words and so on indicate other similar passages.

original: tattātparyaparyālocanāyāṃ ca jagato brahmavikāratvaṃ tadanantyavaṃ cāvagamyate iti cenna /
analyzed: tad tātparya paryālocanāyām ca jagataḥ brahma vikāra tvam tad anantyavam ca avagamyate iti ced na
translated: And if it is argued that the non-difference of the world from Brahman is understood from the consideration of the purport of those passages, that is not so.

analyzed: mahāvākya avāntaravākya upakrama tva pradhāna vāci tva ādi abhāvena asya śruti upalakṣaṇayā upādāne nimitta abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no reason for including this passage as an indication of the Vedic text, due to the absence of being the beginning of a great sentence, expressing the primary meaning, and so on.

analyzed: abhyupetya api upalakṣaṇa tvam āha avikāra tve iti
translated: Even accepting the indicative nature, he says in the word non-modification.

original: vikarātvādanyasminsādṛśyādau śrutyarthatayoktanyāyena sādhite sati śrutitātparyaparyālocanayā ca kathaṃ tadananyatā siddhayediti / /
analyzed: vikarā tvāt anyasmin sādṛśya ādau śruti arthatayā ukta nyāyena sādhite sati śruti tātparya paryālocanayā ca katham tad ananyatā siddhayet iti
translated: How can the non-difference from that be established by the consideration of the purport of the Vedic text, when modification and other things are proved by the reasoning stated as the meaning of the Vedic text, such as similarity and so on?

analyzed: yat api uktam ādi pada gṛhītāt aitadātmyam idam sarvam ityādi vākyāt tad ananyatva siddhiḥ iti tat api asat
translated: And what was said - that the non-difference from that is established from the passages beginning with in that all this has its Self included by the word and so on - that is also not so.

analyzed: ādi padena vākya antara grahaṇasya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible to include other sentences by the word and so on.

original: tathā satyeteṣāmapi śabdatvenārambhaṇādiśabdebhya iti prayogaprasaṅgāt /🔽astu vā kathañcidādipadopāttatātvaṃ
analyzed: tathā sati eteṣām api śabda tvena ārambhaṇa ādi śabdebhyaḥ iti prayoga prasaṅgāt  astu vā kathañcid ādi pada upātta tā tvam
translated: If that were so, then due to their being words, there would be the possibility of using the expression from the words beginning with 'arambhanam' and so on.

analyzed: teṣām vākyānām
translated: Or let there be the inclusion by the word and so on of those passages in some way.

analyzed: tathā api nā etebhyaḥ tad ananya tā siddhayati
translated: Still, non-difference from them is not established for these.

analyzed: upapatti viruddha tvāt iti āśayena pṛcchati katham ca iti
translated: With the idea that this is contrary to reason, he asks How, indeed?

original: yā sūtrakṛtā pratijñātā śrutibhiśca pratipāditā sā jagatastadananyatā kathaṃ kiṃprakārā /
analyzed: yā sūtrakṛtā pratijñātā śrutibhiḥ ca pratipāditā sā jagataḥ tad ananyatā katham kiṃprakārā
translated: The non-difference of the world from that which was affirmed by the author of the Vedanta and taught by the scriptures, how is that? In what way?

original: kiṃ pikaḥ kokilaḥ' /🔽itivadekatvalakṣaṇā kiṃvā mṛdghaṭa itivadvikārari
analyzed: kim pikaḥ kokilaḥ  itivat ekatva lakṣaṇā kiṃvā mṛd ghaṭaḥ itivat vikārari
translated: Is it like The cuckoo is a bird,

analyzed: vikārira
translated: indicating identity, or like The pot is of clay, indicating the relation of the modified and the modifier?

analyzed: tva lakṣaṇā iti praśna arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the question.

analyzed: ādyam ākṣipati katham ca iti
translated: He rejects the first by saying How, indeed?

original: ekatvalakṣaṇā jagatastadananyatā tu kathaṃ sūtrakṛtā pratijñāyeta /
analyzed: ekatva lakṣaṇā jagataḥ tad ananyatā tu katham sūtrakṛtā pratijñāyeta
translated: How, indeed, could the author of the Vedanta affirm the non-difference of the world from that, which is indicated by identity?

original: kathaṃ ca śrutibhiḥ pratipādyeta na kathañcidityarthaḥ /
analyzed: katham ca śrutibhiḥ pratipādyeta na kathañcid iti arthaḥ
translated: And how could it be taught by the scriptures? In no way at all, is the meaning.

analyzed: atra hetum āha avikāra tve iti
translated: Here he gives the reason, saying Because of the immutability of Brahman.

original: brahmaṇo 'vikāratva uktanyāyena sādhite sati jagatastu vikārātmakatve pratyakṣādipramite sati viruddhadharmādhikaraṇatvāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ vikāra tve ukta nyāyena sādhite sati jagataḥ tu vikāra ātmaka tve pratyakṣa ādi pramite sati viruddha dharma adhikaraṇa tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: When the immutability of Brahman has been established by the stated reasoning, and when the world is known by perception etc. to be of the nature of modification, then, because it has contradictory properties as its substratum, is the idea.

analyzed: dvitīyam ākṣipati katham ca iti
translated: He rejects the second by saying How, indeed?

analyzed: vikāri vikāra tva rūpaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is in the form of the modified and the modifier.

analyzed: ākṣepe yuktim āha jagataḥ tu iti
translated: In the denial, he states the reason thus: 'of the world' etc.

analyzed: vyākhyānam pūrvavat
translated: The explanation is as before.

analyzed: nanu evam upapatti viruddhā api jagataḥ brahma ananyatā aṅgīkaraṇīyā
translated: But in this way, even if it contradicts reason, the non-difference of the world from Brahman must be accepted.

analyzed: anyathā etad ātmyam idam sarvam ityādi śrutīnām aprāmāṇya prasaṅgāt iti atas āha katham ca iti
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the invalidity of the scriptures that state 'all this has that as its Self' and so on. To this, he says 'how' etc.

analyzed: avikāri tve pi vikāra tvāt anyasmin tad adhīna tva ādau śruti arthe svātantrye ca viśiṣṭa tve
translated: Even if there is immutability, when the meaning of the scriptures, such as dependence on that and the like, other than modification, and independence in the qualified nature,

analyzed: iti ukta nyāyena sādhite sati katham tad ananyatā aṅgīkartum ucitā
translated: have been established by the reasoning stated, how is it proper to accept that non-difference?

analyzed: sa avakāśa śruti pratītā u pi arthaḥ niravakāśa upapatti virodhāt tyājyaḥ eva
translated: Even if a meaning is understood from scriptures with scope, it must be abandoned due to contradiction with reason without scope.

analyzed: yathā uktam abhimāni adhikaraṇe iti bhāvaḥ
translated: As stated in the section on superimposition. This is the idea.

analyzed: aparam api vyākhyānam dūṣayati katham ca iti
translated: He criticizes another explanation thus: 'how' etc.

analyzed: iti prāha iti anuvartate
translated: 'Thus he said' is continued.

analyzed: yadi atra kārya mātra prapañcasya anṛta tvam sūtrakṛtaḥ bhimatam syāt
translated: If the author of the aphorisms intended the mere product of effects to be false,

analyzed: tadā anṛta tvam iti eva brūyāt
translated: then he would have said 'false'.

analyzed: tat ananyatvam iti katham prāha
translated: How did he say 'that non-difference'?

analyzed: nahi brahma ananyatva śabdaḥ
translated: For the word 'non-difference from Brahman' does not mean 'false'.

analyzed: tathā sati brahmaṇaḥ pi anṛta tva prasaṅgāt
translated: If that were so, then Brahman also would be non-true.

original: nanu ca tadananyatvaṃ tadvayatirekeṇābhāva iti vyākhyātam /
analyzed: nanu ca tad ananyatvam tad vayatirekeṇa abhāvaḥ iti vyākhyātam
translated: But it has been explained that non-difference from that means non-existence apart from that.

analyzed: satyam  na tathā api anṛta tva lābhaḥ
translated: True.🔽Even so, non-truth is not gained.

analyzed: tad vayatirekeṇa na asti iti ukte tad ātmanā asti iti labhyate
translated: When it is said that it does not exist apart from that, it is understood that it exists in the nature of that.

analyzed: na punar sarvathā api anṛta tvam
translated: But not at all in the sense of non-truth.

analyzed: anyathā brahma atirekeṇa asataḥ jīva caitanyasya api sarvathā anṛta tvam syāt
translated: Otherwise, the individual consciousness, which does not exist apart from Brahman, would also be entirely non-true.

analyzed: prasiddham ca etat  yad viśiṣṭa viṣayaḥ
translated: And this is well known.

analyzed: pratiṣedhaḥ viśeṣaṇam upasaṅkrāmati iti
translated: That a negation with a qualified object passes over to the qualification.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: tathā api brahma vivarta tā jñāpanāya evam uktam iti ced na
translated: Even so, if it is argued that this is said in order to teach that this is a transformation of Brahman, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati tatra āropita tva  m iti vaktavya tvāt
translated: If that were so, then it should be said that it is superimposed there.

original: nahi śuktikāśakale kaladhautamāropitamiti vaktavye tatonanyaditi prayuñjajyate /🔽atha brahmasattayaivedaṃ sat /
analyzed: nahi śuktikā śakale kaladhautam āropitam iti vaktavye tatas na anyat iti  atha brahma sattayā eva idam sat
translated: For when it is to be said that refined gold is superimposed on a piece of shell, one does not use the expression it is not different from that.🔽If it is argued that this is the purpose of this statement, namely, to show that this exists only by the existence of Brahman,

analyzed: na aparā sattā asya asti iti jñāpanam etasya prayojanam iti ced
translated: and that it has no other existence.

analyzed: tarhi paramārtha sat eva idam iti āyātam iti katham anṛta tvam
translated: Then it follows that this is ultimately real. How then can it be non-true?

original: atha yeyaṃ prapañce sattāvagamyate sādhiṣṭhānabrahmagataivāropitetyanena jñāpyata iti cet /
analyzed: atha yā iyam prapañce sattā avagamyate sā adhiṣṭhāna brahma gatā eva āropitā iti anena jñāpyate iti ced
translated: If it be said that it is shown by this (verse) that the existence which is perceived in the world is only superimposed on Brahman which is the substratum,

analyzed: pyāropita ākārasya anyatra pāramārthyam āvaśyakam
translated: then, as in the case of the doctrine of non-apprehension of difference, so in the case of the doctrine of non-apprehension of the non-different, it is necessary that the form superimposed on another should be real in that other.

analyzed: tathātve ca ākāśa tva ādikam api brahmaṇi pāramārthikam aṅgīkāryaṃraṇīyam syāt
translated: And if that be so, then the reality of the nature of ether, etc. in Brahman must be admitted, and it would be as good as refuted.

analyzed: rajata tva ādikam ca śuktikāyām iti
translated: And the nature of silver, etc. in the mother-of-pearl, etc.

original: yadvā syāllokavaditi bhoktṛbhogyaprapañcasya satyatāmabhidhāyedānīṃ kathaṃ ca tadananyateti tadviruddhamanṛtatvaṃ prāheti yojanā /
analyzed: yat vā syāt loka vat iti bhoktṛ bhogya prapañcasya satyatām abhidhāya idānīm katham ca tad ananyatā iti tad viruddham anṛta tvam prāha iti yojanā
translated: Or, the construction is: having stated the reality of the world of enjoyer and enjoyed by saying it may be like the world, now he states the unreality which is contrary to that, by saying how can that be non-different?

analyzed: nanu sūtrakāraḥ paramārtha abhiprāyeṇa tad ananyatvam iti āha
translated: But the author of the aphorisms says that is non-different with reference to the highest truth.

analyzed: vyavahāra abhiprāyeṇa tu syāt loka vat iti
translated: But with reference to usage he says it may be like the world.

analyzed: tat kutas virodha sati ced na
translated: How can there be a contradiction in this? If it be said that there is, we reply: no.

analyzed: pratāraka tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of being a deceiver.

analyzed: anyathā pratyācakṣīta
translated: Otherwise he would have rejected it.

analyzed: a pratyākhyāya eva kārya prapañcam
translated: Without rejecting the world of effects,

analyzed: pariṇāma prakriyām āśrayati
translated: he resorts to the process of modification.

analyzed: sa guṇeṣu upāsaneṣu upayokṣyate iti iti ced
translated: If it be said that it will be useful in the meditations with attributes,

analyzed: kim sa guṇa upāsana viṣaya prayojane prakṛta viṣaya prayojana anukūle
translated: Is it favourable to the purpose of the subject-matter, which is the object of meditation with attributes?

analyzed: uta tad viruddhe  atha udāsīne
translated: Or is it contrary to it?🔽Or is it neutral?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: bheda viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because it has difference as its object.

analyzed: sāṃsārika phala tvāt ca
translated: And because it has worldly results.

analyzed: bheda vāsanā hi su dṛḍhā tām eva upodbalayet
translated: For the impression of difference is very strong, it would only strengthen that.

analyzed: atas eva na tṛtīyaḥ pi
translated: For this very reason, not the third either.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: anāpta tva aparihārāt iti
translated: Because it does not avoid being incomplete.

analyzed: athavā āstām tāvat iyam grantha ārjava cintā
translated: Or let this consideration of the straightforwardness of the text rest for now.

original: kathaṃ ca tadananyatānṛtatvalakṣaṇā jagato yuktā syāt /
analyzed: katham ca tad ananyatā anṛta tva lakṣaṇā jagataḥ yuktā syāt
translated: And how could the characteristic of the unreality of the non-difference of the world be proper?

analyzed: na kathañcid iti yojyam
translated: It should be connected as in no way.

analyzed: atra hetum āha jagataḥ iti
translated: Here he gives the reason, saying of the world and so on.

analyzed: avikāri tva brahma vivarta tva abhāve
translated: In the absence of being a modification of Brahman.

analyzed: yat ca avikṛtam ityādi ukta nyāyena
translated: And what is unmodified, etc., according to the reasoning stated.

analyzed: evam pramāṇa abhāva para tvena api pūrvavat vayākhyeyam iti
translated: Thus, even as having the absence of valid means of knowledge as its purport, it should be explained as before.

original: evaṃ tarhi ko 'syārtha ityata āha svatantreti //
analyzed: evam tarhi kaḥ sya arthaḥ iti atas āha svatantra iti
translated: If so, then what is the meaning of this? Therefore he says independent and so on.

analyzed: svatantra kāraṇa anyatvam tena hi atra
translated: The difference from an independent cause is prohibited here by that.

original: yata evaṃ jagato brahmānanyatvamanekavidhamapi nātra pratipādyaṃ /
analyzed: yatas evam jagataḥ brahma ananyatvam anekavidham api nā atra pratipādyam
translated: Since thus the non-difference of the world from Brahman, in many ways, is not to be taught here,

analyzed: tena iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is by that.

analyzed: anena apavyākhyāna nirākaraṇam sva vyākhyāna dṛḍhīkaraṇa artha tvāt na asaṅgatam iti smārayati
translated: By this (verse) he reminds us that the refutation of the misinterpretations is not irrelevant, because it serves to strengthen his own interpretation.

analyzed: kartṛ anadhīna sattā śakti ādimat kāraṇa antara tad vyapekṣā khalu ghaṭa ādi sṛṣṭiḥ dṛṣṭā  tatas mahat ādi sṛṣṭiḥ api kartṛ vyatirikta svatantra kāraṇa sa vyapekṣā sṛṣṭi tvāt ghaṭa sṛṣṭi vat
translated: The creation of pots, etc., is seen to be dependent on a cause other than the creator, which possesses existence, power, etc., not dependent on anything else.🔽Therefore, the creation of Mahat, etc., is also dependent on a cause other than the creator, which is independent, because it is a creation, like the creation of a pot.

analyzed: mahat ādikam vā sa apekṣa utpattikam
translated: Or Mahat, etc., are effects whose production is dependent on a cause other than the creator, which is independent, because they are effects, like a pot.

original: prakṛtyādikaṃ vā svatantraṃ kāraṇatvānmṛdādivat /🔽īśvaro vā svatantrakāraṇasavyaṇāntarasā
analyzed: prakṛti ādikam vā svatantram kāraṇa tvāt mṛd ādi vat  īśvaraḥ vā svatantra kāraṇa savya ṇa antarasā
translated: Or Prakṛti, etc., are independent causes, because they are causes, like clay, etc.

analyzed: pekṣaḥ kartṛ tvāt kulāla lādi
translated: Or God is dependent on a cause other than an independent one, because he is an agent, like a potter, etc.

original: vaditi yuktiviruddhatvājjanmādisūtre 'bhipretaṃ yatparasyaiva brahmaṇaḥ svātantryaṃ tannopapadyate /
analyzed: vat iti yukti viruddha tvāt janma ādi sūtre bhipretam yat parasya eva brahmaṇaḥ svātantryam tat na upapadyate
translated: Thus, because it is contrary to reason, the independence of Brahman alone, which is intended in the aphorism on origination, etc., is not tenable.

analyzed: na ca śruti virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with the scriptures.

analyzed: śrutīnām brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatva mātra paratvāt
translated: Because the scriptures are concerned only with Brahman being the cause of the world.

analyzed: svatantra kāraṇa antara nirāse śruteḥ abhāvāt
translated: There is no scripture for the denial of an independent other cause.

analyzed: bhāve pi apauruṣeya tayā śruti prābalya vat bāhulyena yukti prābalyasya api sambhavāt
translated: The Veda is not authoritative due to the possibility of a counter-argument.

analyzed: sat pratipakṣa tayā  tyā abhipreta avadhāraṇa anupapatteḥ iti evam prāptam
translated: This is the prima facie view.

analyzed: svatantra kāraṇa anyatvam brahmaṇaḥ nyasya svatantra kāraṇatvam iti yāvat
translated: The meaning is: the existence of another independent cause, i.e., the existence of something other than Brahman as an independent cause.

analyzed: atra adhikaraṇe
translated: In this section.

analyzed: tad ananyatvam iti anena
translated: That is not so is denied by the words it is not different from that.

analyzed: mahat ādi sṛṣṭau yat svatantra kāraṇam tasya tad ananyatvam iti
translated: The meaning is: that which is the independent cause in the creation of Mahat and so on, it is not different from that.

analyzed: yadi atra svatantra kāraṇa abhāvaḥ iti eva brūyāt
translated: If one were to say here that there is an absence of an independent cause,

analyzed: tadā brahmaṇaḥ u pi svātantryam pratiṣiddham syāt
translated: then even Brahman's independence would be denied.

original: tadananyatvaṃ svatantrakāraṇasyetyukte hi svatantrakāraṇaṃ tadeva nānyaditi labhyate /🔽tadupapādanāya yatārambhaṇaśabdādibhyaḥ' /
analyzed: tad ananyatvam svatantra kāraṇasya iti ukte hi svatantra kāraṇam tat eva na anyat iti labhyate  tad upapādanāya yata ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ
translated: For when it is said that the non-difference from that is of an independent cause, it is understood that the independent cause is that itself, not something else.

analyzed: iti sva pakṣe pramāṇam uktam  yaḥ ca bhāve ca upalabdheḥ
translated: In order to establish that, the means of valid knowledge in one's own view is stated: From the words beginning with 'arambhanam' (Chand. Up. 6.1.1).🔽And the absence of means of valid knowledge in the contrary view is stated: And because it is perceived in non-existence.

analyzed: iti vipakṣe pramāṇa abhāvaḥ tat ubhayam hi śabdena sūcayati
translated: This both is indicated by the word hi (therefore).

analyzed: nanu ārambhaṇa ādi ākṣepa śabda ādibhyaḥ iti vaktavyam
translated: But should it not be said from the objections based on the word 'ārabhyaṇa' and so on?

analyzed: satyam  lakṣita lakṣaṇayā eṣaḥ eva arthaḥ pratipādyate iti adoṣaḥ
translated: True.🔽The same meaning is being conveyed by suggestive indication, so there is no fault.

analyzed: tathā api kim svid āsīt adhiṣṭhānam iti
translated: Even so, What indeed was the substratum? - this is the statement of the Ṛg Veda.

analyzed: śrauta nirdeśa anusāreṇa adhiṣṭhānasya upādānam ucitam iti ced na  śābdāt api artha prādhānyasya balavat tvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is proper to mention the substratum in accordance with the Vedic injunction, that is not so.🔽Because the meaning is stronger than the word.

analyzed: sādhakatamam karaṇam iti vacana asmaraṇāt
translated: Because it is not remembered that the best means is the instrument.

original: nanu ca svatantrakāraṇasya brahmānanyatvaṃ pratijñāya kāraṇāntarābhāve pramāṇopanyāso 'saṅgataḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca svatantra kāraṇasya brahma ananyatvam pratijñāya kāraṇa antara abhāve pramāṇa upanyāsaḥ saṅgataḥ
translated: But is it not irrelevant to state the proof of the absence of other causes after affirming that Brahman is not different from the independent cause?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: asti atra abhiprāyaḥ
translated: There is an intention here.

analyzed: vakṣyate hi
translated: For it will be said:

analyzed: ca brahma atirikta prakṛti ādi kāraṇa sadbhāvaḥ
translated: The existence of causes other than Brahman, such as Prakṛti, is stated.

analyzed: ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ tad abhāvaḥ vagamyate
translated: Their absence is understood from words like 'ārabhyaṇa'.

original: tatorthātsvatantrakāraṇāntarabhāve ca pramāṇairupalabdheḥ prasaṅga iti vadanpramāṇābhāvamāha /
analyzed: tatas ṛthāt svatantra kāraṇa antara bhāve ca pramāṇaiḥ upalabdheḥ prasaṅgaḥ iti vadan pramāṇa abhāvam āha
translated: Therefore, when the existence of other independent causes is perceived by means of proofs, it is said that there is an undesirable consequence, and thus he states the absence of proof.

analyzed: evam manyate
translated: He thinks as follows:

original: śuṣkābhyo bahuyuktibhyo 'pi śrutyanugṛhītānāṃ bahvīnāṃ yuktīnāṃ prābalyāttadviruddhānāṃ pūrvapakṣayuktīnāmaprāmāṇyamiti / /
analyzed: śuṣkābhyaḥ śruti anugṛhītānām bahvīnām yuktīnām prābalyāt tad viruddhānām pūrvapakṣa yuktīnām aprāmāṇyam iti
translated: Even from many dry arguments, the prior arguments which are contrary to those [arguments] which are supported by scripture and are many and strong, are not valid.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: adbhayaḥ sambhūtaḥ ityādi vacanāt katham brahma atiriktasya svatantra kāraṇasya anupalabdhiḥ
translated: How is there no perception of a self-sufficient cause other than Brahman, from statements such as He arose from the waters?

original: nacātra na svātantryaṃ śrūyata iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca atra na svātantryam śrūyate iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that independence is not mentioned here.

analyzed: pāratantrya anuktau svātantryasya loka anurodhāt eva siddheḥ iti
translated: Because independence is established by worldly consensus itself, even if dependence is not stated.

analyzed: etad parihārāya sūtram om sattvāt ca avarasya iti om
translated: To answer this, the sutra is: And because of the existence of the lower.

analyzed: tasya ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of that [sutra]:

original: syādayaṃ doṣo yadi vayaṃ brahmātiriktaṃ kāraṇameva nāstīti vadāmaḥ /
analyzed: syāt ayam doṣaḥ yadi vayam brahma atiriktam kāraṇam eva na asti iti vadāmaḥ
translated: This fault would arise if we said that there is no cause at all apart from Brahman.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: avarasya tad adhīnasya prakṛti ādeḥ kāraṇasya sattvāt iti
translated: Because there is a cause, such as prakriti, which is lower and dependent on that [Brahman].

original: tadidaṃ parihārāya na paryāptam /🔽yāvatā pūrvapakṣiṇā pāratantryānuktau svātantryameva setyasyatītyuktam /
analyzed: tat idam parihārāya na paryāptam  yāvatā pūrvapakṣiṇā pāratantrya anuktau svātantryam eva sā iti asyati iti uktam
translated: This is not sufficient to answer that [objection].🔽Because the opponent has said that if dependence is not stated, independence itself is established.

analyzed: anyathā pūrvapakṣasya nirdala tva āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, because the opponent's position would be without support.

original: ityataḥ prakṛtyādeḥ kāraṇajātasyeśvarādhīnasattākatva pramāṇaṃ darśayansūtraṃ vyācaṣṭe dravyamiti //
analyzed: iti atas prakṛti ādeḥ kāraṇa jātasya īśvara adhīna sattāka tva pramāṇam darśayan sūtram vyācaṣṭe dravyam iti
translated: Therefore, showing the proof that the group of causes beginning with Prakṛti depends on God for existence, he explains the aphorism with the word 'substance'.

analyzed: sattvāt ca aparasya
translated: And because of the existence of another.

original: asadvyapadeśān neti cen na dharmāntareṇa vākyaśeṣāt / / / /
analyzed: asat vyapadeśāt na iti ced na dharma antareṇa vākyaśeṣāt
translated: If it be said that it is not so on account of the designation of non-existence, it is not so, on account of another attribute, as appears from the complementary passage.

original: dravyaṃ karma ca kālaśca svabhāvaścetanā dhṛtiḥ /
analyzed: dravyam karma ca kālaḥ ca svabhāvaḥ cetanā dhṛtiḥ
translated: Substance, action, time, nature, intelligence, and support,

analyzed: yad prasādāt ime santi na santi yad upekṣayā
translated: by whose favour these exist, and by whose neglect they do not exist,

analyzed: iti śruteḥ tad vaśasya
translated: on account of this Vedic text, the existence of that which is subject to it is accepted.

analyzed: cetanāḥ jīvāḥ
translated: Intelligence refers to the souls.

analyzed: dhṛtiḥ cit prakṛtiḥ
translated: Support refers to the Nature.

analyzed: dhāraka tvāt iti śruteḥ
translated: Because it is the supporter.

analyzed: prakṛti ādeḥ tad vaśasya bhāvaḥ aṅgīkriyate
translated: The existence of that which is subject to that is accepted, i.e., of the Nature, etc.

analyzed: atas dbhayaḥ sambhūtaḥ iti atra api svātantrya asiddheḥ na anupalabdhiḥ yuktā iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, even in the text 'He is born of water', since independence is not established, non-apprehension is not proper. This is the meaning.

original: yadyapi ārambhaṇaśabdāderadbhayaḥ sambhūta iti śruteśca parasparaviredhādarthāpattyaivaiṣo 'rtho labhyate /
analyzed: yadi api ārambhaṇa śabda ādeḥ adbhayaḥ sambhūtaḥ iti śruteḥ ca paraspara viredhāt arthāpattyā eva eṣaḥ rthaḥ labhyate
translated: Although this meaning is obtained by presumption itself due to the mutual contradiction of the words 'arising' etc. and the Vedic text 'He is born of water',

analyzed: tathā api manda apekṣayā spaṣṭa śruti udāharaṇam
translated: nevertheless, the example of the clear Vedic text is given with reference to the dull-witted.

original: yadvā svatantrakāraṇānyatvaṃ niṣiddhayata ityanena paratantrakāṇāntarasadbhāvaḥ sūcitaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā svatantra kāraṇa anyatvam iti anena paratantra kāṇa antara sadbhāvaḥ sūcitaḥ
translated: Or, by the phrase 'the difference of an independent cause is denied', the existence of a dependent cause is indicated.

analyzed: anyathā kāraṇa anya tvam iti eva syā brūyāt
translated: Otherwise, he would have simply said 'the difference of a cause'.

original: sa paratantrakāraṇasadbhāvaḥ kṛta ityata āha dravyamiti //
analyzed: sa paratantra kāraṇa sadbhāvaḥ kṛtaḥ iti atas āha dravyam iti
translated: That dependent cause is established, therefore he says 'substance' etc.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ gamyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is 'is understood'.

analyzed: atra tad vaśa tvam vidheyam
translated: Here, that subordination is to be enjoined.

analyzed: kāra ra sadbhāvasya pareṇa api aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because the existence of a cause is accepted by the opponent as well.

original: oṃ asadvayapadeśānneti cenna dharmāntareṇa vākyaśeṣāt oṃ //
analyzed: om asat vayapadeśāt na iti ced na dharma antareṇa vākyaśeṣāt om
translated: If it be said that it is not so because of the declaration of non-existence, no, because of another attribute, due to the remainder of the sentence.

analyzed: iti sūtram
translated: This is the aphorism.

analyzed: tatra ākṣepasya ayam arthaḥ
translated: Here, this is the meaning of the objection:

analyzed: na asat āsīt na usat āsīt tadānīm
translated: 'There was neither non-existence nor existence then' (Rg. Veda 10.129.1).

analyzed: iti mahāpralaye mūrta amūrta ādeḥ aśeṣasya asattva vyapadeśāt kāraṇa upalabdhi paricodanā
translated: Due to the declaration of non-existence of the entire manifest and unmanifest at the time of the great dissolution, there is a challenge to the perception of the cause.

original: tasyeśvaravaśasyāṅgīkāreṇa samādhānaṃ ca nopapadyate /🔽nacāyaṃ pakṣaḥasaditi cet' /
analyzed: tasya īśvara vaśasya aṅgīkāreṇa samādhānam ca nā upapadyate  na ca ayam pakṣaḥ asat iti ced
translated: And the solution by accepting it as under the control of God is not possible.

analyzed: ityādinā eva nirākṛtaḥ
translated: And this view is not refuted by the statement 'if it be said that it is not so' etc.

analyzed: tatra īśvarasya api anaṅgīkārāt
translated: Because there God is not accepted.

analyzed: iha punar īśvaram aṅgīkṛtya kāraṇa antara nirākaraṇāt
translated: But here, accepting God, the denial of another cause is made.

analyzed: na ca adbhayaḥ sambhūtaḥ
translated: And 'from water it came into being' (Svet. Up. 6.8).

analyzed: ityādi virodhaḥ
translated: This is the contradiction.

analyzed: atra mahāpralaye kāraṇa antara sadbhāvasya aśravaṇāt
translated: Here, because the existence of another cause in the great dissolution is not heard,

analyzed: īśvara atirikta kartṛkāsu sṛṣṭiṣu ap ādi kāraṇa sadbhāva paratvāt ca
translated: and because the statements about the existence of the cause of non-existence, etc., in creations other than those by God are about that.

analyzed: evam ca ārambhaṇa śabda ādayaḥ pi samañjasāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: And thus the words arambhana and so on become reasonable.

analyzed: atra na iti siddhānta aṃśam vyācaṣṭe dravyam iti
translated: Here, he explains the part of the conclusion na (it is not so) with dravya (substance).

analyzed: na mahāpralaye kāraṇa antarasya abhāvaḥ vācyaḥ
translated: It should not be said that there is no other cause in the great dissolution.

analyzed: kintu tad vaśasya bhāvaḥ eva
translated: But there is existence under its control.

analyzed: tasya tad vaśa tvam kutas iti ced
translated: If it is asked how it is under its control,

analyzed: dravyam iti
translated: it is said dravya (substance).

analyzed: śruteḥ iti  nanu na asat āsīt
translated: It is because of the Vedic text.

analyzed: iti sarvasya asattva vyapadeśāt katham na iti atas uktam dharma antareṇa iti
translated: But since it is said that in the beginning there was neither non-existence nor existence (Rg Veda 10.129.6), how can it not be so? Therefore it is said by another attribute.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe tad vaśasya iti
translated: He explains that with taddhasya (that of it).

analyzed: sāvadhāraṇam ca idam
translated: And this is with a restrictive particle.

analyzed: tad vaśasya eva bhāvaḥ pralaye
translated: There is existence under its control in the dissolution.

analyzed: na svatantrasya  tatas svātantrya lakṣaṇa dharma viśeṣa abhiprāyeṇa asattva vyapadeśaḥ yujyate
translated: Not of the independent one.🔽Therefore, the designation of non-existence is appropriate with the intention of a particular attribute characterized by independence.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a metaphor.

analyzed: yathā uktam bhāṣye
translated: As it is said in the Bhāṣya (commentary).

original: yatkhalu paratantramavyaktaṃ kāryānabhimukhaṃ tadasaditi vyapadiśyate / /🔽kutaḥ śruteḥ mukhyārthaparityāgenāmukhyārtho 'ṅgīkriyate /
analyzed: yat khalu paratantram avyaktam kārya anabhimukham tat asat iti vyapadiśyate  kutas śruteḥ mukhya artha parityāgena amukhya arthaḥ ṅgīkriyate
translated: That which is indeed dependent on another, unmanifest, not facing its effect, is called non-existent.🔽Why? Because the primary meaning is abandoned and the secondary meaning is accepted.

analyzed: tamaḥ āsīt ityādi vākya śeṣāt
translated: From the remainder of the sentence beginning with tamas āsa (there was darkness).

analyzed: na ca tamaḥ brahma  ānīda vātam
translated: And tamas is not Brahman.🔽Ānīd vātam (it breathed forth the air).

analyzed: iti tasya pṛthak avasthāna ukteḥ
translated: Because its separate existence is stated.

analyzed: na ca ananta prakāśasya tamaḥ tvam upapadyate
translated: And the state of tamas is not proper for the infinite light.

analyzed: kintu prakṛteḥ eva
translated: But it is of prakriti itself.

analyzed: ācchādaka tva ādeḥ iti
translated: Because of its covering nature, etc.

original: nanu ca pralaye 'vasthitaṃ cetprakṛtyādi tasya svātantryādidharmābhāvaḥ kutaḥ /🔽yenaivaṃ vyākhyāyata iti cet /
analyzed: nanu ca pralaye ced prakṛti ādi tasya svātantrya ādi dharma abhāvaḥ kutas  yena evam vyākhyāyate iti ced
translated: But if prakriti and others exist at the time of dissolution, how can they be devoid of the attributes of independence, etc.?

analyzed: vākya upakrama tad śeṣayoḥ virodhāt arthāpattyā eva iti brūmaḥ
translated: If it is asked why it is explained thus, we say it is by presumption itself due to the contradiction between the beginning of the sentence and its remainder.

original: śrūyate ca spaṣṭamityāśayavānvākyaśeṣādityetatprakārāntareṇa vyācaṣṭe na para iti // /
analyzed: śrūyate ca spaṣṭam iti āśayavān vākya śeṣāt iti etat prakāra antareṇa vyācaṣṭe na paras iti
translated: With the intention that it is heard clearly, he explains from the remainder of the sentence in a different way as not other.

analyzed: na paraḥ iti atas
translated: Not other - from this...

analyzed: tasmāt ha anyatra paras kiñca na āsa
translated: Therefore, there is nothing else higher than that, nor is there anything lower.

analyzed: iti atas vākya śeṣāt prakṛti ādīnām pralaye svātantrya ādi abhāvaḥ vagamyate iti arthaḥ
translated: From this remainder of the sentence, the absence of independence, etc. of prakriti and others at the time of dissolution is understood - this is the meaning.

original: iha hi tasmādbrahmaṇo 'nyatprakṛtyādikaṃ paraḥ paraṃ svātantryādidharmopetaṃ nāseti tatsadbhāvābhyupagamena paratvaṃ niṣiddhayate /
analyzed: iha hi tasmāt brahmaṇaḥ nyat prakṛti ādikam paras param svātantrya ādi dharma upetam tad sadbhāva abhyupagamena paratvam
translated: For here it is not said that anything else, such as primordial matter, is superior to that Brahman, which possesses the attributes of independence, etc.; its superiority is denied by accepting its existence.

analyzed: anyathā para śabda vaiyarthyāt iti
translated: Otherwise, the word para would be meaningless.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be argued:

analyzed: kāraṇa antara sadbhāvam abhyupagamya tasya īśvara adhīna tām vadatā siddhāntinā idam vaktavyam
translated: By accepting the existence of another cause, the proponent of the conclusion should say that it is dependent on God.

original: kimīśvaraḥ prakṛtyādibhirvināpi kadācitsṛṣṭayādikaṃ karotyuta taireveti niyamaḥ /
analyzed: kim īśvaraḥ prakṛti ādibhiḥ vinā api kadācid sṛṣṭayā ādikam karoti uta taiḥ eva iti niyamaḥ
translated: Does God sometimes create, etc., even without primordial matter, etc., or is there a rule that it is only with them?

original: ādye teṣāṃ kathaṃ kāraṇatvamaniyatatvāt /🔽anyathā rāsabhasyāpi ghapa
analyzed: ādye teṣām katham kāraṇa tvam aniyata tvāt  anyathā rāsabhasya api ghapa
translated: If the first, how can they be causes, being not necessary?

analyzed: ṭa kāraṇa tā āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, even a donkey would be the cause of a horse.

original: dvitīye tu kathaṃ tatparityāgena kadāpyakurvāṇasyeśvarasya svātantryam /
analyzed: dvitīye tu katham tad parityāgena kadāpi akurvāṇasya īśvarasya svātantryam
translated: But if the second, how can God, who never acts without them, be independent?

analyzed: katham ca niyamena apekṣaṇīyānām teṣām pāratantryam
translated: And how can they, who are necessarily required, be dependent?

original: evaṃ pṛkṛtyaiva mahāntaṃ mahataivāhaṅkāramityādiniyamaṃ kadācidapahāya sṛjati utānena niyamenaiva /
analyzed: evam pṛkṛtyā eva mahāntam mahatā eva ahaṅkāram ityādi niyamam kadācid apahāya sṛjati uta anena niyamena eva
translated: In the same way, does God sometimes create, abandoning the rule by primordial matter he creates Mahat, by Mahat he creates ego, etc., or by this very rule?

analyzed: ādye tu aniyata tvena akāraṇatva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If the first, there is the undesirable consequence of being not a cause due to being not necessary.

original: dvitīye punarīśvarādeḥ svātantryādyanupapattiḥ /🔽tathā prakṛtyādikamupādānīkṛtya kālādikaṃ nimittīkṛtya sṛjatīti niyame vyatyāse coktadoṣānuṣaṅgaḥ / /
analyzed: dvitīye punar īśvara ādeḥ svātantrya ādi anupapattiḥ  tathā prakṛti ādikam upādānīkṛtya kāla ādikam nimittīkṛtya sṛjati iti niyame vyatyāse ca ukta doṣa anuṣaṅgaḥ
translated: In the second case, the independence, etc. of God and others is not possible.🔽Similarly, if it is said that He creates by taking primordial matter, etc. as the material cause and time, etc. as the instrumental cause, then the previously stated faults follow from such a restriction and reversal.

original: ato yuktibādhitatvādasyārthasya kāraṇāntaranirapekṣa eva bhagavantsṛṣṭayādikaṃ karātītyeva jyāyaḥ /
analyzed: atas yukti bādhita tvāt asya arthasya kāraṇa antara nirapekṣaḥ eva bhagavan sṛṣṭayā ādikam karāti iti eva jyāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, because this meaning is contradicted by reasoning, it is better to accept that the Lord creates without depending on any other cause.

analyzed: evam ca nirargalam aiśvaryam asya samarthitam syāt
translated: And in this way, His unrestricted lordship would be established.

analyzed: na ca pramāṇa bādhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: adbhayaḥ sambhūtaḥ pṛthivyai rasāt ca ityādeḥ anīśvara kartṛka avāntara sṛṣṭi viṣaya tvasya ukta tvāt
translated: Because it has been said that statements like He arose from the waters, from the earth, and from the essence refer to a subsidiary creation not made by God.

original: tama āsīdityādau tamaḥprabhṛtīnāṃ pralaye sattvaśravaṇe 'pīśvarakartṛkāyāṃ sṛṣṭau kāraṇatvāśravaṇādityāśaṅkāpanodanārthaṃ sūtram //
analyzed: tamaḥ āsīt ityādau tamaḥ prabhṛtīnām pralaye sattva śravaṇe pi īśvara kartṛkāyām sṛṣṭau kāraṇatva aśravaṇāt iti āśaṅkā apanodana artham sūtram
translated: Even though statements like It was darkness refer to the existence of darkness, etc. at the time of dissolution, the fact that they are not stated as causes in the creation made by God is removed by the following sutra.

analyzed: om yukteḥ śabda antarāt ca om  iti
translated: Om. Because of reasoning and other statements, Om.

analyzed: asya ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of that.

analyzed: na ukta yukti virodhena bhagavataḥ kāraṇa antara vidhura tvam urarīkartavyam
translated: The fact that the Lord is devoid of other causes should not be accepted due to the contradiction with the stated reasoning.

analyzed: kāraṇa antara sadbhāva abhyupagame pi prakṛti ādeḥ kāraṇa tvasya īśvara ādi svātantrya ādikasya ca yukteḥ
translated: Even if the existence of another cause is accepted, the causality of Prakriti and others and the independence of God and others is reasonable.

original: nacaivaṃ tarhi vinigamane kāraṇābhāva iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca evam tarhi vinigamane kāraṇa abhāvaḥ iti vācyam
translated: And in that case, it should not be said that there is no reason for the determination.

analyzed: adbhayaḥ sambhūtaḥ hiraṇya garbhaḥ iti ādi śabda antarāt
translated: Because of the different word from water in the statement Hiranyagarbha was born from water.

analyzed: pūrva udāhṛta śabda vilakṣaṇa śabdaḥ śabda antaram
translated: Different word means a word that is different from the previously quoted words.

analyzed: tena idam uktam bhavati
translated: By that, this is said:

original: yadyapi prāgudāhṛtāḥ śabdāḥ kathañcidanyathā netu śakyante /
analyzed: yadi api prāc udāhṛtāḥ śabdāḥ kathañcid anyathā netu śakyante
translated: Although the previously quoted words can be interpreted otherwise somehow,

analyzed: tathā api ayam na tathā
translated: this one is not like that.

analyzed: atra īśvara kartṛkāyām eva sṛṣṭau kāraṇa antara sadbhāva śravaṇāt
translated: Because in this [statement], the existence of another cause is heard only in the creation done by God.

analyzed: nahi hiraṇyagarbha sṛṣṭiḥ anīśvara kartṛkā
translated: For the creation of Hiranyagarbha is not done by one who is not God.

analyzed: tasya eva prathama ja tvāt iti
translated: Because He alone is the first-born.

original: atra yukteriti yā svapakṣe kāraṇatvāderghaṭanoktā sā kathamityapekṣāyāmāha śakto 'pīti /
analyzed: atra yukteḥ iti yā sva pakṣe kāraṇa tva ādeḥ ghaṭanā uktā sā katham iti apekṣāyām āha
translated: Here, the reason is stated as the arrangement of causality and so on in one's own position. When there is expectation of how that is, it is said although able.

original: yukteḥ śabdāntarāc ca / / / /🔽śakto 'pi hyanyathākartuṃ svecchāniyamato hariḥ /
analyzed: yukteḥ śabda antarāt ca  śaktaḥ hi anyathā kartum sva icchā niyamataḥ hariḥ
translated: By reason and by a different word.

analyzed: kāraṇaiḥ niyataiḥ eva karoti idam jagat sadā
translated: For Hari, although able to create otherwise, always creates this world only with fixed causes, by the restriction of His own will.

analyzed: anyathā kāraṇaiḥ vinā
translated: Otherwise, without causes.

original: kartuṃ śakto 'pi hariḥ kāraṇāntarāṇyupādāyaiva kariṣyāmīti svecchāniyamataḥ kāraṇairevedaṃ jagatsadā sṛjati /
analyzed: kartum śaktaḥ api hariḥ kāraṇa antarāṇi upādāya eva kariṣyāmi iti sva icchā niyamataḥ kāraṇaiḥ evā idam jagat sadā sṛjati
translated: Even though able to create without causes, Hari creates this world always only with causes, by the restriction of His own will, thinking, I will create only by taking other causes.

analyzed: evam anyathā
translated: Similarly, otherwise.🔽Taking Prakṛti as the cause, the Great One by Ahamkāra, and so on.

original: prakṛtyāhaṅkāramahaṅkāreṇa mahāntamiti evam tathā prakṛtiṃ nimittīkṛtya kālādikaṃ
analyzed: prakṛtyā ahaṅkāram ahaṅkāreṇa mahāntam iti evam tathā prakṛtim nimittīkṛtya kāla ādikam
translated: Even though able to create by taking Prakṛti as the cause and taking time etc.

analyzed: ca upādānīkṛtya kartum śaktaḥ pi etena eva idam etat upādānīkṛtya eva idam srakṣyāmi iti sva icchā niyamataḥ
translated: as the material cause, by the restriction of His own will, thinking, I will create this only by taking this as the material cause,

analyzed: niyataiḥ kḷptaiḥ eva
translated: only with the fixed, established causes.

original: tathā niyataiḥ svaniyatasattāśaktyādimadbhireva kāraṇairidaṃ jagatsadā karotīti yojanā / /
analyzed: tathā niyataiḥ sva niyata sattā śakti ādimadbhiḥ eva kāraṇaiḥ idam jagat sadā karoti iti yojanā
translated: Similarly, this world is always created by the Lord only with the fixed causes, which possess the fixed power of existence etc. This is the construction of the sentence.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: yat uktam īśvarasya kāraṇa upādāna ādi niyamaḥ sti na vā iti
translated: It has been said whether there is restriction of cause, material cause etc. for God or not.

analyzed: tatra asti iti brūmaḥ
translated: To that we say there is.

analyzed: tathā ca prakṛti ādīnām kāraṇa tvam yuktam
translated: And thus the causality of Prakṛti etc. is proper.

original: saca niyamo na kulālāderiva tānyapahāya vyatyasya vā akaraṇe śaktyabhāvanibandhanaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca niyamaḥ na kulāla ādeḥ iva tāni apahāya vyatyasya vā akaraṇe śakti abhāva nibandhanaḥ
translated: And that restriction is not due to the absence of power in not creating without abandoning or inverting them like a potter etc.

original: yena tasya svātantryam teṣāṃ ca pāratantryaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: yena tasya svātantryam teṣām ca pāratantryam na syāt
translated: By which (means) there would be no independence of Him and dependence of them.

analyzed: kinnāma sva icchā āyattaḥ eva
translated: What is it? It is only dependent on His own will.

analyzed: tatas svātantrya ādikam api yuktam
translated: Therefore, independence etc. are also proper.

analyzed: na ca tāni svādhīna sattā śakti ādimanti
translated: And those (means) do not have existence, power etc. under their own control.

analyzed: yena aiśvaryam nirargalam na syāt
translated: By which sovereignty would not be unobstructed.

analyzed: kintu bhagavati eva tadīyam sattā ādikam āyatate
translated: But in the Lord alone, His existence etc. are extended.

analyzed: tatas tat sācivyam atiśayena aiśvaryasya dyotakam eva
translated: Therefore, that assistance is only a revealer of sovereignty in an extraordinary way.

analyzed: yathā uktam sādhanānām sādhana tvam yat ātma adhīnam iṣyate
translated: As it is said: When the instrumentality of the means is considered to be dependent on the self,

analyzed: tadā sādhana sampattiḥ aiśvarya dyotikā bhavet iti
translated: then the perfection of the means would be a revealer of sovereignty.

original: nanu śaktasyāpīśvarasya tanniyamānusaraṇecchā kuta iti cet /
analyzed: nanu śaktasya api īśvarasya tad niyama anusaraṇa icchā kutas iti ced
translated: If it is asked why the desire to follow that restriction of the powerful Lord arises,

original: kiṃ kāraṇaṃ pṛcchasyuta jñāpakam /🔽ādye svabhāvo 'yamiti brūmaḥ vadāmaḥ /
analyzed: kim kāraṇam pṛcchasi uta jñāpakam  ādye svabhāvaḥ yam iti brūmaḥ vadāmaḥ
translated: what is being asked? The cause or the indicator?

analyzed: dvitīye tu śruti prasiddheḥ iti
translated: If the first, we say it is His nature. If the second, we say it is because of the well-known Vedic texts.

analyzed: tat idam uktam hi śabdena
translated: This is what is stated by the word Hi (indeed).

analyzed: śrutim ca udāhariṣyati
translated: And the Vedic text will be cited.

original: anena śabdāntarācceti sūtraṃ prakārāntareṇa vyākhyātaṃ jñātavyam /
analyzed: anena śabda antarāt ca iti sūtram prakāra antareṇa vyākhyātam jñātavyam
translated: It should be understood that this sutra And from another word is explained in a different way by this.

analyzed: śabda antaram ca śabda viśeṣaḥ
translated: And another word is a particular word.

analyzed: vivakṣita artha pratipādakaḥ śabdaḥ iti yāvat
translated: That is, a word is that which conveys the intended meaning.

analyzed: paṭa vat ca yathā prāṇa ādiḥ iti sūtre
translated: And like a cloth, as in the sutra 'Just as life, etc.'

analyzed: bhāṣye eva vyakte
translated: It is clear in the commentary itself.

analyzed: anye punar anyathā etāni sūtrāṇi varṇayanti
translated: Others, however, explain these sutras differently.

analyzed: tathā hi  bhāve ca upalabdheḥ
translated: Thus:🔽And because the effect is perceived when the cause exists.

original: mṛdādeḥ kāraṇasya bhāva eva ghaṭādeḥ kāryasyopalabdheścānanyatvaṃ kāraṇātkāyarsya /
analyzed: mṛd ādeḥ kāraṇasya bhāvaḥ eva ghaṭa ādeḥ kāryasya upalabdheḥ ca ananya tvam kāraṇāt
translated: Because the effect, such as a pot, is perceived only when the cause, such as clay, exists, the effect is not different from the cause.

analyzed: nahi yat yatas bhinnam tat tad bhāvaḥ eva upalabhyate
translated: For what is different from something is not perceived to exist only when the former exists.

analyzed: na hi aśvaḥ gotaḥ nyaḥ goḥ bhāvaḥ eva upalabhyate
translated: For a horse, which is different from a cow, is not perceived to exist only when a cow exists.

analyzed: kiñca bhāve tila ādau kāraṇe
translated: Moreover, when the cause, such as sesame seeds, exists,

analyzed: taila ādi upalabhyate
translated: the effect, such as oil, is perceived.

analyzed: kārye ca bhāve kuṇḍala ādau suvarṇa ādikam
translated: And when the effect, such as an earring, exists, gold, etc.,

analyzed: atas ca tad abheda siddhiḥ
translated: are perceived. Therefore, the non-difference of the two is established.

analyzed: sattvāt ca avarasya
translated: And because the effect is said to exist prior to the cause.

analyzed: avara kālīnasya prāc utpatteḥ sat eva somya idam agre āsīt
translated: Because the effect, which exists at a later time, is said to exist prior to its origination, as in the statement 'This world existed in the form of Being alone, O dear one, in the beginning.'

original: iti sattvāvadhārarāccānanyatvaṃ kāraṇātkāryasya / /🔽asadvayapadeśānneti cenna dharmāntareṇa vākyaśeṣāt /
analyzed: iti kāraṇāt kāryasya  asat vayapadeśāt na iti ced na dharma antareṇa vākyaśeṣāt
translated: And because of the determination of existence, the effect is not different from the cause.

analyzed: asat eva idam agre āsīt
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because it is said to be non-existent, it is not so, because it is a different property, as stated in the remainder of the sentence.

analyzed: asat vai idam agre āsīt
translated: 'This world existed in the form of non-existence alone in the beginning.'🔽'This world existed in the form of non-existence alone in the beginning.'

analyzed: iti prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya asattva vyapadeśāt na iti ced na
translated: If it be argued that “on account of the said declaration of the effect being non-existent before birth, it cannot be so”, that cannot be so.

analyzed: bhavet etat yadi kārya svarūpa abhiprāyeṇa ayam vyapadeśaḥ syāt kintu vyakta tva lakṣaṇa dharma antara abhiprāyeṇa
translated: This would be so if the said declaration were made with reference to the form of the effect; as a matter of fact, however, it is made with reference to another property, in the form of being ‘manifest’.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why so?

original: vākyaśeṣāt /🔽asadevedamagra āsīt ityasacchabdenopakrame nirdiṣyaṃ punastatsadāsīditi vākyaśeṣe nirdiśati /
analyzed: vākya śeṣāt  asat eva idam agre āsīt iti asat śabdena upakrame nirdiṣyam punar tat sat āsīt iti vākyaśeṣe nirdiśati
translated: Because of the supplementary passage.🔽In the passage ‘In the beginning, this was non-existent’, the term ‘non-existent’ is used in the opening sentence, with reference to what is going to be described; and in the subsequent sentence ‘It became existent’, it is spoken of as ‘existent’;

analyzed: asat vā iti atra api tat ātmānam svayam akuruta iti
translated: and again in the passage ‘It became non-existent’, the term ‘non-existent’ is used with reference to the same thing that was spoken of as ‘existent’.

analyzed: tena jñāyate na asat kāryam dharma antareṇa eva asattva vyapadeśaḥ iti
translated: From all this it follows that the effect is not non-existent; the term ‘non-existent’ is used with reference to another property.

analyzed: yukteḥ śabda antarāt ca
translated: On the ground of reason and of other Vedic texts.

original: yukteśca kāyarsya prāgutpatteḥ sattvaṃ kāraṇādananyatvaṃ ca gamyate /
analyzed: yukteḥ ca prāk utpatteḥ sattvam kāraṇāt ananya tvam ca gamyate
translated: On the ground of reason, it is understood that the effect must be existent before birth, and it cannot be different from the cause.

analyzed: śabda antarāt ca
translated: And on the ground of other Vedic texts.

original: yuktistāvadasadakāraṇādityādikā sāṅkhayoktā /🔽vṛttivikalpānupapattyādikā ca saugatoktā /🔽śabdāntaraṃ cāsadvayapadeśādanyaḥsadeva somyedamagra āsīt' /
analyzed: yuktiḥ tāvat asat akāraṇāt iti ādikā sāṅkhayā uktā  vṛtti vikalpa anupapatti ādikā ca saugata uktā  śabda antaram ca asat vayapadeśāt anyaḥ sat eva somya idam agre āsīt
translated: The reasonings that have been put forward by the Sāṃkhyas are such as ‘because what is non-existent cannot be produced’, and so forth;🔽and those put forward by the Buddhists are such as ‘because the notion of the effect being existent cannot be explained, etc. etc.’🔽As for the other Vedic texts, there is the text quoted above (under Text 21) ‘In the beginning, this was existent only, one, without a second’, which speaks of the effect as existent;

analyzed: iti ādi sat vayapadeśaḥ
translated: and there is the other text (Chāndogya Upaniṣad, 6.2.1) ‘In the beginning, this was existent only, one, without a second’, which also speaks of the effect as existent.

analyzed: paṭa vat ca
translated: And also because it is like the Cloth.

original: saṃveṣyitaprasāritapaṭanyāyenedaṃ kāraṇātkāryasyānanyatvaṃ prāgutpatteḥ sattvaṃ ca pratipattavyam / /
analyzed: saṃveṣyita prasārita paṭa nyāyena idam kāraṇāt kāryasya ananya tvam prāk utpatteḥ sattvam ca pratipattavyam
translated: This non-difference of the effect from the cause, and its existence prior to origination, should be understood in the manner of a cloth being spread out and drawn out.

original: atra sūtrākṣarāṇāmārjavānārjavādicintā śiṣyaireva kriyatāmityāśayavān yaduktaṃ kāraṇātkāryasyānanyatvaṃ
analyzed: atra sūtra akṣarāṇām ārjava anārjava ādi cintā śiṣyaiḥ eva kriyatām iti āśayavān yat uktam kāraṇāt kāryasya ananyatvam
translated: Here, the thought of the straightness, crookedness, etc. of the letters of the aphorism should be done by the disciples themselves. With this intention, he thinks that what is said, the non-difference of the effect from the cause,

analyzed: tat tāvat nirākariṣyan kim anena prabandhena nimitta kāraṇa ananya tvam kāryasya upapāditam
translated: that he will refute. What has been established by this series of arguments? Is it the non-difference of the effect from the instrumental cause?

original: utopādānakāraṇānanyatvamiti vikalpaṃ cetasi nidhāyādyaṃ nirākaroti nityabheda iti //🔽nityabhedo nimittena hy / / / // / / //
analyzed: uta upādānakāraṇa ananyatvam iti vikalpam cetasi nidhāya ādyam nirākaroti nitya bhedaḥ iti  nitya bhedaḥ nimittena hi
translated: Or is it the non-difference of the effect from the material cause? Having placed this alternative in his mind, he first refutes the first [view] with The difference is eternal.🔽The difference is eternal, because of the instrumental cause.

analyzed: nitya śabdaḥ niyama arthaḥ
translated: The word eternal means always.

analyzed: bhedaḥ eva iti
translated: The difference alone.

analyzed: kāryasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is of the effect.

analyzed: hi iti sarva pramāṇa prasiddhim sūcayati
translated: Hi indicates the well-known fact of all means of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā ca sarvam idam bādhita viṣayam iti
translated: And thus, all this has an invalid object.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second [view] is not [correct].

analyzed: prakṛta anupayogāt
translated: Because it is not useful for the present topic.

analyzed: viyat ādi prapañcasya brahma ananyatvam upapādayitum khalu asya upanyāsaḥ
translated: For this [argument] is introduced in order to establish the non-difference of the world beginning with ether from Brahman.

original: tadyadi nāma upādānānanyatvaṃ kāryasya tadā kimāyātaṃ prakṛte /
analyzed: tat yadi nāma upādāna ananyatvam kāryasya tadā kim āyātam prakṛte
translated: If the effect is not different from the material cause, then what is the relevance to the present topic?

original: nahi brahma prapañcopādānamityetaduktaprāyamiti manvāno dūṣaṇāntaramāha upādāneneti //
analyzed: nahi brahma prapañca upādānam iti etat ukta prāyam iti manvānaḥ dūṣaṇa antaram āha upādānena iti
translated: For it has almost been said that Brahman is not the material cause of the world. Thinking this, he states another fault: By the material cause, there are two...

analyzed: upādānena tu dvayam
translated: By the material cause, there are two...

analyzed: hi iti anuvartyate
translated: Hi is to be supplied.

analyzed: upādānena kāryasya dvayam bheda abhedau pramitau
translated: By the material cause, two things are known about the effect: difference and non-difference.

analyzed: tatas smin api pakṣe bādhita viṣaya tvam iti
translated: Therefore, in this view also, the subject is contradicted.

original: kathaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇena bhinnābhinnaṃ pramitamityata āha asaditi //
analyzed: katham kāryam kāraṇena bhinna abhinnam pramitam iti atas āha asat iti
translated: How is it known that the effect is different and non-different from the cause? To this he says: What is non-existent...

analyzed: asat yat kārya rūpeṇa kāraṇa ātma tayā asti hi
translated: What is non-existent, indeed, exists in the form of the effect and the nature of the cause...

original: yat ghaṭādikaṃ mṛdādikāraṇātmatayā prāgutpatterastīti pramitaṃ pareṇāṅgīkṛtaṃ ca
analyzed: yat ghaṭa ādikam mṛd ādi kāraṇa ātmatayā prāk utpatteḥ asti iti pramitam pareṇa aṅgīkṛtam ca
translated: What is admitted by the opponent as existing in the form of the cause such as clay, etc. before its production,

original: tadeva pṛthubudhnodarākārādinā kāryarūpera prāgutpatterasat hi yasmāttasmādupādānena
analyzed: tat eva pṛthu budhna udara ākāra ādinā prāk utpatteḥ asat hi yasmāt tasmāt upādānena
translated: that very thing is non-existent in the form of the effect such as having a bulbous, flat-bottomed, spherical shape, etc. before its production, because it is so. Therefore,

analyzed: bhinna abhinnam iti niścīyate
translated: it is ascertained to be different and non-different by the material cause.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

original: paro hi ghaṭādeḥ kāryasya prāgutpatteḥ sattvamabhyupagacchati /
analyzed: paraḥ hi ghaṭa ādeḥ kāryasya prāk utpatteḥ sattvam abhyupagacchati
translated: The opponent accepts the existence of the effect such as the pot before its production.

analyzed: tat kim pṛthak eva uta mṛd ādi kāraṇa ātmatayā iti vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be said whether it is different or identical with the material cause like clay etc.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ  anabhyupagamāt
translated: The first is not so.🔽Because it is not accepted.

analyzed: anupalabdheḥ ca
translated: And because it is not perceived.

analyzed: dvitīye tu kāryasya upādāna abhedaḥ tāvat aṅgīkṛtaḥ
translated: But in the second case, it is admitted that the effect is non-different from the material cause.

analyzed: na ca atyanta abhedaḥ
translated: And it is not absolutely non-different.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ kārya ākāreṇa prāk utpatteḥ asattvāt
translated: Because the effect like a pot etc. does not exist prior to its production in the form of an effect.

analyzed: yadā hi ghaṭa ādikam mṛd ādinā atyanta abhinnam syāt
translated: For if the pot etc. were absolutely non-different from clay etc.,

analyzed: tadā prāk utpatteḥ ghaṭa ādi rūpeṇa sat syāt
translated: then it would exist in the form of a pot etc. prior to its production.

analyzed: mṛd ādeḥ tadā sattvāt
translated: Because clay etc. would exist at that time.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: tena jānīmaḥ ghaṭa ādikam mṛd ādinā bhinna abhinnam iti
translated: Therefore we know that the pot etc. are different and non-different from clay etc.

original: atyantāsatkāryavādinaṃ prati bhedābhedasamarthanaṃ virodhaparihāraścottaratra vidhāsyata iti / /
analyzed: atyanta asatkārya vādinam prati bheda abheda samarthanam virodha parihāraḥ ca uttaratra vidhāsyate iti
translated: The establishment of difference and non-difference and the avoidance of contradiction will be done later on against the proponent of absolutely non-existent effect.

original: yacca kāryasya prāgutpatteḥ sattvamuktaṃ tadapi nopapannamityāha asaditi //
analyzed: yat ca kāryasya prāk utpatteḥ sattvam uktam tat api na upapannam iti āha asat iti
translated: And what has been said about the existence of the effect prior to its production, that also is not proper. He says: The non-existent etc.

analyzed: yat ghaṭa ādikam prāk utpatteḥ asti iti āvayoḥ sammatam
translated: That the pot etc. existed prior to its production is agreed upon by both of us.

analyzed: tat eva tat asat ca yasmāt tasmāt sat eva iti satkārya vādaḥ nupapannaḥ eva
translated: That itself is it at that time. Therefore, because it is existent, the doctrine of existent effect is not proper.

original: tasyaiva tadaiva tatraiva sattvamasattvaṃ ca viruddhamiti cenna /
analyzed: tasya eva tadā eva tatra eva sattvam asattvam ca viruddham iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is contradictory that the same thing should be both existent and non-existent at the same time and in the same place, we reply:

analyzed: rūpa bhedena avirodhāt iti āśayena uktam kāraṇa ātma tayā kārya rūpeṇa iti
translated: No, because there is no contradiction, since there is a difference of form. With this idea in mind, it is said that (the effect) is in the form of the cause.

original: nanvevaṃ sati kiñcitsadeva kiñcit asadeva sadasattu na kimapi syāt /
analyzed: nanu evam sati kiñcid sat eva kiñcid asat eva sat asat tu na kim api syāt
translated: If this is so, then something is existent only, something is non-existent only, but nothing is both existent and non-existent.

analyzed: na syāt
translated: It will not be so.

analyzed: tayoḥ api rūpayoḥ atyanta bheda abhāvāt iti
translated: Because there is no absolute difference between the two forms.

original: syādetaduktaṃ yadyasattvaṃ prāgutpatteḥ kāryasya syāttadeva kutaḥ /
analyzed: syāt etat uktam yadi asattvam prāk utpatteḥ kāryasya syāt tat eva kutas
translated: This may be said: If the effect were non-existent before production, then how could it be so?

original: tathā cātyantābhinnaṃ kāryamupādānenetyato vipakṣe bādhakapradarśanena kāryasya prāgutpatterasattvamupādānādbhedaṃ copapādayati anavastheti
analyzed: tathā ca atyanta abhinnam kāryam upādānena iti atas vipakṣe bādhaka pradarśanena kāryasya prāk utpatteḥ asattvam upādānāt bhedam ca upapādayati anavasthā iti
translated: And thus, since the effect is absolutely non-different from the material cause, in order to establish the non-existence of the effect before production and its difference from the material cause by showing the contradiction in the contrary, he says:

analyzed: anavasthā anyathā hi syāt sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ
translated: There would be an infinite regress, as in the case of production and destruction everywhere.

original: anyathā kāryasya prāgutpatterātyantike sattve kāraṇenātyantābhede cāṅgīkṛte sarvatrotpattināśayoranavasthā avyavasthā syāt /
analyzed: anyathā kāryasya prāc utpatteḥ ātyantike sattve kāraṇena atyanta abhede ca aṅgīkṛte sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ anavasthā avyavasthā syāt
translated: Otherwise, if the absolute existence of the effect before production and its absolute non-difference from the cause were admitted, there would be an infinite regress, an indefinite state, of production and destruction everywhere.

analyzed: yathā hi
translated: As in the case of.

analyzed: paṭaḥ tantu ātmakaḥ prāk api san eva
translated: The cloth, which is of the nature of threads, is existent even before.

original: tathā tantavo 'pi svakāraṇātmakāḥ santa evetyanena krameṇa sarvasya mūlakāraṇātmakatvenātyantikaṃ sattvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā tantavaḥ pi sva kāraṇa ātmakāḥ santaḥ eva iti anena krameṇa sarvasya mūla kāraṇa ātmaka tvena ātyantikam sattvam syāt
translated: And in the same way, the threads also are existent, being of the nature of their cause. In this way, everything would have absolute existence as being of the nature of the original cause.

original: naca mūlakāraṇamutpadyate vinaśyati ceti paṭādīnāmapyutpattivināśau na syātām /
analyzed: na ca mūla kāraṇam utpadyate vinaśyati ca iti paṭa ādīnām api utpatti vināśau na syātām
translated: And since the original cause does not arise or perish, the arising and perishing of cloth and so on would not occur.

original: tathāca paṭādaya utpattivināśavanta ātmādayastadrahitā iti lokavedaprasiddhotpavināśavyavasthā na syāditi /
analyzed: tathā ca paṭa ādayaḥ utpatti vināśavantaḥ ātma ādayaḥ tad rahitāḥ iti loka veda prasiddha utpa vināśa vyavasthā na syāt iti
translated: And in that case, the well-known distinction between cloth and so on having arising and perishing, and the self and so on being devoid of that, would not be possible.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an indication.

analyzed: paṭa ādīnām utpatti vināśa abhāve tad kāraka vyāpāra vaikalyam syāt iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should be seen that if cloth and so on have no arising and perishing, there would be a deficiency in the activity of their causes.

analyzed: yat vā utpatti nāśa śabdābhyām sattvam asattvam ca upalakṣyate
translated: Or else, by the words 'arising' and 'perishing', existence and non-existence are indicated.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam arthaḥ  yadi paṭaḥ tantu ātmakaḥ prāc utpatteḥ api san eva tadā tadā
translated: And from that, this is the meaning:

analyzed: pi upalabhyeta tantu vat
translated: If cloth, being of the nature of threads, were existent even before arising, like the threads, it would be perceived then also.

analyzed: yadi ca anupalabhyamānaḥ pi san abhyupeyate
translated: And if, even though not perceived, it is accepted as existent,

analyzed: tadā sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ sat asat tvayoḥ anavasthā syāt
translated: then everywhere there would be an infinite regress of existence and non-existence in arising and perishing.

original: upalabhyamānaṃ ghaṭādikamastyanupalabhyamānaṃ kharaviṣāṇādikaṃ nāstīti sarvajanasammatā vyavasthā na syāt / /
analyzed: upalabhyamānam ghaṭa ādikam asti anupalabhyamānam khara viṣāṇa ādikam na asti iti sarva jana sammatā vyavasthā na syāt
translated: The established rule that what is perceived, such as a pot, exists, and what is not perceived, such as a barren woman's son, does not exist, would not be accepted by all people.

analyzed: athavā utpatti vināśa śabdābhyām tad upapādanasya upalakṣaṇam
translated: Or, the words 'origination' and 'destruction' indicate the establishment of that [existence of effect].

analyzed: tathā ca evam yojanā āstām tāvat anyat
translated: And thus the arrangement is as follows: Let alone other things.🔽In the doctrine of satkārya, everywhere, for the disciple or the opponent, the establishment in the form 'a non-existent does not originate, an existent does not perish' would also be endless.

original: satkāryavāde sarvatra śiṣyaṃ prativādinaṃ vā prati utpattināśayornāsadutpadyate na sadvinaśyatītyevaṃrūpopapādanasyāpyanavasthāvasthānābhāvaḥ 🔽syāt /
analyzed: satkārya vāde sarvatra śiṣyam prativādinam vā prati utpatti nāśayoḥ na asat utpadyate na sat vinaśyati iti evaṃrūpa upapādanasya api anavasthā avasthāna abhāvaḥ  syāt
translated: There would be a state of non-existence.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Indeed, it is like this.

original: idamupapādanaṃ kimarthamiti vācyam /🔽śiṣyādervidyotpattaye 'vidyānāśāya vāda jalpādau tu khyātyādyutpādāyeti cet /
analyzed: idam upapādanam kimartham iti vācyam  śiṣya ādeḥ vidyā utpattaye vidyā nāśāya vāda jalpa ādau tu khyāti ādi utpādāya iti ced
translated: It should be said for what purpose this establishment is.

analyzed: tad vidyā ādikam sat ced na utpādyam
translated: If it is said for the origination of knowledge in the disciple, or for the destruction of ignorance, or for the production of fame etc. in debate, then that knowledge etc. if it is existent, should not be produced.

analyzed: sattvāt ātma vat
translated: Because of existence, like the self.

analyzed: asat ced na utpādayitum śakyam
translated: If it is non-existent, it cannot be produced.

analyzed: anyathā satkārya vāda bhaṅga prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the consequence of the destruction of the doctrine of satkārya.

analyzed: evam avidyā satī ced na vināśyā
translated: Similarly, if ignorance is existent, it should not be destroyed.

analyzed: anyathā apasiddhānta āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the fallacy of self-contradiction.

analyzed: asatī ced nitarām na tāram
translated: If it is non-existent, it is all the more not to be crossed over.

analyzed: nitya nivṛtta tvāt
translated: Because of eternal cessation.

analyzed: tatas sarvathā pratipādana asambhavaḥ eva iti
translated: Therefore, there is simply an impossibility of establishing [the effect] in any way.

analyzed: yadi vā utpatti vināśayoḥ iti viruddha dharma upalakṣaṇam
translated: Or if [the word] 'utpattivināśayor' [in the Sāṃkhyakārikā] indicates contradictory properties,

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: it is like this.

original: yadi kāryamupādānātmakameva sadeva ca prāgutpatteḥ syāt /🔽tadotpattivināśādidharmāṇāmanavasthā syāt /
analyzed: yadi kāryam upādāna ātmakam eva sat eva ca prāk utpatteḥ syāt  tadā utpatti vināśa ādi dharmāṇām anavasthā syāt
translated: If the effect were to exist prior to its origination, having the nature of its material cause and being existent,🔽then there would be an infinite regress of properties such as origination and destruction.

analyzed: tantavaḥ prāk eva santaḥ na idānīm utpadyante
translated: The threads, which already exist, do not originate now.

analyzed: paṭaḥ tu utpadyate
translated: But the cloth originates.

analyzed: tantuṣu avinaṣṭeṣu eva paṭaḥ vinaśyati
translated: The cloth is destroyed even while the threads are not destroyed.

analyzed: tantavaḥ bahavaḥ paṭaḥ tu ekaḥ
translated: The threads are many, but the cloth is one.

analyzed: evam ākāra abhidhāna buddhi kārya bhedaḥ pi draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: The difference in form, name, cognition, and effect should be seen in the same way.

analyzed: sā eṣā vyavasthā na syāt iti
translated: This arrangement would not be possible.

analyzed: nanu etat sakalam api paṭavat ca
translated: But all this is like the cloth,

analyzed: yathā prāṇa ādiḥ iti vyakti avyakti avaṣṭambhena parihṛtam
translated: as it has been answered by the distinction between manifestation and non-manifestation, like the breath and so on.

original: tathāhi /🔽vyaktyapekṣayotpattiḥ paṭādīnāmavyaktyapekṣayā ca vināśo yujyate /🔽vyaktyavyaktyarthameva ca kārakāṇyupayujyante /
analyzed: tathā hi  vyakti apekṣayā utpattiḥ paṭa ādīnām avyakti apekṣayā ca vināśaḥ yujyate  vyakti avyakti artham eva ca kārakāṇi upayujyante
translated: It is like this.🔽The origination of cloth and so on is possible in relation to manifestation, and the destruction in relation to non-manifestation.🔽The causal factors are employed for the sake of manifestation and non-manifestation.

analyzed: vyakti avyaktibhyām eva upalabdhi anupalabdhī bhavataḥ
translated: Perception and non-perception occur only through manifestation and non-manifestation.

analyzed: atas eva pratipādanam saṅgacchate
translated: For this very reason, the explanation is appropriate.

analyzed: vyakta avyakta rūpeṇa eva viruddha dharmāḥ vyavatiṣṭhante
translated: Things with contradictory properties are established only in the manifest and unmanifest forms.

original: yathā hi saṃveṣyitaḥ paṭo na sphuṭaṃ paṭa iti pratīyate /
analyzed: yathā hi saṃveṣyitaḥ paṭaḥ na sphuṭam paṭaḥ iti pratīyate
translated: For just as a cloth that is folded is not clearly perceived as a cloth,

analyzed: na prāvriyate na śītam apanudati
translated: it does not cover, it does not remove cold,

analyzed: na bahu deśa vyāpī bhavati
translated: it does not extend over many places.

analyzed: prasāritaḥ tu sphuṭa pratīti ādimān
translated: But when it is spread out, it has clear perception and so on.

analyzed: na ca etāvatā bhedaḥ
translated: And yet it is not different by this much.

analyzed: na api prasāritaḥ prāk asat
translated: Nor is the spread-out cloth non-existent before.

original: yathā ca prāṇāyāmena niruddhaḥ śārīro vāyurjīvanamātraṃ karoti notkṣepaṇādi /
analyzed: yathā ca prāṇāyāmena niruddhaḥ śārīraḥ vāyuḥ jīvana mātram karoti na utkṣepaṇa ādi
translated: And just as the bodily air restrained by breath control only sustains life, not throwing up and so on,

analyzed: nirodha apagame tu āsādita vyaktiḥ tat api karoti
translated: but when the restraint is removed, it performs that too, having attained manifestation,

analyzed: na tāvat mātreṇa bhidyate
translated: it is not different by that much alone.

analyzed: prāk asan vā
translated: Or it was non-existent before.

analyzed: tathā eva etat api vyakti avyaktibhyām samañjasam iti
translated: In the same way, this too is consistent with manifestation and non-manifestation.

analyzed: atra brūmaḥ
translated: To this we say:

original: keyaṃ paṭasya prāgutpatterūrdhvaṃ ca vināśādavyaktirmadhye ca vyaktiḥ /
analyzed: kā iyam paṭasya prāc utpatteḥ ūrdhvam ca vināśāt avyaktiḥ madhye ca vyaktiḥ
translated: What is this non-manifestation of the cloth before its production and after its destruction, and manifestation in the middle?

analyzed: anupalabdhiḥ avyaktiḥ upalabdhiḥ vyaktiḥ iti ced tatra āha anavasthā iti
translated: If it is said that non-perception is non-manifestation and perception is manifestation, then he says infinite regress and so on.

analyzed: yadi upalabdhi anupalabdhī eva utpatti vināśau
translated: If perception and non-perception themselves are production and destruction,

analyzed: tadā sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ anavasthā syāt
translated: Then there would be an infinite regress of origination and destruction everywhere.

original: yadyadopalabdhaṃ tattadaivotpannam anupalabdhaṃ ca vinaṣṭamiti syāditi yāvat /
analyzed: yat yadā upalabdham tat tadā eva utpannam anupalabdham ca vinaṣṭam iti syāt iti yāvat
translated: That which is perceived is originated at that time only, and what is not perceived is destroyed, this is the meaning up to here.

original: kiñca prāgutpattessattve paṭasya kasmānnopalabdhiḥ kathaṃ cordhvamupalabdhiriti praśnasya upalabdhyanupalabdhianupalabdhyupalabdhi
analyzed: kiñca prāk utpatteḥ sattve paṭasya kasmāt na upalabdhiḥ katham ca ūrdhvam upalabdhiḥ iti praśnasya upalabdhi anupalabdhi anupalabdhi upalabdhi
translated: Moreover, if a cloth exists before its origination, why is it not perceived? And how is it perceived later? The answer to this question is that it is only by perception and non-perception, non-perception and perception.

analyzed: bhyām eva iti parihāram vadan devānām priyaḥ ślāghanīya prajñaḥ syāt
translated: Thus speaking, the beloved of the gods would have praiseworthy wisdom.

original: api ca prāgūrdhvaṃ ca tantūpalabdhau kathaṃ tanmātrasya sataḥ paṭasyānupalabdhiḥ /
analyzed: api ca prāk ūrdhvam ca tantu upalabdhau katham tanmātrasya sataḥ paṭasya anupalabdhiḥ
translated: Moreover, if the threads are perceived before and after, how can there be non-perception of the cloth which is existent as mere threads?

analyzed: anyathā tantūnām api sā syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be non-perception of the threads also.

analyzed: atha paṭa dharmau eva vyakti avyaktī
translated: If manifestation and non-manifestation are the properties of the cloth itself,

original: tadā tāvapi tantūnāṃ vidyete na vā /
analyzed: tadā tau api tantūnām vidyete na vā
translated: then do they exist in the threads or not?

analyzed: na ced na kārya kāraṇayeḥ atyanta abhedaḥ
translated: If not, then there is absolute non-difference between cause and effect.

analyzed: vidyete ced tatra āha anavasthā iti
translated: If they do exist, then he says there is an infinite regress.

original: utpattināśavyavahārahetūvyaktyavyaktī yadi tantuṣvapi vidyete tadā sarvatrotpattināśayoranavasthā syāt /
analyzed: utpatti nāśa vyavahāra hetū vyakti avyaktī yadi tantuṣu api vidyete tadā sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ anavasthā syāt
translated: If manifestation and non-manifestation, which are the causes of the conventions of origination and destruction, exist in the threads also, then there would be an infinite regress of origination and destruction everywhere.

analyzed: tantavaḥ na utpannāḥ na naṣṭāḥ
translated: The threads are neither produced nor destroyed.

analyzed: kintu paṭaḥ eva iti utpatti vināśa vyavasthā na syāt iti
translated: But the cloth itself is not so. Therefore, there would be no rule of production and destruction.

analyzed: kiñca iyam abhivyaktiḥ utpatti ādi vyavahāra kāraṇatayā upādīyate
translated: Moreover, this manifestation is accepted as the cause of the usage of production, etc.

original: sā kiṃ cakracīvarādibhiḥ prāgasatyevotpadyate mudgarābhighātādinā ca naśyati /
analyzed: sā kim cakra cīvara ādibhiḥ prāk asatī evā utpadyate mudgara abhighāta ādinā ca naśyati
translated: Is it that it is produced only when it did not exist before, by the wheel, cloth, etc., and is destroyed by the blow of a hammer, etc.?

analyzed: uta prāk api satī eva a vināśinī ca
translated: Or is it that it exists even before and is indestructible?

analyzed: evam avyaktiḥ api kim prāk asatī mudgara abhighāta ādinā utpadyate
