translated: Similarly, is manifestation produced by the blow of a hammer, etc., when it did not exist before?

analyzed: kiṃvā prāk api satī
translated: Or does it exist even before?

original: ubhayatrādyau dūṣayati anavastheti //🔽vyaktyavyaktyorutpattināśavattve sarvatrotpattināśayoranavasthā vyavasthābhāvaḥ syāt /
analyzed: ubhayatra ādyau dūṣayati anavasthā iti  vyakti avyaktyoḥ utpatti nāśa vat tve sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ anavasthā vyavasthā bhāvaḥ syāt
translated: He criticizes the first two in both cases, saying there would be no final basis, etc.🔽If manifestation and non-manifestation had production and destruction, there would be no final basis, no establishment, of production and destruction everywhere.

analyzed: na kiñcid asat utpadyate na kiñcid sat vinaśyati iti siddhānta virodhaḥ hāniḥ
translated: There would be the fault of contradicting the established doctrine that nothing non-existent is produced and nothing existent is destroyed.

analyzed: syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there would be loss.

analyzed: dvitīyau dūṣayati anavasthā iti
translated: He criticizes the second two, saying there would be no final basis, etc.

analyzed: vyakti avyaktyoḥ sadā sattve sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ anavasthā vyavasthitiḥ syāt
translated: If manifestation and non-manifestation always exist, there would be no final basis, no establishment, of production and destruction everywhere.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is because:

original: etāvantaṃ kālamanutpanno ghaṭa idānīmutpanna iti tāvanna syāt /
analyzed: etāvantam kālam anutpannaḥ ghaṭaḥ idānīm utpannaḥ iti tāvat na syāt
translated: It would not be possible to say that a pot, which was not produced for this long time, is now produced.

analyzed: utpatti vyavahāra hetoḥ abhivyakteḥ prāk api sattvāt
translated: Because of the existence of manifestation, which is the cause of the convention of production, even before.

analyzed: tathā mudgara abhighāta ādi uttarakālam api ghaṭa sattva vyavahāraḥ syāt
translated: Similarly, there would be the convention of the existence of a pot even after the blow of a hammer,

analyzed: tad hetoḥ abhivyakteḥ avinaṣṭa tvāt
translated: because the cause of that, manifestation, is not destroyed.

original: tathedānīmeva naṣṭo ghaṭa ityapi na syāt /
analyzed: tathā idānīm eva naṣṭaḥ ghaṭaḥ iti api na syāt
translated: Similarly, it would not be possible to say that the pot is now destroyed.

analyzed: vināśa vyavahāra kāraṇa anabhivyakteḥ prāk api sattvāt iti
translated: Because of the existence of manifestation, which is the cause of the convention of destruction, even before.

analyzed: kāraka vyāpāra vaiphalya tādavasthyam sphuṭam eva
translated: The clear consequence is that the activity of the cause is futile.

analyzed: atha etad doṣa parihārāya vyakti avyaktyoḥ api vyakti avyaktī svīkriyete
translated: If, in order to avoid this fault, manifestation and non-manifestation are also accepted to have manifestation and non-manifestation,

analyzed: tadā tayoḥ api ukta vikalpa doṣa anuṣaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: then the consequence of the mentioned faults of alternatives would apply to them as well.

analyzed: atha tatra api vyakti avyakti antara aṅgīkāraḥ tadā anavasthā syāt iti āha anavasthā iti
translated: If manifestation and non-manifestation are also accepted to have further manifestation and non-manifestation, then there would be an infinite regress. Thus he says an infinite regress would result.

analyzed: utpatti nāśayoḥ iti viṣaya saptamī
translated: Of production and destruction is the objective locative.

analyzed: santu anantāḥ vyaktayaḥ vyaktayaḥ ca
translated: Let there be an infinite number of manifestations and non-manifestations.

analyzed: mūla kṣaya abhāvāt na anavasthā doṣaḥ iti atas āha anavasthā iti
translated: Since there is no absence of the root, there is no fault of infinite regress. Therefore he says an infinite regress would result.

analyzed: anyathā anavacchinna vyakti avyakti paramparā aṅgīkāre ghaṭa ādau utpatti nāśayoḥ anavasthā anavakḷptiḥ syāt
translated: If it were admitted that the series of individuals and non-individuals is not delimited in any other way, then in every case, in a pot etc., the origination and destruction would not be established.

analyzed: uttara uttara vyakti avyakti siddhau hi pūrva pūrva vyakti avyaktīnām utpatti nāśa vyavahāra nidāna tvam
translated: For, indeed, the designation of the origination and destruction of the preceding individuals and non-individuals is based on the establishment of the succeeding individuals and non-individuals.

analyzed: tatas prayojana parikṣaya hetu tvāt anavasthā dūṣaṇam eva
translated: Therefore, since it is the cause of the destruction of the purpose, the infinite regress is indeed a fault.

original: nanvidaṃ bhavatāmapi samānam /🔽prāgasataḥ sattāsamavāyo hi janiriṣyate /
analyzed: nanu idam bhavatām api samānam  prāk asataḥ sattā samavāyaḥ hi janiḥ iṣyate
translated: But this is the same for you also.🔽For the inherence of existence in what was previously non-existent is accepted as origination.

original: sattāsamavāyāha ca sadā santāviti prāgvināśottaramapi janiḥ syāt /
analyzed: sattā samavāya āha ca sadā santau iti prāk vināśa uttaram api janiḥ syāt
translated: And the inherence of existence is always in what exists. Thus origination would occur even before destruction and after it.

analyzed: vināśaḥ ca na syāt iti atas āha anavasthā iti
translated: And there would be no destruction. Therefore he says infinite regress.

original: iyaṃ sarvatrotpattivināśayoranavasthāvyavasthitiḥ anyathā samavāyasya janitvāṅgīkṛtāveva hi syāt /
analyzed: iyam sarvatra utpatti vināśayoḥ anavasthā vyavasthitiḥ anyathā samavāyasya janitva aṅgīkṛtau eva hi syāt
translated: This is the establishment of the infinite regress of origination and destruction everywhere. Otherwise, it would occur only if the inherence were accepted as the cause of origination.

analyzed: na asmad mate
translated: But not in our opinion.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa janeḥ vakṣyamāṇa tvāt iti
translated: Because origination is going to be explained in a different way.

original: nanu janiḥ kiṃ prāk satī uta kārakavyāpārajanyā /
analyzed: nanu janiḥ kim prāk satī uta kāraka vyāpāra janyā
translated: But is origination existent before, or is it produced by the activity of the cause?

analyzed: ādye prāk uktaḥ eva doṣaḥ
translated: If the first, the previously stated fault applies.

analyzed: dvitīye janeḥ janiḥ api tathā iti anavasthā
translated: If the second, then there would be an infinite regress, as the origination of origination would also be like that.

analyzed: evam vināśaḥ api iti atas āha anavasthā iti
translated: Thus, destruction also is like this. Therefore, he says: The regress would be endless.

analyzed: sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ iyam ukta anavasthā
translated: This regress is stated for origination and destruction everywhere.

analyzed: anyathā ghaṭa janeḥ anyā janeḥ janiḥ iti aṅgīkāraḥ eva syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would be accepted that the origination of the pot is different from the origination of origination.

analyzed: na tu evam aṅgīkriyate
translated: But this is not accepted.

analyzed: api tarhi ghaṭa janma eva janmanaḥ janma iti
translated: Rather, it is accepted that the origination of the pot is the origination of origination.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ yathā janeḥ janiḥ na anyā tasyāḥ vastu janiḥ janiḥ iti
translated: As they say: Just as the origination of origination is not different from it, the origination of origination is the origination of the existent.

original: ghaṭo jāyate ghaṭajanma jāyata ityanayorekārthataiva hi laukikaparīkṣakasammatā /
analyzed: ghaṭaḥ jāyate ghaṭa janma jāyate iti anayoḥ ekārtha tā eva hi laukika parīkṣaka sammatā
translated: For the common people and the investigators agree that the meaning of the pot originates and the origination of the pot originates is the same.

analyzed: na ca vyakti avyaktyoḥ api evam aṅgīkartum ucitam
translated: And it is not proper to accept that the same is true of manifestation and non-manifestation.

analyzed: janma vināśau upalabdhi anupalabdhī vā vihāya vyakti avyaktyoḥ eva aprāmāṇika tvāt iti
translated: For manifestation and non-manifestation are not accepted as the origination and destruction or the perception and non-perception of an existent, because they are not authoritative.

original: nanu yadyasadutpadyeta sacca vinaśyeta tadā sarvatrotpattināśayoranavasthaiva syāt /🔽evaṃ sati hi khara
analyzed: nanu yadi asat utpadyeta sat ca vinaśyeta tadā sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ anavasthā eva syāt  evam sati hi khara
translated: If the non-existent originates and the existent is destroyed, then there would be an endless regress of origination and destruction everywhere.

analyzed: śaśaviṣāṇam api utpadyeta
translated: For if that were so, even the horn of a donkey would originate.

analyzed: ātmā ca naśyet iti atas āha anavasthā iti
translated: And the self would be destroyed. Therefore, he says: The regress would be endless.

analyzed: anyathā kāraṇa śakti an ādaraṇe hi īm utpatti vināśayoḥ anavasthā syāt
translated: For if the power of the cause were not accepted, there would be an endless regress of origination and destruction.

analyzed: na ca evam kintu yasya utpatti kāraṇam asti tat asat api utpadyate
translated: And it is not so, but that which has a cause of origination is originated even though it is non-existent.

original: yasya ca vināśakāraṇaṃ vidyate tatsadapi niruddhayate /
analyzed: yasya ca vināśa kāraṇam vidyate tat sat api niruddhayate
translated: And that which has a cause of destruction is destroyed even though it exists.

analyzed: na ca khara viṣāṇa janmani ātma vināśe vā kāraṇam asti iti tayoḥ janana vināśa abhāvaḥ
translated: And there is no cause for the origination of a barren woman's son or for the destruction of the self, so their origination and destruction do not occur.

original: kāraṇasvabhāvānanugame tu satkāryavādino 'pyatiprasaṅga eveti /🔽athavā syādiyamanavasthā yadyatyantāsadevotpadyate sanmātraṃ vinaśyatīti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇa svabhāva ananugame tu satkārya vādinaḥ pi atiprasaṅgaḥ evā iti  athavā syāt iyam anavasthā yadi atyanta asat eva utpadyate sat mātram vinaśyati iti brūmaḥ
translated: But if the nature of the cause is not followed, there is an excessive consequence even for the proponents of the existent effect.

original: sadasadevotpadyata iti coktaṃ vināśakāraṇavadeva ca vinaśyatīti / /
analyzed: sat asat eva utpadyate iti ca uktam vināśa kāraṇa vat eva ca vinaśyati iti
translated: Or this may be a regress, if what is absolutely non-existent is originated and only what exists is destroyed. We say that what is both existent and non-existent is originated, and that it is destroyed only like the cause of destruction.

analyzed: yat ca uktam bhāve ca upalabdheḥ iti sūtra artha tvena
translated: And what was said as the meaning of the aphorism And because of the apprehension of existence,

analyzed: tad vayāpya vyāpaka bhāvena eva upapannam na atyanta abheda sādhakam
translated: that is established by the relation of pervasion and pervaded alone, and does not prove absolute non-difference.

analyzed: atha kāraṇa uparakta buddhiḥ sāmānādhikaraṇya buddhiḥ vā atra abhimatā iti matam
translated: Or if it is thought that the cognition affected by the cause or the cognition of co-reference is intended here,

analyzed: sā api abheda mātreṇa caritārthā na atyanta abheda sādhanāya alam
translated: that also serves the purpose of mere non-difference and is not sufficient to prove absolute non-difference.

analyzed: kiñca etat yukteḥ ca iti anena eva śakya saṅgraham na punar abhidhātavyam
translated: And this (argument) can be included by the phrase 'and from reasoning' itself, it need not be stated again.

analyzed: atha anena pratyakṣam upanyasyate tat api na atyanta abheda sādhakam
translated: If this (argument) is adduced to establish perception, that too does not prove absolute non-difference.

analyzed: atas eva bhāvāt ca upalabdheḥ iti sūtra vipariṇāmaḥ pi nirastaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the modification of the aphorism 'and from the apprehension of existence' is also refuted.

analyzed: sattvāt ca avasyā iti yuktiḥ ced yukteḥ ca iti etena eva gatārtha tā
translated: If the reasoning 'and because of the existence of the necessary condition' is meant, it is already included by the phrase 'and from reasoning' itself.

analyzed: śrutiḥ ced śabda antarāt ca iti anena
translated: If the Vedic text is meant, it is included by the phrase 'and from another Vedic text'.

analyzed: asat vayapadeśāt iti tu paricodanā eva asaṅga tā
translated: But the objection 'because of the declaration of non-existence' is itself irrelevant.

original: paramārthato brahmakāraṇatāparatvenāpātatastu śūnyasyābhāvasya vā kāraṇabhāvapratipādakatāpratibhāsena kāryāsattvasya śrutāvapratīteḥ /
analyzed: paramārthataḥ brahma kāraṇatā paratvena āpātataḥ tu śūnyasya abhāvasya vā kāraṇa bhāva pratipādaka tā pratibhāsena kārya asattvasya śrutau apratīteḥ
translated: Because, in the ultimate sense, it is meant to establish Brahman as the cause, but apparently it appears to teach the causal nature of the Void or non-existence, and the non-existence of effects is not understood in the Vedic text.

analyzed: yukteḥ iti ukta yuktim tu uttaratra apākariṣyāmaḥ  śabda antaram tu ācāryeṇa eva anyatra anyathā eva vyākhyātam
translated: As for the reasoning stated by the phrase 'from reasoning', we shall refute it later.🔽But the other Vedic text has been explained differently by the teacher himself elsewhere.

analyzed: paṭe prāṇa ādau ca na atyanta anupasañjāta viśeṣa tvam iti anudāharaṇam eva iti alam prapañcena
translated: And the cloth and the vital principle etc. are not absolutely devoid of specific properties, so they are not even examples. Enough of this elaboration.

original: yaduktaṃ śakto 'pi hīti yacca nityabheda itrata tadubhayaṃ śrutyāpi sādhayati śakto 'pīti //
analyzed: yat uktam hi iti yat ca nitya bhedaḥ tat ubhayam śrutyā api sādhayati
translated: What was said - Even though able - and what was said about eternal difference, both of those he establishes with scripture as well, with Even though able.

analyzed: śaktaḥ pi bhagavān viṣṇuḥ a kartum kartum anyathā
translated: Even though able, Lord Vishnu creates, destroys, and modifies.

analyzed: sva bhinnam kāraṇa abhinna bhinnam viśvam karoti ajaḥ
translated: The unborn one creates the universe, different from himself, different from the causes, and not different from the causes.

analyzed: iti śruteḥ avasitaḥ ukta arthaḥ yam aśeṣatas
translated: This meaning stated here is completely concluded from this scripture.

analyzed: a kartum śaktaḥ u pi karoti
translated: Even though able to not create, he creates.

original: anyathā vinā kāraṇaistadvayatyāsena ca kartuṃ śakto 'pi niyataiḥ kāraṇaiḥ karotīcchayeti yojyam /
analyzed: anyathā vinā kāraṇaiḥ tad vayatyāsena ca kartum śaktā api niyataiḥ kāraṇaiḥ karoti icchayā iti yojyam
translated: Even though able to create without causes or by changing them, he creates with fixed causes, by his will. This should be connected.

analyzed: svasmāt nimitta kāraṇāt bhinnam
translated: Different from himself, the instrumental cause.

analyzed: upādānakāraṇena abhinnam bhinnam ca
translated: Different from the material cause, and not different.

original: saṃsāriṇo hi viṣyigṛhītā iveśvarapreritā aniṣyamapi dhārakaprayatnenākṛtvā na sthātumīśate /
analyzed: saṃsāriṇaḥ hi viṣyi gṛhītāḥ iva īśvara preritāḥ aniṣyam api dhāraka prayatnena a kṛtvā na sthātum īśate
translated: For the transmigrators, as if possessed by an object, impelled by God, are not able to remain without making even what is undesirable with the effort of a supporter.

analyzed: na ca bhagavān tathā iti a kartum
translated: And the Lord is not like that. Therefore, even though able to not create, he creates. This is what was said.

original: aśeṣataḥ prāgidānīṃ cokto na tu sannihita evetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: aśeṣatas prāk idānīm ca uktaḥ na tu sannihitaḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: Completely, as stated before and now, but not only in the present. This is the meaning.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām ārambhaṇa adhikaraṇam
translated: Here ends the first chapter in the commentary Nyāyasudhā on Jaimini's Mīmāṃsāsūtras.
VII. The section on the designation of other things.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām itara vyapadeśa adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the section on the designation of other things.

analyzed: om itara vyapadeśāt hita akaraṇa ādi doṣa prasaktiḥ om
translated: Om. Because of the designation of other things, the faults of performing what is beneficial and so on are entailed. Om.

original: asminnadhikaraṇe jīvakartṛtvapakṣaḥ śrutiprāpto vistarānnirākriyata iti bhāṣyam /
analyzed: asmin adhikaraṇe jīva kartṛ tva pakṣaḥ śruti prāptaḥ vistarāt nirākriyate iti bhāṣyam
translated: The commentary says that in this section, the view of the individual soul as the agent, which is established by scripture, is refuted in detail.

analyzed: atra vaktavyam
translated: Here, it should be said.

analyzed: kim atra jīvasya sarvathā kartṛ tvam nirākriyate
translated: Is the individual soul's agency being refuted in every way here?

analyzed: uta īśvara adhīnam tat aṅgīkṛtya svātantrya mātram
translated: Or is its independence alone accepted, subject to God?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ  tathā sati kartā śāstra atharvat tvāt ityādi vakṣyamāṇa virodha āpatteḥ
translated: Not the first.🔽Because if that were so, there would be the consequence of contradicting what will be said later, such as the agent because of being the object of injunctions.

analyzed: svatas kartṛ tva anupapattiḥ ityādi viśeṣaṇa vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt ca
translated: And because it would follow that qualifications such as the impossibility of agency by itself would be pointless.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: hita karaṇa ādi doṣa prasaktiḥ ityādi sūtrāṇām svātantrya nirākaraṇa paratvena śakya yojana tve pi
translated: Even though the sūtras beginning with the faults of performing what is beneficial and so on are entailed can be connected as being about the refutation of independence,

analyzed: kṛtsna prasaktiḥ niravayava tva śabda koṣaḥ vā iti asya sūtrasya aśakya vyākhyāna tvāt
translated: because the sūtra is the entire universe subject to manifestation or is the word-treasury of the indivisible? cannot be explained.

original: idaṃ hi sūtraṃ sarvathā kartṛtvaṃ nirākurvadupalabhyate /
analyzed: idam hi sūtram sarvathā kartṛ tvam nirākurvat upalabhyate
translated: For this sūtra is seen to refute agency in every way.

analyzed: tathā hi  kartṛ tvam kṛtsna eka deśābhyām vyāptam
translated: For thus:🔽Agency is pervaded by the whole and a part.

original: tatra kṛtsnaprasaktāvanubhavavirodhaḥ /🔽ekadeśāṅgīkāre caatha yaḥ sa jīvaḥ sa nityo niravayavaḥ' /
analyzed: tatra kṛtsna prasaktau anubhava virodhaḥ  eka deśa aṅgīkāre ca atha yaḥ sa jīvaḥ sa nityaḥ niravayavaḥ
translated: In that, if the whole is applied, there is contradiction with experience.

analyzed: iti an aṃśa tva śruti vyākopaḥ syāt
translated: And if a part is accepted, then there would be contradiction with the scriptural statement of the partlessness of the individual soul, which is eternal and partless.

analyzed: nahi sāmarthya apara paryāyam prayatna ādi rūpam kartṛ tvam asmākam jīvāt bhinnam
translated: For us, agency, which is synonymous with capability and has the form of effort, etc., is not different from the individual soul,

original: yena tasya vicitratve 'pi jīvasya niraṃśatvaṃ na vyāhanyeta /🔽tato vyāpakanivṛttyā vyāpyaṃ kartṛtvamapi vicitratve 'pi jīvasya niraṃśatvaṃ na vyāhanyeta /
analyzed: yena tasya vicitra tve pi jīvasya niraṃśa tvam na vyāhanyeta  tatas vyāpaka nivṛttyā vyāpyam kartṛ tvam api vicitra tve pi jīvasya niraṃśa tvam na vyāhanyeta
translated: by which, even in its variety, the partlessness of the individual soul would not be contradicted.

original: tato vyāpakanivṛttyā vyāpyaṃ kartṛtvamapi nivartata iti khalvasyatra
analyzed: tatas vyāpaka nivṛttyā vyāpyam kartṛ tvam api nivartate iti khalu asi atra
translated: Therefore, by the cessation of the pervader, the pervaded agency also ceases. Thus,

analyzed: tātparyam pratīyate
translated: it is understood that this is the purport of the text.

analyzed: prasaṅgasya viparyaye paryavasāna avaśyambhāvāt
translated: Because the pervasion must be concluded in the opposite of the contingency.

original: atha jīvakartṛtvasyeśvarādhīnatānaṅgīkāra evaito prasaṅgāvuktau na kartṛtvamātre /
analyzed: atha jīva kartṛ tvasya īśvara adhīna tā anaṅgīkāre prasaṅgau uktau na kartṛ tva mātre
translated: If it is argued that these contingencies are stated only in the non-acceptance of the dependence of the agency of the individual soul on God, not in mere agency,

analyzed: tathā ca īśvara adhīna tvam eva bhaviṣyati iti ced na
translated: and that in that case, dependence on God alone will be obtained by the conclusion in the opposite, it is not so.

original: syādapyevaṃ yadi jīvakartṛtvasyeśvarādhīnatvāṅgīkāreṇemau prasaṅgau śakyasamādhānau syātām /
analyzed: syāt api evam yadi jīva kartṛ tvasya īśvara adhīna tva aṅgīkāreṇa imau prasaṅgau śakya samādhānau syātām
translated: This might be so, if these two objections could be met by admitting that the individual soul's agency is dependent on God.

original: nacaivaṃ parādhīnenāpi khalvanena kṛtsnena vā kartavyamekadeśena vā /
analyzed: na ca evam para adhīnena api khalu anena kṛtsnena vā kartavyam eka deśena vā
translated: But it is not so. For even if it is dependent on another, it must be done either wholly or in part.

analyzed: tṛtīya prakāra abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no third alternative.

analyzed: bhāve vā tena eva apara adhīna tve pi kartṛ tva upapatteḥ
translated: Or if there were, then even without dependence on another, agency would be possible by that [third alternative].

original: ato viparyayāparyavasānānnaivaṃ vyākhyānaṃ yuktamiti kartṛtvābhāva eva tātparyam /
analyzed: atas viparyaya aparyavasānāt na evam vyākhyānam yuktam iti kartṛ tva abhāvaḥ eva tātparyam
translated: Therefore, because the opposite does not follow, this explanation is not proper. The real purport is the non-existence of agency.

analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyamāṇa virodhaḥ
translated: And thus there is the contradiction stated later.

analyzed: atha vastutas na asti eva jīvasya kartṛ tvam
translated: Or rather, in reality there is no agency of the individual soul at all.

analyzed: ābhimānikam tu tat iti avirodhaḥ
translated: But that [agency] is only figurative, so there is no contradiction.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: vihāra upadeśāt ityādinā vāstavasya eva tasya sādhayiṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because its reality will be established by [the next aphorism] beginning with because of the teaching of enjoyment, etc.

analyzed: atas durghaṭam etat adhikaraṇam iti atas dvitīya pakṣam aṅgīkṛtya prasaṅgau jīva kartṛ tvasya īśvara adhīna tā anaṅgīkāra viṣayau
translated: Therefore this section is difficult to understand. So, accepting the second view, the objections are to be explained as referring to the non-acceptance of the dependence of the individual soul's agency on God,🔽first stating the way of removing the objections by citing scriptural passages,

analyzed: vyākariṣyan ādau tāvat īśvara adhīna tā aṅgīkāre prasaṅga nivṛtti prakāram āgama vākya udāharaṇena
translated: accepting the dependence of the individual soul's agency on God,

analyzed: darśayati an aṃśasya api iti
translated: He shows that even a partless [entity] can have some power.

analyzed: itara vyapadeśāt dhita akaraṇa ādi doṣa prasaktiḥ  an aṃśasya api jīvasya kiñcid sāmarthya yojanām
translated: Due to the designation of another, the faults of not performing and so on would follow.

analyzed: kāryeṣu yaḥ karoti addhā namaḥ tasmai svayambhuve
translated: Even for a partless individual, the one who arranges some power in effects, I truly pay homage to that self-existent one.

analyzed: kiñcid sāmarthya yojanām kārya anurūpa sāmarthya prayogāt
translated: Arranging some power, by employing power in accordance with the effect.

analyzed: svayambhuve svatantrāya  iti vacanāt avasitaḥ yam abhipretaḥ arthaḥ iti anuvartate
translated: To the self-existent one, the independent one.🔽Thus, the intended meaning is completed, and this continues.

analyzed: tatas ca etat uktam bhavati
translated: And thus this is said:

analyzed: yadi jīvaḥ parameśvara adhīna tayā kartā aṅgīkriyate
translated: If the individual is accepted as the agent in dependence on the Supreme Lord,

analyzed: tadā upapadyate eva tasya kartṛ tvam
translated: then his agency is indeed possible.

analyzed: prasaṅgayoḥ samādhātum śakya tvāt
translated: Because the two absurd consequences can be resolved.

analyzed: an aṃśa tvasya abhyupagamena hi na niravayava tva śabda koṣaḥ
translated: For by accepting partlessness, the treasury of the word partless is not [used].

analyzed: an aṃśasya api parameśvara acintya śakti vaśena kārya anurūpa sāmarthya prayoga sambhavāt na kṛtsna prasaktiḥ iti
translated: Even for a partless [entity], by the inconceivable power of the Supreme Lord, the employment of power in accordance with the effect is possible, so there is no consequence of being complete.

analyzed: sphuṭībhaviṣyati
translated: And this will become clear immediately after.

original: evamupodghātaprakriyayā viparyayaparyavasānopapattimuktvedānīṃ vivakṣitārthe sūtraṃ yojayati yadīti //🔽yadi bhāgena kāryeṣu jīvaśaktiṃ na yojayet /
analyzed: evam upodghāta prakriyayā viparyaya paryavasāna upapattim uktvā idānīm vivakṣita arthe sūtram yojayati yadi iti  yadi bhāgena kāryeṣu jīva śaktim na yojayet
translated: Having thus stated the argument by way of introduction, concluding with the opposite, he now connects the sutra with the intended meaning, with the word if.🔽If Hari (Vishnu) does not employ the power of the individual soul in parts in the effects,

analyzed: hariḥ tadā hi sarvatra kṛtsna yatna ūṃśitā api vā
translated: then everywhere there would be the fault of the entire effort being employed in parts.

analyzed: bhāgena kārya anuguṇa aṃśena
translated: In parts - according to the part that is suitable for the effect.

original: atra yadīśvarādhīnatayā kartā na syāditi vaktavye yadi bhāgenetyādivacanaṃ prasaṅgasphuṭīkaraṇārtham /
analyzed: atra yadi īśvara adhīna tayā kartā na syāt iti vaktavye yadi bhāgena ityādi vacanam prasaṅga sphuṭīkaraṇa artham
translated: Here, although it should be said that if the agent were not dependent on God, the statement beginning with if in parts is for the sake of clarifying the contingency.

analyzed: īśvara adhīna tva prakāra prapañcana artham ca
translated: And for the sake of elaborating the mode of dependence on God.

analyzed: sarvatra tṛṇa ādāna ādau api kṛtsna yatna ūṃśitā api vā prasajyeta
translated: And then, even in the case of cutting grass and so on, there would be the fault of the entire effort being employed in parts everywhere.

analyzed: tathā ca anubhava śruti virodhaḥ
translated: And thus there would be contradiction with experience and scripture.

original: tasmātparameśvarādhīna eva jīvaḥ karteti śeṣaḥ /🔽na copādhikṛtāṃśakalpanayā kartṛtvasyāvidyakatvena vo
analyzed: tasmāt parameśvara adhīnaḥ eva jīvaḥ kartā iti śeṣaḥ  na ca upādhi kṛta aṃśa kalpanayā kartṛ tvasya āvidyaka tvena vā
translated: Therefore, the individual soul is the agent only dependent on the Supreme Lord - this is the remainder.

analyzed: ca upapattiḥ
translated: And the agency is not established by the assumption of a part due to an attribute, or by its being based on ignorance.

analyzed: an aṃśasya api ityādi pramāṇa siddha upapanna upapādaka parityāgena aprāmāṇika anupapanna svīkārasya ayukta tvāt
translated: Because it is not proper to abandon the established and reasonable means of proof like even of the partless and accept what is unauthoritative and unreasonable.

analyzed: nanu jīva śaktyā eva idam ghaṭatām
translated: But let this be accomplished by the power of the individual soul itself.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.
Because it has no incomprehensible power which is not a constituent of it.

analyzed: bhāve vā hita akaraṇa ādi doṣa prasaktiḥ
translated: Or if it has, then there is the contingence of the defect of not doing what is good.

analyzed: na hi atra adhikaraṇe pūrvapakṣiṇā mahat ādi sakala kārya kartṛ tvam jīvasya a śaṅkitam
translated: For in this Adhikarana, the opponent does not suspect the individual soul to be the maker of all effects beginning with Mahat.

analyzed: kintu ghaṭa ādi kartṛ tvam
translated: But he suspects it to be the maker of the jar and other things.

analyzed: tat tāvat anubhava siddha tvāt kulāla ādīnām na tyaktum śakyam
translated: That is, however, incapable of being denied, because it is established by experience.

original: tatreśvarasyāpi kartṛtvāṅgīkāre kalpāgauravaṃ syādityato neśvarasya sarvakartṛtvamiti /
analyzed: tatra īśvarasya api kartṛ tva aṅgīkāre kalpa agauravam syāt iti atas na īśvarasya sarva kartṛ tvam iti
translated: If the Lord also is admitted to be the maker, then there will be the defect of too much of assumption. Hence the Lord is not the maker of all things.

analyzed: tathā ca katham acintya śakti prasaktiḥ
translated: And how then can there be the contingence of incomprehensible power?

original: nanu ca vyatireko gandhavaditi jīvānāmanekarūpatāṃ sūtrakāra eva vakṣyati /
analyzed: nanu ca vyatirekaḥ gandha vat iti jīvānām aneka rūpatām sūtrakāraḥ eva vakṣyati
translated: But the author of the Sastras himself will declare the difference of the individual souls to be like that of the odours, in the passage, The souls are many, like the odours.

analyzed: utkrānti gati āgatīnām iti aṇu tvam ca
translated: And he will declare their minuteness in the passage, Of the going out, the going and the coming.

original: na cāṇoryugapadanekarūpatvaṃ vinā sāṃśatayopapadyata iti sāṃśatāpi tata eva siddhā /
analyzed: na ca aṇoḥ yugapad aneka rūpa tvam vinā sāṃśatayā upapadyate iti sāṃśatā api tatas eva siddhā
translated: And minuteness is not possible without the simultaneous presence of many forms in the atom. Hence their divisibility is also established from that very fact.

original: tatkathamatra niravayavatvaśabdakopo vetyavādīditi gūḍhābhisandherāśaṅkāmaviditābhiprāyaiva pariharati aṃśino hītyādinā //
analyzed: tat katham atra niravayavatva śabda kopaḥ vā iti avādīt iti gūḍha abhisandheḥ āśaṅkām avidita abhiprāyā eva pariharati aṃśinaḥ hi ityādinā
translated: How then can there be the contradiction of the word avayava, partless, in this passage? Thus asked the opponent, who had a hidden intention. The questioner, who was not aware of the intention, answered it with the passage beginning with the words, The possessor of parts, etc.

original: sārdhena ślokadvayena / /🔽aṃśino hi paṭādyā ye bhinnaireva parasparam /
analyzed: sārdhena śloka dvayena  aṃśinaḥ hi paṭa ādyāḥ ye bhinnaiḥ eva parasparam
translated: By half a verse and two verses.🔽For those with parts, such as cloth, are said to be with parts that are different from each other,

analyzed: aṃśaiḥ aṃśinaḥ ucyante na evam eva hi cetanāḥ
translated: but conscious beings are not like that.

original: ato 'naṃśina ityeva śrutireteṣu vartate /🔽apyanekasvarūpeṣu viśeṣādeva kevalam // / / //
analyzed: atas na aṃśinaḥ iti eva śrutiḥ eteṣu vartate  api aneka svarūpeṣu viśeṣāt eva kevalam
translated: Therefore, the Vedic text applies to them only as partless.🔽Even in those with many forms, it is only due to the difference.

analyzed: bahu svarūpa tā ākhyā tu teṣu asti eva hi sa aṃśa tā
translated: But the state of having many forms is indeed the state of having parts in them.

analyzed: tatra bahu svarūpa tā ākhyā iti anena vakṣyamāṇam abhyupaiti
translated: There, by called having many forms, he accepts what will be said.

analyzed: bahu iti anekatva upalakṣaṇam
translated: Many indicates plurality.

analyzed: bahu svarūpa tayā khyāyate iti bahu svarūpa tā ākhyā
translated: It is called having many forms because it appears as having many forms.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ śruti niṣedhyāyāḥ
translated: The word but indicates the difference from what is prohibited by the Vedic text.

analyzed: teṣu cetaneṣu
translated: And in those conscious beings.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ pramāṇa prasiddhim dyotayati  atas eva asti eva iti avadhāraṇam
translated: The word indeed indicates the well-known means of valid knowledge.🔽For this very reason, the restriction is indeed is used.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam arthaḥ
translated: And thus, this is the meaning.

original: astyeva vakṣyamāṇānekasvarūpatāṇutvaṃ ca tadanyathānupapattisiddhā sāṃśatā ca /
analyzed: asti eva vakṣyamāṇa aneka svarūpa tā aṇu tvam ca tad anyathā anupapatti siddhā sāṃśa tā ca
translated: The state of having many forms and atomicity, which will be mentioned, and the state of having parts, which is established by the impossibility of any other explanation, are indeed present.

analyzed: prāmāṇikasya tyaktum aśakya tvāt iti
translated: Because what is established by means of valid knowledge cannot be abandoned.

original: tarhi kathamatra tadviruddhamuktamityata uktam aṃśina ityādi //
analyzed: tarhi katham atra tad viruddham uktam iti atas uktam aṃśinaḥ ityādi
translated: Then, how is that contradictory to it stated here? To this it is said: of the whole, etc.

analyzed: ādyaḥ hi śabdaḥ pramāṇa prasiddhau dvitīyaḥ yasmāt iti arthe
translated: The first word hi (means) in the well-known (proof), the second (means) because.

original: ye paṭādyā aṃśinaḥ prasiddhāste parasparaṃ bhinnairevāṃśairaṃśinā ca vakṣyamāṇaprakāreṇa bhinnābhinnaireva na tvatyantābhinnaiḥ tantvādibhiraṃśairaṃśina
analyzed: ye paṭa ādyāḥ aṃśinaḥ prasiddhāḥ te parasparam bhinnaiḥ eva aṃśaiḥ aṃśinā ca vakṣyamāṇa prakāreṇa bhinna abhinnaiḥ eva na tu atyanta abhinnaiḥ tantu ādibhiḥ aṃśaiḥ aṃśinaḥ
translated: Those wholes such as cloth, etc. which are well-known, are said to be wholes with parts which are mutually different, and with a whole which is different and non-different in the manner to be stated, but not with parts such as threads which are absolutely non-different.

analyzed: ucyante
translated: They are said to be wholes with parts which are absolutely non-different.

analyzed: cetanāḥ tu evam eva paṭa ādi vat ukta rūpaiḥ aṃśaiḥ aṃśinaḥ na bhavanti
translated: But the conscious beings are not wholes in the same way as cloth, etc. with parts of the described kind.

analyzed: kintu parasparam aṃśinā ca atyanta abhinnaiḥ
translated: But with each other and with the whole which are absolutely non-different.

original: yasmādevamataḥ prasiddhāṃśivaidharmyādevānekasvarūpeṣu tata eva sāṃśeṣvapyeteṣu cetaneṣvanaṃśina iti śrutirvartate /
analyzed: yasmāt evam atas prasiddha aṃśi vaidharmyāt eva aneka svarūpeṣu tatas eva sa aṃśeṣu api eteṣu cetaneṣu an aṃśinaḥ iti śrutiḥ vartate
translated: Because of this, therefore, the Vedic text applies to these conscious beings which have many forms and are therefore also with parts, as wholes without parts, only on the basis of the similarity with the well-known wholes.

analyzed: na tu sarvathā aṃśa rāhitya abhiprāyeṇa
translated: But not with the intention that they are absolutely without parts.

analyzed: atas na virodhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore there is no contradiction.

original: nanu yadi bhedo nāsti kathaṃ tarhyanekatvaṃ tasyābhedavyāptatvāt /
analyzed: nanu yadi bhedaḥ na asti katham tarhi anekatvam tasya abheda vyāpta tvāt
translated: But if there is no difference, then how can there be multiplicity, since that is pervaded by non-difference?

analyzed: katham ca aṃśi tvam
translated: And how can there be the state of being with parts?

analyzed: matu arthasya bhedena vinā anupapatteḥ iti atas uktam viśeṣāt eva iti
translated: Since the meaning of the compound matvartha cannot be understood without difference, it is said only by difference.

analyzed: bheda abhāve pi kevalam tat pratinidheḥ viśeṣāt evā aneka svarūpeṣu iti yojanā  yat vā api aneka svarūpeṣu
translated: Even in the absence of difference, only by the difference of its substitute, in the case of many forms.

analyzed: iti anena eva vakṣyamāṇam aṅgīkṛtya aṃśinaḥ ityādinā virodhaḥ parihṛtaḥ
translated: Or, by this very [statement] even in the case of many forms, accepting what will be said, the contradiction is removed by [the statement] beginning with of the whole, etc.

analyzed: tatra bheda abhāve katham anekatvam aṃśitvam ca iti āśaṅkām
translated: There, doubting how multiplicity and being a whole are possible in the absence of difference,

analyzed: viśeṣāt eva ityādi pāda trayeṇa pariharati
translated: he removes [the doubt] with the three feet beginning with only by difference, etc.

original: kevalameva bhedena vinaiva teṣu bahusvarūpatā tayā khyāyamānā sāṃśatā cāsti /
analyzed: kevalam eva bhedena vinā eva teṣu bahu svarūpa tā tayā khyāyamānā sa aṃśa tā ca asti
translated: There is indeed multiplicity in them, only without difference, and the appearance of being a whole by that.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: viśeṣāt eva iti
translated: Only by difference.

analyzed: kutas etat kalpyate
translated: From where is this imagined?

original: śrutidvayavirodhādeveti hiśabdenāha /🔽atra jīvasyeti prakṛte 'pi yaccetanā iti sāmānyenoktam /
analyzed: śruti dvaya virodhāt eva iti hi śabdena āha  atra jīvasya iti prakṛte yat cetanā iti sāmānyena uktam
translated: By the contradiction of the two Vedic statements alone. This is stated by the word hi.🔽Here, although the individual soul is the subject, it is stated in general as the conscious [entities].

analyzed: tena cetana mātre pi ayam nyāyaḥ iti sūcayati
translated: By that, he indicates that this principle applies even to mere consciousness.

original: athavā yadyaṃśino jīvāstarhi paṭādivadeva syurityasyācetanatvamupādhimanena dyotayati / /
analyzed: athavā yadi aṃśinaḥ jīvāḥ tarhi paṭa ādi vat eva syuḥ iti asya acetana tvam upādhim anena dyotayati
translated: Or, if the individual souls are wholes, then they would be like a cloth, etc. This [verse] indicates the non-existence of consciousness as a limiting adjunct.

analyzed: nanu evam tarhi kim jīva kartṛ tvasya īśvara adhīna tva kalpanayā
translated: If so, then why imagine the agency of the individual soul to be dependent on God?

analyzed: tad abhāve pi svatas bahu rūpa tva sadbhāvena eka deśataḥ kriyā upapattau kṛtsna prasakteḥ abhāvāt
translated: Even without that, due to the existence of the soul's own manifold nature, the action is logically possible in part, so there is no problem of the whole being engaged.

analyzed: vibhinna aṃśa abhāvena niravayava tva śabda kopasya api parihārāt
translated: And because the objection of the word partless due to the absence of different parts is also avoided.

original: etadatiriktasya ceśvarakṛtyasyādarśanāditi pūrvapakṣiṇā svābhisandhāvudghāṭite satyāha bahutveneti //
analyzed: etad atiriktasya ca īśvara kṛtyasya adarśanāt iti pūrvapakṣiṇā sva abhisandhau udghāṭite sati āha bahutvena iti
translated: And because no function of God other than this is seen. When the opponent has thus revealed his intention, he says by plurality, etc.

analyzed: bahu tvena avinābhāvāt bhinna tā niyamāt bhavet
translated: By plurality, there would certainly be difference due to the invariable concomitance of that.

analyzed: yadi nā evam niyama kṛt bhagavān puruṣottamaḥ
translated: If the Lord, the Supreme Person, were not thus the ordainer...

original: yadi bhagavānpuruṣottama evaṃ na niyamakṛdbahutve 'pi bhedo jīveṣu mā bhūditi vyavasthāyāḥ kartā na syāt /
analyzed: yadi bhagavān puruṣottamaḥ evam na niyama kṛt bahu tve pi bhedaḥ jīveṣu mā bhūt iti vyavasthāyāḥ kartā na syāt
translated: If the Lord, the Supreme Person, were not thus the ordainer, not the maker of the rule that there should be no difference among the individual souls even in plurality,

original: tadā bahutvena hetunā jīveṣvapi bhinnatā bhavet /
analyzed: tadā bahu tvena hetunā jīveṣu api bhinna tā bhavet
translated: then by the reason of plurality, there would be difference even among the individual souls.

analyzed: bahu tva saṅkhayāyāḥ bhinna tvena avinābhāva lakṣaṇāt niyamāt
translated: Because of the invariable concomitance characterized by the relation of the number many with difference.

analyzed: yathā uktam tad anuvidhānāt pṛthaktvam iti
translated: As it is said: Difference is due to its being regulated by that.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.
If the Jiva's agency is accepted without reference to the Supreme Lord, the two objections stated above cannot be avoided in any way.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: kṛtsna prasaktiḥ tāvat katham pariharaṇīyā
translated: How is the objection of the whole being applied to be avoided?

analyzed: bahu tva sadbhāvena iti ced
translated: If it is said by the existence of plurality,

original: tarhi bahutvasya loke bhedāvinābhūtatvena jīvasya bahutve bhinnatvamapyāpadyeta /
analyzed: tarhi bahu tvasya loke bheda avinābhūta tvena jīvasya bahu tve bhinna tvam api āpadyeta
translated: then plurality being inseparable from difference in the world, the Jiva would also become different in having plurality.

analyzed: tathā ca durātmā niravayava tva śabda kopaḥ duṣparihāraḥ
translated: And thus the objection of the word 'indivisible' being contradicted by the wicked soul is difficult to avoid.

analyzed: atha tad parihāra artham bhedaḥ na iṣyate
translated: If, in order to avoid that, difference is not accepted,

analyzed: tadā vyāpaka nivṛttyā vyāpya nivṛtteḥ āvaśyaka tvāt bahu tva saṅkhayā api tyājyā syāt
translated: then, because of the necessity of the cessation of the pervaded due to the cessation of the pervader, the number of plurality would also have to be abandoned.

original: tathā ca punaḥ saiva kṛtyā kṛtsnaprasaktirāskandeta /
analyzed: tathā ca punar sā eva kṛtyā kṛtsna prasaktiḥ āskandeta
translated: And thus again, the very same objection of the whole being applied would arise.

original: atha jaḍeṣveva yatra bahutvaṃ tatra bheda iti niyamo na cetaneṣviti cet /
analyzed: atha jaḍeṣu eva yatra bahu tvam tatra bhedaḥ iti niyamaḥ na cetaneṣu iti ced
translated: If it is said that the rule is that where there is plurality in the inert, there is difference, but not in the conscious,

analyzed: kutas etat
translated: where does this come from?

analyzed: tathā darśanāt iti ced na
translated: If it is said because it is seen thus, it is not so.

analyzed: yatas kāraka praśnaḥ yam na pramāṇa praśnaḥ
translated: Because this is a question about the agent, not a question about the means of knowledge.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ yam padārthānām iti ced na
translated: If it is said this is the nature of things, it is not so.

analyzed: anīśvara vāda pādaprasārikā pātāt
translated: Because of the fall of the foot of the argument of the doctrine of non-God.

analyzed: kiñca viruddhaḥ ca svabhāvaḥ ca iti katham
translated: Moreover, how can there be an inherent contradiction?

original: nahi svayameva svena sadvitīya iti yuktam /
analyzed: nahi svayam eva svena sa dvitīyaḥ iti yuktam
translated: For it is not proper to say that something is itself accompanied by itself.

analyzed: pramita tvāt na virodhaḥ iti tu pratyuktam
translated: But it has been replied that there is no contradiction because it is established.

analyzed: caitanya sāmarthyāt idam ghaṭate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this is possible due to the power of consciousness,

analyzed: dhūmavān api kaścid niragnikaḥ ghaṭatām
translated: then let something that has smoke also be possible without fire.

analyzed: atha viśeṣa śaktyā idam upapadyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this is possible due to the power of a particular [cause],

analyzed: ghaṭe pi upapadyatām
translated: then let it be possible even in a pot.

analyzed: nahi tatra viśeṣaḥ na asti
translated: For there is no absence of a particular [cause] there.

analyzed: viśeṣa vaicitryāt na iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is not so due to the variety of particulars,

analyzed: tat eva kutas
translated: then where does that [variety] come from?

analyzed: tasmāt bhagavān eva svarūpa svabhāva viśeṣāṇām niyāmakaḥ caitanyam avacchedakam vidhāya
translated: Therefore, the Lord alone, being the regulator of the forms, natures, and particulars, having determined consciousness as the limiting factor,

original: viśeṣaṃ nimittīkṛtya viruddhe apyabhedabahutve samāveśyābhedena niravayavatvaśabdakopamapāsya
analyzed: viśeṣam nimittīkṛtya viruddhe api abheda bahutve samāveśya abhedena niravayava tva śabda kopam apāsya
translated: having included even the contradictory oneness and plurality by making the particular the cause, having removed the objection of the word partless due to oneness,

original: bahutvena kṛtsnaprasaktiṃ nyakkṛtya kāryānurūpaṃ sāmarthyāviśeṣaṃ ni
analyzed: bahu tvena kṛtsna prasaktim nyakkṛtya kārya anurūpam sāmarthya aviśeṣam ni
translated: having set aside the application to the whole due to plurality, having applied the particular power in accordance with the effect,

analyzed: yojayan jīvena kārayati iti aṅgīkartavyam iti
translated: it must be accepted that He causes [the world] to be produced by the individual soul.

original: nanvetatsarvaṃ jīvasāmarthyādināśakyasampādanaṃ kathaṃ bhagavānapi sampādayedityata āha tasya tviti // /
analyzed: nanu etat sarvam jīva sāmarthya ādinā aśakya sampādanam katham bhagavān api sampādayet iti atas āha tasya tu iti
translated: But all this is not possible to be accomplished by the power of the individual soul, how then can the Lord accomplish it? To this he says: But of Him, because of His having all powers, all is possible.

analyzed: tasya tu aśeṣa śakti tvāt yujyate sa varmā iva ca
translated: But of Him, because of His having all powers, all is possible.

original: tadevamasya sūtrasyaivaṃ tātparyavyākhyāne na kaścidvirodha iti sthitam //
analyzed: tat evam asya sūtrasya evam tātparya vyākhyāne na kaścid virodhaḥ iti sthitam
translated: Thus it is established that there is no contradiction in explaining the purport of this aphorism in this way.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām itara vyapadeśa adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the designation of other in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.
Chapter VIII: On the basis of verbal testimony.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām śabda mūla tva adhikaraṇam
translated: Now begins the chapter on the basis of verbal testimony in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: om śruteḥ tu śabda mūla tvāt om
translated: Om. But because of the basis of verbal testimony.

analyzed: nanu īśvarasya api kartṛ tvam na yujyate
translated: But the agency of God also is not proper.

analyzed: jīva vat kṛtsna prasakteḥ  nahi brahmāṇḍa pipīlikāṇḍa
translated: Because of the possibility of doing everything, like the individual soul.

analyzed: nirmāṇe samam sāmarthyam prayuñjānaḥ prekṣāvān bhavati
translated: For one who is engaged in creating the universe and the ant-hill with equal ability is not a wise man.

analyzed: gati antara abhāvāt na doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is no fault because there is no other way, it is not so.

analyzed: īśvara tva vyāghātāt  atha etad parihāra atharma eka deśena pravṛttiḥ aṅgīkriyate tadā anā iha nānā
translated: Because it contradicts being God.🔽But if it is accepted that He acts with a part of that means of avoiding the fault, then there is no such thing here.

analyzed: syāt
translated: There would be the contradiction of the word stating that He is partless, as in He is without parts.

analyzed: śarīra indriya ādi vikala tvāt ca na kartṛ tvam
translated: And because it is devoid of a body, sense organs, etc., it cannot be an agent.

analyzed: nahi kaścid śarīra ādi vikalaḥ kartā upalabdhaḥ
translated: For no one devoid of a body, etc. is seen to be an agent.

analyzed: bhūmi ādi ādhāra vidhura tvāt ca
translated: And because it is devoid of a support like the earth, etc.

original: evaṃ daurghaṭye 'pi yadi kartṛtvamīśvarasya syāttadā jīvasyāpi kinna syāt /
analyzed: evam daurghaṭye pi yadi kartṛ tvam īśvarasya syāt tadā jīvasya api kim na syāt
translated: Thus, even if the agency of God were possible in spite of the difficulty, why should not the individual soul also be an agent?

analyzed: viśeṣa adarśanāt
translated: Because no difference is seen.

original: evañca sarvakartṛtvaṃ dūranirastamityayaṃ pūrvapakṣo 'trādhikaraṇe nirasyate /🔽tasya tātparyamāha tasya tviti //
analyzed: evam ca sarva kartṛ tvam dūra nirastam iti ayam pūrvapakṣaḥ tra adhikaraṇe nirasyate  tasya tātparyam āha tasya tu iti
translated: And thus, the prima facie view that His being the agent of all is far-fetched is refuted in this section.🔽Its purport is stated by the word tu (but) in the verse.

analyzed: śruteḥ tu śabda mūla tvāt
translated: But on account of the Vedic text, which is the basis of the word,

analyzed: tasya tu aśeṣa śakti tvāt yujyate sa varmā iva ca
translated: But on account of His having all potencies, everything is possible for Him.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ jīvāt viśeṣam dyotayati
translated: The word tu (but) indicates a difference from the individual soul.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ hetu samuccaye
translated: The word ca (and) is for the cumulative force of the reasons.

analyzed: īśvarasya alaukika tva śruteḥ āgama eka agamya tvena yukti virodha anavakāśāt
translated: Because the Vedic text speaks of God as being in the world, and because there is no scope for contradiction by reasoning, since He is to be known only through the scriptures.

analyzed: vicitra śaktiḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: The soul is endowed with various potencies.

analyzed: sarvaiḥ yuktā śaktibhiḥ devatā sā
translated: The deity is endowed with all potencies.

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhiḥ vicitra aśeṣa śakti tva avagamāt ca
translated: Thus, because it is understood from such Vedic texts that He has all potencies in various ways.

analyzed: sarvam bhinna aṃśa rahitasya api kāryeṣu kṛtsna prasakti abhāvaḥ
translated: Even though devoid of different parts, there is no possibility of His being entirely engaged in all effects.

analyzed: svarūpa aṃśa bāhulye pi bheda abhāvaḥ
translated: Even if there is an abundance of forms and parts, there is no difference.

original: aṃśataḥ kāryakaraṇe 'pi niravayavatvaśabdakopābhāvaḥ /🔽dehādirahitasyāpi kartṛtvanirvāha ityādi yujyata iti /
analyzed: aṃśataḥ kārya karaṇe pi niravayava tva śabda kopa abhāvaḥ  deha ādi rahitasya api kartṛ tva nirvāhe ityādi yujyate iti
translated: Even if the effect and means are partial, there is no contradiction with the word without parts.🔽It is proper to say that even one devoid of body etc. can perform actions, and so on.

analyzed: nanu durghaṭam api jīva kartṛ tvam īśvara śaktyā ghaṭate iti atīta adhikaraṇe bhihitam
translated: But it has been said in the previous section that even though the agency of the individual soul is difficult to conceive, it is possible by the power of God.

analyzed: tathā ca katham atra pūrvapakṣa avakāśaḥ
translated: And so how can there be scope for a prima facie view here?

original: yo hi paratra pramitaṃ ghaṭayitumīṣye saḥ svasminna īṣye ityasambhāvitam /
analyzed: yaḥ hi paratra pramitam ghaṭayitum īṣye saḥ svasmin naḥ īṣye iti asambhāvitam
translated: It is not possible that one who wishes to establish what is well-known elsewhere would not wish to establish it for himself.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: na eṣa ṛthaḥ sūtra kṛtā atīta adhikaraṇe bhihitaḥ
translated: This meaning was not stated by the author of the aphorisms in the previous section.

original: kintvāgāminamarthaṃ manasi nidhāya jīvakartṛtvavādanirāsa eva vihitaḥ /
analyzed: kintu āgāminam artham manasi nidhāya jīva kartṛ tva vāda nirāsaḥ eva vihitaḥ
translated: But keeping in mind the future meaning, he only refuted the doctrine of the individual soul's agency.

original: bhāṣyakāreṇa tu śiṣyahitaiṣiṇā vakṣyamāṇamapyarthamākṛṣṭa pūrvottaravirodhaḥ parihṛta iti / /
analyzed: bhāṣyakāreṇa tu śiṣya hita eṣiṇā vakṣyamāṇam api artham ākṛṣṭa pūrva uttara virodhaḥ parihṛtaḥ iti
translated: But the commentator, desiring the welfare of his students, drew in the future meaning and removed the contradiction between the previous and subsequent sections.

original: pariṇāmavādino vivartavādinaśca brahmaṇo jagadupādānatvaṃ kṛtsnaprasaktirityanenākṣipya śrutestvityādinā samādhīyata iti vyācakṣate /
analyzed: pariṇāma vādinaḥ vivarta vādinaḥ ca brahmaṇaḥ jagat upādānatvam kṛtsna prasaktiḥ iti anena ākṣipya śruteḥ tu ityādinā samādhīyate iti vyācakṣate
translated: Thus they explain: The doctrine of Brahman being the material cause of the world, which is held by the transformationists and the emanationists, is refuted by this section on the objection of the entire being involved. The objection is stated in the words if Brahman is the material cause etc., and the reply is given in the words but it is established by scripture etc.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: na brahma jagadupādānam /🔽yatastathātve kṛtsnasyāpi brahmaṇaḥ kāryākāratāprasaktiḥ syāt /
analyzed: na brahma jagat upādānam  yatas tathātve kṛtsnasya api brahmaṇaḥ kārya akāra tā prasaktiḥ syāt
translated: Brahman is not the material cause of the world.🔽For if it were so, the whole of Brahman would have to be regarded as assuming the form of effects.

original: sthitau ca brahmābhāve taddarśanopadeśānarthakyādi syāt /🔽athaitaddoṣaparijihīrṣayā brahma ekadeśena pariṇamate ekadeśena cāvatiṣṭhata ityucyate tadāniṣkalaṃ śāntam' /
analyzed: sthitau ca brahma abhāve tad darśana upadeśa ānarthakya ādi syāt  atha etad doṣa parijihīrṣayā brahma eka deśena pariṇamate eka deśena ca avatiṣṭhate iti ucyate tadā aniṣkalam śāntam
translated: And if Brahman were not to exist in the state of effect, the teaching of the knowledge of Brahman would be useless, and so on.

analyzed: ityādi niravayava tva śabda kopaḥ syāt iti
translated: If, in order to avoid these difficulties, it be said that Brahman transforms itself partially and remains as it is partially, then there would be the undesirable contingency of the contradiction of the scriptural texts which declare Brahman to be without parts, as, for instance, It is without parts, tranquil, etc.

analyzed: atra ucyate
translated: To this we reply:

analyzed: na ayam doṣaḥ  tadā ātmānam svayam akuruta
translated: This is no fault.

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ brahmaṇaḥ jagat upādāna tvasya kṛtsna pariṇāma abhāvasya ca avagamāt
translated: For from such scriptural texts as It made itself its own Self, it is understood that Brahman is the material cause of the world and that the whole of Brahman does not become transformed.

analyzed: śabda mūla tvena yukti virodha anavakāśāt ca
translated: And there is no room for the contradiction of reasoning, since it is based on the scriptures.

original: api ca sarvaśaktyupetā ca paradevatā śrūyate /
analyzed: api ca sarva śakti upetā ca para devatā śrūyate
translated: Moreover, the highest God is declared to be endowed with all powers,

analyzed: sarva karmā sarva kāmaḥ ityādi
translated: as, for instance, in the passage, He is all action, all desire.

analyzed: tatas niravayavasya api brahmaṇaḥ kṛtsna prasakti abhāvena eva jagat upādānatvam upapannam ityādi
translated: Therefore, even though Brahman is without parts, it is logically possible that it is the material cause of the world, since the whole of it does not become transformed.

analyzed: tat etat vayākhyānam anupapannam
translated: This explanation is not correct.

analyzed: evam sati eṣām sūtrāṇām etad adhyāya antarbhāva lakṣaṇa saṅgati abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: If this were so, then these sūtras would be connected with this chapter by the characteristic of being included in it.

original: tatkathamityata āha virodha iti // /🔽virodhaḥ sarvavaiśiṣṭaye yo dvitīye nirasyate /
analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha virodhaḥ iti  virodhaḥ sarva vaiśiṣṭaye yaḥ dvitīye nirasyate
translated: How is this? Therefore it is said: contradiction.🔽The contradiction that is refuted in the second chapter regarding the superiority of everything of Nārāyaṇa,

analyzed: nārāyaṇasya tu adhyāye
translated: in the chapter on Nārāyaṇa...

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word tu (but) is for determination.

analyzed: para brahmaṇā nārāyaṇasya sarvasmāt cetanāt acetanāt ca vaiśiṣyaye vailakṣaṇye
translated: The contradiction regarding the superiority of everything of Nārāyaṇa over the supreme Brahman, regarding the difference,

original: paramotkṛṣṭatve 'tyantavyāvṛttatve ca yo yuktyādivirodhaḥ sa evātra dvitīye 'dhyāye nirasyate /
analyzed: parama utkṛṣṭa tve tyanta vyāvṛtta tve ca yaḥ yukti ādi virodhaḥ saḥ eva atra dvitīye dhyāye nirasyate
translated: the highest excellence, and the complete exclusion of Nārāyaṇa, that very contradiction is refuted here in the second chapter.

analyzed: sakala jagat upādana tvena sarva ātmaka tvam tu na
translated: But being the cause of the entire world and being the essence of everything is not the superiority of everything.

analyzed: na api tat upayuktam
translated: Nor is it useful for that.

analyzed: pratyuta viruddham eva
translated: On the contrary, it is contradictory.

original: tatkathaṃ tatra virodhaparihāro 'trāntarbhāvamāsādayet /🔽nanu jagadupādānatvādeva sarvavaiśiṣyayaṃ brahmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: tat katham tatra  nanu jagat upādāna tvāt eva brahmaṇaḥ
translated: How then could the removal of contradiction there be included here?🔽But is not the superiority of Brahman over everything due to being the cause of the world?

analyzed: nahi jagat jagat upādānam iti ced
translated: For the world is not the cause of the world, if this is argued,

analyzed: tat kim upādāna upādeyayoḥ bhedam manyase
translated: then do you consider there to be a difference between the cause and the caused?

analyzed: tathā ca tad ananyatvam iti ukta virodhaḥ
translated: And thus there is contradiction with what was said about non-difference from that.

original: jagat brahmaṇo na bhidyate brahma tu jagato bhidyata iti cet / na /
analyzed: jagat brahmaṇaḥ na bhidyate brahma tu jagataḥ bhidyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the world is not different from Brahman, but Brahman is different from the world, it is not so.

analyzed: ukta uttara tvāt  prāk brahma upādāna tvasya anukta tvāt kṛtsna prasakti ādi paricodanā eva anavakāśā
translated: Because the answer has already been given.🔽Since Brahman's being the material cause was not stated before, the objection regarding the entire universe being produced and so on has no scope.

analyzed: pariṇāma pratipādaka śruteḥ abhāvena gagana ādi prapañca ātmakasya tad asambhavi śabda mūla tva sarva śakti tva ādi asambhavena ca samādhānam api ayuktam
translated: The solution is also incorrect because there is no scriptural statement teaching transformation, and because the universe consisting of space etc. cannot have as its basis what is impossible, such as being rooted in words, having all powers, etc.

analyzed: vivarta vāde tu sarvathā api nā eṣā śaṅkā avakāśam aśnute
translated: But in the doctrine of manifestation, this doubt has no scope at all.

analyzed: śukti ādikam iva rajata ādi āropasya brahma avidyaka prapañca āropasya adhiṣṭhānam iti spaṣṭam ārambhaṇa adhikaraṇe bhihitam
translated: It has been clearly stated in the beginning section that Brahman is the basis of the superimposition of the manifestation of the world, which is due to ignorance, just as silver etc. is superimposed on mother-of-pearl etc.

analyzed: tatra katham kṛtsna eka deśa vicāraḥ
translated: How can there be a consideration of the whole and a part in that case?

analyzed: ukta an avachānāt śaṅgā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the doubt arises due to the stated non-exclusion,

analyzed: tarhi uktam smara iti vaktavyam
translated: then it should be said that the stated is remembered.

analyzed: spaṣṭam ca āropita tvam prapañcasya brahmaṇi upapādanīyam
translated: And the superimposition of the world on Brahman should be clearly established.

analyzed: śruteḥ tu ityādeḥ tu kā saṅgatiḥ
translated: What connection can there be with the statement beginning with but because of the scriptures?

analyzed: kaścid parihāra adarśana sambhrānta cittaḥ āha
translated: Someone, his mind confused by not seeing an answer, says:

analyzed: avidyā saṃvalitam khalu brahma jagat upādānam
translated: Brahman, indeed, mixed with ignorance, is the material cause of the world.

analyzed: tatra avidyā upādāna tvasya ayam ākṣepaḥ parihāraḥ ca iti
translated: Here, this is the objection and the answer to the argument that ignorance is the material cause.

analyzed: tat atīva mandam
translated: That is very foolish.

analyzed: na hi avidyāyāḥ upādāna tvam api vāstavam
translated: For ignorance is not even a real material cause.

analyzed: tasya avicārita ramaṇīya tayā eva śaṅkā viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because it is the object of doubt only by being pleasing when not examined.

original: kiñca kṛtsnaprasaktiḥ sāvayavatvaṃ cāvidyāyāṃ kiṃ kariṣyati /
analyzed: kiñca kṛtsna prasaktiḥ sāvayavatvam ca avidyāyām kim kariṣyati
translated: Moreover, what will the inclusion of everything and the divisibility of ignorance do?

analyzed: samādhānam tu
translated: But the solution is completely irrelevant.

analyzed: etena vikaraṇa tvāt iti ākṣepa parihārau api asaṅga tau veditavyau
translated: By this, the objection and the answer based on being without parts should be understood to be irrelevant.

analyzed: nahi bhrama adhiṣṭhāna tā śarīra ādikam apekṣate
translated: For the substratum of error does not depend on the body, etc.

analyzed: īśvara viṣayam tat iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it refers to God, no.

analyzed: tasya kiraṇa tva abhāvena ākṣepa anudayāt ityādikam svayam eva śiṣyaiḥ avagantavyam iti asaṅgatiḥ eva ācāryeṇa uktā
translated: Because the objection does not arise due to the absence of rays in him. Thus, the irrelevance has been stated by the teacher himself that the disciples should understand this.

original: syādevamasaṅgatiryadi brahmaṇaḥ sarvavaiśiṣyaye virodhaparihāro 'dhyāhāyarḥ syāttadeva kuta ityata āha tadanya iti /
analyzed: syāt evam asaṅgatiḥ yadi brahmaṇaḥ sarva vaiśiṣyaye virodha parihāraḥ syāt tat eva kutas iti atas āha tad anyaḥ iti
translated: This would be an irrelevance if the removal of contradiction in Brahman's superiority over everything were the purpose of the chapter. How is that known? To this he says that other etc.

analyzed: tad anye tatra tatragāḥ
translated: The others are to be found here and there in the various sections.

analyzed: tasmāt sarva vaiśiṣyaya viṣayāt anye virodhāḥ tatra tatra eva adhikaraṇeṣu gatāḥ parihṛtāḥ
translated: Therefore, the other contradictions are to be found here and there in the various sections and have been refuted.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: avirodha lakṣaṇaḥ dvitīyaḥ dhyāyaḥ iti tāvat sammatam
translated: It is generally accepted that the second chapter has the characteristic of non-contradiction.

original: na cānukte 'rthe virodhaparihāraḥ saṅgata iti prathamādhyāyārthe 'virodho dvitīyasyārthaḥ /
analyzed: na ca anukte rthe virodha parihāraḥ saṅgataḥ iti prathama adhyāya arthe virodhaḥ dvitīyasya arthaḥ
translated: And since the removal of contradiction is not appropriate in an unexpressed meaning, the non-contradiction of the meaning of the first chapter is the meaning of the second.

analyzed: prathame ca ādi sūtreṇa śāstrīya viṣaya prayojana pradarśana mukhena brahma jijñāsāyāḥ katarvya tvam uktam
translated: And in the first, by the first aphorism, the performance of the inquiry into Brahman is stated by way of showing the scriptural subject matter and purpose.

analyzed: tat catur adhyāyī parisamāpyam na ekatra paryavasyati
translated: And that is to be completed in four chapters, not concluded in one place.

analyzed: tatas kim tat brahma
translated: Then what is that Brahman?

original: kiṃ jīvo 'tha jaḍamiti svarūpajijñāsāyāṃ śṛṅgagrāhikayā pradarśayitumaśakyatvāt /
analyzed: kim jaḍam iti svarūpa jijñāsāyām śṛṅga grāhikayā pradarśayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: Is it the individual soul or the insentient? In the inquiry into its nature, since it cannot be shown by seizing the peak,

original: dvitīyasūtre sarvato vailakṣaṇyapradarśanena sarvotkṛṣṭaṃ sarvasmādvayāvṛttaṃ ceti pratipāditam /
analyzed: dvitīya sūtre sarvatas vailakṣaṇya pradarśanena sarva utkṛṣṭam sarvasmāt vayāvṛttam ca iti pratipāditam
translated: in the second aphorism, by showing its difference from everything, it is taught that it is the most excellent of all and distinct from everything.

analyzed: sajātīya vijātīya asambhāvita dharmasya lakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: Because a characteristic is a property not possible in things of the same or different kinds.

analyzed: sakala itara vyāvṛtteḥ ca tad prayojana tvāt
translated: And because that is the purpose of the exclusion of the qualified and other things.

original: tṛtīyasūtre śāstraṃ tatra pramāṇamabhidhāya tasyottaraprabandhena sāmānyato viśeṣataśca sakalajīvajaḍavyāvṛttavastuviṣayatā samarthitā /
analyzed: tṛtīya sūtre śāstram tatra pramāṇam abhidhāya tasya uttara prabandhena sāmānyatas viśeṣatas ca sakala jīva jaḍa vyāvṛtta vastu viṣaya tā samarthitā
translated: In the third aphorism, having stated that the scripture is the means of knowledge there, its general and specific subject matter as the object of all living beings and insentient things is established by the subsequent text.

analyzed: evam ca dvaye virodhaḥ pariharaṇīyāḥ bhavanti
translated: Thus, the two contradictions are to be removed.

analyzed: dvitīya sūtra siddha sarva vaiśiṣyaya viṣayāḥ śāstra samanvaya viṣayāḥ ca
translated: Those which are established by the second aphorism as having all excellences, and those which are the subject matter of the harmony of the scriptures.

original: tatra dvitīyā vikāraśabdādityādinā tatra tatraivādhikaraṇe parihṛtā iti pariśeṣātsarvavaiśiṣyayaviṣayavirodhaparihāra eva dvitīyārtha iti jñāyata
analyzed: tatra dvitīyā vikāra śabdāt ityādinā tatra tatra eva adhikaraṇe parihṛtā iti pariśeṣāt sarva vaiśiṣyaya viṣaya virodha parihāraḥ eva dvitīyā arthaḥ iti jñāyata
translated: There, the second is removed in various sections beginning with from the word 'modification' etc. Thus, by elimination, it is understood that the removal of the contradiction regarding the subject matter of all excellences is itself the meaning of the second.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: nanu ca śrutīnāṃ parasparavirodho 'pi dvitīye 'dhyāye na viyadaśruterityādinā parihṛtaḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca śrutīnām paraspara virodhaḥ dvitīye dhyāye na viyat aśruteḥ ityādinā parihṛtaḥ
translated: But the contradiction between the scriptures themselves is also removed in the second chapter by because the sky is not mentioned etc.

original: tatkathamucyate brahmaṇaḥ sarvavaiśiṣyaye virodho dvitīye nirasyata iti tatrāha sṛṣṭīti //
analyzed: tat katham ucyate brahmaṇaḥ sarva vaiśiṣyaye virodhaḥ dvitīye nirasyate iti tatra āha sṛṣṭi iti
translated: How then can it be said that the contradiction regarding Brahman's all-excellence is removed in the second? There he says sṛṣṭi etc.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vākyānām jīva rūpa abhidhāyinām
translated: Of the statements about creation and dissolution, which express the form of the individual soul,

analyzed: api anyonya avirodhaḥ tu dvitīya adhyāya gocaraḥ
translated: But the non-contradiction of the others is the sphere of the second chapter.

analyzed: jīva rūpa abhidhāyinām vākyānām
translated: Of the statements expressing the form of the individual soul.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is an indication.

analyzed: prāṇa ādi viṣayāṇām ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: And it should be seen that it is also of those referring to the vital breath etc.

analyzed: sṛṣṭayā ādi viśeṣaṇam upapatti sūcana artham
translated: The qualification beginning with creation is for the purpose of indicating the reason.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word but is for the purpose of distinguishing.

original: yo dvitīyādhyāyagocaro vākyānāmanyonyavirodhaḥ so 'pi pārameśvarasarvavaiśiṣyayavirodhaparihāra eva /
analyzed: yaḥ dvitīya adhyāya gocaraḥ vākyānām anyonya virodhaḥ saḥ pi pārameśvara sarva vaiśiṣyaya virodha parihāraḥ eva
translated: That mutual contradiction of the statements which is the sphere of the second chapter is also the avoidance of contradiction in the supreme Lordship and all excellence.

analyzed: kintu prathama dvitīya pādayoḥ sākṣat tṛtīya caturthayoḥ tu vyavadhānena iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: But the difference is that in the first and second quarters it is direct, in the third and fourth it is indirect.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: śrutīnāṃ parasparavirodhaparihāraḥ kiṃ tatprāmāṇyanirṇayamātraphalaḥ kiṃ vā prameyanirṇayaphalaḥ /
analyzed: śrutīnām paraspara virodha parihāraḥ kim tad prāmāṇya nirṇaya mātra phalaḥ kim vā prameya nirṇaya phalaḥ
translated: Is the avoidance of mutual contradiction of the scriptures only for the purpose of determining their validity, or for the purpose of determining the object of knowledge?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: mīmāṃsāyāḥ nyāya śāstra tva āpatteḥ
translated: Because then the Mimamsa would become a treatise on logic.

analyzed: kiñca evam sati viyat ādi sṛṣṭayā ādi viṣaya vākya virodha parihāraḥ eva kasmāt kriyate
translated: Moreover, if it were so, why is the avoidance of contradiction of the statements referring to the creation etc. of the sky etc. done at all?

analyzed: udita homa ādi vākyānām api nyāya darśane iva upādāna upapatteḥ
translated: Because the statements about the oblations offered at sunrise etc. can also be included in the Nyaya philosophy.

analyzed: ākāśa vāyu ādi kramaḥ ca atra na atyantam upayujyate
translated: And the order beginning with space and air is not at all useful here.

analyzed: dvitīye pi kim sṛṣṭayā ādikam eva prameyam uta tad aṅgi bhūtam anyat
translated: In the second also, is creation etc. itself the object of knowledge, or something else which is subsidiary to that?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: tasya svarūpataḥ prayojana tvāt
translated: Because that is not purposeful in itself.
It is not to be taught first.

analyzed: anyathā punar udita homa ādi vākya virodha parihāraḥ pi kāryaḥ syāt
translated: Otherwise, the avoidance of contradiction with the statements about the re-enacted oblations etc. would also have to be done.

analyzed: nirhetukaḥ
translated: The extraction of the subject matter of creation etc. is also without a reason.

analyzed: atas dvitīyaḥ eva pariśiṣyate
translated: Therefore, only the second remains.

analyzed: na ca anyat asti sṛṣṭayā ādi prameyasya aṅgi prathama uktam dvitīya sūtra abhihitāt brahmaṇaḥ
translated: And there is nothing else that is subsidiary to the object of knowledge such as creation etc., because Brahman mentioned in the second aphorism is superior to everything mentioned in the first.

analyzed: atas yuktam uktam
translated: Therefore, what was said is correct.

original: tadevaṃ paroktasūtrārthasya dvitīyādhyāyāntarbhāvalakṣaṇasaṅgatyabhāvādvirodhāccokta eva sūtrārtha iti siddham / /🔽atreśvarasya śarīrendriyādikaraṇarahitatvātkartṛtvaṃ nopapadyate ityākṣepasamādhānārthaṃ sūtram //
analyzed: tat evam para ukta sūtra arthasya dvitīya adhyāya antarbhāva lakṣaṇa saṅgati abhāvāt virodhāt ca uktaḥ eva sūtra arthaḥ iti siddham  / atra īśvarasya śarīra indriya ādi karaṇa rahita tvāt kartṛ tvam na upapadyate iti ākṣepa samādhāna artham sūtram
translated: Thus, it is established that the meaning of the aphorism stated by the opponent is not internally connected with the second chapter and is contradictory, so the meaning of the aphorism stated by us is correct.🔽Here, because the Lord is devoid of body, sense organs and other instruments, agency is not possible. To resolve this objection, the aphorism is:

analyzed: om vikaraṇa tvāt na iti ced tat uktam om  iti
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because of being without instruments, that has been stated.🔽This is the aphorism.

analyzed: etat anārambhaṇīyam
translated: This should not be begun.

analyzed: punarukta tvāt
translated: Because it is a repetition.

analyzed: śruteḥ tu śabda mūla tvāt
translated: But the Vedic text is based on the word.

analyzed: ca evam vicitrāḥ ca hi
translated: And thus various and in the Self.

original: sarvopetā ca taddarśanāditi sūtrairevālaukikatvaśabdaikasamadhigamyatvavicitrānantaśaktitvādiyuktibhiḥ sarvasyāpi daurghaṭyasya parihṛtatvāt
analyzed: sarva upetā ca tad darśanāt iti sūtraiḥ eva alaukika tva śabda eka samadhigamya tva vicitra ananta śakti tva ādi yuktibhiḥ sarvasya api daurghaṭyasya parihṛta tvāt
translated: And endowed with all, because it is seen. Thus, by the sutras themselves, all the difficulties such as being otherworldly, being known only through the word, having various infinite powers, etc. are removed.

original: yo hi sākṣātkārakādhiṣṭhānasya neṣye sa śarīravyavadhānamapekṣate /
analyzed: yaḥ hi sākṣātkāraka adhiṣṭhānasya neṣye sa śarīra vyavadhānam apekṣate
translated: One who does not accept the substratum of direct perception needs the obstruction of the body.

analyzed: yasya ca āgantukam jñānam sa tad artham indriyāṇi
translated: And one whose knowledge is adventitious needs the senses for that purpose.

original: yaśca guruśarīro nāvasthātuṃ śaknoti sa kṣityādikamādhāram /
analyzed: yaḥ ca guru śarīraḥ na avasthātum śaknoti sa kṣiti ādikam ādhāram
translated: And one who cannot remain in the heavy body needs the support of the earth, etc.

analyzed: bhagavān tu sarva śaktiḥ sarvajñaḥ
translated: But the Lord, who is all-powerful and omniscient, what purpose does He need?

original: naca kācidabhyadhikā śaṅkāsti yena punarārambhaḥ syādityata āha māneti //
analyzed: na ca kācid abhyadhikā śaṅkā asti yena punar ārambhaḥ syāt iti atas āha māna iti
translated: And there is no other doubt that could lead to a new beginning. Therefore he says: By the distinction of the means of knowledge and the object of knowledge, repetition does not occur.

analyzed: vikaraṇa tvāt na iti ced tat uktam
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because of being disembodied, that has been stated.

analyzed: māna meya viśeṣeṇa punaruktiḥ na jāyate
translated: By the distinction of the means of knowledge and the object of knowledge, repetition does not occur.

original: yathā ata eva prāṇa ityādau mānaikye 'pi meyaviśeṣaṇa na punaruktidoṣastathātra meyaikye 'pi mānaviśeṣaṇa na punaruktidoṣaḥ /
analyzed: yathā atas eva prāṇaḥ ityādau māna aikye na punarukti doṣaḥ tathā atra meya aikye na punarukti doṣaḥ
translated: Just as in the case of prana etc., even though the means of knowledge are the same, there is no fault of repetition by specifying the object, similarly here, even though the object is the same, there is no fault of repetition by specifying the means of knowledge.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  kim ukta artha ukti mātram doṣaḥ
translated: This is what is said.🔽Is the mere statement of what has been said a fault?

analyzed: kim vā ukta anatirikta uktiḥ
translated: Or is it the statement of what has been said in excess?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: ukta parihāra atideśa ukteḥ api doṣa tva anuṣaṅgāt
translated: Because even the statement of the extension of the reply to what has been said is implied to be a fault.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tu prakṛte na siddhaḥ
translated: But the second is not established in the present case.

analyzed: prameya aikye pi pramāṇa bhedasya sattvāt
translated: Because even when the object of knowledge is the same, there is a difference in the means of knowledge.

original: iha hi cidānandādyātmakadivyamaṅgalavigrahavato mahāpuruṣasya prākṛtaśarīrādyabhāve 'pi sakalakāryakartṛtvamapāṇipāda ityādiśrutimāśrityoktamiti
analyzed: iha hi cit ānanda ādi ātmaka divya maṅgala vigrahavataḥ mahāpuruṣasya prākṛta śarīra ādi abhāve pi sakala kārya kartṛ tvam apāṇi pādaḥ ityādi śrutim āśritya uktam iti
translated: For here, it is said that even in the absence of a natural body etc. of the great person who has a divine auspicious form consisting of consciousness, bliss etc., he is the agent of all effects, relying on the statement without hands and feet etc. in the scriptures.

analyzed: yat vā māna meyayoḥ viśeṣeṇa iti yojyam
translated: Or, it should be connected as by specifying the means of knowledge and the object of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā ca ayam atharḥ
translated: And the meaning of this is as follows.

original: pūrvasūtraiḥ sāmānyaviṣayapramāṇānyāśritya sāmānyata eva sarvānupapattiparihāro vihitaḥ /
analyzed: pūrva sūtraiḥ sāmānya viṣaya pramāṇāni āśritya sāmānyatas eva sarva anupapatti parihāraḥ vihitaḥ
translated: By the previous aphorisms, relying on the means of knowledge which have general objects, the removal of all inconsistencies is accomplished in a general way.

original: iha tu viśeṣaviṣayeṇaiva pramāṇena viśeṣānupapattiparihāraḥ kriyata iti kathaṃ punaruktidoṣāvakāśa iti /
analyzed: iha tu viśeṣa viṣayeṇa eva pramāṇena viśeṣa anupapatti parihāraḥ kriyate iti katham punarukti doṣa avakāśaḥ iti
translated: But here, the removal of the impossibility of the particular is done by a means of knowledge that has a particular as its object. So how can there be an occasion for the fault of repetition?

analyzed: tathā api ākṣepaḥ na upapadyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that even so, the objection is not appropriate, it is not so.

analyzed: viśeṣa jijñāsayā upapatteḥ iti
translated: Because the inquiry into the particular is appropriate.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām śabda mūla tva adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the basis of words in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: na prayojana adhikaraṇam
translated: IX. The chapter on the absence of purpose.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām na prayojana adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on the absence of purpose.

analyzed: om na prayojanavat tvāt om
translated: Om. Not because of having a purpose. Om.

analyzed: om loka vat tu līlā kaivalyam om  yad prayojana artham sṛṣṭayā ādiḥ tad ūna tvāt apūrṇa tā iti ākṣepa parihārāya idam adhikaraṇam ārabhyate
translated: But like in the world, the līlā is mere freedom.🔽This chapter is begun to rebut the objection that the purpose for which creation etc. occur is incomplete, because it is less than that.

analyzed: tat etat anupapannam iti ābhāti
translated: This appears to be illogical.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

original: yadyatra kartṛtvena prayojanavattvaṃ prasādhyāpūrṇatvasādhanaṃ pūrvapakṣiṇo vivakṣitaṃ syāttadā prathamasūtramayuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi atra kartṛ tvena prayojanavat tvam prasādhya apūrṇa tva sādhanam pūrvapakṣiṇaḥ vivakṣitam syāt tadā prathama sūtram ayuktam syāt
translated: If the opponent's intention were to prove the incompleteness by establishing the purposefulness as the agent here, then the first aphorism would be illogical.

analyzed: apūrṇa tā sādhakam prati prayojanavat tva hetoḥ asiddha tvāt
translated: Because the reason of purposefulness is unestablished with respect to the proof of incompleteness.

original: atha kartā cetprayojanavānsyāt tathā cāpūrṇaḥ syādityāpādanaṃ vivakṣitam /
analyzed: atha kartā ced prayojanavān syāt tathā ca apūrṇaḥ syāt iti āpādanam vivakṣitam
translated: Now, if it is intended to argue that if the agent were purposeful, then he would be incomplete,

analyzed: tadā vyartham eva idam sūtram
translated: then this aphorism is useless.
