analyzed: na ca apūrṇaḥ tatas na prayojanavān iti pareṇa eva aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: And it is not accepted by the opponent that he is incomplete and therefore not purposeful.

analyzed: anyathā viparyaya aparyavasānāt
translated: Otherwise, because of the impossibility of the opposite.

analyzed: loka vat tu līlā kaivalyam iti dvitīya sūtram tu pakṣa dvaye pi ayuktam
translated: But the second aphorism, But like in the world, the sport is solely, is not appropriate in either case.

analyzed: sādhana āpādana dūṣaṇasya an udbhāvanāt iti
translated: Because the refutation of the proof and the reductio ad absurdum is not stated.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: īśvarasya sṛṣṭayā ādinā prayojanam asti na vā
translated: Does God have a purpose in creation etc. or not?

analyzed: ādye pūrṇa tvam prasajyeta
translated: In the first case, incompleteness would result.

original: dvitīye tu kartṛtvānupapattiḥ tasya prayojanavyāptatvādityubhayathāpīśvarasya jagatsṛṣṭayādikartṛtvānupapattirityatra pūrvapakṣiṇo vivakṣitam
analyzed: dvitīye tu kartṛ tva anupapattiḥ tasya prayojana vyāpta tvāt iti ubhayathā api īśvarasya jagat sṛṣṭayā ādi kartṛ tva anupapattiḥ iti atra pūrvapakṣiṇaḥ vivakṣitam
translated: In the second case, there is an impossibility of agency, because that is pervaded by purpose. Thus, in both ways, the impossibility of God being the agent of creation etc. of the world is intended here by the opponent.

analyzed: tatra prathama sūtreṇa prayojana abhāva pakṣam sa yuktikam upādatte
translated: There, with the first aphorism, he presents the view of the absence of purpose along with reasoning.

analyzed: tatra ukta doṣa parihāra artham dvitīyam sūtram
translated: For the purpose of avoiding the faults stated there, the second aphorism is.

original: yadvā kartṛtvena prayojanasya tena cāpūrṇatvasya idaṃ sa dhanaṃ vivakṣitamutāpādanamiti siddhāntī vikalpyādyamādyena nirācaṣṭe /
analyzed: yat vā kartṛ tvena prayojanasya tena ca apūrṇa tvasya idam sa dhanam vivakṣitam uta āpādanam iti siddhāntī vikalpya ādyam ādyena nirācaṣṭe
translated: Or, is it intended that this is the wealth of the one who is not complete due to not being the agent of the purpose? The proponent of the conclusion rejects the first of these alternatives with the first [rejection].

analyzed: na kartṛ tvena prayojanavat tvam sādhyam
translated: The fact that [the Lord] is the agent of the purpose is not to be established.

analyzed: kṛtakṛtya tvena prayojana abhāvasya eva niścita tvāt
translated: Because the absence of purpose due to having done what was to be done is itself certain.

analyzed: na ca asiddhaḥ hetuḥ
translated: And the reason is not unestablished.

original: athaiṣa eva parama ānando niraniṣyo niravadya iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: atha eṣaḥ eva paramaḥ ānandaḥ niraniṣyaḥ niravadyaḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: For it is said in the scripture: This indeed is the highest bliss, free from hatred, free from blame.

analyzed: prayojanavat tvena āpūrṇa tā anumānam tu garbhasrāveṇa eva galitam iti
translated: But the inference of incompleteness due to having a purpose is dissolved by the abortion itself.

analyzed: ādyasya dūṣaṇa antaram vadan dvitīyam dvitīyena nirākaroti iti
translated: Saying that the first [rejection] is another fault, he refutes the second with the second [rejection].

original: nanūktamatra lokavaditi sūtreṇa sādhanasyāpādanasya vā na kiñciddūṣaṇamudbhāvyata iti /
analyzed: nanu uktam atra loka vat iti sūtreṇa sādhanasya āpādanasya vā na kiñcid dūṣaṇam udbhāvyate iti
translated: But it has been said here that no fault is pointed out regarding the proof or the reductio argument by the sūtra like in the world.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: bādhā ādeḥ udbhāvanāt iti āśayavān dvitīya sūtrasya tātparyam āha sadā iti
translated: With the intention that [faults] such as contradiction are pointed out, he states the purport of the second sūtra with sat [i.e. sat is the second word of the second sūtra].

analyzed: na prayojanavat tvāt
translated: Not because of having a purpose...

analyzed: loka vat tu līlā kaivalyam
translated: But the freedom [of the Lord] is like in the world, only for play...

analyzed: sadā pravṛttiḥ īśasya svabhāvāt eva kevalam
translated: The activity of the Lord is always only due to His nature...

original: yathā loke jvalanapavanādīnāṃ tatheśasyāpi sadā sṛṣṭayādau kevalaṃ prayojanena vinā svabhāvādeva pravṛttiḥ pramiteti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yathā loke jvalana pavana ādīnām tathā īśasya api sadā sṛṣṭayā ādau kevalam prayojanena vinā svabhāvāt eva pravṛttiḥ pramitā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: As in the world, so in the case of God also, the activity is always in creation etc. only by nature, without any purpose. The rest is understood.

analyzed: tat anena īśvarasya pravṛttyā prayojana sādhanam anaikāntikam bādhita viṣayam ca
translated: By this it is said that the activity of God is inconclusive and contradicts the established fact in establishing the purpose.

analyzed: prasaṅgaḥ tu vyapti vikalaḥ viparyaya aparyavasāyī ca iti uktam bhavati
translated: But the reductio ad absurdum is devoid of pervasion and does not lead to the opposite conclusion.

analyzed: atha manyeta
translated: Now, if one thinks:

analyzed: cetana pravṛttiḥ na prayojanena vinā dṛṣṭā
translated: The activity of a conscious being is not seen without a purpose.

analyzed: atas na anaikāntya ādi iti
translated: Therefore, it is not inconclusive etc.

analyzed: tat api na asti
translated: That is also not so.

analyzed: mattasya sukha udrekāt eva nṛtta gāna ādi pravṛtti darśanāt
translated: Because the activity of dancing, singing etc. is seen even from the excess of happiness of an intoxicated person.

original: nanu ca prekṣāvatpravṛttirna prayojanoddeśena vinopalabdhā iyaṃ ca prekṣāvatpravṛttiḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca prekṣāvat pravṛttiḥ na prayojana uddeśena vinā upalabdhā iyam ca prekṣāvat pravṛttiḥ
translated: But is not the activity of an intelligent being seen without the aim of a purpose? And this is the activity of an intelligent being.

original: ataḥ prayojanoddeśavatī syāditi sādhyamāpādyaṃ cetyata āha aṅgeti //🔽aṅgaceṣyā yathā puṃsaḥ kāściduddeśavarjitāḥ // / / //
analyzed: atas prayojana uddeśavatī syāt iti sādhyam āpādyam ca iti atas āha aṅga iti  aṅga ceṣyāḥ yathā puṃsaḥ kāścid uddeśa varjitāḥ
translated: Therefore, it should have the aim of a purpose. If this is the conclusion to be deduced, then he says:🔽Some activities of the body of a person are devoid of a purpose.

analyzed: kāścid vayākhyāna ādau aṅguli cālana ādikāḥ
translated: Some, like the movement of fingers in explaining etc.

analyzed: uddeśa varjitāḥ prayojana uddeśa varjitāḥ
translated: Are devoid of a purpose, i.e., devoid of the aim of a purpose.

analyzed: tathā īśasya api pravṛttiḥ iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: Similarly, the activity of the Lord also, as connected with the preceding text.

analyzed: tathā api anaikāntya ādi anistāraḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even so, the objection of inconclusiveness remains, this is the idea.

original: yaduktamīśvarasya pravṛttiḥ prayojanena vinā svabhāvādeva pramiteti /
analyzed: yat uktam īśvarasya pravṛttiḥ prayojanena vinā svabhāvāt eva pramitā iti
translated: What was said - that the activity of God is established to be due to His own nature, without any purpose -

analyzed: tad pramāṇam idānīm āha devasya iti
translated: That proof is now stated by the Lord, as follows:

analyzed: devasya eṣa svabhāvaḥ yam iti āha śrutiḥ añjasā
translated: The scripture clearly states that this is the nature of the Lord.

analyzed: devasya eṣa svabhāvaḥ yam āpta kāmasya kā spṛhā
translated: For the Lord, whose desires are fulfilled, what is there to desire?

analyzed: iti śrutiḥ añjasā sphuṭam uktam artham āha
translated: The scripture clearly states the meaning that is evident.

analyzed: devasya ayam sṛṣṭayā ādi viṣayaḥ eṣaḥ icchā
translated: This is the desire of the Lord regarding creation and so on.

analyzed: tad pūrvikā pravṛttiḥ iti yāvat
translated: It is preceded by that, i.e., activity.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ eva
translated: It is just His nature.

analyzed: na prayojanāya
translated: Not for any purpose.

analyzed: kutas āpta kāmasya prayojana spṛhā sambhavāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Why? Because desire for a purpose is not possible for one whose desires are fulfilled, this is the meaning.

analyzed: kecid idam sūtram anyathā vyācakṣate
translated: Some explain this aphorism differently.

original: yathā loke saptadvīpāṃ medinīmadhitiṣṭhataḥ sampūṇarśauryavīryaparākramasyāpi mahārājasya kevalalīlaikaprayojanāḥ kandukādyārambhā dṛśyante
analyzed: yathā loke sapta dvīpām medinīm adhitiṣṭhataḥ sampūṇa ṛśaurya vīrya parākramasya api mahā rājasya kevala līlā eka prayojanāḥ kanduka ādi ārambhāḥ dṛśyante
translated: Just as in the world, even for a great king who rules over the land with its seven islands, and who is fully endowed with courage, valor, and prowess, the beginnings of play with a ball and other such things are seen to have play alone as their purpose,

original: tathaiva parasyāpi brahmaṇaḥ svasaṅkalpamātrāvakḷptajagajjanmasthitidhvaṃsāderlīlaiva prayojanamiti tadetannirākaroti krīḍāmiti //
analyzed: tathā eva parasya api brahmaṇaḥ sva saṅkalpa mātra avakḷpta jagat janma sthiti dhvaṃsa ādeḥ līlā eva prayojanam iti tat etat nirākaroti krīḍām iti
translated: In the same way, the purpose of the Supreme Brahman's creation, sustenance, and destruction of the world, which are established by His mere will, is also mere sport. This is refuted by saying kridām (in the verse).

analyzed: krīḍām prayojanam kṛtvā sṛṣṭiḥ śruti virodhinī
translated: Creation with sport as the purpose contradicts the Vedas.

analyzed: bhoga artham sṛṣṭiḥ iti anye krīḍā tharm iti ca apare
translated: Others say creation is for enjoyment, and still others say it is for the sake of sport.

original: iti krīḍāprayojanāṃ bhagavataḥ sṛṣṭayādipravṛttiṃ vadataḥ pūrvapakṣīkṛtya devasyaiva svabhāvo 'yamiti sayuktikaṃ prayojanaleśābhāvaḥ śrutyā
analyzed: iti krīḍā prayojanām bhagavataḥ sṛṣṭayā ādi pravṛttim vadataḥ pūrvapakṣīkṛtya devasya eva svabhāvaḥ yam iti sa yuktikam prayojana leśa abhāvaḥ śrutyā
translated: Thus, having presented the prima facie view that the Lord's engagement in creation etc. has sport as its purpose, the absence of even a trace of purpose is established through reasoning by the opponent that this is simply the nature of the Lord.

analyzed: siddhāntitaḥ
translated: This is the conclusion.

analyzed: atas śruti viruddha tvāt apavyākhyānam eva etat
translated: Therefore, this is mere misinterpretation, as it contradicts the Vedas.

analyzed: sūtra akṣara ananuguṇam ca etat vayākhyānam iti āha iti iti
translated: This interpretation is also not in accordance with the words of the sutra, he says iti.

analyzed: iti kevala līlā eva nirṇītā prabhuṇā svayam
translated: Thus, mere sport alone has been determined by the Lord Himself.

original: yata evaṃkrīḍāṃ prayojanaṃ kṛtvā sṛṣṭiḥ śrutivirodhinī' /
analyzed: yatas evam krīḍām prayojanam kṛtvā sṛṣṭiḥ śruti virodhinī
translated: Since this is so, creation with sport as the purpose contradicts the Vedas.

original: iti tasmāt śrutyanusāriṇā prabhuṇā svayaṃ sākṣātsṛṣṭaṃ kevalalīlaiva sṛṣṭayādipravṛttirnirṇītā līlākaivalyamiti /
analyzed: iti tasmāt śruti anusāriṇā prabhuṇā svayam sākṣāt sṛṣṭam kevala līlā eva sṛṣṭayā ādi pravṛttiḥ nirṇītā līlā kaivalyam iti
translated: Therefore, by the Lord Himself, who follows the Vedas, it has been directly declared that the engagement in creation etc. is mere sport alone, called Lilakaivalya (the state of being mere sport).

analyzed: na tu līlā arthā iti
translated: But not for the sake of play. Therefore, this explanation is also inappropriate.

analyzed: yat vā pūrva vākya uktaḥ hetuḥ
translated: Or, the reason stated in the previous sentence is this.

analyzed: ayam sādhya nirdeśaḥ
translated: This is the statement of the conclusion.

original: yasmāllīlāṃ prayojanaṃ kṛtvā sṛṣṭiḥ śrutivirodhinī tasmādetatsūtre kevalalīlaiva sūtrakṛtā nirṇītā vyākhyātā na punarlīlārtheti / /
analyzed: yasmāt līlām prayojanam kṛtvā sṛṣṭiḥ śruti virodhinī tasmāt etad sūtre kevala līlā eva sūtra kṛtā nirṇītā vyākhyātā na punar līlā arthā iti
translated: Since creation is contrary to the scriptures when taken as having play as its purpose, therefore, in this aphorism, the author of the aphorism has determined and explained mere play alone, not for the sake of play.

analyzed: kiñca kartṛ tvena prayojanavat tām sādhayan āpādayan vā praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Moreover, one who establishes or refutes the purposelessness of creation by the argument of its being an act should be asked:

analyzed: kim prayojanam sva sambandhi vivakṣitam
translated: Is the purpose intended to be related to the creator himself,🔽or to others,

analyzed: uta para sambandhi  atha sādhāraṇam  ādye sādhane na aikāntyam  āpādane vyāpti abhāvaḥ
translated: or is it common?🔽If the first, the reason is inconclusive.🔽If the refutation, there is no pervasion.

analyzed: viparyaya paryavasāne vyabhicāraḥ eva
translated: If the opposite is concluded, there is simply an error.

original: dṛśyante hi kṛpālavaḥ svaprayojanamanuddiśya paraprayojanārthameva pravartamānāḥ /
analyzed: dṛśyante hi kṛpālavaḥ sva prayojanam an uddiśya para prayojana artham eva pravartamānāḥ
translated: For those who are compassionate are seen engaging for the sake of others' purposes without specifying their own purpose.

analyzed: na ca adṛṣṭa artham iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said to be for an unseen purpose.

analyzed: paśūnām paśu prāyāṇām ca apatya pālana ādau pravṛtti darśanāt
translated: For the activity of animals and those like animals is seen in the care of their offspring and so on.

analyzed: na ca prayojana uddeśi tā kṛpālu tā ca iti sambhavati
translated: And it is not possible that compassion is directed towards a purpose.

analyzed: dvitīye pi anaikāntya ādikam eva
translated: In the second case also, there is the same fallacy of inconclusiveness, etc.

analyzed: sva prayojana artham pravṛtteḥ bahulam upalambhāt
translated: Because it is often observed that [the Lord] acts for His own purpose.

original: bhagavato 'pi svaprayojanābhāve 'pi paraprayojanoddeśitāṅgīkāreṇa krameṇa siddhasādhaneṣyāpādanāsiddhatvaprasaṅgaṅgāśca /🔽ata eva na tṛtīyo 'pi /
analyzed: bhagavataḥ pi sva prayojana abhāve pi para prayojana uddeśita aṅgīkāreṇa krameṇa  atas eva na tṛtīyaḥ pi
translated: And even if the Lord has no purpose of His own, if it is accepted that He acts with the intention of others' purposes, then the fallacies of proving what is already established and the reason being unestablished would follow in due course.

analyzed: atas eva yena  kenacid kartṛ tva tve
translated: For this very reason, the third [alternative] is also not [acceptable].🔽For this very reason, [the objection] that the qualification [of being an agent] is by some [other] means,

original: viśeṣaṇaṃ / pravṛttisvabhāvatve sadā pravartetetyatiprasañjanaṃ ca pratyuktam / /
analyzed: viśeṣaṇam pravṛtti svabhāva tve sadā pravarteta iti atiprasañjanam ca pratyuktam
translated: and the over-extension [of the argument] that if [the Lord] has the nature of activity, He would always be active, is answered.

analyzed: syāt etat evam
translated: This might be so,

analyzed: yadi īśvara pravṛttau para prayojana uddeśaḥ syāt na ca asau aṅgīkartum ucitaḥ
translated: if the purpose of others were intended in the activity of God, but that cannot be accepted.

original: kā spṛhā na kāpīti śrutyā neti sūtrakāreṇa ca sarvathā prayojanoddeśasya nivāritatvādityata āha ātmeti //
analyzed: kā spṛhā na kā api iti śrutyā na iti sūtrakāreṇa ca sarvathā prayojana uddeśasya nivārita tvāt iti atas āha ātmā iti
translated: What is the desire? None at all. This is denied by the Śruti and by the author of the sūtra. Therefore, he says:

analyzed: ātma prayojana arthāya spṛhām śrutiḥ avārayat
translated: The Śruti denies desire for the purpose of one's own self.

analyzed: śrutiḥ iti sūtrakṛtā u pi upalakṣaṇam
translated: Śruti also indicates the author of the sūtra.

analyzed: para prayojana artha tām tu aṅgīkurute eva iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that [the author of the sūtra] does indeed accept the purpose of others.

analyzed: kutas etat avagamyate iti atas āha na iti
translated: From where is this understood? Therefore, he says no.

analyzed: na prayojanavat tvena iti atas āha jagadguruḥ
translated: Not by being purposeful. Therefore he says: the teacher of the world.

analyzed: yatas para prayojanam aṅgīkṛtya ātma prayojana artha tām eva na iti nyavārayat
translated: Because he rejected the very purposefulness for oneself, accepting the purposefulness for another.

original: ata eva hi prayojanavattvāditi tatra hetumāha anyathā naitaṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: atas eva hi prayojanavat tvāt iti tatra hetum āha anyathā na etam brūyāt
translated: For this very reason, he states the reason there as because it is purposeful, saying otherwise he would not say this.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: yadi neti sautrīpratijñā svaparaprayojanaviṣayā syāt tadā prayojanavattvāditi heturanaikāntikaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi na iti sautrī pratijñā sva para prayojana viṣayā syāt tadā prayojanavat tvāt iti hetuḥ anaikāntikaḥ syāt
translated: If the sutra's thesis not so were about the purpose for oneself and others, then the reason because it is purposeful would be inconclusive.

analyzed: svayam vyāpāra sādhya prayojanavataḥ pi para prayojana uddeśena vyāpāra darśanāt
translated: Because even one who has accomplished his own purpose is seen to act with the intention of another's purpose.

analyzed: sva prayojana mātra viṣaya tve tu na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: But if it is only about one's own purpose, this fault does not arise.

original: yo 'vāptayatprayojanaḥ sa svārthaṃ na taduddiśatīti vyāpteranavadyatvāt /
analyzed: yaḥ vā āpta yad prayojanaḥ sa sva artham na tat uddiśati iti vyāpteḥ anavadya tvāt
translated: Because the pervasion is faultless, that one who has attained his own purpose does not act with that as the object.

original: ataḥ prayojanavattvāditi hetuṃ brahmaṇaḥ sūtrakṛdātmaprayojanoddeśameva neti nivāritavān /
analyzed: atas prayojanavat tvāt iti hetum brahmaṇaḥ sūtrakṛt ātma prayojana uddeśam eva na iti nivāritavān
translated: Therefore, the author of the sutra, by stating the reason because it is purposeful, has rejected the very intention of one's own purpose for Brahman.

analyzed: na para prayojana uddeśam api
translated: Not even the intention of another's purpose.

analyzed: tathātve tad vayāptam eva kam api hetum brūyāt
translated: If it were so, he would state some reason pervaded by that.

analyzed: sva prayojana niṣedham kurvāṇaḥ viśeṣa niṣedhasya śeṣa abhyanujñā jñāpaka tvāt para prayojana spṛhām abhyupaiti iti manujānāti iti api
translated: One who denies his own purpose, because the prohibition of a particular thing indicates the permission of the rest, is understood to admit the desire for another's purpose.

analyzed: jñāyate iti
translated: It is also understood.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a mere indication.

original: śrutirapyāptakāmasyeti hetugarbhaviśeṣaṇaṃ prayuñjānā'tmaprayojanaspṛhāmevākṣipati paraprayojanaspṛhāmabhyupaitīti jñāyata ityapi draṣṭavyam
analyzed: śrutiḥ api āpta kāmasya iti hetu garbha viśeṣaṇam prayuñjānā ātma prayojana spṛhām eva ākṣipati para prayojana spṛhām abhyupaiti iti jñāyate iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: The Śruti also, using the qualification containing the reason of one who has attained his own purpose, is seen to imply the desire for one's own purpose, and is understood to admit the desire for another's purpose.

analyzed: iha hi buddhiḥ eva īśvarasya avyāhatā kriyāśaktiḥ
translated: Here, the intellect itself is the unobstructed power of action of God.

analyzed: tathā eva sarvasya upapattau kim icchā prayatna kalpanayā
translated: When everything is possible in that way, what is the use of assuming desire and effort?

analyzed: yat vā prayatnaḥ karta tvam
translated: Or, effort is the state of being an agent.

analyzed: tasya eva ākhyāta artha tayā nirṇīta tvāt  sa ca dvedhā buddhim apekṣate
translated: Because that itself has been determined as the meaning of the verb.

analyzed: utpatti artham viṣaya niyama artham ca
translated: And that is twofold: it requires intellect for origination and for the restriction of objects.

analyzed: tatra īśvara prayatnaḥ yadi api nitya tvāt na utpattau apekṣate buddhim
translated: Although God's effort, being eternal, does not require intellect for origination,

analyzed: tathā api viṣaya niyama artham tām apekṣate eva
translated: nevertheless, it does require intellect for the restriction of objects.

analyzed: na hi nirviṣayaḥ eva asau
translated: For it is not without an object,

analyzed: vyartha tva prasaṅgāt
translated: because that would lead to the absurdity of its being useless.

analyzed: na ca svabhāvataḥ eva artha pravaṇaḥ
translated: And it is not naturally inclined towards objects.

analyzed: buddhi tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would then be cognition.

analyzed: buddhiḥ eva hi svabhāvataḥ rtha pravaṇā
translated: For cognition alone is naturally inclined towards objects.

analyzed: atas jñāna prayatnābhyām eva sarva nirvāhāt na īśvarasya icchā asti
translated: Therefore, since everything is accomplished by knowledge and effort alone, there is no desire for God.

analyzed: na ca icchayā prayatnasya viṣaya niyamaḥ
translated: And the object of effort is not determined by desire.

analyzed: tasyāḥ api svatas viṣaya pravaṇa tā bhāvāt
translated: Because that also lacks natural inclination towards an object.

original: tadarthaṃ buddhayaṅgīkāre tayaiva prayatnasya viṣayaniyamopapatteḥ kimantargaḍunecchayeti manvānyamā
analyzed: tad artham buddhayaṅgīkāre tayā eva prayatnasya viṣaya niyama upapatteḥ kim antargaḍunā icchayā iti
translated: Thinking that the object of effort can be explained by cognition itself, what is the use of an internal desire?

analyzed: nāḥ kecitkā spṛhā
translated: Some think this way. What is the desire?

analyzed: śrutiḥ nā īśvarasya prayojana icchā mātra niṣedha parā
translated: Others explain that the statement does not aim to negate the mere desire for purpose of God.

analyzed: kintu icchā lakṣaṇam guṇam eva niṣedhati iti vyācakṣate
translated: But it negates the quality characterized as desire itself.

analyzed: tat nirākaroti icchā mātram iti
translated: He refutes that with mere desire etc.

analyzed: icchā mātram prabhoḥ sṛṣṭiḥ iti sṛṣṭau viniścitāḥ
translated: The wise are certain that mere desire of the Lord is creation.

analyzed: iti praśaṃsayā
translated: Thus, by praise...

analyzed: kā spṛhā iti śrutyā na īśvarasya icchā mātram niṣiṣedhyate
translated: By the statement what is the desire?, mere desire of God is not to be negated.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: icchāvat tvasya pramāṇataḥ siddha tvāt
translated: Because the state of having desire is established by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

analyzed: vibhūtim prasavam tu anye manyante sṛṣṭi cintakāḥ
translated: Others think that creation is the manifestation of the unmanifest.

analyzed: svapnam āyāsa rūpā iti sṛṣṭiḥ anyaiḥ vikalpitā
translated: Some imagine creation to be like a dream or an illusion.

analyzed: kālāt prasūtim bhūtānām manyante kāla cintakāḥ
translated: Those who think about time consider the birth of beings to be from time.

original: iti pariṇāmavādaṃ vivartavādaṃ kālādinimittavādaṃ cānyamatatvenoktvecchāmātramiti śrutyā svamatamucyate /🔽ye sṛṣṭiviṣaye viśiṣṭaniścayavantaste /
analyzed: iti pariṇāma vādam vivarta vādam kāla ādi nimitta vādam ca anya mata tvena uktvā icchā mātram iti śrutyā sva matam ucyate  ye sṛṣṭi viṣaye viśiṣṭa niścayavantaḥ te
translated: Thus, having stated the doctrine of evolution, the doctrine of manifestation, and the doctrine of time as the cause as the views of others, the scripture states its own view as mere will.

original: prabhoricchāmātrādhīnā sṛṣṭirna brahmapariṇāmo naca tadvivarto nāpi kālādinimitteti manyanta iti /
analyzed: prabhoḥ icchā mātra adhīnā sṛṣṭiḥ na brahma pariṇāmaḥ na ca tad vivartaḥ nā api kāla ādi nimittā iti manyante iti
translated: Those who have specific certainty regarding creation consider it to be dependent solely on the will of the Lord. It is not an evolution of Brahman, nor is it a manifestation of it, nor is it caused by time, etc.

original: anayā prabhoricchāmātrāyattatāṃ sṛṣṭermanyamānānāṃ viniścitā iti praśaṃsayā tasyecchāvattvamavagamyate /
analyzed: anayā prabhoḥ icchā mātra āyatta tām sṛṣṭeḥ manyamānānām viniścitāḥ iti praśaṃsayā tasya icchāvat tvam avagamyate
translated: By this praise of those who consider creation to be dependent solely on the will of the Lord as those who have specific certainty, it is understood that He possesses will.

original: yadīśvarasyecchā na syāt tadā tadāyattatāṃ sṛṣṭermanyamānā vipayarstāḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: yadi īśvarasya icchā na syāt tadā tad āyatta tām sṛṣṭeḥ manyamānāḥ syuḥ
translated: If there were no will of God, then those who consider creation to be dependent on that would be mistaken.

analyzed: viśiṣṭa niścayavantaḥ iti eṣā praśaṃsā anupapannā syāt
translated: And the praise those who have specific certainty would be inappropriate.

analyzed: na ca praśaṃsā tvāt eva artha asiddhiḥ
translated: And the establishment of the meaning is not just by the praise itself.

analyzed: pūrva uttara pakṣa avadhāraṇa prasaṅge praśaṃsā anupapannā syāt
translated: If there were no possibility of determining the prima facie view and the final view, praise would be impossible.

analyzed: na ca praśaṃsā tvāt eva artha asiddhiḥ
translated: And the establishment of the meaning is not just because of praise.
Because even praise must be in accordance with reality when there is the possibility of determining the prima facie view and the final view.

analyzed: anyathā pariṇāma ādi vādāḥ api praśaṃsyeran
translated: Otherwise, even the doctrines of transformation and so on would be praised.

analyzed: kāma śrutibhyaḥ ca eva  na kevalam śruta artha anupapattyā
translated: And also from the statements of desire.🔽Not only from the impossibility of the meaning of the scriptures.

analyzed: api tarhikāmaḥ tat agre sa marvatā adhi
translated: But rather, He desired in the beginning.

analyzed: sā u kāmayata
translated: He desired.

analyzed: ityādibhyaḥ bhagavataḥ kāma pratipādaka śrutibhyaḥ ca icchā avagamyate
translated: From these scriptures that teach the desire of the Lord, desire is understood.

analyzed: eva śabdaḥ śrutīnām arthāpattitaḥ prābalya sūcakaḥ
translated: The word eva (only) indicates the superiority of the scriptures over presumption.

analyzed: icchā kāma śabdayoḥ jñāna prayatna upalakṣaṇa tvasya sambhavāt na arthāpatti śrutibhyām icchā siddhiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the establishment of desire is not by presumption and scripture because it is possible that the words icchā (desire) and kāma (desire) denote knowledge and effort, it is not so.

analyzed: mukhye bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction in the primary meaning.

analyzed: yuktitaḥ
translated: By reasoning.

analyzed: mā vā saitsīt icchā rthāpatti śrutibhyām yuktitaḥ tāvat setsyati
translated: Whether or not it is desire, it will be established by reasoning.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ icchāvān ātma tvāt yajñadatta vat
translated: God has desire because He is the Self, like Yajñadatta.

analyzed: na ca mukta ādau vyabhicāraḥ
translated: And there is no fallacy in the case of a gem, etc.

analyzed: tatra api tasyāḥ sādhayiṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: For even there, that [causation] is to be established.

analyzed: jñānavat tvāt  prayatnavat tvāt
translated: Because of having knowledge.🔽Because of having effort.

analyzed: kartṛ tvāt vā
translated: Or because of being an agent.

analyzed: īśvara jñānam vā icchā samāna āśrayam jñāna tvāt asmat ādi jñāna vat
translated: The knowledge of God has the same substratum as will, because it is knowledge, like my own knowledge.

analyzed: evam tad prayatnam api pakṣīkṛtya prayoktavyam
translated: In the same way, His effort should be taken as the subject and used [in an inference].

analyzed: yat vā kṣiti ādikam icchāvat janyam kāryatvāt ghaṭa vat
translated: Or, the earth, etc. are produced by will, because they are effects, like a pot.

original: nanvevaṃ duḥkhādikamapi sādhayituṃ śakyamiti cettatkimatiprasaṅgabhīruṇā kṣityāderbuddhimatkāraṇakatvānumānamapi tyakṣyate /
analyzed: nanu evam duḥkha ādikam api sādhayitum śakyam iti ced tat kim atiprasaṅga bhīruṇā kṣiti ādeḥ buddhimat kāraṇakatva anumānam api tyakṣyate
translated: If it is argued that in this way suffering, etc. can also be established, then will the inference of the earth, etc. being produced by an intelligent cause also be abandoned out of fear of over-extension?

original: duḥkhādisādhane bādho 'sti na buddhisādhana iti cet /
analyzed: duḥkha ādi sādhane bādhaḥ sti na buddhi sādhane iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there is contradiction in establishing suffering, etc., but not in establishing intelligence,

analyzed: samam prakṛte pi
translated: it is the same in the present case as well.

analyzed: mahā tātparya yukteḥ ca
translated: And because of the great purposefulness [of the Vedas].

analyzed: nanu īśvarasya icchā abhāve bādhaka abhāvāt aprayojaka tvam anumānānām iti
translated: If there were no will of God, the inferences would be unjustifiable because there would be no contradiction.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

original: mahātātparyayukteśca /🔽yadīśvarasya icchā na syāt tadā tasminsarvavedānāṃ vedāntānāṃ
analyzed: mahā tātparya yukteḥ ca  yadi īśvarasya icchā na syāt tadā tasmin sarva vedānām vedāntānām
translated: And because of the great purposefulness [of the Vedas].🔽If there were no will of God, then there would be no great purpose of all the Vedas and the Vedānta

analyzed: mahā tātparyam na syāt iti bādhaka sadbhāvāt
translated: in Him. Therefore, because there is a contradiction, [the inferences are not unjustifiable].

analyzed: icchā niṣprayojanā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that desire is purposeless,

analyzed: syāt evam yadi prayojanam anurudhya kalpyate
translated: it would be so if a purpose were assumed to be served.

analyzed: anyatas siddhe rthe kim prayojana gaveṣaṇayā
translated: But when the meaning is established elsewhere, what is the use of searching for a purpose?

analyzed: na icchā mātram
translated: Mere desire is not prohibited.

analyzed: kiñca evam sati buddhiḥ api nā aṅgīkaraṇīyā
translated: Moreover, if this is so, even cognition should not be accepted.

analyzed: svarūpa sāmarthyena eva īśvarasya kartṛ tva upapatteḥ  loka vairūpyam iti ced
translated: Because the agency of God is logically possible by the inherent power of his nature.🔽If it is argued that this is contrary to worldly usage,

analyzed: tat kim udāsīnasya boddhuḥ kartṛ tvam upalabdham loke  yena an icchataḥ tat īśvarasya aṅgīkriyate
translated: then is the agency of a neutral cognizer observed in the world?🔽By which the agency of God, even though unwilling, is accepted.

analyzed: prayatnavataḥ eva vā kartṛ tvam bhaviṣyati
translated: Or the agency will be only of one who has effort.

analyzed: tasya viṣaya niyama artham buddhiḥ eṣya vyeti ced na
translated: If it is argued that cognition should be accepted for the purpose of restricting its object, it is not so.

analyzed: buddhi vat svatas viṣaya pravaṇa tā upapatteḥ
translated: Because the inclination towards an object is logically possible by itself, like cognition.

original: tathātve buddhito bhedo na syāditi cenna buddhitvādinaiva tadupapatteḥ /
analyzed: tathātve buddhitaḥ bhedaḥ na syāt iti ced na buddhi tva ādinā eva tad upapatteḥ
translated: If it is argued that in that case there would be no difference from cognition, it is not so, because that is logically possible by cognition itself.

original: anyathā paropādhikaviṣayapravaṇatvayoricchāprayatnayorapi bhedā na syāt /🔽viṣayaniyamārthamiti ca ko 'rthaḥ /
analyzed: anyathā para upādhika viṣaya pravaṇa tvayoḥ icchā prayatnayoḥ api bhedāḥ na syāt  viṣaya niyama artham iti ca kaḥ rthaḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be no difference even between desire and effort, which have the inclination towards objects that are adventitious to them.🔽And what is the meaning of for the purpose of restricting the object?

analyzed: kim viṣaya viśeṣa sambaddha tayā utpādānār
translated: Does it mean producing in association with a particular object?

analyzed: tham uta utpannasya sthitasya eva vā tad sambandha artham
translated: Or for the purpose of the connection of that with what is produced or what exists.

analyzed: atha tad jñāna artham
translated: Or for the purpose of knowing that.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: anādi tvāt
translated: Because of beginninglessness.

analyzed: sa ādi tve pi kakā  raṇasā apekṣata
translated: Even if there were a beginning,🔽because of the dependence on a cause,

analyzed: yā buddheḥ api paratas viṣaya pravaṇa tā āpatteḥ
translated: the mind also becomes inclined towards an external object.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: paurvāparyaḥ bhāvāt
translated: Because of the absence of sequence.

original: nahi prayatnaḥ utpādya sthitvā vā paścādviṣayeṇa sambaddhayate /
analyzed: nahi prayatnaḥ utpādya sthitvā vā paścāt viṣayeṇa sambaddhayate
translated: For effort is not produced, nor does it remain connected with the object later.

analyzed: na tṛtīyaḥ
translated: Not the third.

analyzed: svarūpa grāhaka pramāṇena eka tad grahaṇāt
translated: Because the cognition of that is by a means of knowledge that grasps its own form.

analyzed: buddheḥ api para apekṣā prasaṅgāt ca iti  mahā tātparya yukteḥ ca iti yat uktam tat asat
translated: And because it would follow that the mind also depends on something else.🔽And what was said about the great purport being due to the great purpose of the scriptures, that is not so.

original: yadīśvaro necchāvānsyāttadā śrutimahātātparyaviṣayo na syādityatra vyāptyabhāvāt /
analyzed: yadi īśvaraḥ na icchāvān syāt tadā śruti mahā tātparya viṣayaḥ na syāt iti atra vyāpti abhāvāt
translated: If God were not a desirer, then He would not be the object of the great purpose of the scriptures. Because there is no pervasion here.

analyzed: icchā rahitasya api dharma ādeḥ tad tad śāstra mahā tātparya viṣaya tva darśanāt
translated: Because even one devoid of desire, such as Dharma, is seen to be the object of the great purpose of those scriptures.

analyzed: āpādyasya aniṣṭa tva abhāvāt ca iti atas uktam vivṛṇoti mokṣa arthāḥ iti
translated: And because what is to be inferred is not undesirable. In order to explain this, he says having the purpose of liberation and so on.

original: mokṣārthāḥ śrutayo yasmāt sa ca tasya prasādataḥ /
analyzed: mokṣa arthāḥ śrutayaḥ yasmāt sa ca tasya prasādataḥ
translated: The scriptures have the purpose of liberation, because that [liberation] is by His grace.

analyzed: unninīṣati vākyāt ca loka dṛṣṭa anusārataḥ
translated: And from the statement of Unninīṣati, in accordance with worldly experience.

analyzed: icchāṃnimittakaḥ yasmāt tad abhāve kutas śrutiḥ
translated: Because desire is the cause, how can there be a Vedic text without it?

analyzed: mahā tātparya rahitā pramāṇa tvam gamiṣyati
translated: It will not attain the status of a means of valid knowledge, being devoid of great purpose.

original: yasmātkāraṇātsarvā api śrutayo mokṣārthāḥ mokṣaprayojanāstasmāttadabhāve parameśvarasyecchābhāve tata eva mokṣārthatābhāve śrutistatra mahātātparyarahitā 🔽syāt /
analyzed: yasmāt kāraṇāt sarvāḥ api śrutayaḥ mokṣa arthāḥ mokṣa prayojanāḥ tasmāt tad abhāve parameśvarasya icchā bhāve tatas eva mokṣa artha tā bhāve śrutiḥ tatra mahā tātparya rahitā  syāt
translated: Since all the Vedic texts are for the sake of liberation, for the purpose of liberation, therefore, in the absence of that, in the absence of the Supreme Lord's desire, in the absence of that itself, the purpose of liberation, the Vedic text would be devoid of great purpose there.

analyzed: tathā ca katham pramāṇa tvam gamiṣyati iti yojanā
translated: And how will it attain the status of a means of valid knowledge? This is the construction.

analyzed: mokṣa artha tve kim īśvarasya icchayā iti atas uktam sa ca iti
translated: If it is for the sake of liberation, what is the use of the Lord's desire? To this it is said: sa ca (and that).

original: sa ca mokṣastasya īśvarasya prasādato yasmāttasmāttadabhāva iti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca mokṣaḥ tasya īśvarasya prasādataḥ yasmāt tasmāt tad abhāvaḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: And that liberation is from the grace of that Lord. Since that is so, therefore, in the absence of that, the connection is with the absence of that.

original: tathāpīśvarasya prasādena bhāvyaṃ kimicchayetyata prasādata ityetadvayākhyātam icchānimittaka iti //
analyzed: tathā api īśvarasya prasādena bhāvyam kim icchayā iti ata prasādataḥ iti etat vayākhyātam icchā nimittakaḥ iti
translated: Even so, the grace of the Lord must be there. What is the use of desire? To this, prasādāt (from grace) is explained as icchānimittaka (caused by desire).

original: īśvarajñānādeva mokṣasiddheḥ kiṃ tatprasādenetyata uktam loketi //
analyzed: īśvara jñānāt eva mokṣa siddheḥ kim tad prasādena iti atas uktam loka iti
translated: Since liberation is accomplished only by the knowledge of the Lord, what is the use of His grace? To this it is said: loke (in the world).

original: vimato bandhamokṣaḥ prabhuprasādasādhyo mokṣatvāt śṛṅkhalāmokṣavat ityādilokadṛṣṭavyāptyupetānumānānusārataḥ ityatharḥ /
analyzed: vimataḥ bandha mokṣaḥ prabhu prasāda sādhyaḥ mokṣa tvāt śṛṅkhalā mokṣa vat ityādi loka dṛṣṭa vyāpti upeta anumāna anusārataḥ iti atharḥ
translated: The meaning is: The bondage and liberation of the one under consideration are to be accomplished by the grace of the Lord, because they are liberation, like the liberation from chains. In accordance with inference based on the pervasion observed in the world.

analyzed: na kevalam anumānāt kintu āgamāt api iti uktam unninīṣati iti
translated: It is said that not only from inference, but also from scripture. Thus it is said Unninīṣati (desires to lead upwards).

analyzed: eṣa hi eṣa sādhu karma kārayati tam
translated: For this one indeed makes him do good deeds,

analyzed: yamebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ unninīṣate
translated: whom he desires to lead upwards from these worlds.

analyzed: iti vākyāt ca
translated: And from this sentence.

analyzed: atra karma iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: Here action is a mere indication.

analyzed: unninīṣate ūrdhvam netum icchati
translated: Unninīṣate means desires to lead upwards.

original: yadvā prasādaśabdenecchocyate ityata idaṃ vākyaṃ vākyametat jñāpakam /
analyzed: yat vā prasāda śabdena icchā ucyate iti atas idam vākyam vākyam etat jñāpakam
translated: Or, since grace is said to be desire, this sentence is an indicator.

analyzed: loka dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa  nusārataḥ iti etat api asya eva arthasya jñāpakam uktam
translated: In accordance with what is observed in the world.🔽This is also said to be an indicator of this very meaning.

analyzed: śrutayaḥ iti upakramya śrutiḥ iti ekavacanam kaimutya artham
translated: Having begun with the Vedas, the singular śruti is used for the sake of emphasis.

analyzed: ekam api vākyam na tatra mahā tātparyavat syāt
translated: Even a single sentence would not have such great importance there.

analyzed: kim uta sarvāḥ śrutayaḥ iti
translated: How much less so all the Vedas?

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: śāstram hi sādhya sādhana bhāvavat viṣaya prayojanavat tayā vyāptam
translated: For the scriptures are pervaded by having an object and purpose that have the nature of means and ends.

analyzed: tatra śrutīnām mokṣaḥ eva prayojanam
translated: Among them, liberation alone is the purpose of the Vedas.

analyzed: teṣām duḥkha prahāṇāya śrutiḥ eṣā pravartate
translated: For the cessation of their suffering, this scripture proceeds.

analyzed: iti vacanāt
translated: Thus it is said.

analyzed: mokṣāt anyatra ātyantika duḥkha prahāṇa ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible to completely abandon suffering anywhere else than in liberation.

analyzed: svarga ādi prayojanam bhavat api avāntaram eva na pradhānam
translated: Even if the purpose is heaven etc., that is only secondary, not primary.

analyzed: viṣayaḥ tu parameśvaraḥ eva
translated: But the object is the Supreme Lord Himself.

analyzed: sarve vedāḥ yat padam āmananti
translated: All the Vedas proclaim that one state.

analyzed: iti ādi vacanāt
translated: Thus it is said.

analyzed: dharma ādikam tu avāntara pratipādyam
translated: But dharma etc. are the secondary subjects.

analyzed: abhipreta prayojana sādhanam ca viṣaya tām aśnute
translated: And that which is the means of attaining the desired purpose becomes the object.

analyzed: na ca dharma ādikam mokṣa sādhanam
translated: And dharma etc. are not the means of attaining liberation.

analyzed: puṇya citaḥ lokaḥ kṣīyate iti śruteḥ
translated: The world of the virtuous perishes. Thus it is heard.

analyzed: atas bhagavati eva mokṣa sādhana tvāt savar śrutīnām mahā tātparyam
translated: Therefore, in the Supreme Lord alone, because He is the means of attaining liberation, the great purport of all the scriptures lies.

analyzed: na ca avyāpṛtāt sādhanāt phala siddhiḥ
translated: And the result is not accomplished from a means that is not engaged.

analyzed: vyāpāraḥ ca prasādaḥ eva
translated: And the engagement is only grace.

analyzed: na tu śruti janitam tad jñāna sākṣātkāraḥ vā
translated: But not the knowledge produced by the scriptures or the direct realization of that.

analyzed: yasya prasādāt
translated: By whose grace.

analyzed: ityādi vākyāt ukta anumānāt ca
translated: Thus it is said. And because of the stated inference.

analyzed: jñānam tu prasāda sādhanam iti na sambandha anupapattiḥ
translated: But knowledge is the means of attaining grace. Thus there is no inconsistency in the relation.
Grace is a particular kind of desire.

original: tathā satiunninīṣate'tadicchayā yato hyasya bandhamokṣau pratiṣṭhitau' /🔽ityādiśrutibhiḥyasya prasādāt' /🔽iti śruteraikārthyalābhāt /🔽prasanno 'smīti pratītau paropacikīrṣāyā eva sphuraṇāt /
analyzed: tathā sati unninīṣata itad icchayā yatas hi asya bandha mokṣau pratiṣṭhitau  ityādi śrutibhiḥ yasya prasādāt  iti śruteḥ aikārthya lābhāt  prasannaḥ smi iti pratītau para upacikīrṣāyāḥ eva sphuraṇāt
translated: If that is so, then by the statements of the Upanisads, such as, 'He who desires to attain the Unmanifest, by His will, for in Him are established the bondage and liberation of all' (Svet. 6. 19),🔽and by the statement, 'By whose grace' (Svet. 6. 23),🔽there is the gain of the oneness of meaning.🔽And when there is the feeling, 'I am pleased', there is the manifestation of the desire to help others.

original: tathāca yadīśvaro necchāvāṃstadā na prasidedghaṭavat /🔽sāmānyābhāve viśeṣābhāvaniyamāt /🔽prasādarahitaśca na mokṣasādhanaṃ syāt /🔽yadyatra vivakṣitāvāntaravyāpārarahitaṃ na tattatra sādhanamiti vyāpteḥ /🔽mokṣaṃ pratyasādhanaṃ ca na mokṣaśāstramahātātparyaviṣayaḥ syāt /🔽tathāca mokṣaprayojanatā śrutīnāṃ hīyeta /🔽naca viṣayāntaraṃ prayojanāntaraṃ cāstīti viṣayaprayojanaśūnyatvādaprāmāṇyamevāpadyeta /🔽naca tadapauruṣeyatāyānāśaṅkitadoṣasya vākyasyopapadyate /
analyzed: tathā ca yadi īśvaraḥ na icchāvān tadā na prasidet ghaṭa vat 🔽sāmānya abhāve viśeṣa abhāva niyamāt 🔽prasāda rahitaḥ ca na mokṣa sādhanam syāt 🔽yat yatra vivakṣita avāntara vyāpāra rahitam na tat tatra sādhanam iti vyāpteḥ 🔽mokṣam prati asādhanam ca na mokṣa śāstra mahā tātparya viṣayaḥ syāt 🔽tathā ca mokṣa prayojana tā śrutīnām hīyeta 🔽na ca viṣaya antaram prayojana antaram ca asti iti viṣaya prayojana śūnya tvāt aprāmāṇyam eva āpadyeta 🔽na ca tat apauruṣeya tāyai an āśaṅkita doṣasya vākyasya upapadyate

analyzed: atas vaśyam uktena krameṇa icchāvat tvam bhagavataḥ ṅgīkaraṇīyam iti
translated: Therefore, the Lord's possession of desire must necessarily be accepted in the order stated.

analyzed: nanu viṣaya abhāve syāt aprāmāṇyam
translated: But if there is no object, there would be invalidity.

analyzed: phala abhāve tu katham aprāmāṇya āpādanam
translated: But how can invalidity be entailed if there is no result?

analyzed: nahi phalavat tvam prāmāṇyam
translated: For validity does not consist in having a result.

analyzed: kintu yāthārthyam eva iti uktam
translated: But rather in being in accordance with reality, as has been stated.

original: nāpi prāmāṇyasya vyāpakam /🔽tṛṇādidarśanasya prayojanābhāve 'pi prāmāṇyābhyupagamādityata āha yāthārthyameveti // /🔽yāthārthyameva mānatvamapi vākyaṃ prayojakam /
analyzed: nā api prāmāṇyasya vyāpakam  tṛṇa ādi darśanasya prayojana abhāve pi prāmāṇya abhyupagamāt iti atas āha yāthārthyam eva iti  yāthārthyam eva māna tvam api vākyam prayojakam
translated: Nor is it pervaded by [having a result].🔽Because even the seeing of grass etc. is accepted as valid even when there is no purpose, therefore it is said: Being in accordance with reality alone is validity, and a statement is the cause of validity.

analyzed: māna tvam eti
translated: Being in accordance with reality alone is validity, and a statement is the cause of validity.

analyzed: yadi api yāthārthyam eva mānatvam na phalavattvam
translated: Even though being in accordance with reality alone is validity, not having a result,

analyzed: na api tena vyāptam
translated: and it is not pervaded by that,

analyzed: tathā api vākyam prayojakam eva mānatvam eti iti yuktam āpādanam
translated: nevertheless, it is proper to draw the conclusion that a statement is the cause of validity.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati /🔽prāmāṇyamātrasya prayojanavattvena vyāptyabhāve 'pi tadviśeṣasya vākyaprāmāṇyasyāstyeva /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  prāmāṇya mātrasya prayojanavat tvena vyāpti abhāve pi tad viśeṣasya vākya prāmāṇyasya asti eva
translated: This is what is being said.🔽Even though the mere validity is not pervaded by having a purpose, that particular case of validity, namely the validity of a statement, does exist.

analyzed: padānām iṣya sādhane eva gṛhīta saṅgatika tvāt
translated: Because the connection of the words is understood only in what is to be accomplished.

analyzed: pada saṅgati grahaṇa savyapekṣasya eva vākyasya bodhaka tvāt
translated: Because a sentence is expressive only in dependence on the apprehension of the connection of words.

analyzed: phalasya viṣaya viśeṣe vākya prāmāṇya nirṇaya hetu tvāt ca
translated: And because the result is the cause of determining the validity of a sentence with regard to a particular object.

original: ato vyāpakābhāve vyāpyavākyaprāmāṇyābhāvāpādanamupapannameveti / /🔽nanu ca mahātātparyagocarasya viṣayasya paramaprayojanasya cābhāve 'pyavāntaraviṣayeṇa
analyzed: atas vyāpaka abhāve vyāpya vākya prāmāṇya abhāva āpādanam upapannam eva iti  nanu ca mahā tātparya gocarasya viṣayasya parama prayojanasya ca abhāve pi avāntaraviṣayeṇa
translated: Therefore, the consequence that when the pervader is absent, the pervaded sentence cannot be valid, is indeed reasonable.🔽But even if there is no object or supreme purpose which is the sphere of the great purpose, the Veda will be a means of valid knowledge with regard to its object and purpose by means of the secondary object

original: dharmādināpradhānaprayojanena ca svargādinā viṣayaprayojanavatī śrutiḥ pramāṇaṃ bhaviṣyati🔽ityata āha tatrāpīti //🔽tatrāpi yat sampūrṇaprayojanam // / / //
analyzed: dharma ādinā a pradhāna prayojanena ca svarga ādinā viṣaya prayojanavatī śrutiḥ pramāṇam bhaviṣyati  iti atas āha tatra api iti  tatra api yat sampūrṇa prayojanam
translated: such as Dharma, and the subsidiary purpose such as heaven.🔽To this he says: Even in that case, that which has a complete purpose...

analyzed: vākye pi nirdhāraṇe saptamī
translated: In that sentence also, the locative case is used in the sense of determination.

analyzed: prayojanavat tve pi iti vā
translated: Or it may mean even when it has a purpose.

analyzed: yat vākyam sampūrṇa prayojanam mahā prayojanam
translated: That sentence which has a complete purpose, a great purpose,

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: and this is an indication.

analyzed: pradhāna viṣayam ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen as having a primary object.

analyzed: yat iti śravaṇāt tat iti labhyate  sampūrṇa prayojanam iti ca āvartanīyam
translated: Since the word 'yat' is heard, 'tat' is understood.🔽And 'having a complete purpose' should be repeated.

analyzed: māna tvam eti iti anuvartanīyam
translated: And 'becomes a means of valid knowledge' should be continued.

analyzed: tathā ca ayam arthaḥ
translated: And the meaning is this:

analyzed: na avāntara viṣaya prayojanābhyām vākyasya prāmāṇyam sambhavati
translated: Nor is the authoritativeness of a sentence possible through an intermediate object or purpose.

analyzed: kinnāma yat vākyam yat mahā
translated: What indeed is the sentence that, with reference to a great🔽purpose, is engaged in conveying a principal object, that, by those very

original: hatprayojanamuddiśya yaṃ pradhānaṃ viṣayaṃ pratipādayituṃ pravṛttaṃ tattābhyāṃeva🔽prayojanaviṣaṭābhyāmupetaṃ prāmāṇyamaśnute /
analyzed: hat prayojanam uddiśya yam pradhānam viṣayam pratipādayitum pravṛttam tat tābhyām eva  prayojana viṣaṭābhyām upetam prāmāṇyam aśnute
translated: two, the purpose and the object, attains authoritativeness.

analyzed: tad abhāve vā antara prayojana ādeḥ api asiddheḥ
translated: In the absence of that, even an intermediate purpose and so on are not established.

analyzed: siddhau vā vā tasya eva prādhānya prāpteḥ
translated: If established, then that itself becomes principal.

analyzed: veda vākyam ca mokṣa uddeśena mahā tatparya upetam iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that the Vedic sentence, with reference to liberation, is endowed with a great purpose.

analyzed: tat tayoḥ eva viṣaya prayojanayoḥ upapattau pramāṇam syāt na anyathā iti
translated: That, by the establishment of those two alone, the object and the purpose, would be authoritative, not otherwise.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām na prayojana adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on purpose in the commentary called Naya-sudha.

analyzed: vaiṣamya nairghṛṇya adhikaraṇam
translated: X. The chapter on inequality and cruelty.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām vaiṣamya nairghṛṇya adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the commentary called Naya-sudha, the chapter on inequality and cruelty.

original: oṃ vaiṣamyanairghṛṇye na sāpekṣatvāttathā hi darśayati oṃ //
analyzed: om vaiṣamya nairghṛṇye na sāpekṣa tvāt tathā hi darśayati om
translated: Om. Inequality and cruelty are not, because of dependence. Thus it is shown.

analyzed: prāṇinām
translated: The various bodies, senses, etc. of living beings,

original: viṣayāṃstatphalaṃ ca sukhaduḥkhalakṣaṇamutpādayannīśvaraḥ kiṃ tadīyaṃ dharmādharmarūpaṃ karmāpekṣate na vā /
analyzed: viṣayān tad phalam ca sukha duḥkha lakṣaṇam utpādayan īśvaraḥ kim tadīyam dharma adharma rūpam karma apekṣate na vā
translated: Does God, producing the objects of sense and their fruits, pleasure and pain, have regard to the merit and demerit of the individual, or not?

original: ādye tasya svātantryapracyutiḥ /🔽dvitīye nirnimittaṃ kāṃścitsukhayanviṣamaḥ syāt /
analyzed: ādye tasya svātantrya pracyutiḥ  dvitīye nirnimittam kāṃścid sukhayan viṣamaḥ syāt
translated: If the first, then he loses his independence.🔽If the second, then he would be partial, causing pleasure to some without reason,

analyzed: kāṃścid duḥkhayan nirghṛṇaḥ syāt
translated: and he would be merciless, causing pain to some without reason.

analyzed: iti ubhayathā na tasya sarva kartṛ tvam iti eṣava  pūrvapakṣaḥ tra adhikaraṇe nirākriyate
translated: Thus, in either case, he is not the creator of all. This is the prima facie view.🔽It is refuted in this section.

original: tatra tāvadādyena sūtreṇa karmādisāpekṣasya kartṛtvamabhyupetya vaiṣamyanairghaṇye parihṛte /
analyzed: tatra tāvat ādyena sūtreṇa karma ādi sāpekṣasya kartṛ tvam abhyupetya vaiṣamya nairghaṇye parihṛte
translated: There, first, by the first aphorism, having accepted the creator's dependence on merit, etc., the inequality and mercilessness are refuted.

analyzed: apekṣaṇīyam karma ādi īśvara āyattam na vā
translated: Is the merit, etc., to be taken into account dependent on God or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe sarva kāraṇatva hāniḥ
translated: If not, then the doctrine of his being the cause of all is lost.

original: ādye nirnimittaṃ viṣamāṇāṃ karmaṇāṃ kārayiturvaiṣamyanairghṛṇye syātāmityākṣipya karmādīnāmanāditātvā
analyzed: ādye nirnimittam viṣamāṇām karmaṇām kārayituḥ vaiṣamya nairghṛṇye syātām iti ākṣipya karma ādīnām anāditā tvā
translated: If the first, then the creator, causing unequal actions without reason, would be partial and merciless. This being objected to, the solution is stated by accepting the beginninglessness of merit, etc.,

analyzed: abhyupagamena samādhānam uktam na karma avibhāgāt iti ced na anādi tvāt
translated: in the aphorism If it be said that it is not so, because merit is not divided, no; because of beginninglessness.

analyzed: iti sūtreṇa
translated: By this aphorism.

original: evaṃ tarhi karmādisāpekṣasya svātantryaṃ na syādityāśaṅkayoktamupapadyate ceti /
analyzed: evam tarhi karma ādi sāpekṣasya svātantryam na syāt iti āśaṅkayā uktam upapadyate ca iti
translated: If it is so, then the independence of God, who is dependent on action etc., will not be possible. To remove this doubt, it is said that it is logically possible.

analyzed: karma ādi apekṣasya api tasya svātantryam upapadyate
translated: Even though dependent on action etc., His independence is logically possible.

analyzed: karma ādi sattā ādeḥ api tad adhīna tvasya ārambhaṇa adhikaraṇe samarthita tvāt
translated: Because in the Adhikaraṇa on Creation, it has been established that the existence etc. of action etc. are also dependent on Him.

analyzed: nahi svādhīna sattā ādikam apekṣamāṇasya svātantrya pracyutiḥ yuktā iti
translated: For one who is dependent on existence etc. that are under His control, it is not proper to lose His independence.

analyzed: evam ca tarhi tad apekṣā nāma anapekṣā eva
translated: If it is so, then dependence on that is itself non-dependence.

analyzed: tathā ca punar vaiṣamya ādi āpattiḥ iti āśaṅkayā uktam upalabhyate ca iti
translated: And in that case, the objection of inequality etc. arises again. To remove this doubt, it is said that it is perceived.

analyzed: upalabhyate hi ice
translated: For it is perceived that

analyzed: śvarasya īdṛśam vaiṣamyam nirghṛṇa tvam ca pramāṇaiḥ
translated: such inequality and cruelty of God are established by proofs.

analyzed: atas na idam aniṣyam iti
translated: Therefore, this is not undesirable.

analyzed: tat idam ayuktam
translated: This is improper.

original: vaiṣamyanairghṛṇye hi vastuto dūṣaṇe na vā /
analyzed: vaiṣamya nairghṛṇye hi vastutas dūṣaṇe na vā
translated: For inequality and cruelty are either really faults or not.

analyzed: ādye katham antatas pi aṅgīkriyete
translated: If the first, how can they be accepted even at the end?

analyzed: dvitīye prathamam eva aṅgīkārye
translated: If the second, they should be accepted first itself.

analyzed: kim sāpekṣa tā pakṣam kakṣīkṛtya tatra dūṣaṇa parihāra kleśena
translated: What is the use of taking the side of dependence and then making the effort to refute and accept the faults there?

analyzed: tathā ca bakabandhaka
translated: And in that case, it is like the story of the crane and the snake.

analyzed: rītiḥ iti atas bhiprāyam āha vaiṣamyam iti
translated: Therefore, he states the intention with disparity.🔽🔽

original: vaiṣamyanairghṛṇye na sāpekṣatvāt tathā hi darśayati / / / /🔽vaiṣamyaṃ caiva nairghṛṇyaṃ vedāprāmāṇyakāraṇam /
analyzed: vaiṣamya nairghṛṇye na sāpekṣa tvāt tathā hi darśayati  vaiṣamyam ca eva nairghṛṇyam veda aprāmāṇya kāraṇam
translated: To this, the author replies: The inequality and cruelty are not the causes of the unreliability of the Veda, because it shows otherwise.🔽Inequality and cruelty are not the causes of the unreliability of the Veda.

analyzed: na aṅgīkāryam atas na vaiṣamya ādi nāmakam
translated: Therefore, anything else that is called inequality, etc., should not be accepted.

original: dvividhaṃ khalvidaṃ vaiṣamyaṃ nirghṛṇatvaṃ ca /🔽ekaṃ dhakarmādyanapekṣatāprayuktam /
analyzed: dvividham khalu idam vaiṣamyam nirghṛṇa tvam ca  ekam dha karma ādi an apekṣa tā prayuktam
translated: Indeed, this inequality and cruelty are of two kinds.🔽One is due to independence from karma, etc.

analyzed: aparam tu sāpekṣa tve pi karma ādi sattā ādeḥ api īśvara adhīnatva prayuktam
translated: But the other is due to the dependence of the existence, etc., of karma on God, even though there is dependence.

analyzed: tatra ādyam veda aprāmāṇya kāraṇatvena dūṣaṇa tvāt na īśvarasya aṅgīkartum ucitam
translated: Among them, the first is not proper to be accepted as belonging to God, because it is a fault as the cause of the unreliability of the Veda.

original: vedo hi dharmaṃ sukhasādhanamadharmaṃ ca duḥkhasādhanamāha /
analyzed: vedaḥ hi dharmam sukha sādhanam adharmam ca duḥkha sādhanam āha
translated: For the Veda declares that dharma is the means of attaining happiness and adharma is the means of attaining suffering.

original: tatra yadīśvaro dharmādharmānapekṣya viṣamo nirghṛṇaśca syāt tadā vedoditaṃ dharmādharmayoḥ sukhaduḥkhasādhanatvamasatsyāt /
analyzed: tatra yadi īśvaraḥ dharma adharmān apekṣya viṣamaḥ nirghṛṇaḥ ca syāt tadā veda uditam dharma adharmayoḥ sukha duḥkha sādhanatvam asat syāt
translated: If God were unequal and cruel, disregarding dharma and adharma, then the statement in the Veda that dharma and adharma are the means of attaining happiness and suffering would be false.

analyzed: tathā ca tasya katham prāmāṇyam syāt
translated: And how could that be reliable in that case?

analyzed: atas sūtrakāreṇa karma ādi sāpekṣa tā pakṣam urarīkṛtya tat parihṛtam
translated: Therefore, the author of the aphorisms has accepted the view that God is dependent on actions etc., and has refuted that.

original: ato 'nyattu dvitīyaṃ vaiṣamyaṃ nairghṛṇyaṃ ca na vaiṣamyādināmakaṃ dūṣaṇarūpaṃ na bhavatīti yāvat /
analyzed: atas nyat tu dvitīyam vaiṣamyam nairghṛṇyam ca na vaiṣamya ādi nāmakam dūṣaṇa rūpam na bhavati iti yāvat
translated: But the second inequality and cruelty are not the fault called inequality etc. This is the meaning.

original: tathāhi vaiṣamyādikaṃ tāvanna svarūpeṇa doṣaḥ kintu doṣahetutayā /
analyzed: tathā hi vaiṣamya ādikam tāvat na svarūpeṇa doṣaḥ kintu doṣa hetutayā
translated: For, inequality etc. are not faults in themselves, but as causes of faults.

analyzed: na ca idam veda aprāmāṇya kāraṇam
translated: And this is not a cause of the invalidity of the Veda.
Because dependence on actions etc. is accepted.

analyzed: nā api jīvānām iva īśvarasya pratyavāya hetuḥ
translated: Nor is it a cause of misfortune for God, as it is for individual souls.

analyzed: tad abhāvāt
translated: Because that is absent.

analyzed: atas dūṣaṇa tvāt aṅgīkṛtam sūtrakṛtā iti na kaścid doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, because it is not a fault, it is accepted by the author of the aphorisms. Thus there is no fault.

analyzed: tathā ca bhāgyam
translated: And so it is fortunate.

analyzed: na ca punar vaiṣamya ādi āpātena doṣaḥ iti
translated: And there is no fault due to the occurrence of inequality etc. again.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām vaiṣamya nairghṛṇya adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Inequality and Cruelty in the commentary called 'Naya-sudha'.
XI. Chapter on the possibility of all attributes.

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām sarva dharma upapatti adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the commentary called 'Naya-sudha', the chapter on the possibility of all attributes.

analyzed: om sarva dharma upapatteḥ ca om
translated: Om. Because of the possibility of all attributes.

original: sarve cetanā apūrṇaguṇā doṣiṇaśca dṛṣṭāstaddṛṣṭāntena cetanatvādīśvarasyāpi samāsavyāsābhyāmaparipūṇarguṇatvaṃ doṣitvaṃ ca syāditi pūrvapakṣo 🔽'trādhikaraṇe nirasyate /
analyzed: sarve cetanāḥ apūrṇa guṇāḥ doṣiṇaḥ ca dṛṣṭāḥ tad dṛṣṭāntena cetana tvāt īśvarasya api samāsa vyāsābhyām doṣi tvam ca syāt iti  tra adhikaraṇe nirasyate
translated: And all conscious beings are seen to be incomplete in their qualities and to have faults. By analogy, the Lord, being conscious, would also be incomplete in his qualities and have faults, either collectively or individually. This is the prima facie view.

analyzed: tat idam aspaṣṭam bhāṣye
translated: Here, in this section, that is refuted.🔽This is not clear in the Bhāṣya.

analyzed: caśabda samuccitāyāḥ śruteḥ eva udāhṛta tvāt
translated: Because only the quoted scripture, along with the word and, is mentioned.

analyzed: yukteḥ avyutpādanāt
translated: Because reasoning is not explained.

analyzed: tatas spaṣṭam yad adhīnāḥ iti  sarva dharma upapatteḥ ca
translated: Therefore, it is clear that they are dependent on Him.🔽And because all things are possible.

original: yadadhīnā guṇāścaiva doṣā api hi sarvaśaḥ /
analyzed: yad adhīnāḥ guṇāḥ ca eva doṣāḥ api hi sarvaśas
translated: On whom are dependent all the qualities and also all the faults,

original: guṇāstasya kathaṃ na syuḥ syurdeṣāśca kathaṃ punaḥ // / / //
analyzed: guṇāḥ tasya katham na syuḥ syuḥ deṣāḥ ca katham punar
translated: how can He not have qualities? And how can He have faults again?

analyzed: ca api śabdau anyonya samuccaye
translated: The words and and also are for including each other.

analyzed: evaśabdasya yad adhīnāḥ eva iti anvayaḥ
translated: The word eva (only) is to be connected with yad-adhīnāḥ.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ sarvasya bhagavat adhīna tāyām śruti ādi prasiddhim dyotayati
translated: The word hi (for) indicates the well-known fact of the dependence of everything on the Lord through scripture etc.

analyzed: katham iti ākṣepe
translated: Katham (how) is a rhetorical question.

analyzed: dvedhā hi vastu na prāpyate
translated: A thing is not obtained in two ways:

analyzed: tatra svātantrya abhāvāt vā prepsā bhāvāt vā
translated: either due to lack of independence or lack of desire.

analyzed: dvedhā ca na hīyate
translated: And it is not lost in two ways:

analyzed: svātantrya abhāvāt vā jihāsā abhāvāt vā
translated: either due to lack of independence or lack of willingness to give up.

analyzed: asti tāvat īśvarasya sarvatra svātantryam
translated: There is indeed the independence of God everywhere.

original: asti ca mayā sarvadā'nandādiguṇavatā duḥkhādidoṣavarjitena bhāvyamitīcchā /
analyzed: asti ca mayā sarvadā ānanda ādi guṇavatā duḥkha ādi doṣa varjitena bhāvyam iti icchā
translated: And there is the desire: I must always be endowed with the qualities of bliss etc. and devoid of the faults of suffering etc.

analyzed: prekṣāvat tvāt
translated: Because of being intelligent.

original: ataḥ kathaṃ tasyānandādiguṇapūrṇatvaṃ duḥkhādisarvadoṣadūratvaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: atas katham tasya ānanda ādi guṇa pūrṇa tvam duḥkha ādi sarva doṣa dūra tvam na bhavati
translated: Therefore, how is it that His being full of the qualities of bliss etc. and being far from all faults of suffering etc. does not occur?

analyzed: atra ete prayogāḥ
translated: Here are the arguments:

analyzed: īśvaraḥ sakala guṇa pūrṇaḥ sarva doṣa dūraḥ ca
translated: God is full of all qualities and far from all faults.

analyzed: svatantra tvāt
translated: Because of being independent.

analyzed: vyatirekeṇa yajñadatta vat
translated: By way of exclusion, like Yajnadatta.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ vipratipanna guṇavān  tatra prepsāvat tve sati svatantra tvāt
translated: God possesses the qualities disputed by others.🔽Because of being independent, given the desire for that.

original: yo yatra prepsāvatve sati svatantraḥ sa tadvān yathā sampratipannaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ yatra prepsāvatve sati svatantraḥ sa tadvān yathā sampratipannaḥ
translated: One who is independent in regard to something, given the desire for that, possesses that, like what is commonly accepted.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ na vimata doṣavān
translated: God does not possess the faults disputed by others.

analyzed: tad jihāsu tve sati svatantra tvāt
translated: Because of being independent, given the aversion to that.

original: yo yatra jihāsāvattve sati svatantraḥ sa tadabhāvavān /
analyzed: yaḥ yatra jihāsāvat tve sati svatantraḥ sa tad abhāvavān
translated: One who is independent in regard to something, given the aversion to that, does not possess that.

analyzed: yathā sammataḥ iti
translated: Like what is commonly accepted.

analyzed: sarva dharma apapatteḥ tat vākyaiḥ api hi tādṛśaiḥ
translated: Even by such statements, because of the acceptance of all things,

analyzed: nirdoṣa aśeṣa guṇakaḥ nirṇītaḥ bhagavān hariḥ
translated: Lord Hari is determined to be endowed with all faultless qualities.

analyzed: iti śrīmat ānandatīrtha bhagavat pāda ācārya viracite śrī brahmasūtra anuvyākhyāne dvitīya adhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first quarter of the second chapter of the Anubhasya on the Brahmasutras, composed by the great teacher Sriman Anandatirtha.

original: tat evamuktaprakāreṇa sarveṣāṃ dharmāṇāṃ guṇānāṃ doṣābhāvānāṃ ca sambandhinyāstatpratipādikayā upapatteḥ tādṛśaiḥ sarvaguṇapūrtyāderupapādakaiḥ🔽hiśabdasteṣāṃguṇāḥ śrutāḥ' /
analyzed: tat evam ukta prakāreṇa sarveṣām dharmāṇām guṇānām doṣa abhāvānām ca sambandhinyāḥ tad pratipādikayā upapatteḥ tādṛśaiḥ sarva guṇa pūrti ādeḥ upapādakaiḥ  hi śabdaḥ teṣām guṇāḥ śrutāḥ
translated: Thus, by the above-mentioned means, of all the qualities, the absence of faults, and the related statements that teach them, by such means that fulfill all the qualities, etc.,

analyzed: ityādīnām prasiddhānām sūcayati
translated: The word hi (in fact) indicates the well-known statements such as Those are the qualities heard.🔽This indicates the well-known statements such as Those are the qualities heard.

original: tadanena svapakṣe pramāṇamabhidadhataiva parakīyayuktīnāṃ kālātyayāpadiṣṭatvaṃ svātantryābhāvopādhiduṣṭatvaṃ coktaṃ bhavatīti /
analyzed: tat anena sva pakṣe pramāṇam abhidadhatā eva parakīya yuktīnām kāla atyaya apadiṣṭa tvam svātantrya abhāva upādhi duṣṭa tvam ca uktam bhavati iti
translated: By this, while presenting the means of valid knowledge in one's own view, it is said that the arguments of others are fallacious due to being too late, and that they are faulty due to the condition of lack of independence.

analyzed: iti śrīmat pūrṇapramati bhagavat pāda su kṛteḥ anuvyākhyānasya praguṇa jayatīrtha ākhya yatinā
translated: Thus ends the first quarter of the second chapter in the commentary on the Anubhasya of the blessed and greatly wise Lord's Sutras, composed by the monk named Praguna Jayatirtha, who is skilled in the good deeds of the blessed Lord.

original: kṛtāyāṃ ṭīkāyāṃ viṣamapadavākyātharvivṛtau dvitīyādhyāyasya prathamacaraṇaḥ paryavasitaḥ //
analyzed: kṛtāyām ṭīkāyām viṣamapada vākya atha rvivṛtau dvitīya adhyāyasya prathama caraṇaḥ paryavasitaḥ
translated: The second quarter of the second chapter, which explains the meaning of the difficult words and sentences, is concluded.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām dvitīya adhyāyasya prathama caraṇaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first quarter of the second chapter in the auspicious Naya-sudha.

analyzed: adhyaya pada
translated: Study. Word
I. The Section on the Incoherence of Arrangement

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām racanānupapatti adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the section on the incoherence of arrangement...

original: sakalajagajjanmādikāraṇe sakalaguṇaparipūrṇe samastāvadyagandhavidhure pare brahmaṇi viṣṇau samastaśrutisamanvayo yaḥ prathamādhyāye 'bhihitaḥ /
analyzed: sakala jagat janma ādi kāraṇe sakala guṇa paripūrṇe samasta avadya gandha vidhure pare brahmaṇi viṣṇau samasta śruti samanvayaḥ yaḥ prathama adhyāye bhihitaḥ
translated: The harmony of all the Upaniṣads with Viṣṇu, the supreme Brahman, who is the cause of the creation etc. of the entire world, who is perfect with all good qualities, and who is devoid of the taint of all faults, was stated in the first chapter.

analyzed: tasya sāṅkhaya ādi samaya virodhena anyathātva śaṅkāyām tad nirākaraṇa artham ayam
translated: When there is doubt about its being otherwise due to the contradiction with the Sāṅkhya and other systems, this [section]

analyzed: ṅkām nivārayitum dvitīya pādaḥ ārabhyate
translated: is begun in the second quarter to remove that doubt.

analyzed: nanu anārambhaṇīyaḥ eva ayam pādaḥ
translated: But this section is not to be begun at all.

original: tathāhi sāṅkhayādimatāni kiṃ smṛtitvenoktārthamanyathamantīti śaṅkayate /🔽kiṃvā yuktyupetatayā /🔽athavā śrutyupetatayā /
analyzed: tathā hi sāṅkhaya ādi matāni kim smṛti tvena ukta artham anyathamanti iti śaṅkayate  kiṃvā yukti upeta tayā  athavā śruti upeta tayā
translated: For thus, are the Sāṅkhya and other systems doubted to be otherwise than what is stated due to being remembered?🔽Or are they so due to being supported by reasoning?🔽Or are they so due to being supported by the Vedas?

analyzed: yat vā pratyakṣa upeta tayā
translated: Or are they so due to being supported by perception?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ pratismṛti parāhata tvena āpti niścāyaka abhāvena ca teṣām apasmṛti tvasya prathama pāde samarthita tvāt
translated: The first is not so, because their being un-remembered was established in the first section, due to being contradicted by the counter-remembrance and due to the absence of a determiner of the trustworthy.

analyzed: atas eva na caturthaḥ
translated: For the same reason, the fourth [alternative] is not so.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second [alternative] is not so.

analyzed: ukta artha viruddhānām sakala yuktīnām ābhāsa tvasya tatra eva vyutpādita tvāt
translated: Because the fact that all the arguments contrary to the meaning stated are fallacious has been explained there itself.

analyzed: prabala yukti virodhaḥ tra nirasyate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the contradiction by strong arguments is being refuted here, it is not so.

analyzed: prābalyam hi yuktīnām śruti ādi pramāṇa mūla tvena
translated: For the strength of arguments lies in their being based on scriptures etc.,

analyzed: tad saṃvādi tvena vā
translated: or in their being in agreement with them,

analyzed: bahutvena vā syāt
translated: or in their being numerous.

analyzed: sarvathā api na adhika āśaṅkā avakāśaḥ
translated: In any case, there is no scope for further doubt.

original: śrutyādisaṃvādinīnāṃ tanmūlānāṃ bahvīnāṃ ca yuktīnāṃ tatraiva nirākṛtatvāt /
analyzed: śruti ādi saṃvādinīnām tad mūlānām bahvīnām ca yuktīnām tatra eva nirākṛta tvāt
translated: Because all the arguments that are in agreement with scriptures etc., that are based on them, and that are numerous, have been refuted there itself.

original: kāścideva tatra nirastā na samastā iti cenna /
analyzed: kāścid eva tatra nirastāḥ na samastāḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that only some have been refuted there, not all, it is not so.

analyzed: sūtrāṇām upalakṣaṇa artha tvāt
translated: Because the sūtras are meant to be illustrative.

analyzed: anyathā yukti ābhāsānām ananta tvena aparyavasānam syāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be no end due to the infinite number of fallacious arguments.

analyzed: pāda bhedaḥ ca evam sati na syāt
translated: And the division into sections would not be possible in that case.

analyzed: na tṛtīyaḥ samasta śrutīnām brahmaṇi samanvayasya ukta tvāt
translated: The third alternative is not correct, because the complete agreement of all the scriptures with Brahman has been stated.

analyzed: atra kaścid āha
translated: Here someone says:

analyzed: sva pakṣa sādana para pakṣa pratikṣepābhyām eva nirṇayaḥ bhavati
translated: A decision is reached only through establishing one's own position and refuting the opponent's position.

analyzed: tatra prathama adhyāye sva pakṣe pramāṇam uktam
translated: In that, in the first chapter, the means of knowledge for one's own position has been stated.

analyzed: tasya yukti virodhaḥ dvitīyasya ādya pādena nirastaḥ
translated: The contradiction with reasoning of the second [part] is refuted by the first quarter [of the commentary].

original: evaṃ svapakṣasthāpane jāte parapakṣapratikṣepātharmayaṃ vāda ārabhyata iti /
analyzed: evam sva pakṣa sthāpane jāte para pakṣa pratikṣepa atharma ayam vādaḥ ārabhyate iti
translated: Thus, when one's own position has been established, the refutation of the opponent's position begins with the second chapter.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: parapakṣa pratikṣepaḥ hi tadīya sādhana nirāsāt anyaḥ nā asti
translated: For the refutation of the opponent's position is nothing but the refutation of his proofs.

analyzed: sādhanāni ca smṛti ādīni eva
translated: And the proofs are precisely memory and the rest.

original: nirastāni ca samastāni tāni prathamapāda iti kimasya kṛtyam /
analyzed: nirastāni ca samastāni tāni prathama pāde iti kim asya kṛtyam
translated: And all those have been refuted in the first quarter [of the commentary]. So what is the purpose of this [second chapter]?

analyzed: kiñca evam sati virodha parihāraḥ dhyāya arthaḥ na syāt iti
translated: Moreover, if it were so, then the resolution of contradictions would not be the subject matter of the treatise.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha
translated: Another [commentator] says:

original: uktārthe smṛtinyāyavirodho nāstīti sthāpite 'pyasti brahmaṇi samanvayābhāvaśaṅkā /
analyzed: ukta arthe smṛti nyāya virodhaḥ nā asti iti sthāpite pi asti brahmaṇi samanvaya abhāva śaṅkā
translated: Even though it has been established that there is no contradiction with memory and reasoning regarding the meaning stated, there is still doubt about the absence of the connection of Brahman.

analyzed: katham
translated: How is that?

analyzed: yadi api anumānam brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatvam apabādhitum nā alam
translated: Although inference is not capable of refuting the fact that Brahman is the cause of the world,

analyzed: tathā api kāraṇa antaram jagataḥ avagamayitum alam
translated: it is still capable of revealing another cause of the world.

original: tataśca vastuvikalpānupapatteranyataraparigrahe hetvabhāvāt brahmaiva jagatkāraṇamiti na niścetuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: tatas ca vastu vikalpa anupapatteḥ anyatara parigrahe hetu abhāvāt brahma eva jagat kāraṇam iti na niścetum śakyate
translated: And then, because the option of a different [cause] is not possible, and because there is no reason for accepting one [cause] over the other, it cannot be ascertained that Brahman alone is the cause of the world.

original: pratyuta sarvajñapraṇetṛkatvenānumānasyopabṛṃhitatvāt pradhānādyeva jagatkāraṇaṃ na brahmeti buddhiḥ syāt /
analyzed: pratyuta sarvajña praṇetṛka tvena anumānasya upabṛṃhita tvāt pradhāna ādi eva jagat kāraṇam na brahma iti buddhiḥ syāt
translated: On the contrary, since inference is strengthened by the fact that it has an omniscient author, the idea might arise that primordial matter itself is the cause of the world, not Brahman.

original: ato na kevalaṃ brahmaṇo jagatkāraṇatvamapabādhitumanumānaṃ notsahate /
analyzed: atas na kevalam brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇatvam apabādhitum anumānam nā utsahate
translated: Therefore, not only is inference unable to refute Brahman's being the cause of the world,

original: kintu kāraṇāntaramapyavagamayituṃ nālamiti pradarśanārthaṃ dvitīyaḥ pāda ārabhyata iti /
analyzed: kintu kāraṇa antaram api avagamayitum na alam iti pradarśana artham dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ ārabhyate iti
translated: but it is also unable to ascertain any other cause. In order to demonstrate this, the second section is begun.

analyzed: etat api uktam
translated: This has also been said.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

analyzed: kim anena uktam syāt
translated: What would be meant by this?

original: yadi / prāk svābhimatārthe yuktivirodhaparihāreṇa svapakṣasthapānā vihitā /
analyzed: yadi prāk sva abhimata arthe yukti virodha parihāreṇa sva pakṣa sthapānā vihitā
translated: If it is said that earlier, having established one's own position by avoiding contradiction with reasoning regarding one's own desired meaning,

analyzed: idānīm parapakṣa pratikṣepaḥ vidhīyate iti
translated: now the rejection of the opponent's position is being done.

analyzed: tadā uktam eva uttaram
translated: Then the very same answer is given.

analyzed: atha yukti virodha parihāraḥ eva pāda dvaya arthaḥ
translated: But if the purpose of both sections is to avoid contradiction with reasoning,

analyzed: kintu sva pakṣa virodhi yukti nirākaraṇam prathame
translated: then in the first, the refutation of reasonings contradicting one's own position,

analyzed: dvitīye tu parapakṣa sādhaka yukti nirākaraṇam iti tat na
translated: and in the second, the refutation of reasonings establishing the opponent's position. That is not so.

analyzed: nyāya sāmyena tāsām api śakya nirākaraṇa tvāt sārvajñam
translated: Because those can also be refuted by the same reasoning, omniscience

analyzed: sarvajña tvam ca praṇetṝṇām prāk eva nirastam
translated: and the omniscience of the authors have already been refuted.

original: ato nāyaṃ pāda ārambhaṇīya ityata āha smṛtīti //
analyzed: atas na ayam pādaḥ ārambhaṇīyaḥ iti atas āha smṛti iti
translated: Therefore, this section should not be begun. Hence he says memory and so on.

analyzed: smṛti yukti śruti guṇa yuktayaḥ bahu yuktayaḥ
translated: Many arguments, such as those based on memory, reasoning, and the qualities of the scriptures,

analyzed: evam caturvidhāḥ nā eva viruddhayante nu ayam prati
translated: In this way, the four types of arguments are not contradictory with regard to the meaning.

analyzed: iti prathama pādena nirṇīte pi abhiyogataḥ
translated: Even though it has been determined by the first section,

analyzed: darśanānām pravṛtta tvāt mandaḥ āśaṅkate punar
translated: Because the systems of philosophy are still being practiced, the dull-witted one doubts again.

analyzed: śrutayaḥ gurau upasarjanāni
translated: The scriptures are the prepositions

analyzed: yāsām tāḥ tathā uktāḥ
translated: Those that have them are said to be so.

analyzed: caturvidhāḥ virodhi pratītayaḥ
translated: The four types of contradictory cognitions.

original: anvayaṃ prati na viruddhayante iti śrutisamanvayasiddhamarthaṃ nānyathayituṃ śaknuvantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: anvayam prati na viruddhayante iti śruti samanvaya siddham artham na anyathayitum śaknuvanti iti arthaḥ
translated: They are not contradictory with regard to the meaning. The meaning is that they cannot make the meaning established by the harmony of the scriptures otherwise.

analyzed: abhiyogaḥ āgrahaḥ
translated: Abhiyoga is insistence.

analyzed: dṛśyate prameyam ebhiḥ iti darśanāni sāṅkhaya ādi śāstrāṇi
translated: The systems of philosophy are the Sankhya and other scriptures, by which the objects of knowledge are seen.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

original: yadyapi paramatasādhakānāmasmanmatabādhakānāṃ ca smṛtyādīnāmābhāsatvavyutpādanena spaparapakṣasādhanopālambhau kṛtāveveti paramārthaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api para mata sādhakānām asmad mata bādhakānām ca smṛti ādīnām ābhāsa tva vyutpādanena kṛtau eva iti paramārthaḥ
