translated: Thus it is.

analyzed: yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarva vid
translated: He who is omniscient, who knows all.

analyzed: yaḥ yonim adhitiṣṭhati ekaḥ ityādi
translated: He who alone presides over the source.

analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ parasya pratipakṣa bhūtā eva
translated: And thus scripture is itself the counter-argument of the opponent.

analyzed: pauruṣeyaḥ kim smṛti itihāsa purāṇa lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: Is the human one characterized by smrti, itihāsa, and purāṇa?

analyzed: uta sāṅkhayā ācārya praṇītaḥ
translated: Or is it composed by the teacher of the Sāṃkhya?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: tasya api asmad mata anusāri tvāt
translated: Because that [Sāṃkhya] also follows our doctrine.

analyzed: prakṛtim puruṣam ca eva praviśya puruṣottamaḥ
translated: Having entered into both Prakṛti and Puruṣa, the Supreme Person,

analyzed: kṣobhayāmāsa bhagavān sṛṣṭaya artham jagataḥ vibhuḥ
translated: the Blessed Lord, the Ruler, agitated [them] for the sake of creating the world.

analyzed: iti ādi vacanāt
translated: This and other statements [show that the Sāṃkhya agrees with us].

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ  tad prāṇyasya asammateḥ  āpta ukta tvena tad prāmāṇya siddhiḥ iti ced tatra āha āpta tvam iti
translated: Not the second.🔽Because that [Sāṃkhya] is not accepted by us.

analyzed: āpta tvam ukta mārgeṇa vaktuḥ na eva upapadyate
translated: If it is argued that the validity of that [Sāṃkhya] is established by being stated by a trustworthy person, then he [Śaṅkara] says trustworthiness [and so on].🔽Trustworthiness does not hold for the speaker in the way stated.

original: uktamārgeṇa śrutireva pramā hi na ityuktarītyā śrutiviruddhabhāṣitvādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ukta mārgeṇa śrutiḥ eva pramā hi naḥ iti ukta rītyā śruti viruddha bhāṣi tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the statement contradicts the Veda in the way stated, that the Veda alone is valid knowledge.

analyzed: vaktuḥ sāṅkhaya praṇetuḥ
translated: Of the speaker, the author of the Sāṃkhya.

analyzed: yat vai itareṣām ca anupalabdheḥ iti ukta mārgeṇa
translated: Or in the way stated, that the others are not perceived.

analyzed: sāṅkhaya śāstre pi hi ākhyāyikāsu yogya anupalabdhi bādhitāḥ bahavaḥ rthāḥ pratipādyante
translated: For in the Sāṃkhya scriptures, many things contradicted by the perception of what is possible are taught in the stories.

analyzed: athavā avipralambhaḥ tat jñānam
translated: Or, non-deception is the knowledge of that.

analyzed: ityādi ukta mārgeṇa āpta tva niścāyaka pramāṇa abhāvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no means of valid knowledge that ascertains trustworthiness in the way stated and so on.

analyzed: kapilaḥ vāsudeva ākhyaḥ tantram sāṅkhayam jagāda ha
translated: Kapila, known as Vāsudeva, taught the Sāṃkhya system.

analyzed: brahma ādibhyaḥ ca devebhyaḥ bhṛgu ādibhyaḥ tathā eva ca  tathā eva asuraye sarva veda artha paribṛṃhitam
translated: And to the gods beginning with Brahmā, and likewise to Bhṛgu and others,🔽And likewise to Asuri, Kapila expounded another, which is supported by the meaning of all the Vedas,

analyzed: sarva veda viruddham ca kapilaḥ jagāda ha
translated: And which contradicts all the Vedas.

analyzed: sāṅkhayam āsuraye nyasmai kutarka paribṛṃhitam
translated: The Sāṃkhya, supported by bad reasoning, was expounded by another Kapila to Asuri.

analyzed: iti purāṇa ukta mārgeṇa iti vā
translated: Or according to the path stated in the Purāṇas.

analyzed: ṛṣim prasūtam kapilam
translated: The sage Kapila, born from the egg,

analyzed: ityādi śruti udāharaṇam api anena eva nirastam
translated: The citation of this and other śrutis is also refuted by this alone.

analyzed: etena eva āgamāt yogi pratyakṣa avagame
translated: By this alone, In the comprehension by the perception of yogis through the āgamas, etc.,

analyzed: iti apākṛtam
translated: It is rejected.

analyzed: na kevalam ukta mārgeṇa āpta tva anupapattiḥ  kinnāma anupapanna bhāṣi tvāt api iti āha aprāmāṇya iti
translated: Not only is the non-establishment of being an authority not possible by the stated path,🔽But also because of speaking what is not logically possible, he says in the non-authoritativeness, etc.

analyzed: a prāmāṇya svatas tvasya svīkārāt api
translated: Because of accepting the self-evidence of non-authoritativeness, etc.

analyzed: api śabdena prāmāṇya svatastvam api samuccinoti
translated: The word also includes the self-evidence of authoritativeness.

analyzed: jñānānām prāmāṇyam aprāmāṇyam jñāna kāraṇa mātra adhīna utpattikam iti svīkaroti sāṅkhayaḥ
translated: The Sāṃkhya accepts that the authoritativeness or non-authoritativeness of cognitions arises only from the causes of the cognitions.

analyzed: tat ca anupapannam iti atas pi asau na āptaḥ
translated: And that is logically impossible, therefore he is not an authority.

analyzed: katham prāmāṇya aprāmāṇyayoḥ svatastvam anupapannam iti atas āha māyi vat iti
translated: How is the intrinsic nature of validity and invalidity not established? To this he says like a magician.

analyzed: māyi vat
translated: Like a magician.

analyzed: sva ukta akhila niṣedhī syān
translated: He would deny everything he has said.

original: prāmāṇyāprāmāṇyayorjñānakāraṇamātrajanyatve sāṅkhayasya vacanenotpannaṃ jñānaṃ pramāṇamapramāṇaṃ cetyubhayātmakaṃ vā syāt /🔽parasparavirādhenobhayavikalaṃ vā jñānamātramutpadyetadyate /
analyzed: prāmāṇya aprāmāṇyayoḥ jñāna kāraṇa mātra janya tve sāṅkhayasya vacanena utpannam jñānam pramāṇam apramāṇam ca iti ubhaya ātmakam vā syāt  paraspara virādhena ubhaya vikalam vā jñāna mātram utpadyeta yate
translated: If validity and invalidity were produced merely by the cause of knowledge, then the knowledge produced by the words of the Sāṃkhya would either be both valid and invalid,

original: niḥsvabhāvasya jñānasyānupapattyā notpadyatedyeta vā /🔽ādye sadasadvilakṣaṇaṃ viśvaṃ manyamāno māyāvādī yathā svoktaniṣedhī sadvilakṣaṇamityuktyā prāptasyāsattvasya /
analyzed: niḥsvabhāvasya jñānasya anupapattyā na utpadyate idyeta vā  ādye sat asat vilakṣaṇam viśvam manyamānaḥ māyā vādī yathā sva ukta niṣedhī sat vilakṣaṇam iti uktyā prāptasya asattvasya
translated: or knowledge would be produced as deficient in both due to mutual contradiction, or it would not be produced at all due to the impossibility of knowledge without essence.

analyzed: svayam eva asat vilakṣaṇam iti niṣedhāt
translated: In the first case, just as the Mādhyamika, who considers the universe to be different from existence and non-existence, denies existence, which is obtained by the statement different from existence, by himself saying different from non-existence,

original: asadvilakṣaṇamityuktyā ca prāptasya sattvasya svayameva sadvilakṣaṇamiti niṣedhāt /
analyzed: asat vilakṣaṇam iti uktyā ca prāptasya sattvasya svayam eva sat vilakṣaṇam iti niṣedhāt
translated: and by the statement different from non-existence, he denies existence, which is obtained, by himself saying different from existence.

analyzed: tathā sva ukta akhila niṣedhī syāt
translated: In the same way, the Sāṃkhya would also deny everything he has said.

original: tadvākyajanitajñānasya yāthārthye hi prakṛtirjagatkāraṇamityādiko 'rtho yo labdhaḥ /
analyzed: tad vākya janita jñānasya yāthārthye hi prakṛtiḥ jagat kāraṇam iti ādikaḥ rthaḥ yaḥ labdhaḥ
translated: For if the knowledge produced by that statement is true, then the meaning that has been obtained, that Prakṛti is the cause of the world, etc.,

analyzed: saḥ eva arthaḥ tasya ayāthārthye niṣiddhaḥ syāt
translated: that very meaning would be negated if it were false.

analyzed: viṣaya viparyāsa anatirekāt
translated: Because falsity is not different from error regarding the object.

analyzed: ubhaya svatastve vastunaḥ viruddha ākāra dvaya āliṅgita tvam prasajyeta iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if both were independent, the object would be related to two contradictory forms.

analyzed: māyā śabdasya vrīhi ādi tvāt māyī iti sādhu
translated: Since the word māyā is a collective noun like vrīhi, etc., māyī is correct.

original: nanvevamapi yāthārthyena prakṛtirjagatkāraṇamityādiko 'rthastāvatsiddhayatītyata āha naceti //🔽na ca kiñcit prasiddhayati // / / //
analyzed: nanu evam api yāthārthyena prakṛtiḥ jagat kāraṇam iti ādikaḥ rthaḥ tāvat siddhayati iti atas āha na ca iti  na ca kiñcid
translated: Even so, the meaning that Prakṛti is the cause of the world, etc., is established by truthfulness, so how is it that nothing is established?

analyzed: nahi paraspara virodhe kim api siddhayati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: For when there is mutual contradiction, nothing is established.

analyzed: tarhi prāmāṇyasya kā gatiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked what is the course of validity then,

analyzed: a prāmāṇye dīyatām dṛṣṭiḥ
translated: let the eye be given even in invalidity.

analyzed: dvitīye doṣam āha na ca iti
translated: In the second, he says not and so on.

analyzed: jñānam hi yathā avasthitam ayathā avasthitam vā artham viṣayīkuryāt
translated: For knowledge would cognize an object as it exists or not as it exists.

analyzed: tṛtīya prakāra a nirūpaṇāt
translated: Because a third kind is not specified.

analyzed: tathā ca prāmāṇya aprāmāṇya vikalam jñānam ayaḥ śalākā vat aviṣayam eva syāt
translated: And thus knowledge, which is devoid of validity and invalidity, would be objectless like an iron bar.

analyzed: evam ca na sāṅkhaya vacanāt kiñcid prasiddhayati iti
translated: And thus nothing is established from the Sāṃkhya statements.

analyzed: tṛtīye tu jagat āndhyam eva syāt iti āha na ca iti
translated: But in the third case, there would be blindness of the world. He says not and so on.

original: syādetat yadā jñānakāraṇaṃ guṇopetaṃ tadā tadīyāyāmaprāmāṇyajananaśaktau guṇena pratibaddhāyāṃ pramāṇajñānamevotpadyate /
analyzed: syāt etat yadā jñāna kāraṇam guṇa upetam tadā tadīyāyām aprāmāṇya janana śaktau guṇena pratibaddhāyām pramāṇa jñānam eva utpadyate
translated: This may be said: When the cause of knowledge is endowed with qualities, then in the power to produce invalidity belonging to it, which is obstructed by the quality, only valid knowledge arises.

original: yadā tu doṣopetaṃ tadā doṣeṇa prāmāṇyajananaśaktau pratibaddhāyāṃ apramāṇajñānamevotpadyate /
analyzed: yadā tu doṣa upetam tadā doṣeṇa prāmāṇya janana śaktau pratibaddhāyām apramāṇa jñānam eva utpadyate
translated: But when it is endowed with faults, then in the power to produce validity, which is obstructed by the fault, only invalid knowledge arises.

original: nahi kimapi karaṇaṃ yugapadubhayopetamubhayavikalaṃ vā sambhavati /
analyzed: nahi kim api karaṇam yugapad ubhaya upetam ubhaya vikalam vā sambhavati
translated: For no instrument can possibly be endowed with both or devoid of both at the same time.

analyzed: yena ukta doṣaḥ syāt iti
translated: By which the stated fault would occur.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: kimartham ittham kalpyate
translated: For what purpose is this imagined in this way?

analyzed: jñānasya ubhaya ākāra tva prasakteḥ iti ced
translated: If it is said: because of the possibility of knowledge having both forms,

analyzed: tad prasaktiḥ api kutas nā abhyupagantavyā
translated: then why should that possibility not be accepted?

analyzed: virodha bhayāt iti ced
translated: If it is said: because of the fear of contradiction,

analyzed: karaṇe pi ubhaya śakti virodhāt kutas na bibheṣi
translated: then why are you not afraid of the contradiction of both powers in the instrument?

analyzed: yat api viruddha kārya dvaya janakam karaṇam tad sahakāri sāhitya āhita śaktikam eva
translated: And that instrument which produces two contradictory effects is only one whose power is produced by the association of auxiliaries.

analyzed: prakṛte ca tathā abhyupagame dvayoḥ api paratas tva āpattiḥ
translated: And in the present case, if that is accepted, then both would have to be regarded as extraneously caused.

analyzed: kiñca vacane kau guṇa doṣau
translated: Moreover, what are the good and bad points in a statement?

analyzed: āpta anāpta tva praṇīta tve iti ced
translated: If it is said that they are being composed by a reliable or unreliable person,

analyzed: tarhi ubhaya abhāvāt veda vākyena ubhaya ātmakam anubhaya ātmakam vā jñānam utpadyeta
translated: then either a knowledge with both natures or without both natures would arise from a Vedic statement.

analyzed: na utpadyeta vā
translated: Or it would not arise at all.

analyzed: an āpta praṇīta tvam guṇaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is said that being composed by an unreliable person is a bad point,

original: tarhyāptāpraṇītatvaṃ doṣo 'pi kinna syāditi sa eva prasaṅgaḥ / /
analyzed: tarhi āpta apraṇīta tvam doṣaḥ api kinna syāt iti saḥ eva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then why should not being composed by a reliable person also be a bad point? Thus the same objection arises.

original: etena sāṅkhayācāryavacanaṃ svata eva pramāṇaṃ kimāptiniścayenetyapi nirastam /
analyzed: etena sāṅkhayā ācārya vacanam svatas eva pramāṇam kim āpti niścayena iti api nirastam
translated: By this, it is also refuted that the statement of the Sankhya teacher is a means of valid knowledge by itself, what is the use of ascertaining reliability?

analyzed: aprāmāṇyasya api svatas tvena ukta sakala doṣa āpatteḥ
translated: Because even unreliability would be said to be intrinsic, all the stated faults would be incurred.

analyzed: atha mahājana parigrahāt tad prāmāṇya niścayaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is said that the ascertainment of its validity is due to the acceptance of the majority, that is not so.

analyzed: pūjya artha tve siddheḥ
translated: Because the meaning of being worshipped is not established.

analyzed: bahu artha tve savyabhicāra tvāt sandigdha asiddheḥ ca iti
translated: Because of the fallacy of being inconclusive and the fallacy of being doubtful, if it is said to be the meaning of many.

analyzed: mā bhūt prakṛti kāraṇa tve prapañcasya pratyakṣam pramāṇam
translated: Let there be no perception as a means of valid knowledge in the case of the world having a primal substance as its cause.

analyzed: mā ca bhūt āgamaḥ
translated: And let there not be scripture.

analyzed: anumānam tu bhaviṣyati
translated: But there will be inference.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: bhedānām parimāṇāt samanvayāt śaktitaḥ pravṛtteḥ ca
translated: From the finiteness of the differences, from the connection, and from the activity according to capacity,

analyzed: kāraṇa kārya avibhāgāt avibhāgāt vaiśvarūpasya iti
translated: from the non-division of cause and effect, from the non-division of the variety.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: kāraṇa kārya vibhāgāt avibhāgāt vaiśvarūpyasya mūla kāraṇam asti avyaktam
translated: From the non-division of cause and effect, from the non-division of the variety, there is an unmanifest primordial cause.

analyzed: yathā kūrma śarīre santi eva aṅgāni tatas vibhajyante
translated: Just as the limbs exist in the body of a tortoise and are divided from it,

analyzed: tasmin eva avyaktībhavanti
translated: they become unmanifest in it alone.

original: evaṃ kāraṇānmṛtpiṇḍāddhemapiṇḍādvā kāryāṇi ghaṭamukuṭādīni vibhajyante /🔽santyeva ca pṛthivyādīni kāraṇāttanmātrāt /
analyzed: evam kāraṇāt mṛd piṇḍāt hema piṇḍāt vā kāryāṇi ghaṭa mukuṭa ādīni vibhajyante  santi eva ca pṛthivī ādīni kāraṇāt tanmātrāt
translated: In the same way, from the causal clay or gold lump, the effects such as pots, crowns, etc. are divided.🔽And the earth etc. exist in the causal subtle element.

analyzed: santi eva ca tanmātrāṇi ahaṅkārāt
translated: And the subtle elements exist in ego.

analyzed: san eva ca ahaṅkāraḥ mahataḥ
translated: And ego is in the great one.

analyzed: sat eva ca mahat parama avyaktāt iti
translated: And the great one is in the supreme unmanifest.

original: so 'yaṃ kāraṇātparamāvyaktātpāramparyeṇa viśvasya kāryasya vibhāgaḥ pratisarge /
analyzed: saḥ yam kāraṇāt parama avyaktāt pāramparyeṇa viśvasya kāryasya vibhāgaḥ pratisarge
translated: This is the division of the entire effect from the primordial unmanifest cause in the reverse order.

original: mṛtpiṇḍaṃ hemapiṇḍaṃ vā ghaṭamukuṭādayo viśanto 'vyaktībhavantīti tatkāraṇarūpamevānabhivyaktaghaṭamukuṭādikāryamapekṣyāvyaktaṃ bhavati /🔽evaṃ pṛthivyādayastanmātrāṇi viśantaḥ svāpekṣayā tanmātramavyaktayanti /
analyzed: mṛd piṇḍam hema piṇḍam vā ghaṭa mukuṭa ādayaḥ viśantaḥ vyaktībhavanti iti tad kāraṇa rūpam eva anabhivyakta ghaṭa mukuṭa ādi kāryam apekṣya avyaktam bhavati  evam pṛthivī ādayaḥ tanmātrāṇi viśantaḥ sva apekṣayā tanmātram avyaktayanti
translated: A lump of clay or a lump of gold, entering into the forms of a jar, a crown, etc., become unmanifest. Therefore, the unmanifest is that which is the form of the cause, in relation to the effect such as the jar, the crown, etc., which are not yet manifest.🔽In the same way, earth, etc., entering into the subtle elements, become unmanifest in relation to them.

analyzed: evam tanmātrāṇi ahaṅkāram viśanti ahaṅkāram avyaktayanti
translated: In the same way, the subtle elements, entering into egoism, become unmanifest in relation to egoism.

analyzed: evam ahaṅkāraḥ mahāntam āviśat mahāntam avyaktayati
translated: In the same way, egoism, entering into Mahat, becomes unmanifest in relation to Mahat.

analyzed: mahān prakṛtim sva kāraṇam viśati
translated: Mahat enters into Prakṛti, its own cause.

original: prakṛtestu na kvacinniveśa iti sā sarvakāryāṇāmavyaktameva /
analyzed: prakṛteḥ tu na kvacid niveśaḥ iti sā sarva kāryāṇām avyaktam eva
translated: But Prakṛti has no place anywhere, so it is the unmanifest of all effects.

analyzed: saḥ yama vibhāgaḥ prakṛtau vaiśvarūpyasya nānā rūpasya kāryasya
translated: This is the undifferentiated state of Prakṛti, the cause of the manifold universe.

original: tasmātkāraṇe kāryasya sata eva vibhāgāvibhāgābhyāmavyaktaṃ kāraṇamastīti / /
analyzed: tasmāt kāraṇe kāryasya sataḥ eva vibhāga avibhāgābhyām avyaktam kāraṇam asti iti
translated: Therefore, the unmanifest cause exists, of which the existent effect is a part, through division and non-division.

original: itaśca / śaktitaḥ pravṛtteḥ /🔽kāraṇaśaktito hi kāryaṃ pravartate /🔽aśaktātkāraṇātkāryasyānutpatteḥ /
analyzed: itas ca śaktitaḥ pravṛtteḥ  kāraṇa śaktitaḥ hi kāryam pravartate  aśaktāt kāraṇāt kāryasya anutpatteḥ
translated: And for this reason also: because of activity from potentiality.🔽The effect proceeds from the potentiality of the cause.🔽Because an effect does not arise from an incapable cause.

analyzed: śaktiḥ ca kāraṇa gatā na kāryasya avyakta tvāt anyā
translated: And potentiality, which belongs to the cause, is not different from the unmanifestness of the effect.

original: astu tarhi mahata eva paramāvyaktatvamityata uktaṃ bhedānāṃ parimāṇāditi /
analyzed: astu tarhi mahataḥ eva parama avyakta tvam iti atas uktam bhedānām parimāṇāt iti
translated: Well, then, let the great one alone be the supreme unmanifest. To this it is said: because of the finiteness of the distinctions.

analyzed: mahat ādīnām avyāpaka tvāt avyakta kāraṇaka tvam ghaṭa ādi vat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the great one and others are not all-pervading, and therefore have an unmanifest cause, like a pot and so on.

analyzed: itas ca samanvayāt
translated: And for this reason also: because of the connection.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha bhoga samanvitāni hi kāryāṇi
translated: For the effects are connected with the experience of pleasure and pain.

analyzed: yāni ca yad ūpam anugatāni tāni tad svabhāva avyaktakāni
translated: And those that follow a certain form are of the nature of that unmanifest.

analyzed: yathā mṛd hema rūpam anugatāḥ ghaṭa mukuṭa ādayaḥ mṛd hema piṇḍa avyaktakāḥ
translated: Just as pots, crowns, etc., which follow the form of clay and gold, are unmanifest as clay and gold.

analyzed: tasmāt asti sukha duḥkha mahā ūha ātmakānām sattva rajaḥ tamasām sāmya avasthā vyaktam bhedānām iti
translated: Therefore, there is an unmanifest state of equilibrium of the qualities sattva, rajas, and tamas, which have the nature of pleasure, pain, and delusion, and of the distinctions.

analyzed: yadi api etāni anumānāni avyakta svarūpam sādhayanti
translated: Even though these inferences establish the nature of the unmanifest,

analyzed: tathā api mahat ādi kāraṇatayā eva tat etaiḥ siddhayati iti
translated: still it is established by them only as the cause of the great one and others.

analyzed: atra vaktavyam
translated: Here it should be said:

analyzed: kim etaiḥ anumānaiḥ jagat upādānatā mātreṇa avyaktam siddhayati
translated: Do these inferences establish the unmanifest merely as the material cause of the world,

analyzed: uta svātantryeṇa api itipi
translated: or also independently?

analyzed: ādye siddhasādhanam
translated: In the first case, it is a futile rejoinder,

analyzed: asmābhiḥ api viśva upādānasya pradhānasya abhyupagata tvāt
translated: because we also accept prakriti as the material cause of the universe.

analyzed: śarīra rūpakaḥ
translated: The body is a metaphor.

analyzed: iti hi uktam
translated: Thus it has been said.

analyzed: dvitīyam nirākartum sūtram
translated: To refute the second [view], the Sūtra says:

analyzed: racanā anupapatteḥ ca na anumānam iti
translated: And because of the impossibility of arrangement, there is no inference.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe idam iti
translated: He explains that as follows:

analyzed: idam na acetana vaśam vastu tvāt pratipanna vat
translated: This [universe] is not under the control of the non-sentient, because it is an object, like what is accepted.

analyzed: iti eva pratiṣiddhasya kena mūla anumā bhavet
translated: By whom can the original inference of what has thus been refuted be established?

analyzed: mahāda ādi kāryam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the effect beginning with the Great One.

analyzed: acetana vaśam svatantra acetana adhīna utpattikam
translated: Under the control of the non-sentient means having an origination dependent on an independent non-sentient being.

analyzed: pratipanna vat
translated: Like what is accepted.

analyzed: pradhāna vat
translated: Like the Primordial Matter.

original: āstāṃ tāvaddūṣaṇāntaram iti pratyanumānenaiva pratiṣiddhasya pradhānasvātantryasya mūlānumā sādhikānumā kena sāmarthyena bhavet pramāṇamiti
analyzed: āstām tāvat dūṣaṇa antaram iti pratyanumānena eva pratiṣiddhasya pradhāna svātantryasya mūla anumā sādhikā anumā kena sāmarthyena bhavet pramāṇam iti
translated: Let alone the other refutations, by this counter-inference alone, by whom can the original inference of the independence of Primordial Matter, which has been refuted, be established as a valid means of knowledge?

analyzed: śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is implied.

analyzed: mūla anumā iti vā āvartanīyam
translated: Or the word original inference should be repeated.

analyzed: kim ākṣepe  akārya tvam atra upādhiḥ iti ced na
translated: What is the meaning of kim in the sense of questioning?

analyzed: paṭa ādau sādhya avyāpteḥ
translated: If it is argued that non-being an effect is the reason here, that is not so.🔽Because the conclusion is not pervaded by cloth, etc.

analyzed: paṭa ādeḥ kuvinda ādi adhiṣṭhita tantu ādi kāya rtvasya anvaya vyatirekābhyām upalambhāt
translated: Because cloth, etc. are observed by concomitance and non-concomitance to be the effect of weavers, etc.

original: evaṃ pradhānasya racanāyāḥ svatantrapravṛtteranumānavirodhenānupapatternānumānaṃ tatra pramāṇamiti sūtrākṣarayojanāṃ manasi nidhāya sūtratātparyamuktam
analyzed: evam pradhānasya racanāyāḥ svatantra pravṛtteḥ anumāna virodhena anupapatteḥ na anumānam tatra pramāṇam iti sūtra akṣara yojanām manasi nidhāya sūtra tātparyam uktam
translated: Thus, the arrangement of the primordial matter, which is independent, being inconsistent with inference, inference is not a means of knowledge in that matter. Having thus determined the arrangement of the words of the aphorism in the mind, the purport of the aphorism has been stated.

analyzed: idānīm tām eva vivṛṇvan pratipakṣa antaram āha svatantra iti
translated: Now, explaining that very [purport], he states another counter-argument, beginning with 'svatantrye' [i.e., 'If the primordial matter were independent'].

analyzed: svatantra vṛttī racanā sā ca eva acetane kutas
translated: And that arrangement is in an unconscious [primordial matter], how is it possible?

analyzed: caśabdaḥ numāna antara samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' [in the aphorism] is for the inclusion of another inference.

analyzed: kutas eva iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is: 'How is it possible?'

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: pradhānam svatantra pravṛtti rahitam acetana tvāt
translated: The primordial matter is devoid of independent activity, because it is unconscious.

analyzed: tantu ādi vat iti
translated: Like a thread, etc.

original: nanvacetanatve 'pi pradhānasya svātantryeṇa pravṛttirastu ko virodhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu acetana tve pi pradhānasya svātantryeṇa pravṛttiḥ astu kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: Even if the primordial matter is unconscious, let there be activity by its own independence. What is the contradiction?

original: tathāca vipakṣe bādhakābhāvādaprayojako 'yaṃ heturityata āha acetanatvamiti //
analyzed: tathā ca vipakṣe bādhaka abhāvāt aprayojakaḥ yam hetuḥ iti atas āha acetana tvam iti
translated: And thus, in the contrary case, there being no sublating means of knowledge, this reason is irrelevant. To this he says 'Achetana-tvam' [i.e., 'Unconsciousness and independence are contradicted by the cognition of the self'].

analyzed: acetana tvam svātantryam iti
translated: Unconsciousness and independence are contradicted by the cognition of the self.

analyzed: tāvat eva hi anena āśaṅkanīyam yasmin āśaṅkayamāne sva vacana sva kriyā sva nyāya pramāṇa antara virodhaḥ na prāduṣyāt
translated: For, this [primordial matter] can be suspected only to that extent, on suspecting which there would be no contradiction with one's own statement, one's own action, logic, or other means of knowledge.

analyzed: nahi kaścid evam śaṅkate
translated: For no one entertains such a doubt.

original: mūko 'pi vaktā kinna syāt /🔽śabdo 'pratipādakaḥ kinna bhavet /
analyzed: mūkaḥ pi vaktā kin na syāt  śabdo pratipādakaḥ kinna bhavet
translated: Why should not even a dumb person be a speaker?🔽Why should not a word fail to convey its meaning?

analyzed: anumāna tvāt anumāna mātram apramāṇam kutas na syāt
translated: Why should inference not be a means of valid knowledge, being mere inference?

analyzed: agniḥ anuṣṇaḥ kutas na bhavet iti
translated: Why should fire not be non-hot?

original: na hyeṣā śaṅkāpiśācī kadācicchāntimupāgacchati /🔽tasmādevāmāśaṅkamāno na laukiko nāpi parīkṣaka ityunmattavadupekṣaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: na hi eṣā śaṅkā piśācī kadācid śāntim upāgacchati  tasmāt evām āśaṅkamānaḥ na laukikaḥ na api parīkṣakaḥ iti unmatta vat upekṣaṇīyaḥ
translated: For this doubt-demoness never attains peace.🔽Therefore, one who entertains such doubts is neither a worldly person nor an investigator, and should be disregarded like a madman.

analyzed: prakṛte ca acetana tvam svātantryam
translated: And in the present context, the insentience and independence of the pradhāna are contradicted by one's own cognition.

analyzed: sva vyāhatam pramāṇa viruddham ca
translated: They are self-contradictory and opposed to valid knowledge.

original: tasmādacetanatve 'pi svatantrapravṛttirastu pradhānasyeti śaṅkaiva notpattumarhatīti kimatra bādhakopanyāseneti / /
analyzed: tasmāt acetana tve pi svatantra pravṛttiḥ astu pradhānasya iti śaṅkā eva nā utpattum arhati iti kim atra bādhaka upanyāsena iti
translated: Therefore, the mere suspicion that there may be independent activity of the pradhāna even though it is insentient, should not arise at all. What need is there then to adduce any refutation here?

original: nanvacetanasya svātantryaśaṅkāyāṃ kathaṃ svavyāhatiḥ /🔽nahi svātantryaṃ nāma caitanyam /
analyzed: nanu acetanasya svātantrya śaṅkāyām katham sva vyāhatiḥ  nahi svātantryam nāma caitanyam
translated: But if there is a suspicion of independence in an insentient entity, how is there self-contradiction?🔽For independence is not the same as sentience.

analyzed: na api acetana tvam nāma asvātantryam
translated: Nor is insentience the same as non-independence.

analyzed: katham ca pramāṇa virodhaḥ
translated: And how is there contradiction with valid knowledge?

original: ityata svavyāghātaṃ tāvadupapādayituṃ svātantryaṃ vyākhyāti sveccheti //
analyzed: iti atas sva vyāghātam tāvat upapādayitum svātantryam vyākhyāti sva icchā iti
translated: Thus, in order to establish his own contradiction, he explains independence as follows: By his own will.

analyzed: sva icchā anusāri tām eva svātantryam hi vidaḥ viduḥ
translated: The wise know independence to be the state of following one's own will.

analyzed: pravṛttau iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is in action.

analyzed: vidaḥ viduḥ iti anena sakala vidvas sammatam etat iti āha
translated: By saying the wise know, he says this is accepted by all the wise.

original: ata eva hi svātantryābhāvādvṛkṣastiṣṭhatītyādikartṛtvavyavahāro gauṇa iti sarve pratipannāḥ / /
analyzed: atas eva hi svātantrya abhāvāt vṛkṣaḥ tiṣṭhati ityādi kartṛ tva vyavahāraḥ gauṇaḥ iti sarve pratipannāḥ
translated: For this very reason, all agree that the usage of the agent in the tree stands and so on is secondary, due to the absence of independence.

analyzed: tathā api katham sva vyāhatiḥ
translated: Even so, how is there self-contradiction?

original: nahyacetanatvaṃ nāmecchāvirahaḥ /🔽kinnāma caitanyaviraha ityata āha kuta iti //
analyzed: na hi acetana tvam nāma icchā virahaḥ  kinnāma caitanya virahaḥ iti atas āha kutas iti
translated: For being insentient does not mean the absence of will.

analyzed: kutas icchā acetanasya  acetanasya icchā kutas kāraṇāt jāyate
translated: Rather, it means the absence of consciousness. Thus he says from what (cause).🔽From what (cause) does the will of the insentient arise?

analyzed: na kutaścid
translated: It arises from no cause at all.

analyzed: jñānam eva hi icchāyāḥ janakam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that knowledge alone is the producer of will.

original: tathāpi kimityata āha secchaṃ cediti // /🔽secchaṃ cet kimacetanam // / / //
analyzed: tathā api kim iti atas āha sa iccham ced iti  sa iccham ced kim acetanam
translated: Even so, what then? Thus he says if it has will.🔽If it has will, then how can it be insentient?

original: secchaṃ cedaṅgīkṛtaṃ tadā tadacetanaṃ kiṃ cetanamevetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: seccham ced aṅgīkṛtam tadā tat acetanam kim cetanam eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that if it is accepted as having will, then how can it be insentient, but rather it would be sentient.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

original: acetanamapi pradhānaṃ svātantryeṇa pravṛttimadastviti vadatācetanamicchāvadastvityuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: acetanam api pradhānam svātantryeṇa pravṛttimat astu iti vadatā acetanam icchāvat astu iti uktam syāt
translated: If it is said that the non-sentient pradhāna should be active independently, it would be as if it were said that the non-sentient is endowed with desire.
Because it is accepted by all that being guided by one's own will is the meaning of the word 'independence'.

analyzed: acetanasya icchāvat tvam aṅgīkurvāṇena cetana tvam api aṅgīkartavyam syāt
translated: And one who accepts that the non-sentient is endowed with desire would have to accept sentience as well.

analyzed: anvaya vyatirekābhyām icchāyāḥ sva samāna āśraya caitanya kāryatva avadhāraṇāt
translated: Because by positive and negative concomitance it is ascertained that desire is the effect of sentience that inheres in the same substratum.

analyzed: kārya aṅgīkāre kāraṇa anaṅgīkārasya anucita tvāt
translated: Because when the effect is accepted, the non-acceptance of the cause is not proper.

analyzed: acetanam cetanam iti ca sphuṭā vyāhatiḥ iti
translated: And there is a clear contradiction in calling the non-sentient the sentient.

analyzed: etena etat api nirastam
translated: By this, this is also refuted.

original: acetanatvaṃ svātantryaṃ ca yadi parasparavyāhataṃ tarhyacetanatvena svatantrapravṛttirāhityasādhane sādhyāviśiṣṭatādoṣaḥ syāditi /
analyzed: acetana tvam svātantryam ca yadi paraspara vyāhatam tarhi acetana tvena svatantra pravṛtti rāhitya sādhane sādhya aviśiṣṭa tā doṣaḥ syāt iti
translated: If non-sentience and independence are mutually contradictory, then in proving the absence of independent activity by non-sentience, there would be the fault of the probandum not being qualified.

analyzed: nahi asmābhiḥ acetana tva svātantryayoḥ vandhyā apatyavatī iti vat sākṣāt virodhaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: For we do not say that non-sentience and independence are directly contradictory like a barren woman having a child.

analyzed: kintu svātantrya balena caitanyam pareṇa aṅgīkārya
translated: But independence must be accepted by the opponent as being due to sentience,

original: kārayitvā anenaiva svātantryāṅgīkāre 'cetanatvānupapattiriti bādhakaṃ coktaṃ bhavati / /🔽evamacetanasya svātantryāṅgīkāre svavyāhatimupapādya pramāṇavirodhamapyupapādayati icchāmīti //
analyzed: kārayitvā anena eva svātantrya aṅgīkāre cetana tva anupapattiḥ iti bādhakam ca uktam bhavati  evam acetanasya svātantrya aṅgīkāre sva vyāhatim upapādya pramāṇa virodham api upapādayati icchāmi iti
translated: And by this very [argument] it is said that there is an objection that it is not possible for the insentient to be independent.🔽Thus, having explained the contradiction with one's own words in accepting the independence of the insentient, he also explains the contradiction with valid means of knowledge by saying I desire...

analyzed: icchāmi aham iti hi eva nija anubhava rodhataḥ
translated: For, I desire is indeed contradicted by one's own experience.

analyzed: acetana icchā apagatā
translated: The desire of the insentient is...

analyzed: hi śabdena asya anumānasya viśva jana prasiddha tvam sūcayati
translated: The word indeed indicates the well-known nature of this inference to all people.

analyzed: eva śabdasya apagatā eva iti anvayaḥ
translated: The word eva (indeed) is to be connected with agatā (has gone).🔽One's own experience is the experience of the witness.

analyzed: aham icchāmi iti tāvat icchā ātma sambandhinī sākṣiṇā anubhūyate
translated: I desire - thus the desire is experienced by the witness as connected with the self.

analyzed: na ca sā dvi kartṛkā sambhavati
translated: And that cannot be possible with two agents.

analyzed: kvāpi ekasya vyāpārasya dvi kartṛka tva anupalambhāt  tatas ca acetanasya icchā aṅgīkṛtā avaitada
translated: Because the activity of one is never seen to have two agents anywhere.🔽Therefore, if the desire of the insentient is accepted,

analyzed: cetta  d anubhava virodhāt acetanasya icchā apagatā nā asti iti yāvat
translated: then🔽due to the contradiction with this experience, the desire of the insentient has gone, i.e., does not exist - this is the meaning.

original: icchābhāve ca svecchānusāritvalakṣaṇaṃ svātantryaṃ dūrotsāritamiti bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: icchā abhāve ca sva icchā anusāri tva lakṣaṇam svātantryam dūra utsāritam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And in the absence of desire, independence characterized by acting according to one's own will is far removed - this is the idea.

analyzed: nanu navam asti anubhavaḥ kintu aham icchāmi icchā
translated: Surely, there is experience in the ninth [stage], but I desire, desire

analyzed: mī iti vyavahāra mātram
translated: But there is indeed a ninth [type of cognition], namely, experience. However, the expression I desire is merely a convention.

analyzed: tasya api nimittam bheda agrahaḥ
translated: The cause of that [desire] is also the non-apprehension of difference.

original: ātmā hi nityo nirvikāraścaitanyamātravapurna tasyecchādikartṛtvamāgantukaṃ sambhavati /
analyzed: ātmā hi nityaḥ nirvikāraḥ caitanya mātra vapuḥ na tasya icchā ādi kartṛ tvam āgantukam sambhavati
translated: For the self is eternal, changeless, and has consciousness alone as its essence. It cannot have desire etc. as adventitious [qualities].

analyzed: kintu antaḥkaraṇasya eva prasava dharma tvāt
translated: But the internal organ alone has the nature of origination.

analyzed: tayoḥ ca ātma antaḥkaraṇayoḥ bheda agrahāt itaretara dharma vyavahāraḥ pravartate
translated: And due to the non-apprehension of the difference between the self and the internal organ, the convention of the attributes of each other occurs.

analyzed: bheda agrahe ca nimittam sannidhānam
translated: And the cause of the non-apprehension of difference is proximity.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: tasmāt tad saṃyogāt acetanam cetanāvat iva liṅgam
translated: Therefore, the non-intelligent [body], due to its connection with that [self], appears as if it were intelligent.

original: guṇakartṛtve ca tathā karteva bhavatyudāsīnaḥ' / iti /
analyzed: guṇa kartṛ tve ca tathā kartā iva bhavati udāsīnaḥ iti
translated: And in the case of the quality being the agent, the self appears as if it were the agent, though indifferent.

analyzed: atas nubhava balāt cetanasya eva icchāvat tvam na acetanasya iti ayuktam iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: Therefore, it is not proper to say that only the intelligent one has desire, not the non-intelligent one, on the strength of experience. To this he says if etc.

analyzed: yadi bheda agraho tra ca
translated: If the non-apprehension of difference is here the cause of the convention,

analyzed: katham na sa ghaṭasya syān
translated: how could it not be of the pot?

original: yadi evamanubhava eva nāsti kintu vyavahāramātram /
analyzed: yadi evam anubhavaḥ eva na asti kintu vyavahāra mātram
translated: If it is so, then there is no experience at all, but only a convention.

original: atra ca vyavahāre bhedāgraha eva nimittamucyate /
analyzed: atra ca vyavahāre bheda agrahaḥ eva nimittam ucyate
translated: And in this convention, the non-apprehension of difference is said to be the cause.

original: tadā sa bhedāgraho ghaṭasya kiṃ kathaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: tadā sa bheda agrahaḥ ghaṭasya kim katham na syāt
translated: Then, how could there be no apprehension of the difference of the pot?

analyzed: vyavahāra hetuḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: the cause of usage.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: sva prakāśa anubhava apalāpa doṣaḥ tāvat  vyavahāre ca nimittam na asti
translated: First, there is the fault of denying self-luminous experience.🔽And there is no cause for usage.

analyzed: na ca bheda agrahaḥ
translated: And there is no non-apprehension of difference.

analyzed: viśiṣṭa vyavahārasya tādṛśa jñāna kārya tā niyamāt
translated: Because a particular usage is necessarily the effect of such knowledge.

original: anyathā ghaṭapaṭāvapītaretarabhedaṃ na gṛhṇīta itītaretaradharmasaṃsargavyavahāraḥ syāditi / /
analyzed: anyathā ghaṭa paṭau api itaretara bhedam na gṛhṇītaḥ iti itaretara dharma saṃsarga vyavahāraḥ syāt iti
translated: Otherwise, even pot and cloth would not apprehend each other's difference, so there would be usage of the connection of each other's properties.

original: nanu gṛhyamāṇayorbhedagraho vyavahāraheturna tu bhedāgrahamātram /🔽naca ghaṭapaṭau svarūpaṃ gṛhṇītastatkathamatiprasaṅga iti cet /
analyzed: nanu gṛhyamāṇayoḥ bheda grahaḥ vyavahāra hetuḥ na tu bheda agraha mātram  na ca ghaṭa paṭau sva rūpam gṛhṇītaḥ tat katham atiprasaṅgaḥ iti ced
translated: But if the apprehension of difference of what is being apprehended is the cause of usage, not merely the non-apprehension of difference,🔽and if pot and cloth do not apprehend their own nature, how can there be an overextension?

analyzed: kim ayam viśiṣṭaḥ bheda agrahaḥ ntaḥkaraṇasya uta ātmanaḥ
translated: Is this special non-apprehension of difference of the internal organ, or of the self?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: tasya acetana tvena svarūpa graha anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is insentient, it cannot apprehend its own nature.

original: upapattau vā sa kathaṃ viśiṣṭo bhedāgraho ghaṭasya na syāt /
analyzed: upapattau vā sa katham viśiṣṭaḥ bheda agrahaḥ ghaṭasya na syāt
translated: If it can, how could that special non-apprehension of difference not be of the pot?

analyzed: tathā ca vyavahāraḥ pi syāt
translated: And in that case, there would be usage.

analyzed: nanu antaḥkaraṇe sti caitanya āropaḥ na ghaṭe
translated: But the superimposition of sentience is on the internal organ, not on the pot.

analyzed: atas na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this is not an overextension,

analyzed: kim tasya nimittam
translated: what is the cause of that?

analyzed: sannidhānam iti ced
translated: If it is said to be proximity,

original: tarhi sarvagatātmasannidhānaṃ ghaṭe 'pyastīti kathaṃ sa na ghaṭasya syāt /
analyzed: tarhi sarvagata ātma sannidhānam ghaṭe pi asti iti katham sa na ghaṭasya syāt
translated: then since the proximity of the omnipresent self exists in a pot as well, how can it not belong to the pot?

analyzed: nanu na saṃyoga mātram nimittam
translated: But it is not mere conjunction that is the cause.

analyzed: kintu upakārya upakāraka bhāve sati
translated: Rather, it is when there is a relation of benefit and being benefited.

analyzed: sa ca asti ātma antaḥkaraṇayoḥ
translated: And that exists between the self and the internal organ.

analyzed: puruṣasya darśana artham iti ukta tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is for the purpose of the person's seeing,

original: tarhi ghaṭo 'pi puruṣasyopakāraka iti kathaṃ sa na ghaṭasya syāt /
analyzed: tarhi ghaṭaḥ pi puruṣasya upakārakaḥ iti katham sa na ghaṭasya syāt
translated: then since the pot is also beneficial to the person, how can it not belong to the pot?

analyzed: dvitīye kim ātmanaḥ uta antaḥkaraṇasya
translated: In the second case, does the usage belong to the self or to the internal organ?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first,

analyzed: tasya nirvikārasya vyavahāra kriyā anupapatteḥ
translated: because for it, which is changeless, the activity of usage is not possible.

analyzed: upapattau vā kim icchayā aparāddham  dvitīye bheda agraheṇa anyatra
translated: If it is possible, what harm is there in accepting it?🔽If it is argued that the usage with regard to something else is due to the non-apprehension of difference in something else,

original: sya vyavahāraścetkathaṃ sa na ghaṭasya syāt / /
analyzed: vyavahāraḥ ced katham sa na ghaṭasya syāt
translated: how can it not belong to the pot?

original: kiñca yadi bhedāgrahādantaḥkaraṇadharma evecchā'tmani vyavahriyata ityaṅgīkriyate
analyzed: kiñca yadi bheda agrahāt antaḥkaraṇa dharmaḥ eva icchā ātmani vyavahriyate iti aṅgīkriyate
translated: Moreover, if it is accepted that desire, which is a property of the internal organ, is used with regard to the self due to the non-apprehension of difference,

original: tadā ghaṭasyāpyātmanā bhedāgrahātpṛthubudhnodarākāro 'hamiti vyavahāraḥ kathaṃ na
analyzed: tadā ghaṭasya api ātmanā bheda agrahāt pṛthu budhna udara ākāraḥ ham iti vyavahāraḥ katham na
translated: Then, how is it that even in the case of a pot, due to the non-apprehension of difference from the self, there is the usage I am of the shape of a broad base, belly, and mouth?

analyzed: syāt iti gūḍha abhisandheḥ uttaram
translated: Then, how could there not be the usage I am of the shape of a pot with a broad base and a belly due to the non-apprehension of difference even in the case of the pot? This is the answer of one who has a hidden intention.

analyzed: yat vā atra ca ātma antaḥkaraṇayoḥ ca sphuṭam pratibhāsamāna bhedayoḥ api iti hṛdayam
translated: Or, the heart of the matter here is that the self and the internal organ, although having a difference that appears clearly, are not apprehended as different.

original: yadi bhedāgrahaḥ syāttadā kathaṃ sa bhedāgraho ghaṭasyātmanaśca na syāditi yojanā /
analyzed: yadi bheda agrahaḥ syāt tadā katham sa bheda agrahaḥ ghaṭasya ātmanaḥ ca na syāt iti yojanā
translated: If there were non-apprehension of difference, then how could that non-apprehension of difference not be in the case of the pot and the self? This is the construction.

analyzed: athavā evam vadan praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Or, one who speaks thus should be asked:

original: bhedāgrahaḥ kiṃ bhedagrahasya virodhī na veti /
analyzed: bheda agrahaḥ kim bheda grahasya virodhī na vā iti
translated: Is the non-apprehension of difference contradictory to the apprehension of difference or not?

original: neti pakṣe kathaṃ sa ghaṭasyātmanā paṭādinā vā na syādityuttaram / /
analyzed: na iti pakṣe katham sa ghaṭasya ātmanā paṭa ādinā vā na syāt iti uttaram
translated: If the answer is no, then the answer is how could that non-apprehension of difference not be in the case of the pot or the cloth etc.?

analyzed: nanu bheda grahaḥ bheda agraha virodhī
translated: But the apprehension of difference is contradictory to the non-apprehension of difference.

original: sa cāsti ghaṭa iti kutastatra bhedāgrahastatprayukto vyavahāro veti gūḍhābhisandhimajānato dvitīyapakṣamāśaṅkayāha mana iti //
analyzed: sa ca asti ghaṭaḥ iti kutas tatra bheda agrahaḥ tad prayuktaḥ vyavahāraḥ vā iti gūḍha abhisandhim a jānataḥ dvitīya pakṣam āśaṅkayā āha manaḥ iti
translated: And that exists in the case of the pot. So how could there be non-apprehension of difference there or the usage resulting from it? Not understanding the hidden intention, suspecting the second alternative, he says mind etc.

analyzed: manaḥ me iti bhedataḥ
translated: Mind is mine as different.

analyzed: manasaḥ api gṛhīta tvāt
translated: Because the mind is also apprehended.

analyzed: bhedataḥ iti tasiḥ
translated: The third case ending in tas is as different.

original: yadi bhedagraho bhedāgrahavirodhīti bhedena gṛhyamāṇe ghaṭe na bhedāgraha ityucyate /
analyzed: yadi bheda grahaḥ bheda agraha virodhi iti bhedena gṛhyamāṇe ghaṭe na bheda agrahaḥ iti ucyate
translated: If it is said that the apprehension of difference is incompatible with the non-apprehension of difference, and when a pot is apprehended as different, there is no non-apprehension of difference,

original: tadā me mana iti manaso 'pi bhedena gṛhītatvānnātmanā bhedāgrahaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tadā me manaḥ iti manasaḥ u pi bhedena gṛhīta tvāt na ātmanā bheda agrahaḥ syāt
translated: then, since the mind is also apprehended as different, there would be no non-apprehension of difference with respect to the self.

analyzed: tathā ca bheda agraha nimittaḥ ham icchāmi iti vyavahāraḥ iti asat
translated: And thus it is not true that the usage I desire is due to the non-apprehension of difference.

analyzed: kintu anubhava nimitte eva
translated: But it is rather due to experience.

original: ata eva nāntaḥkaraṇadharmasyātmanyāropa ityapi yuktam /🔽bhedagrahasadbhāvena āropahetorbhedāgrahasyāyogāt /
analyzed: atas eva na antaḥkaraṇa dharmasya ātmani āropaḥ iti api yuktam  bheda graha sadbhāvena āropa hetoḥ bheda agrahasya ayogāt
translated: For this very reason, it is also correct that the property of the internal organ is not superimposed on the self.🔽Because the non-apprehension of difference, which is the cause of superimposition, is not possible due to the presence of the apprehension of difference.

analyzed: na hi avidita bhedam sambandhi tayā gṛhyate
translated: For what is not known as different is not apprehended as related.

analyzed: ātmani api prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the same is the case with the self.

analyzed: kena punar pramāṇena manaḥ gṛhyate
translated: But by what means is the mind apprehended?

analyzed: sākṣiṇā iti vadāmaḥ
translated: We say it is by the witness.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For this is the case.

analyzed: na tāvat cakṣuḥ ādinā tad avagamaḥ
translated: The understanding of that is not by the eye, etc.

analyzed: arūpi dravya tvāt
translated: Because it is a formless substance.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi a vyāpāre pi upalabdheḥ
translated: Because it is perceived even when the eye, etc. are not functioning.

analyzed: na ca anumānena
translated: And not by inference.

analyzed: liṅga abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no logical ground.

analyzed: nanu asti yugapad jñāna anutpattiḥ manasaḥ liṅgam
translated: But isn't the non-arising of knowledge simultaneously [the logical ground for the existence of the mind]? For this is the case.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus:

analyzed: bāhya indriyeṣu svaiḥ svaiḥ viṣayaiḥ yugapad sannikṛṣṭeṣu ātmanā adhiṣṭhiteṣu api na yugapad jñānāni jāyante
translated: Even when the external sense organs are simultaneously in contact with their respective objects and are controlled by the self, the cognitions do not arise simultaneously.

analyzed: tena jñāyate sti etebhyaḥ nyat sahakāri
translated: Therefore, it is understood that there is something else besides them that assists.

analyzed: yat saṃyoga krama vaśāt jñāna kramaḥ prakramate iti
translated: By which the sequence of cognitions proceeds due to the sequence of conjunctions.

analyzed: atra kaścid āha
translated: Here someone says:

analyzed: ātmanaḥ eva evaṃvidha sāmarthya kalpanā upapattau anyathā asiddham anumānam
translated: Since it is possible to imagine the self itself to have such power, the inference is not established otherwise.

analyzed: manasaḥ prati indriya saṃyoga vyavahāre kramavati kāraṇa antara śūnye na aikāntikam ca
translated: And it is inconclusive regarding the mind, which operates sequentially in relation to each sense organ, being devoid of other causes.

original: phalasya ca vṛkṣaśatpatataḥ kramavartinyākāśasaṃyoge kuṭhārādivyāpāre ca /
analyzed: phalasya ca vṛkṣaśat patataḥ krama vartini ākāśa saṃyoge kuṭhāra ādi vyāpāre ca
translated: And regarding the fruit, which falls from the tree, in the sequential conjunction with space, and in the operation of the axe, etc.

analyzed: indriyāṇām prati viṣaya saṃyoga vyāpāre ca iti
translated: And in the operation of the sense organs in relation to the conjunction with each object.

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: That is incorrect.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa anusāriṇī hi kalpanā
translated: For imagination follows what is seen.

analyzed: kartā hi aneka karaṇa adhiṣṭhānena yugapad nānā kāryāṇi kurvāṇaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: For a doer is seen to perform many actions simultaneously by controlling many instruments.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Indeed, it is so.

original: yugapanmāṇavako gacchati paṭhati panthānamīkṣate vahati ca kamaṇḍalum /
analyzed: yugapad māṇavakaḥ gacchati paṭhati panthānam īkṣate vahati ca kamaṇḍalum
translated: A student goes, reads, looks at the paths, and carries a water pot simultaneously.

analyzed: tasmāt na eva kartṛ dharmaḥ yuktaḥ kalpayitum
translated: Therefore, it is not proper to imagine a property of the doer.

analyzed: kintu dṛṣṭa tvāt dravya antaram eva avyāpakam
translated: But because it is seen, it is a separate substance that is not all-pervading.

analyzed: anaikāntyam tu na asti eva
translated: But there is no inconclusiveness.

analyzed: tatra api kriyā krama ādeḥ nimittasya vidyamāna tvāt iti
translated: Because even there, the cause such as the sequence of actions is present.

analyzed: atra ucyate
translated: To this it is said.

analyzed: asti tāvat avivekinām api manaḥ pratītiḥ
translated: There is indeed the cognition of mind even for those who do not discriminate.

analyzed: mama manaḥ nyatra gatam ityādi vyavahārāt
translated: Because of expressions like my mind has gone elsewhere.

analyzed: na ca te yugapad jñāna anutpattim jānanti
translated: And they do not know the non-arising of cognitions simultaneously.

analyzed: pratyuta yugapad eva jñāna utpattim manyante
translated: On the contrary, they think that cognitions arise simultaneously.

original: anyathā vyāsaṅge kramadarśanenānyatrāpi kramānumānaṃ parasya vyarthaṃ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā vyāsaṅge krama darśanena anyatra api krama anumānam parasya vyartham syāt
translated: Otherwise, the opponent's inference of sequence elsewhere based on the observation of sequence in confusion would be pointless.

analyzed: tasmāt liṅga darśanāt prāk eva bhavat idam manaḥ jñānam na tad nimittakam iti
translated: Therefore, this cognition of mind exists even before the observation of the mark, and is not caused by that.

analyzed: astu tarhi buddhaya ādīnām asamavāyi kāraṇasya saṃyogasya āśraya tayā manaḥ siddhiḥ
translated: Then let there be the establishment of mind as the substratum of conjunction, which is the non-inherent cause of intellect and so on.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: pratyakṣa jñāne tāvat indriya ātma saṃyogasya eva asamavāyi kāraṇa tvasya upapatteḥ
translated: Because in the case of perception, the contact of the self with the sense organ is itself the non-inherent cause.

analyzed: anumiti ādau liṅga jñāna ādeḥ
translated: In the case of inference etc., it is the knowledge of the mark.

analyzed: smṛtau bhāvanāyāḥ
translated: In the case of memory, it is the impression.

analyzed: sukha ādau iṣya artha upalabdha ādeḥ iti
translated: In the case of pleasure etc., it is the apprehension of the desired object and so on.

analyzed: nitya viśeṣa guṇānām saṃyoga asamavāyi kāraṇa tva niyamāt na evam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that this is not so in the case of the eternal specific qualities, because they are necessarily the conjoined and non-inherent causes, [we say] no.

analyzed: vibhāga ja śabda ja śabde vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of the deviation in the case of the sound produced by disjunction and the sound produced by sound.

analyzed: a śrāvaṇat tvena hetu viśeṣaṇāt na iti ced
translated: If it be said that it is not so because the reason is qualified by being non-audible,

original: yathā tarhi vibhāgādiśabde kāraṇāntaradarśanāttannirāsārthaṃ vyāptigrahaṇavelāyāṃ prayatyate tathā sukhādinirāsāya prayatanīyam /
analyzed: yathā tarhi vibhāga ādi śabde kāraṇa antara darśanāt tad nirāsa artham vyāpti grahaṇa velāyām prayatyate tathā sukha ādi nirāsāya prayatanīyam
translated: then just as effort is made at the time of grasping the pervasion in order to refute that [non-audible sound] by showing another cause in the case of the sound produced by disjunction etc., so effort should be made to refute pleasure etc.

analyzed: asamavāyi kāraṇa antara darśanasya tulya tvāt
translated: Because the perception of another non-inherent cause is the same.

analyzed: nimittam tat iti ced na
translated: If it be said that it is the cause, no.

analyzed: asamavāyi kāraṇa lakṣaṇasya ativyāpti prāpteḥ iti  na ca sukha ādi upalabdhi karaṇa tvena manaḥ siddhiḥ
translated: Because of the attainment of over-pervasion of the definition of non-inherent cause.🔽And the establishment of the mind is not by the fact of being the means of perceiving pleasure etc.

analyzed: sākṣi siddha tayā anyathā asiddheḥ
translated: Because it is established by the witness, otherwise it is not established.

analyzed: evam anumāna antaram api nirasanīyam
translated: In the same way, other inferences should also be refuted.

analyzed: na ca āgamaḥ manasi pramāṇam
translated: And scripture is not a means of valid knowledge regarding the mind.

analyzed: jāti badhirāṇām api tad pratyayāt
translated: Because of the cognition of that even in the deaf and dumb.

analyzed: tasmāt siddham sākṣi grāhya tvam manasaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is established that the mind is grasped by the witness.

original: tasya ca tenaivātmano bhinnatayā grahaṇādbhedāgrahāsambhavenecchāmyahamīti na bhedāgrahanibandhano vyavahāra iti / /
analyzed: tasya ca tena eva ātmanaḥ bhinna tayā grahaṇāt bheda agraha asambhavena icchāmi aham iti na bheda agraha nibandhanaḥ vyavahāraḥ iti
translated: And since that [self] is apprehended by that [intellect] as different from itself, the non-apprehension of difference being impossible, the usage based on the non-apprehension of difference, 'I desire this', is not possible.

original: nanu ca kāmaḥsaṅkalpo vicikitsā śraddhāśraddhā dhṛtiradhṛtirbhīrhīrityetatsarvaṃ mana eva' /
analyzed: nanu ca kāmaḥ saṅkalpaḥ vicikitsā śraddhā aśraddhā dhṛtiḥ adhṛtiḥ bhīḥ hīḥ iti etat sarvam manaḥ eva
translated: But it is said in the Śruti: 'Desire, resolve, doubt, faith, lack of faith, firmness, lack of firmness, fear, and lack of fear - all this is only the mind.'

analyzed: iti śrutau kāmasya antaḥkaraṇa rūpa tvam tāvat pratīyate
translated: Thus, the nature of desire as the internal organ is understood.

analyzed: na ca śrautena arthena anyathā bhavitum yuktam
translated: And it is not proper for the meaning of the Śruti to be otherwise.

analyzed: atas balavat bādhaka upanipātāt icchāmi aham iti bheda agraha nimittam vyavahāra mātram etad aṅgīkaraṇīyam
translated: Therefore, due to the occurrence of a strong contradiction, this usage based on the non-apprehension of difference, 'I desire this', should be accepted as mere usage.

original: na tvātmana icchāsambandhānubhavaḥ /🔽naca me mana iti bhedagrahāttadagrahāsambhavaḥ /
analyzed: na tu ātmanaḥ icchā sambandha anubhavaḥ  na ca me manaḥ iti bheda grahāt tad agraha asambhavaḥ
translated: But there is no experience of the self being connected with desire.🔽And it is not impossible to have non-apprehension of that due to the apprehension of difference as 'my mind'.

analyzed: me caitanyam iti vat vayavahāra mātra tvāt
translated: Because it is mere usage like 'my consciousness'.

analyzed: na ca ukta anupapattiḥ
translated: And there is no inconsistency with what has been said.

analyzed: sattva rajaḥ tamasām ādi kāryam hi buddhiḥ iti ucyate
translated: The effect of sattva, rajas, and tamas is called intellect.

analyzed: sā ca aṃśa trayavatī
translated: And that has three parts.

analyzed: puruṣa uparāgaḥ viṣaya uparāgaḥ vyāpāra āveśaḥ ca iti aṃśāḥ
translated: The parts are: attachment to the self, attachment to objects, and engagement in activity.

analyzed: bhavati hi aham idam karomi iti
translated: For there is 'I am doing this'.

analyzed: tatra aham iti cetanā uparāgaḥ darpaṇasya eva mukha uparāgaḥ bheda agrahāt atāttvikaḥ
translated: There, the attachment to the idea of 'I' is the mere attachment of the mirror to the face, not real due to non-apprehension of difference.

original: idamiti viṣayoparāga indriyapranāḍikayā pariṇatibhedo darparasyeva malasambandhaḥ pāramārthikaḥ /
analyzed: idam iti viṣaya uparāgaḥ indriya pranāḍikayā pariṇati bhedaḥ darparasya iva mala sambandhaḥ pāramārthikaḥ
translated: The attachment to the object as 'this' is the difference in modification through the medium of the sense organs, like the connection with dirt in a mirror, real.

analyzed: tathā ubhaya āyattaḥ vyāpāra āveśaḥ
translated: Similarly, the manifestation of activity is dependent on both.

analyzed: eṣā eva diś aham icchāmi iti atra api iti atas āha ubhayā iti
translated: This is the direction in the case of 'I desire this' also. Therefore it is said: 'both' etc.

analyzed: ubhaya ātmaka tā yatas
translated: Because of the nature of being both.

analyzed: kāmasya tu manaḥ kāmaḥ
translated: But the mind is desire for one who desires.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word 'tu' (but) is for determination.

analyzed: tatas iti upaskartavyam
translated: 'From that' should be supplied.

analyzed: yatas kāraṇāt kāmasya ubhaya ātmaka tā asti
translated: Because of that reason, desire has the nature of being both.

analyzed: ātma dharma tā manaḥ dharma tā ca
translated: The nature of the self and the nature of the mind.

original: tata eva manaḥ kāma iti śrutirupapadyate /
analyzed: tatas eva manaḥ kāmaḥ iti śrutiḥ upapadyate
translated: For that very reason, the statement that the mind is desire is appropriate.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: bhavet idam bheda agraha kalpanam
translated: This would be an assumption of non-apprehension of difference,

analyzed: yadi ātmanaḥ kāmavat tvam pāramārthikam na syāt
translated: if the reality of the self having desire were not so.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction.

analyzed: dvividhaḥ hi kāmaḥ sti
translated: For there are two kinds of desire.

analyzed: ekaḥ paraḥ ntaḥkaraṇa dharmaḥ
translated: One is a property of the self, the other is a property of the internal organ.

analyzed: tatra antaḥkaraṇa dharmam kāmam abhipretya śrutiḥ pravṛttā
translated: There, with reference to the attribute of the internal organ, desire, the Śruti has begun.

analyzed: na ātmanaḥ kāmavat tvam bādhate
translated: The fact that the self has desires does not contradict this.

original: nahi devadatto gomāniti vākyaṃ yajñadattasya gosambandhaṃ bādhituṃ śaknotīti / /
analyzed: nahi devadattaḥ gomān iti vākyam yajñadattasya go sambandham bādhitum śaknoti iti
translated: For a statement that Devadatta possesses a cow cannot contradict the connection of Yajñadatta with a cow.

analyzed: syāt etat evam
translated: This may be so.

analyzed: yadi kāma dvaividhyam pramitam syāt
translated: If the twofold nature of desire were established.

analyzed: etat eva kutas iti ced
translated: If it be asked how this is so,

analyzed: śruti anubhava balāt tāvat
translated: it is so by the force of the experience of Śruti.

analyzed: prakāra sahasra anusaraṇe pi a ghaṭanāyām khalu anubhava apalāpa sāhasam abhyupeyam
translated: Even when following thousands of ways, if there is no explanation, one must accept the audacity of rejecting experience.

analyzed: pramāṇa antaram ca āha priya iti
translated: And he states another means of knowledge: priye (in what is dear).

analyzed: priya apriya vibhedataḥ
translated: From the distinction between what is dear and what is not dear,

analyzed: dvaividhyam dṛśyate ca asya
translated: its twofold nature is seen.

analyzed: priyam iti ātyantika iṣyam ucyate priyam iti ca tātkālika iṣyam
translated: What is dear refers to what is ultimately desirable, and what is not dear refers to what is temporarily desirable.

analyzed: viṣayeṇa viṣayiṇaḥ upalakṣaṇam
translated: The object is a metonym for the subject.

analyzed: asya kāmasya
translated: Of this desire.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: asti tāvadāstikakāmukasya puruṣasya srakcandavanitādau idaṃ me syādityekataḥ kāmaḥ /
analyzed: asti tāvat āstika kāmukasya puruṣasya srak canda vanitā ādau idam me syāt iti ekatas kāmaḥ
translated: For a man who is a believer and a lover, there is desire for the garland, wine, and women, etc., in one place, thinking May this be mine.

analyzed: anyatas tyajeyam iti
translated: In another place, there is the thought I should abandon this.

analyzed: na ca ekaḥ eva ayam
translated: And this is not just one.

analyzed: viruddha rūpa tvāt
translated: Because of its contradictory nature.

analyzed: na ca dvau api manaḥ dharmau
translated: And both are not properties of the mind.

analyzed: yaugapadyāt  yugapad sajātīya dharma janana ayogāt
translated: Because they occur simultaneously.🔽Because it is not possible for two properties of the same kind to be produced simultaneously.

analyzed: na ca yaugapadyam na asti  anubhava siddha tvāt
translated: And simultaneity does not not exist.🔽Because it is established by experience.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt ca
translated: And because there is no contradiction.

original: tatra yo 'priyaviṣayaḥ saḥ antaḥkaraṇadharmaḥ yastu priyaviṣayaḥ sa ātmadharma iti / /
analyzed: tatra priya viṣayaḥ saḥ antaḥkaraṇa dharmaḥ yaḥ tu priya viṣayaḥ saḥ ātma dharmaḥ iti
translated: Among them, that which has an unpleasant object is a property of the internal organ, but that which has a pleasant object is a property of the self.

analyzed: yat vā priya apriya śabdābhyām mukti saṃsārau ucyete
translated: Or, by the words 'pleasant' and 'unpleasant', liberation and transmigration are spoken of.

analyzed: tad sambandhi vibhedena kāma dvaividhyam dṛśyate iti
translated: The twofoldness of desire is seen by the difference in what is related to that.

analyzed: asti tāvat saṃsāre pracuraḥ yam antaḥkaraṇa vṛtti rūpaḥ kāmaḥ
translated: There is indeed this desire in the form of modification of the internal organ which is abundant in transmigration.

analyzed: asti ca asau muktau
translated: And it exists in liberation.

analyzed: sa yadi pitṛ loka kāmaḥ bhavati
translated: If he becomes one who desires the world of the manes.

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ
translated: Because of this and other statements in the scriptures.

analyzed: na ca ekaḥ eva ayam
translated: And this is not one only.

analyzed: muktau antaḥkaraṇa vilayāt
translated: Because of the dissolution of the internal organ in liberation.

analyzed: tathā ca asau ātma dharmaḥ bhyupeyaḥ
translated: And thus it must be accepted as a property of the self.

original: nacāgantukadharmasambandho muktāviti prāgapi kāmadvaividhyaṃ siddhayatīti / /🔽śrutibādhaparihārasya prayojanamāha tasmāditi // /
analyzed: na ca āgantuka dharma sambandhaḥ muktau iti prāk api kāma dvaividhyam  śruti bādha parihārasya prayojanam āha tasmāt iti
translated: And there is no connection with adventitious properties in liberation. Thus the twofoldness of desire is established even before.

analyzed: tasmāt bheda agrahaḥ kutas
translated: He states the purpose of the avoidance of contradiction with scripture as follows: Therefore, how can there be non-apprehension of difference?

analyzed: śruti virodhasya parihṛta tvāt bheda agrahaḥ kutas pramāṇāt kalpanīyaḥ
translated: Since the contradiction with the scriptures has been removed, how can the non-apprehension of difference be imagined on the basis of any means of knowledge?

analyzed: kutas ca anubhava apalāpena vyavahārasya tad nimitta tvam
translated: And how can the functioning of the world be said to be due to that, by denying experience?

analyzed: na kutas pi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: not from anywhere at all.

original: anenācetanasya pradhānasya svātantryeṇa jagatkāraṇatvaṃ sādhayatāmanumānamapi svavacanavirodhaḥ pramāṇavirodhaścoktau bhavataḥ /
analyzed: anena acetanasya pradhānasya svātantryeṇa jagat kāraṇatvam sādhayatām anumānam api sva vacana virodhaḥ pramāṇa virodhaḥ ca uktau bhavataḥ
translated: By this, it is said that even the inference stated by those who try to establish that the insentient pradhāna is the cause of the world by its own independence is contradictory to one's own statement and to the means of knowledge.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāntaḥ ca sādhya vikalaḥ
translated: And the example is deficient in the probandum.

analyzed: acetana svātantryasya kvāpi asammateḥ iti
translated: Because the independence of the insentient is not accepted anywhere.

analyzed: sūtra artham upasaṃharan na anumānam iti etat prakāra antareṇa vyācaṣṭe racanā iti
translated: Concluding the meaning of the aphorism, he explains the word inference in a different way, saying arrangement and so on.

analyzed: racanā anupapatteḥ tat na
translated: Because of the impossibility of arrangement, that which is understood by all inference is

analyzed: acetanam jagat kartṛ
translated: the insentient creator of the world.

analyzed: tat tasmāt
translated: That.

analyzed: sarvajña anumā gatam anumānam prakṛti ādikam
translated: That which is understood by all inference is the natural origination, etc.

analyzed: kasyacid pratyakṣam  prameya tvāt iti sarvam asādhaka anumayā avagatam
translated: It is the perception of someone.🔽Because of being an object of knowledge, all is understood by an inference that does not establish anything.

analyzed: etat anumāna siddha sarvajña vākya avagatam iti yāvat
translated: It is understood by the statement of the omniscient one who is established by this inference.

analyzed: yadvā anumāna siddha prāmāṇyaka tvena anumāna pradhāna tvena ca sarvajña abhimatasya vākyam eva sarvajña anumā ucyate
translated: Or, if it is established by inference to have validity and is mainly inferential, then the statement of one who is accepted as omniscient is said to be known by all knowledge.

analyzed: vyākhyāna antarasya ca idam prayojanam
translated: And this is the purpose of another explanation.

original: yatprāguktaṃ na yogipratyakṣeṇa sāṅkhayācāryavacanena vāyamarthaḥ siddhayatīti tadapi sūtrasūcitameveti jñāpanam /
analyzed: yat prāguktam na yogi pratyakṣeṇa sāṅkhayā ācārya vacanena vā ayam arthaḥ siddhayati iti tat api sūtra sūcitam evā iti jñāpanam
translated: That which was said before, that this meaning is not established by the perception of a yogi or by the words of the Sankhya teacher, that too is indicated by the aphorism.

original: yadā tu sarvajñābhimatotprekṣitayā bhedānāṃ parimāṇādityādikayānumayāvagatamānumānamiti yojanā /🔽tadā vaicitrya
analyzed: yadā tu sarvajña abhimata utprekṣitayā bhedānām parimāṇāt ityādikayā anumayā avagatam ānumānam iti yojanā  tadā vaicitrya
translated: But when it is construed as inference understood by the inference inferred by the one accepted as omniscient, imagined by the one accepted as omniscient, such as from the finitude of differences and so on,

analyzed: trī pradarśanam vyākhyāna antara prayojanam
translated: then the purpose of another explanation is to show the variety.

analyzed: jagatkartṛ svātantryeṇa jagat kāraṇam
translated: The creator of the world is the independent cause of the world.

analyzed: syāt etat  parimāṇa ādi hetubhiḥ tāvat mahat ādi kāryāṇām kim api mūla kāraṇam asti iti avagamyate
translated: This may be said.🔽It is understood that there is some fundamental cause of effects such as Mahat and so on by means of reasons such as finitude and so on.

analyzed: tasya api kāraṇa antara kalpane pramāṇa abhāvāt anavasthānāt ca
translated: Because there is no evidence for postulating another cause of that and because of infinite regress.

original: tasya ca svātantryaṃ kārakāntarāprayojyatvameva natu svecchānusāritvam /
analyzed: tasya ca svātantryam kāraka antara aprayojya tvam eva na tu sva icchā anusāri tvam
translated: And its independence is just the non-employability of other agents, not the conformity to one's own will.

analyzed: yena ukta doṣaḥ syāt
translated: By which the stated fault would be.

analyzed: tat ca tad prayoktuḥ kāraka antarasya aprāmāṇika tvāt eva siddham
translated: And that is established by the very fact that the other agent who employs it is not authoritative.

analyzed: na ca acetanasya tat asambhāvitam
translated: And it is not impossible for the insentient.

analyzed: acetaneṣu api payaḥ mbu prabhṛtiṣu darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen even in insentient things like milk and water.

analyzed: acetanam eva hi payaḥ nyān adhiṣṭhitam api vatsa vivṛddhaya rtham pravartate
translated: For milk, though not controlled by another, acts for the growth of the calf.

analyzed: dadhi bhāvam ca āpadyate
translated: And it becomes curd.

analyzed: ghana vinirmuktam ca ambu jambīra nārikela ādiṣu anekavidham vikāram prāpnoti
translated: And water, when freed from clouds, attains many kinds of modifications in things like citron and coconut.

analyzed: na ādeyam ca apasarpati
translated: And what is not to be given moves away.🔽And grass eaten by cows becomes milky.

original: tṛṇaṃ ca gavā jagdhaṃ kṣīrībhavati /🔽ayaścāyaskāntamabhisarpati /🔽nacaidaṃ nācetanavaśam' /
analyzed: tṛṇam ca gavā jagdham kṣīrībhavati  ayaḥ ca ayaskāntam abhisarpati  na ca edam na acetana vaśam
translated: And iron moves towards the lodestone.🔽And this is not under the control of the insentient.

analyzed: ityādi pramāṇa virodhaḥ
translated: There is contradiction with such valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: tasya ukta sthāneṣu eva anaikāntyam
translated: Its inconclusiveness is in the very places mentioned.

analyzed: na ca idam brahma vādinām sammatam
translated: And this is not accepted by the proponents of Brahman.

analyzed: yena siddha sādhanam syāt iti āśaṅkā parihāra artham sūtram
translated: By which there would be the establishment of what is already established. To remove this doubt, the aphorism is:

analyzed: om payaḥ mbu vat ced tatra api om
translated: If it is like milk and water, there also.

analyzed: iti  tat vayācaṣṭe payaḥ mbu ādi ca iti
translated: Thus.🔽He explains that as If it is like milk and water, there also.

analyzed: payaḥ mbu vat ced tatra api
translated: If it is like milk and water, there also.

analyzed: payaḥ mbu ādi ca na upamā
translated: Milk and water, etc. are not analogies.

analyzed: etad praśāsti vacanāt cetana acetanasya ca
translated: And from the statement of the Lord of the two, the conscious and the non-conscious.

analyzed: upamā svārtha sambhāvanāyām asmadīya hetu vyabhicāre ca iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The simile is for the purpose of expressing one's own opinion and for showing the fallacy of the reason in our view.

original: yathātra sādhyaṃ vyabhicarati tathā pakṣe 'pi vyabhicaratu heturityevamarthaṃ hi vyabhicārodbhāvanam /
analyzed: yathā atra sādhyam vyabhicarati tathā pakṣe vyabhicaratu hetuḥ iti evam artham hi vyabhicāra udbhāvanam
translated: The purpose of pointing out the fallacy is to show that just as the conclusion is fallacious, so also the reason is fallacious in the subject.

analyzed: tat atra na yujyate  cetana acetanasya etat praśāsti vacanāt
translated: But this is not proper here.🔽Because of the statement of the Lord of the two, the conscious and the non-conscious.
Because of the Vedic statement that teaches the instigation by the Supreme Lord.

original: ādyaścaśabdo laukikānāṃ svatantratayā pratīyamānamapītyarthe /🔽dvitīyastu na kevalamacetanasya /
analyzed: ādyaḥ caśabdaḥ laukikānām svatantra tayā pratīyamānam api iti arthe  dvitīyaḥ tu na kevalam acetanasya
translated: And the first 'ca' (and) word is for the purpose of expressing that which is understood as independent by worldly people.🔽The second 'ca' (and) word is not only for the non-conscious.

analyzed: kintu ubhayasya api iti
translated: But also for both.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said.

analyzed: kāraka antara aprayojya tva lakṣaṇam api svātantryam na pradhānasya upapadyate
translated: Even the independence characterized by not being dependent on other agents is not possible for the principal.

analyzed: asambhāvita tvāt  ukta anumāna viruddha tvāt ca
translated: Because it is not accepted.🔽And because it is contradicted by the stated inference.

analyzed: yat uktam atra payaḥ mbu ādi vat iti
translated: What was said here, that it is like milk, water, etc.,

analyzed: tat asat  tatra api īśvara preraṇayā etasya vai akṣarasya
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: ityadi śruti siddha tvāt
translated: Because even there, it is established by Vedic statements such as 'of this imperishable one' and so on, by the instigation of God.

original: ata eva pradhānasya paraprayojyatve pramāṇābhāvo 'pi parāsta iti /
analyzed: atas eva pradhānasya para prayojya tve pramāṇa abhāvaḥ pi parāstaḥ iti
translated: For this very reason, the absence of any proof of the pradhāna being employed by another is also refuted.

analyzed: sūtre payaḥ mbu vat iti ukte na udāharaṇam ādaraṇīyam
translated: Although the sūtra uses the example of milk and water, that example should not be taken.

analyzed: sthala antare sambhāvanā vyabhicāraḥ ca bhaviṣyataḥ iti āśaṅkā parihāra arthasya vyatireka anavasthiteḥ ca anapekṣa tvāt
translated: To remove the doubt that there may be a possibility of error in another case, the word ādi (beginning with) is used in the subsequent sūtra avyatireka-anavasthiteścānapāyāt (because there is no escape from the non-difference and infinite regress).

analyzed: iti uttara sūtrasya api vyākhyānāya ādi pada prayogaḥ
translated: To explain that subsequent sūtra, the word ādi is used.

analyzed: yat vā payaḥ mbu grahaṇam upalakṣaṇam iti abhipretya ādi padam pratyuktam
translated: Or, the word ādi is used in reply, intending that the mention of milk and water is a mere illustration.

analyzed: uttara sūtram tu kaimutya artham
translated: But the subsequent sūtra is for the purpose of a reductio ad absurdum.

analyzed: cetana pravṛtteḥ api īśvara vyatirekeṇa anavasthiteḥ acetana pravṛtteḥ tad adhīna tvam kimu vācyam iti
translated: Even the activity of conscious beings, apart from God, is not established, so what need be said of the activity of insentient beings being dependent on Him?

analyzed: tad vayākhyānāya cetana acetanasya ca iti uktam
translated: To explain that, of the conscious and insentient is said.

analyzed: kiñca parimāṇāt iti hetuḥ tāvat anaikāntikaḥ
translated: Moreover, the reason because of finiteness is inconclusive.

analyzed: sattva rajaḥ tamasām sāmya avasthā hi prakṛtiḥ ucyate
translated: The state of equilibrium of sattva, rajas, and tamas is called prakrti (primordial matter).

analyzed: sattva ādayaḥ ca parimitāḥ eva
translated: And sattva and the others are indeed finite.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: ap agnīḥ anabhaḥ haṅkṛt mahat tattva guṇatrayaiḥ
translated: Without fire, without space, without ego, with the great principle, the three qualities,

analyzed: kramāt daśa uttaraiḥ
translated: By the ten-fold increase in order.

analyzed: ādi iti
translated: The beginning is in the Purva Mimamsa philosophy.

original: naca prakṛtiravyaktāntaravatīti kathaṃ nānaikāntyam /🔽naca parimitasyāpi mūlaprakṛtitve bādhakamasti /
analyzed: na ca prakṛtiḥ avyakta antaravatī iti katham na anaikāntyam  na ca parimitasya api mūlaprakṛti tve bādhakam asti
translated: And since the primordial nature does not contain another unmanifest, how is there not over-extension?🔽And there is no contradiction in even a limited thing being the primordial cause.

analyzed: sārvatrika kārya anutpatti parimitānām eva kāraṇa tvam
translated: The production of effects everywhere is due to limited causes only.

analyzed: tantu ādiṣu darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen in threads and so on.

analyzed: aparimitasya kṛtsna eka deśa vikalpa anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because the option of the whole and part is not possible for the unlimited.

analyzed: asmākam tu īśvara śaktyā eva upapadyate
translated: For us, it is possible only through the power of God.

analyzed: samanvayāt iti api asat
translated: The argument because of the doctrine of the identity of the effect with the cause is also not correct.

analyzed: yat kāryam yat anugatimat tat tādṛś kāraṇa upetam iti asyāḥ vyāpteḥ avyaktāt vayakta janma aṅgīkāreṇa eva bhagna tvāt
translated: Because the pervasion that whatever effect has the property of inhering in that, it is endowed with a cause of that kind, is broken down itself by accepting the production of the manifest from the unmanifest.

original: śaktitaḥ pravṛtteścetyetadapi na vivakṣitārthasādhakam /🔽antarbhāvitakāryatvameva kāraṇasya śaktirityasya siddhau hi tathā syāt /
analyzed: śaktitaḥ pravṛtteḥ ca iti etat api na vivakṣita artha sādhakam  antar bhāvita kārya tvam eva kāraṇasya śaktiḥ iti asya siddhau hi tathā syāt
translated: The argument because of activity from potentiality is also not a proof of the intended meaning.🔽It would be so only if the potentiality of a cause were established as the inherence of the effect itself.

analyzed: tat ca satkārya vāda nirvāhyam iti
translated: And that is to be accomplished by the doctrine of the existence of the effect.

analyzed: atas eva vibhāga avibhāgau api nirastau
translated: For this very reason, the arguments because of division and non-division are also refuted.

analyzed: vibhāga avibhāgayoḥ eva satkārya vāda siddhaya dhīnayoḥ asattvāt
translated: Because division and non-division themselves, which depend on the establishment of the doctrine of the existence of the effect, do not exist.
