translated: Otherwise, he would have said 'by men' and so on.

analyzed: mohanam vinā iti ubhaya vākyaśeṣaḥ parihāsaḥ
translated: The remainder of both statements is a joke.

analyzed: śāstra praṇetrā suraguruṇā ayogya jana vyāmohanam prayojanam labdham
translated: The preceptor of the gods, the author of the treatise, has obtained the purpose of deluding the unworthy.

analyzed: anyaiḥ ca mithyājñānam
translated: And by others, false knowledge.

analyzed: na atas dhikam iti
translated: Therefore, there is nothing more than this.

analyzed: kim atas yadi evam iti atas āha sva iti
translated: What follows from this if it is so? Therefore, it is said 'one's own' and so on.

analyzed: sva para artha vihīna tvāt
translated: Because it is devoid of one's own and others' purposes.

analyzed: niṣphalam śāstram iti vakṣyamāṇam siṃhāvalokana nyāye
translated: The statement that the treatise is fruitless is followed by the lion's gaze method,

analyzed: k itena anuvartate
translated: as indicated by the word kitya.

analyzed: tat ca upalakṣaṇam
translated: And that is a synecdoche.

analyzed: nirviṣayam ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: Devoid of object should also be seen.

analyzed: viṣaya prayojanavat tvam hi sva para viṣaya prayojanavat tayā vyāptam
translated: For having an object and purpose is pervaded by having one's own and others' objects and purposes.

analyzed: tṛtīya prakāra abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no third type.

analyzed: sarva prakāra parityāgena sāmānya anavasthānāt
translated: Because the general does not exist by abandoning all types.

original: tataśca vyāpikāyāḥ svaparaviṣayaprayojanavattāyā abhāvāttadvayāptaṃ viṣayaprayojanavattvamapi nāstītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca vyāpikāyāḥ sva para viṣaya prayojanavat tāyāḥ abhāvāt tat vayāptam viṣaya prayojanavat tvam api na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: And therefore, due to the absence of the pervaded having one's own and others' objects and purposes, the pervasion that having an object and purpose is also absent. This is the meaning.

analyzed: astu evam viṣaya prayojana śūnyam asmadīyam śāstram
translated: Let our treatise be thus devoid of object and purpose.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas sūtram vyākhyāti sva matena eva iti
translated: What then? Therefore, the aphorism is explained by his own view, saying by his own view alone.

analyzed: sva matena eva niṣphalam
translated: By his own view alone it is fruitless.

analyzed: kim iti unmatta vat śāstram vṛthā pralapati svayam
translated: Why does the treatise babble pointlessly like a madman by itself?

original: yata evaṃ svamatenaiva niṣphalaṃ nirviṣayaṃ ca na kevalaṃ paropapādanameva /
analyzed: yatas evam sva matena eva niṣphalam nirviṣayam ca na kevalam para upapādanam eva
translated: Since it is thus fruitless and devoid of object by his own view alone, not only is it the establishment of others,

analyzed: tasmāt vṛthā viṣaya prayojana śūnyam
translated: therefore it is pointless, devoid of object and purpose.

analyzed: yasmāt vādinā cārvākeṇa prativādibhiḥ ca tad itaraiḥ sarvaiḥ viṣaya prayojana śūnyatayā abhyupagatam
translated: Because it has been accepted by the proponent Cārvāka and by all the opponents other than him as devoid of subject matter and purpose.

analyzed: tasmāt viṣaya prayojana śūnyam eva iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that it is indeed devoid of subject matter and purpose.

analyzed: yasmāt vṛthā tasmāt tat śāstram kim iti svayam prekṣāvān pralapati
translated: Since it is useless, why does the wise one himself speak it?

analyzed: prekṣāvatā na ārambhaṇīyam iti yāvat
translated: It means that it should not be begun by the wise.

original: viṣayaprayojanaśūnyaṃ cārabhamāṇo na laukiko nāpi parīkṣaka ityunmattavadupekṣaṇīyaḥ syāditi /
analyzed: viṣaya prayojana śūnyam ca ārabhamāṇaḥ na laukikaḥ na api parīkṣakaḥ iti unmatta vat upekṣaṇīyaḥ syāt iti
translated: And one who begins what is devoid of subject matter and purpose is neither worldly nor an investigator, so he should be disregarded like a madman.

analyzed: yat vā niṣphalam iti prayojana abhāva abhidhānam
translated: Or, useless means the absence of purpose.

analyzed: vṛthā iti viṣaya abhāva vacanam
translated: In vain means the absence of subject matter.

original: tathācaivaṃ sūtrayojanā /🔽na kevalaṃ paropapādanena kintu svābhyupagame 'pyarthābhāvādanārambhaṇīyaṃ śāstramiti śeṣa iti /
analyzed: tathā ca evam sūtra yojanā  na kevalam para upapādanena kintu sva abhyupagame pi artha abhāvāt anārambhaṇīyam śāstram iti śeṣaḥ iti
translated: And thus the arrangement of the sūtra is as follows.🔽Not only because of establishing others, but also because of the absence of purpose in one's own acceptance, the treatise should not be begun - this is the remainder.

analyzed: artha abhāva hetoḥ asiddhi parihārāya abhyupagame pi iti uktam
translated: In order to avoid the fallacy of unestablished reason regarding the absence of purpose, even in one's own acceptance is stated.

analyzed: nanu ca pramāṇa anurodhi prayojanam
translated: But is the purpose in accordance with the means of knowledge?

analyzed: na punar prayojanam anurudhya aprāmāṇikaḥ yarthaḥ ṅgīkartum ucitaḥ
translated: And it is not proper to accept an object that is not authoritative in accordance with the purpose.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because of overextension.

analyzed: pramāṇam ca pratyakṣam eva na anyat
translated: And the only means of valid knowledge is perception, not any other.

analyzed: na ca evam lokavyavahāra ucchedaḥ
translated: And thus there is no cutting off of worldly usage.

analyzed: sambhāvanayā eva tad upapatteḥ  saṃvādena ca prāmāṇya abhimānāt
translated: Because that is possible even by mere supposition.🔽And because of the belief in validity through agreement.

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa ca dehaḥ eva ātmā upalabhyate
translated: And by perception, the body alone is perceived as the self.

original: gauro 'haṃ jānāmīti /🔽tathāca kālāntarabhāviprayojanānvayinaḥ puruṣasya abhāvātkathaṃ dharmamokṣākhyaṃ prayojanamatīndriyaśca viṣayo 'ṅgīkartuṃ śakyata ityata āha
analyzed: gauraḥ ham jānāmi iti  tathā ca kāla antara bhāvi prayojana anvayinaḥ puruṣasya abhāvāt katham dharma mokṣa ākhyam prayojanam atīndriyaḥ ca viṣayaḥ ṅgīkartum śakyate iti atas āha
translated: I, who am fair, know.

analyzed: dehāt iti
translated: And thus, because of the absence of a person who is connected with the purpose occurring at a later time, how can the purpose called Dharma and liberation, and the object beyond the senses, be accepted? To this he says

analyzed: dehāt anyaḥ nubhavate ātmā bhāti śarīriṇām
translated: The self of embodied beings appears as different from the body to the experiencer,

original: mama deha iti vyaktaṃ mamārtha itivat sadā // / / //
analyzed: mama dehaḥ iti vyaktam mama arthaḥ iti vat sadā
translated: like this is my body and this is my purpose at all times.

analyzed: anubhavataḥ para abhyupagata prāmāṇyena pratyakṣeṇa eva
translated: To the experiencer, by perception itself, whose validity is accepted by others.

original: mama deha iti hyahaṅkārāspadātmasambandhī dehaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: mama dehaḥ iti hi ahaṅkāra āspada ātma sambandhī dehaḥ pratīyate
translated: For the body is cognized as related to the self, which is the basis of the notion of I.

analyzed: na ca anya tā pratītau sambandha pratītiḥ upapadyate
translated: And the cognition of relation is not possible when difference is cognized.

original: yathā mamārtha iti pratītau bhedapratītipūrvaka eva sambandhābhāsa iti /
analyzed: yathā mama arthaḥ iti pratītau bheda pratīti pūrvakaḥ eva sambandha ābhāsaḥ iti
translated: Just as the apparent relation is only preceded by the cognition of difference in the cognition of this is my purpose.

analyzed: nanu evam pratibhāsaḥ eva na asti
translated: But in that case, such an appearance does not exist at all.

original: api tarhi ghaṭasya svarūpamitivadvayavahāramātramiti cenna kalpakābhāvāt /🔽viparītapratīmi
analyzed: api tarhi ghaṭasya svarūpam iti vat vayavahāra mātram iti ced na kalpaka abhāvāt  viparīta pratīmi
translated: If it be said that it is mere usage like the expression 'the form of the jar', no (says the siddhāntin); because there is no reason for such an assumption.

analyzed: tau khalu evam kalpyate
translated: For, the assumption is made on the ground of the appearance of an illusion.

analyzed: na ca evam prakṛte
translated: But it is not so in the case in question.

analyzed: kasyacid kadācid api dehaḥ ham iti pramā bhāvāt
translated: Because there is no valid cognition in anyone at any time that the body is the self.

analyzed: tat idam uktam śarīriṇām sadā iti
translated: This is what is meant by the words 'of embodied beings, it is true' (in the kärikā).

analyzed: atas eva bhramaḥ stu iti nirastam
translated: For this very reason, the objection that the appearance also may be an illusion is set aside.

analyzed: asti gauraḥ ham iti pramā iti ced na
translated: If it be said that there is the valid cognition 'I am fair', no (says the siddhāntin);

analyzed: pratipakṣa tayā bādhaka tva anupapatteḥ
translated: because it cannot be a sublater as being itself a counter-argument.

analyzed: kiñca na ayam deha ātma tā avabhāsaḥ
translated: Moreover, this appearance of the body as the self is not (the appearance of the body as the self);

analyzed: kintu deha dharmasya ātma dharma tā avabhāsaḥ
translated: but it is the appearance of the attribute of the body as the attribute of the self.

analyzed: na ca vyadhikaraṇayoḥ virodhaḥ sti
translated: And there is no contradiction between what belongs to different substrata.

analyzed: tad abhāve katham asau iti ced
translated: If it be asked how it is so in the absence of that (i.e. the appearance of the body as the self),

analyzed: kim etat anumānam arthāpattiḥ vā praśna mātram vā
translated: is it an inference, or a presumption, or a mere question?

analyzed: na prathama dvitīyau
translated: It is neither the first nor the second,

analyzed: apasiddhāntāt
translated: because of the fallacy of the proposition being contrary to fact.

original: sphaṭikajapākusumayorabhedāpratibhāse 'pi taddharmasya tatra pratītidarśanācca /🔽tṛtīye tu vakṣyate /
analyzed: sphaṭika japā kusumayoḥ abheda apratibhāse tad dharmasya tatra pratīti darśanāt ca  tṛtīye tu vakṣyate
translated: And because even in the absence of the appearance of the identity of the crystal and the japā flower, the attribute of one is seen to be present in the other.

analyzed: astu pratītiḥ
translated: In the third (i.e. if it is a mere question), it will be said (that the appearance of the body as the self is not a mere question).🔽Let there be the appearance (of the body as the self).

analyzed: pratyakṣam iti tu kutas
translated: But how can it be perception?

analyzed: abādha pratibhāsasya pratyakṣāt anyasya pareṇa anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because the other [means of valid cognition] which is not perception and has unobstructed appearance is not accepted by the opponent.

analyzed: abhyupagame vā prāmāṇya aparihārāt
translated: Or if it is accepted, because the validity [of that other means of valid cognition] cannot be avoided.

analyzed: a parokṣa tayā anubhavāt ca
translated: And because [the self] is experienced as non-obstructed.

analyzed: tat idam uktam vyaktam iti
translated: This is what is meant by the words clearly [in the root text].

analyzed: na ca tat eva asiddham
translated: And that [self] is not unestablished.

analyzed: liṅga ādi anusandhāna abhāve pi bhāvāt
translated: Because [the self] exists even in the absence of the recollection of inferential marks, etc.

analyzed: anyathā deha pratibhāsasya api tat na syāt
translated: Otherwise, the appearance of the body would not be [established] either.

analyzed: etat api uktam sadā iti
translated: This is also stated by the words existing [in the root text].

analyzed: kecid āhuḥ
translated: Some say:

analyzed: deha ātma bheda jñānam samādhi paripākavatām eva iti
translated: The knowledge of the difference between the body and the self belongs only to those who are well-versed in meditation.

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not so.

original: āvipālagopālaṃ mama deha itrata pratibhāsasyānapalapanīyatvāt /🔽ata evāha śarīriṇāṃ aśarīrā
analyzed: āvipāla gopālam mama dehaḥ pratibhāsasya an apalapanīya tvāt  atas eva āha śarīriṇām aśarīrā
translated: Because the appearance of my body cannot be denied, even for shepherds and cowherds.

analyzed: bhimāninām iti
translated: For this very reason, he says of embodied beings, of disembodied [in the root text].

original: nanvastvātmā dehātiriktastathāpyarthakāmātirikte puruṣārthe tatsādhanādau ca kiṃ mānam /
analyzed: nanu astu ātmā deha atiriktaḥ tathā api artha kāma atirikte puruṣa arthe tad sādhana ādau ca kim mānam
translated: Now, even if the self is distinct from the body, what is the evidence for [the self] being a human goal distinct from wealth and pleasure, and for the means to that [self]?

analyzed: veda ādiḥ āgamaḥ numānam ca iti vadāmaḥ
translated: We say that [the evidence] is scripture such as the Vedas and inference.

analyzed: tasya prāmāṇyam eva kutas iti ced
translated: If it is asked What is the evidence for the validity of that [scripture and inference]?,

analyzed: tatra āha pratyakṣasya eva iti
translated: there he says of perception alone [in the root text].🔽By what is it ascertained that only perception is a means of valid cognition? ...

analyzed: pratyakṣasya eva māna tvam iti kena avasīyate
translated: By whom is it ascertained that perception alone is valid?🔽

analyzed: yat pareṇa abhyupagatam artha ādi tat kutas siddham iti vaktavyam
translated: It should be stated how that which is accepted by others, such as meaning, etc., is established.

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa iti ced
translated: If it is said by perception,

analyzed: pratyakṣasya māna tvam iti eva kena avasīyate
translated: how is it ascertained that perception is valid?

analyzed: tathā ca puruṣa artha tad sādhana mātra asiddhau jagat anīham āpadyeta iti
translated: And thus, if only the means of human goals are not established, the world would become inactive.

analyzed: pratyakṣa jñānam tāvat pratīyate
translated: First of all, perceptual knowledge is cognized.

analyzed: prāmāṇyam ca jñāna grāhaka mātra grāhyam
translated: And validity is to be grasped only by the apprehender of knowledge.

analyzed: atas katham uktaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, how is the fault stated?

analyzed: prāmāṇya paratas tva āvāde pi bādhaka abhāva ādinā pratyakṣa prāmāṇya siddhiḥ iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: Even in the doctrine of the extrinsic validity of perception, the validity of perception is established by the absence of contradiction, etc. Therefore it is said: if it is said, etc.

original: yadi tatsādhakaṃ vedaprāmāṇye na kathaṃ bhavet // / / //
analyzed: yadi tat sādhakam veda prāmāṇye na katham bhavet
translated: If that is the means of establishing it, how could it not be in the case of the validity of the Veda?

original: yadi pratyakṣajñānaprāmāṇyasya jñānagrāhakaṃ vā bādhakābhāvādikaṃ vā sādhakamucyate /
analyzed: yadi pratyakṣa jñāna prāmāṇyasya jñāna grāhakam vā bādhaka abhāva ādikam vā sādhakam ucyate
translated: If the apprehender of knowledge or the absence of contradiction, etc., is said to be the means of establishing the validity of perceptual knowledge,

original: tarhi tadeva vedaprāmāṇyaviṣaye kathaṃ sādhakaṃ na bhavet /
analyzed: tarhi tat eva veda prāmāṇya viṣaye katham sādhakam na bhavet
translated: then how could that very thing not be the means of establishing the validity of the Veda?

analyzed: nahi veda vākyāt jñānam na utpadyate
translated: For knowledge does not arise from Vedic statements.

analyzed: na ca na pratīyate
translated: Nor is it not cognized.

analyzed: atra veda grahaṇam upalakṣaṇam
translated: Here, the mention of the Veda is by way of illustration.

analyzed: atas eva anyā iti sāmānyena vakṣyati
translated: For this very reason, he will say other in the general sense.

analyzed: nanu jñāna grāhakasya prāmāṇya grāhaka tvam iti utsargaḥ
translated: But it is a general rule that the cognition of a cognition implies the cognition of its validity.

analyzed: apavādena tva
translated: But by an exception

analyzed: satya prāmāṇyam api gṛhyate
translated: invalidity is also apprehended.

analyzed: tat katham veda ādi prāmāṇya siddhiḥ
translated: How then is the validity of the Veda, etc. established?

analyzed: paratas tve pi bādhaka abhāvaḥ kutas iti ced
translated: If it be asked how there is absence of contradiction even in the case of extrinsic validity,

analyzed: samam etat pratyakṣe pi
translated: this is equally so in the case of perception also.

original: anupalambhādapavādādyabhāvaḥ pratyakṣasiddha iti cet /🔽tulyametadvedādāvityāha na ceti //🔽nacānyāmānatā kvāpi pramāṇenāvasīyate // / / //
analyzed: anupalambhāt apavāda ādi abhāvaḥ pratyakṣa siddhaḥ iti ced  tulyam etat veda ādau iti āha na ca iti  na ca anya amāna tā kvāpi pramāṇena avasīyate
translated: If it be said that the absence of contradiction, etc. is established by perception because of non-apprehension,🔽this is equally so in the case of the Veda, etc., he says: And nowhere is the invalidity of any means of knowledge ascertained.

analyzed: pratyakṣāt anyayoḥ anumāna āgamayoḥ amāna tā  kvāpi viṣaye
translated: The invalidity of inference and verbal testimony, which are other than perception, is nowhere in any case.

analyzed: yat vā pratyakṣa prāmāṇyam abhyupagacchan praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Or else, one who accepts the validity of perception should be asked:

original: kiṃ tvayānubhūyamānasyaikasyaiva pratyakṣasya mānatvam uta sarvasyāpi pratyakṣasya /
analyzed: kim tvayā anubhūyamānasya ekasya eva pratyakṣasya māna tvam uta sarvasya api pratyakṣasya
translated: Is the validity of only one perception experienced by you, or of all perception?

analyzed: ādye doṣam āha pratyakṣasya eva iti
translated: In the first case, he states the fault: Of perception alone, etc.

original: itareṣāmapi pratyakṣāṇāṃ tattulyasāmagrījanyatve satyekasyaiva pratyakṣasya mānatvamiti kenāvasīyate /
analyzed: itareṣām api pratyakṣāṇām tad tulya sāmagrī janya tve sati ekasya eva pratyakṣasya māna tvam iti kena avasīyate
translated: If the other perceptions also are produced by similar conditions, by what is it ascertained that only one perception is valid?

analyzed: dvitīye doṣam āha pratyakṣasya eva iti
translated: In the second case, he states the fault: Of perception alone, etc.

original: pratyakṣasya mānatvameva sarvamapi pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇamiti kenāvasīyate /🔽anubhūyamānapratyakṣādanyasya pratyakṣasya /
analyzed: pratyakṣasya māna tvam eva sarvam api pratyakṣam pramāṇam iti kena avasīyate  anubhūyamāna pratyakṣāt anyasya pratyakṣasya
translated: All perception is valid - by whom is this ascertained?🔽By another perception which is being experienced, or by the validity of that [perception].

analyzed: tad prāmāṇyasya vā ca avasāyakam na kim api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is nothing at all that ascertains it.

original: parakīyavacanena ceṣyayā vā pratyakṣamavagamya pratyakṣatvena tasya prāmāṇyamavagamyata ityata āha yadīti //
analyzed: parakīya vacanena ceṣyayā vā pratyakṣam avagamya pratyakṣa tvena tasya prāmāṇyam avagamyate iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: Or if it is accepted that perception is understood through the words of others or through desire, and its validity as perception is understood, then he says if [the following verse].

original: pratyakṣasya tatprāmāṇyasya ca sādhakaṃ vacanamanumānaṃ ca yadi pramāṇamiṣyate tarhi vedādiprāmāṇye kathaṃ na bhavet /
analyzed: pratyakṣasya tad prāmāṇyasya ca sādhakam vacanam anumānam ca yadi pramāṇam iṣyate tarhi veda ādi prāmāṇye katham na bhavet
translated: If it is accepted that the words and inference which establish perception and its validity are valid, then how could the validity of the Veda and so on not be [valid]?

analyzed: abhyupagamaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is accepted.

analyzed: evam anumāna āgama prāmāṇyam prati api vikalpaḥ
translated: In the same way, there is an option regarding the validity of inference and scripture.

analyzed: ādyaḥ tu pūrvavat nirastaḥ
translated: But the first [option] has been refuted as before.

analyzed: apasiddhāntaḥ ca adhikaḥ
translated: And there is the additional [fault of] contradicting one's own doctrine.

analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati na ca iti
translated: He refutes the second [option] with And it is not so.

analyzed: anyayoḥ para puruṣa ādi vartinoḥ anumāna āgamayoḥ amāna tā
translated: The invalidity of the other two, inference and scripture, which are in the domain of other people and so on,

analyzed: pūrvavat āśraya ādi asiddheḥ
translated: is due to the non-establishment of the basis and so on, as before.

analyzed: tad sādhaka aṅgīkāre ca vyāghātāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And if the means of establishing that [validity] are accepted, there is contradiction - this is the idea.

analyzed: nanu artha sannikṛṣṭa karaṇa janya tvāt pratyakṣam pramāṇam  anumāna āgamayoḥ atīta ādikam api viṣayīkurvatoḥ tad abhāvāt katham prāmāṇyam iti
translated: Is not perception a means of valid knowledge because it is produced by the sense organs in contact with the object?🔽How can inference and verbal testimony, which have the past etc. as their objects, be means of valid knowledge, since they lack that [contact]?

original: kiṃ yāthārthyameva prāmāṇyaṃ tanniyāmakaśca sannikarṣaḥ anyathātiprasaṅgādityabhiprāyaḥ uta viṣayasannikṛṣṭakaraṇajanyatvaṃ prāmāṇyamiti /
analyzed: kim yāthārthyam eva prāmāṇyam tad niyāmakaḥ ca sannikarṣaḥ anyathā atiprasaṅgāt iti abhiprāyaḥ uta viṣaya sannikṛṣṭa karaṇa janya tvam prāmāṇyam iti
translated: Is the being a means of valid knowledge just the being in accordance with the object, and is the contact [with the object] the regulator of that, because otherwise there would be an overextension [of the means of valid knowledge]? Or is the being produced by the sense organs in contact with the object the being a means of valid knowledge?

original: ādye 'pi kiṃ yathākathañcitsannikarṣo niyāmakaḥ uta saṃyoga eva /
analyzed: ādye pi kim yathā kathañcid sannikarṣaḥ niyāmakaḥ uta saṃyogaḥ eva
translated: Even in the first case, is the contact in any way the regulator, or is it only conjunction?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati na ca iti  evam tarhi anyayoḥ anumāna āgamayoḥ amāna tā na asti
translated: He refutes the first [alternative] with And that is not so.🔽If it is so, then inference and verbal testimony do not have the nature of being a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: avinābhāva ādi sannikarṣasya tatra api sattvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the contact with invariable concomitance etc. exists even in those [two].

analyzed: dvitīye doṣam āha kvāpi iti
translated: In the second [alternative], he states the fault with In some cases.

analyzed: kvāpi pramāṇe cākṣuṣe śrāvaṇe ca
translated: In some cases, in perception, in visual and auditory [perception].

analyzed: na avasīyate na abhyupagamyate ṛtha saṃyukta karaṇa janya tā  pareṇa golaka ādya
translated: The being produced by the sense organs in contact with the object is not ascertained, is not accepted.

analyzed: tiriktasya cakṣuḥ ādeḥ anabhyupagamāt
translated: By the opponent, because of the non-acceptance of the eye etc. apart from the globe etc.

analyzed: tad ātmakasya ca artha saṃyoga abhāvāt
translated: And because of the absence of contact with the object in what has that [globe etc.] as its nature.

analyzed: tatas pratyakṣasya api kasyacid prāmāṇyam na syāt iti
translated: Then, even some perception would not be valid, so it is said.

analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati na ca iti
translated: He refutes the second by saying not so and so on.

analyzed: yāthārthyāt anyā artha sannikṛṣṭa karaṇa janya tā lakṣaṇā māna tā na vaktavyā
translated: The validity characterized by being produced by a sense organ in contact with an object, which is different from being in accordance with reality, should not be stated.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha kvāpi iti
translated: Why? For this reason, he says nowhere and so on.

analyzed: pūrvavat cākṣuṣa ādau avyāpteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is over-extension even in the case of perception, etc., as before.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is a mere illustration.

analyzed: viparyaya ādau ativyāptiḥ ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen that there is over-extension even in the case of error, etc.

analyzed: yāthārthye sati idam lakṣaṇam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this definition is for what is in accordance with reality,

analyzed: tarhi tat eva astu kim viśeṣyeṇa
translated: then let that alone be the definition. What is the use of qualifying it?

analyzed: anumāna ādi vyāvṛtti artham iti ced na  tad aprāmāṇyasya adya api asiddheḥ iti āha na ca iti
translated: If it is argued that this is for the purpose of excluding inference, etc., it is not so.🔽Because the invalidity of those has not been established even today, he says not so and so on.

analyzed: nanu veda ādi arthasya anupambha bādhita tvāt katham tad prāmāṇyam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that since the meaning of the Veda, etc. is contradicted by non-apprehension, how can it be valid, it is not so.

analyzed: veda ādinā eva upalabdheḥ
translated: Because it is apprehended only by the Veda, etc.

analyzed: tad anyena na upalabhyate iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is not apprehended by anything else,

analyzed: tat kim pramāṇa antara saṃvādi tvam prāmāṇyam
translated: then is validity the agreement with another means of knowledge?

analyzed: addhā iti ced tatra āha na ca iti
translated: If it is accepted, then he says not so and so on.

analyzed: pramāṇa antara saṃvāda lakṣaṇā mānatā na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the validity characterized by the agreement with another means of knowledge is not so.

analyzed: kutas na iti atas āha kvāpi iti
translated: Why not? For this reason, he says nowhere and so on.

original: anavasthāprasaṅgāt kvāpi pramāṇe nāvasīyate /🔽yataḥ yadvā kvāpi svasukhādijñāne pramāṇa
analyzed: anavasthā prasaṅgāt kvāpi pramāṇe na avasīyate  yatas yat vā kvāpi sva sukha ādi jñāne
translated: Because of the contingence of infinite regress, no means of valid knowledge is ascertained anywhere.

original: ṇe saṃvāda eva nāvasīyate iti yojyamityalam / /
analyzed: saṃvādaḥ eva na avasīyate iti yojyam iti alam
translated: Or, it should be connected as: because in some cognition of one's own happiness etc., agreement itself is not ascertained as a means of valid knowledge. Enough of this.

analyzed: sūtra artham upasaṃharati sva matena iti  sva matena artha rahitaḥ upekṣyaḥ pakṣaḥ īdṛśaḥ
translated: He concludes the meaning of the aphorism with the words by his own opinion.🔽Such a thesis devoid of purpose should be disregarded by one's own opinion.

analyzed: sva sammatyā eva artha rahitaḥ viṣaya prayojana rahitaḥ
translated: By his own opinion, devoid of purpose, devoid of object and purpose.

analyzed: īdṛśaḥ īśvara ādi atīndriya anabhyupagama lakṣṇaḥ
translated: Such, characterized by the non-acceptance of God and other supersensibles.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām abhyupagama adhikaraṇam
translated: Here ends the chapter on acceptance in the commentary of the revered Nyāyasudhā.
V. The chapter on the person and the stone

original: atha śrīmannyāyasudhāyāṃ puruṣāśmādhikaraṇam //🔽puruṣāśmavad iti cet tathāpi / / / /
analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām puruṣa aśma adhikaraṇam  puruṣa aśma vat iti ced tathā api
translated: Now, in the commentary of the revered Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on the person and the stone.🔽If it is argued that it is like a person and a stone, then also...

analyzed: om puruṣa aśma vat iti ced tathā api om
translated: Om. If it is argued that it is like a person and a stone, then also...

analyzed: atra anīśvatra nirīśvara sāṅkhaya eka deśinām puruṣa upasarjana prakṛti kartṛkatva vādinām matam apākriyate
translated: Here, the opinion of the followers of the Sāṃkhya school who do not accept God, who assert that the world is created by Prakṛi with Puruṣa as a mere accessory, is refuted.

analyzed: nanu evam tarhi tad anantaram eva idam ārambhaṇīyam
translated: If so, then this should have been begun immediately after that.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True.

analyzed: tathā api abhyadhika āśaṅkā anusāreṇa iyam uktiḥ
translated: Nevertheless, this statement is made in accordance with the subsequent doubts.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus.

analyzed: parama cetanasya bhagavataḥ eva sarva kartṛ tvam prāk uktam
translated: It has been said before that the Supreme Conscious Being, the Lord alone, is the creator of all.

analyzed: tasya kevala prakṛti kartṛka tva vādaḥ sākṣāt virodhi iti prathamam apākṛtaḥ
translated: The doctrine that He is the creator only through Primordial Matter is directly contradictory, so it has been refuted first.

analyzed: tatra mā bhūt kevalasya acetanasya pradhānasya jagat kartṛ tvam
translated: There, let it not be that the mere unconscious Primordial Matter is the creator of the world.

original: īśvarānugṛhītasya tu bhaviṣyatītyāśaṅkā dvitīyādhikaraṇe nirastānirākṛtā /🔽mā bhūdacetanasya kartṛtvaṃ kintu śarīrasyaiva caitanyāśrayasya kartṛtvamastvityāśaṅkaya śarīrasya caitanyāśrayatāyogāt punastadavasthaḥ kartṛtvāyoga
analyzed: īśvara anugṛhītasya tu bhaviṣyati iti āśaṅkā dvitīya adhikaraṇe nirastā anirākṛtā  mā bhūt acetanasya kartṛ tvam kintu śarīrasya eva caitanya āśrayasya kartṛ tvam astu iti āśaṅkaya śarīrasya caitanya āśraya tā yogāt punar tad avasthaḥ kartṛ tva ayoga
translated: But it will be for one favored by God - this doubt has been removed in the second section.

analyzed: iti tṛtīye bhihitam
translated: Let it not be that the unconscious is the creator, but let the body alone, which is the abode of consciousness, be the creator - suspecting this, it has been said in the third section that due to the body's unsuitability as the abode of consciousness, the unsuitability of being the creator remains as before.

original: idānīṃ tu kevalasyācetanasya kartṛtvāyoge 'pi cetanasannidhānena tadupapatteḥ kimīśvareṇetyā🔽ṇetyeṣā śaṅkā nirākriyate / /
analyzed: idānīm tu kevalasya acetanasya kartṛ tva ayoge cetana sannidhānena tad upapatteḥ kim īśvareṇa iti ā  ṇā iti eṣā śaṅkā nirākriyate
translated: Now, even though the mere unconscious is unsuitable to be the creator, if that is possible through the presence of consciousness, what is the use of God? - this doubt is being refuted.

original: tanmatarītiḥ sūtra evokteti tadeva vyācaṣṭe sannidhānāditi //
analyzed: tad mata rītiḥ sūtre evā uktā iti tat eva vyācaṣṭe sannidhānāt iti
translated: The method of that view is stated in the aphorism itself, so he explains it: From the presence etc.

analyzed: sannidhānāt cetanasya vartate yadi acetanam
translated: If the unconscious operates due to the presence of consciousness,

analyzed: tathā api abuddhi pūrva tvāt ukta doṣaḥ samaḥ bhavet
translated: Still, because of the absence of intelligence, the stated fault would be the same.

original: yathā khalvacetanameva śarīraṃ cetanasyātmanaḥ sannidhānamātreṇa aśmānayanādikaṃ karoti /
analyzed: yathā khalu acetanam eva śarīram cetanasya ātmanaḥ sannidhāna mātreṇa aśma ānayana ādikam karoti
translated: Just as the insentient body alone, by the mere presence of the sentient self, performs actions like bringing a stone,

analyzed: evam acetanā api prakṛtiḥ puruṣa sannidhānāt mahat ādi kāryam kariṣyati
translated: in the same way, the insentient prakriti will also produce effects like mahat, by the presence of the purusha.

analyzed: tathā ca prayogaḥ
translated: And thus the argument is:

analyzed: mahat ādikam puruṣa upasarjana prakṛti kartṛkam kārya tvāt aśma ānayana ādi vat iti
translated: Mahat and so on are produced by prakriti, which is subordinate to the purusha, because they are effects, like bringing a stone and so on.

analyzed: evam ca kim īśvareṇa iti śaṅkā arthaḥ
translated: And thus, what is the use of God? This is the meaning of the objection.

analyzed: yadi api evam abhyadhikam āśaṅkitam tathā api racanā anupapatteḥ iti ukta doṣaḥ samaḥ bhavet
translated: Even though thus a greater [objection] is raised, still the stated fault of the impossibility of arrangement would be the same.

analyzed: na parihṛtaḥ bhavet
translated: It would not be avoided.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: a buddhi pūrva tvāt
translated: Because of the absence of intelligence.

analyzed: prakṛteḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Prakriti is implied.

analyzed: buddhiḥ pūrvā yasya tat buddhi pūrvam
translated: That which has intelligence as the prior cause is with intelligence as the prior cause.

analyzed: jñāna icchā prayatnāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Knowledge, desire, and effort are meant.

original: na vidyate buddhipūrvaṃ yasya tattathoktaṃ tasya bhāvastattvam /
analyzed: na vidyate buddhi pūrvam yasya tat tathā uktam tasya bhāvaḥ tattvam
translated: That which does not have intelligence as the prior cause is said to be so. The state of that is the nature.

analyzed: tasmāt
translated: Therefore.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: jñāna icchā prayatnavat tvam hi kartṛ tvam
translated: For having knowledge, desire, and effort is being an agent.

analyzed: na ca puruṣa sannidhāne pi
translated: And even in the presence of the soul,

analyzed: na prakṛteḥ buddhimat tvam sambhavati
translated: the intelligence of Nature is not possible.

analyzed: acetana tva aṅgīkāra virodhāt
translated: Because it contradicts the acceptance of its being non-intelligent.

analyzed: na ca buddhai abhāve tad kāryayoḥ icchā prayatnayoḥ api sambhavaḥ
translated: And if there is no intelligence, then desire and effort, which are its effects, are also not possible.

analyzed: tathā ca acetanasya kartṛ tva pratijñā vyāhatā eva iti
translated: And thus the declaration of the non-intelligent being the agent is contradicted.

analyzed: śarīrasya aśma ānayana ādi kartṛ tvam nidarśitam
translated: But the agency of the body, which is a means of the soul, in bringing the stone etc. has been shown.

analyzed: tat katham etat im iti ced na
translated: How is this so? If this is asked, it is not so.

analyzed: śarīrasya api ukta rītyā kartṛ tva asammateḥ
translated: Because the agency of the body is not accepted in the manner stated.

analyzed: dūṣaṇa antaram ca dṛṣṭānte darśayitum sūtram
translated: And in order to show another fault in the example, there is a sutra:

analyzed: om aṅgitva anupapatteḥ om
translated: Om. Because of the impossibility of being the principal.

analyzed: iti  tat vayācaṣṭe aṅgi tvāt iti
translated: This is the sutra.🔽He explains it as Because of the impossibility of being the principal.

analyzed: aṅgi tva anupapatteḥ ca  aṅgi tvam puruṣasya eva sarvaiḥ api anubhūyate
translated: And because of the impossibility of being the principal.🔽The state of being the principal is experienced by all as belonging to the soul alone.

analyzed: tad aṅga tva uktitaḥ ca eva syāt sarvasya apalāpakaḥ
translated: And because of the statement of its being a part, there would be the denial of everything.
The word and is for the purpose of including another fault.
The word only is for the purpose of clarifying the question that will be asked.

analyzed: aṅgi tvam pradhāna tvam śarīram prati iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The state of being the principal, which is being the primary, in relation to the body, is the remainder.

analyzed: tad aṅga tva uktitaḥ tasya upasarjana tva aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because it is said to be a part of that, its subordination is accepted.

analyzed: syāt sāṅkhayaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is it would be Sāṅkhya.

analyzed: nanu etat prakṛta viruddham
translated: But this is contrary to the subject matter.

analyzed: parameśvarasya hi sarva kartṛ tvam upapādayitum ayam ārambhaḥ
translated: For this beginning is to establish the supreme Lord as the doer of all.

original: tathāca aśmānayanādikārye jīvasya prādhānyopapādanaṃ kathaṃ na prakaraṇaviruddhamiti cenna /
analyzed: tathā ca aśma ānayana ādi kārye jīvasya prādhānya upapādanam katham na prakaraṇa viruddham iti ced na
translated: And so, how is the establishment of the individual soul as the principal in the action of bringing the stone not contrary to the context? If it is argued thus, it is not so.

original: jīvagatasya amukhyasya kartṛtvasya nirāsa eva yadā pramāṇavirodhaḥ tadā kimu vaktavyaṃ
analyzed: jīva gatasya amukhyasya kartṛ tvasya nirāsaḥ eva yadā pramāṇa virodhaḥ tadā kimu vaktavyam
translated: When there is contradiction with the means of knowledge in the mere denial of the secondary agency belonging to the individual soul, then what need be said

analyzed: sarva kartuḥ īśvarasya apalāpaḥ iti etad pradarśanāya eva sūtrakṛtā jīvasya aṅgi tva upapādanāt iti āśayavān āha kimu iti
translated: about the denial of the supreme Lord, the doer of all? In order to demonstrate this very thing, the author of the aphorisms has established the individual soul as a subordinate agent. With this intention, he says what need be said.

analyzed: kimu sarveśvarasya asya hi apalāṣāt yatas khilam
translated: What need be said about the denial of this all-powerful one, from whom all...

analyzed: asya sarva kartṛ tvena pratipipādayiṣitasya
translated: Of this [Lord], who is intended to be established as the doer of all.

analyzed: uttara sūtre ca asya aṅgīkāra vāda tvam sphuṭībhaviṣyati iti hi śabdena sūcayati
translated: And in the next aphorism, its being a statement of acceptance will become clear. This is indicated by the word hi.

original: kathaṃ jīvasya prādhānyanirāsādapyatiśayeneśvaranirāsaḥ pramāṇaviruddha ityata āha yata iti //
analyzed: katham jīvasya prādhānya nirāsāt api atiśayena īśvara nirāsaḥ pramāṇa viruddhaḥ iti atas āha yatas iti
translated: How does the denial of God become even more contrary to valid means of knowledge by the denial of the primacy of the individual soul? To this he says because etc.

original: yataḥ kāraṇādakhilaṃ pramāṇaṃ yogipratyakṣānumānāgamātmakaṃ sarvakartāramīśvaraṃ pratipādayati tasmāditi pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: yatas kāraṇāt akhilam pramāṇam yogi pratyakṣa anumāna āgama ātmakam sarva kartāram īśvaram pratipādayati tasmāt iti pūrveṇa sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous statement: because all means of knowledge, consisting of yogic perception, inference, and scripture, point to God as the creator of all.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām puruṣa aśma adhikaraṇam
translated: Here ends the chapter on the Person and the Stone in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.
VI. The Chapter on Inference Otherwise

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām anyathā anumiti adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on Inference Otherwise.

analyzed: anyathā anumitau ca jña śakti viyogāt
translated: And in the inference otherwise, due to the absence of the power of knowledge...

analyzed: om anyathā anumitau ca jña śakti viyogāt om
translated: Om. And in the inference otherwise, due to the absence of the power of knowledge.

analyzed: prakṛti upasarjana puruṣa kartṛ tva vādinām nirīśvara sāṅkhaya eka deśinām matam atra nirākriyate
translated: The view of those who say that the soul is the agent with prakriti as a subordinate factor, and who are partial to the atheistic Sankhya, is refuted here.

analyzed: tathā hi aśma ānayana pra
translated: To this end, the bringing of a stone...

analyzed: na ādi pravṛttau tāvat puruṣasya prādhānyam śarīrasya ca upasarjana tvam anubhava siddham iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the primacy of the soul and the subordination of the body are established by experience in the beginningless activity.

analyzed: tathā ca tad dṛṣṭāntena mahat ādi kāryam api prakṛti upasarjana puruṣa kartṛkam anumīyate
translated: And thus, by that example, the effect beginning with Mahat is also inferred to be produced by the Purusha with Prakriti as the subordinate cause.

analyzed: puruṣasya ca cetana tvena na kartṛ tva anupapattiḥ
translated: And since the Purusha is conscious, there is no impossibility of its being the agent.

analyzed: suṣupti ādau ca kartṛ tva anupalambhāt prakṛtiḥ upasarjana bhūtā aṅgīkaraṇīyā
translated: And since agency is not perceived in deep sleep and so on, Prakriti is to be accepted as the subordinate cause.

analyzed: evam ca kim īśvareṇa iti
translated: And thus, what is the use of God?

original: atra vaktavyaṃ kiṃ puruṣasyaikākinaḥ kutrāpi svātantryaṃ nāsti uta astīti /
analyzed: atra vaktavyam kim puruṣasya ekākinaḥ kutra api svātantryam na asti uta asti iti
translated: Here it should be said whether the Purusha has no independence anywhere, or it does.

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayitum sūtram vyācaṣṭe aṅgi tvam iti
translated: To refute the first, the aphorism is explained as follows:

analyzed: aṅgi tvam yadi tasya eva svātantryam ced na ca akhilam
translated: If it has the status of the principal, and if it has independence, but not in everything,

analyzed: tad preraṇe pi aśakta tvāt svatantraḥ nyaḥ hi apekṣitaḥ
translated: then, even in its instigation, it is incapable, and another independent one is required.

analyzed: yadi puruṣasya eva aṅgi
translated: If the Purusha has the status of the principal,

analyzed: sya aṅgi tvam prādhānyam kartṛ tvam iti yāvat
translated: then it has the status of the principal, which means it is the primary, the agent.

analyzed: prakṛteḥ tu upasarjana tvam eva iti pūrva matāt anyathā anumīyate
translated: But Prakriti has only the status of the subordinate cause, so it is inferred differently from the previous view.

original: tatrāpi ca puruṣasyākhilaṃ svātantryaṃ nāstīti pakṣo yadyaṅgīkriyate tadā svatantro 'nyaḥ parameśvaro 'ṅgīkaraṇīya eva syāt /
analyzed: tatra api ca puruṣasya akhilam svātantryam na asti iti pakṣaḥ yadi aṅgīkriyate tadā svatantraḥ parameśvaraḥ ṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ eva syāt
translated: And even there, if the view is accepted that the Purusha does not have complete independence, then another independent Supreme Lord would have to be accepted.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: prakṛti preraṇe puruṣasya aśakta tvāt
translated: Because the Spirit is incapable of instigating the Nature.

analyzed: mā bhūt tāvat kārya antara artham īśvara apekṣā
translated: Let it be that there is no need of God for any other purpose than that of the effect.

analyzed: tathā api prakṛti preraṇa artham apekṣaṇīyaḥ eva asau iti apeḥ arthaḥ
translated: Yet the sense of the word 'ca' is that He is to be depended upon for the instigation of the Nature.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is meant.

original: na tāvatsattāmātreṇa saṃyogamātreṇa vā pradhānasya kartāraṃ puruṣaṃ pratyupasarjanatvam /
analyzed: na tāvat sattā mātreṇa saṃyoga mātreṇa vā pradhānasya kartāram puruṣam prati upasarjana tvam
translated: The Spirit is not subordinate to the Nature merely by its existence or mere conjunction with it.

analyzed: supti pralaya ādau api prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would lead to absurdity even in sleep and dissolution.

analyzed: kintu karaṇa tva ādinā
translated: But it is by its being an instrument, etc.

analyzed: na ca kartrā aprayujyamānasya karaṇa tva ādikam dṛṣṭam
translated: And the state of being an instrument, etc. is not seen in that which is not employed by the agent.

analyzed: na ca tat eva tad preraṇe karaṇa ādi
translated: And that itself cannot be the instrument, etc. in the instigation of that.

analyzed: sva vṛtti virodhāt
translated: Because that would be self-contradictory.

original: tathāca prakṛtinirapekṣasya puruṣasya kvāpi vyāpārāsāmarthye 'vaśyamanyena sahakāriṇā bhāvyam /
analyzed: tathā ca prakṛti nirapekṣasya puruṣasya kvāpi vyāpāra asāmarthye vaśyam anyena sahakāriṇā bhāvyam
translated: And thus, when the Spirit, independent of the Nature, is incapable of any operation, it must certainly have some other co-operator.

analyzed: na ca asau api evaṃvidhaḥ eva
translated: And that also cannot be of the same kind.

analyzed: tasya api sahakāri antara apekṣāyām anavasthā prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if that also needs another co-operator, there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: atas svatantraḥ eva asau aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: Therefore, He must be accepted as independent.

original: sa eva ceśvara iti kathamasau nābhyupagamyata iti / /
analyzed: saḥ eva ca īśvaraḥ iti katham asau na abhyupagamyate iti
translated: And He alone is God. How then is He not accepted?

analyzed: dvitīyam niṣedhati na ca iti
translated: He refutes the second view with the word 'ca' (and).

analyzed: na ca svātantryam asya eva
translated: And it is not independent of itself.

analyzed: tathā sati prakṛti anapekṣa tva prasaṅgena asya
translated: In that case, because of the consequence of being independent of the primordial matter,

analyzed: sva siddhānta virodha āpatteḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: there is the fault of contradicting one's own doctrine. This is the idea.

analyzed: anena vipratiṣedhāt ca iti sūtram vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: By this, the sutra And because of contradiction is explained.

analyzed: vipratiṣedhāt ca asamañjasam
translated: And because of contradiction, it is incoherent.

analyzed: sūtrasya artha antaram āha pratyakṣa ādi iti
translated: The sutra is explained in another way by perception etc.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi virodhataḥ  pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇaiḥ hi puruṣasya asvātantryam sarvadā
translated: Because of contradiction with perception etc.

analyzed: palabhyate  prakāra antareṇa vyācaṣṭe hita iti  hita ākṛti ādi doṣāt ca
translated: For the independence of the person is always perceived everywhere by the means of knowledge such as perception.🔽He explains in another way by welfare etc.🔽And because of the fault of doing what is harmful etc.

analyzed: ādi padena āhita kriyā upādīyate
translated: By the word etc. harmful action is included.

analyzed: evam pañca matāni nirākṛtya upasaṃharati bhadram iti
translated: Having thus refuted the five views, he concludes by welfare etc.

analyzed: bhadram na anīśvaram matam
translated: Welfare is not the view of the Lord.

analyzed: pātañjala abhimatasya īśvarasya īśvara lakṣaṇa abhāvāt tat api anīśvaram eva matam iti
translated: Because the Lord accepted by the followers of Patanjali lacks the characteristics of the Lord, that view is also not about the Lord.

original: nanvanyānyapi bhinnakasaṃsāramocakādīnyanīśvarāṇi matāni santi tāni kuto na nirākriyante /
analyzed: nanu anyāni api bhinnaka saṃsāra mocaka ādīni anīśvarāṇi matāni santi tāni kutas na nirākriyante
translated: But are there not other views of non-lords such as the liberator from worldly existence and others? Why are they not refuted?

original: uktadoṣaireva nirastatvāt abhyadhikāśaṅkābhāvāccetyāha saṃsāriṇa iti // /🔽saṃsāriṇo 'nyaṃ sarveśaṃ sarvaśaktimanaupamam /🔽cetanācetanasyāsya sattvādestadadhīnatām /
analyzed: ukta doṣaiḥ eva nirasta tvāt abhyadhika āśaṅkā bhāvāt ca iti āha saṃsāriṇaḥ iti  saṃsāriṇaḥ sarva īśam sarva śaktim anaupamam  cetana acetanasya asya sattva ādeḥ tad adhīna tām
translated: Because they have been refuted by the previously stated faults and because there is no greater doubt, he says of the transmigrating beings and so on.🔽They do not accept the dependence of this world of the conscious and the insentient on Him, who is other than the transmigrating beings, the Lord of all, all-powerful, incomparable,

original: nāṅgīkurvanti ye teṣāṃ sarveṣāṃ ca samā ime // / / //
analyzed: na aṅgīkurvanti ye teṣām sarveṣām ca samāḥ ime
translated: of all these who do not accept, these faults are the same.

analyzed: saṃsāri padam īśvara atirikta upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word transmigrating beings indicates those other than God.

analyzed: sarva īśam iti viśeṣya padam
translated: Lord of all is the qualifying word.

analyzed: tena na paunaruktayam
translated: Therefore there is no repetition.

analyzed: upamā eva upamam
translated: Upam means comparison.

analyzed: svārthikaḥ ṇ  na asti aupamam yasya asau anaupamaḥ
translated: The suffix aṇ is used in the sense of its own meaning.🔽That which does not have upam is anoupama.

analyzed: yat vā upamāyāḥ ayam aupamaḥ
translated: Or, this is the upam of upamā.

analyzed: sa upamaḥ iti yāvat
translated: As much as to say having upam.

analyzed: tatas nañ samāsaḥ
translated: Therefore it is a negative compound.

analyzed: asya prapañcasya
translated: Of this world.

analyzed: ime kathitāḥ doṣāḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is these faults are stated.

original: na kevalaṃ sarveśaṃ svarūpeṇānaṅgīrkurvatāmime doṣāḥ /🔽kintu tamaṅgīkṛtyāpi jīvādya
analyzed: na kevalam sarva īśam sva rūpeṇa anaṅgīḥ kurvatām ime doṣāḥ  kintu tam aṅgīkṛtya api jīva adya
translated: Not only are these faults for those who do not accept God as the nature,

analyzed: nya tva ādi viśeṣaṇāni tasya an aṅgīkurvatām api
translated: but also for those who accept Him but do not accept the qualifications such as being different from the individual soul and so on.

analyzed: tathātve phalataḥ tasya anīśvara tvāt iti
translated: Because in that case, He would not be God in effect.

analyzed: kim atas yadi evam anīśvara matam asamañjasam iti atas āha tasmāt iti
translated: What follows from this if the doctrine of non-God is not well-reasoned? Therefore, he says tasmāt (therefore).

analyzed: tasmāt śruti pramāṇena yuktibhiḥ ca paraḥ hariḥ
translated: Therefore, by the authority of the Vedas and by reasonings, the highest Hari,

analyzed: aṅgīkā yartamaḥ nityaḥ sarvaiḥ api su niścitam
translated: should be accepted as eternal by all, and well ascertained.

analyzed: na parapakṣa nirāsa mātreṇa sva pakṣa siddhiḥ iti atas śruti pramāṇena ityādi uktam
translated: The establishment of one's own position is not merely by refuting the opponent's position. Hence it is said by the authority of the Vedas etc.

analyzed: paraḥ utkṛṣṭaḥ ukta viśeṣaṇa upapannaḥ
translated: The highest is the superior one endowed with the mentioned qualities.

analyzed: nityaḥ iti sāmarthyāt aṅgīkārasya viśeṣaṇam
translated: Eternal is the qualification of acceptance by implication.

analyzed: sarvadā iti yāvat
translated: Up to all times.

analyzed: niścayasya sva para pakṣa sādhana upālambha atirikta anapekṣa tvāt prāmāṇika niścayasya ca asamīcīna tva ayogāt su niścitam iti uktam
translated: Since ascertainment is independent of establishing one's own position and refuting the opponent's position, and since an authoritative ascertainment cannot be incorrect, it is said to be well ascertained.

original: prathamādhyāyavyutpāditena parapakṣopālambhena ca yathālakṣitaṃ brahma siddhamityāśayaḥ /
analyzed: prathama adhyāya vyutpāditena parapakṣa upālambhena ca yathā lakṣitam brahma siddham iti āśayaḥ
translated: The intention is that Brahman, as characterized by the refutation of the opponent's position explained in the first chapter, is established.

analyzed: nanu evam tarhi uttara adhikaraṇānām ānarambhaḥ eva
translated: If it is so, then the subsequent sections are meaningless.

analyzed: nirākariṣyamāṇaiḥ u
translated: Even by those to be refuted,

analyzed: rapi ukta viśeṣaṇasya īśvarasya anabhyupagata tvāt iti ced
translated: the God endowed with the mentioned qualities is not accepted. If this is argued,

analyzed: satyam
translated: it is true.

analyzed: tathā api tad matānām atyanta heya tā pradarśanāya dūṣaṇa antarāṇi vyutpādanayitum uttaraḥ granthaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, the subsequent text is to explain the faults in their views in order to show that they are to be completely rejected.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām anyathā anumiti adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the inference of other things in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.
VI. The Chapter on Vaiśeṣika

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām vaiśeṣika adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on Vaiśeṣika.

analyzed: mahat dīrgha vat vā hrasva parimaṇḍalābhyām
translated: Or like large and long, from small and round.

original: oṃ mahaddīrghavadvā hrasvaparimaṇḍalābhyām oṃ //🔽nityajñānaprayatnecchaṃ saṅkhayadyairapi pañcabhiḥ /
analyzed: om mahat dīrghavat vā hrasva parimaṇḍalābhyām om  nitya jñāna prayatna iccham saṅkha yad yaiḥ api pañcabhiḥ
translated: Om. Like large and long, from small and round. Om.

analyzed: yuktam īśam vadanti anye
translated: Others say that the Lord is endowed with eternal knowledge, effort, and will, and also with the five subtle elements.🔽...

analyzed: atra paramāṇu ārambha vādinām vaiśeṣika ādīnām matam apākriyate
translated: Here, the view of the Vaiśeṣika and others who advocate the creation from atoms is refuted.

analyzed: nanu vaiśeṣika ādayaḥ parameśvaram aṅgīkurvanti eva
translated: But do not the Vaiśeṣika and others accept the Supreme Lord?

original: tatkathaṃ tannirāsāyādhikaraṇārambha ityāśaṅkaya yadyapīśvaraṃ svarūpeṇāṅgīkuvarnti tathāpi taddharmeṣu sukhādiṣu vipratipadyanta eva /
analyzed: tat katham tad nirāsāya adhikaraṇa ārambhaḥ iti āśaṅkaya yadi api īśvaram svarūpeṇa aṅgīkuvarnti tathā api tad dharmeṣu sukha ādiṣu vipratipadyante eva
translated: How then is this section begun for the purpose of refuting Him? Anticipating this doubt, although they accept the Lord in His nature, they still disagree about His attributes such as bliss,

original: tathā sṛṣṭipralayādividhiṃ cānyathā manyanta ityato yuktastannirāsāyādhikaraṇārambha ityāśayavāṃstanmatamupanyasyati nityeti //
analyzed: tathā sṛṣṭi pralaya ādi vidhim ca anyathā manyante iti atas yuktaḥ tad nirāsāya adhikaraṇa ārambhaḥ iti āśayavān tad matam upanyasyati nitya iti
translated: and they think differently about the injunctions of creation, dissolution, and so on. Therefore, the beginning of this section for the purpose of refuting them is appropriate. With this intention, he presents their view, saying eternal and so on.

analyzed: īśam vadantaḥ nye iti āhuḥ iti vakṣyamāṇena anvayaḥ
translated: Others say that God has eight qualities, as will be stated later.

analyzed: nityā jñāna prayatna icchā yasya asau tathā uktaḥ
translated: He who has eternal knowledge, effort, and desire is said to be such.

analyzed: saṅkhaya ādyaiḥ saṅkhaya a parimāṇa pṛthak tava saṃyoga vibhāgaiḥ
translated: By number, etc., he is endowed with number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction.

analyzed: sa avadhāraṇam ca etat
translated: And this is restrictive.

analyzed: evam aṣṭaguṇakam eva vadantaḥ iti
translated: They say that he has exactly eight qualities.

analyzed: nitya dravya āśritāni ekatva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇāni nityāni eva dvitva dvipṛthaktava ādīni
translated: The unities, twonesses, separateness, and dimensions that inhere in eternal substances are eternal. The twonesses, twosome separateness, etc.,

original: saṃyogavibhāgau ca savartrānityā eveti siddhatvātsaṅkhayādau vidyamāno 'pi nityānityavibhāgo nābhihitaḥ /
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāgau ca savartrā anityāḥ eva iti siddha tvāt saṅkhaya ādau nitya anitya vibhāgaḥ na abhihitaḥ
translated: and conjunction and disjunction are everywhere non-eternal. Since this is well known, the distinction between eternal and non-eternal in number, etc., is not stated, although it exists.

analyzed: jñāna ādīnām tu jīva āśritānām anitya tvāt atra nitya tva saṅkīrtanam
translated: But since knowledge, etc., which inhere in the soul, are non-eternal, their eternality is mentioned here.

analyzed: yadi api kecid īśvaram ṣaḍguṇam ācakṣate
translated: Although some call God to have six qualities,

analyzed: tathā api na tat paramam matam iti aṣṭaguṇa tvam eva upanyastam
translated: nevertheless that is not the highest opinion, so only the eight qualities are stated.

analyzed: evam ātreyasya jñāna anitya tvam api nā upanyastam
translated: Similarly, the non-eternality of knowledge of Atreya is not stated.

analyzed: yat vā nitya tva saṅkīrtanam guṇa antara abhāve yukti tvena kṛtam
translated: Or, the mention of eternality is made as a reason for the absence of other qualities.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Indeed, it is so.

analyzed: jīvātmānaḥ buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharma bhāvanābhiḥ navabhiḥ viśeṣa guṇaiḥ yuktāḥ
translated: The individual souls are endowed with nine specific qualities: cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, merit, demerit, and impression.

analyzed: tatra nitya yathārtha jñānasya moha abhāvāt tad prabhavasya dveṣasya abhāvaḥ
translated: Among them, due to the absence of delusion in eternal and true knowledge, there is an absence of hatred that arises from it.

analyzed: tad abhāve tad mūlayoḥ dharma ādyayoḥ abhāvaḥ
translated: In its absence, there is an absence of merit and demerit that are rooted in it.

analyzed: icchāyāḥ api moha abhāvena arāga rūpa tvāt na dharma ādi kāraṇa tvam
translated: Desire also, being of the nature of attachment due to the absence of delusion, is not the cause of merit etc.

original: dharmādyabhāve ca tatkāryayoḥ sukhaduḥkhayorabhāva eva /🔽nityajñānatvādeva smṛtyasambhavena kalpakābhāvādbhāvanāyā apyabhāva iti /
analyzed: dharma ādi abhāve ca tad kāryayoḥ sukha duḥkhayoḥ abhāvaḥ eva  nitya jñāna tvāt eva smṛti asambhavena kalpaka abhāvāt bhāvanāyāḥ api abhāvaḥ iti
translated: And in the absence of merit etc., there is an absence of pleasure and pain which are their effects.🔽And due to eternality and knowledge itself, there is an absence of impression also due to the absence of memory and the absence of an instrument.

original: athavā nityatvena jñānādīnāmakhaṇḍatvaṃ sūcayati / /🔽evamapīśvaraviṣayāṃ vipratipattimupanyasya sṛṣṭiviṣayāmupanyasyati tadiccheti //
analyzed: athavā nitya tvena jñāna ādīnām akhaṇḍa tvam sūcayati  evam api īśvara viṣayām vipratipattim upanyasya sṛṣṭi viṣayām upanyasyati tat icchā iti
translated: Or, by eternality, it indicates the indivisibility of knowledge etc.🔽Thus, having presented the dispute regarding God, he presents the dispute regarding creation with the words It is impelled by His will.

analyzed: tad icchā dṛṣṭa coditāḥ
translated: Impelled by His will.

analyzed: paramāṇavaḥ catur vargāḥ saṃyujyante dviśas khilāḥ
translated: All the atoms of the four classes combine in pairs.

analyzed: mahāpralaye hi vakṣyamāṇaḥ nitya vargaḥ nityāḥ ca dharma adharma saṃskāra ādayaḥ vatiṣṭhante
translated: In the great dissolution, the eternal class that will be mentioned later, and the non-eternal dharmas, adharmas, impressions etc. remain.

original: tato brahmavarṣaśatānte prāṇināṃ bhogabhūtaye maheśvarasya sisṛkṣā sañjāyate /
analyzed: tatas brahmavarṣa śata ante prāṇinām bhoga bhūtaye maheśvarasya sisṛkṣā sañjāyate
translated: Then, at the end of a hundred Brahmic years, for the enjoyment of living beings, the desire to create of Maheśvara arises.

original: tayā ca sarvātmagatā dharmādharmalakṣaṇādṛṣṭādayo labdhavṛttayo bhavanti /
analyzed: tayā ca sarva ātma gatāḥ dharma adharma lakṣaṇa adṛṣṭa ādayaḥ labdha vṛttayaḥ bhavanti
translated: And by that, the dharmas and adharmas characterized as unseen, etc., which reside in all souls, become operative.

analyzed: tatas tad icchayā sisṛkṣā lakṣaṇa īśvara icchayā adṛṣṭaiḥ adṛṣṭa vat ātma saṃyogaiḥ ca iti yāvat
translated: Then, by His will, by the will of Maheśvara characterized as desire to create, the unseen [forces] and the unseen [forces] resembling the soul's conjunctions, up to that extent.

analyzed: coditāḥ preritāḥ
translated: Are impelled, are urged on.

analyzed: kriyāvantaḥ iti yāvat
translated: Are endowed with action, up to that extent.

original: prāk pravibhaktatayāvasthitāḥ paramāṇavaścaturguṇāḥ pāthirvāḥ pāthasīyāstaijasā vāyavīyāśca dviśaḥ saṃyujyante /
analyzed: prāk pravibhakta tayā avasthitāḥ paramāṇavaḥ caturguṇāḥ pāthirvāḥ pāthasīyāḥ taijasāḥ vāyavīyāḥ ca dviśas saṃyujyante
translated: The atoms, which were previously existing in a divided state, having four qualities, the earthly, watery, fiery, and airy, unite in pairs.

original: atra paramāṇava ityevokte manasāmapi grahaṇaṃ syāt /
analyzed: atra paramāṇavaḥ iti eva ukte manasām api grahaṇam syāt
translated: If only atoms were mentioned, the mind would also be included.

analyzed: teṣām saṃyoga sadbhāve vakṣyamāṇam dravya ārambhaka tvam gagana vat asparśavat tvāt ayuktam
translated: Even though they have conjunction, it is not proper for them to be the cause of the origin of substance, like the sky, because of their being devoid of touch.

analyzed: atas tad vayāvṛttaye catur vargāḥ iti uktam
translated: Therefore, in order to exclude that, of the four classes is said.

original: yadvā sajātīyasaṃyoga eva dravyārambhako na tvanya iti anena sūcayati /
analyzed: yat vā sajātīya saṃyogaḥ eva dravya ārambhakaḥ na tu anyaḥ iti anena sūcayati
translated: Or, by this [verse] he indicates that only a conjunction of homogeneous [atoms] is the cause of the origin of substance, not any other.

analyzed: akhilāḥ iti
translated: All [atoms].

analyzed: dviśas saṃyoge niyama vacanāt
translated: Because of the restrictive statement in the conjunction of pairs.

original: ye paramāṇavo dravyārambhāya saṃyujyante te 'khilā dviśo dvau dvāveveti / /
analyzed: ye paramāṇavaḥ dravya ārambhāya saṃyujyante te khilāḥ dviśas dvau dvau eva iti
translated: Those atoms which combine for the production of a substance, all of them in pairs, only two, two.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha paramāṇu iti
translated: What then? Therefore he says: with two atoms, etc.

analyzed: paramāṇu dvayena eva dvayaṇukam nāma jāyate
translated: A dyad named dvyaṇuka is produced with only two atoms.

analyzed: dvayaṇuka trayeṇa tryaṇukam taiḥ caturbhiḥ tad ātmakam
translated: A triad named try-aṇuka with three dyads, and with four of those, a tetrad having their nature.

analyzed: tatas tu aniyamena eva khaṇḍa avayavinām bhavaḥ
translated: Then, without any restriction, the production of parts of wholes.

analyzed: tatas ca aniyamena eva sarva avayavi sambhavaḥ
translated: And from that, without any restriction, the production of all wholes.

analyzed: paramāṇu puñja vādam pariṇāma vādam aniyama vādam ca evaśabdena vyāvartayati
translated: With the word eva he rejects the theory of a heap of atoms, the theory of evolution, and the theory of unrestricted production.

analyzed: paramāṇu dvayena eva  na tu nirantara tayā utpanna paramāṇu dvayam
translated: With only two atoms.🔽But not two atoms produced without interval.

analyzed: nā api paramāṇu dvayam eva saṃyuktam āsādita pariṇāma viśeṣam
translated: Nor even two atoms combined, having attained a particular evolution.

analyzed: na ca traya ādinā iti  jāyate iti asatkārya vādam sūcayati
translated: And not with three or more.🔽Is produced. This indicates the doctrine of non-existent effects.

analyzed: jāti apekṣayā ekavacanam
translated: The singular is used with reference to the universal.

original: tataśca saṃyuktasajātīyaparamāṇudvayaistato 'tyantabhinnāni tatsamavetāni prāgasantyeva dvayaṇukanāmakāni dravyāṇyutpadyanta ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tatas ca saṃyukta sajātīya paramāṇu dvayaiḥ tatas tyanta bhinnāni tad samavetāni prāk asanti eva dvayaṇuka nāmakāni dravyāṇi utpadyante iti arthaḥ
translated: Then, from the two united atoms of the same kind, the substances named dyads, which are absolutely different from them and which were previously non-existent, come into existence, inhering in them. This is the meaning.

analyzed: dvayaṇuka trayeṇa tryaṇukam jāyate iti anurvate
translated: A triad is produced from three dyads.

analyzed: eva iti ca
translated: The word 'eva' (only).

analyzed: atra api pūrvavat vayākhyānam
translated: The explanation here is the same as before.

analyzed: aṇu tva parimāṇasya paramāṇau dvayaṇuke ca sāmyāt dvayaṇuka saṃjñā vat tryaṇuka saṃjñā api upapadyate eva
translated: Since the magnitude of an atom and a dyad is the same, the term 'triad' is also appropriate, just like the term 'dyad'.

original: taiḥ sajātīyaiḥ saṃyuktaiścaturbhistryaṇukaiḥ tadātmakaṃ dravyaṃ jāyate /
analyzed: taiḥ sajātīyaiḥ saṃyuktaiḥ caturbhiḥ tryaṇukaiḥ tad ātmakam dravyam jāyate
translated: From four triads of the same kind, united, a substance consisting of them is produced.

analyzed: tryaṇukeṣu aṇu saṃjñā upacārāt
translated: The term 'atom' is figuratively applied to triads.

analyzed: kecid dvayaṇukaiḥ eva catur aṇuka ārambham abhyupayanti
translated: Some accept that a tetrad is produced only from dyads.

analyzed: tad mata anusāreṇa taidvaryaṇukaiḥ iti vyākhyeyam
translated: According to their view, it should be explained as 'from those four dyads'.

analyzed: dvayaṇukāni trīṇi dravyam
translated: Three dyads produce a substance.

analyzed: yat kāyarma ārabhante tat tri aṇukam
translated: That which is produced by those three is a triad.

analyzed: caturbhiḥ ārabdham catur aṇukam iti
translated: That produced by four is a tetrad.

analyzed: atra ca saṃjñā mukhyā eva
translated: Here, the terms are primary.

analyzed: tatas tri aṇukebhyaḥ catur aṇekebhyaḥ vā
translated: Then, from triads or tetrads,

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word 'tu' (but) has the meaning of distinction.

analyzed: tam eva āha
translated: He himself says this.

analyzed: aniyamena eva etāvadbhiḥ eva iti saṅkhaya aniyamam vinā iti arthaḥ
translated: Without any restriction, i.e., not with a fixed number, is the meaning.

analyzed: dravya samavāyi kāraṇāni khaṇḍa avayavinaḥ
translated: The material substantial causes are the produced substances, the parts of the whole.

original: tryaṇukāderantyāvayavinaśca madhye naikameva khaṇḍāvayavi kintu aniyamenānekānyapi bhavantīti sūcayituṃ bahuvacanam /
analyzed: tryaṇuka ādeḥ antya avayavinaḥ ca madhye na ekam eva khaṇḍa avayavi kintu aniyamena anekāni api bhavanti iti sūcayitum bahuvacanam
translated: The plural number is used to indicate that not only one part of the whole, but many parts also are produced, without any restriction, among the triads and other ultimate parts.

original: tataḥ taiḥ khaṇḍāvayavibhiścāniyamenaiva saṅkhayāniyamaṃ vinaiva sarvāvayavināmantyāvayavināṃ śarīrendriyaviṣayāṇāṃ sambhavaḥ /
analyzed: tatas taiḥ khaṇḍa avayavibhiḥ ca aniyamena eva saṅkhaya aniyamam vinā eva sarva avayavinām antya avayavinām śarīra indriya viṣayāṇām sambhavaḥ
translated: From that, and from the parts of the whole, without any restriction, i.e., not with a fixed number, all the wholes, the ultimate parts, the bodies, senses and objects are produced.

analyzed: tat anena dravya utpattiḥ abhihitā
translated: By this, the production of substances is stated.

analyzed: guṇānām karmaṇām ca sva āśraya dravyeṣu utpādaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: The production of qualities and actions should be seen in their own substratum substances.

analyzed: sarvam api kāryam bhāva rūpam kāraṇa tritaya janyam
translated: Everything that is an effect has the nature of an entity and is produced by three causes.

analyzed: kāraṇāni ca samavāyi asamavāyi nimitta anāmāni  tatra yat sama
translated: And the causes are the inherent, non-inherent and instrumental causes.

analyzed: samavetam tat samavāyi kāraṇam
translated: Among them, that which is inherent and produces an effect is the inherent cause.

analyzed: tad svarūpeṇa darśayati kāraṇam iti
translated: It shows its own nature by saying cause.

analyzed: kāraṇam samavāyi ākhyam paramāṇu ādi tatra hi
translated: The cause is called the inhering cause, such as the atom etc. In that,

analyzed: atra dvayaṇuka ādi kārya utpattau paramāṇu ādi dravya padārthaḥ samavāyikāraṇam
translated: Here, in the production of the effect such as the dyad etc., the substance such as the atom is the inherent cause.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

original: atra paramāṇvādau dravye hi yasmātsarvakāryaṃ samavetamutpadyate tasmāditi śeṣaḥ / /
analyzed: atra paramāṇu ādau dravye hi yasmāt sarva kāryam samavetam utpadyate tasmāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Because in this atom etc., substance, since all effects are produced as inhering, therefore, is the remainder.

analyzed: samavāyi asamavāyi vyatiriktam kāraṇam nimittam
translated: The cause other than the inherent and non-inherent is the instrumental cause.

analyzed: tat udāharati īśa iti
translated: He illustrates that with Iśa etc.

analyzed: īśa icchā dṛṣṭa kālāḥ tu nimittam kāraṇam matam
translated: But the will of the Lord, unseen [potency], and time are considered the instrumental cause.

analyzed: nimittam tu iti anvayaḥ
translated: The instrumental [cause] is to be supplied.

analyzed: idam ca sarva kārya sādhāraṇam nimittam darśitam
translated: And this instrumental cause is shown to be common to all effects.

analyzed: evam anyat api draṣṭavyam
translated: Other [causes] should also be seen in the same way.

analyzed: yathā turī vema ādikam paṭasya ityādi
translated: For example, the loom etc. are the instrumental cause of the cloth, and so on.

analyzed: samavāyi kāraṇa pratyāsannam avadhṛta sāmarthyam asamavāyi kāraṇam
translated: The non-inherent cause is that whose capability is ascertained in proximity to the inherent cause.

analyzed: samavāyi kāraṇa tad samavāyi kāraṇayoḥ anyatara samaveta tvam samavāyi kāraṇa pratyāsanna tvam
translated: Being related to either the inherent cause or the inherent cause of that [inherent cause] is being in proximity to the inherent cause.

analyzed: sāmarthya avadhāraṇam ca ananyathāsiddha niyata pūrva bhāvi tvena bhavati
translated: And the ascertainment of capability occurs through being invariably antecedent without any other way of establishing it.

analyzed: tat ca asamavāyi kāraṇam dravyam samavāyi kāraṇam iti vat na eka uktayā vaktum śakyam
translated: And that non-inherent cause cannot be spoken of as the inherent cause of substance by a single statement.

analyzed: pratikāryam pṛthaktavāt
translated: Because of the difference for each effect.

original: atastadvivekena darśayituṃ tajjñānasya kāyarjñānasāpekṣatvātkāryākāryavibhāgaṃ tāvadāha sāmānyeti // /
analyzed: atas tad vivekena darśayitum tad jñānasya kāya ṛju jñāna sāpekṣa tvāt kārya akārya vibhāgam tāvat āha sāmānya iti
translated: Therefore, in order to show that distinction, and because the knowledge of that depends on the knowledge of the effect, he first states the division of effect and non-effect, beginning with universals, etc.

analyzed: sāmānya antya viśeṣau ca samavāyaḥ ca tat trayam
translated: Universals, the final specificities, and inherence - these three

analyzed: nityam kriyāḥ anityāḥ tu guṇa dravye dvi rūpake
translated: Are eternal. Actions are non-eternal. Qualities and substances have two forms.

analyzed: kārya tva anitya tvayoḥ sama niyamāt nitya anitya vibhāga uktayā kārya akārya vibhāgaḥ eva siddhayati
translated: Since eternality and non-eternality are invariably concomitant, the division into effect and non-effect is established by the statement of the division into eternal and non-eternal.

analyzed: ṣaṭ ime dravya guṇa karma sāmānya viśeṣa samavāyāḥ bhāva rūpāḥ padārthāḥ
translated: These six - substance, quality, action, universal, particularity, and inherence - are the categories that have existence as their form.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ saptamaḥ
translated: Non-existence is the seventh.

analyzed: vidhi rūpaḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: Existence has the form of affirmation.

analyzed: niṣedha rūpaḥ abhāvaḥ
translated: Non-existence has the form of negation.

analyzed: guṇa āśrayaḥ dravyam
translated: Substance is the substratum of qualities.

analyzed: samavāyi kāraṇam vā
translated: Or it is the inherent cause.
Quality has the nature of inhering in a substance and being the inherent cause of a universal.

analyzed: calana ātmakam karma  nityam ekam aneka anugatam
translated: Action has the nature of motion.🔽The universal is eternal, one, and pervades many.

analyzed: ka samavetam sāmānyam
translated: It inheres in substances.

original: nityeṣveva dravyeṣveva vartanta eva ye te antyaviśeṣāḥ /
analyzed: nityeṣu eva dravyeṣu eva vartante eva ye te antya viśeṣāḥ
translated: Those ultimate specificities that exist only in eternal substances.

analyzed: atyanta vyāvṛtti hetavaḥ vā
translated: Or, they are the causes of absolute exclusion.

analyzed: ayuta siddhayoḥ sambandhaḥ samavāyaḥ
translated: The relation of inseparable inherence is between two inseparable things.

analyzed: avaśyam āśraya āśrayi bhāvena avasthitau ayuta siddhau
translated: Inseparable things must exist in the relation of container and contained.

analyzed: nityaḥ sambandhaḥ vā
translated: Or, the relation is eternal.

analyzed: tatra sāmānyam antya viśeṣaḥ ca samavāyaḥ ca iti etat trayam nityam akāryam ca
translated: Among these, the three - universals, ultimate specificities, and inherence - are eternal and non-effects.

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ iti eva ukte dravya guṇa karma sāmānyānām api grahaṇam syāt
translated: If it is said to be a specific quality, then substances, qualities, actions, and universals would also be included.

analyzed: viśiṣṭate nena iti hi viśeṣaḥ
translated: For a specific quality is that by which something is distinguished.

analyzed: dravyam ca daṇḍa ādikam a daṇḍi ādibhyaḥ devadatta ādikam vyāvartayati
translated: A substance like a stick distinguishes Devadatta, etc. from those that are not sticks, etc.

analyzed: guṇaḥ ca nirguṇāt dravyam
translated: A quality distinguishes a substance from that which is devoid of qualities.

analyzed: karma api niṣkriyāt mūrtam
translated: An action distinguishes a corporeal substance from that which is devoid of action.

original: sāmānyaṃ dvividhaṃ paramaparaṃ ca /🔽paraṃ sattā pracurāśrayatvāt /
analyzed: sāmānyam dvividham param aparam ca  param sattā pracura āśraya tvāt
translated: A universal is of two kinds: supreme and subordinate.🔽The supreme universal is existence, because it inheres in the most things.

analyzed: aparam dravya tva ādi alpa āśraya tvāt
translated: The subordinate universals are substance-ness, etc., because they inhere in fewer things.

original: tatra parasāmānyasyānuvṛttimātrahetutvena sāmānyamātratve 'pyaparasāmānyaṃ vyāvṛtterapi hetutvādviśeṣo 'pi ye vyāvartakā bhavanti te 'ntyāḥ
analyzed: tatra para sāmānyasya anuvṛtti mātra hetu tvena sāmānya mātra tve pi apara sāmānyam vyāvṛtteḥ api hetu tvāt viśeṣaḥ ye vyāvartakāḥ bhavanti te ntyāḥ
translated: Among them, the universal of the other, being the cause of mere non-occurrence, is a mere universal, but the other universal is also the cause of exclusion, so it is also a particular. Those that are the causes of exclusion are the ultimate ones.

analyzed: atyanta vyāvṛtti hetavaḥ iti yāvat
translated: That is, they are the causes of absolute exclusion.

analyzed: nahi daṇḍa ādikam tathā
translated: A stick, etc., is not like that.

analyzed: daṇḍi antara ādibhyaḥ vyāvartaka tvāt
translated: Because it is not the cause of exclusion from another stick, etc.

analyzed: kriyāḥ utkṣepaṇa apakṣepaṇa ākuñcana prasaraṇa gamana rūpāḥ anityāḥ ca
translated: Action has the forms of throwing up, throwing down, contracting, expanding, and moving, and is impermanent.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word ca (and) is for determination.

analyzed: na dravya ādi vat ubhaya rūpāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not of both natures like substance, etc.

analyzed: guṇāḥ dravyāṇi ca nitya anitya bhedena dvividhāni iti
translated: Qualities and substances are of two kinds, divided into permanent and impermanent.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

analyzed: dravyāṇi pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśa kāla ādiś ātma manāṃsi
translated: Substances are earth, water, fire, air, space, time, direction, self, and mind.

analyzed: tatra paramāṇu rūpāṇi pṛthivī ādīni catvāri
translated: Among them, the four beginning with earth have atomic forms.

analyzed: gagana ādīni pañca nityāni
translated: The five beginning with space are permanent.

analyzed: dvayaṇuka ādi rūpāṇi pṛthivī ādīni catvāri anityāni iti  guṇāḥ ca anitya dravya gatāḥ anityāḥ eva
translated: The four beginning with earth in the form of binary atoms, etc., are impermanent.🔽And the qualities are only impermanent when located in impermanent substances.

analyzed: pārthiva paramāṇāva ekatva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇa guru tvāni nityāni
translated: In the earth atom, the qualities of oneness, separateness, dimension, and heaviness are permanent.

analyzed: rūpa rasa gandha sparśa aneka tva aneka pṛthaktava saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva saṃskārāḥ anityāḥ
translated: Color, taste, smell, touch, one-ness, many-ness, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, and action are non-eternal.

analyzed: āpye ca pāthasīye ca rūpa rasa sparśa eka tva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇa guru tva dravya tva snehāḥ nityāḥ
translated: In water and watery substances, color, taste, touch, one-ness, one-ness of separateness, dimension, heaviness, substance-ness, and fluidity are eternal.

analyzed: aneka tva aneka pṛthak tava saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva saṃskārāḥ anityāḥ
translated: Many-ness, many-nesses of separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, and action are non-eternal.

analyzed: taijase ca rūpa sparśa eka tva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇāni nityāni
translated: In fire and fiery substances, color, touch, one-ness, one-ness of separateness, and dimension are eternal.

analyzed: aneka tva aneka pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva dravya tva saṃskārāḥ anityāḥ
translated: Many-ness, many-nesses of separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, substance-ness, and action are non-eternal.

analyzed: vāyavīye ca sparśa eka tva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇāni nityāni
translated: In air and airy substances, touch, one-ness, one-ness of separateness, and dimension are eternal.

analyzed: aneka tva aneka pṛthak tava saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva saṃskārāḥ anityāḥ
translated: Many-ness, many-nesses of separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, and action are non-eternal.

analyzed: ākāśe ca eka tva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇāni nityāni
translated: In space, one-ness, one-ness of separateness, and dimension are eternal.

analyzed: a ketva aneka pṛthak tava saṃyoga vibhāga śabdāḥ anityāḥ
translated: Many-ness, many-nesses of separateness, conjunction, disjunction, and sound are non-eternal.

analyzed: kāle diśi ca eka tva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇāni nityāni
translated: In time and direction, one-ness, one-ness of separateness, and dimension are eternal.

analyzed: aneka tva aneka pṛthak tava saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ anityāḥ
translated: Many-ness, many-nesses of separateness, conjunction, and disjunction are non-eternal.

analyzed: ātmani ca eka tva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇāni nityāni
translated: And in the self, unity, singularity, and dimension are eternal.

analyzed: aneka tva aneka pṛthak tava saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ buddhi ādayaḥ ca nava anityāḥ
translated: Plurality, multiplicity, conjunction, disjunction, and the nine beginning with intellect are non-eternal.

analyzed: īśvarasya api viśeṣaḥ bhihitaḥ
translated: The special qualities of God have also been mentioned.

analyzed: manasi ca eka tva ekapṛthaktava parimāṇāni nityāni
translated: And in the mind, unity, singularity, and dimension are eternal.

analyzed: aneka tva aneka pṛthak tava saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva saṃskārāḥ anityāḥ
translated: Plurality, multiplicity, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, and impressions are non-eternal.

analyzed: iti vivekaḥ
translated: Thus is the distinction.

original: evaṃ kāryākāryavibhāgamuktavā yasya yadasamavāyikāraṇaṃ tadāha kārya iti //🔽kārye guṇakriyāṇāṃ tu samavāyyanyakāraṇam /
analyzed: evam kārya akārya vibhāgam uktavā yasya yat asamavāyi kāraṇam tat āha kārye iti  kārye guṇa kriyāṇām tu samavāyi anya kāraṇam
translated: Having thus stated the division of effects and non-effects, he says that for any entity, its non-inherent cause is the effect, etc.🔽For qualities and actions in an effect, the inherent and other causes are

analyzed: kāraṇa sthāḥ guṇa ādyāḥ tu saṃyogaḥ dravya kāraṇam
