translated: to enlighten him it is said Even without separation etc.

original: avidāraṇe 'pi hyāsyasya bhinnāvoṣṭhau tu tasya ca // / / //
analyzed: a vidāraṇe hi āsyasya bhinnau oṣṭhau tu tasya ca
translated: For even without separation, the lips of the mouth are indeed different from it.

analyzed: āsyasya iti āsya sambandhinoḥ oṣṭhayoḥ grahaṇam
translated: 'Of the mouth' refers to the lips connected with the mouth.

analyzed: tasya ca māyā vādinaḥ eva
translated: And 'of it' refers to the Mādhyamika himself.

original: yadā hi māyāvādī niruttaratayā tūṣṇīmāste tadā tadīyayoroṣṭhayorvidāraṇalakṣaṇavibhāgābhāve 'pyoṣṭhau bhinnāvanyonyābhāvalakṣaṇabhedavantau
analyzed: yadā hi māyāvādī niruttara tayā tūṣṇīm āste tadā tadīyayoḥ oṣṭhayoḥ vidāraṇa lakṣaṇa vibhāga abhāve pyoṣṭhau bhinnau anyonya abhāva lakṣaṇa bhedavantau
translated: For when the Mādhyamika remains silent out of inability to reply, then even in the absence of the division characterized by the tearing apart of his lips, the lips are still divided, having the difference characterized by mutual absence.

analyzed: bhavate eva
translated: They exist as such.

original: yadabhāve ca yadasti tattato 'nyaditi ca prasiddhameva /
analyzed: yad abhāve ca yat asti tat tatas nyat iti ca prasiddham eva
translated: And it is well known that what exists in the absence of something is different from it.

analyzed: atas vibhāgāt bhedaḥ rtha antaram eva iti jñāyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that difference is something entirely different from division.

original: tasya cetyanena nātaḥ paraṃ svarūpabhede kācidanupapattiḥ sambhāvitāstīti sūcitam /
analyzed: tasya ca iti anena na atas param svarūpa bhede kācid anupapattiḥ sambhāvitā asti iti sūcitam
translated: And by this of that it is indicated that no inconsistency whatsoever is imagined in the difference of nature beyond this.

analyzed: nanu katham na asti
translated: But how is it not?

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāva anupapatti ādeḥ aparihṛta tvāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is not, because the inconsistency of the relation of qualifier and qualified, etc. has not been refuted, it is not so.

analyzed: sva rūpa tve pi viśeṣa balena viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāva sambandha avabhāsa upapatteḥ
translated: Because even if it is of the same nature, the appearance of the relation of qualifier and qualified by the power of particularities is possible.

analyzed: anyathā ānandam brahma ānandam brahmaṇaḥ ityādeḥ anupapatti prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the inconsistency of statements like Brahman is without bliss and Brahman is blissful.

analyzed: saṃśaya viparyaya anupapattiḥ api nā asti
translated: There is also no inconsistency of doubt and error.
Because it is possible that what is known with particularities is unknown.

original: anyathā'tmasvarūpe svayaṃprakāśamāne tatsvarūpamātrāṇāmadvitīyatvānandatvādīnāmapi prakāśanīyamānna jātu kasyacitsaṃśayaviparyayau syātām /
analyzed: anyathā ātma svarūpe svayam prakāśamāne tad svarūpa mātrāṇām advitīya tva ānanda tva ādīnām api jātu kasyacid saṃśaya viparyayau syātām
translated: Otherwise, if the nature of the self were self-luminous, then the nature of that self, such as being without a second, being bliss, etc., would also be illuminated, and no one would ever have doubt or error regarding it.

analyzed: avidyā vaśāt tatra tathā iti ced  atrā api sādṛśyāt iva
translated: If it is argued that it is so due to ignorance,

analyzed: śya vaśāt tathā iti
translated: then here also it should be accepted that it is so due to the influence of similarity, etc.

analyzed: yat ca advaita paryavasānam uktam
translated: And as for the conclusion in non-duality that has been stated,

original: tatkuta iti vaktavyam /🔽yadi manyeta yathā hi lambakarṇa āgato /
analyzed: tat kutas iti vaktavyam  yadi manyeta yathā hi lamba karṇaḥ āgataḥ
translated: it should be said from where that is.

original: nīlamānīyatāmityādau parikaravato yadbhavati tatparikarasyāpi /🔽tathā pratiyogighaṭitasya bhedasya dharmisvarūpatve pratiyogino 'pi tatra nima
analyzed: nīlam ānīyatām ityādau parikaravataḥ yat bhavati tat parikarasya api  tathā pratiyogi ghaṭitasya bhedasya dharmi svarūpa tve tatra
translated: If one thinks that just as when it is said Bring the long-eared one or Bring the blue one, what happens to the attendant is also to the attendant,

original: nnimajjanaṃ syāditi tatra kiṃ sambhāvanayedamucyate uta vyāptyā /
analyzed: syāt iti tatra kim sambhāvanayā idam ucyate uta vyāptyā
translated: similarly, when difference, which is constituted by the counter-correlate, is the nature of the subject, then the submergence of the counter-correlate in that would also occur, then is this stated by way of possibility there, or by way of pervasion?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first,

analyzed: praśithila mūla tvāt
translated: because the root is loose.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second,

analyzed: citraguḥ ānīyatām kāśī nivāsī samāgataḥ ityādau tad abhāvāt
translated: because that is absent in the case of Bring the variegated bull or The resident of Kashi has come.

analyzed: pāramārthikīm dṛṣṭim avalambamānasya tat api asiddham iti ced
translated: If it is argued that even that is unestablished for one who relies on the ultimate view,

original: aho pakṣapāto 'sya yatparasyāniṣyaṃ prasañjayanvyāptigrahaṇāya laukikaṃ dṛṣṭāntaṃ bahumanyate vyabhicāre tu tatrodāste /
analyzed: aho pakṣapātaḥ sya yat parasya aniṣyam prasañjayan vyāpti grahaṇāya laukikam dṛṣṭāntam bahu manyate vyabhicāre tu tatra udāste
translated: Oh, his partiality! In order to grasp the pervasion, he values the worldly example that implies the undesirable for the opponent, but remains silent when there is a fallacy there.

analyzed: para siddhena parasya eva aniṣya āpādanam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the undesirable consequence for the opponent is to be established by what is accepted by the opponent,

analyzed: tarhi mūla śaithilyam api paraḥ sva siddhena pratipatsyate
translated: then the looseness of the root will also be accepted by the opponent through what is accepted by himself.

analyzed: vaicitryam kinnimittam iti ced  vyāvartaka tva mātreṇa pratiyoginām upayogāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: If it is asked what is the cause of diversity,🔽we say that the counter-correlates are useful merely by their property of exclusion.

analyzed: tat evam sva para mata avaloka anapekṣayā eva doṣa udbhāvanāt upekṣaṇam evā unmatta vākya vat māyā vādasya ucitam
translated: Thus, because the statement of faults is made without regard to the views of oneself or others, the doctrine of illusion should be disregarded like the words of a madman.

analyzed: kim nirākaraṇena iti āśayavān upasaṃharati atas iti
translated: With the intention that what is the use of refuting it?, he concludes Therefore etc.

analyzed: atas unmatta vākya tvāt māyā vādaḥ bhyupekṣitaḥ
translated: Therefore, the doctrine of illusion, being like the words of a madman, is disregarded.

original: nanvevaṃvidhaṃ mataṃ siddhāntaviruddhatvātsūtrakṛtā kuto 'tra na nirākṛtamityetadanena parihriyate /
analyzed: nanu evaṃvidham matam siddhānta viruddha tvāt sūtrakṛtā na nirākṛtam iti etat anena parihriyate
translated: But why did the author of the aphorisms not refute this kind of view here, since it contradicts the established doctrine? This is answered by this [verse].

analyzed: upekṣitaḥ sūtrakāreṇa iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is disregarded by the author of the aphorisms.

original: evaṃ samavāyaṃ nirākṛtyedānīṃ sambandhaprasaṅgena sambandhināmapi guṇādīnāṃ prasaktatvādīśvaraguṇasaṅkhayāvipratipattiṃ nirākaroti naceti🔽na cāmandasadānandasyandyanantaguṇārṇavaḥ /
analyzed: evam samavāyam nirākṛtya idānīm sambandha prasaṅgena sambandhinām api guṇa ādīnām prasakta tvāt īśvara guṇa saṅkhaya avipratipattim nirākaroti na ca iti  na ca amanda sat ānanda syandi ananta guṇa arṇavaḥ
translated: Having thus refuted inherence, now, in the context of relation, since the relata such as qualities are also implicated, he refutes the dispute over the number of God's qualities, saying not and so on.🔽And the ocean of infinite qualities, always flowing with intense bliss,

analyzed: īśvaraḥ ṣṭaguṇa tvena prameyaḥ pramita tvataḥ
translated: God is not to be known as having eight qualities, because of the absence of valid knowledge.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ ṣṭaguṇa tvena aṣṭau eva guṇāḥ asya santi iti evaṃrūpeṇa
translated: God is not to be known as having eight qualities, meaning that he has only eight qualities.

analyzed: na prameyaḥ na pratipattavyaḥ
translated: He is not to be understood.

analyzed: kutas apramita tvataḥ aṣṭaguṇa tve pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Why? Because of the absence of valid knowledge, due to the absence of valid means of knowledge regarding having eight qualities.

analyzed: kintu amanda sat ānanda syandi ananta guṇa arṇavaḥ prameyaḥ
translated: But the ocean of infinite qualities, always flowing with intense bliss, is to be known.

analyzed: arṇavaḥ iva arṇavaḥ
translated: Like an ocean, it is an ocean.

analyzed: kṣīrārṇavaḥ sudhā syandī bhavati
translated: The milk ocean flows with nectar.

analyzed: ayam ca analpa vidoṣa ānanda sudhā syandī
translated: And this one flows with the nectar of bliss free from many faults.

analyzed: saḥ nantāḥ guṇāḥ śubha padārthāḥ cintāmaṇi prabhṛtayaḥ smin iti ananta guṇaḥ
translated: And in it are infinite good things, such as wish-fulfilling gems, thus it has infinite qualities.

analyzed: ayam api ānanda ādayaḥ nantāḥ guṇāḥ asmin iti ananta guṇaḥ
translated: And these, bliss and so on, are infinite qualities in it, thus it has infinite qualities.

analyzed: amanda sat ānanda syandī ca asau ananta guṇaḥ ca asau arṇavaḥ ca iti vigrahaḥ
translated: And it always flows with intense bliss, and it has infinite qualities, and it is an ocean, thus the analysis.

analyzed: aṣṭaguṇa tva vat ananta guṇa tve pi īśvarasya pramāṇam na asti iti atas āha mayi iti
translated: As there is no proof for the infinity of qualities in God, he says in Me etc.

analyzed: mayi ananta guṇe nante guṇataḥ nanta vigrahe
translated: In Me, who have infinite qualities, who am infinite, who have an infinite body consisting of qualities,
The ocean of infinite knowledge of the greatness and power of qualities,

analyzed: nārāyaṇaḥ śeṣa cetanebhyaḥ param padam
translated: Narayana is the highest, beyond all conscious beings, the supreme state.

analyzed: ityādi veda tad vākyaiḥ anantaiḥ ca avasīyate  ananta guṇa tā viṣṇoḥ
translated: This is ascertained by infinite Vedic statements and their sentences,🔽The infinity of qualities of Vishnu...

analyzed: anantāḥ guṇāḥ yasya asau ananta guṇaḥ
translated: He who has infinite, innumerable qualities is one with infinite qualities.

analyzed: guṇataḥ nantaḥ iti guṇānām pratyekam anavadhika tvam ananta avāntara viśeṣavat tvam ca abhipreyate
translated: By infinite in qualities it is intended that the qualities are each infinite, and have infinite subdivisions.

analyzed: ananta vigrahaḥ ityantam bhagavat vākyam
translated: The statement of the Lord ends with having an infinite body.

analyzed: uttaram veda vākyam
translated: The subsequent statement is a Vedic statement.

analyzed: guṇa māhātmya iti sāmānya viśeṣābhyām uktam
translated: The greatness of qualities is stated by a general and specific [word].

original: māhātmyaṃ parimāṇātiśayaḥ /🔽paraṃ padamityuddiśyānyaducyata iti na liṅgavyatyayadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: māhātmyam parimāṇa atiśayaḥ  param padam iti uddiśya anyat ucyate iti na liṅga vyatyaya doṣaḥ
translated: Greatness is the excess of magnitude.🔽Having mentioned the supreme state, what is said is not a fault of the change of gender.

original: nanvetāni vacanānyupacaritārthāni kinna syurityata āha kathameveti //
analyzed: nanu etāni vacanāni upacarita arthāni kinna syuḥ iti atas āha katham eva iti
translated: How can these statements not be of secondary meaning? Therefore he says how indeed...

analyzed: katham eva hi apodyate
translated: How indeed is it denied?

analyzed: bādhaka vaśāt hi mukhya arthaḥ u podyate
translated: For the primary meaning is denied only due to the force of contradiction.

analyzed: na ca atra tat asti iti atas nanta guṇa tā viṣṇoḥ katham evā apodyate
translated: And this is not present here. Therefore, how can the infinite number of qualities of Vishnu be denied?

analyzed: yat ca vaiśeṣika ādibhiḥ īśvara jñāna icchā prayatnānām akhaṇḍa tvam uktam tat api asat
translated: And what has been said by the Vaisheshikas and others about the indivisibility of God's knowledge, will, and effort, that is also false.

analyzed: anantam guṇataḥ
translated: As it is said: Infinite in terms of qualities.

analyzed: iti pratyekam guṇānām ananta viśeṣavat tvasya āgama siddha tvāt
translated: Because it is established by scripture that each of the qualities has infinite distinctions.

analyzed: tad anaṅgīkāre bādhakam ca āha yadi iti
translated: And he states the contradiction in not accepting that: If it is said...

analyzed: yadi ananta viśeṣāḥ ca tad jñāna ādeḥ nivāritāḥ
translated: If the infinite distinctions are prevented by that knowledge and so on...

analyzed: katham tad tad viṣaya tā sārvajñya artham vidhīyate
translated: ...how is the state of being the object of that and that enjoined for the sake of omniscience?

analyzed: aupādhika viśeṣaḥ tu pūrvam eva nirākṛtaḥ
translated: The accidental distinction has been refuted earlier...

analyzed: tad tad viṣaya tā ghaṭa ādi viṣaya tā
translated: The state of being the object of that and that refers to being the object of pots and so on.

analyzed: vidhīyate astitvena aṅgīkriyate
translated: Is enjoined, is accepted as existing.

analyzed: mā bhūt tad tad viṣaya tvam iti atas uktam sārvajña artham iti
translated: In order to avoid that state of being the object of that and that, it is said for the sake of omniscience.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is a metaphor.

analyzed: sarva kartṛ tva ādi artham ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: And it should be seen that it is also for the sake of being the agent of everything and so on.

analyzed: atra ananta viśeṣāḥ iti yathā āgama siddha uktiḥ
translated: Here, the infinite distinctions are mentioned according to what is established by scripture.

original: vastutastu yadi īśvarajñānādi nirviśeṣaṃ syāttadā tattadviṣayatvaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: vastutas tu yadi īśvara jñāna ādi nirviśeṣam syāt tadā tad tad viṣayatvam na syāt
translated: But in reality, if the knowledge etc. of God were without distinctions, then it would not have such and such objects.

original: tadā ca tasya sārvajñādikaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: tadā ca tasya sārvajña ādikam na syāt
translated: And then His omniscience etc. would not be possible.

analyzed: sarva viṣaya jñānavān hi sarvajñaḥ nāma  tathā sarva kārya utpatti viṣaya icchā prayatnavān sarva kartā
translated: For one who has knowledge of all objects is called omniscient.🔽Similarly, He who has the will and effort with regard to the origin of all effects is the creator of all.

analyzed: sarva kārya vināśa viṣaya icchā ādimān ca sarva saṃhartā
translated: And He who has the will etc. with regard to the destruction of all effects is the destroyer of all.

analyzed: aṅgīkṛtam ca sārvajña ādi pareṇa parameśvarasya
translated: And the other party accepts the omniscience etc. of the Supreme God.

analyzed: atas tad artham jñāna ādeḥ tad tad viṣaya tayā bhāvyam
translated: Therefore, for that purpose, knowledge etc. must have such and such objects.

analyzed: katham ca tathā sati nirviśeṣa tvam iti
translated: And how can it be without distinctions if that is so?

analyzed: nirastam
translated: This too is refuted.

analyzed: yat āhuḥ
translated: As they say:

analyzed: anityam hi jñāna ādi karma kārakatayā viṣaya sahita tvam apekṣeta
translated: For knowledge etc. that is non-eternal would require association with objects as the instrument of action.

analyzed: nityasya tu kim viṣayeṇa iti
translated: But what is the use of an object for the eternal?

analyzed: viṣayāṇām ca ānantyāt ananta viśeṣa tā siddhiḥ
translated: And because the objects are infinite, it is established that there are infinite distinctions.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: nirviśeṣam eva īśvara jñānam jñapti rūpam
translated: The knowledge of God is indeed without distinctions, having the form of cognition.

analyzed: tat tu taiḥ taiḥ ghaṭa ādi upādhibhiḥ tat tat viṣayam iti vyapadiśyate
translated: But that is designated as having such and such objects by means of such and such limiting adjuncts like pot etc.

analyzed: evam akhaṇḍā eva tasya icchā astu iti evam ākārā
translated: Thus, His will is undivided in this way.

analyzed: tathā api taiḥ taiḥ sṛṣṭayā ādi upādhibhiḥ sisṛkṣā sat jihīrṣā ityādi ucyate
translated: Nevertheless, due to the limiting adjuncts such as creation etc., it is said that He desires to create, desires to preserve, etc.

analyzed: tathā prayatnaḥ pi
translated: Similarly, effort also.

original: ataḥ svato viśeṣābhāve 'pyaupādhikaviśeṣavaśāttattadviṣayatā sārvajñādikaṃ ca yuktamityata āha aupādhiketi //
analyzed: atas svatas viśeṣa abhāve pi aupādhika viśeṣa vaśāt tad tad viṣaya tā sārvajña ādikam ca yuktam iti atas āha aupādhika iti
translated: Therefore, even in the absence of intrinsic distinctions, the state of having that and that object and omniscience etc. are proper due to the influence of distinctions arising from limiting adjuncts. Thus, he says arising from limiting adjuncts etc.

analyzed: aupādhikaḥ pi viśeṣaḥ sti na vā
translated: Is there a distinction arising from limiting adjuncts or not?

analyzed: asti ced katham nirviśeṣa tvam
translated: If there is, how can there be non-distinction?

analyzed: na ced punar sārvajña ādi abhāvaḥ ityādi pūrva ukta nyāyena eva nirastam iti arthaḥ
translated: If not, then omniscience etc. do not exist. The meaning is that this has been refuted by the previously stated reasoning.

analyzed: kiñca upādhiḥ jñāna ādi sambaddhaḥ viśeṣam āpādayet asambaddhaḥ vā
translated: Moreover, would a limiting adjunct, connected with knowledge etc., produce a distinction, or unconnected?

original: ādye sambandho viṣayaviṣayibhāvātirikto nāstīti pūrvameva tadviṣayataiṣyavyā /
analyzed: ādye sambandhaḥ viṣaya viṣayi bhāva atiriktaḥ na asti iti pūrvam eva tad viṣaya tā eṣi avyā
translated: In the first case, since there is no connection other than the relation of object and subject, its object must be accepted as before.

analyzed: dvitīye tiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the second case, there is an absurd consequence.

original: api cāstvityevamākāreṇaivecchādinā sṛṣṭayādikaṃ bhavati uta sṛṣṭayādikaṃ bhavatvityevamākāreṇa /
analyzed: api ca astu iti evam ākāreṇa eva icchā ādinā sṛṣṭayā ādikam bhavati uta sṛṣṭayā ādikam bhavatu iti evam ākāreṇa
translated: Moreover, creation etc. occur only in the form of let there be by will etc., or in the form of may creation etc. occur?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the absurd consequence.

analyzed: dvitīye svatas sa viśeṣa tvam iti eṣā diś
translated: In the second case, there is intrinsic distinction. This is the direction.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika ādayaḥ kecid īśvara jñānam sva prakāśam na bhavati iti āhuḥ
translated: Some, like the Vaiśeṣikas, say that the knowledge of God is not self-luminous.

analyzed: tān apākaroti sva prakāśa tvam api iti
translated: He refutes them with the words self-luminosity, etc.

analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam api tu yaiḥ jñānasya nivāritam
translated: Even self-luminosity is rejected by some regarding knowledge,

analyzed: katham sarvajña tā tasya
translated: how can he be omniscient?

analyzed: yaiḥ tu iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with by some.

analyzed: kecid vaiśeṣika ādayaḥ sva prakāśa tām aṅgīkurvanti iti etat sūcayitum tuśabdaḥ
translated: The word tu (but) is used to indicate that some, like the Vaiśeṣikas, accept self-luminosity.

analyzed: jñānasya īśvara jñānasya
translated: Of knowledge, of the knowledge of God.

analyzed: teṣām pakṣaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is in their view.

analyzed: tasya īśvarasya
translated: Of him, of God.

original: kathaṃ svaprakāśatvābhāve sarvajñatābhāva ityata āha sveti // /
analyzed: katham sva prakāśa tva abhāve sarvajña tā bhāvaḥ iti atas āha sva iti
translated: How can there be omniscience in the absence of self-luminosity? Therefore he says by itself, etc.

analyzed: sva jñāna adhigamam vinā
translated: Without the cognition of its own knowledge, etc.

original: svajñānādhigamābhāvādityarthaḥ /🔽ekameva hīśvarajñānaṃ tacca svavyatiriktameva viṣayīkaroti na tu svarūpamiti kathamīśvaraḥ sarvajñaḥ syāditi /
analyzed: sva jñāna adhigama abhāvāt iti arthaḥ  ekam eva hi īśvara jñānam tat ca sva vyatiriktam eva viṣayīkaroti na tu svarūpam iti katham īśvaraḥ sarvajñaḥ syāt iti
translated: The meaning is: because there is no cognition of its own knowledge.🔽For there is only one knowledge of God, and that makes only what is external to itself its object, not its own form. So how could God be omniscient?

analyzed: sva prakāśa jñāna abhāve pi īśvarasya sārvajña sambhavam śaṅkate jñānam iti
translated: Even in the absence of self-luminous knowledge, he doubts the possibility of omniscience for God with the words knowledge, etc.

analyzed: jñānam viśva adhigam tu ekam tad jñāna viṣayam param
translated: But that knowledge which comprehends the universe is one, and that is the supreme object of knowledge.

analyzed: iti jñāna dvayena eva sarva vid parameśvaraḥ
translated: Thus, by these two knowledges alone, the Supreme Lord is omniscient.

analyzed: iti ced  viśva adhigam sva vyatirikta samasta viṣayam
translated: If it is argued that...🔽That knowledge which has as its object the universe, which is all objects other than itself.

analyzed: tat jñānam viṣayaḥ yasya tat tathā uktam
translated: That knowledge is said to be so because it has as its object that [universe].

original: syādayaṃ doṣo yadīśvarasyaikameva jñānaṃ syānna caivam /
analyzed: syāt ayam doṣaḥ yadi īśvarasya ekam eva jñānam syāt na ca evam
translated: This fault would arise if the Lord had only one knowledge, but it is not so.

analyzed: dve khalu īśvara jñāne
translated: Indeed, there are two knowledges of the Lord.

analyzed: tatra ekam sva vyatirikta dvitīya jñāna sahita sarva viṣayam
translated: Therein, one has as its object all things along with the second knowledge other than itself.
But the second one is that which makes that knowledge its object.

analyzed: evam ca jñānasya sva viṣaya tva abhāve pi īśvarasya evaṃvidha jñāna dvayena eva sarvavit tvam upapadyate iti
translated: Thus, even in the absence of the knowledge being its own object, the omniscience of the Lord is established by these two such knowledges.

original: tathāpīśvarasyāsārvajñaṃ tajjñānasya vā svaprakāśatvaṃ duṣpariharamityāśayavānuttaramāha eṣa eveti //
analyzed: tathā api īśvarasya asārvajñam tad jñānasya vā sva prakāśa tvam duṣpariharam iti āśayavān uttaram āha eṣaḥ eva iti
translated: Nevertheless, the non-omniscience of the Lord or the self-luminousness of that knowledge is difficult to avoid. With this intention, he states the answer as follows:

analyzed: eṣaḥ eva arthaḥ tad jñāna avasitaḥ yadi
translated: If this very meaning is ascertained by that knowledge,

analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam eva syāt
translated: then there would be self-luminousness alone.

analyzed: āstām tāvat sajātīya ātma viśeṣa guṇa yaugapadya anupapattiḥ  jñāna dvayavān aham
translated: Let alone the impossibility of the simultaneous presence of the specific qualities of the self of the same class.🔽I possess two knowledges.

analyzed: jñāna dvayena sarvajñaḥ smi
translated: By means of two knowledges, I am omniscient.

original: idaṃ me jñānametajjñānaviṣayaṃ etaccaitadviṣayamityādireṣa evārtha īśvareṇa jñāyate na vā /
analyzed: idam me jñānam etat jñāna viṣayam etat ca etad viṣayam ityādiḥ eṣaḥ eva arthaḥ īśvareṇa jñāyate na vā
translated: Is this object known by God as 'this is my knowledge', 'this is the object of knowledge', 'this and this are the objects'?

original: neti pakṣe tasya sārvajñaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: na iti pakṣe tasya sārvajñam na syāt
translated: If not, then He would not be omniscient.

analyzed: ādye kim etayoḥ anyatareṇa uta jñāna antareṇa
translated: If so, is it by one of these two or by another knowledge?

analyzed: prathamasya idam uttaram
translated: The answer to the first is this.

original: eṣa evārthastayoranyatareṇa jñānenāvasito viṣayīkṛto yadi tadā tasya jñānasya svaprakāśatvaṃ syādeveti /
analyzed: eṣaḥ eva arthaḥ tayoḥ anyatareṇa jñānena avasitaḥ viṣayīkṛtaḥ yadi tadā tasya jñānasya sva prakāśa tvam syāt eva iti
translated: If this object is ascertained by one of these two knowledges, if it is made the object, then that knowledge must be self-luminous.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha jñānam hi iti
translated: How is that? To this he says 'knowledge' etc.

analyzed: jñānam hi etat viśeṣaṇam
translated: For this knowledge is the qualifier.

analyzed: yadi api etat jñānam na niṣkṛṣṭam svasya sva viṣaya tām āpadyate
translated: Even though this knowledge does not directly become the object of itself,

analyzed: tathā api jñāna viṣayasya etasya jñāna dvayān aham ityādeḥ arthasya viśeṣaṇam bhavati eva
translated: nevertheless, it is indeed the qualifier of the object of knowledge, such as 'this is not known by two knowledges' etc.

analyzed: tathāca viśiṣṭa artha viṣayatve viśeṣaṇa bhūta sva viṣayatvam avarjanīyam eva
translated: And thus, when it has the qualified object as its object, the state of being the qualifier of its own object is unavoidable.

original: nahi daṇḍisākṣātkāre daṇḍo na sphuratīti yuktamiti / /
analyzed: nahi daṇḍi sākṣātkāre daṇḍaḥ na sphurati iti yuktam iti
translated: For it is not proper to say that the stick does not appear in the perception of the man with the stick.

analyzed: dvitīye doṣam āha jñāna antareṇa iti
translated: In the second case, he states the fault with 'by another knowledge' etc.

analyzed: jñāna antareṇa ced atra bhavet evā anavasthitiḥ
translated: If it be said that there is an infinite regress here because of another cognition,

analyzed: jñāna antareṇa tṛtīyena jñānena
translated: by another cognition, by a third cognition.

analyzed: yadi eṣaḥ rthaḥ viṣayīkriyate
translated: If this object is cognized.

original: atra asminpakṣe anavasthitiḥ jñānadvayavānīśvara iti niyamābhāvo bhavet /
analyzed: atra asmin pakṣe anavasthitiḥ jñāna dvayavān īśvaraḥ iti niyama abhāvaḥ bhavet
translated: In this view, there would be an infinite regress, there would be no rule that God has only two cognitions.

original: yastu jñānatrayavāniti niyamaṃ manyate sa praṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu jñāna trayavān iti niyamam manyate sa praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: But he who thinks there is a rule that he has three cognitions should be asked:

analyzed: kim jñāna trayavān aham asmi ityādikam artham īśvaraḥ vetti na vā iti
translated: Does God know the object beginning with I have three cognitions or not?

analyzed: dvitīye tu punar asārvajñam  ādye kim etat traya anyatamena
translated: But in the second case, there is no omniscience.

analyzed: uta caturthena
translated: In the first, is it by any one of these three or by a fourth?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: sva prakāśa tā āpatteḥ
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of self-luminosity.

analyzed: dvitīye punar anavasthā eva
translated: In the second, there is again an infinite regress.

analyzed: evam jñāna antara paramparā abhyupagama vyasanam durvāram syāt
translated: Thus, the difficulty of accepting an endless series of cognitions would be insurmountable.

analyzed: nanu anantāni īśvara jñānāni abhyupagacchāmi kaḥ doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said I accept that God's cognitions are endless, what is the fault?, no.

analyzed: kalpanā gauravāt varam ekasya eva jñānasya sva prakāśa tva abhyupagamaḥ iti āśayavān upasaṃharati sva prakāśa tvam iti
translated: Because of the heaviness of assumption, it is better to accept that a single cognition is self-luminous. With this intention, he concludes with self-luminosity.

original: svaprakāśatvametasmād durnivāryaṃ samāpatet // / / //🔽nanu jñānaṃ na svaprakāśaṃ vastutvādityādeḥ viruddhaṃdi
analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam etasmāt durnivāryam samāpatet  nanu jñānam na sva prakāśam vastu tvāt ityādeḥ
translated: Therefore, self-luminosity follows as irresistible.

analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam katham aṅgīkartum ucitam iti ced na
translated: But it is proper to accept self-luminosity, even though it is contradicted by arguments such as knowledge is not self-luminous, because it is an entity? No.

original: yat vastu / na tatsvaprakāśamiti vyāptijñānaṃ svātmānaṃ na viṣayīkaroti cenna sarvopasaṃhāravadvayāptisiddhiḥ /
analyzed: yat vastu na tat sva prakāśam iti vyāpti jñānam sva ātmānam na viṣayīkaroti ced na sarva upasaṃhāra vat vayāpti siddhiḥ
translated: If the knowledge that whatever is an entity is not self-luminous does not take itself as its object, then the establishment of the pervasion that includes everything is not possible.

analyzed: viṣayīkaraṇe tu sva prakāśa tvam durnivāram iti āśayavataḥ vā upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: But if it does take itself as its object, then self-luminosity is irresistible. With this intention, the opponent's conclusion is stated.

analyzed: yat uktam īśvaraḥ nanta guṇaḥ iti tat anupapannam
translated: What was said that God has infinite qualities is not correct.

analyzed: caturviṃśateḥ adhikānām guṇānām abhāvāt
translated: Because more than twenty-four qualities do not exist.

analyzed: tatra api keṣāñcid īśvare nupapatteḥ
translated: And even there, some are not possible in God.

analyzed: tasmāt upapannaiḥ aṣṭabhiḥ eva guṇaiḥ upapannaḥ bhagavān iti
translated: Therefore, the Blessed One is established with only the eight qualities that are possible.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: śaurya audāya rprāgalbhya prabhṛtīnām guṇānām bhāvāt
translated: Because qualities such as heroism, generosity, and boldness exist.

analyzed: pareṇa svīkṛteṣu api keṣāñcid anupapatti abhāvāt ca
translated: And because some of those accepted by the opponent are not possible.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is how.

analyzed: sukham tāvat īśvarasya kutas nā aṅgīkartavyam
translated: First, why should happiness not be accepted as belonging to God?

original: īśvaraḥ sukharahito duḥkharahitatvādghaṭavat /🔽sukhavāṃścedaduḥkhavānprasajyate devadattavaditi vipakṣe bādhakopapannādanumānāditi cet /
analyzed: īśvaraḥ sukha rahitaḥ duḥkha rahita tvāt ghaṭa vat  sukhavān ced aduḥkhavān prasajyate devadatta vat iti vipakṣe bādhaka upapannāt anumānāt iti ced
translated: God is devoid of happiness, because He is devoid of misery, like a jar.🔽If He were happy, He would be miserable, like Devadatta. If this is argued, then the inference is valid because it overturns the contrary position.

analyzed: tatra anugrāhakasya tarkasya tāvat dūṣaṇam āha sukhavān iti
translated: To that, he first criticizes the supporting reasoning, saying If He were happy...

original: sukhavān duḥkhavāṃśca syāditi vyāptiśca no bhavet // / / //
analyzed: sukhavān duḥkhavān ca syāt iti vyāptiḥ ca no bhavet
translated: And the pervasion that He would be both happy and miserable would not be established.

analyzed: katham vyāpti abhāvaḥ iti atas āha nirduḥkha tvam iti
translated: How is there no pervasion? To this he says The absence of misery...

analyzed: nirduḥkha tvam mahānandaḥ śrutyā evā īśasya bhaṇyate
translated: The absence of misery is said to be the great bliss of God by the scriptures.

analyzed: yadi api sukhi tvam duḥkhi tvena sahacaritam devadatta ādau upalabdham
translated: Although happiness is observed to co-occur with misery in Devadatta and others,

original: tathāpīśvare nirduḥkhe 'pi vācyaṃ prāk prasañjānādvayāptigrahaṇavelāyāmevedaṃ vyāptibhaṅgodbhāvanamiti /
analyzed: tathā api īśvare nirduḥkhe vācyam prāk prasañjānāt vayāpti grahaṇa velāyām evā idam vyāpti bhaṅga udbhāvanam iti
translated: even so, in God, who is without misery, this objection regarding the break in pervasion should have been raised earlier, at the time of grasping the pervasion, before the reductio ad absurdum.

analyzed: sarvatra api evam vaktum śakya tvena ukta doṣa anistārāt iti
translated: Because it can be said in this way in every case, and the stated fault cannot be avoided.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: sva abhyupagama mātreṇa āpādana sthale vyāpti bhaṅga abhidhāne sati evam etat
translated: When a reductio ad absurdum is stated by merely accepting one's own position, then this is the case.

analyzed: na ca evam prakṛte
translated: But it is not so in the present case.

analyzed: śruti balena eva īśvare sukhi tvasya duḥkhi tvasya
translated: By the power of the scriptures alone, the existence of happiness and suffering in God,

analyzed: vyabhicāra upapādanāt
translated: Because it has been shown that the existence of pleasure and pain in God is not contradicted by the scriptures themselves.

analyzed: tat idam uktam śrutyā eva bhaṇyate iti
translated: This is what is meant by the statement that it is stated by the scriptures themselves.

analyzed: pratyekam sambandhāt ekavacanam  kā asau śrutiḥ iti atas rthataḥ tām udāharati yaḥ iti
translated: The singular number is used because of the connection with each individual.

analyzed: śanāyā pipāse ca śoka ādīn ca ativartate
translated: What is that scripture? Therefore, he states it in the sense of the text, He who transcends hunger, thirst, sorrow, and so on,

original: ānandaṃ brahmaṇo vidvān vipāpmetyādikā ca sā // / / //🔽anenayo 'śanāyāpipāse śokaṃ mohaṃ jarāṃ mṛtyumatyeti' /
analyzed: ānandam brahmaṇaḥ vidvān vipāpmā iti ādikā ca sā  śanāyā pipāse śokam moham jarām mṛtyum atyeti
translated: The one who knows the bliss of Brahman, free from sin, and so on.

analyzed: iti śrutim upādatte
translated: By this, he refers to the scripture He transcends hunger, thirst, sorrow, delusion, old age, and death.

analyzed: vipāpmā iti anenayaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā  ityādi śrutim
translated: By free from sin, he refers to the scripture The self is free from sin.
This scripture speaks of the absence of suffering and so on.

original: nanvānandaśruterduḥkhābhāvaviṣayatvopapatterna śrutyavaṣṭambhena prasaṅgamūlabhūtavyāptibhaṅgo vaktuṃ śakyata ityato 'ṅgīkṛtya tāvatsopādhikatvamāha
analyzed: nanu ānanda śruteḥ duḥkha abhāva viṣaya tva upapatteḥ na śruti avaṣṭambhena prasaṅga mūla bhūta vyāpti bhaṅgaḥ vaktum śakyate iti atas ṅgīkṛtya tāvat sopādhikatvam āha  /
translated: But since the statement of bliss can be explained as referring to the absence of suffering, it cannot be said that the pervasion, which is the basis of the reductio argument, is contradicted by the scriptures. Accepting the qualified nature for the time being, he says

analyzed: īśvarasya iti
translated: of God, and so on.

analyzed: īśvarasya tathā iṣṭatvam duḥkhi tva upādhiḥ iti api
translated: Even if it is said that the qualification of being a sufferer is due to God's will in that way,

analyzed: ukte kim uttaram brūyāt śruti anādara tatparaḥ
translated: what answer can one who is devoted to disregarding the scriptures give?

analyzed: tathā iṣṭa tvam duḥkhī bhavatu iti iṣṭa tvam
translated: Similarly, the desire for one to be miserable is the desire for one to be miserable.
The qualifier of misery is the cause of misery.

analyzed: apipadena adharma ādimattvam samuccinoti  anādaraḥ vinā bādhakena pratīta artha parityāgaḥ
translated: The word 'and' includes the possession of unrighteousness, etc.🔽Disregard is the abandonment of the understood meaning without a contradiction.

analyzed: mā bhūt tāvat śruti avaṣṭambhena vyāpti bhaṅgaḥ
translated: Let there not be a violation of the pervasion by the support of the Vedic text.

analyzed: sa upādhika tayā tu bhaviṣyati
translated: But it will be by way of a limiting adjunct.

analyzed: sa upādhika sambandhasya vyabhicāra niyamāt iti
translated: Because the relation with a limiting adjunct is necessarily fallacious.

original: yaḥ sukhī sa duḥkhī bhavatvitīśvarecchāviṣaya eveti niyamānnāyamupādhirityata āha na ceti //
analyzed: yaḥ sukhī sa duḥkhī bhavatu iti īśvara icchā viṣayaḥ eva iti niyamāt na ayam upādhiḥ iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: The restriction that only one who is happy is the object of the wish of the Lord that he become miserable, is not a limiting adjunct. Hence he says 'and' etc.

original: na cātmaduḥkhitecchā syādata etannivāryate // / / //🔽īśvarasya hiānandaṃ brahmaṇo vidvān' /
analyzed: na ca ātma duḥkhitā icchā syāt atas etat nivāryate  īśvarasya hi ānandam brahmaṇaḥ vidvān
translated: And there would be no wish for the misery of the self. Therefore, this is refuted.

analyzed: ityādi śruteḥ sukhi tve pi nā upādhimat tvam
translated: For the Lord, there is no possession of a limiting adjunct, even though he is happy, because of Vedic statements such as 'One who knows Brahman as bliss'.

analyzed: kasya api ātma duḥkhita icchā bhāvāt atas etad upādheḥ vyāpya abhimata vyāpaka tvam
translated: Because no one has the wish for the misery of the self. Therefore, the pervasion of this limiting adjunct over what is intended to be pervaded is refuted.

analyzed: yadi api ayam niyamaḥ na darśana mātreṇa siddhayati
translated: Although this restriction is not established merely by perception,

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: because of over-extension,

analyzed: niyāmakam tu na asti iti vaktum śakyate
translated: it can be said that there is no determining factor.

analyzed: tathā api śruti artha parityāgam vārayitum prasaṅga āpādanāya idam uditam iti draṣṭavyam
translated: Still, it should be seen that this is stated to show the absurdity of abandoning the meaning of the Vedic text.

analyzed: bhavet etat yadi ānanda śrutiḥ sukha vādinī syāt na ca etat asti
translated: This would be so if the statement about bliss were about happiness. But that is not so.

analyzed: tasyāḥ duḥkha abhāva para tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this is because it refers to the absence of pain,

analyzed: kim bādhakāt iyam śrutiḥ svārthāt pracyāvyate uta evam eva
translated: is this Vedic statement to be taken away from its own meaning due to some contradictory evidence, or is it just as it is?

analyzed: na tāvat dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: duḥkha abhāva śruteḥ api anyathayitum śakya tvena tarkasya iṣi āpatti tā āpatteḥ
translated: Because even the statement about the absence of pain can be interpreted otherwise, the argument would lead to the undesirable consequence of being inconclusive.

analyzed: ādye na tāvat pratyakṣam āgamaḥ vā sti
translated: As for the first, there is no contradictory evidence, either perception or scripture.

original: tataḥ sukhitve duḥkhitvaprasaṅgo vā nirduḥkhatvānumānaṃ vā bādhakamiti vācyam /
analyzed: tatas sukhi tve duḥkhi tva prasaṅgaḥ vā nirduḥkha tva anumānam vā bādhakam iti vācyam
translated: Therefore, it must be said that the consequence of being happy would be being miserable, or the inference of being free from misery is the contradictory evidence.

analyzed: tat ubhayam api vyapti bala pravṛttam vā syāt saha darśana mātra bala pravṛttam vā
translated: Both of those could be based on the power of the pervasion, or based on the power of mere simultaneous observation.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: itaretara āśraya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because there would be the undesirable consequence of mutual dependence.

original: siddhe hi śruteḥ svārthapracyāvane tarkānumānayorvyāptisiddhistatsiddhau ca śruteḥ svārthātpracyāvanasiddhiriti / /
analyzed: siddhe hi śruteḥ svārtha pracyāvane tarka anumānayoḥ vyāpti siddhiḥ tad siddhau ca śruteḥ svārthāt pracyāvana siddhiḥ iti
translated: For, if the Vedic statement is established to be taken away from its own meaning, then the establishment of the pervasion of the inference based on the power of the argument would be established. And if that is established, then the establishment of the Vedic statement being taken away from its own meaning would be established.

analyzed: nanu etat bhavatām api samānam
translated: But this is the same for you too.

analyzed: śruteḥ svārtha paratve tarka anumānayoḥ vyāpti bhaṅgaḥ
translated: If the Veda is devoted to its own meaning, then inference and reasoning break the pervasion.

analyzed: sati ca tasmin śruteḥ svārtha para tvam iti
translated: And if that exists, then the Veda is devoted to its own meaning.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: yatas pratīta artha parityāgaḥ eva bādhakam apekṣate
translated: Because only the abandonment of the understood meaning requires a sublater.

analyzed: na svārtha paratvam
translated: Not the devotion to one's own meaning.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvam
translated: The absence of a sublater.

analyzed: tasya pratītyā eva siddha tvāt
translated: Because that is established by the understanding itself.

analyzed: dvitīye tu atiprasaṅgaḥ syāt iti āha saha iti
translated: But in the second case, there would be an overextension. He says together etc.

analyzed: saha darśana mātreṇa śrutīnām apalāpakaḥ
translated: One who denies the Vedas merely by seeing them together...

analyzed: yajña ādeḥ api pāpasya hetu tvam hiṃsayā yuteḥ
translated: The sacrifice etc. are indeed the cause of sin due to being connected with violence.

analyzed: na anumāti katham
translated: How does one not infer...

original: āpādyena sādhyena vā sahadarśanaṃ yasyāpādakasya sādhanasya vā tatsahadarśanam /
analyzed: āpādyena sādhyena vā saha darśanam yasya āpādakasya sādhanasya vā tat saha darśanam
translated: That which has the seen together with the consequence or the probandum is the seen together of that which is to be inferred or the proof.

analyzed: śrutīnām īśvarasya ānanda vādinīnām apalāpakaḥ sva artha pracyāvakaḥ
translated: One who denies the Vedas, which declare the bliss of God, who causes the abandonment of their own meaning.

analyzed: yajña ādeḥ iti ādi padena gobhyaḥ yavasa dānam gṛhyate
translated: The word etc. in sacrifice etc. includes giving grass to cows.

analyzed: yuteḥ yogāt
translated: Due to connection.

analyzed: yadi saha darśana mātreṇa ānanda śruti artha ālāpaḥ kriyeta
translated: If the meaning of the bliss-declaring Vedas were to be denied merely by seeing them together,

original: tadā yā hiṃsā sā pāpaheturiti sahadarśanena jyotiṣyomādiśrutyarthāpalāpo 'pi kriyatāmaviśeṣāditi bhāvaḥ / /
analyzed: tadā yā hiṃsā sā pāpa hetuḥ iti saha darśanena jyotiṣyoma ādi śruti artha apalāpaḥ pi kriyatām aviśeṣāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Then let there be denial of the meaning of the Vedic texts like Jyotiṣṭoma, etc., along with the perception that violence is the cause of sin, because there is no distinction.

analyzed: nanu aviśeṣaḥ siddhaḥ  hiṃsā tva pāpa sādhana tvayoḥ
translated: But the non-distinction is not established.

analyzed: sāhacarye niṣiddha tvasya upādheḥ vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because of the presence of the limiting condition of being prohibited in the concomitance of violence and being a means of sin.

analyzed: na ca sukhi tva duḥkhi tva sambandhe kaścid upādhiḥ asti
translated: And there is no limiting condition in the relation of being happy and being unhappy.

analyzed: īśvarasya tathā iṣṭatvam upādhiḥ tu idānīm api gahanam
translated: The limiting condition is that God desires it that way, but even now it enters the dense forest.

analyzed: iti āśaṅkate tatra iti
translated: He doubts this in the text.

analyzed: tatra yadi upādhiḥ niṣiddha tā
translated: There, if the limiting condition is prohibited...

analyzed: asti iti ucyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: It is said that it exists. This is the remainder.

analyzed: kā iyam niṣiddha tā nāma
translated: What is this called being prohibited?

analyzed: akartavya tayā śruti ukta tvam iti ced
translated: If it is said to be mentioned in the Veda as not to be done,

analyzed: kā iyam akartavya tā api karaṇa anarha tā vā kartuḥ aniṣya hetu tā vā
translated: what is this called not to be done? Is it being unworthy of being done, or is it being the cause of what is not desired by the doer?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: brahma hiṃsāyāḥ api kriyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because even the violence against Brahman is done.

analyzed: dvitīye pi kim sākṣāt aniṣya sādhanatvam paramparayā vā
translated: In the second also, is it directly being a means of what is not desired, or indirectly?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: hiṃsā anantaram eva duḥkha utpāda adarśanāt
translated: Because suffering is not seen to arise immediately after violence.

analyzed: dvitīye tu pāpa sādhanatayā ukta tvam upādhiḥ iti uktam syāt
translated: But in the second case, it would be said that the statement of being the means of evil is the limiting condition.

analyzed: evam ca atra api upādhi sadbhāvāt aviśeṣaḥ eva iti pariharati aduḥkhi tvena iti
translated: And thus, here also, there is no difference because of the existence of the limiting condition. This is the reply.

analyzed: aduḥkhi tvena ca anuktiḥ katham nā upādhi tām vrajet  aduḥkhi tvena anuktiḥ iti
translated: How can the non-mention of being free from suffering not become a limiting condition?🔽The non-mention of being free from suffering.

analyzed: duḥkhi tvena uktiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is the mention of being a sufferer.

original: kāsau devadattādīnāṃ śrautī duḥkhitvoktirityata āha aduḥkhamiti //
analyzed: kā asau devadatta ādīnām śrautī duḥkhi tva uktiḥ iti atas āha aduḥkham iti
translated: What is that Vedic statement of being a sufferer of Devadatta and others? To this he says: The other is free from suffering.

original: aduḥkhamitarat sarvaṃ jīvā eva tu duḥkhinaḥ /
analyzed: aduḥkham itarat sarvam jīvāḥ eva tu duḥkhinaḥ
translated: All else is free from suffering, but only the individual souls are suffering.

analyzed: teṣām duḥkha prahāṇāya śrutiḥ eṣā pravartate
translated: This Veda proceeds for the cessation of their suffering.

analyzed: iti śrutiḥ hi paramā
translated: For this is the highest Veda.

analyzed: pravartate duḥkha prahāṇa sādhanam paramātmānam pratipādayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it proceeds, teaching the highest self, which is the means of attaining the cessation of suffering.

original: evamanumānānugrāhakaṃ tarkaṃ nirākṛtyedānīmīśvaro na sukhī nirduḥkhatvādghaṭavadityanumānamapi dūṣayati śrutyuktiriti //
analyzed: evam anumāna anugrāhakam tarkam nirākṛtya idānīm īśvaraḥ na sukhī nirduḥkha tvāt ghaṭa vat iti anumānam api dūṣayati śruti uktiḥ iti
translated: Having thus refuted the reasoning that supports inference, he now refutes the inference that God is not happy because he is free from suffering, like a pot. He says: The Vedic statement.

analyzed: śruti uktiḥ yadi kāraṇam
translated: If the Vedic statement is the cause,

analyzed: kim kāryam anumānena gaḷa stana samena hi
translated: what is the use of inference, which is like a blind man's palm?

analyzed: kāraṇam pramāyāḥ
translated: The cause of valid knowledge.

analyzed: ānandam brahmaṇaḥ vidvān
translated: One who knows bliss is Brahman.

analyzed: ityādi śrutiḥ pramāṇam na vā
translated: Is this and other such Vedic statements valid or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe apasiddhāntaḥ
translated: If not, it is a contradiction of one's own doctrine.

analyzed: ādye tad bādhita tvena ajāgala stane iva vivakṣita artha asādhakam anumānam upekṣaṇīyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: If so, then inference, like the barren woman's son, is incapable of establishing the intended meaning, being contradicted by that [Vedic statement], and should be disregarded. This is the point.

original: nanu śrutiḥ pramāṇameva kintvanumānaviruddhatvātpratītārthaṃ parityajya duḥkhābhāvaparatayā vyākhyātavyetyāśaṅkaya /
analyzed: nanu śrutiḥ pramāṇam eva kintu anumāna viruddha tvāt pratīta artham parityajya duḥkha abhāva para tayā vyākhyātavyā iti āśaṅkaya
translated: But isn't the Veda itself a valid means of knowledge? However, because it contradicts inference, its understood meaning should be abandoned and it should be explained as referring to the absence of suffering. Anticipating this doubt,

analyzed: na evam
translated: [the author] says No.

analyzed: anumānasya śruti bādhaka tva adarśanāt
translated: Because inference is not seen to contradict the Veda.

analyzed: kvacid upajīvya tva ādinā eva bādhaka tvāt
translated: It is only in some cases that it [inference] is contradictory due to being sublated by something else, such as being based on something else.

analyzed: evam eva bādhaka tva abhyupagame tu atiprasaṅgaḥ syāt iti āha anumānena iti
translated: If it were accepted that it [inference] is contradictory in this way alone, there would be an overextension. Thus [the author] says By inference.

analyzed: anumānena yadi arthaḥ śruti dṛṣṭaḥ vyapodyate
translated: If the meaning seen in the Veda is abandoned,

original: pūrvoktena prakāreṇa neśvaro dharma eva ca /
analyzed: pūrva uktena prakāreṇa na īśvaraḥ dharmaḥ eva ca
translated: then neither God nor Dharma, as stated earlier,

analyzed: syāt tad phalam ca
translated: would exist, and the result of that [Dharma] would also be nonexistent.

analyzed: pūrva uktena śāstrayoni sūtra uktena
translated: As stated earlier in the Sutra on the Source of Dharma.

analyzed: na īśvaraḥ syāt śruti dṛṣṭaḥ pi īśvaraḥ numāna virodhāt tyājyaḥ syāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even if God is seen in the Veda, He should be abandoned due to contradiction with inference. This is the point.

original: dharmaśca naiva syāttatphalaṃ ca naiva syādityatrāpyevameva tātparyam /
analyzed: dharmaḥ ca nā eva syāt tad phalam ca nā eva syāt iti atra api evam eva tātparyam
translated: And the meaning here also is that Dharma would not exist and its result would not exist.

analyzed: yajña kriyā na adṛṣṭa phala hetuḥ kriyā tvāt niṣṭhīvana ādi kriyā vat
translated: The sacrificial act is not the cause of unseen results, because it is an action, like the act of spitting.

analyzed: dharmaḥ vā na sukha sādhanam adṛṣṭa tvāt adharma vat ityādi anumāna sambhavāt
translated: Or Dharma is not a means of happiness, because it is unseen, like adharma. Since such inferences are possible,

analyzed: atiprasaṅgasya viparyaye paryavasānam āha tena iti
translated: The conclusion of the over-extension in the opposite is stated by therefore etc.

analyzed: tena atra śrutiḥ eva pramā bhavet
translated: Therefore, here, the Veda itself would be the valid cognition.

analyzed: yasmāt upajīvya tva ādi rahitena anumānena ānanda śruteḥ bādhā abhyupagame niṣya prasaṅgaḥ tena kāraṇena eṣā śrutiḥ atra īśvarasya ānandavat tve eva pramā pramāṇam
translated: Since, if the contradiction of the statement of bliss by inference devoid of the dependence etc. is accepted, there would be undesirable consequences, by that reason, this Veda is the valid cognition only with regard to the blissfulness of God here,

analyzed: bhavet na punar anyathā yojyā iti  mā bhūt śrutiḥ apramāṇam
translated: and it should not be interpreted otherwise.🔽Let the Veda not be invalid.

analyzed: mā ca bhūt anumāna bādhayā artha antara parā
translated: And let it not be referring to something else due to being contradicted by inference.

analyzed: tathā api anumānasya bādhikā kutas
translated: Even then, how can it contradict inference?

analyzed: pratirodhikā tu bhavet iti atas āha īśasya iti
translated: But it can be a counter-agent. Therefore it is said of God etc.

analyzed: īśasya anumayā siddheḥ śrutiḥ dhamiḥ pramā bhavet
translated: Since God is established by inference, the Veda would be the valid cognition of Dharma.

original: tayā sarvaguṇaiḥ pūrṇa ukta īśo yatastataḥ // / / //
analyzed: tayā sarva guṇaiḥ pūrṇaḥ uktaḥ īśaḥ yatas tatas
translated: And by that, the Lord is said to be full of all qualities, because of that.

analyzed: an ānanda anumā tasya dharmi grāhi virodhataḥ
translated: The inference of non-bliss in Him is contradicted by the pramāṇa that apprehends the substratum.

analyzed: na pramāṇam bhavet
translated: It cannot be a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: anumayā iti śruti vyatirikta pramāṇa upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word anumāna (inference) is a reference to other means of valid knowledge besides verbal testimony.
The pramāṇa that apprehends the substratum is the means of valid knowledge that apprehends the substratum.

original: anumānaṃ hi pramāṇāntareṇa siddhe dharmiṇi pravartate nānyathā /
analyzed: anumānam hi pramāṇa antareṇa siddhe dharmiṇi pravartate na anyathā
translated: For inference operates when the substratum is established by another means of valid knowledge, not otherwise.

original: atra ceśvaro dharmī na cāsāvanumānena siddhayatīti samarthitaṃ prāk /
analyzed: atra ca īśvaraḥ dharmī na ca asau anumānena siddhayati iti samarthitam prāk
translated: And here, the Lord is the substratum, and He is not established by inference, as has been argued earlier.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi aviṣaya tvam tu parasya api sammatam
translated: But the fact that He is not the object of perception etc. is accepted by the opponent as well.

original: tataḥ pariśeṣāt śrutireva dharmiṇaḥ parameśvarasya grāhiketyeṣyavyam /
analyzed: tatas pariśeṣāt śrutiḥ eva dharmiṇaḥ parameśvarasya grāhikā iti eṣyavyam
translated: Therefore, by elimination, it must be accepted that verbal testimony alone is the apprehender of the supreme Lord, the substratum.

analyzed: tathā ca anena anumānena śruti prāmāṇyam anumatam
translated: And thus, by this inference, the validity of verbal testimony is accepted.

analyzed: anyathā svasya anutthāna prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, it would lead to the absurdity of its own non-establishment.

analyzed: sā ca upajīvyā śrutiḥ īśvaram ānandavantam ācaṣṭe  tatas tad virodhāt anumānam apramāṇam eva
translated: And that verbal testimony, which is to be relied upon, declares the Lord to be blissful.🔽Therefore, because of its contradiction, inference is not a means of valid knowledge at all.

analyzed: agni svarūpa grāhaka pratyakṣa viruddha tad śaitya anumāna vat iti
translated: Like the inference of the coolness of fire, which is contradicted by perception that apprehends the nature of fire.

original: naca vācyaṃ yaḥ sarvajña ityādivākyamanumānasyopajīvyaṃ nānandavādīti /
analyzed: na ca vācyam yaḥ sarvajñaḥ ityādi vākyam anumānasya upajīvyam na ānanda vādi iti
translated: And it cannot be said that the statement He who is omniscient etc. is the basis of inference, not the statement about bliss.

analyzed: sarvasya api vedasya eka vākya tvena ardhaja  caratīyā yogāt  anyathā agni grāhakam eva upajīvyam
translated: Because all the Veda is one sentence, there is no contradiction in the half-verse.🔽Otherwise, it might be said that only that which apprehends fire is the basis,

analyzed: na tu tat auṣṇya grāhakam iti api syāt
translated: but not that which apprehends its heat.

analyzed: anena eva nyāyena īśvarasya vigraha rāhitya ādi anumānam api sarvam śruti viruddha tvāt apramāṇam eva iti āśayavān upasaṃharati tasmāt iti
translated: With this very reasoning, all inference of the Lord's lack of a body etc. is also not a means of valid knowledge due to contradicting the scriptures. With this intention, he concludes with Therefore.

analyzed: tasmāt na anumātra upayoginī
translated: Therefore, inference is not useful at all.

analyzed: atra īśvara vākye
translated: Here, in the statement about the Lord.

original: ata eva sarvaguṇaiḥ pūrṇa ityuktam anyathā'nandavānityavakṣyat / /🔽anupapattyantaraṃ vaiśeṣikādidarśane darśayannityameva ca bhāvāt' /
analyzed: atas eva sarva guṇaiḥ pūrṇaḥ iti uktam anyathā ānandavān iti avakṣyat  anupapatti antaram vaiśeṣika ādi darśane darśayan nityam eva ca bhāvāt
translated: For this very reason, it is said to be full of all qualities. Otherwise, it would have said possessing bliss.

original: iti sūtraṃ vyākhyāti nityecchatvāditi //🔽nityecchatvāt pareśasya paramāṇusadātvataḥ /
analyzed: iti sūtram vyākhyāti nitya icchā tvāt iti  nitya icchā tvāt para īśasya paramāṇu sadātvataḥ
translated: Showing another inconsistency in the Vaiśeṣika and other systems, he explains the aphorism And because of the eternal existence as Because of the Lord's eternal will.🔽Because of the eternal existence of the atom, and because of the eternal existence of the unseen, the effect would always exist.

analyzed: adṛṣṭa kālayoḥ ca eva bhāvāt kāryam sadā bhavet
translated: Because of the eternal will of the Supreme Lord, the eternal existence of the atom, and the eternal existence of the unseen, the effect would always exist.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika ādayaḥ hi kāla viśeṣe dvayaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa mahābhūta sṛṣṭim abhyupagacchanti
translated: For the Vaiśeṣikas and others accept the creation of the great elements in a series beginning with the two atoms, at a particular time.

analyzed: tad tadīya prakriyā paryālocanāyām nā upapadyate
translated: This is not possible when examining their respective theories.

analyzed: kintu tad pakṣe kāryam sadā bhavet
translated: But in their view, the effect would always exist.

analyzed: yadā abhilaṣṭate tatas prāk api bhavet
translated: It would exist even before what is desired,

analyzed: kutas
translated: why?

analyzed: kāraṇa sāmagrī sampatti nibandhanaḥ hi kārya utpatteḥ kāla niyamaḥ
translated: For the restriction of time in the production of an effect is based on the completeness of the assemblage of causes.

analyzed: tatra ādi sṛṣṭau paramāṇavaḥ samavāyikāraṇa bhūtāḥ tāvat sadā vidyante
translated: In that case, in the initial creation, the atoms, which are the inherent causes, always exist.

analyzed: nimitta kāraṇam ca īśvara icchā nityā eva
translated: And the instrumental cause, God's will, is always present.

analyzed: tathā kālaḥ
translated: So are time and space.

original: yadyapyadṛṣṭaṃ dharmādharmasamākhyātaṃ na nityaṃ tathāpi pralaye 'stītyaṅgīkriyata eva /
analyzed: yadi api adṛṣṭam dharma adharma samākhyātam na nityam tathā api pralaye sti iti aṅgīkriyate eva
translated: Although the unseen, called virtue and vice, is not eternal, it is still accepted as existing at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: vṛttilābhaḥ tadā na asti iti ced na
translated: If it is said that its manifestation does not exist then, that is not so.

analyzed: tasya api īśvara icchā ādi kāraṇakasya tad bhāve bhāva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because even that, which has God's will etc. as its cause, cannot be non-existent when that exists.

analyzed: atas eva paramāṇu saṃyogasya asamavāyi kāraṇasya abhāvāt na sadā sṛsat ādi sṛ
translated: For this very reason, it is refuted that the creation of the great elements etc. does not occur always because the conjunction of the atoms, which is the non-inherent cause, does not exist.

analyzed: mahat ādi sṛ  nirastam
translated: The creation of the great elements etc.

analyzed: saṃyoga anutpādasya api anupapatteḥ
translated: is not possible even if the conjunction does not arise.

analyzed: tad asamavāyi kāraṇa karma abhāvāt iti ced na
translated: If it be said that this is because there is no action which is the non-inherent cause of that [i.e., of the world], [we reply:] no.

analyzed: tad anutpādasya api ayogāt
translated: Because the non-production of that [i.e., of the world] is also impossible.

analyzed: na ca atas ni advayaṇuka ādeḥ kāraṇam asti  yad vaikalyāt abhilaṣita samayāt prāk kārya abhāvaḥ bhavet
translated: And there is no other cause of the dyad, etc.,🔽by the deficiency of which there would be non-existence of the effect prior to the desired conjunction.

analyzed: satyām ca abhimata sāmagṣām kārya anudaye paścāt api nā utpadyeta
translated: And when the desired conjunction exists, the effect would not arise even later,

analyzed: niyāmaka abhāvāt iti
translated: because there is no restriction.

analyzed: sadātvam sadātatvanam
translated: The word 'ever' [is used].

analyzed: bhāvāt pralaye pi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: eva śabdasya sadā eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The word 'ever' is connected with 'the effect would exist'.

analyzed: kāryam bhavet iti ca abhyupagamya uktam
translated: And this is said on the assumption [that the effect exists].

analyzed: vastutas tu tad pakṣe kadāpi dvayaṇuka ādi utpattiḥ na sambhavati
translated: But in reality, in that view, the production of the dyad, etc., is never possible.

analyzed: vināśa kāraṇasya īśvara icchā ādeḥ sadātana tvena sat pratipakṣa tvāt
translated: Because the cause of destruction, such as God's will, is always present, and is a counter-agent to existence.

analyzed: kārya utpatti sahakṛtam eva īśvara icchā ādikam vināśa kāraṇam iti aṅgīkāre pi utpatti anantaram eva vināśaḥ prasajyeta iti
translated: Even if it is accepted that God's will, etc., is the cause of destruction only when it cooperates with the production of the effect, destruction would still occur immediately after production.

analyzed: atas eva sṛṣṭa yādi iti vakṣyati
translated: For this very reason, he will say 'creation, etc.'

original: syādevaṃ yadi kālamātraṃ sṛṣṭervā saṃhārasya vā kāraṇaṃ syāt /
analyzed: syāt evam yadi kāla mātram sṛṣṭeḥ vā saṃhārasya vā kāraṇam syāt
translated: This would be so if time alone were the cause of creation or dissolution.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: kintu kāla viśeṣe eva atas tad bhāva abhāvābhyām sṛṣṭi saṃhāra niyamaḥ ghaṭate
translated: But it is only at a particular time that creation and dissolution are possible due to the existence or non-existence of that [time].

original: tathā neśvarecchāmātraṃ sṛṣṭayādihetuḥ kintu tadviśeṣa eva tatastadbhāvābhāvaprayuktā sṛṣṭayādivyavasthā syāditi cenna /
analyzed: tathā nā īśvara icchā mātram sṛṣṭayā ādi hetuḥ kintu tad viśeṣaḥ eva tatas tad bhāva abhāva prayuktā sṛṣṭayā ādi vyavasthā syāt iti ced na
translated: Similarly, the mere will of God is not the cause of creation etc., but only a particular aspect of it. Therefore, the arrangement of creation etc. would be due to the existence or non-existence of that [particular aspect]. This is not so.

analyzed: kim kāla deśa ādeḥ aupādhikaḥ bhedaḥ
translated: Is the difference of time, place etc. adventitious?

analyzed: kiṃvā svābhāvikaḥ
translated: Or is it natural?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: nirasta tvāt
translated: Because it has been refuted.

analyzed: dvitīye tu apasiddhāntaḥ iti āha nahi iti
translated: In the second case, there is a contradiction of one's own doctrine. He says no etc.

analyzed: na hi kāla vibhedaḥ sti tad pakṣe  hi śabdena ākāśa kāla diśām ekaika tvāt
translated: For, in that view, there is no difference in time.

analyzed: ityādi tad vākyam smārayati
translated: By the word hi (for), he reminds of the statement beginning with because space, time and direction are one each.

analyzed: kāla iti īśvara icchāyāḥ api upalakṣaṇam
translated: In time also indicates the will of God.

analyzed: nanu idam dūṣaṇam bhavatām api samānam
translated: But this criticism is the same for you also.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus:

analyzed: mahat ādi upādānakāraṇam prakṛtiḥ nityā eva
translated: The material cause of Mahat and other [effects] is Nature, which is eternal.

analyzed: tathā nimitta kāraṇam īśvara icchā kāla ādikam api
translated: Similarly, the instrumental cause is also the will of God, time etc.

analyzed: tat eva ca pralaya kāraṇam
translated: And that alone is the cause of dissolution.

original: ataḥ sṛṣṭipralayasamayaniyamo bhavatāmapi durghaṭa ityata āha asmanmata iti //
analyzed: atas sṛṣṭi pralaya samaya niyamaḥ bhavatām api durghaṭaḥ iti atas āha asmad mataḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the restriction of the time of creation and dissolution is difficult to establish even for you. Hence he says in our view etc.

analyzed: smanmate hareḥ
translated: In our view, of Hari.

analyzed: viśeṣa kāle eva etat sṛṣṭa yādi icchā sadātanā
translated: This desire for creation etc. is indeed eternal, but only at specific times.

analyzed: yadi api asmad mate hareḥ icchā sadātanā
translated: Even though in our view Hari's desire is eternal,

analyzed: prakṛti ādi upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: this is an illustration of Prakṛti and others.

original: tathāpi viśeṣakāla evaitasya mahadādeḥ sṛṣṭayādi bhavatīti yojanā /
analyzed: tathā api viśeṣa kāle eva etasya mahat ādeḥ sṛṣṭayādi bhavati iti yojanā
translated: Nevertheless, the creation etc. of this Mahat and others occurs only at specific times - this is the construction.

analyzed: asmābhiḥ kāle svabhāvataḥ eva bhedaḥ bhyupagamyate
translated: We accept the difference of time as inherent.

original: tathā ca kālaviśeṣasyaiva sṛṣṭiṃ saṃhāraṃ ca kāraṇatvāttadbhāvābhāvābhyāṃ satsvapītarakāraṇeṣu sṛṣṭayādisamayaniyamo yujyata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca kāla viśeṣasya eva sṛṣṭim saṃhāram ca kāraṇa tvāt tad bhāva abhāvābhyām satsu api itara kāraṇeṣu sṛṣṭayā ādi samaya niyamaḥ yujyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, since only specific time is the cause of creation and dissolution, even when other causes are present, the restriction of the time of creation etc. is reasonable due to its existence and non-existence - this is the idea.

analyzed: nanu kāla viśeṣaḥ iti vācyam
translated: But it should be said specific time.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: viśiṣṭataḥ iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: Viśiṣṭataḥ means viśeṣa.

analyzed: sa ca asau kālaḥ ca iti vigraha grahaṇāt
translated: And that is kāla - this is the compound.🔽But it should be sadātana.

analyzed: nanu sadātanī iti bhavitavyam  mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: na ayam ṭyu ṭyuloḥ anya rataḥ pratyayaḥ
translated: This is not a suffix denoting the present participle or another.

analyzed: kintu bhabhā
translated: But this suffix tan

analyzed: vā arthe tana pratyayaḥ yam
translated: denotes the meaning of existence.

analyzed: athavā tanā iti tanote rūpam etat
translated: Or tan is the form of tanoti.

original: nanu te kālabhedā yadi nityāstadā sa prasaṅgastadavasthaḥ /
analyzed: nanu te kāla bhedāḥ yadi nityāḥ tadā sa prasaṅgaḥ tad avasthaḥ
translated: But if those divisions of time are eternal, then that consequence remains as it is.

analyzed: vyarthaḥ ca kāla bheda abhyupagamaḥ
translated: And the assumption of the difference of time is useless.

analyzed: anitya tve tat kāraṇam vācyam iti ced
translated: If it is said that in non-eternality, its cause should be stated,

analyzed: satyam  upādānam tu prakṛtiḥ eva
translated: it is true.🔽But the material cause is only nature.

analyzed: nimittam āha viśeṣāḥ ca iti
translated: The instrumental cause is stated by the word 'specialities'.

analyzed: viśeṣāḥ ca eva kālasya hareḥ icchā vaśāḥ sadā
translated: And the specialities of time are always under the control of Hari's will.

original: na kevalaṃ mahadādi kintu kālasya viśeṣāśca kṣaṇalavādayaḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam mahat ādi kintu kālasya viśeṣāḥ ca kṣaṇa lava ādayaḥ
translated: Not only Mahat and the rest, but also the specialities of time such as the moment, the second, etc.

analyzed: eva śabdasya hareḥ eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The word 'only' is connected with 'of Hari'.

original: sadetyanena na yugapatsarvakṣaṇasṛṣṭiryena teṣāmapi kṣaṇikatvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: sadā iti anena na yugapad sarva kṣaṇa sṛṣṭiḥ yena teṣām api kṣaṇika tvam syāt
translated: By the word 'always', it is said that not all moments are created simultaneously, by which they too would be momentary.

analyzed: kintu nirantara pravāha tayā iti uktam bhavati
translated: But it is said that they are created by a continuous stream.

original: nanu kālaviśeṣāṇāṃ parameśvarājjanma kutaḥ pramāṇātsiddhamityata āha sarva iti //
analyzed: nanu kāla viśeṣāṇām parameśvarāt janma kutas pramāṇāt siddham iti atas āha sarve iti
translated: But from what means is it known that the specialities of time are born from the Supreme Lord? To this he says 'all' etc.

original: sarve nimeṣā iti hi śrutirevāha sādaram // / / //
analyzed: sarve nimeṣāḥ iti hi śrutiḥ eva āha sādaram
translated: The scripture itself emphatically declares that all the twinklings of the eye are born from Him.

analyzed: sarve nimeṣāḥ jajñire vidyutaḥ puruṣāt adhi
translated: All the twinklings of the eye are born from the Person, from the lightning.

analyzed: iti śrutiḥ eva kāla viśeṣāṇām īśvarāt janim āha hi iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the scripture itself declares that the specialities of time are born from the Lord.

original: viśeṣaṇadyotata iti vidyuttasmātparamapuruṣātsarve nimeṣāḥ kālabhedā adhijajñire yatāsvaṃ jāyanta iti /
analyzed: viśeṣaṇa dyotate iti vidyut tasmāt paramapuruṣāt sarve nimeṣāḥ kāla bhedāḥ adhijajñire yata āsvam jāyante iti
translated: From that Supreme Person, all the divisions of time, the twinklings of an eye, are born, each according to its own nature.

analyzed: nanu eṣā śrutiḥ kāla upādhīnām īśvarāt jananam āha
translated: But this Vedic text speaks of the origin of the limiting adjuncts of time from God,

analyzed: na tu kālasya
translated: not of time itself.

analyzed: tathā sati kāṣṭhā kalā muhartāḥ ca iti uttara vākyasya paunaruktya prasaṅgāt
translated: If it were so, then the subsequent statement and the kashthas, kalas, muhurtas, etc. would be redundant.

analyzed: nahi sarva nimeṣa atiriktam kāṣṭhā kalā ādikam asti
translated: For there is no kashtha, kala, etc. apart from all twinklings of an eye.

original: upādhayastu nimeṣādirūpāḥ pṛthageveti na tatra punaruktidoṣa ityata uktam sādaramiti //
analyzed: upādhayaḥ tu nimeṣa ādi rūpāḥ pṛthak eva iti na tatra punarukti doṣaḥ iti atas uktam sādaram iti
translated: But the limiting adjuncts in the form of twinklings of an eye, etc. are different, so there is no fault of redundancy there. Thus it is said with emphasis.

original: yatsarvanimeṣajanmābhidhāya punaḥ kāṣṭhādijanmābhidhatte tadādarārthamityato na punaruktidoṣaḥ /
analyzed: yat sarva nimeṣa janma abhidhāya punar kāṣṭha ādi janma abhidhatte tat ādara artham iti atas na punarukti doṣaḥ
translated: When it speaks of the origin of all twinklings of an eye and then again speaks of the origin of kashthas, etc., that is for the purpose of emphasis, so there is no fault of redundancy.

analyzed: upādhi bhedaḥ tu na upapadyate iti uktam eva iti
translated: It has already been said that the difference in limiting adjuncts is not tenable.

analyzed: nanu nimeṣa ādi śabdāḥ akṣi pakṣma saṃyoga ādi vācinaḥ na sākṣāt kāla abhidhāyinaḥ
translated: But the words twinkling of an eye, etc. denote the conjunction of the eyelashes with the eye, etc., not directly the time.

original: ato neyaṃ śrutirvyaktaṃ kālasyaiveśvarājjanma pratipādayitumalamityato 'tra spaṣṭāṃ śrutiṃ cāha udīrayatīti //
analyzed: atas na iyam śrutiḥ vyaktam kālasya eva īśvarāt janma pratipādayitum alam iti atas spaṣṭām śrutim ca āha udīrayati iti
translated: Therefore this Vedic text is clearly not able to teach the origin of time from God. Thus, to state a clear Vedic text on this, he says it is said.

analyzed: udīrayati kāla ākhya śaktim iti asya vāc api
translated: His speech also manifests the power called time.

analyzed: saḥ ntar śarīre rpita bhūta sūkṣmaḥ kāla ātmikām śaktim udīrayāṇaḥ
translated: He, having placed the subtle elements in the body, manifesting the power which is of the nature of time,

analyzed: iti asya īśvarasya vāc api kālasya īśvarāt utpattim āha iti arthaḥ
translated: This means that the speech of that God also declares the origin of time from God.

analyzed: kāla ātmikām kāla ākhyām sahakāri śaktim udīrayāṇaḥ janayan iti arthaḥ
translated: Manifesting, generating the power called time, which is the cooperating power of the nature of time.

analyzed: atra kāla śabdāt īśvarasya jagat sṛṣṭau śakti tva abhidhānāt ca na artha antara kalpanā avakāśaḥ
translated: Here, since the word time expresses the power of God in the creation of the world, there is no scope for assuming anything else.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be argued.

analyzed: kālaḥ tāvat sarva utpattimatām nimittam
translated: Time is indeed the cause of all that is produced.

analyzed: na ca kālasya utpattau kāla antaram asti
translated: And there is no other time in the origin of time.

analyzed: tat katham tasya upapattiḥ
translated: How then is it possible?

original: pūrvakālaḥ parakālasya nimittamiti cenna /🔽idānīṃ jātastadānīṃ jāta ityadhikaraṇatayā kālasya kāraṇatāvadhāraṇāt /
analyzed: pūrva kālaḥ para kālasya nimittam iti ced na  idānīm jātaḥ tadānīm jātaḥ iti adhikaraṇa tayā kālasya kāraṇatā avadhāraṇāt
translated: If it is argued that the past time is the cause of the future time, it is not so.🔽Because time is determined as the cause by the relation of the present time to the past time, as in born now, born then.

original: adhikaraṇasya kāryotpattisamānakālīnatāyā gehe jāto goṣṭhe jāta ityādau niścitatvādityata āha kālasyeti //
analyzed: adhikaraṇasya kārya utpatti samāna kālīna tāyāḥ gehe jātaḥ goṣṭhe jātaḥ ityādau niścita tvāt iti atas āha kālasya iti
translated: Since the simultaneity of the cause with the production of the effect is ascertained in born in the house, born in the cowpen, etc., therefore he says of time.

analyzed: kālasya kālaga tvena na virodhaḥ kaścana
translated: And there is no contradiction at all due to the time being subject to time.

analyzed: kālasya utpatti aṅgīkāre na kevalam sādhaka sadbhāvaḥ
translated: When the origination of time is accepted, not only is there the existence of a proof,

analyzed: kintu kaścana virodhaḥ na asti iti yojanā
translated: but also there is no contradiction at all. This is the construction.

analyzed: etat ca prapañcayiṣyate
translated: And this will be elaborated.

original: evaṃ svamate kālaviśeṣabhāvābhāvaprayuktaḥ sṛṣṭayādeḥ samayaniyama iti samarthitam /
analyzed: evam sva mate kāla viśeṣa bhāva abhāva prayuktaḥ sṛṣṭayā ādeḥ samaya niyamaḥ iti samarthitam
translated: Thus, it has been established that the restriction of creation etc. is due to the presence and absence of specific times in one's own view.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa tam samarthayate
translated: He establishes it in another way, beginning with asankhyāta.

analyzed: asaṅkhayāt a viśeṣa tvāt icchāyāḥ api sarvadā
translated: Even the desire, due to having innumerable distinctions, is always...

analyzed: sarvadā vidyamānāyāḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is existing.

analyzed: sarvadā vidyamānāyāḥ api īśvara icchayāḥ
translated: Even the desire of God, which always exists, is reasonable to have a restriction of creation etc. due to the manifestation and non-manifestation of that, because it has innumerable distinctions such as the desire to create, etc. which exist in the form of the manifestation of power.

original: tvāt tadvayaktyavyaktiprayuktaḥ sṛṣṭayādeḥ samaniyamo yujyata ityarthaḥ /🔽yadyapi kālabhedamātreṇa kṛtasamādhānametat /
analyzed: tvāt tad vayakti avyakti prayuktaḥ sṛṣṭayā ādeḥ samaniyamaḥ yujyate iti arthaḥ  yadi api kāla bheda mātreṇa kṛta samādhānam etat
translated: This is the meaning.🔽Although this has been resolved merely by the difference in time,

analyzed: kāla viśeṣe srakṣyāmi iti evaṃrūpa tvāt bhagavat icchāyāḥ na mogha tvam āpadyate
translated: the desire of God, in the form I will create in a specific time, does not become futile.

analyzed: tathā api vastu sthitiḥ iyam darśitā veditavyā
translated: Still, this is the true state of things that should be understood.

analyzed: kālasya kāla ga tvena iti uktam
translated: It is said that time is the going of time.

original: tatra kiṃ kālaḥ svagataḥ kiṃ vā kālāntaragataḥ /
analyzed: tatra kim kālaḥ svagataḥ kim vā kāla antara gataḥ
translated: There, is time related to itself or to another time?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: sva skandha ārohaṇa vat viruddha tvāt
translated: Because it is contradictory, like climbing one's own shoulders.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: tad abhāvāt
translated: Because it does not exist.

analyzed: bhāve vā kāla antara sṛṣṭi vaiyarthyāt
translated: Or if it exists, because it is useless to create another time.

original: tasyāpyutpattau kālāntarāṅgīkāraprasaṅgādityataḥ sapramāṇakamuktaṃ vivṛṇoti īśa iti //
analyzed: tasya api utpattau kāla antara aṅgīkāra prasaṅgāt iti atas sa pramāṇakam uktam vivṛṇoti īśaḥ iti
translated: Because if that also arises, it would lead to the acceptance of another time. Therefore, what has been said along with its proof is explained by the word Lord.

original: īśo deśaś ca kālaś ca svagatā eva sarvadā // / / //
analyzed: īśaḥ deśaḥ ca kālaḥ ca svagatāḥ eva sarvadā
translated: The Lord, the place, and the time are always related to themselves.

analyzed: deśaḥ iti avyākṛta ākāśa abhidhānam
translated: Here, place is the designation for the unmanifested space.

original: svagatā ityuktyā prāptāṃ deśakālayoḥ svātantryaśaṅkāṃ vārayati īśādhīnāviti // /
analyzed: svagatāḥ iti uktyā prāptām deśa kālayoḥ svātantrya śaṅkām vārayati īśa adhīnau iti
translated: By saying related to themselves, the doubt of the independence of place and time that has arisen is refuted by dependent on the Lord.

original: īśādhīnau ca tau nityaṃ tadādhārau ca tadgatau /
analyzed: īśa adhīnau ca tau nityam tad ādhārau ca tad gatau
translated: And those two are always dependent on the Lord, they are the basis of that, and they are related to that.

original: iti śrutirapi prāha kāle svoddiṣṭa eva tu // / / //🔽tatkālasṛṣṭimevāto vāñchatīśaḥ sadaiva hi /
analyzed: iti śrutiḥ api prāha kāle sva uddiṣṭe eva tu  tad kāla sṛṣṭim eva atas vāñchati īśaḥ sadā eva hi
translated: Thus, the Veda also says, but only at the time indicated by itself.🔽Therefore, the Lord always desires only the creation of that time.

original: syāt kālaḥ sa tadaiveti kālasya svagatatvataḥ // / / //
analyzed: syāt kālaḥ sa tadā evā iti kālasya svagata tvataḥ
translated: That time would be only then, because of the time being related to itself.🔽Here is the corrected and aligned text:

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa mātreṇa sattā pratīti pravṛttīnām parameśvara āyatta tvam ucyate
translated: It is said that existence, cognition and activity are dependent on the Supreme Lord by mere specification.

analyzed: śrutiḥ api iti sākṣiṇam samuccinoti
translated: The Śruti also - this includes the witness.

original: yataḥ kālasya svagatatvaṃ śrutiḥ prāha sākṣiṇā ca siddham /
analyzed: yatas kālasya svagata tvam śrutiḥ prāha sākṣiṇā ca siddham
translated: Because the Śruti declares the self-relatedness of time, and it is established by the witness.

original: ataḥ kālasya svagatatvataḥ /🔽sa kālastadaiva syāditīśaḥ sadaiva svoddiṣya eva kāle /
analyzed: atas kālasya svagata tvataḥ  sa kālaḥ tadā eva syāt iti īśaḥ sadā eva svoddiṣye eva kāle
translated: Therefore, from the self-relatedness of time.🔽That time is only at that time, the Lord always desires only the creation at the time indicated by Himself.

analyzed: tad tad kāla sṛṣṭim eva vāñchati iti anvayaḥ
translated: The construction is: He always desires the creation of that and that time.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: kāla atirikta kāryāṇām eva kālaḥ adhikaraṇa tayā kāraṇam na kālasya
translated: Time is the substratum and cause only of effects other than time, not of time itself.

original: kevalaṃ śvo ghaṭaṃ sraṣṭāsmītivatkālasṛṣṭiṃ vāñchataḥ parameśvarasyādhikaraṇatayoddeśyaḥ kālaḥ ka iti praśno 'vaśiṣyate /
analyzed: kevalam śvas ghaṭam sraṣṭāsmi iti vat kāla sṛṣṭim vāñchataḥ parameśvarasya adhikaraṇa tayā uddeśyaḥ kālaḥ kaḥ iti praśnaḥ
