translated: Only the question remains: What is the time that is the substratum and object of the Supreme Lord who desires the creation of time, as if thinking Tomorrow I will create a pot?

analyzed: tatra yaḥ sṛjyaḥ saḥ eva iti uttaram
translated: The answer to that is: It is that which is to be created.

analyzed: nahi sṛjyasya prāk sattvam asti
translated: For the thing to be created does not exist prior to creation,

analyzed: yena uddeśya tvam sattvam apekṣeta
translated: by which its being the object would require its existence.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa adhikartavya tā ca ekasya eva śruti ādi siddhā viśeṣa balāt ca upapadyate
translated: And the relation of substratum and object of action of the same [time] is established by Śruti etc., and is also logically possible by the force of the particular [statement].

analyzed: atas na kālasya utpattau kācid anupapattiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no inconsistency in the origination of time.

original: yaduktaṃ yadeśvarecchā sisṛkṣākārā vyajyate tadā mahadādisṛṣṭibharvati /
analyzed: yat uktam yadā īśvara icchā sisṛkṣā ākārā vyajyate tadā mahat ādi sṛṣṭi bharvati
translated: It has been said that when the Lord's will manifests in the form of creation, then the creation of Mahat and others takes place.

original: yadā tu sañjihīrṣārūpā sampadyate tadā saṃhāro bhavatīti /
analyzed: yadā tu sañjihīrṣā rūpā sampadyate tadā saṃhāraḥ bhavati iti
translated: But when it becomes in the form of destruction, then dissolution occurs.

analyzed: tatra idam vaicitryam kinnimittam iti vācyam
translated: In that case, it should be stated what is the cause of this diversity.

analyzed: na ca kāla viśeṣaḥ nimittam iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to say that the cause is a particular time.

analyzed: tasya īśvara icchā āyatta tvāt
translated: Because that is dependent on the Lord's will.

analyzed: na api puruṣa artha āyattam  pāratantrya āpatteḥ iti atas āha svabhāvāt eva iti
translated: Nor is it dependent on the purpose of the individual soul.🔽Because that would lead to dependence on another. Therefore, he says: by nature alone.

analyzed: svabhāvāt eva hi icchā eṣā
translated: For this desire is of the nature of the Lord himself.

analyzed: eṣā vicitrā
translated: This is diverse.

analyzed: tasmāt kāla viśeṣāṇām īśvara adhīna tve na itaretarāśraya doṣa āpattiḥ iti hi śabda arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the word hi is that when the particular times are dependent on the Lord, there is no fault of mutual dependence.

analyzed: kutas etat iti atas āha devasya iti
translated: From where does this follow? Therefore, he says: of the Lord.

analyzed: devasya eva iti śruteḥ
translated: Because it is heard that it is of the Lord alone.

analyzed: etat avagamyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is understood.

analyzed: aparaḥ āha
translated: Another says:

analyzed: kim anayā kāla ādi vaicitrya kalpanayā
translated: What is the use of imagining this diversity of time, etc.?

original: yāvatā kāraṇānāṃ kāryāṇāṃ ca svabhāvādeva samayaniyamopapatteḥ /
analyzed: yāvatā kāraṇānām kāryāṇām ca svabhāvāt eva samaya niyama upapatteḥ
translated: For the restriction of time is possible by the nature of the causes and effects themselves.

analyzed: antatas pi hi svabhāva vādaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: For in the end, the doctrine of intrinsic nature must be accepted.

original: tato varamādāveva svabhāvavādābhyupagama iti /🔽ata āha svabhāvo 'pīti //
analyzed: tatas varam ādau eva svabhāva vāda abhyupagamaḥ iti  atas āha svabhāvaḥ pi iti
translated: Therefore, it is better to accept the doctrine of intrinsic nature from the beginning.🔽Therefore, he says: Intrinsic nature is also said to be dependent on the will of the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ pi pareśa icchā vaśaḥ iti uditaḥ purā
translated: Intrinsic nature is also said to be dependent on the will of the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: purā acetanānām viśeṣaḥ yaḥ ityādau
translated: In the beginning, the difference of insentient things is stated.

analyzed: svabhāva vādam abhyupagacchatā api tad niyāmaka tayā īśvaraḥ aṅgīkāryaḥ
translated: Even one who accepts the doctrine of intrinsic nature must accept God as the regulator.

original: tatastatraikatraiva svabhāvānusaraṇe pramāṇāyatte 'ṅgīkārye kimanekatra tadabhyupagameneti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tatas tatra ekatra eva svabhāva anusaraṇe pramāṇa āyatte ṅgīkārye kim anekatra tad abhyupagamena iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, when one must accept the dependence on intrinsic nature in one place alone, which is dependent on evidence, what is the use of accepting it in many places? This is the idea.

original: na kevalaṃ pūrvoktameva pramāṇaṃ smartavyam /🔽kintu pramāṇāntaramapyastītyāha nityā iti //
analyzed: na kevalam pūrvoktam eva pramāṇam smartavyam  kintu pramāṇa antaram api asti iti āha nityāḥ iti
translated: Not only the previously stated evidence should be remembered,🔽but there is also another evidence. He says: The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.

original: nityā anityāśca tatastadadhīnā iti śrutiḥ // / / //🔽tata ityasya śrutāveva parāmarśaviṣayo draṣṭavyaḥ /🔽śrutiḥ sarvasyeśvarādhīnatāmāheti śeṣaḥ / /
analyzed: nityāḥ anityāḥ ca tatas tad adhīnāḥ iti śrutiḥ  tatas iti asya śrutau eva parāmarśa viṣayaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ  śrutiḥ sarvasya īśvara adhīna tām āha iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.🔽The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.

analyzed: anupapatti antaram vaiśeṣika ādi mate darśayan
translated: The eternal and non-eternal are dependent on that, as stated in the scriptures.

analyzed: om rūpa ādimat tvāt ca viparyayaḥ darśanāt om
translated: The eternal and

analyzed: om ubhayathā ca doṣāt om
translated: Om. And because of the fault in both ways. Om.

analyzed: iti sūtra dvayam vyācaṣṭe rūpa iti
translated: He explains the two aphorisms thus: Form, etc.

analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvāt ca viparyayaḥ darśanāt
translated: And because of the contradiction shown by having form, etc.

analyzed: ubhayathā ca doṣāt
translated: And because of the fault in both ways.

analyzed: rūpa sparśa ādi hetubhyaḥ paramāṇoḥ anitya tā
translated: The impermanence of the atom is inferred from the causes of form, touch, etc.

analyzed: anumeyā
translated: It is to be inferred.

analyzed: paramāṇoḥ iti jāti apekṣam ekavacanam
translated: The singular number in atom is in relation to the class.

analyzed: pārthiva ādīnām caturvidhānām paramāṇūnām nitya tām upayānti vaiśeṣika ādayaḥ
translated: The Vaiśeṣikas and others maintain the permanence of the four kinds of atoms, earth and so on.

analyzed: tat anupapannam
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: pāthirvāḥ pāthasīyāḥ taijasāḥ ca paramāṇavaḥ nityāḥ rūpavat tvāt paṭa vat
translated: Earthly, watery, and fiery atoms are impermanent because they have form, like a cloth.

original: yadvā caturvidhā apyanityāḥ sparśavattvātpaṭavat /🔽evaṃ pārthitavā āpyāścānityā rasavattvātpaṭavat /
analyzed: yat vā caturvidhāḥ api anityāḥ sparśavat tvāt paṭa vat  evam āpyāḥ ca anityāḥ rasavat tvāt paṭa vat
translated: Or, all four are impermanent because they have touch, like a cloth.🔽Similarly, earthly and watery atoms are impermanent because they have taste, like a cloth.

analyzed: pārthivāḥ anityāḥ gandhavat tvāt tadvat eva ityādi anumāna viruddha tvāt
translated: Earthly atoms are impermanent because they have smell, like a cloth. Thus, because it contradicts inference,

analyzed: na ca sāvayavatvam upādhiḥ
translated: having parts is not a counter-example.

analyzed: guṇa ādau sādhya avyāpteḥ
translated: Because the probandum is not pervaded in qualities and so on.

analyzed: naca dravya tva avacchinne sādhye sya upādhi tvam
translated: And when substantiality is the probandum, it is not a counter-example.

analyzed: yat rūpa ādimat tat sa avayavam iti sādhana vyāpaka tvāt
translated: Because the reason pervades whatever has form, etc., it has parts.

analyzed: na ca dharmi grāhaka virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with the cognition of the substratum.

analyzed: sākṣiṇā eva paramāṇu siddheḥ ukta tvāt
translated: Because it has been said that the atom is established by the witness itself.

analyzed: anitya tve ca paramāṇūnām na mūla kāraṇa tva siddhiḥ
translated: And if the atoms are non-eternal, they cannot be established as the primary cause.

original: yadi ca rūpādimanto 'pi paramāṇavo nānityāstadā ghaṭādayo 'pyanityā na syuraviśeṣāt /
analyzed: yadi ca rūpa ādimantaḥ pi paramāṇavaḥ na anityāḥ tadā ghaṭa ādayaḥ pi anityāḥ na syuḥ aviśeṣāt
translated: And if the atoms, though possessing color etc., are not non-eternal, then even pots etc. would not be non-eternal, due to the absence of distinction.

original: tathācapi na paramāṇūnāṃ mūlakāraṇatvam /🔽naceśvare hetūnāṃ vyabhicāraḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca api na paramāṇūnām mūla kāraṇa tvam  na ca īśvare hetūnām vyabhicāraḥ
translated: And even so, the atoms cannot be the primary cause.🔽And the reason is not fallacious in the case of God.

analyzed: bhautika tvena viśeṣaṇāt
translated: Because it is qualified by being produced from material causes.

analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyati
translated: And thus he will say:

original: bhautikaṃ tveva rūpādi vyāptaṃ nāśena no mate' / /
analyzed: bhautikam tu eva rūpa ādi vyāptam nāśena naḥ mate
translated: But we do not accept that color etc. which are produced from material causes are pervaded by destruction.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: nanu asmābhiḥ bhūta sūkṣmāṇām nitya tā aṅgīkriyate
translated: But we accept the eternality of the subtle elements.

analyzed: tat katham evam anumīyate  mā evam
translated: How then is it inferred thus?🔽Not so.

analyzed: nahi paramāṇavaḥ bhūta sūkṣmāṇi  kinnāma ahaṃkāraḥ
translated: For the atoms are not the subtle elements.

analyzed: mātrā upacitāni
translated: What then? They are accumulated by mere egoism.

analyzed: vikṛta ākārāḥ ca anityāḥ eva iti  aparigrahāt ca atyantam anapekṣā
translated: And they are of modified form and are indeed non-eternal.🔽And because they are not accepted, they are absolutely not depended upon.

analyzed: om aparigrahāt ca atyantam anapekṣā om
translated: And because they are not accepted, they are absolutely not depended upon.

analyzed: iti sūtram vyācaṣṭe śrītīnām ca iti
translated: He explains the aphorism thus: And because of the contradiction of the scriptures, that view is not accepted.

analyzed: śrutīnām ca viruddha tvāt na tat matam
translated: And because of the contradiction of the scriptures, that view is not accepted.

analyzed: upādeyam atas ca ayam aviruddhaḥ samanvayaḥ
translated: Therefore, this non-contradictory harmony is to be accepted.

analyzed: sambandha mātre ṣaṣṭhī
translated: The genitive case is used to denote mere relation.

analyzed: anyathā tṛtīyā syāt
translated: Otherwise, the instrumental case would be used.

analyzed: śrutayaḥ ca ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ
translated: And the Vedic texts such as Space is born from the Self

analyzed: ityādyāḥ tatra tatra udāhṛtāḥ jñātavyāḥ
translated: should be understood as quoted there and there.

original: vaiśeṣikādimatasyānupādeyatve siddhe kiṃ labdhamityata āha ataśceti //
analyzed: vaiśeṣika ādi matasya anupādeya tve siddhe kim labdham iti atas āha atas ca iti
translated: When it is established that the Vaiśeṣika and other doctrines are not to be accepted, what is gained by it? Therefore, it is said from this.
This refers to the Supreme Brahman, which is full of all qualities.

original: aviruddha iti na vaiśeṣikāsidamatavirodenāsamañjaso mantavya iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: aviruddhaḥ iti na vaiśeṣika asida mata virodena asamañjasaḥ mantavyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it should not be considered incoherent due to contradiction with the doctrines of the Vaiśeṣikas and others.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām vaiśeṣika adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Vaiśeṣika in the commentary Nāya-Su-dhā.
VII. The chapter on the whole

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām samudāya adhikaraṇam
translated: Now begins the chapter on the whole in the commentary Nāya-Su-dhā.

analyzed: samudāyaḥ ubhaya hetuke tad aprāptiḥ
translated: The whole is produced by both, but its non-attainment is not.

analyzed: om samudāyaḥ ubhaya hetuke tad aprāptiḥ om
translated: Om. The whole is produced by both, but its non-attainment is not.

analyzed: atha idānīm saugata matam apākriyate
translated: Now, the doctrine of the Buddhists is being refuted.

analyzed: te ca caturvidhāḥ
translated: And they are of four kinds.

analyzed: vaibhāṣikāḥ sautrāntikāḥ mādhyamikāḥ yoga ācārāḥ ca iti
translated: Vaibhāṣikas, Sautrāntikas, Mādhyamikas, and Yogācāras.

original: tatra jagatsatyameva paramāṇumayamācakṣāṇānāṃ vaiśeṣikādīnāṃ nirasanaprasaṅgādanatibhedaṃ vaibhāṣikasautrāntikamatamādau tāvannirākriyate /
analyzed: tatra jagat satyam eva paramāṇu mayam ācakṣāṇānām vaiśeṣika ādīnām nirasana prasaṅgāt anatibhedam vaibhāṣika sautrāntika matam ādau tāvat nirākriyate
translated: There, the Vaibhāṣika and Sautrāntika views, which are not very different, are first refuted, because they are to be refuted in connection with the Vaiśeṣika and others who maintain that the real world consists of atoms.

analyzed: vipratipattim darśayan tad matam upanyasyati vaibhāṣikāḥ ca iti
translated: Showing the disagreement, he presents their view with The Vaibhāṣikas and Sautrāntikas.

analyzed: vaibhāṣikāḥ ca sautrāntāḥ svarasa kṣaṇikam jagat
translated: The Vaibhāṣikas and Sautrāntikas say that the world is momentary and self-destructible.

analyzed: āhuḥ iti vakṣyamāṇena sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is with what is to be said.

analyzed: kṣaṇikam kṣaṇa mātra avasthāyi
translated: Momentary means lasting only a moment.

original: mudgarābhighātādīnāṃ vināśahetūnāṃ pratikṣaṇamanupalambhātkathaṃ kṣaṇabhaṅgitvamityata uktam svaraseti //
analyzed: mudgara abhighāta ādīnām vināśa hetūnām pratikṣaṇam anupalambhāt katham kṣaṇabhaṅgi tvam iti atas uktam svarasa iti
translated: How is it momentary destruction, since causes of destruction such as the blow of a hammer are not perceived every moment? To this it is said by its own nature.

original: svabhāvenaiva kṣaṇikaṃ svabhāva evāyaṃ vastuno yadvināśitvam /
analyzed: svabhāvena eva kṣaṇikam svabhāvaḥ eva ayam vastunaḥ yat vināśi tvam
translated: It is momentary by its own nature. This is the very nature of a thing that it is destructible.

analyzed: tatra kā kāraṇa apekṣā
translated: What need is there for a cause in that?

analyzed: mudgara ādayaḥ pi na vastu vināśa hetavaḥ
translated: The hammer and so on are not the causes of the destruction of a thing.

analyzed: kinnāma ghaṭa āditaḥ kapāla ādeḥ visadṛśa kāryasya utpattau nimitta bhūtāḥ eva iti
translated: Rather, they are merely the instrumental causes in the production of an effect that is different from the pot, such as potsherds, and so on.

original: nanu ca kāraṇānāṃ kriyayā saṃyoge sati tatsamavetatayā tatpariṇāmatayā vā kāryeṇotpattavyam /
analyzed: nanu ca kāraṇānām kriyayā saṃyoge sati tad samaveta tayā tad pariṇāma tayā vā kāryeṇa utpattavyam
translated: But when there is conjunction of causes with action, the effect should arise either as inhering in them or as their modification.

original: tatkāryeṇāpyevamiti kathaṃ kṣaṇikatvaṃ jagata ityata āha aṇūnāmiti //
analyzed: tad kāryeṇa api evam iti katham kṣaṇika tvam jagataḥ iti atas āha aṇūnām iti
translated: And in the same way, even with that effect. How then is the momentariness of the world? To this he says 'of atoms' etc.

analyzed: aṇūnām samudāyam ca
translated: And the collection of atoms

analyzed: jagat āhuḥ
translated: they call the world.

analyzed: aṇu samudāyāḥ eva go ghaṭa ādi bodha bodhyāḥ
translated: The collections of atoms alone are to be understood by the cognitions of cow, pot etc.

analyzed: na tu tad atiriktaḥ vayavī nāma asti
translated: There is no such thing as a whole apart from that.

analyzed: yena kṣaṇika tā virudhyeta
translated: By which momentariness would be contradicted.

analyzed: aṇu mātram iti vaktavye samudāya grahaṇam ekaḥ mahān iti pratyakṣa pratyaya virodha parihāra artham
translated: When it should be said 'just an atom', the mention of 'collection' is for the sake of avoiding contradiction with the cognition 'one, great', which is perception.

original: pratyekamaṇūnāmapratyakṣatve 'nekatve 'mahattve 'pi tatsamudāyasya pratyakṣatvādi yujyata iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: pratyekam aṇūnām apratyakṣa tve nekatve mahattve pi tad samudāyasya pratyakṣa tva ādi yujyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that even though the individual atoms are not perceptible, are many, and are not great, it is proper for their collection to be perceptible etc.

original: samudāyo hi melakena kenacit🔽puṃsā bhavati /🔽nacāsmadādistathetīśvaro 'bhyupagantavyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: samudāyaḥ hi melakena kenacid  puṃsā bhavati  na ca asmad ādiḥ tathā iti īśvaraḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ syāt
translated: For a collection is made by some combination.🔽And one like us is not so. Therefore God should be accepted.

original: tathāvayavyanabhyupagame goghaṭādivilakṣaṇākāratā na syādityata āha kāleti //
analyzed: tathā avayavi anabhyupagame go ghaṭa ādi vilakṣaṇa ākāra tā na syāt iti atas āha kāla iti
translated: Similarly, if a whole is not accepted, there would not be a form different from cow, pot etc. To this he says 'in time' etc.🔽And in time, action, and cause,

analyzed: ca kāla karma nimittataḥ
translated: from that.

analyzed: utpatti kāle yuktānām
translated: Of those that are connected at the time of origination.

original: kālakarmaṇī ca te nimitte ca tataḥ /
analyzed: kālakarmaṇī ca te nimitte ca tatas
translated: And time and action are the causes of those.

analyzed: utpatti kāle ādi sṛṣṭau
translated: At the time of origination, at the beginning of creation.

analyzed: anyadā tu nimitta antaram asti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But it is the intention that there is another cause at other times.

analyzed: yuktānām sannikṛṣṭa tayā utpannānām aṇūnām samudāyam iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The compound with of the collection of atoms is connected.

original: karmādivaśādeva tathā tathā sannikṛṣṭāḥ paramāṇavo jāyante /
analyzed: karma ādi vaśāt eva tathā tathā sannikṛṣṭāḥ paramāṇavaḥ jāyante
translated: The atoms are born in such and such a way, due to the power of karma and so on, as being in close proximity.

analyzed: yatā yathā go ghaṭa ādi vicitra ākāra avabhāsaḥ syāt
translated: So that there may be the appearance of various forms such as cows, pots, and so on.

analyzed: tatra kim īśvareṇa
translated: What is the use of God in that?

analyzed: kim vā avayavinā
translated: Or of a whole?

analyzed: siddhāntinā api hi karma ādikam nimittam aṅgīkartavyam
translated: Even the proponent of the established doctrine must accept karma and so on as the cause.

analyzed: saṃyogaḥ ca avayavi utpāda anuguṇaḥ
translated: And conjunction is favorable to the production of the whole.

analyzed: tāvatā eva sarvam upapadyate
translated: With just that, everything is possible, it is said.

analyzed: kim anātma prapañcaḥ eva kṣaṇikaḥ na iti āha ātmānam iti
translated: Is only the non-self-world momentary? No, he says the self and so on.

original: ātmānaṃ ca kṣaṇasthitim // / / //🔽kṣaṇikatvahetoḥ sattvasya sarvatra sāmyāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: ātmānam ca kṣaṇa sthitim  kṣaṇika tva hetoḥ sattvasya sarvatra sāmyāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And the self is momentary.🔽The idea is that the reason of momentariness is equally applicable everywhere.

analyzed: kṣaṇika tve pratyabhijñā virodhaḥ iti atas āha nityam iti
translated: If it is momentary, there is a contradiction with recognition. Therefore he says eternal and so on.

analyzed: nityam santānam eteṣām
translated: Eternal is the continuum of those.

analyzed: eteṣām aṇūnām
translated: Of those atoms.

analyzed: pratyabhijñā iti bhāvaḥ  na ca evam sattvasya anaikāntyāt
translated: The idea is that recognition has a continuum as its object.🔽And it is not so, because existence is not one-sided.

analyzed: santānasya sattva abhāvāt
translated: Because a continuum does not exist.

analyzed: evam sāmānyatas nirūpya vibhāgam āha pañca iti
translated: Having thus described in general, he states the division with five etc.

analyzed: pañca skandha ātmanā sthitam
translated: It exists in the form of the five aggregates.

analyzed: jagat vṛkṣam pañca skandha ātmanā sthitam āhuḥ
translated: They say that the world-tree exists in the form of the five aggregates.

analyzed: pañca skandhān āha saṃskāra iti
translated: He says that the five aggregates are formations etc.

analyzed: saṃskāra rūpa vijñāna sañjñā duḥkha ātmanā sthitiḥ
translated: The existence of formations, form, consciousness, perception, and suffering is...

analyzed: sthitiḥ skandhānām iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is the existence of the aggregates.

analyzed: samanantara pratyayaḥ saṃskāra skandhaḥ
translated: The immediately preceding condition is the aggregate of formations.

analyzed: rūpa rasa gandha sparśa śabda ātmakāḥ paramāṇavaḥ rūpa skandhaḥ
translated: The atoms consisting of form, taste, smell, touch, and sound are the aggregate of form.
Non-conceptual cognition is the aggregate of consciousness.

analyzed: sa vikalpakam jñānam saṃjñā skandhaḥ
translated: Conceptual cognition is the aggregate of perception.

analyzed: vedanā apara paryāyam duḥkham ca eka skandhaḥ
translated: Suffering, which is synonymous with feeling, is one aggregate.

analyzed: atra rūpa skandhaḥ bāhyaḥ
translated: Here, the aggregate of form is external.

analyzed: anye catvāraḥ ābhyantarāḥ iti āhuḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The other four are internal, he says. This is the connection.

original: sukhādīnāṃ padārthāntareṇa vidyamānatvātkathaṃ pañcaiva skandhā ityata āha duḥkhābhāvāditi //
analyzed: sukha ādīnām padārtha antareṇa vidyamāna tvāt katham pañca eva skandhāḥ iti atas āha duḥkha abhāvāt iti
translated: Since pleasure, etc. exist as separate things, how are there only five aggregates? Therefore it is said: because of the absence of suffering.

analyzed: duḥkha abhāvam sukham ca āhuḥ
translated: They call the absence of suffering pleasure.

analyzed: caśabdena kecid sukham vedanā skandhe ntar bhāvayanti iti sūcitam bhavati
translated: The word ca (and) indicates that some include pleasure in the aggregate of feeling.

analyzed: yadvā anukta samuccaya arthaḥ caśabdaḥ
translated: Or the word ca (and) has the meaning of including what is not mentioned.

analyzed: yathā mūrta abhāve eva ākāśam
translated: For example, space is merely the absence of form.

analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ eva pṛthivī ādyāḥ
translated: Earth, etc. are merely form, etc.

analyzed: saṅkhaya ādayaḥ tu guṇāḥ pṛthak anupalambhāt na santi eva
translated: But number, etc. are not real qualities because they are not perceived separately.

analyzed: deśa antara utpādaḥ eva karma pratyaya ālambanam
translated: The production in a different place is merely the basis for the effect of action.

analyzed: kṣaṇikasya vāstava karma ayogāt  sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭa tayā utpādaḥ eva saṃyoga ādi vyavahāra gocaraḥ
translated: Because an instantaneous [entity] cannot really perform an action.🔽The production as near or far is merely the sphere of the conventions of conjunction, etc.

analyzed: a tad vaya āvṛttiḥ eva go tva ādi sāmānya buddhi bodhyā ityādi
translated: The exclusion of that is merely what is to be understood by the cognition of the universal such as cowness, etc.

analyzed: a rūpa jñāna santatim
translated: The continuum of non-form cognition is...

analyzed: mokṣam
translated: Liberation is...

analyzed: arūpā iti
translated: Non-form means:

analyzed: santanyamānam jñānam eva ātmā tasya viṣaya upaplavaḥ saṃsāraḥ
translated: The self is merely the continuum of cognition. The wandering in saṃsāra is the disturbance of its objects.

original: arūpā nirviṣayā yā jñānasantatistāmeve mokṣamāhurnānyamityato na pañcaskandhaprakriyābhaṅga iti / /
analyzed: arūpā nirviṣayā yā jñāna santatiḥ tām eve mokṣam āhuḥ na anyam iti atas na pañca skandha prakriyā bhaṅgaḥ iti
translated: That uninterrupted series of cognitions which is formless and objectless, that alone they declare to be liberation, not anything else. Therefore there is no contradiction with the doctrine of the five aggregates.

original: evaṃ vaibhāṣikasautrāntikayoḥ sādhāraṇaṃ matamupanyasyāvāntarabhedaṃ tu nirākaraṇaprastāva
analyzed: evam vaibhāṣika sautrāntikayoḥ sādhāraṇam matam upanyasya avāntarabhedam tu nirākaraṇa prastāva
translated: Having thus presented the common doctrine of the Vaibhāṣikas and Sautrāntikas, the author, wishing to state the minor differences,

original: eva vivakṣuryattāvaduktaṃ paramāṇusamudāya eva goghaṭādiprapañco na tvavayavī kaścidastīti
analyzed: eva vivakṣuḥ yat tāvat uktam paramāṇu samudāyaḥ eva go ghaṭa ādi prapañcaḥ na tu avayavī kaścid asti iti
translated: refutes them in the course of the discussion itself. As for what was said that the world of cows, pots, etc. is just a collection of atoms, and that there is no such thing as a whole,

original: tannirākartuṃ samudāya ubhayahetuke 'pi tadaprāptiriti sūtraṃ vyācaṣṭe sa iti //
analyzed: tat nirākartum samudāye ubhaya hetuke tad aprāptiḥ iti sūtram vyācaṣṭe saḥ iti
translated: in order to refute that, he explains the sūtra The collection is not attained even though both are causes with the verse That.

analyzed: sa samudāyaḥ hi na ekasmāt eva yujyate
translated: That collection is not tenable as arising from a single [atom].

analyzed: yaḥ yam go ghaṭa ādi buddhi viṣaya tvena abhyupagataḥ samudāyaḥ sa kim eka paramāṇu hetukaḥ
translated: Is this collection, which is accepted as the object of the cognition of cows, pots, etc., caused by a single atom?

analyzed: kiṃvā aneka paramāṇu hetukaḥ
translated: Or is it caused by many atoms?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: ekasmāt paramāṇoḥ samudāya utpāda anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for a collection to arise from a single atom.

analyzed: na hi ekaikasmin tarau taru samudāya buddhiḥ kasya api vidyate
translated: For no one has the cognition of a collection of trees with respect to each individual tree.

analyzed: samudāya kalpanam vā anarthakam āpadyeta
translated: Or the postulation of a collection would be pointless.

analyzed: mahat tva aindriyaka tvayoḥ a samarthita tvāt
translated: Because greatness and being a sense object are not established.

analyzed: anena api śabda labdhaḥ rthaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: By this, the meaning obtained from the word api is shown.

analyzed: dvitīyam nirākaroti na iti
translated: He refutes the second by saying no.

analyzed: na ubhayoḥ caḥ
translated: Neither of both is to be supplied.

analyzed: ubhaya grahaṇam aneka mātra upalakṣaṇam  sakāśāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The word both is a mere indication of plurality.🔽From is to be supplied.

analyzed: caśabdena samudāyaḥ yujyate iti anukṛṣṭate
translated: By the word ca, the whole is connected is supplied.

analyzed: kutas na yujyate iti ced
translated: If it is asked why it is not connected,

original: anekahetukatve 'pi kimasamuditānekahetuko 'tha samuditānekahetuka iti vaktavyam /🔽ādye sarvatratrāpi
analyzed: aneka hetuka tve pi kim asamudita aneka hetukaḥ samudita aneka hetukaḥ iti vaktavyam  ādye sarvatra tra api
translated: it should be said whether it is caused by many uncombined causes or by many combined causes.

analyzed: go ghaṭa ādi buddhi prasaktiḥ
translated: In the first case, the cognition of cow, pot, etc. would arise everywhere.

analyzed: asamudita paramāṇūnām sarvatra bhāvāt
translated: Because uncombined atoms exist everywhere,

analyzed: samudāyasya ca tanmātra hetuka tvāt  samudāya aṅgīkāra vaiyathya ṛ prasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: and because the whole has only that as its cause.🔽And there would be the undesirable consequence of accepting the whole.

analyzed: dvitīya anupapattau hetum āha ubhaya tvam iti
translated: He gives the reason for the impossibility of the second by saying the state of being both etc.
The state of being both, which depends on the whole is to be supplied.

analyzed: yat yasmāt ubhaya tvam samudita aneka tvam samudāya sāpekṣam
translated: Because the state of being both, which is the state of being many combined, depends on the whole.

analyzed: jāte hi samudāye na ekeṣām samudita tvam saṃbhavati
translated: For when the whole is produced, the state of being combined of many is possible.

analyzed: tasmāt na iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the connection is therefore not.

original: samuditānekatvasya samudāyasāpekṣatve 'pi kutastataḥ samudāyotpādo na yujyata ityāśaṅkāṃ pariharatsūtrārthamupasaṃharati ata iti //
analyzed: samudita anekatvasya samudāya sāpekṣa tve pi kutas tatas samudāya utpādaḥ na yujyate iti āśaṅkām pariharat sūtra artham upasaṃharati atas iti
translated: In order to remove the doubt as to why the production of the aggregate is not possible from that [i.e., the atoms], although the state of being many united depends on the aggregate, he concludes the meaning of the aphorism with the word therefore.

analyzed: atas nyonya āśraya tvena samudāyaḥ na yujyate
translated: Therefore, the aggregate is not possible due to mutual dependence.

analyzed: samudāyasya samudita anekeṣām ca itaretara apekṣa utpattika tvena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: due to the production of the aggregate and the many united depending on each other.

analyzed: samudāya anutpattau
translated: And in the non-production of the aggregate,

original: cāṇūnāṃ mahāneka iti pratyakṣabuddhigocaratāyogādavaśyamaṅgīkaraṇīyo 'vayavīti /🔽kiñcāyaṃ samudāyaḥ kiṃ paramāṇūnāṃ saṃyogaḥ kiṃvānekatvasaṅkhayā /
analyzed: ca aṇūnām mahān ekaḥ iti pratyakṣa buddhi gocara tā yogāt avaśyam aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ vayavī iti  kiñca ayam samudāyaḥ kim paramāṇūnām saṃyogaḥ kiṃvā aneka tva saṅkhayā
translated: the cognition of the gross as many atoms is not possible, so the whole must necessarily be accepted.🔽Moreover, is this aggregate the conjunction of atoms, or the number of many,

analyzed: uta dravya antaram
translated: or a different substance?

analyzed: na ādya dvitīyau
translated: Not the first or second,

analyzed: anaṅgīkārāt  aṅgīkāre pi atīndriya āśritayoḥ tayoḥ aindriyaka tva anupapattiḥ
translated: because they are not accepted.🔽Even if accepted, those two, which are based on the imperceptible, cannot reasonably be perceptible.

analyzed: tṛtīye saḥ eva avayavī
translated: In the third [alternative], that [aggregate] is itself the whole.

analyzed: sāṃvṛtaḥ sau iti ced
translated: If it is said that it is conventional,

analyzed: tarhi punar mahān ityādi pramā anupapattiḥ tad avasthā eva
translated: then the non-apprehension of valid cognition such as gross and so on remains the same.

analyzed: bhrāntiḥ iyam iti ced na
translated: If it is said that this is an illusion, no.

analyzed: bhrānteḥ abhrānti pūrvaka tvena kvacid mahat tva ādeḥ vāstava tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because error must have non-error as its antecedent, it would follow that greatness, etc. are real in some cases.

analyzed: anādi vāsanā vaśāt anādiḥ evā iyam bhrāntiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that this error is beginningless due to beginningless latent impressions, that is not so.

analyzed: nīla ādi jñānasya api tathātva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the cognition of blue, etc. is also like that.

analyzed: nanu viṣamam idam ucyate
translated: But this is said to be inconsistent.

analyzed: avayavini bādhaka sadbhāvāt
translated: Because there is a refutation of the whole.

original: tathāhi /🔽avayavī kimavayaveṣu pratyekaṃ kārtsyena vartate /🔽kiṃ vaikadeśena /
analyzed: tathā hi  avayavī kim avayaveṣu pratyekam kārtsyena vartate  kim vā eka deśena
translated: Indeed, it is like this.🔽Does the whole exist in each part completely?🔽Or in part?

analyzed: ādye nekatva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the first case, there would be the consequence of multiplicity.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: tasya avayavān vihāya eka deśa abhāvāt
translated: Because, apart from the parts, there is no partial existence.

analyzed: bhāve atra api vṛtti vikalpa prasaṅgāt
translated: If it exists, then even here there would be the consequence of the option of inherence.

original: kiñca keṣucittantuṣu calatsu tadgato 'vayavī calati na vā /
analyzed: kiñca keṣucid tantuṣu calatsu tad gataḥ vayavī calati na vā
translated: Moreover, when some of the threads are moving, does the whole located in them move or not?

analyzed: na iti pakṣe yuta siddhi prasaṅgaḥ
translated: If not, there would be the consequence of co-inherence.

original: ādye tu niścalāvayavāśrito na calatīti calācalatvalakṣaṇo viruddhadharmādhyāsaḥ /
analyzed: ādye tu niścala avayava āśritaḥ na calati iti cala acala tva lakṣaṇaḥ viruddha dharma adhyāsaḥ
translated: But in the first case, it does not move supported by the unmoving parts, so there is the superimposition of contradictory properties characterized by moving and not moving.

analyzed: evam āvṛtta anāvṛta tva rakta arakta tva lakṣaṇau api viruddha dharma adhyāsau draṣṭavyau iti
translated: Similarly, the superimpositions of contradictory properties characterized by being covered and uncovered, and being red and not red, should be seen.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: na asmābhiḥ avayavebhyaḥ tyanta bhinnaḥ vayavī gṛhyate
translated: We do not apprehend the whole as absolutely different from the parts.

analyzed: kintu tad pariṇāma viśeṣaḥ eva
translated: But rather as a particular transformation of that [material cause].

analyzed: tatra kutas vṛtti vikalpa avakāśaḥ
translated: So how can there be room for the alternatives of inherence?🔽As for the contradiction of motion and rest, etc., it is removed

analyzed: virodha vat apākriyate iti na avayavini bādhaka sadbhāvaḥ
translated: like the contradiction of difference and non-difference, etc., so there is no evidence of contradiction in the whole.

analyzed: na ca vācyam samudāyaḥ bhavadbhiḥ aṅgīkriya
translated: And it should not be said that you accept the whole,

analyzed: kṛte eva tatas ca
translated: and then

analyzed: tra ākṣepa samādhāna sāmyam iti
translated: that the objection and solution are the same.

analyzed: yatas nekeṣām eka kāla deśa kārya ādi avacchedena melanam samudāyaḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: Because the whole is accepted as the combination of many things by the restriction of time, place, effect, etc.

original: sa cāmilitebhya eva bhavatīti /🔽sthāyitānāṃ ca tatsambhavo na kṣaṇabhaṅgavāda iti vakṣyati / /
analyzed: sa ca amilitebhyaḥ eva bhavati iti  sthāyi tānām ca tad sambhavaḥ na kṣaṇabhaṅga vādaḥ iti vakṣyati
translated: And that can only happen from things that are not already combined.🔽And that is possible for enduring things, not for the doctrine of momentariness, as will be stated.

original: uktamarthamākṣipya samādadhatsūtram oṃ itaretarapratyayatvāditi cennotpattimātranimittatvāt oṃ //
analyzed: uktam artham ākṣipya samādadhat sūtram om itaretara pratyaya tvāt iti ced na utpatti mātra nimitta tvāt om
translated: The aphorism, having raised the question about the matter stated, and settled it, is: If it be said that it is because they are reciprocal conditions, no; because of the mere fact of origination.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tatra ākṣepa aṃśam tāvat vayācaṣṭe anyonya iti
translated: There, he first explains the part of the objection: Other and so on.

analyzed: itaretara pratyaya tvāt iti ced na utpatti mātra nimitta tvāt
translated: If it be said that it is because they are reciprocal conditions, no; because of the mere fact of origination.
The cognition of the aggregate nature of the soul is due to the mutual dependence of the atoms.

analyzed: syāt tat sadātana tve tat ca sāmīpya hetukam
translated: Even if that [aggregate] were eternal, it would be caused by proximity.

analyzed: iti ced
translated: If it is said so...

analyzed: bhavet idam anyonya āśraya tvam yadi ayam samudāyaḥ kādācitkaḥ syāt
translated: This mutual dependence would be true if this aggregate were occasional.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: sadātanam tu imam abhyupagacchāmaḥ
translated: We accept it to be eternal.

original: evaṃ tarhi sṛṣṭipralayavyavasthā na syāditi cenna /
analyzed: evam tarhi sṛṣṭi pralaya vyavasthā na syāt iti ced na
translated: If so, then there would be no establishment of creation and dissolution. If it is said so, it is not so.

original: yatastasya samudāyasya sadātanatve 'pi puṃsaḥ samudāyatvavedanaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yatas tasya samudāyasya sadātana tve pi puṃsaḥ samudāya tva vedanam syāt
translated: Because, even if that aggregate is eternal, the cognition of the aggregate nature of the soul would be occasional.

analyzed: kadācid iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is understood.

analyzed: tatas tad apekṣayā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the establishment of creation etc. is logically possible in relation to that. This is the idea.

original: samudāyasya sadātanatve tadvedanamapi kutaḥ kādācitkamityata uktam tacceti //
analyzed: samudāyasya sadātana tve tad vedanam api kutas kādācitkam iti atas uktam tat ca iti
translated: If the aggregate is eternal, how can its cognition also be occasional? To this it is said: That...

analyzed: tad samudāya tva vedanam paramāṇu sāmīpya hetukam
translated: That cognition of the aggregate nature is caused by the proximity of the atoms.

analyzed: na ca sāmīpyam sadā asti iti vedanasya kādācitkatvam iti
translated: And proximity does not exist eternally. Therefore, the cognition is occasional.

analyzed: samudāya tva vedanasya sāmīpya hetuka tā kutas iti atas uktam
translated: How is the cognition of the aggregate nature caused by proximity? To this it is said:

analyzed: āha anyonya iti
translated: It is said: Mutual...

analyzed: anyonya paramāṇu jñāna apekṣayā hi tat bhavati
translated: For that [cognition of a composite] arises in dependence on the cognition of other atoms.

analyzed: na ca anyonya jñānam sāmīpyena vinā bhavati iti
translated: And cognition of other [atoms] does not occur without proximity.

analyzed: nanu vedanam eva pumān iti saugatāḥ manyante
translated: But the Buddhists think that the person is just feeling.

analyzed: tat katham puṃsaḥ vedanam iti
translated: So how can it be said that the person is the feeling?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: jñānam hi dvividham bhavati
translated: For knowledge is of two kinds:

analyzed: pravṛtti jñānam ālaya jñānam ca iti
translated: knowledge of engagement and knowledge of the storehouse.

analyzed: tatra ālaya jñānam pravṛtti jñāna duḥkha saṃskāra āspadam pumān iti ucyate
translated: Among them, the knowledge of the storehouse, which is the basis of the suffering and formations of the knowledge of engagement, is called the person.

analyzed: pravṛtti jñānam tu samudāya tva vedanam iti na virodhaḥ
translated: But the knowledge of engagement is the awareness of the state of being a composite. There is no contradiction.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  aneke paramāṇavaḥ eva samudāyaḥ
translated: This is what is being said:🔽A composite is just many atoms.

analyzed: tad aneka tvam ca samudāya tvam
translated: And that multiplicity is the state of being a composite.

analyzed: tat militeṣu iva viraleṣu api vidyate
translated: It exists in the scattered [atoms] just as in the assembled [atoms].

analyzed: kintu na sadā samudāya tva vedanam bhavati
translated: But the awareness of the state of being a composite does not always occur.

analyzed: itara paramāṇu sahita itara paramāṇu sahita itara paramāṇu jñāne sati hi samudāya tva jñānam bhavati
translated: For the awareness of the state of being a composite occurs when there is the awareness of the other atoms associated with it and the other atoms not associated with it.

analyzed: apekṣā buddheḥ aneka tva vyañjaka tvāt
translated: Because the awareness of dependence manifests multiplicity.

analyzed: naca itaretara paramāṇu jñāne sati hi samudāya tva jñānam bhavati
translated: And the awareness of the state of being a composite does not occur when there is the awareness of the other atoms not associated with it.

analyzed: apekṣā buddheḥ aneka tva vyañjaka tvāt
translated: Because the cognition of dependence manifests multiplicity.

analyzed: naca itaretara paramāṇu jñāne sati hi samudāya tva jñānam bhavati
translated: And the cognition of the aggregate does not occur when there is cognition of the other atoms.

analyzed: mathudhurā pāṭalīputra sthitayoḥ vṛkṣayoḥ itaretara pratyayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: The mutual cognition of trees situated in Mathurā and Pāṭaliputra is seen.

analyzed: kiñca adhipati sahakāri ālambana samanantara pratyayāḥ catvāraḥ hi jñāna hetavaḥ
translated: Moreover, the four conditions are the causes of knowledge: the dominant, the cooperative, the object, and the immediate antecedent.

original: adhipatirindriyam /🔽naca viralānāṃ paramāṇūnāmindriyālambanaviralaparamāṇubhyastadālambanatayā tathātathā sannikṛṣṭāḥ paramāṇavo jāyante /
analyzed: adhipatiḥ indriyam  na ca viralānām paramāṇūnām indriya ālambana virala paramāṇubhyaḥ tad ālambana tayā tathā tathā sannikṛṣṭāḥ paramāṇavaḥ jāyante
translated: The dominant condition is the sense faculty.🔽And from the sparse atoms that are the object of the sense faculty, the atoms that are so and so close to it are not born.

analyzed: an adhipati indriyebhyaḥ ca ādhipati indriyāṇi
translated: And from the sense faculties that are not dominant, the sense faculties that are dominant are born.

analyzed: atha idānīm samanantara pratyaya balāt ekaḥ mahān iti jñānam utpadyate
translated: Now, the cognition of one great [object] arises by the power of the immediate antecedent condition.

analyzed: tena na anyonya āśraya tvam
translated: Therefore, there is no mutual dependence.

analyzed: nā api sṛṣṭayā ādi anupapattiḥ iti
translated: Nor is the non-apprehension of creation, etc. impossible.

analyzed: etena pakṣa antaram api sūcitam
translated: By this, another position is also indicated.

analyzed: virala paramāṇubhyaḥ sannikṛṣṭāḥ paramāṇavaḥ jāyante
translated: From the sparse atoms, the close atoms are born.

analyzed: tat eva teṣām samudāya tvam
translated: That itself is their aggregate nature.

analyzed: atas na kaścid doṣaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, there is no fault at all.

analyzed: samādhāna aṃśam vyācaṣṭe kāryā iti
translated: He explains the part of the solution with effect, etc.
The cause is engaged only in the mere production of the effect.

analyzed: na tu kārya viśeṣeṣu vyāpṛtam kāraṇam bhavet
translated: But the cause cannot be engaged in the production of particular effects.

original: kāryasambhūtimātre vyāpṛtiryasya tattathoktaṃ kāraṇaṃ kāryasambhūtimātravyāpṛtiḥ yatastato neti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: kārya sambhūti mātre vyāpṛtiḥ yasya tat tathā uktam kāraṇam kārya sambhūti mātra vyāpṛtiḥ yatas tatas na iti śeṣaḥ
translated: That which is engaged only in the mere production of the effect is said to be so. The cause is engaged only in the mere production of the effect. Therefore, it is not so. The rest is understood.

analyzed: yathā anutam etat na parihāra kṣamam atas bhiprāyam āha na tu iti
translated: This is not capable of being refuted as it has been stated. Therefore, he states the intention with the words but etc.

analyzed: viśiṣṭante iti viśeṣāḥ
translated: Particulars means specific things.

analyzed: kāryāṇi eva viśeṣāḥ kārya viśeṣāḥ
translated: Effects themselves are particulars, specific effects.

analyzed: kāraṇam iti jātau ekavacanam
translated: Cause is singular in the neuter.

analyzed: kāraṇāni khalu sva sadṛśa kārya janana vyāpārāṇi
translated: Causes are indeed engaged in producing effects similar to themselves.

analyzed: na tu visadṛśa kārya janane vyāpṛtāni iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are not engaged in producing dissimilar effects.

analyzed: kim atas yadi evam iti atas āha atas iti
translated: What follows from this if it is so? Therefore, he says for this reason etc.

analyzed: atas ṛtha indriya saṃyogi rūpa kāraṇa tā ātmanaḥ
translated: For this reason, the cause of the cognition of the self is the form of conjunction.

analyzed: saṃyogi rūpa rāhityāt nā eva tad jñāna tā api hi  sadṛśa kārya janakatva niyamāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Due to the absence of the form of conjunction, there is no cognition of that either.🔽The meaning is that it is restricted to producing similar effects.

original: saṃyogirūpe grāhyagrāhakarūpe ye arthendriye tayoḥ kāryayoḥ kāraṇatā saṃyogirūpakāraṇatā /
analyzed: saṃyogi rūpe grāhya grāhaka rūpe ye artha indriye tayoḥ kāryayoḥ kāraṇa tā saṃyogi rūpa kāraṇa tā
translated: The cause of the two effects, which are the forms of the grasped and the grasper, is the causal form of conjunction.

analyzed: artha indriyayoḥ saṃyogi rūpa kāraṇa tā artha indriya saṃyogi rūpa kāraṇa tā
translated: The form of the cause consisting in the conjunction of the object and sense organ is the form of the cause consisting in the conjunction of the object and sense organ.

analyzed: sā na eva upapadyate
translated: That is not possible at all.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: hi yasmāt kāraṇasya ātmanaḥ na eva tad jñāna tā asti iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: because the cause, the self, does not have that knowledge at all.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati  kāraṇam hi sadṛśa kārya janana svabhāvam vā
translated: This is what is said:🔽Either the cause would have the nature of producing an effect similar to itself,

analyzed: syāt visadṛśa kārya janana svabhāvam vā
translated: or the nature of producing an effect dissimilar to itself,

analyzed: ubhaya svabhāvam vā  anubhaya janana
translated: or the nature of both,

analyzed: svabhāvam vā
translated: or the nature of not producing either.

original: tatra yatrādyaḥ kalpo 'ṅgīkriyate tadendriyānālambanebhyo viralaparamāṇubhyastathābhūtā eva paramāṇavo jāyeran /
analyzed: tatra yatra ādyaḥ kalpaḥ ṅgīkriyate tadā indriya anālambanebhyaḥ virala paramāṇubhyaḥ tathābhūtāḥ eva paramāṇavaḥ jāyeran
translated: Among these, if the first hypothesis is accepted, then from the atoms that are not the object of the sense organ and are sparse, atoms of the same kind would be produced.

analyzed: na punar kadācid indriya ālambana bhūtāḥ militāḥ
translated: And they would never come together to become the object of the sense organ.

analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ ca artha anadhipatibhyaḥ tathāvidhāni eva indriyāṇi utpadyeran
translated: And from the sense organs, which are the dominant conditions for the objects, sense organs of the same kind would be produced.

analyzed: na jātu artha adhipati indriyāṇi
translated: The sense organs are never the dominant conditions for the objects.

analyzed: ātmānaḥ ca a samudāya jñānāt tādṛśaḥ eva ātmā jāyeta
translated: And from the self, which does not know the collection, an exactly similar self would be produced.

analyzed: na kadācid tad jñānavān
translated: It would never have that knowledge.

analyzed: anyathā kāraṇa paramāṇu ādīnām api indriya ālambana tva ādikam abhyupagantavyam syāt
translated: Otherwise, one would have to accept that the causal atoms and so on are the objects of the sense organs and so on.

analyzed: itarathā sadṛśa kārya janana svabhāva bhaṅga āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of the nature of producing similar effects.

analyzed: ubhayathā samudāya vedanasya kādācitka tvam na upapadyate iti
translated: In both cases, the occasional nature of the cognition of the aggregate is not possible.

analyzed: dvitīyam āśaṅkate viśeṣa iti
translated: He suspects the second in the verse beginning with viśeṣe.

analyzed: viśa ṣaṣ kārya janakam yadi kāraṇam iṣyate
translated: If a cause is accepted as producing a specific effect,

analyzed: tathā ca indriya anālambana vila paramāṇu ādibhyaḥ tad ālambana milita paramāṇu ādi janiḥ upapadyate iti bhāvaḥ
translated: then the production of the aggregate of atoms, etc. that are the objects of the senses, from the individual atoms, etc. that are not the objects of the senses, becomes logically possible. This is the idea.

analyzed: nirākaroti kutas iti
translated: He refutes it in the verse beginning with kutas.

analyzed: kutas samāna rūpa tvam kāryāṇām api sarvaśas
translated: How can there be the same form even in all the effects?

analyzed: tarhi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is then.

analyzed: sarvaśas pi kāryāṇām iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The relation is even in all the effects.

analyzed: atra kārya grahaṇam para mata anusāreṇa
translated: Here, the mention of effect is according to the opponent's view.

analyzed: kāraṇasya visadṛśa kāyaḥ janana svabhāva tāyām ākapālabhāvāt sarveṣu api ghaṭa kṣaṇeṣu ghaṭa ākāra tā na syāt
translated: If the cause has the nature of producing dissimilar effects, then the form of pot would not be there in all the moments of pot, due to the absence of the cause.

analyzed: kintu ghaṭa kṣaṇāt gaja kṣaṇaḥ tatas gardabha kṣaṇaḥ utpadyate
translated: But the moment of elephant arises from the moment of pot, and from that the moment of donkey arises.

analyzed: tathā nīla kṣaṇāt pīta kṣaṇaḥ tatas kapota kṣaṇaḥ jāyeta
translated: Similarly, the moment of yellow arises from the moment of blue, and from that the moment of pigeon is born.

analyzed: nīla anuvṛttiḥ tu na syāt iti
translated: But the continuation of blue would not be there.

original: astu tarhyubhayasvabhāvaṃ kāraṇamiti tṛtīyaḥ pakṣa iti cenna /
analyzed: astu tarhi ubhaya svabhāvam kāraṇam iti tṛtīyaḥ pakṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the cause should then have both natures, the third alternative, that is not so.

analyzed: virodhena ekasya api ajanana prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of contradiction, even one cannot produce.

analyzed: avirodhe tu āha atas iti
translated: If there is no contradiction, he says therefore.

analyzed: atas niyatyā yat kiñcid yasya kasya api kāraṇam
translated: Therefore, without restriction, anything can be the cause of anything at all.

analyzed: prakṛta pakṣa dvayam samāhṛtya atas iti parāmṛśati
translated: Referring to the two original alternatives, he refers to therefore.

original: aniyatyā ghaṭo ghaṭasyaiva nīlonīlasyaiveti niyatiṃ vinā /
analyzed: aniyatyā ghaṭaḥ ghaṭasya eva nīlaḥ nīlasya eva iti niyatim vinā
translated: Without restriction, a pot is only of a pot, blue is only of blue, without restriction.

analyzed: yat kiñcid ghaṭa ādikam nīla ādikam vā
translated: Anything at all, such as a pot, etc., or blue, etc.

analyzed: yasya kasya api ghaṭa ādeḥ aghaṭa ādeḥ nīla ādeḥ anīla ādeḥ ca
translated: Can be the cause of anything at all, such as a pot, etc., or not a pot, etc., or blue, etc., or not blue, etc.

analyzed: kāraṇam syāt
translated: It would be a cause.

analyzed: ghaṭa kṣaṇasya ubhayavidha kārya janana svabhāva tve sau tat ubhayam janayet
translated: If the moment of the pot has the nature of producing both kinds of effects, it would produce both.

analyzed: tathā ca upalabhyeta iti yāvat
translated: And it is perceived as such, up to this extent.

analyzed: kecid idam vākyam pūrva vākya śeṣa tayā vyācakṣate
translated: Some explain this sentence as a continuation of the previous sentence.

analyzed: sarvaśas u pi kāryāṇām samāna rūpa tvam na syāt
translated: Even the complete form of effects would not be the same.

analyzed: kintu visadṛśa kārya janana svabhāva tvāt ghaṭa ādikam gaja ādeḥ kāraṇam syāt iti
translated: But because of having the nature of producing dissimilar effects, a pot, etc., would be the cause of an elephant, etc.

analyzed: na caturthaḥ
translated: And not the fourth.

analyzed: arthakriyā rahitasya asattva prāpteḥ
translated: Because of the consequence of non-existence for what is devoid of causal efficiency.

analyzed: arthakriyā kāri tvam sattvam iti hi saugatāḥ
translated: The Buddhists hold that the essence of an object consists in its causal efficiency.

original: nanu ca kāryajananamātraṃ vastunaḥ svabhāva ityaṅgīkurmo na tūkteṣu kamapi pakṣamityata āha ata iti //
analyzed: nanu ca kārya janana mātram vastunaḥ svabhāvaḥ iti aṅgīkurmaḥ na tu ukteṣu kam api pakṣam iti atas āha atas iti
translated: We admit that the production of an effect is the essence of an object but we do not subscribe to any one of the above hypotheses.

analyzed: buddhi stham imam kalpam atas iti parāmṛśati
translated: The word 'ataḥ' (in the text) refers to the above hypothesis.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgaḥ tu na tirohitaḥ
translated: The charge of absurdity has not been met.

original: syādetat /🔽yathā bhavanmate pramājananasvabhāvatve 'pīndriyāderdeṣasahakārivaśādapramājananam /🔽tathā kāraṇasya sadṛśakāryajanakatve 'pyadṛṣṭādisahakārisāmarthyātkadācidvisadṛśakāryajananaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: syāt etat  yathā bhavat mate pramā janana svabhāva tve pi indriya ādeḥ deṣa sahakāri vaśāt apramā jananam  tathā kāraṇasya sadṛśa kārya janaka tve pi adṛṣṭa ādi sahakāri sāmarthyāt kadācid visadṛśa kārya jananam bhaviṣyati
translated: The Buddhists may contend thus:🔽The sense-organs such as eyes etc. are essentially productive of true knowledge. But they sometimes produce false knowledge because of the co-operation of some defects.🔽Similarly, though a cause is essentially productive of an effect similar to itself yet sometimes it produces an effect dissimilar to itself owing to the influence of some other factors such as the unseen force.

original: yadvā yathā sāṅkhayānāmindriyādīni pramāpramājananasvabhāvāni /🔽tatrāpramāpratipakṣāṇāṃ guṇānāmupanipāte pramāmevopajanayanti /
analyzed: yat vā yathā sāṅkhayānām indriya ādīni pramā pramā janana svabhāvāni  tatra apramā pratipakṣāṇām guṇānām upanipāte pramām eva upajanayanti
translated: Or, the sense-organs such as eyes etc. are essentially productive of both true and false perceptions according to the Sankhya thinkers.🔽When the good qualities which are hostile to false perceptions come forward, they produce true perceptions.

analyzed: pramā pratipakṣāṇām doṣāṇām upanipāte tu apramām
translated: When the defects which are hostile to true perceptions come forward, they produce false perceptions.

analyzed: tathā kāraṇasya ubhaya svabhāva tve pi adṛṣṭa ādi vaśāt tad anyatara janma upapatsyate
translated: Similarly, though a cause is essentially productive of both effects yet it produces one or the other effect owing to the influence of some other factors such as the unseen force.

analyzed: athavā yathā naiyāyika ādīnām indriya ādīni jñāna mātra janana svabhāvāni
translated: Or, just as for the Naiyāyikas and others, the senses etc. have the nature of merely producing knowledge,

analyzed: guṇa ādi sahakāri upanipātena pramādi utpa
translated: and the production of valid knowledge is due to the conjunction of qualities etc. as cooperating factors,

analyzed: papattiḥ tathā kāraṇam kārya janana svabhāvam eva  adṛṣṭa ādi sahakāri samavadhānāt tu
translated: in the same way, the cause has the nature of only producing its effect.

original: tatsadṛśaṃ visadṛśaṃ vā janayiṣyatītyata āha adṛṣṭamapīti //
analyzed: tat sadṛśam visadṛśam vā janayiṣyati iti atas āha adṛṣṭam api iti
translated: But due to the conjunction of unseen etc. cooperating factors, it will produce something similar or dissimilar to itself. Therefore he says Even the unseen...

analyzed: adṛṣṭam api tasya eva viśeṣa āpādakam kutas
translated: Even the unseen is the producer of that very particular. Why?

analyzed: atra adṛṣṭa grahaṇam upalakṣaṇam sahakāri mātrasya
translated: Here, the mention of the unseen is a mere indication of cooperating factors in general.

analyzed: adṛṣṭam api viśeṣasya
translated: The unseen is also the particular.

analyzed: ādye visadṛśa kārya janaka tvasya dvitīya nyatara pratibandhasya
translated: In the first case, it produces a dissimilar effect. In the second, it is the obstruction of either.

analyzed: tṛtīye tu ubhaya janaka tvasya āpādam kutas iti ekam vākyam
translated: In the third, it produces both. Why is it the producer? This is one sentence.

analyzed: tathā hi  pūrva pūrvatara ādi adṛṣṭa kṣaṇa aviśeṣa an āpādakāḥ tad āpādakāḥ vā
translated: It is like this.🔽The previous, earlier, etc. moments of unseen are either non-producers of that particular or producers of that particular.

analyzed: ādye tu asya adṛṣṭa kṣaṇasya viśeṣa āpādaka tvam na
translated: In the first case, the unseen moment's being the producer of the particular is not established.

analyzed: kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no cause.

analyzed: viśeṣa anāpādaka adṛṣṭa kṣaṇa ajanyaḥ
translated: This [effect] is also produced by the unseen moment that is not a producer of the particular.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa kṣaṇaḥ sahakāri vaśāt viśeṣam āpādayiṣyati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the seen moment will produce a special effect by the power of cooperating causes, that is not so.

analyzed: tad sahakāriṇī api asya sāmyāt
translated: Because this [seen moment] is the same as those cooperating causes.

analyzed: a tatra api sahakāri a natra anusaraṇe gauravam iti
translated: And if one follows [the cooperating causes] in that [seen moment] as well, there is a heavy burden.

original: tasyaiva kāraṇasya viśeṣāpādakaṃ kuta ityaparaṃ vākyam /
analyzed: tasya eva kāraṇasya viśeṣa āpādakam kutas iti aparam vākyam
translated: How can there be a producer of a special effect for that very cause? This is another sentence.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

analyzed: viśeṣa apavādakam api adṛṣṭam kim vivakṣitasya eva kāraṇasya viśeṣam āpādayati
translated: Is the unseen [cause] that produces a special effect only for the intended cause,

analyzed: kāraṇa mātrasya vā
translated: or for a cause in general?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: niyāmakayoḥ kāraṇa jñāpakayoḥ abhāvāt iti
translated: Because there is no determining cause or indicator.

analyzed: yebhyaḥ indriya an ālamabana virala paramāṇubhyaḥ tad ālambana milita paramāṇu utpattiḥ āśāsyate
translated: From which sense faculties that are not in contact, sparse atoms, the arising of those sense faculties that are in contact, aggregated atoms, is expected.

analyzed: yatas ca artha anadhipateḥ indriyāt artha adhipati indriyasya
translated: And from which sense faculty that is not the dominant condition of an object, the sense faculty that is the dominant condition of an object.

analyzed: yasmāt ca samudāya jñāna rahitāt ātmanaḥ tadvat ātma utpādaḥ
translated: And from which self that lacks the knowledge of a whole, the arising of that kind of self.

analyzed: tat idam tasya eva iti ucyate
translated: This is said to be of that very [cause].

analyzed: ubhayatra api dvi
translated: In both cases, the two

analyzed: dvitīyau kalpau dūṣayati yasya iti
translated: The second two alternatives are refuted by saying of which.

analyzed: yasya kasya api yat kiñcid viśeṣam upapādayet
translated: It would produce a special effect for any cause whatsoever.

analyzed: atra api yat kiñcid adṛṣṭam viśaṣam upapādayet iti ekam vākyam
translated: Here also, the sentence is: it would produce some unseen special property.

original: yadi pūvarpūrvatarādyadṛṣṭasyāpyasti viśeṣāpādakatvaṃ tarhi tadapi pūvarpūrvatarādiparamāṇvādau viśeṣamāpādayedeva /
analyzed: yadi pūvar pūrvatara ādi adṛṣṭasya api asti viśeṣa āpādaka tvam tarhi tat api pūvar pūrvatara ādi paramāṇu ādau viśeṣam āpādayet eva
translated: If the unseen has the power to produce special properties even in the previously unseen, then it would produce special properties even in the previously unseen atoms and so on.

analyzed: samarthasya kṣepa an abhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is not accepted that a capable [cause] is neglected.

analyzed: tathā ca samudāya pratīteḥ samaya niyamaḥ na syāt iti
translated: And thus, because of the cognition of the whole, there would be no restriction of convention.

analyzed: yasya kasya api viśeṣam upapādayet iti dvitīyam
translated: The second [alternative] is: it would produce some special property of anything at all.

original: yadi kāraṇamātrasya viśeṣāpādakamadṛṣṭamaṅgīkriyate tadā sarveṣāmapi kāraṇānāṃ viśeṣamupapāditam /
analyzed: yadi kāraṇa mātrasya viśeṣa āpādakam adṛṣṭam aṅgīkriyate tadā sarveṣām api kāraṇānām viśeṣam upapāditam
translated: If the unseen is accepted as producing special properties of causes alone, then the special properties of all causes are produced.

analyzed: tathā ca ghaṭa paramāṇu melane sarveṣām api melanam syāt
translated: And thus, in the combination of pot-atoms, there would be combination of all of them.

analyzed: na tu kutra api abhilaṣita paramāṇu avasthānam bhavet
translated: But there would be no desired arrangement of atoms anywhere.

analyzed: na ca yugapad sarva samudāyaḥ dṛśyate iti
translated: And the whole collection is not seen simultaneously.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought:

analyzed: sarvam idam sva vyāhatam
translated: All this is self-contradictory.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For instance:

original: tantavo yadi sadṛśakāryajananasvabhāvāstadā tantvantarameva janayeyurna tu paṭam /
analyzed: tantavaḥ yadi sadṛśa kārya janana svabhāvāḥ tadā tantu antaram eva janayeyuḥ na tu paṭam
translated: If the threads have the nature of producing a similar effect, then they would produce only another thread, not a cloth.

original: yadi ca visadṛśakāryajananasvabhāvāstadā na tebhyaḥ pārthivapaṭasyotpattiḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca visadṛśa kārya janana svabhāvāḥ tadā na tebhyaḥ pārthiva paṭasya utpattiḥ syāt
translated: And if they have the nature of producing dissimilar effects, then the cloth made of earth would not arise from them.

analyzed: kintu pāthasīyam kim api jāyeta
translated: But something made of earth would be produced.

analyzed: ubhaya svabhāva tvam tu viruddham
translated: But having both natures is contradictory.

analyzed: anubhaya svabhāva tve paṭasya api anutpattiḥ
translated: If they have neither nature, the cloth would not arise either.

analyzed: sahakāri vaśāt vayavasthā aṅgīkāre sahakāriṣu api idam samānam
translated: If you accept that the cloth is established by the power of the auxiliaries, this is the same for the auxiliaries.

analyzed: atha ucyeta
translated: Now, if it is said:

analyzed: kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: But the relation of effect and cause between the thread and cloth certainly exists.

analyzed: pramitasya apanhava anarha tvāt
translated: Because what is known cannot be denied.

original: sa ca yathā yathopapadyate tathā tathā kalpayiṣyata iti /
analyzed: sa ca yathā yathā upapadyate tathā tathā kalpayiṣyate iti
translated: And that will be imagined in whatever way it is possible.

analyzed: samam etat samā api iti atas āha kāryam ca iti
translated: This is the same as the opponent's argument. Therefore it is said: The effect and the cause...

original: kāryaṃ ca kāraṇaṃ caiva yatkiñcid yasya kasyacit // / / //
analyzed: kāryam ca kāraṇam ca eva yat kiñcid yasya kasyacid
translated: Whatever effect and cause there may be of anything whatsoever...

analyzed: bhavet niyāmaka abhāvāt
translated: Would not be restricted...

original: nityavināśitva itayetadvakṣyamāṇamatrāpi sambaddhayate /🔽yatkiñcinnīlādikaṃ yasya kasyacideva pītādeḥ kāryaṃ syāt /
analyzed: nitya vināśi tve itayā etat vakṣyamāṇam atra api sambaddhayate  yat kiñcid nīla ādikam yasya kasyacid eva pīta ādeḥ kāryam syāt
translated: Because of eternal destruction... This will be explained later and is connected here as well.🔽Any blue, etc. would be the effect of any yellow, etc.

original: yatkiñcitpītādikaṃ yasya kasyacideva nīlādeḥ kāraṇaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yat kiñcid pīta ādikam yasya kasyacid eva nīla ādeḥ kāraṇam syāt
translated: Any yellow, etc. would be the cause of any blue, etc.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is that?

original: nīlā nīlasyaiva kāryaṃ syāt na pītasya /
analyzed: nīlā nīlasya eva kāryam syāt na pītasya
translated: The blue would be the effect of the blue only, not of the yellow.

analyzed: nīlam eva nīlasya kāraṇam na pītam iti atra
translated: Blue itself is the cause of the blue, not the yellow. In this case,

analyzed: ti niyāmaka abhāvāt iti yojanā
translated: the meaning is that there is no absence of a determining factor.

analyzed: caśabdau mithas samuccaye
translated: The words ca (and) are for mutual inclusion.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: sambhavati sthira vāde parihāraḥ yam
translated: This answer is possible in the doctrine of permanence.

original: yadyatra samavetaṃ yadyenākāreṇa pariṇataṃ vā tattasya kāraṇaṃ kāryaṃ ceti niyāmakasadbhāvena kāyarkāraṇabhāvāvadhāraṇe sati tadupapādakakalpanopapatteḥ
analyzed: yat yatra samavetam yat yena ākāreṇa pariṇatam vā tat tasya kāraṇam kāryam ca iti niyāmaka sadbhāvena sati tad upapādaka kalpanā upapatteḥ
translated: If it is determined that something is the cause and effect of something else by the existence of a determining factor, namely, that which inheres in it or which is transformed into that form, then the assumption of what establishes that is possible.

original: kṣaṇabhaṅgunaye tu pūrvottarakṣaṇayorniranvayavināśotpādayoḥ kāyarkāraṇabhāvāvadhāraṇopāya eva nāsti /
analyzed: kṣaṇabhaṅgu naye tu pūrva uttara kṣaṇayoḥ niranvaya vināśa utpādayoḥ eva nā asti
translated: But in the doctrine of momentariness, there is no means at all of determining the relation of cause and effect between the preceding and succeeding moments, which are destroyed and produced without remainder.

analyzed: samavāya pariṇāmayoḥ abhāvāt
translated: Because inherence and transformation do not exist.

analyzed: tathā ca kasya balāt upapādakam kalpayiṣyate iti
translated: And in that case, by the power of what will one assume what establishes it?

original: samavāyapariṇāmayārabhāve 'pi yadyadapekṣayā pūrvabhāvi tadeva tasya kāraṇam /
analyzed: samavāya pariṇāma yāra bhāve pi yat yat apekṣayā pūrva bhāvi tat eva tasya kāraṇam
translated: Even in the absence of inherence and transformation, whatever precedes in relation to what is that the cause of that.

original: yacca yadapekṣayā paścādbhāvi tadeva tasya kāryamityavadhāraṇopapatterniyāmakābhāvo 'siddha ityataḥ kāryaniyamaṃ tāvannirākaroti idamasyaiveti
analyzed: yat ca yad apekṣayā paścāt bhāvi tat eva tasya kāryam iti avadhāraṇa upapatteḥ niyāmaka abhāvaḥ siddhaḥ iti atas kārya niyamam tāvat nirākaroti idam asya eva iti
translated: And because it is possible to determine that what is later in relation to what is that effect of that, the absence of a determining factor is not established. Therefore, he first refutes the restriction of effects, saying This is the cause of this alone.

analyzed: idam asya eva kāraṇam
translated: This is the cause of this alone.

original: iti nityavināśitve kena mānena gamyate // / /d //🔽idaṃ nīlamasya nīla
analyzed: iti nitya vināśi tve kena mānena gamyate  idam nīlam asya nīla
translated: How is this known in the case of eternal destruction?

analyzed: sya eva kāraṇam
translated: This blue is the effect of this blue alone.

analyzed: na tu pītasya
translated: But not of the yellow.

analyzed: iti evam nīlasya nīla kārya tvam
translated: Thus, the blue is the effect of the blue.

analyzed: nitya vināśi tve niranvaya vināśa utpāda pakṣe
translated: In the case of eternal destruction, in the view of destruction and origination without remainder.

original: kena mānena na kenāpi /🔽paścādbhāvamātrasya nīlasyeva pītasyāpi
analyzed: kena mānena na kena api  paścādbhāva mātrasya nīlasya iva pītasya api
translated: By what means of knowledge? By none.🔽Because mere later existence belongs to the yellow as well as to the blue,

analyzed: la apekṣayā iva pīta apekṣayā api sattvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: just as it does to the blue. This is the idea.

analyzed: sādeśyam sārūpyam vā niyāmakam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that co-existence or similarity is the determining factor, that is not so.

original: viralaparamāṇubhyo militānāṃ militebhyaśca viralānāmutpattyaṅgīkārāt /🔽kāraṇaniyamamapyapākaroti idaṃ neti //
analyzed: virala paramāṇubhyaḥ militānām militebhyaḥ ca viralānām utpatti aṅgīkārāt  kāraṇa niyamam api apākaroti idam na iti
translated: Because the arising of the aggregated from the sparse atoms and of the sparse from the aggregated is accepted.🔽He also refutes the restriction of causes, saying This does not arise from that.

analyzed: idam na jāyate muṣmāt iti atra api na kāraṇam
translated: Here also, there is no cause for saying This does not arise from that.

original: idaṃ nīlamamuṣmātpītānna jāyate kintu nīlādevetyatra nīlasya kāraṇatvāvadhāraṇe 'pi /
analyzed: idam nīlam amuṣmāt pītāt na jāyate kintu nīlāt eva iti atra nīlasya kāraṇatva avadhāraṇe pi
translated: Even when it is ascertained that this blue is the cause of that blue, not of yellow, but only of blue,

analyzed: kāraṇam pramāṇam na asti
translated: there is no proof of the cause.

original: nīlasyeva pītasyapi nīlāpekṣayā pūrvabhāvitāyāḥ sattvāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nīlasya iva pītasya api nīla apekṣayā pūrva bhāvitāyāḥ sattvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that just as blue, so also yellow exists prior to blue.

original: nanu yathā bhavatāṃ samavāyapariṇāmayorabhāve 'pi kuvindapaṭayoḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvāvadhāraṇaṃ tathā mamāpi bhaviṣyatītyata āha idamasyeti //
analyzed: nanu yathā bhavatām samavāya pariṇāmayoḥ abhāve kuvinda paṭayoḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva avadhāraṇam tathā mama api bhaviṣyati iti atas āha idam asya iti
translated: But it may be argued that just as for you, even in the absence of inherence and transformation, the relation of cause and effect between the weaver and the cloth is ascertained, so it will be for me also. To this he says this is of that etc.

analyzed: nitya vināśi tve ātmanaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is if the self is eternal and perishable.

analyzed: yujyate smākam nimitta kāraṇa kāryayoḥ tad bhāva avadhāraṇam anyatra an upakṣīṇa anvaya vyatirekābhyām
translated: For us, the ascertainment of that relation of cause and effect between the instrumental cause and effect is proper elsewhere by the non-depletion of positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: na tu parasya
translated: But not for the other.

analyzed: asmābhiḥ anvaya vyatireka anusandhātuḥ ātmanaḥ sthāyi tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because we accept the permanence of the self who perceives positive and negative concomitance,

analyzed: pareṇa ca kṣaṇika tā svīkārāt
translated: and because the other accepts momentariness.

analyzed: nahi tathāvidhaḥ nvaya vyatirekayoḥ anyatra anupakṣayasya ca avadhṛteḥ īṣyaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that such a perception of positive and negative concomitance and non-depletion elsewhere is not accepted.

analyzed: yojanā tu pūrvavat eva
translated: The construction is the same as before.

original: evaṃ samudāyaṃ nirākṛtya sarvasya kṣaṇikatāmadhunā pramāṇābhāvena tadvirodhena cāpākartumuttaro granthaḥ /
analyzed: evam samudāyam nirākṛtya sarvasya kṣaṇika tām adhunā pramāṇa abhāvena tad virodhena ca apākartum uttaraḥ granthaḥ
translated: Having thus refuted the whole, the subsequent text is now intended to refute momentariness of everything by the absence of any means of valid knowledge and by contradiction of it.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To this effect.

analyzed: na kevalam samudāyaḥ na upapadyate
translated: Not only the whole is not possible,

analyzed: kinnāma sarvasya kṣaṇika tā ca
translated: but also the momentariness of everything.

analyzed: tatra pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no means of valid knowledge for that.

analyzed: nanu pratyakṣam kṣaṇika tām arthānām avagamayati
translated: But does not perception ascertain the momentariness of things?

analyzed: tat hi vartamāna mātra gocaram arthasya vatarmāna kṣaṇa mātra sambandhinīm sattām avagāhate
translated: For that has the present alone as its sphere. It comprehends the existence related to the present moment of an object,

analyzed: na pūrva uttara kṣaṇa sambandhanīm api
translated: but not that related to the preceding and succeeding moments.

analyzed: tat katham kṣaṇika tvam arthānām aprāmāṇikam iti
translated: How then is the momentariness of things without a means of valid knowledge?

analyzed: ucyate  kim idam kṣaṇika tvam nāma
translated: It is said.🔽What is this called momentariness?

analyzed: kim kṣaṇa sambandhi sattvam  kiṃvā kṣaṇa mātre eva utpatti nāśavat tvam
translated: Is it the existence related to a moment?🔽Or is it the state of having origination and destruction in a moment alone?

analyzed: yat vā kṣaṇa antara asambandhi tve sati eka kṣaṇa sambandhi tvam
translated: Or is it the state of being related to one moment while not being related to another moment?

analyzed: ādyaḥ tviṣyaḥ eva
translated: The first is accepted itself.

analyzed: sthāyinaḥ pi arthasya eka kṣaṇa sattā svīkārāt
translated: Because even a permanent object is accepted as existing for one moment.

analyzed: dvitīya tṛtīyau dūṣayati vināśa iti
translated: He refutes the second and third by saying in destruction...

analyzed: vināśa utpattayaḥ ca eva na dṛśyante sadātanāḥ
translated: And their destruction and origination are not seen to be eternal.

analyzed: aneka padārtha sambandhi tvena bahuvacanam
translated: The plural is used because it is related to many things.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ tṛtīya pakṣa samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is for the purpose of including the third alternative.

analyzed: eva śabdasya na eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The word eva (only) is connected with na (not).

analyzed: sadātanāḥ pratikṣaṇa bhāvinyaḥ
translated: Eternal means occurring every moment.

original: pratyakṣaṃ khalvarthānāṃ vatarmānakālasattāmavagāhate na punaḥ kṣaṇamātrabhāvināvutpattivināśāvapi /
analyzed: pratyakṣam khalu arthānām vatarmāna kāla sattām avagāhate na punar kṣaṇa mātra bhāvinau utpatti vināśau api
translated: Indeed, perception penetrates the existence of objects in the present time, but not even their origination and destruction occurring in a mere moment.

analyzed: nā api kṣaṇa antara sambandhi tvam
translated: Nor the relation to another moment.

analyzed: tathā ca katham tena kṣaṇika tā siddhayet iti
translated: And how then could momentariness be established by that?

original: nanu ca pratyakṣaṃ pūrvottarakṣaṇavatirtvamapyarthasya gṛhṇāti na vā /
analyzed: nanu ca pratyakṣam pūrva uttara kṣaṇavatiḥ tvam api arthasya gṛhṇāti na vā
translated: But does perception also grasp the continuity of the object in the previous and subsequent moments or not?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: vartamāna mātra grāhi tvāt
translated: Because it only grasps the present.

original: dvitīye tu pratyakṣānupalambhena parvottarakṣaṇayorasattvasiddheḥ kṣaṇikataiva sidhyeditiddheti cet /
analyzed: dvitīye tu pratyakṣa anupalambhena parva uttara kṣaṇayoḥ asattva siddheḥ kṣaṇikatā eva sidhyet iti iddhā iti ced
translated: But if in the second case, the non-existence of the previous and subsequent moments is established by perception and non-apprehension, then momentariness itself would be established.

analyzed: dvitīyam tāvat urarīkumarḥ
translated: But the second should be examined first.

analyzed: na ca evam kṣaṇika tā siddhiḥ
translated: And thus there is no establishment of momentariness.

analyzed: yogya anupalambhasya eva asattva gamaka tvāt
translated: Because only the non-apprehension of what is possible is the cause of non-existence.

analyzed: na ca pūrva uttara kāla vartinā pratyakṣa yogyā
translated: And it is not capable of being perceived by what exists at an earlier or later time.

analyzed: vatar māna mātra grāhitāyāḥ pareṇa eva ukta tvāt
translated: Because the opponent himself has said that it grasps only the present.

analyzed: astu vā ādyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: Or let the first alternative be accepted.

original: kasyācitpratyakṣasya vartamānamātragrāhitve 'pi tadevedamiti pratyabhijñānalakṣaṇasya tadabhāvādityāśayenāha dṛśyata iti //
analyzed: kasyācid pratyakṣasya vartamāna mātra grāhi tve pi tat eva idam iti pratyabhijñāna lakṣaṇasya tad abhāvāt iti āśayena āha dṛśyate iti
translated: Even if some perception has the nature of grasping only the present, that is not the case with recognition, which is characterized by the thought This is the same. With this intention, he says is seen.

analyzed: dṛśyate pratyabhijñātaḥ sthira tvam sarva vastuṣu
translated: The stability of all things is seen when recognized.

analyzed: viṣayīkriyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is made an object.

analyzed: tṛtīyā arthe tasiḥ
translated: The suffix tasi has the sense of the third case.

analyzed: ekasya eva aneka kṣaṇa sambandhi tvam sthira tvam
translated: Stability is the relation of a single thing to many moments.

original: etena na kevalaṃ pratyakṣaṃ kṣaṇikatāṃ na gocarayati /
analyzed: etena na kevalam pratyakṣam kṣaṇikatām na gocarayati
translated: By this, it is shown that perception not only does not perceive momentariness,

analyzed: kintu sthāyi tām
translated: but also that it perceives permanence.

original: tvamapi gocarayatītyapīti vadatā parapakṣe pramāṇavirodhaḥ svapakṣe pramāṇasadbhāvaścodito bhavati / /🔽anenaanusmṛteśca' /
analyzed: tvam api gocarayati iti api iti vadatā para pakṣe pramāṇa virodhaḥ sva pakṣe pramāṇa sadbhāvaḥ coditaḥ bhavati  anena anusmṛteḥ ca
translated: By saying also, it is shown that in the opponent's view there is contradiction with valid cognition, and in one's own view there is the existence of valid cognition.🔽By this, the aphorism And because of non-remembrance

analyzed: iti sūtram kṛta vyākhyānam veditavyam
translated: should be understood to have been explained.

original: sarvavastuṣvityanena saugatānāṃ pratyabhijñānirākaraṇaṃ vaiśeṣikādimatameva spṛśati na tvasmanmatamiti sūcayati /
analyzed: sarva vastuṣu iti anena saugatānām pratyabhijñā nirākaraṇam vaiśeṣika ādi matam eva spṛśati na tu asmad matam iti sūcayati
translated: By the words ‘all things’ the author indicates that the denial of Recognition put forward by the Buddhist touches the doctrine of the Vaiśeṣika and others, and not his own doctrine.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is what is meant.

original: kimanayā pratyabhijñayā nityatvenābhyupagateṣu paramāṇvādiṣu sthiratvaṃ sādhyate kiṃvā ghaṭādiṣu /
analyzed: kim anayā pratyabhijñayā nitya tvena abhyupagateṣu paramāṇu ādiṣu sthira tvam sādhyate kiṃvā ghaṭa ādiṣu
translated: Is it the permanence of Atoms and other eternal substances postulated by the other party that is sought to be proved by this Recognition? Or is it the impermanence of the Jar and other things?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The former cannot be right.
