analyzed: teṣām atīndriya tvena pratyabhijñā pratyakṣa gocara tvasya abhyupagantum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because Atoms and other such things being beyond the reach of the senses, it is not possible to admit that they are within the range of the Perception of Recognition.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Nor can the second be right;
because even under the other party’s view, the Recognition in regard to the Jar, etc. has to be regarded as wrong.

original: yadā hi ghaṭādau sūcyagrādinaiko 'pi paramāṇurapaiti tadā naṣṭavyameva tadārabdhena dvayaṇukena /
analyzed: yadā hi ghaṭa ādau sūci agra ādinā ekaḥ pi paramāṇuḥ apaiti tadā naṣṭavyam eva tad ārabdhena dvayaṇukena
translated: Because when even a single Atom is taken away from the Jar, etc. the Dyad composed of that Atom becomes destroyed;

analyzed: vibhāgena asamavāyi kāraṇasya saṃyogasya naṣṭa tvāt
translated: because the Conjunction which is the non-inherent cause of the Dyad becomes destroyed by the separation (of the Atom).

analyzed: dvayaṇuka nāśe samavāyi kāraṇa nāśāt tryaṇuka nāśaḥ iti anena krameṇa ghaṭa nāśaḥ api avaśyambhāvī
translated: When the Dyad is destroyed, the Triad composed of that becomes destroyed, by the destruction of its constituent; and so on in due course, the Jar itself becomes destroyed.

original: naca paramāṇuḥ pratyakṣo yena tadapagamānapagamau pratyakṣeṇa śakyaniścayau /
analyzed: na ca paramāṇuḥ pratyakṣaḥ yena tad apagama anapagamau pratyakṣeṇa śakya niścayau
translated: The Atom itself is not perceptible; by the disappearance or non-disappearance of which, the certainty could be secured by Perception.

original: naca vācyaṃ nibiḍāvayaveṣu sphaṭikādiṣu pratyabhijñayā sthiratvaṃ setsyatīti /
analyzed: na ca vācyam nibiḍa avayaveṣu sphaṭika ādiṣu pratyabhijñayā sthira tvam setsyati iti
translated: Nor can it be said that stability will be established by recognition in crystals and so on with closely packed parts.

analyzed: tatra api paramāṇu apagama abhāvasya pratyakṣeṇa niścetum aśakya tvāt
translated: Even there, the absence of the departure of atoms cannot be ascertained by perception.

analyzed: nibiḍa avayava tvam ca na vibhāga ayogya avayava tvam
translated: And being closely packed does not mean having parts that are not fit for division.

analyzed: vibhāgasya pratyakṣa siddha tvāt
translated: Because division is established by perception.

analyzed: kintu ghaṭa āditas pi utkṛṣṭa kāraṇa apekṣa tvam
translated: But it means requiring a cause superior even to a pot and so on.

analyzed: na ca tad viśeṣa abhāvaḥ śakyaḥ smābhiḥ avagantum
translated: And we cannot understand the absence of that difference.

analyzed: dṛśyate hi kālataḥ sphaṭika ādau api guru tva apakarṣaḥ
translated: For heaviness is seen to decrease even in crystal over time.

analyzed: na ca avayava an apagame sa sambhavati iti
translated: And that is not possible without the departure of parts.

analyzed: nā api guṇa ādau sthāyi tvam pratyabhijñayā
translated: Nor is stability in qualities and so on established by recognition.

original: tasyāpi kasyacidatīndriyatvāt /🔽kasyacidghaṭāditulyatvāt sāmānyādikaṃ tu svarūpato nāstyeva /
analyzed: tasya api kasyacid atīndriya tvāt  kasyacid ghaṭa ādi tulya tvāt sāmānya ādikam tu svarūpataḥ na asti eva
translated: Because some of those are also beyond the senses.🔽But universals and so on do not exist at all in their own form.

original: sattve 'pi rūpādisamānameveti śaṅkitaprāmāṇyaṃ pratyabhijñānaṃ na kutrāpi sthairyasiddhau pramāṇayituṃ yuktamiti / /
analyzed: sattve pi rūpa ādi samānam eva iti śaṅkita prāmāṇyam pratyabhijñānam na kutra api sthairya siddhau pramāṇayitum yuktam iti
translated: Even if they exist, they are the same as form and so on. Thus recognition, whose validity is suspected, cannot be used as evidence for the establishment of stability anywhere.

analyzed: atra ucyate
translated: To this it is said:

analyzed: syāt ayam doṣaḥ paramāṇu ārambha vādinām
translated: This fault would apply to those who maintain that creation begins with atoms.

analyzed: na pariṇāma vādinām asmākam
translated: But not to us, who maintain evolution.

analyzed: tat eva hi vastu avayava upacaya apacayābhyām anyathā vikriyate
translated: For they think that it is just that same thing which is modified in another way by the increase and decrease of its parts.

original: na punaranyadeva bhavatīti hi pariṇāmavādino manyante ataḥ pratyakṣayogyeṣu sarvavastuṣu pratyabhijñayā sthiratvagrahaṇaṃ yuktameveti /
analyzed: na punar anyat eva bhavati iti hi pariṇāma vādinaḥ manyante atas pratyakṣa yogyeṣu sarva vastuṣu pratyabhijñayā sthira tva grahaṇam yuktam eva iti
translated: It does not become something else. Therefore, in all things that are fit to be perceived by perception, it is quite proper to grasp their permanence by recognition.

analyzed: nanu bhavat mate pratyabhijñā bhramaḥ eva
translated: But even according to your view, recognition is just an error.

analyzed: bhrāntiḥ eva
translated: It is indeed an error.🔽Because in the doctrine of evolution, the difference and non-difference of the previous and subsequent things are accepted.

analyzed: tat eva idam iti ca pratyabhijñayā atyanta abhedasya avagāhanāt
translated: And because of the complete non-difference that is grasped by recognition in the form that is this very thing.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: yadā tu yadi hi
translated: If, however,

analyzed: pūrva uttara kāla bhāvinoḥ abhedaḥ pratyabhijñā viṣayaḥ ṅgīkriyate
translated: if the non-difference of what exists at earlier and later times is accepted as the object of recognition,

original: tadā sāvadhāraṇasya pratyabhijñānasya bhramatve 'pi tadidamiti tu na bhramaḥ /
analyzed: tadā sāvadhāraṇasya pratyabhijñānasya bhrama tve tat idam iti tu na bhramaḥ
translated: then even if recognition with a definite reference is an error, this is that very thing is not an error.

analyzed: tena eva ca sthāyi tva siddhi ddheḥ
translated: And because permanence is established by that [recognition].

original: yadā tu kālādidvayasambandho viṣayastadā sāvadhāraṇamapi na bhrama iti /
analyzed: yadā tu kāla ādi dvaya sambandhaḥ viṣayaḥ tadā sāvadhāraṇam api na bhramaḥ iti
translated: But when the object is the relation to the two times, etc., then even with a definite reference it is not an error.

original: nanvidaṃ pratyabhijñānaṃ parilūnapunarjātakuntalāpādāviva bhrāntaṃ kinna syāditi cet na /
analyzed: nanu idam pratyabhijñānam parilūna punar jāta kuntala pādau iva bhrāntam kim na syāt iti ced na
translated: If it be asked how this recognition is not like the illusion of a woman with hair cut off and grown again, we reply: No,

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt  evam eva bhrānta
translated: because there is no sublating cognition.

analyzed: nti tva abhyupagame nīla ādi pratyayānām api tathātva āpatti iti aprāpteḥ
translated: If it be admitted that it is an illusion in this way, then the cognitions of blue, etc. also would be of the same nature, and the result would be the non-apprehension of objects.

analyzed: na ca pratyakṣam bādhakam iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that perception is not a sublating cognition.

analyzed: pratyakṣasya ābādhaka tve pi anumānam bādhakam bhaviṣyati iti śaṅkate phala ādīnām iti
translated: Fearing that inference might be a sublating cognition even when perception is not sublated, he says:

analyzed: phala ādīnām viśeṣeṇa sarvatra api anumīyate
translated: The difference in the size of effects, etc. is inferred everywhere.

analyzed: note jump in vese numbering
translated: Note: The verse numbers are jumped.

original: no lacuna in text/🔽sattvena kṣaṇikatvaṃ cedākāśasyāviśeṣataḥ /
analyzed: naḥ lacunaḥ in text  sattvena kṣaṇika tvam ced ākāśasya aviśeṣataḥ
translated: No lacuna in the text.🔽If momentariness is inferred from existence, then there is no difference from space.

analyzed: aviśeṣaḥ khilasya api sattvāt kim nā anumīyate
translated: Why is not the non-difference of everything inferred from existence?

analyzed: ādi padena deha dīpa ādi grahaṇam
translated: The word etc. includes the body, lamp, etc.

analyzed: viśeṣeṇa parimāṇa bhedena
translated: Difference means difference in size.

analyzed: kṣaṇika tvam tāvat
translated: Momentariety is first

analyzed: anumīyate iti sambandhaḥ
translated: inferred. This is the connection.

original: tatastaddṛṣṭāntena sarvatra phalādivyatirikte 'pi vastuni sattvena hetunā pañcaskandhā ityanumānaṃ sthiratvaviṣayapratyabhijñāyā bādhakaṃ bhaviṣyati
analyzed: tatas tad dṛṣṭāntena sarvatra phala ādi vyatirikte vastuni sattvena hetunā pañca skandhāḥ iti anumānam sthira tva viṣaya pratyabhijñāyāḥ bādhakam bhaviṣyati
translated: Then, by that example, the inference that the five aggregates exist as the reason in all things except the effect, etc., will be a refutation of the recognition that has the nature of permanence as its object.

analyzed: na ca phala ādi dṛṣṭāntaḥ sādhya vikalaḥ
translated: And the example of the effect, etc., is not devoid of the probandum.

analyzed: yat viruddha parimāṇam tat nānā dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭa paṭau
translated: That which has contradictory dimensions is seen to be different, like a pot and a cloth.

analyzed: viruddha parimāṇam ca phala ādikam pūrva uttara kṣaṇayoḥ
translated: And the effect, etc., have contradictory dimensions in the preceding and subsequent moments.

analyzed: iti anumānena phala ādīnām kṣaṇika tā siddheḥ iti
translated: Thus, by inference, the momentariness of the effect, etc., is established.

analyzed: pariharati ākāśasya iti
translated: He answers with of space, etc.

analyzed: aviśeṣatas
translated: Without distinction, of the preceding and subsequent moments,

analyzed: yoḥ bheda rahita tvataḥ
translated: devoid of difference.🔽Without distinction means devoid of difference between the preceding and subsequent moments.

analyzed: akhilasya api vipratipannasya
translated: Of all those who have doubts.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: yat sat tat akṣaṇikam yathā ākāśam
translated: That which exists is momentary, like space.

analyzed: sat ca nīla ādi iti pratyanumāna pratiruddha tvena anumānasya ābhāsa tvāt na pratyabhijñā bādhaka tvam sambhavati iti
translated: And blue, etc., are existent. Thus, because it is contradicted by a counter-inference, the inference is fallacious. Therefore, it cannot possibly contradict recognition.

analyzed: na ca ākāśa dṛṣṭāntaḥ sādhya vikalaḥ
translated: And the example of space is not devoid of the probandum.

original: ākāśo dvau nirodhau ca nityaṃ trayamasaṃskṛtam' /
analyzed: ākāśaḥ dvau nirodhau ca nityam trayam asaṃskṛtam
translated: Space and the two cessations are permanent, the three are unconditioned.

analyzed: pareṇa eva aṅgīkṛta tvāt kṣaṇika tā sādhakasya parimāṇa bheda ādeḥ ākāśe bhāvāt ca
translated: Because it is accepted by the opponent himself, and because difference in size, etc., which proves momentariness, does not exist in space.

analyzed: tat idam amum api u
translated: This is also stated by him

analyzed: aviśeṣataḥ parimāṇa bheda ādi rahita tvataḥ iti
translated: as due to the absence of difference in size, etc.

analyzed: yat u ākāśasya aviśeṣataḥ parimāṇa bheda rahita tvataḥ
translated: Or, due to the absence of difference in size in space,

original: taddṛṣṭāntenākhilasyāpi phalāderaviśeṣaḥ pūrvottarakālayoḥ parimāṇabhedābhāvaḥ sattvāt kiṃ nānumīyata iti yojanā /
analyzed: tad dṛṣṭāntena akhilasya api phala ādeḥ aviśeṣaḥ pūrva uttara kālayoḥ parimāṇa bheda abhāvaḥ sattvāt kim nā anumīyate iti yojanā
translated: why is not the absence of difference in size before and after of all effects, etc. inferred by that example? This is the construction.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: na anumānam pratyabhijñāyāḥ bādhakam bhavitum arhati
translated: Inference cannot be a refutation of recognition.

analyzed: anumānasya pratyakṣataḥ dubarla tvena tad bādhya tvāt
translated: Because inference is weaker than perception, it is refuted by that.

analyzed: anyathā phala ādikam parimāṇa bheda rahitam sattvāt ākāśa vat iti api anumāna prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the consequence of inference like The effect, etc. is without difference in size, because it exists, like space.

analyzed: na hi atra pratyakṣa ādi bādham vinā kaścid doṣaḥ sti
translated: For there is no fault here except the refutation by perception, etc.

analyzed: tathāca tad dṛṣṭānte kṣaṇikatva sādhakasya asiddha tvāt sādhya vikala tā syāt
translated: And thus, in that example, because the proof of momentariness is unestablished, there would be the fallacy of the probandum being unestablished.

analyzed: tatas pratyakṣa virodhena eva asya anumānasya aprāmāṇyam  anyathā anyonya āśraya tā
translated: Then, by contradiction with perception itself, this inference is not valid.

analyzed: prasaṅgaḥ iti eva vaktavyam
translated: Otherwise, it should be said that there is the fault of mutual dependence.

analyzed: tat ca samam prakṛte pi iti
translated: And that is the same in the present case as well.

analyzed: etena ākāśe ca aviśeṣāt
translated: By this, the aphorism And in space, because there is no distinction

analyzed: iti sūtram vyākhyātam bhavati  tat anena kṣaṇika tva tā
translated: is explained.

original: sādhakānumānasya satpratipakṣatvaṃ bādhitaviṣayatvaṃ ca vadatā'kāśe 'nā🔽naikāntyamapi sūcitam /
analyzed: sādhaka anumānasya sat pratipakṣa tvam bādhita viṣaya tvam ca vadatā ākāśe nā  na aikāntyam api sūcitam
translated: By this, it is shown that the inference proving momentariness has a counter-argument and its object is contradicted, and non-monotony is also indicated in space.

analyzed: bhavat anumānasya api phala ādinā anaikāntyam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that your inference also has non-monotony due to fruits etc., it is not so.

analyzed: tatra api kṣaṇikatā bhāvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt iti
translated: Because even there, the absence of momentariness will be stated.

analyzed: bhavet idam yadi ākāśasya sattvam syāt
translated: This would be so if the existence of space were so.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: mūrta abhāva tvāt ākāśasya
translated: Because space is the absence of the corporeal.

analyzed: bhāva tvam hi sattvam atra vivakṣitam
translated: For existence is intended here as being.

analyzed: sa sva rūpa tve pi vā sattve
translated: Or, even if it has its own nature, it is existent.

analyzed: abhāvaḥ niḥsvarūpaḥ iti aṅgīkṛtam iti āśaṅkayā āha yadi iti
translated: Fearing that it is accepted that non-existence is without nature, he says if etc.

original: yadyākāśasya sattvaṃ na kuta eva narādiṣu // / / //
analyzed: yadi ākāśasya sattvam na kutas eva nara ādiṣu
translated: If the existence of space is not so, how much less so in humans etc.?

original: yadyākāśasya sattvaṃ nāstītyaṅgīkṛtya pratyanumāne 'tiprasaṅgānumāne ca dṛṣṭāntasya sādhanavaikalyaṃ svānumānasyānaikāntikatvābhāvaścocyate
analyzed: yadi ākāśasya sattvam na asti iti aṅgīkṛtya pratyanumāne tiprasaṅga anumāne ca dṛṣṭāntasya sādhana vaikalyam sva anumānasya anaikāntika tva abhāvaḥ ca ucyate
translated: If it is said that the example in the counter-inference and the inference of over-extension are defective due to accepting the non-existence of space, and that our own inference is not inconclusive,

original: tadā dehādiṣu sattvaṃ kuta eva siddhamiti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: tadā deha ādiṣu sattvam kutas eva siddham iti brūmaḥ
translated: then we say that the existence of the body etc. is established from where?

analyzed: tathā ca parakīyasya api dṛṣṭāntasya sādhana vaikalyam syāt
translated: And in that case, the example of the opponent would also be defective.

original: yadi ca vidhimukhapratyayavedyatvāddehādīnāṃ bhāvatvaṃ pramāviṣayatvātsattvaṃ cocyate /
analyzed: yadi ca vidhi mukha pratyaya vedya tvāt deha ādīnām bhāva tvam pramā viṣaya tvāt sattvam ca ucyate
translated: And if the existence of the body etc. is said to be due to being known by cognition with a positive aspect, and their existence is due to being the object of valid cognition,

analyzed: tat ākāśe pi samānam iti  pramāṇa antareṇa ākāśasya abhāva tvam vārayitum upodghātam āha sa dharmī iti
translated: then the same applies to space as well.🔽In order to refute the non-existence of space by another means of valid cognition, he begins by saying that which is the substratum etc.

analyzed: sadharmi pratiyogi tvam ākāśasya avagamyate
translated: It is understood that space has a substratum and a counter-correlate.

analyzed: yatra abhāvaḥ sa dharmī
translated: Where there is absence, that is the substratum.

analyzed: yasya abhāvaḥ sa pratiyogī  tad ubhayavat tvam abhāvasya niyāmakam vyāpakam
translated: That of which there is absence is the counter-correlate.🔽The possession of both of these is the determining, the all-pervading, of absence.

analyzed: yaḥ bhāvaḥ sa dharmi pratiyogi sahitaḥ eva
translated: Every absence is accompanied by a substratum and a counter-correlate.

analyzed: yathā ghaṭa ādi abhāvaḥ
translated: Like the absence of a pot etc.

original: sa hi bhūtalādidharmiṇā ghaṭādipratiyoginā copeta eveti /
analyzed: sa hi bhū tala ādi dharmiṇā ghaṭa ādi pratiyoginā ca upetaḥ eva iti
translated: For that is indeed accompanied by a substratum such as the ground, and by a counter-correlate such as a pot etc.

analyzed: nanu idam anupapannam
translated: But this is not correct.

original: abhāvasya hi dharmipratiyogisāhityaniyamaḥ kiṃ deśataḥ syāt /
analyzed: abhāvasya hi dharmi pratiyogi sāhitya niyamaḥ kim deśataḥ syāt
translated: For the restriction of the absence to the presence of the substratum and the counter-correlate, is it to be in space?

analyzed: kiṃvā kālataḥ
translated: Or is it to be in time?

analyzed: ādye dharmiṇā sādeśyam tāvat na asti  bhū talasya sva āśraye
translated: In the first case, there is no co-location with the substratum.🔽The ground is in its own substratum.

analyzed: abhāvasya tu bhū tale vṛtteḥ
translated: But the absence is located on the ground.

analyzed: pratiyoginā tu viruddham eva
translated: But with the counter-correlate, it is contradictory.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tu yadi api dharmiṇā kathañcid syāt
translated: In the second case, although it may somehow be with the substratum,

analyzed: tathā api pratiyoginā na asti eva
translated: nevertheless, it does not exist with the counter-correlate.

analyzed: prāgabhāva pradhvaṃsa abhāvayoḥ pratiyogi bhinna kāla tva niyamāt iti āśaṅkām pariharan abhāvasya dharmi pratiyogi sāhitya vyāpta tvam upapādayati tau vinā iti
translated: Because the prior absence and posterior absence are restricted to being at a different time than the counter-correlate. To remove this doubt, he explains the pervasion of the absence by the presence of the substratum and the counter-correlate with Without those two, the absence is never seen anywhere.

original: tau vinā na hy abhāvaś ca kvaciddṛṣṭaḥ kadācana // / /ab //🔽atra dṛṣṭa iti prakaraṇāttau vineti tajjñānaṃ vinetyatharḥ /🔽caśabdo 'bhāvo dṛśyamāno dharmipratiyogipratītāveva dṛśyata ityanvayasamuccayārthaḥ /
analyzed: tau vinā na hi abhāvaḥ ca kvacid dṛṣṭaḥ kadācana  atra dṛṣṭaḥ iti prakaraṇāt tau vinā iti tad jñānam vinā iti atharḥ  caśabdaḥ bhāvaḥ dṛśyamānaḥ dharmi pratiyogi pratītau eva dṛśyate iti anvaya samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: Without those two, the absence is never seen anywhere.🔽Here, is seen is understood from the context as without the knowledge of those two. The word and is for the inclusive disjunction that the absence, when seen, is seen only when the substratum and the counter-correlate are cognized.

analyzed: hi śabdena anvaya vyatirekayoḥ prasiddha tvam sūcayati
translated: The word indeed indicates the well-known nature of the positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: tat anena anvaya vyatirekābhyām abhāva pratīteḥ dharmi pratiyogi pratīti pūrvaka tayā vyāptiḥ upapāditā bhavati
translated: By this, it is shown that the cognition of non-existence is pervaded by being preceded by the cognition of the substratum and the counter-correlate, through positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: yat vā tau iti
translated: Or, by the words tadevam

analyzed: ti anena na jñānam upalakṣaṇīyam
translated: the cognition is indicated.

original: abhāvaḥ pratīyamāno dharmipratiyogighaṭita evātredaṃ nāstītyādirūpeṇa pratīyate /
analyzed: abhāvaḥ pratīyamānaḥ dharmi pratiyogi ghaṭitaḥ eva atra idam na asti ityādi rūpeṇa pratīyate
translated: When non-existence is cognized, it is cognized only in the form of this is not here etc., which is constituted by the substratum and the counter-correlate.

analyzed: na tu tau vinā kevalaḥ iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām eka jñāna sambandhena vyāpya vyāpaka bhāva upapādanam etat iti avagantavyam
translated: But not without them, only by itself. It should be understood that this establishes the relation of the pervaded and the pervader in the form of being connected with a single cognition, through positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: prātar gaja ādi abhāva jñānam tu anyathā upapādayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will explain the cognition of the absence of an elephant inside in another way.

original: kimato yadyevamabhāvasya yadyevamabhāvasya dharmipratiyogisāhityaṃ pratītau vyāpakamityata āha adharmīti
analyzed: kim atas yadi evam abhāvasya yadi evam abhāvasya dharmi pratiyogi sāhityam pratītau vyāpakam iti atas āha adharmi iti
translated: What follows from this, if the presence of the substratum and the counter-correlate is the pervasion in the cognition of non-existence? To this he says adharmi

analyzed: adharmi pratiyogi tvam ākāśasya avagamyate
translated: The absence of a substratum and a counter-correlate is understood in the case of space.

analyzed: pratītau abhāvasya vyāpakam sadharmi pratiyogi tvam ākāśāt tāvat vayāvarta ṛtyate
translated: The pervasion of non-existence in the cognition, which is the presence of a substratum and a counter-correlate, is excluded from space.

analyzed: yasmāt ākāśaḥ iti eva avagamyate na tu atra idam na asti iti
translated: Because only space is understood, not this is not here.

original: iyamapi ca vastuto mūrtābhāvagocaraiva pratītiḥ pralayādivannañvarjitābhilāpasambandhādatādṛśīva prakāśata iti cenna /
analyzed: iyam api ca vastutas mūrta abhāva gocarā eva pratītiḥ pralaya ādi vat nañ varjita abhilāpa sambandhāt atādṛśī iva prakāśate iti ced na
translated: And this cognition also, in reality, has as its object the absence of the material, like the cognition of dissolution, etc. It appears as if it were not so, due to the connection with the word produced by the negative particle. But this is not so.

analyzed: nīla ādi pratiteḥ api tathātva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the consequence that the cognition of blue, etc. would also be like that.

analyzed: anānubhāvika tvasya ubhayatra api sāmyāt
translated: Because the non-manifestation is the same in both cases.

analyzed: tathā ca parasya api asiddhayā ādi āpātaḥ  vyāpaka nivṛttyā ca
translated: And thus, the opponent would also incur the fallacy of unestablished reasons, etc.

analyzed: vyāpya nivṛttiḥ avaśyaṃbhāvinī iti ākāśasya na abhāva tvam iti
translated: And because the cessation of the pervader necessarily leads to the cessation of the pervaded, space cannot be a non-entity.

analyzed: tat ayam prayogaḥ
translated: This is the argument.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ na abhāvaḥ dharmi pratiyoginau vinā eva pratīyamāna tvāt rūpa vat iti
translated: Space is not a non-entity, because it is cognized even without a substratum and its opposite, like form.

original: kiñca mūrtābhāvamākāśaṃ vadatā yo dharmī tasyocyate sa evāsmākamākāśa iti nāmnayeva vivādo 'vaśiṣyate /
analyzed: kiñca mūrta abhāvam ākāśam vadatā yaḥ dharmī tasya ucyate saḥ eva asmākam ākāśaḥ iti nāmnayā iva vivādaḥ
translated: Moreover, for one who says that space is the absence of the material, the substratum of that is said to be the same as our space. Thus, only a dispute over the name remains.

analyzed: vakṣyate ca etat viyat adhikaraṇe iti
translated: And this will be stated in the chapter on space.

analyzed: sūtra dvaya artham upasaṃharati svīkāra iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the two aphorisms with the word acceptance, etc.

analyzed: svīkāra tyāgataḥ dṛṣṭa dṛṣṭayoḥ sarva vastuṣu
translated: In the acceptance and rejection of the unseen and seen, in all things,

analyzed: guṇān unmattaḥ eva asau vidadhāti adhikam punar
translated: He, not mad, again establishes an additional quality.

analyzed: adṛṣṭasya kṣaṇika tva ādeḥ svīkṛti kāra
translated: The one who accepts the unseen, such as momentariness,

analyzed: dṛṣṭasya sthira tva ādeḥ tyāgataḥ
translated: Because of the abandonment of the seen stability, etc.

analyzed: asau saugataḥ
translated: That one is a Buddhist.

analyzed: adhikam svatas iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: more from itself.

analyzed: unmattam api svasmāt adhika vivekavantam sthā
translated: It makes even a madman appear to be more discerning than himself.

analyzed: khyāpayati iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: na hyunmattaḥ sarvatrāpramitaṃ svīkaroti nāpi pramitaṃ tyajatīti /
analyzed: na hi unmattaḥ sarvatra apramitam svīkaroti na api pramitam tyajati iti
translated: For a madman does not accept everything that is not ascertained, nor does he abandon what is ascertained.

original: nanu ca yadi nīlādikaṃ na syāttadā sanna syāt /
analyzed: nanu ca yadi nīla ādikam na syāt tadā sat na syāt
translated: But if blue, etc. were not, then it would not be existent.

analyzed: arthakriyā kāri tvam hi sattvam
translated: For the capacity for effective action is existence.

analyzed: vyāptam ca krama yaugapadyābhyām
translated: And that is pervaded by sequence and simultaneity.

analyzed: tṛtīya prakāra abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no third type.

analyzed: na ca sthire tad sambhavaḥ prasaṅga tad viparyayābhyām
translated: And that is not possible for a permanent thing, because of the absurdity and its opposite.

analyzed: tathā hi  sthāyībhāvaḥ kim svī  svakīyām artha kriyām krameṇa kuryāt yugapad vā
translated: It is like this.🔽Does a permanent thing perform its own function gradually or simultaneously?

original: ādye kālāntarabhāvinīmarthakriyāṃ pratīdānīṃ samartho na vā /
analyzed: ādye kāla antara bhāvinīm arthakriyām prati idānīm samarthaḥ na vā
translated: If the first, is it now capable of producing the function that will occur at a later time or not?

analyzed: prathame tām api idānīṃnīm eva kuryāt
translated: In the first case, it would produce that now itself.

analyzed: samarthasya kṣepa ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible to delay what is capable.

analyzed: dvitīye tadā api na kuryāt
translated: In the second case, it would not produce it then either.

analyzed: idānīm asamarthaḥ tadānīm samartha tvāt kariṣyati iti ced
translated: If it is argued that even though it is not capable now, it will produce it then because it was capable then,

analyzed: tadā sāmarthya asāmarthya lakṣaṇa viruddha dharma adhyāsaḥ bhāvam bhindyāt
translated: Then, the superimposition of contradictory properties characterized by capability and incapability would divide the entity.

original: dvitīye tvādyakṣaṇa eva kartavyasya sarvasya kṛtatvāt dvitīyādikṣaṇe 'sattvamavarjanīyameva /
analyzed: dvitīye tu ādi akṣaṇe eva kartavyasya sarvasya kṛta tvāt dvitīya ādi kṣaṇe sattvam avarjanīyam eva
translated: But in the second case, since everything to be done is done at the very first moment, non-existence in the second and subsequent moments is unavoidable.

analyzed: tat evam anukūla tarka bala labdha pratibandhasya kṣaṇikatva anumānasya balavat tvāt pratyabhijñā pratyanumāne tad bādhite na sthairya sādhanāya alam iti
translated: Thus, since the inference of momentariness, which has obtained its connection by the force of favorable reasoning, is strong, and the inference of recognition is contradicted by it, it is not able to establish permanence.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: eṣām tarkāṇām pratitarka parāhata tva ādinā ābhāsa tvāt
translated: Because these reasonings are fallacious due to being refuted by counter-reasonings and so on.

original: tathāhi /🔽yadyātmānātmaprapañcaḥ sarvo 'pi kṣaṇikaḥ syāttadā pramāpramārūpaḥ sarvokalo
analyzed: tathā hi  yadi ātma anātma prapañcaḥ kṣaṇikaḥ syāt tadā pramā pramā rūpaḥ
translated: Thus it is.

analyzed: pi anumāna āgama pratyabhijñā lakṣaṇaḥ vyavahāraḥ lupyeta
translated: If the entire manifold of self and non-self were momentary, then all worldly activity characterized by valid cognition, invalid cognition, inference, scripture, and recognition would be destroyed.

original: tarkasyāpyasya notthānaṃ syāt /🔽tasya tajjātīyasya vā tena tajjātīyena vā saha bhūyaḥ sambandhāvagame na
analyzed: tarkasya api asya na utthānam syāt  tasya tad jātīyasya vā tena tad jātīyena vā saha bhūyas sambandha avagame na
translated: This reasoning would not arise either.🔽When the relation of that or a similar kind with that or a similar kind is understood again,

analyzed: ta tādātmya tad utpatti avadhāraṇena vā 🔽ca upādhi abhāvāt ya
translated: it is not ascertained by identity or origination from that,🔽or because of the absence of a limiting condition, and so on.

analyzed: vadhāraṇena vā vyabhicāra abhāva niścaye sati vyāpti avadhāraṇam
translated: Or, when the absence of contradiction is ascertained by ascertainment, there is the ascertainment of pervasion.

analyzed: avadhṛta vyāpteḥ ca pakṣa darśanam liṅga darśanam ca
translated: And for one who has ascertained the pervasion, there is the perception of the subject and the perception of the reason.

original: tato 'nubhūtavyāptismaraṇam /🔽atha yanmayā vyāptatvena jñātaṃ liṅgaṃ tadatra pakṣe 'stītyanusandhānam /
analyzed: tatas nu bhūta vyāpti smaraṇam  atha yat mayā vyāpta tvena jñātam liṅgam tat atra pakṣe sti iti anusandhānam
translated: Then there is the recollection of the experienced pervasion.🔽Then there is the understanding that the reason which has been known by me as pervaded is present in this subject.

analyzed: atha idānīm anumitiḥ iti anumāna prakriyā
translated: Then there is inference. This is the process of inference.

analyzed: na hi etat sarvam kṣaṇikasya ātmanaḥ sambhavati
translated: For all this is not possible for a momentary self.

original: yena hi sakṛt dhūmo dṛṣṭo naṣṭa evāsau /
analyzed: yena hi sakṛt dhūmaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ naṣṭaḥ eva asau
translated: For the smoke that was seen once is destroyed itself.

analyzed: kasya bhūyas darśanam kasya ca vyāpti avadhāraṇa ādi
translated: Whose is the repeated seeing? And whose is the ascertainment of pervasion, etc.?

original: yasmiṃśca parvate dhūmo dṛṣṭo naṣṭa evāsau /🔽kutra punarvyāptiliṅgānusandhānam /
analyzed: yasmin ca parvate dhūmaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ naṣṭaḥ eva asau  kutra punar vyāpti liṅga anusandhānam
translated: And the smoke that was seen on that mountain is destroyed itself.🔽And where is the recollection of the pervasion and the reason?

analyzed: kutra ca sādhya adhyavasāyaḥ  evam āgame pi ekaika varṇa śravaṇāni
translated: And where is the ascertainment of the conclusion?

analyzed: pada anusandhānam
translated: In the same way, in the case of a verbal testimony, there are the hearings of each letter.🔽There is the recollection of the words.

analyzed: samaya grahaḥ
translated: There is the apprehension of the convention.

analyzed: punar pada śravaṇam
translated: Again there is the hearing of the words.

analyzed: samaya smaraṇam  vākya artha jñānam iti aneka saṃvikā anusandhā
translated: There is the recollection of the convention.

analyzed: ndhānam na ātmanaḥ kṣaṇika tāyām upapadyate
translated: There is the knowledge of the meaning of the sentence. Thus the recollection of many different things is not possible for a momentary self.

original: pratyabhijñānamapi yena pūrvāvastho 'rtho jñātastenaiva tasya vā tatsadṛśasya vā darśane bhavati /
analyzed: pratyabhijñānam api yena pūrva avasthaḥ rthaḥ jñātaḥ tena eva tasya vā tad sadṛśasya vā darśane bhavati
translated: Recognition also occurs when one who has known an object in a previous state sees that very object or something similar to it.

analyzed: tat katham kṣaṇikasya ātmanaḥ syāt
translated: How could that be for a momentary self?

analyzed: anumānena tarkaḥ pi vyākhyātaḥ  pratikṣaṇam ātmanaḥ na ātmanaḥ ca bhede pi anumānā
translated: Inference and reasoning have also been explained.

analyzed: di aṅgīkāre tiprasaṅgaḥ syāt
translated: Even if there is a difference between the self and the non-self at every moment, if inference and so on are accepted, there would be an absurd consequence.

analyzed: yasya kasyacid vayāpti jñāne bhavet syāt
translated: If anyone knows the pervasion, even a resident of the coconut islands would have knowledge of fire.

analyzed: parvate liṅga darśanena hrade pi agniḥ anumīyeta ityādi
translated: If the inferential mark is seen on a mountain, fire would be inferred even in a lake, and so on.

original: pūrvottarakṣaṇavartināmātmanāṃ parvatādīnāṃ ca kāryakāraṇabhāvādupapanno 'numānādivyavahāra iti cetna /
analyzed: pūrva uttara kṣaṇa vartinām ātmanām parvata ādīnām ca kārya kāraṇa bhāvāt upapannaḥ numāna ādi vyavahāraḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the practice of inference and so on is justified by the relation of cause and effect between the selves and mountains, etc., existing in the preceding and succeeding moments, that is not so.

analyzed: anya tvasya anapāyāt
translated: Because difference is not avoided.

analyzed: anyathā upādhyāya śiṣya buddhayā ādau api prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the absurd consequence of the relation of teacher and student, cognition, etc. also.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is the view

analyzed: kāraṇa kṣaṇāḥ kārya kṣaṇeṣu
translated: that the moments of the cause transmit the impressions to the moments of the effect,

analyzed: atas pūrva pūrva ātma saṃskāra yoginām uttara uttareṣām ātmanām anumāna ādi vyavahāraḥ yujyate
translated: then the practice of inference and so on is justified for the succeeding selves possessing the impressions of the preceding selves.

analyzed: parvata ādayaḥ pi pūrva
translated: Even mountains and so on, which are not selves, are capable of the practice of inference and so on, because they are the cause of the succeeding effects.

analyzed: pūrva saṃskāra bhājaḥ pakṣa ādi tvam aśnuvate iti
translated: They enjoy the state of being a fortnight etc. due to the impressions of the past.

analyzed: etad nirākaraṇāya sūtram
translated: To refute this, there is the sutra:

analyzed: om uttara utpāde ca pūrva nirodhāt om
translated: Om. Because of the cessation of the previous moment at the arising of the subsequent moment, Om.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe uttarā iti  uttara utpāde ca pūrva nirodhāt
translated: He explains it as follows: Uttara etc.🔽Because of the cessation of the previous moment at the arising of the subsequent moment.

analyzed: uttara utpatti mātreṇa vināśāt pūvarvastunaḥ
translated: Because of the destruction of the previous entity merely by the arising of the subsequent moment,🔽The imparting of impressions by anything anywhere is not tenable.🔽Of any cause.

original: na saṃskārārpakatvaṃ ca yujyate kasyacit kvacit // / / // /🔽kasyacit kāraṇasya /🔽kacit kārye /
analyzed: na saṃskāra arpaka tvam ca yujyate kasyacid kvacid  kasyacid kāraṇasya  kacid kārye
translated: In any effect.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha atas iti
translated: What follows from this? Therefore, he says ataḥ etc.

original: ato jñātaṃ mayetyādi na jñeyamanumā kutaḥ // / / //🔽ātmanaḥ kṣaṇikatvātsaṃskārāparṇasya cāvā
analyzed: atas jñātam mayā ityādi na jñeyam anumā kutas  ātmanaḥ kṣaṇika tvāt saṃskāra aparṇasya
translated: Therefore, I have known this etc. should not be known. How can there be inference?

analyzed: sambhavāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Because of the momentariness of the self and the impossibility of the imparting of impressions. This is the meaning.

original: yanmayā vyāptatvena jñātaṃ tadatra vidyata ityādi yathā bhavati tathā na jñeyaṃ jñātumaśakyam /
analyzed: yat mayā vyāpta tvena jñātam tat atra vidyate ityādi yathā bhavati tathā na jñeyam jñātum aśakyam
translated: That which is known by me as pervaded exists here etc. should not be known in the same way. It cannot be known.

analyzed: tatas ca anumā kutas  āgama ādeḥ api upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: And from that, how can there be inference?🔽This also indicates the scriptures etc.

analyzed: nanu asti tāvat anumāna ādi vyavahāraḥ
translated: But there is indeed the usage of inference etc.

analyzed: sarva loka siddhasya apahnava ayogāt
translated: Because it is impossible to deny what is established in all the worlds.

original: tadbalenālaukikamapyasahabhāvinaḥ saṃskārārpakatvaṃ kalpayiṣyata ityata āha ekatvamiti //
analyzed: tad balena alaukikam api asahabhāvinaḥ saṃskāra arpaka tvam kalpayiṣyate iti atas āha ekatvam iti
translated: It will be assumed that even though it is not of the nature of the world, it has the power to produce the non-coexistent formations by its power. Therefore, he says: The oneness, etc.

analyzed: eka tvam anubhūti stham tyaktavā nirmānakā bhidā
translated: The difference, abandoning the oneness established in experience, is without reason.

analyzed: kutas ātma ādikeṣu syāt
translated: From where would it be in the self and others?

analyzed: kim anumāna ādi vyavahāra anyathā anupapatti mātreṇa alaukikam kalpanīyam
translated: Is the non-worldly to be imagined merely because of the impossibility of other explanations of the usage of inference, etc.?

analyzed: kiṃvā ātma ādeḥ kṣaṇika tve sati
translated: Or, even if the self and others are momentary?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: ātma ādeḥ sthāyi tvena eva tad upapatteḥ
translated: Because that is possible even with the permanence of the self and others.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tu syāt
translated: The second may be so.

analyzed: yadi ātma ādeḥ kṣaṇika tvam siddham syāt
translated: If the momentariness of the self and others were established.

analyzed: na ca tat asti
translated: But that does not exist.

analyzed: pramāṇa bādhita tvāt niṣpramāṇaka tvāt ca iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it is contradicted by valid cognition and is without any valid cognition.

analyzed: ekatvam bhidā iti atra pūrva uttara kālayoḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: In the oneness in the difference, the remainder is in the earlier and later times.

analyzed: anubhūti stham pratyabhijñā siddham
translated: Established in experience, established by recognition.

analyzed: kutas ṅgīkāryā iti adhyāhārāt samāna kartṛtā siddhiḥ
translated: From the implication that it should be accepted, the establishment of the same agent.

original: nanu ca pratyabhijñānaṃ bhrāntamityuktam /🔽tatkathamātmāderaikyaṃ tataḥ siddhayedityata āha valyeveti //
analyzed: nanu ca pratyabhijñānam bhrāntam iti uktam  tat katham ātma ādeḥ aikyam tatas siddhayet iti atas āha valyā iva iti
translated: But it has been said that recognition is mistaken.🔽How then can the oneness of the self and others be established from that? Therefore, he says: Only the strong, etc.

analyzed: balyā iva anubhavaḥ yatas
translated: From where the experience is only strong, etc.

original: tarkabalenānumāne niravakāśatayā prabale sati hi tadvirodhātpratyabhijñānaṃ bhrāntaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tarka balena anumāne niravakāśa tayā prabale sati hi tad virodhāt pratyabhijñānam bhrāntam syāt
translated: For if inference, by the force of reasoning, were strong on account of having a non-deficient basis, recognition would be mistaken due to its contradiction.

analyzed: yadā tu tarkasya ukta vidhayā ābhāsa tvam
translated: But when reasoning is of the nature described,

analyzed: tadā kutas kṣaṇikatva anumāna prābalyam
translated: then how can the inference of momentariness be strong?

analyzed: kutas ca pratyabhijñāyāḥ tad bādhaḥ
translated: And how can recognition be contradicted by that?

analyzed: a bādhitaḥ ca pratyabhijñā anubhavaḥ yatas balyā iva
translated: And since the experience of recognition is not contradicted, it is indeed strong.

analyzed: atas ātma ādeḥ ekatvam tena siddham iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the oneness of the self and so on is established by that. This is the connection.

analyzed: etena anumāna siddhasya bhedasya katham nirmānaka tvam iti api parāstam
translated: By this, it is also refuted how the difference established by inference can be denied.

original: tadupajīvyasya tarkasyādyāpyanavasthānāt / /🔽nanvastūttarotpāda eva pūrvasya nirodhastathāpi kutaḥ pūrvasyottarasminsaṃskārānādhāyakatvamityata āha kāryakāraṇayośceti //🔽kāryakāraṇayoścaikakālīnatvaṃ vinā katham /
analyzed: tad upajīvyasya tarkasya adya api anavasthānāt  nanu astu uttara utpādaḥ eva pūrvasya nirodhaḥ tathā api kutas pūrvasya uttarasmin saṃskāra anādhāyakatvam iti atas āha kārya kāraṇayoḥ ca iti  kārya kāraṇayoḥ ca eka kālīna tvam vinā katham
translated: Because the reasoning that depends on that has not yet ceased.🔽But even if the cessation of the previous [moment] is just the arising of the subsequent [moment], how can the previous [moment] not produce an impression in the subsequent [moment]? To this he says And the simultaneity of cause and effect...🔽And without the simultaneity of cause and effect,

analyzed: pūrva saṃskāra yogī syāt uttaraḥ niyamena ca
translated: how could the subsequent [moment] necessarily possess the impression of the previous [moment]?🔽...

original: uttarotpāda eva pūrvasya nirodhātkāyarkāraṇayorekakālīnatvaṃ tāvannāstīti labhyate /
analyzed: uttara utpādaḥ eva pūrvasya nirodhāt kāya ṛk āraṇayoḥ eka kālīna tvam tāvat na asti iti labhyate
translated: It is understood that there is no simultaneity of the effect and cause, because the cessation of the previous [moment] is precisely the arising of the subsequent [moment].

original: ekakālīnatvaṃ ca vinā pūrvāhitasaṃskārayogitvamuttarasya na yujyate /
analyzed: eka kālīna tvam ca vinā pūrva āhita saṃskāra yogi tvam uttarasya na yujyate
translated: And without simultaneity, it is not reasonable for the subsequent [moment] to be endowed with the impressions deposited by the previous [moment].

original: niyamena cetyanena kvacidapi na yujyate kutaḥ sarvatreti sūcayati /
analyzed: niyamena ca iti anena kvacid api na yujyate kutas sarvatra iti sūcayati
translated: By [the phrase] necessarily, it indicates that it is not reasonable [for the impressions to be deposited] even in some cases, much less in all cases.

original: yadvaikakālīnasya eva saṃskārārpakatvaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ na bhinnakālatva iti vyāpterityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā eka kālīnasya eva saṃskāra arpaka tvam dṛṣṭam na bhinna kāla tve iti vyāpteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is a universal truth that what is simultaneous is seen to deposit impressions, not what is not simultaneous.

original: nanvekakālīnatvābhāve 'pi kutaḥ saṃskārārpakatvaṃ na syādityata āha sambaddhā eveti //
analyzed: nanu eka kālīna tva abhāve pi kutas saṃskāra arpaka tvam na syāt iti atas āha sambaddhāḥ eva iti
translated: But even if there is no simultaneity, why would it not be reasonable for [the impressions] to be deposited? To this he says only what is connected...

analyzed: sambaddhaḥ eva saṃskāram anyatra ādattate khilāḥ
translated: All things that deposit impressions deposit them elsewhere only when connected.

analyzed: asambaddhaḥ katham pūrve uttare vāsanā karaḥ
translated: How could the unconnected previous [moment] be the depositor of impressions in the subsequent [moment]?

original: yasmāt akhilāḥ saṃskārādhāyakāścāmpakakusumādayaḥ padārthāstailādibhiḥ sambaddhā eva anyatra tailādau saṃskāramādadhate /🔽nāsambaddhā ityasti niyamaḥ /🔽naca bhinnakālīnala
analyzed: yasmāt akhilāḥ saṃskāra ādhāyakāḥ cāmpaka kusuma ādayaḥ padārthāḥ taila ādibhiḥ sambaddhāḥ eva anyatra taila ādau saṃskāram ādadhate  na asambaddhāḥ iti asti niyamaḥ  na ca bhinna kālīna la
translated: Because all things that deposit impressions, such as campaka flowers, deposit them elsewhere, in oil, etc., only when connected with oil, etc.🔽There is a rule that they do not deposit them when unconnected.

analyzed: yoḥ sambandhaḥ yujyate
translated: And a relation between what is simultaneous is not reasonable.

analyzed: tasmāt pūrvaḥ tasmin uttare vāsanām na kuryāt iti
translated: Therefore, the previous one is connected with the subsequent one. One should not form a latent impression in that subsequent one.

analyzed: uktam artham buddhayā āroha artham saṅkalayya āha eka kālatayā iti
translated: In order to make the meaning stated easy to understand, he summarizes it, saying at one time, etc.

original: ekakālatayā yogaṃ vinā saṃskārataḥ katham // / / //🔽atraikakālatayā vinā kāryakāraṇayoryogo na yujyate /
analyzed: eka kālatayā yogam vinā saṃskārataḥ katham  atra eka kāla tayā vinā kārya kāraṇayoḥ yogaḥ na yujyate
translated: How can there be an impression from a cause without a connection at one time?🔽Here, a connection between cause and effect without being at one time is not tenable.

original: yogaṃ vinā kāraṇasya kārye saṃskārārpakatvaṃ ca na ghaṭate /
analyzed: yogam vinā kāraṇasya kārye saṃskāra arpaka tvam ca na ghaṭate
translated: Without a connection, it is not possible for a cause to impart an impression to an effect.

analyzed: saṃskārataḥ vinā katham anumāna ādi vyavahāraḥ iti adhyāhāreṇa yojanā
translated: The construction is by supplying the words how can there be the usage of inference, etc. without an impression?

analyzed: saṃskāra āparka tvam ca na ghaṭate
translated: And the remoteness of the impression is not possible.

analyzed: saṃskārataḥ vinā katham anumāna ādi vyavahāraḥ iti adhyāhāreṇa yojanā
translated: The construction is by supplying the words how can there be the usage of inference, etc. without an impression?

original: yadīdaṃ saṅkalanaṃ na kriyeta tadā pūrvoktahetūnāṃ
analyzed: yadi idam saṅkalanam na kriyeta tadā pūrva ukta hetūnām
translated: If this summary were not done, then the stated reasons

analyzed: ktānām pratyekam hetu tvam jñāyeta
translated: would be known as reasons for each one not imparting an impression.

analyzed: sarvatra sādhya nirdeśāt tatra kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: Since the conclusion is stated everywhere, what is the fault there?

analyzed: ukta ākāṅkṣā kuṇṭhita tvam eva iti
translated: It is only the obstruction of the desire stated.

analyzed: atra ete prayogāḥ
translated: Here are the arguments:

analyzed: pūrva kṣaṇe uttara kṣaṇe saṃskāra ādhāyakaḥ na bhavati
translated: The previous moment does not impart an impression to the subsequent moment.

analyzed: tena asaṃbaddha tvāt
translated: Because it is not related to that.

analyzed: yaḥ yena asambaddhaḥ na asau tatra saṃskāra ādhāyakaḥ
translated: That which is not related to something does not cause the production of that,

analyzed: yathā sampratipannaḥ
translated: like what is commonly accepted.

original: yadvā yo yatra saṃskārādhāyakaḥ sa tatsambaddha eva dṛṣṭo yathā sammataḥ /
analyzed: yat vā yaḥ yatra saṃskāra ādhāyakaḥ sa tad sambaddhaḥ eva dṛṣṭaḥ yathā sammataḥ
translated: Or, that which causes the production of something is seen to be related to that, like what is commonly accepted.

original: asambaddhasyāpi saṃskārādhāyakatve mṛgamado vasanamiva sarvaṃ vāsayedaviśeṣāt /
analyzed: asambaddhasya api saṃskāra ādhāyaka tve mṛgamadaḥ vasanam iva sarvam vāsayet aviśeṣāt
translated: If something unrelated could cause production, then like a scentless flower, everything would be perfumed, because there would be no difference.

analyzed: a sambaddhaḥ ca pūrvaḥ uttareṇa
translated: And the previous [moment] is unrelated to the subsequent [moment].

analyzed: tatas bhinna kālīna tvāt
translated: Because they exist at different times.

analyzed: sampratipanna vat
translated: Like what is commonly accepted.

analyzed: bhinna kālīnayoḥ api sambandhe tiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: If there were a relation between things existing at different times, there would be an absurd consequence.

analyzed: bhinna kālīnaḥ ca pūrvam uttareṇa
translated: And the previous [moment] is unrelated to the subsequent [moment].

analyzed: tad utpādaḥ eva vinaṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because it has already ceased at the time of the production of the subsequent [moment].

analyzed: saṃmata vat
translated: Like what is commonly accepted.

analyzed: prāk eva naṣṭasya tena eka kālīna tva śaṅkā eva vyāhatā iti
translated: The doubt that something that has already ceased could exist at the same time as that [subsequent moment] is itself refuted.

analyzed: nanu lākṣā rasa āhita bījapūra kusuma lauhitya vat kim na syāt iti ced na
translated: If it is asked, Why couldn't it be like the redness of a hibiscus flower mixed with lac juice?, no.

analyzed: tatra api niranvaya vināśa utpāda anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because even in that case, the destruction and production without remainder is not accepted.

original: atra ca parasiddhanyāyena parasya bodhanānnāśrayāsiddhayādi śaṅkanīyamiti / /
analyzed: atra ca para siddha nyāyena parasya bodhanāt na āśraya asiddhayā ādi śaṅkanīyam iti
translated: And here, because the other party is being made to understand by means of a principle accepted by them, the fallacy of the basis not being established and so on should not be suspected.

original: bhavedetadyadi kāraṇasya kāryotpāda eva vināśaḥ syāt /
analyzed: bhavet etat yadi kāraṇasya kārya utpādaḥ eva vināśaḥ syāt
translated: This would be so if the destruction of the cause were only the production of the effect.

original: sa eva kutaḥ siddha ityata āha kṣaṇamātramiti //
analyzed: saḥ eva kutas siddhaḥ iti atas āha kṣaṇa mātram iti
translated: How is that itself established? Therefore he says for a mere moment.

analyzed: kṣaṇa mātram avasthānam svīkṛtam sarva vastuṣu
translated: It is accepted that all things remain for a mere moment.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇayoḥ tāvat uttara pūrva tvam āvaśyakam
translated: The later and earlier states of cause and effect are necessarily so.

analyzed: yaugapadye
translated: Because if they were simultaneous, there would be a contradiction with the relation of cause and effect.

original: tataḥ pūrvakṣaṇavarti kāraṇaṃ yadi kāyarkṣaṇe 'pi syāttadā sarvavastūnāmaṅgīkṛtaṃ kṣaṇamātramavasthānaṃ bhajyeta /
analyzed: tatas pūrva kṣaṇa varti kāraṇam yadi syāt tadā sarva vastūnām aṅgīkṛtam kṣaṇa mātram avasthānam bhajyeta
translated: Therefore, if the cause existing in the earlier moment were to exist in the moment of the effect as well, then the accepted mere momentary existence of all things would be destroyed.

original: ataḥ kṣaṇikatvābhyupagama evottarotpāde ca pūrvanirodhaṃ gamayatīti /
analyzed: atas kṣaṇika tva abhyupagamaḥ eva uttara utpāde ca pūrva nirodham gamayati iti
translated: Therefore, the acceptance of momentariness itself implies the cessation of the previous [moment] in the arising of the subsequent [moment].

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be so.

original: kāraṇaṃ kṣaṇasya pūrvavibhāge labdhasattākaṃ madhyavibhāge kāryamutpādyāparavibhāge tatra saṃskāramādhāya naśyatītyaṅgīkāre na ko 'pi doṣa
analyzed: kāraṇam kṣaṇasya pūrva vibhāge labdha sattākam madhya vibhāge kāryam utpādya apara vibhāge tatra saṃskāram ādhāya naśyati iti aṅgīkāre na kaḥ pi doṣa
translated: If it is accepted that the cause, having attained existence in the earlier part of the moment, produces the effect in the middle part, and having imparted modification to it in the later part, perishes, then there is no fault at all.

analyzed: iti atas āha pūrvā iti
translated: Therefore he says earlier and so on.

analyzed: pūrva madhya apara kalā rahitaḥ kṣaṇaḥ iṣyate
translated: The moment is accepted as devoid of earlier, middle, and later parts.

analyzed: atra vibhāga mātram kalā ucyate
translated: Here, the part is called the moment.

analyzed: pūrva aparayoḥ abhāve tad nirūpya madhya abhāvaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: When there is no before and after, the absence of that which is to be determined in the middle is established.

analyzed: iṣyate saugataiḥ
translated: It is accepted by the Buddhists.

original: evaṃ tarkasya pratitarkaparāhatimabhidhāyedānīṃ yathā sthāyinaḥ sattvānupapattirevaṃ
analyzed: evam tarkasya pratitarka parāhatim abhidhāya idānīm yathā sthāyinaḥ sattva anupapattiḥ evam
translated: Thus, having stated that reasoning is refuted by a counter-reasoning, now in order to demonstrate that just as the existence of a permanent thing is not possible,

original: kṣaṇikasyāpi tadanupapatteranukūlatā nāma tarkadoṣa iti pratipādayituṃ sūtram oṃ
analyzed: kṣaṇikasya api tad anupapatteḥ anukūla tā nāma tarka doṣaḥ iti pratipādayitum sūtram om
translated: so the non-possibility of that [existence] for a momentary thing is also a fault of reasoning called unfavorable, in order to teach that, the aphorism is [stated]:

analyzed: asati pratijñā uparodhaḥ yaugapadyam anyathā om
translated: If it does not exist, there is contradiction with the thesis, simultaneity in another way.

analyzed: iti  tat vayācakṣāṇaḥ tāvat vikalpena tat pṛcchati pūrvā iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: asati pratijñā uparodhaḥ yaugapadyam anyathā
translated: Explaining that, he first asks about it with an option: If it does not exist, there is contradiction with the thesis, simultaneity in another way.

analyzed: pūrva bhāva bhavam kāryam uta tad nāśa sambhavam
translated: The effect arises from the previous existence, or is it possible from its destruction?

analyzed: arthakriyā kāri tvam hi sattvam parasya abhimatam
translated: For the other [school], the existence of an object is accepted as the performance of an effect.

analyzed: tat ca vakṣyamāṇavi
translated: And that is pervaded by the two options that will be stated.

analyzed: tṛtīya prakāra a nirūpaṇāt
translated: Because a third type is not determined.

analyzed: na ca tat kṣaṇike sambhavati
translated: And that is not possible for a momentary [thing].

original: tathāhi kṣaṇikādbhāvādbhavatkāryaṃ kiṃ pūrvasya kāraṇasya bhāve bhavati /
analyzed: tathā hi kṣaṇikāt bhāvāt bhavat kāryam kim pūrvasya kāraṇasya bhāve bhavati
translated: Thus, the effect that arises from a momentary thing, does it arise when the previous cause exists?

analyzed: kāraṇa sattā samāna kālīna sattam iti yāvat
translated: It means that its existence is simultaneous with the existence of the cause.

original: uta tasya kāraṇasya nāśe sati sambhavatīti / /
analyzed: uta tasya kāraṇasya nāśe sati sambhavati iti
translated: And it is possible when that cause is destroyed.

analyzed: ādye doṣam āha yaugapadyam iti
translated: In the first case, he states the fault: simultaneity, etc.

analyzed: yaugapadyam sati bhavet utpādyānām aśeṣatas  sati kāraṇe
translated: Simultaneity would be possible if all that is to be produced exists.🔽If the effect exists when the cause exists.

analyzed: kāryam bhavati ced tarhi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: if it is so.

analyzed: kṣaṇikam hi kāraṇam
translated: For the cause is momentary.

original: kāryaṃ ca tatsattāsamānakālīnasattaṃ cetkāryakāraṇayoḥ sahotpāda ityuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: kāryam ca tad sattā samāna kālīna sattam ced kārya kāraṇayoḥ sahotpādaḥ iti uktam syāt
translated: And if the effect exists at the same time as its existence, it would be said that the effect and cause arise together.

original: kṣaṇe vibhāgābhāvasyoktatvāt tattatkāryāṇāmapyayameva nyāya iti tatsantānabhāvināpya
analyzed: kṣaṇe vibhāga abhāvasya ukta tvāt tad tad kāryāṇām api ayam eva nyāyaḥ iti tad santāna bhāvinā api a
translated: Since the absence of division in a moment has been stated, this is the same reasoning for each effect. Therefore, even for those that occur in its continuum,

analyzed: ma śeṣa kāryāṇām yaugapadyam syāt
translated: the simultaneity of all effects would occur.

analyzed: tat ca pratyakṣa ādi viruddham iti
translated: And that is contradicted by perception, etc.

analyzed: atra yadi api yugapad bhavatoḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva anupapattiḥ api dūṣaṇam
translated: Here, although the impossibility of the relation of cause and effect for what occurs simultaneously is also a fault,

analyzed: tathā api tad śiṣyaiḥ eva jñātum śakyate iti
translated: nevertheless, that can be known by the disciples alone.

analyzed: ubhayathā ca doṣāt
translated: And because there is a fault in both ways,

analyzed: iti sūtre kathitam iti vācā atra na uktam
translated: it is stated in the sutra ubhayathā ca doṣāt, but is not stated here in words.

original: dvitīyaṃ nirākaroti vināśe cediti //🔽vināśe cenna tatkāryaṃ / / / // / / //
analyzed: dvitīyam nirākaroti vināśe ced iti  vināśe ced na tat kāryam
translated: He refutes the second by saying if it is in destruction, etc.🔽If it is in destruction, then that is not its effect.

analyzed: kāraṇasya kāryam bhavet tarhi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is: then the effect of the cause would be.

analyzed: tat tasya kāryam na bhavati iti āpannam
translated: It follows that it is not the effect of that [cause].

analyzed: anyathā sarvasya sarvam kāryam syāt
translated: Otherwise, everything would be the effect of everything.

analyzed: na hi ānantarya mātreṇa kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: For the relation of cause and effect is not merely based on immediate sequence.

analyzed: tathātve vināśa kārya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were so, destruction would be the effect [of the cause].

analyzed: ānantaryasya anya apekṣayā api sattvāt
translated: Because immediate sequence exists even in relation to something else.

analyzed: sādeśya ādeḥ apākṛta tvāt
translated: Because co-existence, etc. have been refuted.

original: evamanyasyāpi kāryaṃ na bhavatīti na kāryaṃ syādakāraṇaṃ vā /
analyzed: evam anyasya api kāryam na bhavati iti na kāryam syāt akāraṇam vā
translated: In the same way, it would not be the effect of anything else either, so it would not be an effect or it would be without a cause.

analyzed: ubhayathā api pūrvasya arthakriyā virahāt asattva prāptiḥ iti
translated: In both cases, because the previous [moment] is devoid of activity, it follows that it does not exist.

analyzed: sūtrakṛtā saugata abhyupagatam pakṣam pradhānīkṛtya dūṣaṇam uktam
translated: The author of the treatise stated the refutation, making the Sautrāntika's accepted position primary.

analyzed: bhāṣyakṛtā tu abhāvasya bhāva sāpekṣa tvāt tena krameṇa atas rtha virodha abhāvaḥ
translated: But the author of the commentary said that because non-existence depends on existence, there is no contradiction in meaning in that order.

analyzed: nanu asti tāvat pratikṣaṇam kārya utpattiḥ
translated: But isn't there indeed the arising of an effect every moment?

analyzed: na ca kāryam kāraṇena vinā utpattum alam
translated: And an effect cannot arise without a cause.

analyzed: tathā sati nityam sattvam asattvam vā ica iti āpatteḥ
translated: Because if it were so, it would follow that it is either eternally existent or non-existent.

analyzed: atas kārya utpattiḥ eva anyatara pakṣa doṣam ābhāsayiṣyati
translated: Therefore, the arising of an effect will only reveal the fault of one of the two positions,

original: pakṣāntaraṃ vā grāhayiṣyatītyata āha kāryotpattau ceti //
analyzed: pakṣa antaram vā grāhayiṣyati iti atas āha kārya utpattau ca iti
translated: or it will make one accept another position. Thus he says If there is the arising of an effect...

analyzed: kārya utpattau ca kā pramā
translated: And what is the evidence for the production of effects?

analyzed: syāt etat yadi pratikṣaṇam kārya utpattiḥ pramāṇavatī syāt
translated: This may be said: if the production of effects moment by moment were established by evidence,

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: but this is not the case.

analyzed: na ca sva aṅgīkāra mātreṇa artha antara ākṣepa sāmarthyam atiprasaṅgāt iti
translated: And by merely accepting one's own position, one cannot project another meaning, due to overextension.

analyzed: nanu asti yat sat tat kṣaṇikam yathā deha ādi
translated: But there is [evidence], because what exists is momentary, like the body and so on.

original: sacca vivādapadamiti pratikṣaṇaṃ kāryotpattau pramāṇamiti cenna /
analyzed: sat ca vivāda padam iti pratikṣaṇam kārya utpattau pramāṇam iti ced na
translated: And the subject of dispute exists, so there is evidence for the production of effects moment by moment. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: asya eva nirākriyamāṇa tvāt  deha ādīnām adeha
translated: Because this [argument] is being refuted.

analyzed: pi kṣaṇika tva abhāvena dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vikala tvāt ca
translated: Because the body and so on are not momentary, the example lacks the property to be proven.

original: nanu dehādeḥ pūrvottarakṣaṇayoḥ parimāṇabhedena bhedasiddhau kṣaṇikatvasiddhirityuktamityasya āha abhede 'pīti //
analyzed: nanu deha ādeḥ pūrva uttara kṣaṇayoḥ parimāṇa bhedena bheda siddhau kṣaṇika tva siddhiḥ iti uktam iti asya āha abhede pi iti
translated: But it was said that the momentariness is established by the difference in size between the body and so on in the previous and subsequent moments. To this he says even without difference.

analyzed: abhedena viśeṣeṇa deha dīpa phala ādiṣu
translated: Even without difference, the difference in size of the body, lamp, fruit, and so on,

analyzed: viśeṣa darśanam yuktam asmākam  pūrva uttara kṣaṇayoḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: the perception of difference is proper for us.🔽The remainder is in the previous and subsequent moments.

analyzed: viśeṣeṇa ārambha vāda dvailakṣaṇyena
translated: With difference, meaning with the difference from the beginningless doctrine.

analyzed: ādi padena aṅkura ādi
translated: The word and so on includes sprouts and so on.

analyzed: viśeṣa darśanam parimāṇa bheda darśanam
translated: The perception of difference is the perception of difference in size.

analyzed: asmākam pariṇāma vādinām mate
translated: In our view, which is that of the proponents of evolution.

analyzed: ayam atharḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: ārambha vādinaḥ hi parimāṇam yāvaddravyabhāvi abhyupayanti  avayava saṅkhaya atiśaya anatiśaya āyatta tvāt parimāṇa bhedasya
translated: For the proponents of origination accept that size exists as long as the substance exists.🔽Because the difference in size depends on the excess or non-excess of the number of parts.

analyzed: avayava apacaye dravya vināśasya avayava upacaye ca tad utpādasya avarjanīya tvāt
translated: Because when the parts are reduced, the destruction of the substance is inevitable, and when the parts are increased, its production is inevitable.

original: atasteṣāṃ parimāṇabhedo dravyaṃ bhindyādeva /🔽asmākaṃ tvavasthitameva dravyamavayavopacayāpacayābhyāṃ tatta
analyzed: atas teṣām parimāṇa bhedaḥ dravyam bhindyāt eva  asmākam tu avasthitam eva dravyam avayava upacaya apacayābhyām tat te
translated: Therefore, for them, the difference in size would indeed divide the substance.

analyzed: t parimāṇaka tayā vikriyate iti darśanam
translated: But for us, the substance remains as it is, and it is seen to be modified by having such and such size through the increase and decrease of parts.

analyzed: tatra parimāṇa bhedaḥ na bhedam ākṣipati iti
translated: In that case, the difference in size does not imply difference.

analyzed: kiñca phala ādīnām pūrva uttara kṣaṇayoḥ bhedaḥ sādhyate
translated: Moreover, the difference between the earlier and later moments of the fruit etc. is to be proved.

analyzed: uta abheda abhāvaḥ
translated: Or the absence of non-difference.

analyzed: ādye siddhasādhanam
translated: In the first case, it is the establishment of what is already established.

analyzed: bhedasya asmābhiḥ api aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because difference is accepted by us also.

analyzed: tāvatā kṣaṇabhaṅga asiddheḥ
translated: To that extent, momentariness is not established.

analyzed: dvitīye doṣam āha anubhūtitaḥ iti
translated: In the second case, he states the fault with from experience etc.

analyzed: anubhūtitaḥ
translated: From experience...

original: viśeṣadarśanaṃ mānaṃ yadi na sthairyadṛk kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: viśeṣa darśanam mānam yadi na sthairya dṛś kutas
translated: If the perception of difference is valid, then why is the perception of permanence not valid?

analyzed: tat idam phalam iti pratyabhijñayā pūrva uttara kṣaṇayoḥ abheda siddheḥ bādhita viṣayam anumānam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: inference has an contradicted object, because the non-difference of the preceding and succeeding moments is established by the recognition that this is the same effect.

analyzed: bhrāntā pratyabhijñā nā abhedam sādhayitum alam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that recognition is mistaken and cannot establish non-difference,

original: tarhi bhrāntaṃ parimāṇabhedadarśanaṃ na bhedasādhanāyālamiti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: tarhi bhrāntam parimāṇa bheda darśanam na bheda sādhanāya alam iti brūmaḥ
translated: then we say that the mistaken perception of difference in size cannot establish difference.

analyzed: parimāṇa bheda darśanam bādhaka abhāvāt pramāṇam eva iti ced tatra āha viśeṣa iti
translated: If it is argued that the perception of difference in size is a valid cognition because there is no contradiction, then there he says special etc.

analyzed: tarhi sthairya dṛś kutas na mānam
translated: Then why is the perception of permanence not a valid cognition?

analyzed: tasyāḥ api bādhaka rahita tvāt
translated: Because that also is free from contradiction.

analyzed: viśeṣa darśanam bādhakam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the perception of difference is the contradiction,

analyzed: tarhi sthairya darśanam kutas na bādhakam
translated: then why is the perception of permanence not the contradiction?

analyzed: a taḥ n upalabhyamāna viśeṣayoḥ anayoḥ
translated: Therefore, since these two are not perceived to be different,

analyzed: bādhya bādhaka bhāva ayogāt anyonya pratipakṣatā ananubhavāt ca anyatara pakṣapātam parityajya bheda abheda viṣaya tayā eva vyavasthāpanam yuktam
translated: it is proper to establish them as having the nature of difference and non-difference, abandoning partiality towards either, because of the impossibility of the relation of contradicted and contradictor and because of the non-experience of mutual opposition.

original: anyathā dṛṣṭānte sādhyasandehenāpi parānumānaṃ duṣyaṃ syāditi /
analyzed: anyathā dṛṣṭānte sādhya sandehena api para anumānam duṣyam syāt iti
translated: Otherwise, even in the example, the inference for others would be faulty due to doubt regarding the probandum.

original: evaṃ tarkāṅgāntaravaikalyaṃ svayamūhanīyam / /🔽nanvetāni sūtrāṇi kuto vyutkrameṇamato
analyzed: evam tarka aṅga antara vaikalyam svayam ūhanīyam  nanu etāni sūtrāṇi kutas
translated: Thus the deficiency of other parts of reasoning should be understood by oneself.

analyzed: vyākhyātāni
translated: But from where are these aphorisms explained in reverse order?

original: ucyate /🔽upodghātaprakriyayā sūtrakāreṇaivādau bādhakāni nirākṛtyānte niṣkaṇṭakā pratyabhijñopanyastā /
analyzed: ucyate  upodghāta prakriyayā sūtrakāreṇa eva ādau bādhakāni nirākṛtya ante niṣkaṇṭakā pratyabhijñā upanyastā
translated: It is said.🔽By the method of introduction, the author of the aphorisms himself first refuted the objections and finally presented the non-obstructed recognition.

original: bhāṣyakāreṇa tu subodhatvāya śiṣyākāṅkṣākrameṇādau pratyabhijñāmabhidhāyānantaraṃ tadbādhakāni parihṛtānīti / /
analyzed: bhāṣyakāreṇa tu su bodha tvāya śiṣya ākāṅkṣā krameṇa ādau pratyabhijñām abhidhāya anantaram tad bādhakāni parihṛtāni iti
translated: But the author of the commentary, for the sake of easy understanding, first mentioned recognition according to the desire of the disciples and then later refuted the objections against it.

original: duḥkhābhāvaṃ sukhaṃ cāhuriti yadanūditaṃ tannirākaroti digiti //🔽diksukhe ca khadṛṣṭāntād bhāvau saccet kvacid bhaved // / / //
analyzed: duḥkha abhāvam sukham ca āhuḥ iti yat anūditam tat nirākaroti diś iti  diś sukhe ca kha dṛṣṭāntāt bhāvau sat ced kvacid bhavet
translated: He refutes the statement They say that the absence of suffering is happiness with the word direction.🔽And in the case of directional happiness, if existence is somewhere, it would be due to the example of space.

analyzed: sva dṛṣṭāntāt iti ākāśasya bhāva tve yaḥ nyāyaḥ bhihitaḥ tasmāt iti hetvatideśaḥ
translated: The inference is that the reason is stated by the method stated in the case of the existence of space.

analyzed: dharmi pratiyogi nirapekṣam eva vidhi rūpeṇa pratīyamāna tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is cognized as an injunction independent of the subject and the counter-correlate.

analyzed: sadbhāvaḥ kvacid bhavet ced tad dṛṣṭāntena iti śeṣaḥ
translated: If existence would be somewhere, it would be due to that example. This is the remainder.

original: anenānyathā rūpādināmapi bhāvatvaṃ na syādaviśeṣāditi bādhakaṃ sūcayati /
analyzed: anena anyathā rūpa ādinām api bhāva tvam na syāt aviśeṣāt iti bādhakam sūcayati
translated: By this, he indicates the objection that otherwise, form etc. would also not be existent due to lack of distinction.

analyzed: yadi api diśaḥ na ākāśāt bhidyante
translated: Although the directions are not different from space,

analyzed: tathā api ākāśasya bhāga sadbhāvam jñāpayitum tāsām grahaṇam
translated: nevertheless, in order to indicate that space has parts, they are mentioned.

analyzed: ekavacanam tu jāti abhiprāyam
translated: But the singular number is intended to refer to the class.

original: etenākāśe cāviśeṣāditi sūtraṃ prakārāntareṇa vyākhyātaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: etena ākāśe ca aviśeṣāt iti sūtram prakāra antareṇa vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: By this, the sūtra And because there is no distinction in space is explained in a different way.

analyzed: ākāśa ādīnām bhāva tva samarthanena pañca skandha ātmakam viśvam iti nirastam
translated: By establishing that space and so on are real, the view that the universe consists of five aggregates is refuted.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ jñāna ātmaka tvam tu na asmākam aniṣyam viruddham
translated: But the self being of the nature of knowledge is not undesirable or contradictory for us.

analyzed: kṣaṇabhaṅgi tāyāḥ nirasta tvāt
translated: Because momentariness has been refuted.

analyzed: jñānasya api grāhaka tāyāḥ pareṇa abhyupagata tvāt
translated: And because the opponent accepts that knowledge also has the nature of the apprehender.

analyzed: mokṣaḥ tu caturthe parīkṣiṣyate
translated: But liberation will be examined in the fourth chapter.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: vaibhāṣikasautrāntikayoryaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ svamataviruddhaḥ siddhāntaḥ sa eva nirākṛtaḥ /
analyzed: vaibhāṣika sautrāntikayoḥ yaḥ sādhāraṇaḥ sva mata viruddhaḥ siddhāntaḥ saḥ eva nirākṛtaḥ
translated: The common doctrine of the Vaibhāṣikas and Sautrāntikas, which is contrary to their own opinion, has been refuted.

analyzed: yaḥ tu sautrāntikasya siddhānta viśeṣaḥ pramāṇam tāvat vividham
translated: But the specific doctrine of the Sautrāntikas is as follows: First, there are two kinds of valid cognition.

analyzed: prameya dvaividhyāt
translated: Because the objects of knowledge are twofold.

original: tatra jñānātiriktaḥ sarve 'pi rūpādiprapañco 'numeya eva na tu pratyakṣaḥ /
analyzed: tatra jñāna atiriktaḥ sarve rūpa ādi prapañcaḥ nu meyaḥ eva na tu pratyakṣaḥ
translated: Among them, all the manifold things such as form, etc., which are beyond knowledge, are only inferable, not perceptible.

original: jñānaṃ tu nīlādyākāraṃ pratyakṣavedyam' / iti /🔽sa kasmānna nirākṛta ityata āha viśvamiti //
analyzed: jñānam tu nīla ādi ākāram pratyakṣa vedyam iti  sa kasmāt na nirākṛtaḥ iti atas āha viśvam iti
translated: But knowledge has the form of blue, etc., and is directly perceptible.🔽Why is he not refuted? To this he says the entire (universe), etc.

analyzed: viśvam pratyakṣa gam tyaktavā tayoḥ yaḥ vadet
translated: He who, abandoning the entire (universe) which is directly perceptible, would say that it is inferred by those two,

analyzed: māyā vādi vat eva asau upekṣyaḥ bhūtim icchatā
translated: should be disregarded by one who desires prosperity, just like the proponent of illusion.

original: tayoḥ vaibhāṣikasautrāntikayormadhye yaḥ sautrāntiko viśvaṃ rūpādikaṃ pratyakṣagaṃ tyaktvā rūpāderviśvasya pratyakṣavedyatāṃ vaibhāṣikādibhirabhyupagatāmanabhyupagamyeti 🔽yāvat /
analyzed: tayoḥ vaibhāṣika sautrāntikayoḥ madhye yaḥ sautrāntikaḥ viśvam rūpa ādikam pratyakṣa gam tyaktvā rūpa ādeḥ viśvasya pratyakṣa vedya tām vaibhāṣika ādibhiḥ abhyupagatām an abhyupagamya iti  yāvat
translated: Among those two, the Vaibhāṣika and the Sautrāntika, the Sautrāntika who abandons the entire (universe) such as form which is directly perceptible, not accepting the fact that form and the entire (universe) are directly perceptible as accepted by the Vaibhāṣikas and others,

analyzed: anumitam vadet rūpa ādeḥ viśvasya anumāna vedya tām aṅgīkuryāt
translated: up to (the Sautrāntika) who would say that the entire (universe) such as form is inferred, who would accept that form and the entire (universe) are known by inference.

analyzed: māyā vādinā tulyam vartate iti māyā vādi vat
translated: He behaves like the proponent of illusion, therefore like the proponent of illusion.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: yathā sarvān duḥsamayān apākurvatā api
translated: Just as the author of the aphorisms, even though not refuting all the doctrines of the Samkhya,

analyzed: sūtrakṛtā na māyā vādaḥ tra pāde nirākṛtaḥ
translated: did not refute the doctrine of illusion in this chapter.

analyzed: tasya atyanta nirdalasya upekṣā eva kāryā
translated: That (doctrine) which is extremely subtle should be disregarded.

original: na tvīṣatsadalaiḥ sāṅkhayādisamayaiḥ saha nirāsa iti jñāpanārtham /
analyzed: na tu īṣat sa dalaiḥ sāṅkhaya ādi samayaiḥ saha nirāsaḥ iti jñāpana artham
translated: It is not that it should be refuted along with the doctrines of the Samkhya and others which are slightly less subtle. This is to make it known.

analyzed: tathā bāhya anumeya tā vādaḥ pi iti
translated: Similarly, the doctrine that (the external world) is inferred (by the internal cognition) should also be (disregarded).

analyzed: nanu māyā vādaḥ sūtra utpatti uttara kāla bhāvī
translated: But the doctrine of illusion is later than the origin of the sutra.

analyzed: tasya katham nirāsa prasaktiḥ
translated: How can it be refuted?

analyzed: mā evam  anādi kālataḥ vṛttāḥ
translated: Not so.

analyzed: iti akta tvāt
translated: Because it is said to have been current from beginningless time.

analyzed: anyathā sāṅkhaya ādi nirāsasya api aprasakteḥ iti
translated: Otherwise, the refutation of Sankhya and others would also be irrelevant.

analyzed: vyāsa
translated: Vyasa.

original: nanvapratiṣiddhamanumānaṃ bhavatīti nyāyena nīlāderviśvasyāpratyakṣatvaṃ sūtrakārasyābhimatameveti kuto na kalpyate /
analyzed: nanu apratiṣiddham anumānam bhavati iti nyāyena nīla ādeḥ viśvasya apratyakṣa tvam sūtrakārasya abhimatam eva iti kutas na kalpyate
translated: But by the rule that inference is valid unless contradicted, it is only the view of the author of the sutra that the universe beginning with blue is not perceptible, so why is that not assumed?

analyzed: na evam na ca evam śakyam
translated: It cannot be so, nor is it possible in this way.

analyzed: pramāṇa aviruddhaḥ pramāṇa anusārī ca sūtrakārasya abhiprāyaḥ kalpanīyaḥ
translated: The intention of the author of the sutra should be assumed to be in accordance with valid means of knowledge, not contradicting them.

analyzed: na ca ayam arthaḥ tathā iti āśavān āha sarva iti  sarva pramāṇa siddham yat buddheḥ bhedena sarvadā
translated: And this meaning is not so, thinking this, he says 'all' etc.🔽How can that which is always established by all means of knowledge as different from cognition,

analyzed: katham nu tasya buddhi tvam
translated: be said to be cognition?

analyzed: ayam atra uttara kramaḥ
translated: The sequence of the answer here is this.

analyzed: nīla ādeḥ arthasya apratyakṣa tvam na vaktum śakyate  nīla ādi pratīteḥ aparokṣa tāyāḥ sākṣi siddha tvāt
translated: The fact that the object beginning with blue is not perceptible cannot be said.🔽Because the non-obstruction of the cognition of blue etc. is established by the witness,

analyzed: indriya vyāpāra bhāva bhāvi tvena anumāna siddha tvāt ca
translated: and because it is established by inference as being due to the presence or absence of the operation of the sense organs.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought,

original: yenārthena yajjñānaṃ jāyate tat tadākāraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yena arthena yat jñānam jāyate tat tad ākāram bhavati
translated: The knowledge arises in the form of that object by which it is caused.

original: tacca jñānaṃ svaprakāśatayā svagataṃ nīlādyākāramapi sākṣātkurute /
analyzed: tat ca jñānam sva prakāśa tayā svagatam nīla ādi ākāram api sākṣātkurute
translated: And that knowledge, being self-luminous, directly experiences the form of blue, etc. that is present in itself.

analyzed: parokṣa tayā upalabhyamānasya nīla ādi ākāra nikarasya buddhi gata tvāt na kaścid doṣaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, since the multitude of forms such as blue, etc. that are perceived as non-concealed, are present in the cognition, there is no fault at all.

analyzed: atra idam upatiṣṭhate
translated: To this, the following is stated:

analyzed: yat aparokṣa tayā avabhāsamānam nīla ādi ākāra cakram buddheḥ bhedena sarvadā sarva pramāṇa siddham
translated: That multitude of forms such as blue, etc. that appear as non-concealed, which is always established by all means of valid knowledge as different from cognition,

analyzed: tasya katham nu buddhi tvam aṅgīkriyate
translated: how can its being cognition be accepted?

analyzed: bahis mukha tayā idantena hi ayam parokṣam avabhāsate
translated: For this multitude of forms such as blue, etc. appears as non-concealed externally,

analyzed: na jātu antarmukha tayā aham nīlam iti
translated: never internally as I am blue.

analyzed: śūnyasya eva

analyzed: saṃvriyate naya iti saṃvṛtiḥ avidyā

analyzed: śūnya avidyā kalpita tvāt akhilam śūnyam iti ucyate

analyzed: sāṃvṛtam satya tvam iṣyate na sat pratyaya virodhaḥ

analyzed: pāramārthika sattvam tu śūnyāt anyasya na kvacid

analyzed: sarvathā abādhya tvam

analyzed: ttvam tad abhāvāt asat idam jagat udgīyate iti

analyzed: sāṃvṛtena eva satyena khilaḥ bhavet

analyzed: akhilaḥ hāna upādāna upekṣā abhijñā abhivādana artha kriyā lakṣaṇaḥ

analyzed: pāramārthika sattvam eva vyavahāra virodhi

analyzed: tasya sarva kriyā rahita tvāt
translated: Because it is devoid of all activity.

original: natu tadabhāva iti bhāvenoktam sāṃvṛtenaiva sattveneti // /
analyzed: na tu tad abhāvaḥ iti bhāvena uktam sāṃvṛtena eva sattvena iti
translated: But not in the absence of that. With this in mind, it is said: by mere conventional existence.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi pralaya viṣayam
translated: It shows the disagreement regarding creation and dissolution,

analyzed: ye vigānam darśayati śūnyāt iti
translated: saying from the Void and so on.

analyzed: śūnyāt saṃvṛti yogena viśvam etat pravartate
translated: This universe proceeds from the Void through conventional connection.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi kāle punar ca ante stimitam śūnya tām vrajet
translated: And again at the end of creation, it would become still and return to the Void.

analyzed: iti brūte  /
translated: Thus it is said.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi kāle pravartata jāyate
translated: At the time of creation, it proceeds, it is born.

analyzed: śūnyasya niṣkriya tvāt katham viśva kartṛ tvam iti atas uktam saṃvṛti yogena iti
translated: Since the Void is inactive, how can it be the creator of the universe? Therefore it is said: through conventional connection.

analyzed: ante pralaya kāle
