translated: At the end, at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: stimitam niṣkriyam
translated: Still, inactive.

original: anena kriyāvibhāgādinyāyena yā viśvasya satyatvavādināṃ pralayaprakriyā sā nirākriyate /
analyzed: anena kriyā vibhāga ādi nyāyena yā viśvasya satya tva vādinām pralaya prakriyā sā nirākriyate
translated: By this, the procedure of dissolution of the universe, as stated by the proponents of the reality of the universe, is refuted, using the principle of the division of action.

analyzed: svāpna gaja ādiḥ iva iti śeṣaḥ
translated: As if a dream elephant and so on. This is the remainder.

analyzed: evam upanyasta mata nirāsa athartvena adhikaraṇam avatārayati tam uddiśya iti
translated: Having thus presented the doctrine to be refuted, he introduces the section with the words with reference to him and so on.

analyzed: tam uddiśya jagāda jagatām guruḥ
translated: With reference to him, the teacher of the worlds said...

original: yattāvaduktaṃ śūnyādevedaṃ jagadutpadyata iti tadyathāśrutamapākartuṃ sūtram oṃ nāsato 'dṛṣṭatvāt oṃ iti /
analyzed: yat tāvat uktam śūnyāt eva idam jagat utpadyate iti tat yathāśrutam apākartum sūtram om na asataḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt om iti
translated: As for what was said that this universe originates from the Void alone, in order to refute that as literally stated, the aphorism begins: Not from the non-existent, because it is not seen.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe na asataḥ iti
translated: He explains that with not from non-existence.

analyzed: na asataḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because non-existence is not seen.

analyzed: second time
translated: For the second time.

analyzed: na asataḥ jagataḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: The existence of the non-existent world is not possible.

original: asataḥ sarvaviśeṣanirmuktatvena gaganakusumasamānācchūnyājjagato bhāvo janma nopapadyate /
analyzed: asataḥ sarva viśeṣa nirmukta tvena gagana kusuma samānāt śūnyāt jagataḥ bhāvaḥ janma na upapadyate
translated: The existence, i.e., origination, of the world from non-existence, which is devoid of all distinctions, like a sky-flower, is not possible.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha na hi iti
translated: Why? To this he says not etc.

analyzed: nahi dṛṣṭā asataḥ janiḥ
translated: The origination of the non-existent is not seen.

analyzed: sataḥ kvacid
translated: Of the existent somewhere.

analyzed: sataḥ bhavataḥ kāryasya iti yāvat
translated: Of the existent, i.e., of the effect.

analyzed: kvacid
translated: Somewhere.

original: asato janirna dṛṣṭā yataḥ /🔽atra sarvatra śūnyasyāsattvamāpādya
analyzed: asataḥ janiḥ na dṛṣṭā yatas  atra sarvatra śūnyasya asattvam āpādya
translated: Because the origination of the non-existent is not seen.🔽Here, in all cases, it should be understood that the non-existence of the void is assumed

analyzed: dūṣaṇa abhidhānam iti jñātavyam
translated: and the objection is stated.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvaḥ prameya abhāvam sādhayati
translated: The absence of a means of knowledge establishes the absence of an object of knowledge.

analyzed: na punar pramāṇa viśeṣa abhāvaḥ
translated: But not the absence of a particular means of knowledge.

analyzed: mā hi bhūt asmat ādi pratyakṣa vyāvṛttyā dharma ādi abhāva siddhiḥ
translated: For let there not be the establishment of the non-existence of dharma etc. by the exclusion of our own perception.

analyzed: tat atra api pramāṇa abhāvāt iti hetuḥ vaktavyaḥ
translated: There also, the reason because of the absence of a means of knowledge should be stated.

analyzed: a dṛṣṭa tvāt iti
translated: Because of non-apprehension.

analyzed: pratyakṣa abhāva kathanam tu katham
translated: But how can the absence of perception be stated?

analyzed: anaikāntika tvāt iti atas āha pramāṇam ca iti
translated: It is said: If it is a means of knowledge etc.

analyzed: pramāṇam ca dṛṣṭiḥ eva akhilāt varam
translated: And perception is the best means of knowledge of all.

original: dṛṣṭiḥ pratyakṣameva akhilāt anumānādagamācca varaṃ pramāṇam /
analyzed: dṛṣṭiḥ pratyakṣam eva akhilāt anumānāt agamāt ca varam pramāṇam
translated: Perception is direct perception, and it is the best means of knowledge of all, of inference and scripture.

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention.

original: nāsato jagato bhāva iti pratijñāya kuta ityākāṅkṣāyāṃ tatra pramāṇābhāvāditi hetuṃ
analyzed: na asataḥ jagataḥ bhāvaḥ iti pratijñāya kutas iti ākāṅkṣāyām tatra pramāṇa abhāvāt iti hetum
translated: Having declared that the non-existent world does not exist, when there is a desire to know the reason, the reason because there is no means of knowledge there

original: manasi nidhāya kataṃ tatra pramāṇābhāva iti jijñāsāyāmanumānāgamayoḥ pratyakṣamūlatvena
analyzed: manasi nidhāya katam tatra pramāṇa abhāvaḥ iti jijñāsāyām anumāna āgamayoḥ pratyakṣa mūla tvena
translated: is kept in mind, and when there is a desire to know how there is no means of knowledge there, inference and scripture are the root of direct perception,

analyzed: tatas pratyakṣam eva varam pramāṇam iti
translated: so direct perception alone is the best means of knowledge.

original: ādāvadṛṣṭatvāditi tadabhāvo 'yaṃ darśito natu pradhānapratijñāyāṃ hetutvena /
analyzed: ādau adṛṣṭa tvāt iti tad abhāvaḥ yam darśitaḥ na tu pradhāna pratijñāyām hetu tvena
translated: The absence of that is shown here as because it is not seen in the beginning, but not as a reason in the principal proposition,

analyzed: yena ukta doṣaḥ syāt iti
translated: so that the stated fault would not occur.

analyzed: tarhi anumāna ādi abhāvaḥ pi
translated: Then the absence of inference etc.

analyzed: vaktavyaḥ iti atas āha pramāṇam ca iti
translated: should also be stated. Therefore he says means of knowledge etc.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ
translated: This is the intention.

analyzed: veda ādeḥ śūnyavādinā prāmāṇyam na aṅgīkriyate
translated: The validity of the Veda etc. is not accepted by the proponent of emptiness.

original: tadīyāgamasya tvasmābhirityato nāstyatrāgamaḥ sampratipanna iti śiṣyaireva śakyate jñātum /
analyzed: tadīya āgamasya tu asmābhiḥ iti atas na asti atra āgamaḥ sampratipannaḥ iti śiṣyaiḥ eva śakyate jñātum
translated: But it is accepted by us, so the students can understand for themselves that there is no scripture accepted here.

analyzed: pratyakṣa abhāvena anumānasya api abhāvaḥ siddhaḥ eva
translated: The absence of inference is established by the absence of direct perception.

analyzed: pratyakṣasya anumāna upajīvya tvāt
translated: Because perception is dependent on inference.

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa kvacid upalabdham eva hi anumānena kvacid sā
translated: For by perception something is perceived somewhere, and by inference that

analyzed: sādhanīyam
translated: must be established somewhere.

analyzed: a taḥ num ān ādya
translated: Therefore, since the non-existence of inference, etc.

analyzed: bhāvasya anuktau api lābhāt adṛṣṭa tvāt iti eva uktam sūtrakṛtā iti
translated: is obtained even when not stated, the author of the aphorisms has said because of non-apprehension, etc.

original: ata eva prāguktam kvaciditi // /🔽mā bhūcchūnyājjagadutpattau pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇam /
analyzed: atas eva prāk uktam kvacid iti  mā bhūt śūnyāt jagat utpattau pratyakṣam pramāṇam
translated: For this very reason, it was said earlier somewhere.🔽Let perception not be a means of valid knowledge in the origination of the world from the Void.

analyzed: mā ca bhūt āgamaḥ
translated: And let the scriptures not be.

analyzed: tathā api anumānam bhaviṣyati
translated: Nevertheless, there will be inference.

original: asataḥ sadutpattau pratyakṣābhāvena dṛṣṭānumānānupapattāvapi sāmānyato dṛṣṭasyopapatteḥ /
analyzed: asataḥ sat utpattau pratyakṣa abhāvena dṛṣṭa anumāna anupapattau api sāmānyataḥ dṛṣṭasya upapatteḥ
translated: Even though inference is not possible in the origination of the existent from the non-existent due to the absence of perception, it is possible by the inference based on general observation.

original: kāraṇasya hi sattve niṣiddhe 'sata eva janma setsyatītyāśaṅkayānumānānāṃ tarkapratighātaṃ vaktuṃ sūtram oṃ udāsīnānāmapi caivaṃ siddhiḥ oṃ
analyzed: kāraṇasya hi sattve niṣiddhe sataḥ eva janma setsyati iti āśaṅkayā anumānānām tarka pratighātam vaktum sūtram om udāsīnānām api ca evam siddhiḥ om
translated: For when the existence of the cause is denied, the birth of the non-existent alone will be established. Fearing this, in order to state the refutation of inference by reasoning, the aphorism is: And thus the establishment of the neutral ones is also like this.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe yadi evam iti
translated: He explains that as follows: If it is so, etc.

original: udāsīnānām api caivaṃ siddhiḥ / / / /🔽yadyevaṃ saptamarasānmadhurādiva pīnatā /
analyzed: udāsīnānām api ca evam siddhiḥ  yadi evam saptama rasāt madhurāt iva pīna tā
translated: And thus the establishment of the neutral ones is also like this.🔽If it is so, then the plumpness of people would be like the sweet taste, etc., from the seventh taste.

analyzed: bhavet janasya mārjārṛṅgam goḥ iva ghātakam
translated: It would be like the killing of a cow by a cat.

original: yadyasata eva yatkiñcitkāryaṃ jāyeta tadā madhurādiva saptamarasāñjanasya pīnatā syāt /🔽goḥ śṛṅgamiva mārjārṛṅgamapi janasya ghātakaṃ bhavedaviśeṣādityanena evaṃ satyudāsīnānāṃ heyopādeyo
analyzed: yadi asataḥ eva yat kiñcid kāryam jāyeta tadā madhurāt iva saptama rasāñjanasya pīna tā syāt  goḥ śṛṅgam iva mārjā ṛṅgam api janasya ghātakam bhavet aviśeṣāt iti anena evam sati udāsīnānām heya upādeya
translated: If something were to arise from a non-existent cause, then like sweetness, the swelling of the seventh rasa (taste) would occur.

original: pekṣaṇīyabuddhayaviṣayāṇāṃ saptamarasādīnāmapi sakāśāt pīnatvādikāryasya siddhiḥ prasajyeteti sūtraṃ vyākhyātaṃ bhavati / /
analyzed: pekṣaṇīya buddhaya viṣayāṇām saptama rasa ādīnām api sakāśāt pīna tva ādi kāryasya siddhiḥ prasajyeta iti sūtram vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: And like the horn of a cow, the horn of a cat would also become a killer of people, due to the absence of distinction. By this, it is explained that in that case, the accomplishment of effects like swelling would result even from the seventh rasa (taste) and so on, which are neutral and are not objects of the intellect that needs to be rejected or accepted. Thus the aphorism is explained.

analyzed: prakāra antareṇa vyākhyāti kārya arthī iti
translated: He explains in another way with One who desires an effect...

analyzed: kārya arthī kāraṇam sat ca na upādadyāt kathañcana
translated: One who desires an effect would never adopt an existent cause...

original: yadyasata eva kāryamutpadyate tadā paṭādikāryārthī kuvindādiḥ sat tantvādikāraṇaṃ sarvathā nopādadīta /
analyzed: yadi asataḥ eva kāryam utpadyate tadā paṭa ādi kārya arthī kuvinda ādiḥ sat tantu ādi kāraṇam sarvathā na upādadīta
translated: If an effect arises from a non-existent cause, then one who desires an effect like a cloth would never adopt an existent cause like threads at all.

analyzed: asataḥ eva paṭa ādi utpatteḥ  atiprasaṅga antaram āha na iti
translated: Because the effect like a cloth arises from a non-existent cause.🔽He states another absurdity with Not...

analyzed: na pravarteta ceṣyāya śūnyāt eva iṣya sambhavāt
translated: And would not engage in what is desired, because what is desired can arise even from a void...

analyzed: na kevalam asataḥ kārya utpattau sat kāraṇa upādāna anupapattiḥ
translated: Not only is the adoption of an existent cause not possible when an effect arises from a non-existent cause,

analyzed: kintu iṣyāya paṭa ādi utpādāya na pravarteta
translated: But it would not engage in producing the desired cloth, etc.

analyzed: na prayateta ca
translated: And it would not strive.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: śūnyāt eva iṣi asambhavāt  etena tantu ādi upādānāt udyu
translated: Because the desired thing can arise only from the void.🔽By this, the aphorism that the accomplishment of cloth, etc. would be for persons who are engaged in collecting threads, etc.,

original: dāsīnānāṃ cikīrṣādirahitānāṃ ca puṃsāṃ paṭādisiddhiḥ syāditi sūtraṃ vyākhyātaṃ bhavati / /
analyzed: dāsīnānām cikīrṣā ādi rahitānām ca puṃsām paṭa ādi siddhiḥ syāt iti sūtram vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: and who are devoid of desire, etc., is explained.

original: prakārāntareṇa vyākhyāti deśeti //🔽deśakālādiniyamo niṃha śūnyāt sato bhavet // / / //
analyzed: prakāra antareṇa vyākhyāti deśa iti  deśa kāla ādi niyamaḥ niṃha śūnyāt sataḥ bhavet
translated: He explains in another way with the word 'deśe' (in place).🔽The restriction of place, time, etc. would be from an existent that is void.

original: śūnyātsataḥ śūnyādeva bhavataḥ kāryasya deśakālāvasthāniyamo na bhavet /
analyzed: śūnyāt sataḥ śūnyāt eva bhavataḥ kāryasya deśa kāla avasthā niyamaḥ na bhavet
translated: The restriction of place, time, and state of the effect that exists from the void, would not be from the void alone.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For example,

original: yadi jagacchūnyādeva bhavet tadā godhūmāḥ kṛṣṇabhūmau sampadyante na pāṇḍubhūmau /
analyzed: yadi jagat śūnyāt eva bhavet tadā godhūmāḥ kṛṣṇa bhūmau sampadyante na pāṇḍu bhūmau
translated: if the world were to exist from the void alone, then wheat would be produced on black soil, not on white soil.

analyzed: vasante kiṃśukāḥ puṣpitāḥ bhavanti
translated: In spring, the kiṃśuka flowers bloom.

analyzed: na varṣāsu
translated: Not in the rainy season.

analyzed: tri hāyiṇī eva gauḥ garbham dhatte na anyathā
translated: A cow conceives only in the third year, not otherwise.

original: satuṣā eva vrīhayo 'ṅkurānutpādayanti netarathetyādideśakālādiniyamaḥ kāryotpattau na syāt /
analyzed: sa tuṣāḥ eva vrīhayaḥ ṅkurān utpādayanti na itarathā iti ādi deśa kāla ādi niyamaḥ kārya utpattau na syāt
translated: Rice with husks alone produces sprouts, not otherwise - such restriction of place, time, etc. in the production of the effect would not be.

analyzed: śūnyasya sarvatra a viśiṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because the void is not distinguished anywhere.

original: anenodāsīnānāṃ deśakālādiniyamānapekṣāṇāmapi kāryāṇāṃ siddhirutpattiḥ syāditi sūtraṃ vyākhyātaṃ bhavati /🔽śūnyādeva kāryotpattau kurtrupādānanimittāpekṣā na syāditi samudāyārthaḥ / /
analyzed: anena udāsīnānām deśa kāla ādi niyama anapekṣāṇām api kāryāṇām siddhiḥ utpattiḥ syāt iti sūtram vyākhyātam bhavati  śūnyāt eva kārya utpattau kurtṛ upādāna nimitta apekṣā na syāt iti samudāya arthaḥ
translated: By this it is explained that the sutra means that even for effects that are neutral, not dependent on restrictions of place, time, etc., there would be origination, i.e., production.🔽The collective meaning is that if the origination of an effect were from emptiness alone, there would be no need for a maker, material cause, or instrumental cause.

analyzed: nanu ādi sṛṣṭau eva śūnyāt kārya utpādam brūmaḥ na sarvadā
translated: But we say that the origination of an effect from emptiness occurs only at the beginning of creation, not always.

analyzed: anyadā tu kartṛ ādi kāṇa gaṇāt eva
translated: At other times, it occurs only from the group of causes such as a maker.

analyzed: atas na atiprasaṅgaḥ iti atas āha puruṣa iti
translated: Therefore, there is no overextension. To this he says purusha (the self).

analyzed: puruṣa icchā anusāreṇa yadi kiñcid prajāyate
translated: If something is produced in accordance with the will of the self,

original: kiṃ nānumīyate tadvad vastutvāt puruṣād bhavaḥ /
analyzed: kim nā anumīyate tadvat vastu tvāt puruṣāt bhavaḥ
translated: why is it not inferred that it arises from the self, like that, because of being an existent?

analyzed: sarvasya api  kiñcid iti adhunātanam kāryam
translated: Of all...🔽Something means the present effect.

analyzed: vastu tvāt kārya tvāt
translated: Because of being an existent means because of being an effect.

analyzed: sarvasya api iti
translated: Of all means

analyzed: ādi kālīnasya api kāryasya iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that even of the effect that existed at the beginning of time.

analyzed: anane nā puruṣaḥ
translated: By this, the self is not inferred.

analyzed: sataḥ ādi kālīnasya kāryasya kartā anumātavyaḥ
translated: The maker of the existent effect that existed at the beginning of time is to be inferred.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

original: dṛṣṭatvāt adhunātanānāṃ kāryāṇāṃ puruṣakartṛtvasya niścitatvāditi prathamasūtraṃ prakārāntareṇa vyākhyātaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: dṛṣṭa tvāt adhunātanānām kāryāṇām puruṣa kartṛ tvasya niścita tvāt iti prathama sūtram prakāra antareṇa vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: The first aphorism is explained in another way: because the existence of a personal agent is certain, since present effects are seen to have such an agent.

analyzed: sūtra bhāṣyayoḥ puruṣa grahaṇam tu upādāna ādi upalakṣaṇam
translated: But the mention of person in the aphorism and commentary is only an illustration of the material cause, etc.

analyzed: nanu idam sarvam api sva vyāhatam
translated: But all this is self-contradictory.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: For example,

analyzed: yat uktam na asataḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt iti
translated: what was said, because non-existence is not seen,

analyzed: tat sataḥ kāraṇa tve pi samānam
translated: that is the same even if existence is the cause.

analyzed: nahi sataḥ kāraṇa tvam api kvāpi āvayoḥ sammatam
translated: For neither of us accepts that existence is even a cause anywhere.

original: nanu ca madhurādiva goḥ śṛṅgamivetyādinā sataḥ sṛṣṭisaṃhārakāritvaṃ nidarśitam /
analyzed: nanu ca madhurāt iva goḥ śṛṅgam iva ityādinā sataḥ sṛṣṭi saṃhāra kāri tvam nidarśitam
translated: But isn't the creation and dissolution of existence shown by like the horn of a cow and so on?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

original: sarvasyāpi jagato 'sattvena tadantaḥpātino madhurāderapi sattvābhāvāt /🔽yaścāyamatiprasaṅgaḥasataḥ kāraṇatve saptamarasāderapi madhurādivat🔽kāryakāritvaprasaṅgaḥ' / iti /
analyzed: sarvasya api jagataḥ sattvena tad antaḥpātinaḥ madhura ādeḥ api sattva abhāvāt  yaḥ ca ayam atiprasaṅgaḥ asataḥ kāraṇa tve saptama rasa ādeḥ api madhura ādi vat  kārya kāri tva prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: Because the entire world is non-existent, and the included sweet taste, etc. also do not exist.🔽And this over-extension, if non-existence is the cause, the seventh taste, etc. would also produce effects like sweet taste,

original: so 'pi sataḥ kāraṇatve tantvādīnāṃ mṛdādikāryakāritvaprasaṅgena tulyaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ u pi sataḥ kāraṇa tve tantu ādīnām mṛd ādi kārya kāri tva prasaṅgena tulyaḥ
translated: is the same as the over-extension that if existence is the cause, threads, etc. would produce effects like clay.

analyzed: tathā api kāraṇa tva mātram sataḥ sti iti ced na
translated: Even so, if it is argued that existence has only causal nature, no.

analyzed: tad sattva asammatyāḥ ukta tvāt
translated: Because it has been said that it is not accepted by sentient beings.

analyzed: nahi sakala vikriyā atītasya kāraṇa tvam śakya sambhāvanam
translated: For it is not possible to conceive that what is completely beyond modification can be a cause.

analyzed: madhura ādīnām saptama rasa ādīnām ca a sattva aviśeṣe sat buddhi bhāva abhāvābhyām viśeṣāt
translated: Even though sweetness, etc. and the seventh taste, etc. are not different in non-existence, there is a difference due to the presence and absence of the notion of existence.

analyzed: yat api kārya arthi ityādi
translated: As for what was said about the one who desires an effect, etc.

original: tadīśvarasya sarvakāraṇatve tata eva paṭādisambhavāttantvādyupādānaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: tad īśvarasya sarva kāraṇa tve tatas eva paṭa ādi sambhavāt tantu ādi upādānam na syāt
translated: If God is the cause of everything, then cloth, etc. would arise from Him alone, so the use of threads, etc. would not be necessary.

analyzed: kuvinda ādeḥ icchā ādikam ca vyartham syāt iti samānam
translated: And the desire, etc. of the weaver would be useless. This is the same.

analyzed: etena deśa kāla ādi iti samīkṛtaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: By this, the absurdity of place, time, etc. should also be understood to be refuted.

analyzed: yat ca puruṣa icchā anusāreṇa iti uktam
translated: And what was said about following the will of a person,

analyzed: tat api tat mahat ādi kāryasya kulāla ādi janya tā sādhana samāna yogakṣemam iti
translated: that is also of the same nature as the proof of the production of the effect such as Mahat, etc. by the potter, etc.

original: atra yadviśvasyāsattvamuktaṃ tattāvannirākartuṃ sūtram oṃ nābhāva upalabdheḥ oṃ //
analyzed: atra yat viśvasya asattvam uktam tat tāvat nirākartum sūtram om na abhāvaḥ upalabdheḥ om
translated: Here, in order to refute what was said about the non-existence of the universe, the aphorism begins: Not non-existence, because of perception.

analyzed: iti
translated: This is the aphorism.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe na ca iti  na abhāvaḥ upalabdheḥ
translated: He explains it as not and so on.🔽Not non-existence, because of perception.

analyzed: na ca abhāvaḥ viśvam sat iti gamyate
translated: And the universe is not known to be non-existent.

analyzed: yatas  bhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Because...🔽The meaning is that it exists.

analyzed: na bhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: An existent is not a non-existent.

analyzed: asat iti yāvat
translated: Asat means non-existent.

original: saditi gamyate yata ityanena viśvasatyatve pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇamuktaṃ veditavyam /🔽pratyakṣeṇa sadityanubhūyamānamapi viśvamasaccetko doṣa ityata āha anubhaveti //
analyzed: sat iti gamyate yatas iti anena viśva satya tve pratyakṣam pramāṇam uktam veditavyam  pratyakṣeṇa sat iti anubhūyamānam api viśvam asat ced kaḥ doṣaḥ iti atas āha anubhava iti
translated: By the words from which it is understood to be existent, it should be understood that perception is the means of valid knowledge for the reality of the universe.🔽If the universe, which is experienced as existent by perception, is non-existent, what is the fault? To this he says If there is contradiction with experience...

analyzed: anubhava vi
translated: ...then how can the opponent's statement be valid?

analyzed: rodhe tu kriyamāṇe iti śeṣaḥ
translated: If there is contradiction with experience, the rest is that it is being done.

original: tatra yadi sattvenopalabhyamānamapyasatsyāttadottaraṃ vadatyapi śūnyavāditi noktaṃ tvayetyataste 'pratibheti bruvāṇaṃ paraṃ prati śūnyavādinaḥ
analyzed: tatra yadi sattvena upalabhyamānam api asat syāt tadā uttaram vadati api śūnyavād iti na uktam tvayā iti atas te pratibhā iti bruvāṇam param prati śūnyavādinaḥ
translated: There, if what is perceived as existent were non-existent, then when you say The opponent's statement is not valid, you would be saying You have no reply, and the proponent of emptiness would be defeated,

analyzed: kopāya abhāvāt parājayaḥ eva āpadyeta
translated: because there would be no reason for anger.

original: yadi ca prāśnikādyavagataṃ kathaṃ madvacanaṃ nāstīti brūyāt tadāṅgīkṛtaṃ pratyakṣasya prāmāṇyamiti sattvena tadavagataṃ viśvaṃ katamasatsyāditi
analyzed: yadi ca prāśnika ādi avagatam katham mad vacanam na asti iti brūyāt tadā aṅgīkṛtam pratyakṣasya prāmāṇyam iti sattvena tat avagatam viśvam katama sat syāt iti
translated: And if one were to say How can my statement be non-existent, as understood by the judges and others? then the validity of perception would be accepted, and which existent universe, understood by that, would be non-existent?

analyzed: ukta doṣa parihāram śaṅkate svapna iti
translated: He doubts the answer to the stated fault with In a dream...

analyzed: svapna bhrānti vat evā idam saṃvṛttyā evā upalabhyate
translated: This is perceived only conventionally, as in a dream or an illusion.🔽...

analyzed: yadi sattvena
translated: If by existence...

analyzed: svapnaḥ ca bhrāntiḥ ca tayoḥ iva svapna bhrānti vat
translated: Like a dream and an illusion, like a dream and an illusion.

analyzed: yadi api parasya svapnaḥ bhrantiḥ eva
translated: Even though a dream is an illusion for the opponent,

analyzed: tathā api go balīvarda nyāyena loka vyavahāram apekṣya pṛthak uktiḥ
translated: still, in accordance with the principle of the cow and the gāvī, it is stated separately with reference to worldly usage.

original: yathā svapne bhrāntau cāsadeva gajādikaṃ sapādikaṃ ca sadityupalabhyate tathāsadevedaṃ viśvaṃ satyatve🔽ttvenopalabhyate /
analyzed: yathā svapne bhrāntau ca asat eva gaja ādikam sa pādikam ca sat iti upalabhyate tathā asat eva idam viśvam satya tve  ttvena upalabhyate
translated: Just as in a dream and an illusion, an unreal elephant, etc. and a foot, etc. are perceived as real, so this entire universe, which is unreal, is perceived as real.

analyzed: etat eva viśvasya śūnya kāraṇa tvam nāma
translated: This very thing is the emptiness of the cause of the universe.

analyzed: na aparam  tatra katham sat iti upalambhena viśvasya satya
translated: There is nothing else.

analyzed: tu asiddhiḥ
translated: How then is the reality of the universe established by the perception of it as real?

original: nacaivamadhiṣṭhānasya draṣṭuḥ karaṇānāṃ taddoṣāṇāṃ ca sattvamaṅgīkāryam /
analyzed: na ca evam adhiṣṭhānasya draṣṭuḥ karaṇānām tad doṣāṇām ca sattvam aṅgīkāryam
translated: And thus the existence of the basis, the seer, the sense organs, and their faults must be accepted.

analyzed: anyathā bhrānti vaicitrya ādi anupapattiḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that the diversity of illusions, etc. is not possible otherwise.

analyzed: asat prakāśana śaktyā saṃvṛtyā eva sarvasya upapattau tad aṅgīkāra vaiyathryāt
translated: Because everything is possible only through the power of the unreal appearing, which is mere convention, and accepting that would be absurd.

analyzed: evam ca na vacana asiddhiḥ
translated: Thus, there is no failure of the statement.

analyzed: sāṃvṛta sattvasya vacanasya pratyakṣeṇa eva siddheḥ
translated: Because the statement, which has conventional existence, is established by perception itself.

analyzed: tāvatā eva vyavahāra upapattau pāramārthika sattvasya upayoga abhāvāt iti
translated: Because the mere existence of the world is sufficient for the conduct of worldly affairs, and there is no use for ultimate reality.

original: etatparihārāya oṃ vaidharmyācca na svapnādivat oṃ //🔽iti sūtram /
analyzed: etad parihārāya om vaidharmyāt ca na svapna ādi vat om  iti sūtram
translated: To answer this, the sutra says: And because of the difference, it is not like in a dream, etc.

analyzed: tat vayācaṣṭe kiñca iti
translated: This is explained by the commentary beginning with And what is more...

analyzed: vaidharmyāt ca na svapna ādi vat
translated: And because of the difference, it is not like in a dream, etc.

analyzed: kiñca atra bhramaḥ na eva nivartate
translated: And what is more, the delusion here does not cease at all.

original: bhavedevaṃ yadi prapañce rajjusarpādāviva sattvapratyayo bhramaḥ syāt /
analyzed: bhavet evam yadi prapañce rajju sarpa ādau iva sattva pratyayaḥ bhramaḥ syāt
translated: This would be so if the appearance of existence in the world were a delusion like the appearance of a snake in a rope.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

original: tathātve atra prapañce satvabhramaḥ kimiti naiva nivartate /
analyzed: tathātve atra prapañce satva bhramaḥ kimiti nā eva nivartate
translated: If it were so, then why does the delusion of existence in this world not cease at all?

analyzed: jñānānām bhrama tva avadhāraṇam hi bādha bodha adhīnam
translated: For the determination of the delusion of cognitions depends on the knowledge of contradiction.

analyzed: sampratipanna sthale tathā darśanāt
translated: Because that is seen in the case of commonly accepted things.

original: pratyayatvamātrādhīnatve prāgapi bādhabodhodayādrajjusarpādijñāne laukikaparīkṣakāṇāṃ bhramatvāvadhāraṇaṃ syāt /
analyzed: pratyaya tva mātra adhīna tve prāk api bādha bodha udayāt rajju sarpa ādi jñāne laukika parīkṣakāṇām bhrama tva avadhāraṇam syāt
translated: If it depended merely on being a cognition, then even before the arising of the knowledge of contradiction, the worldly and critical people would determine the delusion in the cognitions of a snake in a rope, etc.

analyzed: na ca evam kvacid dṛṣṭam
translated: But this is not seen anywhere.

analyzed: na ca prapañca sattā avagamasya bādhakam paśyāmaḥ
translated: And we do not see any contradiction in the apprehension of the existence of the world.

analyzed: tatas na bhrama tva avadhāraṇam yuktam iti
translated: Therefore, it is not proper to determine it as delusion.

analyzed: svapnasya bhrānti tva abhāvaḥ
translated: The unreality of the dream.

analyzed: bhramasya ca adhiṣṭhāna ādi apekṣā niyamaḥ
translated: And the restriction of the illusion to the substratum, etc.

analyzed: sāṃvṛta sattvasya vyavahāra nirvāhaka tvasya abhāvaḥ ca anyatra trā anusandheyaḥ
translated: The absence of the existence of the conventional, which maintains the conduct, should be understood here as established elsewhere.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: kim prapañca pratyayasya idānīm bādhaḥ na asti iti ucyate
translated: Is it said now that there is no contradiction of the idea of the world?

analyzed: uta uttara kāle pi
translated: Or even later?

analyzed: ādye na tāvatā viśva satya tva avadhāraṇam
translated: In the first case, it is not determined that even your world is real,

analyzed: śukti rajata ādau tad ayogāt
translated: because that is not possible in the silver of a shell, etc.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ tu na asti
translated: But the second is not so.

analyzed: prapañca pratyayaḥ bādhiṣyate pratyaya tvāt sampratipanna vat  iti āgāmi bādha siddheḥ iti atas āha anādeḥ iti
translated: The idea of the world will be contradicted, because it is an idea, like what is admitted.🔽Thus, because the contradiction in the future is established, he says of the beginningless (in the verse).

analyzed: anādeḥ asya viśvasya nivṛttiḥ yadi ca iṣyate
translated: If the cessation of this beginningless world is desired,

analyzed: nivṛttiḥ ca nivarteta tasyāḥ bhrānti tva sambhavāt
translated: and the cessation would cease, because its illusion is possible.

analyzed: anāditaḥ nuvṛttasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is of what has continued from the beginning.

analyzed: viśvasya tad pratyayasya  nivṛttiḥ bādhaḥ
translated: Of the world, of that idea.🔽Cessation is contradiction.

analyzed: nivarteta bādhyeta
translated: Would cease, would be contradicted.

analyzed: yadi pratyaya tvāt prapañca pratyayasya bādhaḥ numīyate
translated: If the contradiction of the idea of the world is inferred because it is an idea,

analyzed: tadā avaśyam bādha pratyayasya api bādhena bhāvyam
translated: Then, necessarily, the cognition of annulment must also be annulled.

analyzed: anyathā pratyaya tva hetoḥ tatra vyabhicāra āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the fallacy of the reason being absent in the similar instance.

analyzed: bādhaka pratyayasya bādhya tve prapañca pratyayasya yāthārthya siddhiḥ
translated: If the cognition of annulment is annulled, then the truth of the cognition of the world is established.

analyzed: tiṣṭhatu tāvat parama artha cintā
translated: Let us leave aside the consideration of the ultimate truth for the time being.

analyzed: vyāvahārike tu tathā dṛṣṭam eva
translated: But in the case of empirical reality, it is seen to be so.

original: na kevalamidamāpādanaṃ kintu sambhāvitaṃ caitat /🔽yatprapañcapratyayasya yāthārthyaṃ tannāstitāpratyayasya bādhyatvāt /🔽anādito 'nuvṛttasyānekasajātīyavijātīyasaṃvādava🔽to yāthārthyasambhavāt /
analyzed: na kevalam idam āpādanam kintu sambhāvitam ca etat  yat prapañca pratyayasya yāthārthyam tat nāstitā pratyayasya bādhya tvāt  anāditaḥ nuvṛttasya aneka sajātīya vijātīya saṃvāda vat  taḥ yāthārthya sambhavāt
translated: Not only is this an inference, but it is also a possibility.🔽That the cognition of the world is true is because the cognition of non-existence is annulled.🔽Because it is possible for the cognition of the world, which has been current since beginningless time, to be true, as it is in agreement with many homogeneous and heterogeneous things.

analyzed: kādācitkasya saṃvāda vidhura ruddha  tvena bhrama tva sambhavāt iti
translated: Because it is possible for the cognition of non-existence, which is occasional and not in agreement with reality, to be a delusion, as it is contradicted.

analyzed: nanu ca prapañca nivṛttiḥ nāma śūnyam eva
translated: But is not the cessation of the world just emptiness?

analyzed: tat ca paramārtha rūpam na kalpitam adṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: And that is of the nature of the ultimate truth, not imagined, because it is not seen.

analyzed: tat katham tad pratyayasya bādhya tā syāt
translated: So how can the cognition of that be annulled?

original: kintu prapañcasya dṛṣṭatvena kalpitatvasambhavāttatpratyaya eva bādhyaḥ /
analyzed: kintu prapañcasya dṛṣṭa tvena kalpita tva sambhavāt tad pratyayaḥ eva bādhyaḥ
translated: Rather, because it is possible for the world to be imagined, as it is seen, the cognition of that alone is to be annulled.

original: hetuśca prapañcapratyayatvena vivektavya ityata āha dṛṣṭasyeti //
analyzed: hetuḥ ca prapañca pratyaya tvena vivektavyaḥ iti atas āha dṛṣṭasya iti
translated: And the reason should be distinguished as the condition of the proliferation. Therefore he says of what is seen, etc.

original: dṛṣṭasya bhrāntitā cet syādadṛṣṭe na bhramaḥ kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: dṛṣṭasya bhrānti tā ced syāt adṛṣṭe na bhramaḥ kutas
translated: If the falsity of what is seen were, there would be no delusion in what is not seen. Why?

analyzed: bhrānti tā bhrama śabdābhyām kalpita tvam ucyate
translated: By the words falsity and delusion, imagined nature is meant.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: viparatīmetaduktaṃ yatsarvapramāṇadṛṣṭasya prapañcasya kalpitatvamādāya tatsattāpratyayasya bādhyatvasvīkaraṇam /
analyzed: viparatīm etat uktam yat sarva pramāṇa dṛṣṭasya prapañcasya kalpita tvam ādāya tad sattā pratyayasya bādhya tva svīkaraṇam
translated: This is said in reverse: Taking the imagined nature of the proliferation seen by all valid cognitions, accepting the invalidity of the cognition of its existence.

analyzed: kena api pramāṇena adṛṣṭasya śūnyasya akalpita tvam gṛhītvā tad sattva pratyayasya abādhya tva upādānam
translated: Taking the non-imagined nature of emptiness, which is not seen by any valid cognition, accepting the non-invalidity of the cognition of its existence.

analyzed: prāmāṇikam akalpitam aprāmāṇikam ca aṅgīkriyamāṇam kalpitam iti sarva sammata tvāt iti
translated: What is established by valid cognition is accepted as non-imagined, and what is accepted as not established by valid cognition is taken as imagined. This is agreed upon by all.

analyzed: etat eva dṛṣṭāntena darśayati gavām iti
translated: He shows this very thing by an example, with of cows, etc.

analyzed: gavāmaśṛṅgi bhāvena nahi syāt śaśaśṛṅgi tā
translated: By the non-hornedness of cows, there would not be the horn-ness of rabbits.

analyzed: aśṛṅgi bhāvena sahitā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is accompanied by non-hornedness.

analyzed: kaścid gavām śṛṅgitavam asti iti āha kaścid śaśasya iti
translated: Someone says that there is horn-ness of cows. He says of the rabbit, etc.

original: tatra paroktarītyā gavāṃ śṛṅgitā kalpitā / dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: tatra para ukta rītyā gavām śṛṅgi tā kalpitā dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: There, according to the opponent's statement, the horn-ness of cows is imagined, because it is seen.

analyzed: śaśaśṛṅgitā tu akalpita adṛṣṭa tvāt iti syāt
translated: It would be like a hare's horn, because it is not seen as imagined.

original: na hyevaṃ loke pratītiḥ lokānusāreṇaiva ca paramārtho boddhavyo nānyathā /
analyzed: na hi evam loke pratītiḥ loka anusāreṇa eva ca paramārthaḥ boddhavyaḥ na anyathā
translated: For such is not the understanding in the world. And the ultimate truth should be understood only in accordance with the world, not otherwise.

analyzed: loka nyāyasya eva tad bodha upāya tvāt iti
translated: Because worldly logic itself is the means of knowing that.

analyzed: tat evam pratyakṣa balena viśva satya tā sādhitā
translated: Thus, the truth of the universe is established by the power of perception.

original: tadbādhakaśaṅkā ca parihṛtā /🔽tataḥ kiṃ siddhamityato yaduktaṃ pūrvapakṣiṇā sato 'pi kāraṇatve pramāṇābhāva iti tatparihṛtamiti vadansamīkaraṇāntaramapi pariharati asmākaṃ
analyzed: tad bādhaka śaṅkā ca parihṛtā  tatas kim siddham iti atas yat uktam pūrvapakṣiṇā sataḥ api kāraṇa tve pramāṇa abhāvaḥ iti tat parihṛtam iti vadan samīkaraṇa antaram api pariharati asmākam
translated: And the doubt of its contradiction is removed.

analyzed: tu iti
translated: What is established by that? Therefore, what was said by the opponent that there is no evidence for the causality of the existent, that is refuted. Saying this, he also refutes another objection.🔽But for us,

analyzed: asmākam tu pramāṇena prasādāt īśvarasya ca
translated: by the evidence, by the grace of God,

analyzed: ukta bhaṅgayā āgamānām ca prāmāṇyāt yujyate khilam
translated: and by the validity of the scriptures stated in the refutation, everything is possible.

analyzed: satkāraṇatva vādinām akhilam pareṇa ākṣiptam yujyate
translated: For those who assert the existence of causes, everything that was objected to by the opponent is possible.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

original: bādhavidhureṇa pramāṇena jagataḥ satyatvasiddhau madhurādīnāṃ puṣyayādikāraṇānāṃ sattvasiddheḥ /
analyzed: bādha vidhureṇa pramāṇena jagataḥ satya tva siddhau madhura ādīnām puṣyaya ādi kāraṇānām sattva siddheḥ
translated: When the truth of the world is established by evidence free from contradiction, the existence of causes like honey and so on is established.

original: tantvādīnāṃ ca vicitrasvabhāvatayā pramāṇena siddhānāṃ na mṛdādikāryakāritvaprasaṅgaḥ /🔽nahi sata ivāsato 'pi svabhāvabhedo 'sattvavyāghātāt /
analyzed: tantu ādīnām ca vicitra svabhāva tayā pramāṇena siddhānām na mṛd ādi kārya kāri tva prasaṅgaḥ  nahi sataḥ iva asataḥ pi svabhāva bhedaḥ sattva vyāghātāt
translated: And since threads, etc., are established by valid cognition as having various natures, it does not follow that they produce effects like clay, etc.🔽For, like an existent, a non-existent also has a difference in nature, because it does not contradict non-existence.

analyzed: pramāṇena eva sataḥ kāraṇa tva upalabdheḥ anupapattiḥ ābhāsa bhūtā eva
translated: The non-apprehension of the causal nature of an existent by valid cognition itself is merely an appearance of non-apprehension.

original: pramāṇena sattayā pramitānāṃ madhurādīnāṃ sadbuddhimātravailakṣaṇyakalpanā tyayuktaiva /
analyzed: pramāṇena sattayā pramitānām madhura ādīnām sat buddhi mātra vailakṣaṇya kalpanā tya yuktā eva
translated: The postulation of a mere difference in the cognition of existence of sweet things, etc., which are ascertained as existent by valid cognition, is indeed improper.

analyzed: anyathā sat buddhayā avagatāt saptama rasāt api pīna tā satī syāt
translated: Otherwise, even from the seventh taste, which is cognized by the cognition of existence, corpulence would be existent.

original: īśvarasya sarvakāraṇatve 'pi tantvādyapekṣā puruṣaprayatnādyapekṣā deśakālādiniyamaśca yujyata eva /
analyzed: īśvarasya sarva kāraṇa tve pi tantu ādi apekṣā puruṣa prayatna ādi apekṣā deśa kāla ādi niyamaḥ ca yujyate eva
translated: Even in the case of God being the cause of everything, the dependence on threads, etc., the dependence on human effort, etc., and the restriction by place, time, etc., are indeed proper.

analyzed: tantu ādi apekṣayā eva kāryam utpadyatām iti īśvarasya prasādāt saṅkalpāt
translated: The effect is produced only by the dependence on threads, etc., by the grace of God, by His will.

analyzed: na ca evam nirviśeṣasya śūnyasya saṅkalpaḥ yujyate
translated: And thus, the will of the unqualified void is not proper.

analyzed: na ca etat aprāmāṇikam
translated: And this is not unauthoritative.

analyzed: ārambhaṇa adhikaraṇa ukta rītyā atra āgama anumāna ādīnām pramāra tvāt
translated: Because, in this case, the scriptures, inferences, etc., are valid in the same way as stated in the section on the beginning of creation.

analyzed: na ca veda ādi āgama prāmāṇyam asiddham
translated: And the validity of the scriptures like the Vedas is not unestablished.

analyzed: prathama sūtra ukta rīti āgama prāmāṇyasya siddha tvāt
translated: Because the validity of the scriptures has been established in the manner stated in the first aphorism.

analyzed: anumāne tiprasaṅgaḥ pi āgama prāmāṇyena eva apāste iti
translated: And the great fallacy in inference has also been refuted by the very validity of the scriptures.

original: brahmādīnsṛṣṭayādāvīśvarasteṣu kṛpayāpekṣate parameśvaraniyogānuṣṭhāne teṣāṃ paramapuruṣārthalābhāditi jñāpayituṃ prasādādityuktam / /
analyzed: brahma ādīn sṛṣṭayā ādau īśvaraḥ teṣu kṛpayā apekṣate parameśvara niyoga anuṣṭhāne teṣām parama puruṣa artha lābhāt iti jñāpayitum prasādāt iti uktam
translated: The word grace is used to indicate that God, in creating etc. Brahma and others, has compassion for them, because by obeying the command of the Supreme Lord, they attain the highest human goal.

analyzed: prāk viśvasya
translated: Before the creation of the universe,

original: satyatvasādhanāyopanyastasya pratyakṣasyānyathāsiddhimāśaṅkaya tatparihāratvena vaidharmyācca na svapnādivaditi sūtraṃ vyākhyātam /🔽idānīṃ viśvamithyātve parābhihitasya anumānasya dūṣakatvenāpi tadvayā
analyzed: satya tva sādhanāya upanyastasya pratyakṣasya anyathā asiddhim āśaṅkaya tad parihāra tvena vaidharmyāt ca na svapna ādi vat iti sūtram vyākhyātam  idānīm viśva mithyātve para abhihitasya anumānasya dūṣaka tvena api
translated: fearing that the perception stated for proving the reality of the universe might be otherwise established, the aphorism And because of dissimilarity, it is not like a dream etc. is explained as a reply to that.

original: vyākhyātuṃ mithyātve 'numānaṃ tāvacchaṅkate dṛśyatvāditi //🔽dṛśyatvād vimaṃta mithyā svapnavacced / / / // / / //
analyzed: vyākhyātum mithyātve numānam tāvat śaṅkate dṛśya tvāt iti  dṛśya tvāt mithyā svapna vat ced
translated: Now, in order to explain that as a refutation of the inference stated by the opponent in the unreality of the universe, he raises the question of the unreality of the universe with Because of being perceived, etc.🔽If it is argued that the object of knowledge is unreal like a dream because it is perceived, etc.

analyzed: sarvam mithyā iti ukte sampratipanna mithyātve śukti rajata ādau siddha sādhana tā
translated: When it is said that everything is unreal, there is the fallacy of proving what is already established in the case of silver in a shell, etc., which are admitted to be unreal.

analyzed: śūnye bādhaḥ ca syāt
translated: In the case of the void, there would be contradiction.

analyzed: atas satya tva mithyātvābhyām vimatam iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said that the object of knowledge is real or unreal.

original: vimataṃ gaganādikaṃ mithyā dṛśyatvāt svapnavadityanumānena viśvamithyātvasiddheḥ kathaṃ tatsa
analyzed: vimatam gagana ādikam mithyā dṛśya tvāt svapna vat iti anumānena viśva mithyātva siddheḥ katham tat sa
translated: In the inference The disputed sky, etc. are false, because they are seen, like a dream, the falsity of the universe is established. How then can that be the basis of the distinction of valid and invalid cognition?

analyzed: satya tvam aṅgīkriyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: how can the truth of that [world] be accepted when the falsity of the world is established by the inference that the subject, such as the sky, is false because it is an object of perception, like a dream?

analyzed: dūṣayitum pṛcchati iyam ca iti
translated: In order to refute [this argument], he asks And is this...

analyzed: iyam ca mā
translated: And this [inference]...

original: tiṣṭhatu tāvadviśvam /🔽iyaṃ ca mā idameva dṛśyatvānumānam /
analyzed: tiṣṭhatu tāvat viśvam  iyam ca mā idam eva dṛśya tva anumānam
translated: Let the world remain for now.

original: mithyā satyaṃ tyā ve veti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: mithyā satyam śeṣaḥ
translated: And this [inference] of the perceptibility of the subject is false or true, the rest [of the sentence] is implied.

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati mithyā iti
translated: He refutes the first [alternative] with If it is false...

analyzed: mithyā ced sādhya siddhiḥ na
translated: If it is false, the establishment of the probandum is not...

original: nahi śabde 'vidyamānena cākṣuṣatvena śabdānityatvaṃ siddhayatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nahi śabde vidyamānena cākṣuṣa tvena śabda anitya tvam siddhayati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that the impermanence of sound is not established by the non-existent audibility of sound.

analyzed: dvitīye dṛśya tvam dṛśyam adṛśyam vā
translated: In the second [alternative], perceptibility is either perceptible or imperceptible.

analyzed: prathamam dūṣayati vyabhicāraḥ iti
translated: He refutes the first [alternative] with If there is no fallacy...

analyzed: vyabhicāraḥ na ced bhavet
translated: If there is no fallacy, then...

original: dṛśyatvaṃ mithyā na cedatha ca dṛśyam /🔽tadā dṛśyatvasya
analyzed: dṛśya tvam mithyā na ced atha ca dṛśyam  tadā dṛśya tvasya
translated: If perceptibility is not false and yet is perceptible,🔽then there would be a fallacy of perceptibility

analyzed: dṛśya tve eva vyabhicāraḥ bhavet
translated: only in perceptibility itself.

analyzed: dvitīye tu ajñāna asiddha tā hetoḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that in the second [alternative], the reason is not established by ignorance.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: mithyā eva dṛśya tvam iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say that perceptibility is false.

analyzed: na ca evam sādhya asādhaka tvam  varṇa dairghya ādīnām mithyā bhūtānām api sādhaka tvasya ubhaya siddha tvāt  cākṣuṣa tva ādīnām tu āropa abhāvāt
translated: And it is not so that it does not prove what is to be proved.🔽Because the proving of false letters, length, etc. is established for both [parties].🔽But in the case of being perceptible, etc., there is no superimposition.

analyzed: ārope pi asāṃvyāvahārika tvāt asādhaka tvam
translated: Even in superimposition, because it is not empirical, it does not prove.

original: na tu mithyātvādityata āha sādhakatvamiti //🔽sādhakatvamasatyasya sādhyaṃ vipratipattitaḥ // / / //🔽yatrodāharaṇe mithyātvaṃ sampratipannaṃ tatra sādhakatve /
analyzed: na tu mithyātvāt iti atas āha sādhaka tvam iti  sādhaka tvam asatyasya sādhyam vipratipattitaḥ  yatra udāharaṇe mithyātvam sampratipannam tatra sādhaka tve
translated: But not because of falsity. Therefore he says proving etc.🔽The proving of the false is to be proved due to disagreement.🔽In the example where falsity is agreed upon, there is proving.

original: yatra ca sādhakatvaṃ saṃmataṃ tatra mithyātve vipratipattito 'satyasya sādhakatvaṃ sādhyameva /
analyzed: yatra ca sādhaka tvam saṃmatam tatra mithyātve satyasya sādhaka tvam sādhyam eva
translated: And where proving is accepted, there the proving of the false is to be proved due to disagreement.

original: na punarasmākaṃ siddhamiti / /🔽vipratipattau sādhakatvaṃ mithyātvaṃ vā sādhayiṣyāmīti cet /
analyzed: na punar asmākam siddham iti  vipratipattau sādhaka tvam mithyātvam vā sādhayiṣyāmi iti ced
translated: But it is not established for us.🔽If it is argued that in disagreement, I will prove either the proving or falsity,

analyzed: kim satyena pramāṇena uta mithyābhūtena
translated: is it by a true means of knowledge or by a false one?

analyzed: ādye tu uktam eva uttaram
translated: In the first case, the same answer is given.

analyzed: dvitīye doṣam āha tasya ca iti
translated: In the second case, he states the fault with that etc.

analyzed: tasya ca
translated: And of that...

analyzed: nahi kvāpi asmākam mithyābhūtasya sādhaka tvam sammatam
translated: For nowhere is the proving of the false accepted by us.

analyzed: atas tasya api sādhaka tvam sādhyam eva
translated: Therefore, the validity of that [means of knowledge] also is to be established.

analyzed: tasya api sādhaka tvam sādhayiṣyāmi iti atas āha iti iti
translated: In order to establish the validity of that [means of knowledge], he says thus and so on.

analyzed: iti anavasthā syāt
translated: Thus there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: pūrva ukta prakāreṇa iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is in the manner stated before.

analyzed: nahi sarvam asatyam sādhakam iti ekam pramāṇam asti
translated: For there is no single means of knowledge that everything false is valid.

original: nāpi sadvādī kadāpi sattvāsattvodāsīnena pramāṇena sādhyasiddhimaṅgīkuryāt /
analyzed: nā api sat vādī kadāpi sattva asattva udāsīnena pramāṇena sādhya siddhim aṅgīkuryāt
translated: Nor would the proponent of existence ever accept the establishment of the probandum by a means of knowledge that is neutral with regard to existence and non-existence,

analyzed: yena anavasthā śāntiḥ bhavet iti
translated: by which there would be an end to the infinite regress.

original: evamasiddhivyabhicārābhyāmanumānaṃ nirākṛtya pramāṇabādhaṃ cāha sattvaṃ ceti //
analyzed: evam asiddhi vyabhicārābhyām anumānam nirākṛtya pramāṇa bādham ca āha sattvam ca iti
translated: Having thus refuted inference by means of the fallacies of unestablished [reason] and contradiction, he states the contradiction with valid means of knowledge: And its existence is from experience.

analyzed: sattvam ca asya anubhūtitaḥ
translated: And its existence is from experience.

analyzed: asya prapañcasya
translated: Of this world.

analyzed: anubhūtitaḥ siddham atas bādhita viṣayam ca anumānam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: It is established from experience. Therefore, inference has an contradicted object, is the remainder.

analyzed: na kevalam dṛśya tva anumānasya anena doṣeṇa ābhā sattvam
translated: Not only is the inference of visibility false due to this fault.

original: kintu yadanyadapi prapañcamithyātve 'numānaṃ jaḍatvaṃ vā paricchinnatvaṃ vā parairucyate tasyāpītyāha anubhūtīti //
analyzed: kintu yat anyat api prapañca mithyātve numānam jaḍa tvam vā paricchinna tvam vā paraiḥ ucyate tasya api iti āha anubhūti iti
translated: But also any other inference that is stated by others regarding the falsity of the world, such as inertness or finitude, is also like that. He says from experience and so on.

analyzed: anubhūti virodhena mithyātve mā na kācana
translated: There is no [means of knowledge] at all that contradicts experience in the falsity [of the world].

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is an illustration.

analyzed: pūrva ukta vyabhicāra asiddhibhyām ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: And it should be seen that [the reason] is also [contradicted] by the previously mentioned fallacy of non-establishment and the fallacy of being inconclusive.

analyzed: tathā hi  jaḍa tva ādikam satyam mithyā vā
translated: Because it is like this.🔽Is being dull-witted etc. true or false?

analyzed: ādye jaḍa tva ādimat na vā
translated: If the first, then it has being dull-witted etc. or not.

analyzed: prathame vyabhicāraḥ
translated: In the first case, [the reason] is inconclusive.

analyzed: dvitīye pasiddhāntaḥ
translated: In the second, [the reason] contradicts [the opponent's] doctrine.

analyzed: mithyā ced sādhya siddhiḥ na iti
translated: If [being dull-witted etc.] is false, then the conclusion is not established.

analyzed: bhavet asattvam anumānānām yadi anubhava virodhaḥ bhavet
translated: Inference would be non-existent if there were contradiction with experience.

analyzed: na ca asau asti
translated: But that does not exist.

analyzed: mithyātva apara paryāyam bādhya tvam hi anumāna sādhyam
translated: Being false, which is synonymous with being contradicted, is to be established by inference.

original: naca tadabhāvaḥ pratyakṣeṇa vedyaḥ /🔽tasya vartamānamātraviṣayatvena kathañcidvartamānakālīnābādhābhāvaviṣayatve 'pi kālāntaragata
analyzed: na ca tad abhāvaḥ pratyakṣeṇa vedyaḥ  tasya vartamāna mātra viṣaya tvena kathañcid vartamāna kālīna ābādha abhāva viṣaya tve pi kāla antara gata
translated: And its absence cannot be known by perception.

analyzed: bhāvi bādhā abhāva viṣaya tva ayogāt iti atas āha atīta iti
translated: Because that [perception] has only the present as its object, even if it somehow has as its object the absence of contradiction in the present time, it is not suitable to have as its object the absence of future contradiction in a different time. Therefore he says past etc.

analyzed: atīta anāgatau kālau api naḥ sākṣi gocarau
translated: Even the past and future times are the domain of our witness.

analyzed: atra atīta grahaṇam prāsaṅgikam
translated: Here, the mention of the past is incidental.

analyzed: na kevalam vartamāne iti apeḥ arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of api [in the verse] is not only the present.

analyzed: naḥ sarveṣām
translated: Our means of all [philosophical schools].

analyzed: ttiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Otherwise, the usage qualified by that [witness] would be impossible. This is the idea.

original: kimato yadyevamavartamāno 'pi kālaḥ sākṣigocara ityata āha taditi //
analyzed: kim atas yadi evam avartamānaḥ api kālaḥ sākṣi gocaraḥ iti atas āha tat iti
translated: What follows from this, if the past time is also the object of the witness? To this he says: That.

analyzed: tad sambandhi tayā sattvam api
translated: Existence also by relation to that.🔽Existence by relation to another time is non-sublation.

analyzed: na kevalam vartamāna kālīna bādhā bhāvaḥ nubhava vedyaḥ
translated: Not only the absence of sublation belonging to the present time is to be known by experience.

analyzed: kintu sarva kālagataḥ api iti arthaḥ
translated: But belonging to all times also, is the meaning.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas uktam dṛṣṭasya iti
translated: How is that? To this he says: Of the seen.

analyzed: dṛṣṭasya sākṣi gam  pratyakṣa ādi pratīti viṣayasya
translated: Of the seen by the witness.🔽Of the object of perception etc.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi pratītīnām prāmāṇyasya sākṣiṇā grahaṇāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because the validity of perceptions etc. is grasped by the witness.

original: nahi viṣayasya traikālikābādhyatvamanantarbhāvya tatpratīteḥ prāmāṇyaṃ śakyagrahaṇam /
analyzed: nahi viṣayasya traikālika abādhya tvam an antar bhāvya tad pratīteḥ prāmāṇyam śakya grahaṇam
translated: For the validity of the cognition cannot be grasped without including the non-sublatedness of the object in all three times.

analyzed: yadi pratītim gṛhṇan sākṣī tad prāmāṇya grahaṇa svabhāva tvāt tat gṛhṇan tad viṣayasya traikālika abādhya tvam
translated: If, while grasping the cognition, the witness, by his nature of grasping the validity of that, were to establish the non-sublatedness of the object in all three times,

original: vyavasthāpayettadā śuktirajatādipratīterapi sa eva grāhaka iti tasyā api prāmāṇyaṃ gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: vyavasthāpayet tadā śukti rajata ādi pratīteḥ api saḥ eva grāhakaḥ iti tasyāḥ api prāmāṇyam gṛhṇīyāt
translated: then, since he is the same grasper of the cognition of silver in a shell also, he would grasp the validity of that also.

original: tathāca tadviṣayasyāpi rajatādestraikālikābādhyatvaṃ siddhayedityato dṛṣṭaśabdaṃ vyākhyāti dṛḍheti //
analyzed: tathāca tad viṣayasya api rajata ādeḥ traikālika abādhya tvam siddhayet iti atas dṛṣṭa śabdam vyākhyāti dṛḍha iti
translated: And thus the truth of silver and other things which are its objects would be established as being not negated at any time. Therefore, the word 'dṛṣṭa' (seen) is explained as 'dṛḍha' (firm).

analyzed: dṛḍha dṛṣṭam tu yat dṛṣṭam dṛṣṭa ābhāsaḥ param
translated: But what is firmly seen is seen, and what is different from that is the appearance of the seen.

analyzed: yat nirdeṣa tvena avadhṛtayā pratītyā viṣayīkṛtam
translated: What is made the object by a cognition that is ascertained to be faultless.

analyzed: tat eva dṛṣṭam iti uktam
translated: That alone is said to be seen.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why is it so?

analyzed: itarasya sammugdhasya
translated: Because the other mixed

analyzed: dṛṣṭasya dṛṣṭa ābhāsa tvāt
translated: seen is the appearance of the seen.

analyzed: mukhya amukhyayoḥ ca mukhya grahaṇasya nyāyya tvāt
translated: And because it is proper to take the primary when there is a primary and a secondary.

analyzed: kṛta vyutpādanam ca etat prāk  sat pratipakṣāṇi ca dṛśya tva ādi anumānāni iti āśayavān āha bhrānteḥ iti
translated: And this has been explained before.🔽And the inferences based on visibility etc. are countered. With this intention he says 'because of error'.

analyzed: bhrānteḥ saṃvṛti satyasya viśeṣaḥ vyabhicāravān
translated: The distinction of the conventional truth from error is infallible.

original: tenāpyaṅgīkṛtaḥ samyak sa naḥ satyatvameva hi // / /f //
analyzed: tena api aṅgīkṛtaḥ samyak sa naḥ satya tvam eva hi
translated: That is also accepted by us as real, for that is truth itself.

analyzed: bhrānti viṣaya tvena sampratipannāt śukti rajata ādikāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: from the mother-of-pearl, silver etc. which are agreed upon as the object of error.

original: saṃvṛtisatyasya tathātvenābhyupagatasya viśvasya viśeṣo vailakṣaṇyam avyabhicāravān kadācitkvacidapi sampratipannamithyābhāve avartamānaḥ /
analyzed: saṃvṛti satyasya tathātvena abhyupagatasya viśvasya viśeṣaḥ vailakṣaṇyam avyabhicāravān kadācid kvacid api sampratipanna mithyābhāve avartamānaḥ
translated: The peculiarity, i.e., the difference, of the universe, which is accepted as such by the conventional truth, is that which is invariably present, i.e., never absent, even in the case of a generally accepted false existence somewhere at some time.

analyzed: tena śūnyavādinā api
translated: Even by the proponent of emptiness.

analyzed: samyak iti asandehena
translated: Correctly, i.e., without doubt.

analyzed: saḥ eva viśeṣaḥ
translated: That very peculiarity.

original: naḥ asmākaṃ mate viśvasya satyatvaṃ sādhayiṣyatīti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: naḥ asmākam mate viśvasya satya tvam sādhayiṣyati iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Will establish the truth of the universe in our view, is the remainder.

analyzed: tatas sat pratipakṣāṇi dṛśya tva ādi anumānāni iti
translated: Therefore, the inferences based on being perceived, etc., have a valid counter-argument.

original: atra tenāpi samyagaṅgīkṛta ityanena pakṣadharmatā samarthitā /
analyzed: atra tena api samyak aṅgīkṛtaḥ iti anena pakṣa dharma tā samarthitā
translated: Here, by the phrase even that is accepted by him correctly, the property of being the subject is established.

analyzed: avyabhicāravān iti anena tu vyāptiḥ
translated: But by the phrase invariably present, the pervasion is stated.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: viśvam kālatra abādhyam
translated: The universe is not negated by time and circumstances.

analyzed: prātītika vilakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: Because it is different from the conventional.

original: vyatirekeṇa śuktirajatatādivaditi / /🔽nanu ca śuktirajatādīnāṃ prāk śūnyatattvajñānācchuktyādijñānenaiva nivṛttiḥ bhavati /
analyzed: vyatirekeṇa śukti rajata tā ādi vat iti  nanu ca śukti rajata ādīnām prāk śūnya tattva jñānāt śukti ādi jñānena eva nivṛttiḥ bhavati
translated: By the exclusion, like the silverness of nacre, etc.🔽But isn't the cessation of silverness, etc., already brought about by the cognition of nacre, etc., prior to the knowledge of the truth of emptiness?

original: prapañcasya tu śūnyajñānena kadācinnivṛttirbhaviṣyatītyevaṃ mayā prātītikasāṃvṛtayoḥ vailakṣaṇyamaṅgīkṛtam /
analyzed: prapañcasya tu śūnya jñānena kadācid nivṛttiḥ bhaviṣyati iti evam mayā prātītika sāṃvṛtayoḥ vailakṣaṇyam aṅgīkṛtam
translated: But the cessation of the world will occur sometime in the future by the knowledge of emptiness. Thus, I accept the difference between the conventional and the empirical.

analyzed: naca idam viśva satya tve bhavatā hetūkartum śakyam
translated: And this cannot be made a reason for the truth of the universe by you.

analyzed: virodhāt iti atas āha vijñānāt iti
translated: Because of contradiction. Therefore he says: From consciousness, etc.

analyzed: vijñānāt vyabhicāraḥ syāt kadācid syāt iti pramā
translated: There might be an occasional deviation from this consciousness, so it is a valid cognition.

analyzed: na eva dṛṣṭā
translated: It is never seen.
Deviation is cessation.

analyzed: na ayam viśeṣaḥ ṅgīkartum śakyate
translated: This distinction cannot be accepted.

analyzed: a prāmāṇika tvāt  na hi a prāmāṇikena śṛṅgeṇa aśvaḥ nyataḥ viśi
translated: Because it is not based on valid cognition.

analyzed: śeṣyamāṇaḥ dṛśyate iti
translated: For a horse is not seen to be distinguished from another by a horn that is not based on valid cognition.

original: nanvidaṃ kadācidbādhiṣyate dṛśyatvācchuktirajatādivadityanumānasya sattvātkathamatra pramāṇābhāva ityataḥ tasyo
analyzed: nanu idam kadācid bādhiṣyate dṛśya tvāt śukti rajata ādi vat iti anumānasya sattvāt katham atra pramāṇa abhāvaḥ iti atas tasya u
translated: But isn't this sometimes contradicted, because it is seen, like silver in a shell? How then is there absence of valid cognition here? Therefore, that

analyzed: sva uktam doṣam smārayati pramā iti
translated: reminds us of the fault stated by him with valid cognition, etc.

original: pramā sā ca na bhavet svavirodhataḥ // / / //
analyzed: pramā sā ca na bhavet sva virodhataḥ
translated: And that is not valid cognition, because of self-contradiction.

analyzed: yā ca śaṅkayate sā iti arthaḥ  sva virodhataḥ iti
translated: And what is suspected, that is the meaning.🔽Because of self-contradiction means

analyzed: sva viṣayasya svasya ca bādhya tva āpādaka tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: because it causes the object of itself and itself to be refuted.

analyzed: anyathā vyabhicāra āpatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be deviation.

analyzed: yasya viṣayaḥ sanyat
translated: Whose object is different

analyzed: svayam ca bādhyam
translated: and itself is to be refuted,

analyzed: katham tat pramāṇam bhavet
translated: how could that be valid cognition?

original: ato 'sya viśeṣasyāprāmāṇikatvenāṅgīkartumaśakyatve yo 'nyo viśeṣaḥ prāmāṇikaḥ pramāṇāvirodhī cāṅgīkartavyaḥ /
analyzed: viśeṣasya aprāmāṇika tvena aṅgīkartum aśakya tve yaḥ nyaḥ viśeṣaḥ prāmāṇikaḥ pramāṇa avirodhī ca aṅgīkartavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, since this particular [view] cannot be accepted as being unestablished, another particular [view] that is established by valid means of knowledge and is not contradicted by valid means of knowledge must be accepted.

analyzed: saḥ smākam satya tve hetuḥ bhaviṣyati iti
translated: That will be the reason for our [view of] truth.

analyzed: sa ca pramāṇa gamya tvam arthakriyā kāri tvam ca iti hṛdayam
translated: And that is being known by valid means of knowledge and performing a function - this is the heart [of the matter].

analyzed: nanu tarhi evam eva kutas nā ucyate
translated: But then why is it not stated in this way?

original: tathocyamāne pramāṇānāṃ tattvāvedakatvamatharkriyāyāḥ sattvamasati tadabhāva ityādi bahu saṃvidheyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā ucyamāne pramāṇānām tattva āvedaka tvam atha ṛkriyāyāḥ sattvam asati tad abhāve ityādi bahu saṃvidheyam syāt
translated: If it is stated in this way, many things would have to be stated, such as the fact that the valid means of knowledge truly reveal [reality], that a function exists, and that it does not exist if that [valid means of knowledge] does not exist.

analyzed: lāghava artham tu evam uktam
translated: But it is stated in this way for the sake of brevity.

analyzed: tat api yathāvasaram upapāditam eva
translated: And that has also been explained as appropriate.

analyzed: yat vā prapañcasya abādhya tve pariśeṣa pramāṇam anena uktam
translated: Or, by this [verse], a valid means of knowledge by elimination is stated regarding the unreality of the world.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

analyzed: jagataḥ bādhya tvam abādhya tvam ca prasaktam
translated: The reality and unreality of the world are possible.

analyzed: tṛtīya prakāra abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no third possibility.

analyzed: bādhya tvam ca prasiddha padārtha tattva jñānena anyena vā
translated: And reality is known by the true nature of well-known objects, or by something else.

analyzed: tatra ādyam vādi prativādibhyām anabhyupagamāt
translated: Among them, the first [view] is not accepted by the proponent and the opponent.

analyzed: dvitīyam tu pramāṇa abhāva nirastam
translated: But the second [view] is refuted by the absence of valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: pariśeṣāt abādhya tvam eva siddhayati iti
translated: Therefore, non-sublation alone is established by the remainder.

analyzed: athavā vyāpaka anupalabdhi liṅgakam anumānam anena
translated: Or, this [verse] is an inference based on the logical mark of the non-apprehension of the pervasion.

analyzed: etena śloka dvayena uktam
translated: This is stated by these two verses.

analyzed: bādhya tvam hi vyāptam
translated: Sublatability is pervaded by the nature of being the object of knowledge of the truth that is different from the well-known object.

original: tacca vyāpakamanabhyupagamapramāṇābhāvābhyāṃ jagato vyāvartamānaṃ svavyāpyaṃ bādhyatvamiti vyāvartayati /🔽evaṃ prapañcamithyātvānumānāni nirākṛtyedānīṃ tadanugrāhakatvena /
analyzed: tat ca vyāpakam anabhyupagama pramāṇa abhāvābhyām jagataḥ vyāvartamānam sva vyāpyam bādhya tvam iti vyāvartayati  evam prapañca mithyātva anumānāni nirākṛtya idānīm tad anugrāhaka tvena
translated: And that pervasion, being excluded from the world by the absence of acceptance and the absence of valid cognition, excludes its own pervaded sublatability.

original: satyatvapratyakṣasya pratikūlatvena ca parotprekṣitaṃ tarkamapi nirākartumāśaṅkate bheda iti //
analyzed: satya tva pratyakṣasya pratikūla tvena ca para utprekṣitam tarkam api nirākartum āśaṅkate bhedaḥ iti
translated: Having thus refuted the inferences of the falsity of the world, he now doubts the reasoning imagined by others, which supports that and opposes the perception of truth.🔽He says difference and so on.

analyzed: bhedaḥ viśeṣya dharmi ādi grahaṇa apekṣayā yadi  anyonya āśraya tā hetoḥ durgāhyaḥ iti yan
translated: If difference depends on the apprehension of the qualified, the substratum, and so on,🔽then the reason of mutual dependence is difficult to understand, as stated in the commentary.

analyzed: ādi padena viśeṣaṇa pratiyāginoḥ grahaṇam
translated: The word and so on includes the qualifier and the cognition of the qualified.

analyzed: yadi gṛhyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is if it is apprehended.

analyzed: tarhi iti ca
translated: And then [is used].

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: yadi prapañco sāṃvṛto na syāttadā pratyakṣo 'pyasau na syāt /
analyzed: yadi prapañcaḥ sāṃvṛtaḥ na syāt tadā pratyakṣaḥ pi asau na syāt
translated: If the world were not conventional, then it would not even be perceptible.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: This is because:

original: anekamedabhinno hi prapañca iṣyate /🔽bhedasya cāpratyakṣatāyāṃ so 'pyapratyakṣa eva /
analyzed: aneka meda bhinnaḥ hi prapañcaḥ iṣyate  bhedasya ca apratyakṣa tāyām saḥ pi apratyakṣaḥ eva
translated: For the world is held to be divided into many parts.🔽And when difference is not perceived, that [world] is also not perceived.

analyzed: vinā bhedena tad pratītau advitīya śūnya pratīti āpatteḥ
translated: For if it were perceived without difference, there would be the absurd consequence of the perception of a non-dual void.

original: naca bhedapratītirupapadyate /🔽bhedo hi pratīyamāno ghaṭapaṭau bhinnāviti ghaṭapaṭayovirśeṣaṇatayā /
analyzed: na ca bheda pratītiḥ upapadyate  bhedaḥ hi pratīyamānaḥ ghaṭa paṭau bhinnau iti ghaṭa paṭayoḥ virśeṣaṇa tayā
translated: And the perception of difference is not possible.🔽For if difference were perceived, it would have to be perceived either as the qualifier of pot and cloth, as in pot and cloth are different,

original: ghaṭapaṭayorbheda iti tābhyāṃ viśeṣyatayā vā pratyetavyaḥ /
analyzed: ghaṭa paṭayoḥ bhedaḥ iti tābhyām viśeṣya tayā vā pratyetavyaḥ
translated: or as the qualified by them, as in the difference of pot and cloth.

original: bheda ityeva pratīterabhāvāt /🔽yadvā ghaṭātpaṭo bhinna iti /
analyzed: bhedaḥ iti eva pratīteḥ abhāvāt  yat vā ghaṭāt paṭaḥ bhinnaḥ iti
translated: Because there is no perception of difference as difference alone.🔽Or [it would have to be perceived] as cloth is different from pot,

original: ghaṭātpaṭasya bheda iti vā ghaṭapratiyogitayā paṭadharmikatayā ca bhedagrahaṇameṣyavyam /
analyzed: ghaṭāt paṭasya bhedaḥ iti vā ghaṭa pratiyogi tayā paṭa dharmika tayā ca bheda grahaṇam eṣyavyam
translated: or as the difference of cloth from pot, that is, the apprehension of difference must be as having pot as its counter-correlate and cloth as its substratum.

analyzed: tatra ubhayatra api anyonya āśraya tvam
translated: In both cases, there is mutual dependence.

original: viśeṣyayorghaṭapaṭayorjñāne sati hi tadviśeṣaṇatayā bhedo jñātavyaḥ /
analyzed: viśeṣyayoḥ ghaṭa paṭayoḥ jñāne sati hi tad viśeṣaṇa tayā bhedaḥ jñātavyaḥ
translated: For difference must be known as the qualifier of those two, pot and cloth, when there is knowledge of those two, the qualified.

original: nahi devadattādarśane daṇḍasya tadviśeṣaṇatayā darśanaṃ yujyate /
analyzed: nahi devadatta adarśane daṇḍasya tad viśeṣaṇa tayā darśanam yujyate
translated: For it is not possible to see a stick as the qualifier of it when Devadatta is not seen.

analyzed: viśeṣya jñānam ca bheda apekṣam
translated: And the knowledge of the qualified depends on difference.

analyzed: nahi bheda apratītau ghaṭa paṭau iti dvi tva viśiṣṭa artha pratītiḥ sambhavati
translated: For, when difference is not apprehended, the cognition of an object qualified by duality, as in 'jar and cloth', is not possible.

analyzed: evam viśeṣya tayā bheda pratītau api draṣṭavyam
translated: The same should be understood when difference is apprehended as the qualifier.

analyzed: tathā dharmi pratiyogi jñāne sati bheda jñānam tad nirūpya tvāt
translated: Similarly, when the substratum and the counter-correlate are known, there is knowledge of difference, because it is dependent on them.

analyzed: bheda jñāne eva
translated: And when there is knowledge of difference,

analyzed: ne sati ca dharmi pratiyoginoḥ jñānam
translated: there is knowledge of the substratum and the counter-correlate.

original: nahi bhedāgrahe dharmipratiyogibhāvo 'vagantuṃ śakyate /🔽tathātve ghaṭādghaṭasya bhedaityapi
analyzed: nahi bheda agrahe dharmi pratiyogi bhāvaḥ vagantum śakyate  tathātve ghaṭāt ghaṭasya bhedaḥ eti api
translated: For, when difference is not apprehended, the relation of substratum and counter-correlate cannot be understood.

analyzed: pratītiḥ syāt
translated: If it were so, there would be the cognition 'the difference of the jar from the jar' also.

analyzed: na ca paraspara āśrayāṇi kāryāṇi sambhavanti
translated: And effects cannot be mutually dependent.

original: ato vāstavatve bhedasya pratītyanupapattau prapañcasyāpi tadāpatteravicāritaramaṇīyaḥ saṃvṛtibhaya evāyamaṅgīkaraṇīya iti /
analyzed: atas vāstava tve bhedasya pratīti anupapattau prapañcasya api tad āpatteḥ avicārita ramaṇīyaḥ saṃvṛti bhayaḥ eva ayam aṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, if difference were real, there would be the undesirable consequence of the impossibility of the cognition of difference, and also of the world. Hence, this should be accepted only as a delightful convention, not examined.

analyzed: nirākaroti na iti
translated: He refutes this with 'No'.

analyzed: na tat
translated: That is not so.

analyzed: yat uktam bhedasya durgrāhya tvam tat na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no difficulty in apprehending difference.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha svarūpam iti
translated: How is that? To this he says 'The form' etc.🔽The form of an object is its difference.

analyzed: svarūpam vastunaḥ
translated: The difference in the nature of a thing is...🔽...

original: yat yasmādbhedo vastunaḥ svarūpaṃ tasmāt tasya vastuno grahe
analyzed: yat yasmāt bhedaḥ vastunaḥ svarūpam tasmāt tasya vastunaḥ grahe
translated: Because difference is the nature of an entity, when that entity is apprehended,

analyzed: sati paścāt bheda grahaḥ iti na asti
translated: when it is grasped, then afterwards there is the grasping of the difference. Thus, there is no [mutual dependence].

analyzed: kintu vastu grahaḥ eva bheda grahaḥ
translated: But rather, the grasping of the difference is itself the grasping of the entity.

original: tathāca kvānyonyāśrayatvaṃ yena bhedo durgrahaḥ syāditi /
analyzed: tathā ca kva anyonya āśraya tvam yena bhedaḥ durgrahaḥ syāt iti
translated: And so, where is the mutual dependence by which the difference would be difficult to grasp?

analyzed: yat na tasya grahe grahaḥ
translated: Because when it is grasped, it is not grasped.

original: yasmādvastuno grahe tasya bhedasyāgraho nāsti tasmādbhedo vastunaḥ svarūpamiti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt vastunaḥ grahe tasya bhedasya agrahaḥ na asti tasmāt bhedaḥ vastunaḥ svarūpam iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Because when the entity is grasped, there is no non-grasping of that difference, therefore the difference is the nature of the entity. This is the connection.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

original: vimato bhedo ghaṭasvarūpaṃ bhavitumarhati ghaṭagrahe 'gṛhyamāṇatvarahitatvāt ghaṭasvarūpavadeveti /
analyzed: vimataḥ bhedaḥ ghaṭa svarūpam bhavitum arhati ghaṭa grahe gṛhyamāṇa tva rahita tvāt ghaṭa svarūpa vat eva iti
translated: The difference in question deserves to be the nature of the pot, because it is devoid of being ungrasped when the pot is grasped, just like the nature of the pot itself.

original: yadi atra tasya grahe gṛhyamāṇatvādityevocyeta tadā ghaṭapaṭāviti ghaṭajñānena jñāyamānena paṭenānaikāntikatvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi atra tasya grahe gṛhyamāṇa tvāt iti eva ucyeta tadā ghaṭa paṭau iti ghaṭa jñānena jñāyamānena paṭena anaikāntika tvam syāt
translated: If here it is said simply because it is grasped when it is grasped, then there would be inconclusiveness with respect to the cloth that is known by the cognition of the pot and cloth.

analyzed: tad artham tasya grahe grahaḥ naḥ iti uktam
translated: For that reason, it is said when it is grasped, it is not grasped.

original: nahi ghaṭagrahe gṛhyamāṇo 'pi paṭo ghaṭagrahe sarvathā gṛhyata eveti niyamo 'sti /
analyzed: nahi ghaṭa grahe gṛhyamāṇaḥ pi paṭaḥ ghaṭa grahe sarvathā gṛhyate eva iti niyamaḥ sti
translated: For when the cloth is grasped when the pot is grasped, there is no rule that it is completely grasped by the grasping of the pot.

original: yajjñāne yatsarvathopalabhyate tattatsvarūpamiti vyāptāvucyamānāyāṃ daṇḍijñāne daṇḍo 'pyavaśyaṃ sphuratyeva /
analyzed: yat jñāne yat sarvathā upalabhyate tat tat svarūpam iti vyāptau ucyamānāyām daṇḍi jñāne daṇḍaḥ pi avaśyam sphurati eva
translated: When it is said that whatever is perceived in a cognition in any way is of the nature of that, then in the cognition of a man with a stick, the stick also certainly appears.

analyzed: na ca asau daṇḍinaḥ svarūpam iti atas viśeṣa niṣṭhā eva vyāptiḥ abhidhātavyā
translated: And that is not the nature of the man with the stick. Therefore, the pervasion should be stated to be restricted to the particular.

original: kiñca viśiṣṭaṃ nāma viśeṣaṇasambandhanimitto viśeṣyasyākārabheda iti pī na viśiṣṭapratyaye viśeṣaṇasphuraṇamasti /
analyzed: kiñca viśiṣṭam nāma viśeṣaṇa sambandha nimittaḥ viśeṣyasya ākāra bhedaḥ iti na viśiṣṭa pratyaye viśeṣaṇa sphuraṇam asti
translated: Moreover, what is called qualified is the difference in the form of the qualified due to the relation of the qualifier. Therefore, in the cognition of the qualified, there is no appearance of the qualifier.

analyzed: kinnāma viśeṣaṇa jñānam viśiṣṭa jñāna kāraṇam
translated: Rather, the knowledge of the qualifier is the cause of the knowledge of the qualified.

analyzed: āśu bhāvāt ca na kramaḥ lakṣyate
translated: And because of its rapidity, the sequence is not observed.

original: yadvā ghaṭabhedau pakṣīkṛtya niyamenānyatarapratītāvanyatarasya sphuraṇenānyonyābhinnatvaṃ sādhyam /🔽nahi daṇḍipratītau daṇḍasya
analyzed: yat vā ghaṭa bhedau pakṣīkṛtya niyamena anyatara pratītau anyatarasya sphuraṇena anyonya abhinna tvam sādhyam  nahi daṇḍi pratītau daṇḍasya
translated: Or, taking the pot and its difference as the subject, their mutual non-difference is to be proved by the appearance of one when the other is invariably cognized.🔽For, even when the man with a stick is cognized,

analyzed: sphuraṇe pi
translated: the stick does not appear.🔽But when the stick is cognized, the man with the stick

analyzed: daṇḍa pratītau sarvathā daṇḍinaḥ  sphuraṇam asti iti
translated: appears in every way.

analyzed: bhavet etat yadi bhedaḥ vastu grahaḥ eva gṛhyeta
translated: This would be so if difference were grasped only in the apprehension of the thing.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: kinnāma vastu pratīti uttara kālam eva
translated: Rather, it is only after the apprehension of the thing.

analyzed: nirvikalpake hi
translated: For in the indeterminate cognition,

analyzed: ca pratyaye vastu mātram avabhāsate
translated: In the cognition of difference, only the thing is manifested.

analyzed: bhedaḥ ta vastu darśana uttara kālam pratiyogi smaraṇe sati avabhāsate
translated: The difference is manifested after the perception of the thing, when the recollection of the counter-correlate is present.

analyzed: yathā sādṛśyam abhāvaḥ ca iti atas āha anyathā iti
translated: Like similarity and non-existence. Therefore he says otherwise.

original: anyathāsyāmunā bheda iti vaktuṃ na yujyate // / / //🔽yadi bhedo vastupratītau na pratīyeta tadāsyāmunā bheda ityuttarakālaṃ savikalpakavi
analyzed: anyathā asya amunā bhedaḥ iti vaktum na yujyate  yadi bhedaḥ vastu pratītau na pratīyeta tadā asya amunā bhedaḥ iti uttara kālam sa vikalpa kavi
translated: Otherwise, it is not proper to say 'this is different from that'.

analyzed: jñānam api na jāyeta
translated: If difference were not cognized in the perception of the thing, then even the subsequent determinate cognition this is different from that would not arise.

analyzed: tathā ca tathā vyavahāraḥ pi na syāt
translated: And thus, the corresponding usage would also not be possible.

analyzed: asya amunā iti hi
translated: For this and that

analyzed: dharmi pratiyogitayā vastu dvayam uddiśya bhedaḥ jñāyate
translated: difference is known by indicating two things as the substratum and the counter-correlate.

analyzed: na ca agṛhīta bhedam tathā uddeṣyum śakyate
translated: And that cannot be indicated without the cognition of difference.

analyzed: ekasmin api tad prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would lead to the same [error] even in the case of one [thing].

analyzed: bheda sattā mātreṇa tad upapattiḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is possible by the mere existence of difference, that is not so.

analyzed: dūra stha vanaspatyoḥ abheda pratyaya abhāva prasaṅgāt  doṣāt tatra tathā iti ced na
translated: Because it would lead to the absence of the cognition of non-difference in the case of distant trees.🔽If it is argued that it is so due to a fault [in the cognition], that is not so.
