analyzed: bhedasya svarūpa sattayā eva upayoge doṣasya akiñcitkara tvāt iti
translated: Because if difference is useful only by its own existence, the fault would be ineffective.

original: na kevalaṃ vastudarśane bhedasphuraṇamanabhyupagacchato 'syāmunā bheda iti paścātkālīnaṃ savikalpakajñānaṃ tathā vyavahāraśca nopapadyate /🔽kiṃ tarhītyata āha agṛhīta iti //
analyzed: na kevalam vastu darśane bheda sphuraṇam anabhyupagacchataḥ syām amunā bhedaḥ iti paścātkālīnam savikalpaka jñānam tathā vyavahāraḥ ca nā upapadyate  kim tarhi iti atas āha agṛhītaḥ iti
translated: Not only is the subsequent determinate cognition and usage this is different from that not possible for one who does not accept the manifestation of difference in the perception of an object,

analyzed: agṛhītaḥ yadā bhedaḥ tadā svasmāt iti grahaḥ
translated: but what then? Therefore it is said: When difference is not apprehended, then there is the apprehension 'from itself'.

analyzed: syāt
translated: It would be so.

analyzed: yadi ghaṭa darśane tad bhedaḥ na dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: If even in the perception of the pot, its difference is not seen, then

original: nantaraṃ smaryamāṇaro gṛhyamāṇo vā pratiyogī paṭo 'pi vinā bhedenopalabdhavyaḥ /
analyzed: nantaram gṛhyamāṇaḥ vā pratiyogī vinā bhedena upalabdhavyaḥ
translated: the subsequent object of memory or perception, the counter-correlate cloth, would also have to be perceived without difference.

analyzed: bheda adarśane ca avaśyam abheda jñānam syāt
translated: And in the absence of the perception of difference, the knowledge of non-difference would necessarily be there.

original: tathā cottarakālaṃ svasmātsvayaṃ bhinna iti savikalpako bhedagrahaḥ syāditi /
analyzed: tathā ca uttara kālam svasmāt svayam bhinnaḥ iti sa vikalpakaḥ bheda grahaḥ syāt iti
translated: And in that case, the subsequent determinate apprehension of difference as from itself, it is different would be there.

analyzed: asu evam iti atas āha prati iti iti
translated: Not so, therefore it is said: Because of the contradiction with experience.

analyzed: pratīti virodhāt ca
translated: And because of the contradiction with experience.

analyzed: caśabdasya uttaratra sambandhaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) is connected with what follows.

original: paṭādghaṭo bhinna ityeva hi savikalpikā pratītiranubhūyate /
analyzed: paṭāt ghaṭaḥ bhinnaḥ iti eva hi sa vikalpikā pratītiḥ anubhūyate
translated: For indeed, the determinate cognition the pot is different from the cloth is experienced.

analyzed: na jātu svasmāt svayam bhinnaḥ iti
translated: Never from itself, it is different.

original: ataḥ pratītivirodhādevaṃvidhaḥ savikalpakagraho nāṅgīkartumucita iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: atas pratīti virodhāt evaṃvidhaḥ savikalpaka grahaḥ na aṅgīkartum ucitaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, such a determinate perception is not proper to be accepted, because it contradicts experience.

original: kiñca yadi svasvātsvayaṃ bhinna iti savikalpako bhedagrahaḥ syāt /
analyzed: kiñca yadi sva svāt svayam bhinnaḥ iti sa vikalpakaḥ bheda grahaḥ syāt
translated: Moreover, if there were a determinate perception grasping difference as different from itself,

analyzed: tadā kadācid tathāvidhaḥ syāt  na ca evam iti āha nahi iti
translated: then at some time there would be such verbal usage.🔽But it is not so, he says: No one would ever say...

analyzed: nahi kaścid tathā vadet
translated: No one would ever say...

analyzed: etena kimika pratīti virodhaḥ uta sarva pratīti virodhaḥ
translated: By this, is it a contradiction of some people's experience or of all people's experience?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ vyabhicārāt
translated: Not the first, because of inapplicability.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second,

analyzed: asiddheḥ iti api parāstam
translated: because of non-establishment.

original: kadāpi kasyacidapi tathā vyavahārābhāvena viparītavyavahāreṇa ca sarvapratītisiddheriti /
analyzed: kadāpi kasyacid api tathā vyavahāra abhāvena viparīta vyavahāreṇa ca sarva pratīti siddheḥ iti
translated: Because there is no such usage by anyone at any time, and because all people's experience is established by contrary usage.

analyzed: atas vastu pratītau eva bhedasya sphuraṇāt tad svarūpa tvam eva iti
translated: Therefore, since difference manifests only in the cognition of the thing, it is indeed of the nature of that [thing].

analyzed: nanu evam bhedasya vastu svarūpa tvena tad pratīti bheda abhāvāt itaretara sāpekṣa tvasya sutarām abhāvāt na anyonya āśraya tvam iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that if difference is the nature of the thing, and there is no difference in the cognition of that, then mutual dependence is completely absent, and therefore there is no mutual dependence.

analyzed: tatra kim bhedaḥ dharmiṇaḥ svarūpam
translated: There, is difference the nature of the substratum?

analyzed: uta pratiyoginaḥ pi
translated: Or is it also the nature of the counter-correlate?

analyzed: na tāvat dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: ekasya eva bhedasya ubhaya svarūpa tve dvaita prasaṅgāt  ādye tu yadi api dharmi jñāna bheda jñānayoḥ na anyonya āśraya tvam
translated: For if a single difference has both forms, non-duality would follow.🔽But in the first case, although the knowledge of the substratum and the knowledge of the difference are not mutually dependent,

analyzed: tathā api pratiyogi jñāna apekṣayā anyonya āśraya tvam katham pariharaṇīyam
translated: how can mutual dependence be avoided in relation to the knowledge of the counter-correlate?

analyzed: mā evam  bhedasya svarūpataḥ jñāne pratiyogi viśeṣa jñāna anapekṣaṇāt
translated: Not so.🔽Because when the difference is known as its own form, knowledge of a particular counter-correlate is not required.

analyzed: pratiyogi svarūpa jñāne ca etad bheda jñāna anapekṣaṇāt
translated: And when the form of the counter-correlate is known, knowledge of this difference is not required.

analyzed: astu tarhi viśeṣa jñāne nyonya āśraya tvam
translated: Then let there be mutual dependence in the knowledge of the particular.

analyzed: tat hi ghaṭāt paṭaḥ bhinnaḥ iti utpadyate
translated: For that arises as The cloth is different from the pot.

original: tatra dhamirṇo bhedena pratipannasya vā pratiyogitā / anyathā vā /
analyzed: tatra dhamirṇaḥ bhedena pratipannasya vā pratiyogitā anyathā vā
translated: There, either the substratum is the counter-correlate when it is cognized as different, or otherwise.

analyzed: na tāvat dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: svatas pi bheda pratīti āpatteḥ
translated: Because the cognition of difference would follow even from itself.

original: ādye pratiyogisvarūpabhedapratītau dharmiṇaḥ pratiyogitāyāṃ sa eva nyāyaḥ /
analyzed: ādye pratiyogi svarūpa bheda pratītau dharmiṇaḥ pratiyogitāyām saḥ eva nyāyaḥ
translated: In the first case, when the form of the counter-correlate and the difference are cognized, the same reasoning applies to the substratum being the counter-correlate.

analyzed: tathā ca paṭāt ghaṭasya bheda pratītau ghaṭāt paṭasya bheda pratītiḥ iti anyonya āśraya tvam iti
translated: And so, when the difference of the pot from the cloth is cognized, the difference of the cloth from the pot is cognized, so there is mutual dependence.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

original: vastuto 'nyonyapratiyogikayorghaṭapaṭasvarūpabhedayoḥ pratītayoḥ satorasati sādṛśyādau pratibandhake 'nyonyapratiyogikatayā viśiṣṭabhedapratītau
analyzed: vastutas nyonya pratiyogikayoḥ ghaṭa paṭa sva rūpa bhedayoḥ pratītayoḥ satoḥ asati sādṛśya ādau pratibandhake nyonya pratiyogika tayā viśiṣṭa bheda pratītau
translated: In reality, when the differences in the forms of pot and cloth, which are mutually opposed, are cognized, and when there is no obstruction like similarity, etc., in the cognition of the difference qualified by mutual opposition,

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt iti
translated: there is no contradiction.

original: evaṃ svamatena bhedapratītāvanyonyāśrayatvaṃ parihṛtya bhinnabhedavādināṃ parihāramāha dharmitveti //🔽dharmitvapratiyogitvatadbhedā yugapad yadi /
analyzed: evam sva matena bheda pratītau anyonya āśraya tvam parihṛtya bhinna bheda vādinām parihāram āha dharmi tva iti
translated: Thus, having avoided the mutual dependence in the cognition of difference according to his own view, he states the solution of those who assert different differences as the nature of the subject etc.🔽If the nature of the subject, the nature of the counter-correlate, and their difference are grasped simultaneously,

analyzed: viśeṣaṇam viśeṣyam ca tad bhāvaḥ ca eva gṛhyate
translated: then the qualifier and the qualified, and their existence, are also grasped.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat  dharmi pratiyoginau ca iti api
translated: And this is a mere indication.

analyzed: ti draṣṭavyam
translated: And the subject and the counter-correlate should also be seen.

analyzed: tad bhāvaḥ viśeṣaṇa tvam viśeṣya tvam ca
translated: Their existence means the nature of the qualifier and the qualified.

analyzed: atra viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ anyatara tvāt bhedasya pṛthak grahaṇa abhāvaḥ
translated: Here, the difference is not grasped separately because it is either the qualifier or the qualified.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: kim nirvikalpaka pratītau anyonya āśraya tvam ucyate uta savikalpaka pratītau
translated: Is the mutual dependence being stated in the non-conceptual cognition or in the conceptual cognition?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: tatra dharmi pratiyogi svarūpayoḥ tad bhāvayoḥ tad bhedasya bhedayoḥ vā yugapad ubhaya
translated: There, the nature of the subject and the counter-correlate, their existence, and their difference, or the two differences, are grasped simultaneously.

analyzed: davabhāsanāt  tathā viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya
translated: Because of the illumination of the fire.

analyzed: bhūtabhāva
translated: Similarly, the difference between the two things, the qualified and the qualifier,

analyzed: yoḥ ghaṭa paṭayoḥ bhedasya ca tad bhāvayoḥ ca yugapad pratīteḥ  yugapad eva
translated: such as a pot and a cloth, and the existence of those two, are cognized simultaneously.

analyzed: sarvasya indriya sannikṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because everything is in contact with the senses simultaneously.

analyzed: darśana yogya tvāt ca  nanu dharmi pratiyoginoḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ ca
translated: And because it is fit to be seen.

analyzed: paraḥ bhinna bheda vādibhiḥ na iṣyate
translated: But the existence of that, which is different from the substratum, the counter-correlate, the qualifier and the qualified, is not accepted by the proponents of different differences.

analyzed: tat katham etat
translated: How is this so?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: bhūṣaṇakāra ādibhiḥ tasya aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because it is accepted by Bhūṣaṇakāra and others.

analyzed: teṣām eva ca ayam parihāraḥ iti
translated: And this is the very answer of those [Bhūṣaṇakāra and others].

original: nanu yatra pratiyogī paścātpratīyate tatra yugapadavabhāso nāstīti taddṛṣṭāntena sarvatrāpyevamanumīyata iti cenna /
analyzed: nanu yatra pratiyogī paścāt pratīyate tatra yugapad avabhāsaḥ na asti iti tad dṛṣṭāntena sarvatra api evam anumīyate iti ced na
translated: But if it is argued that where the counter-correlate is cognized later, there is no simultaneous appearance, and by that example it is inferred to be so in all cases, it is not so.

analyzed: asannihita vat sannihitasya api ajñāna sādhane
translated: Because there is contradiction in establishing the non-cognition of the present as if it were absent.

original: yatracapratiyogī na sannihitastatrāpi dharmidharmitvabhedānāṃ tāvadyugapatpratītirnānupapannā /🔽tadidamuktam ko virodha iti //
analyzed: yatra ca pratiyogī na sannihitaḥ tatra api dharmi dharmi tva bhedānām tāvat yugapad pratītiḥ na anupapannā  tat idam uktam kaḥ virodhaḥ iti
translated: And even where the counter-correlate is not present, the simultaneous cognition of the substratum, the property-possessor, the property, and the difference is not impossible.🔽This is what is meant by saying What is the contradiction?

analyzed: kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: What is the contradiction?

analyzed: dvitīyam nirākaroti sva rūpeṇa iti
translated: The second [view] is refuted by [the statement] By its own form...

analyzed: sva rūpeṇa gṛhītaḥ bhedaḥ eva tu
translated: But the difference is grasped by its own form.

analyzed: asya amuṣmāt iti punar viśeṣeṇa eva gṛhyate
translated: But again, it is grasped by a particular distinction, as 'this from that.'

analyzed: asya amuṣmāt iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: 'This from that' is an illustration.

analyzed: anayoḥ bhedaḥ bhinnau imau iti api grāhyam
translated: It should also be understood that 'the difference between these two' means 'these two are different.'

analyzed: nivirkalpaka pratīta arthānām anyonya vaiśiṣyaya mātram savikalpaka jñāne vabhāsate na adhikam iti na tatra api itaretarāśraya tvam iti
translated: In the cognition of objects without conceptual construction, only the mutual distinction appears in the conceptual cognition, not anything more. Thus there is no mutual dependence there.

analyzed: tathā ca āhuḥ bhinna bheda vādinaḥ
translated: And thus say those who advocate the difference of difference.

original: ekasyāmeva nirvikalpikāyāṃ saṃvidi bhedasya bhedinośca yugapadavabhāsane sati tatraikaṃ bhedinamavadhiṃ kṛtvai
analyzed: ekasyām eva nirvikalpikāyām saṃvidi bhedasya bhedinoḥ ca yugapad avabhāsane sati tatra ekam bhedinam avadhim
translated: When difference and the different appear simultaneously in the same non-conceptual cognition, taking one of the different as the limit,

analyzed: dhīkṛtya etasmāt ayam bhinnaḥ iti savikalpaka bodha udayāt katham
translated: taking that as the basis, the conceptual cognition arises, 'This is different from that.' How then
is there not mutual dependence in the view of difference as non-distinct?

analyzed: nanu kimartham ayam paramata upanyāsaḥ
translated: But why is this statement of the opponent's view?

analyzed: bheda pārthakyam antareṇa viśeṣa pratītau asmākam api evam e
translated: In order to show that even for us, in the apprehension of distinction without the distinctness of difference,

analyzed: pi ayam eva parihāraḥ iti jñāpana artham
translated: this same answer is applicable.

analyzed: tarhi idam eva vākyam tathā vyākhyāyatām
translated: Then let this very statement be explained in that way.

analyzed: śaṃśakyam
translated: This cannot be said.

analyzed: tad bhedaḥ ca iti pṛthak bheda grahaṇa virodhāt
translated: And because it contradicts the separate mention of difference.

original: viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvena grahaṇamapi na dharmipratiyogiprakārādbhidyata iti vaiśeṣikaparīkṣāyāmuktam /
analyzed: viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvena grahaṇam api na dharmi pratiyogi prakārāt bhidyate iti vaiśeṣika parīkṣāyām uktam
translated: It has been said in the examination of the Vaiśeṣika that the apprehension in the form of qualifier and qualified does not differ from the form of the substratum and its opposite.

analyzed: atas na atra vyutpādanam api kṛtam iti
translated: Therefore, no explanation has been given here either.

analyzed: evam āpādaka anabhyupagamena anyonya āśraya tva prasaṅgam nirākṛtya idānīm dūṣaṇa antaram pratijānīte kiñca iti
translated: Having thus refuted the logical fallacy of mutual dependence by not accepting the reason, he now promises another fault, saying and also (in the verse).

analyzed: kiñca
translated: And also...

analyzed: anyat ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: something else.

analyzed: katham iti ced
translated: If it is asked how,

original: kimatra yadi dharmyādipratītyapekṣayā bhedaḥ pratīyeta tadānyonyāśrayatvaṃ syādityā
analyzed: kim atra yadi dharmi ādi pratīti apekṣayā bhedaḥ pratīyeta tadā anyonya āśraya tvam syāt iti ā
translated: here if it is supposed that difference is apprehended in dependence on the apprehension of the substratum etc., then mutual dependence would result.

analyzed: ti eva āpādyate
translated: Is this the consequence?

original: kiṃvā yadi bhedaḥ pratīyeta tadānyonyāśrayatvaṃ syāditi /
analyzed: kiṃvā yadi bhedaḥ pratīyeta tadā anyonya āśraya tvam syāt iti
translated: Or if it is supposed that difference is apprehended, then mutual dependence would result.

analyzed: ādye doṣam āha bhedaḥ iti
translated: If the first, he states the fault, saying difference (in the verse).

original: bhedaḥ kathaṃ grāhya iti yaḥ paripṛcchati /
analyzed: bhedaḥ katham grāhyaḥ iti yaḥ paripṛcchati
translated: One who asks how is difference to be grasped?

analyzed: dharmya ādi bheda grahaṇāt tena uktaḥ nyonya saṃśrayaḥ
translated: By the apprehension of the difference of the substratum etc., the mutual dependence is stated by him.

analyzed: katham iti ākṣepe
translated: How? is a question.🔽Asks is a mild expression.

analyzed: paripṛcchati iti mṛdu uktiḥ 🔽ākṣipati iti yāvat
translated: It means accuses.

analyzed: dharmi ādi bheda grahaṇāt dharmi ādi grahaṇa sāpekṣa bheda grahaṇāt
translated: Because the apprehension of difference depends on the apprehension of the substratum, etc.

analyzed: katham idam labhyate  dharmi ādi padasya tad grahaṇa upalakṣaṇa tvāt
translated: How is this understood?🔽Because the word 'substratum' etc. is a mere indication of that [apprehension].

analyzed: ādi padasya ca kāraṇa arthasya avṛtteḥ
translated: And because the word 'etc.' does not occur in the sense of cause.

analyzed: tat etat parasparam vyāhatam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: This is mutually contradictory, is the remainder.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

original: bhedo durgraha iti pratijñāya tadupapattaye hīdamucyate /
analyzed: bhedaḥ durgrahaḥ iti pratijñāya tad upapattaye hi idam ucyate
translated: Having declared that difference is difficult to apprehend, this is said to establish that.

original: anena ca yadi bhedo dharmyādipratītimapekṣya pratīyeta tadānyonyāśrayatvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: anena ca yadi bhedaḥ dharmi ādi pratītim apekṣya pratīyeta tadā anyonya āśraya tvam syāt
translated: And by this, if difference were apprehended in dependence on the apprehension of the substratum, etc., then there would be mutual dependence.

original: tathāca na pratīyetetyāpādanena pratīyate cāto na dharmyādigrahaṇāpekṣā tatpratītiriti labdhaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: tathāca na pratīyeta iti āpādanena pratīyate ca atas na dharmya ādi grahaṇa apekṣā tad pratītiḥ iti labdham bhavet
translated: And thus it would not be apprehended. By the reductio, it is apprehended. Therefore, it would be established that the apprehension of that [difference] does not depend on the apprehension of the substratum, etc.

analyzed: durgrahaḥ pratīyate ca
translated: And thus, 'difference is difficult to apprehend' and 'it is apprehended'.

analyzed: iti etayoḥ katham na pūrva uttara virodhaḥ iti
translated: How is there no contradiction between these two statements?

analyzed: dvitīye pṛcchāmaḥ
translated: In the second [alternative], we ask:

original: kiṃ pareṇa kvāpi bhedo na gṛhītaḥ kiṃvā kvacidgṛhīta iti /
analyzed: kim pareṇa kvāpi bhedaḥ na gṛhītaḥ kiṃvā kvacid gṛhītaḥ iti
translated: Has difference never been apprehended by the opponent anywhere, or has it been apprehended somewhere?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati anyatva iti
translated: He refutes the first [alternative] with 'If difference is not apprehended'.

analyzed: anyatva agrahaṇe proktaḥ katham anyonya saṃśrayaḥ
translated: If difference is not apprehended, how can there be mutual dependence?

original: yadyanyatvaṃ kvāpi na gṛhītaṃ tadānyonyāśrayatvāpādanameva na śakyam /
analyzed: yadi anyatvam kvāpi na gṛhītam tadā anyonya āśraya tva āpādanam eva na śakyam
translated: If otherness is not apprehended anywhere, then the consequence of mutual dependence cannot be stated at all.

analyzed: nirāśraya tvāt
translated: Because it would be baseless.

analyzed: tat hi pratītayoḥ dvayoḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva āśrayaṇe sati āpadyate
translated: For that arises when the relation of cause and effect is assumed between two things that are already known.

analyzed: antatas vādi prativādinoḥ dūṣya dūṣakayoḥ āpādya āpādakayoḥ bheda agrahe nu utthānam eva āpādanasya
translated: In the end, when there is no apprehension of difference between the proponent, the opponent, the one to be refuted, the refuter, the one to be deduced, and the deducer, the deduction does not arise at all.

analyzed: dvitīyam dūṣayati anyatvam iti
translated: He refutes the second view, saying otherness and so on.

analyzed: anya tvam yadi siddham syāt katham anyonya saṃśrayaḥ
translated: If otherness were established, how could there be mutual dependence?

analyzed: siddham pratītam
translated: Established means known.

analyzed: anyonya āśraya tve hi bheda pratītiḥ eva na syāt
translated: For if there were mutual dependence, there would be no apprehension of difference at all.

original: nahyanyonyāśrayāṇi kāryāṇi kvāpi dṛṣṭāni prakalpyante /🔽tathācāsti cedbhedapratītiḥ nūnamābhāsabhūtamevedamanyonyāśrayatvamapratibandhakatvāditi /
analyzed: nahi anyonya āśrayāṇi kāryāṇi kvāpi dṛṣṭāni prakalpyante  tathā ca asti ced bheda pratītiḥ nūnam ābhāsa bhūtam eva idam anyonya āśraya tvam apratibandhaka tvāt iti
translated: For effects that are mutually dependent are not seen anywhere.🔽And if there is such an apprehension of difference, then this mutual dependence is certainly only an appearance, because it does not obstruct.

original: asti bhedapratītiḥ sā na prameti tu tātparyamiti cenna kimanyonyāśrayatvamanyonyotpādaṃ pratibadhanātīti mataṃ /
analyzed: asti bheda pratītiḥ sā na pramā iti tu tātparyam iti ced na kim anyonya āśraya tvam anyonya utpādam matam
translated: If it is argued that the meaning is that the apprehension of difference exists but is not valid cognition, that is not so. Is it held that mutual dependence obstructs mutual production?

analyzed: kiṃvā tad dharmam
translated: Or is it a property of that?

analyzed: ādye katham apramā api bheda pratītiḥ utpadyate
translated: In the first case, how can even a false cognition arise of difference?

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: anyayoḥ anyonya āśraya tvam anyat tu lupyate iti asya anyāya tvāt  sāṃvṛtī prati iti
translated: Because it is unreasonable to say that one of the two is omitted, since the other two are mutually dependent.

analyzed: tipattiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the cognition is conventional,

analyzed: tat kim paṭa
translated: then is the cloth conventional?

original: sāṃvṛta iti yebhyastantubhyo jātasteṣāmeva kāraṇaṃ bhavaviṣyatīti / /
analyzed: sāṃvṛtaḥ iti yebhyaḥ tantubhyaḥ jātaḥ teṣām eva kāraṇam
translated: It will be the cause of those very threads from which it arises.

original: nanvanenāsya tarkasya kiṃ dūṣaṇamuktaṃ syādityata āha etādṛśasyeti //
analyzed: nanu anena asya tarkasya kim dūṣaṇam uktam syāt iti atas āha etādṛśasya iti
translated: But what fault has been stated by this of the reasoning? To this he says of such a one etc.

analyzed: etādṛśasya vaktārau ubhau jāti uttara akarau
translated: Both the speaker and such a one are givers of logical replies.

analyzed: māyī mādhyamikaḥ ca eva
translated: The magician and the Mādhyamika...

original: na kevalametajjātyuttaraṃ kintu yadanyadapi tadīyaṃ vacanam /
analyzed: na kevalam etat jāti uttaram kintu yat anyat api tadīyam vacanam
translated: Not only is this a logical reply, but also any other statement of his.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus it is said:

analyzed: bhedasya api bheda antara bhedya tve na avasthā iti
translated: If difference also is to be differentiated by another difference, there is an infinite regress.

original: tathā bhinne bhedaniveśaścettenaiva bhedena bhinnatāyāmātmāśrayatvaṃ /🔽bhedāntarāṅgīkāre tvanavasthā /
analyzed: tathā bhinne bheda niveśaḥ ced tena eva bhedena bhinna tāyām ātma āśraya tvam  bheda antara aṅgīkāre tu anavasthā
translated: Similarly, if difference is placed in what is different, there is self-dependence in the difference itself being different.🔽If another difference is accepted, there is an infinite regress.

analyzed: abhinne bheda niveśaḥ ced svatas pi paṭasya bheda āpattiḥ iti
translated: If difference is placed in what is non-different, then even the cloth would be different by itself.

original: tathā na tāvatpratyakṣeṇa bheda eva dṛśyate /
analyzed: tathā na tāvat pratyakṣeṇa bhedaḥ eva dṛśyate
translated: Thus difference is not seen by perception alone.

analyzed: bhedaḥ iti eva pratīteḥ anubhavāt
translated: Because of the experience that difference is cognized.

analyzed: vastunaḥ pi pratītau na tāvat bheda pūrvam vastu pratītiḥ
translated: Even if the thing is cognized, the cognition of the thing is not preceded by the cognition of difference.

analyzed: ukta doṣāt
translated: Because of the fault stated.

analyzed: nā api vastu pratīti pūrvikā bheda pratītiḥ
translated: Nor is the cognition of difference preceded by the cognition of the thing.

analyzed: abhedena pratīte bheda pratītau atiprasakteḥ
translated: Because if difference were cognized without identity, there would be excessive extension.

analyzed: na ca yugapad
translated: And not simultaneously.

analyzed: bheda pratītim prati vastu pratīteḥ kāraṇa tvena yaugapadya ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for the cognition of the thing to be simultaneous with the cognition of difference, since it is the cause of the cognition of difference.

analyzed: na ca prakāra antaram asti iti
translated: And there is no other alternative.

original: tathā sattāvatkāraṇaṃ vā kāraṇe sattā vā /
analyzed: tathā sattāvat kāraṇam vā kāraṇe sattā vā
translated: Thus, either existence is the cause, or existence is in the cause.

analyzed: ādye kāraṇasya asattvam
translated: In the first case, the cause is non-existent.

analyzed: dvitīye sataḥ eva kāraṇa tvam ityādi
translated: In the second case, only the non-existent is the cause, and so on.

analyzed: tat sarvam jāti uttaram iti jñāpayitum etādṛśasya iti uktam
translated: In order to show that all of this is a futile rejoinder, such as is said.

analyzed: sarvasya api sva vyāghātaka tvāt
translated: Because all of it contradicts one's own position.

analyzed: bhedasya sattāyāḥ ca svarūpa atiriktayoḥ ayuktayoḥ ktāyāḥ
translated: Because difference and existence, which are not proper apart from the nature [of the thing],

analyzed: kta tāyāḥ
translated: are accepted🔽as improper

analyzed: ayuktāyāḥ  eva aṅgīkaraṇāt ca
translated: only.

analyzed: katamā iyam jātiḥ iti ced na  sāmānya lakṣaṇa sadbhāve nirbandhasya vyartha tvāt
translated: If it is asked What is this kind of futile rejoinder?, it is not so.🔽Because this insistence is pointless when the general characteristic exists.

analyzed: ahetu prasaṅga nityasamāsu antarbhāvāt ca
translated: And because it is included in the fallacious reason, the absurd consequence, and the ever-present.

analyzed: māyā śabdasya vrīhi ādi tvāt māyī iti sādhuḥ
translated: Since the word māyā means rice etc., māyī is correct.

analyzed: śūnyavādi nirāsena eva
translated: By the refutation of the doctrine of emptiness,

original: na māyāvādo 'pi nirasto veditavya ityatideśajñāpanāya māyī cetyuktam /
analyzed: na māyā vādaḥ api nirastaḥ veditavyaḥ iti atideśa jñāpanāya māyī ca iti uktam
translated: it should be understood that the doctrine of māyā is also refuted. To indicate the extension, it is said māyī ca.

analyzed: eva śabdasya uttaratrata sambandhaḥ
translated: The word eva is connected with what follows.

original: nanvetadanyonyāśrayatvādikaṃ sūtrakṛtaiva kuto na nirākṛtamityata āha taditi //
analyzed: nanu etat anyonya āśraya tva ādikam sūtrakṛtā eva kutas na nirākṛtam iti atas āha tat iti
translated: But why did the author of the aphorisms not refute this mutual dependence etc.? To this he says tat.

analyzed: tad upekṣyau bubhūṣubhiḥ
translated: They should be disregarded by those who desire liberation.

analyzed: tasmāt jāti uttara ākara tvāt upekṣyau eva
translated: Therefore, they should be disregarded only because they are sophistical rejoinders.

analyzed: na tu parihārāya prativādīkartavyau
translated: They should not be taken as the opponent's reply for refutation.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: sadalameva pūrvapakṣivacanaṃ nirākartavyaṃ bhavati na nirdalam /
analyzed: sa dalam eva pūrvapakṣi vacanam nirākartavyam bhavati na nirdalam
translated: The opponent's statement along with its reasons should be refuted, not without reasons.

analyzed: anyathā atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be an overextension.

analyzed: etat ca jāti uttara tvena nirdalam iti upekṣitam sūtrakṛtā
translated: And this is disregarded by the author of the aphorisms as a sophistical rejoinder.

analyzed: asmābhiḥ tu śiṣya vyutpādanāya nirākṛtam iti
translated: But by us it is refuted for the instruction of the students.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be the case.

analyzed: śūnyāvādī śūnyam jagat kāraṇam manyate
translated: The proponent of emptiness considers the void to be the cause of the world.

analyzed: māyā vādī tu brahma
translated: But the proponent of māyā considers Brahman.

analyzed: tat katham na asataḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt ityādi śūnyavāda nirāsāya māyā vāde atideśaḥ
translated: Then how is there an extension of the doctrine of māyā to refute the doctrine of emptiness beginning with because the non-existent is not seen?

analyzed: mata vaiṣamye tideśa asambhavāt iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: Because it is not possible to extend to the non-dual Brahman the arguments based on the diversity of opinions regarding the nature of the void.

analyzed: yat śūnya vādinaḥ śūnyam tat eva brahma māyinaḥ
translated: The void of the void-proponents is the same as the Brahman of the illusionists.

analyzed: tasmāt atideśaḥ yuktaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the extension is proper. This is the remainder.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha nahi iti
translated: How is that? Therefore, it is said:

analyzed: nahi lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ sti nirviśeṣa tvataḥ tayoḥ
translated: There is no difference in the definition of the two, because of their being without distinctions.

analyzed: lakṣaṇa bhedena hi vipratipannaḥ bhedaḥ bodhanīyaḥ
translated: For the difference of the two, which is disputed due to the difference in definitions, should be understood.

analyzed: na a ca asau śūnya brahmaṇoḥ sambhavati
translated: And that is not possible for the void and Brahman.

analyzed: dvayoḥ api nirviśeṣa tva aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because both are accepted as without distinctions.

original: nanu nirviśeṣatvena bāhyalakṣaṇabhedābhāve 'pi satyajñānānantānandātmakatvaṃ brahmaṇaḥ svalakṣaṇaṃ māyāvādināṅgīkṛtam /
analyzed: nanu nirviśeṣa tvena bāhya lakṣaṇa bheda abhāve pi satya jñāna ananta ānanda ātmaka tvam brahmaṇaḥ sva lakṣaṇam māyā vādinā aṅgīkṛtam
translated: But even if there is no external difference in definition due to being without distinctions, the definition of Brahman as consisting of truth, knowledge, and infinity is accepted by the illusionists.

analyzed: na śūnyasya śūnya vādinā
translated: Not by the void-proponents of the void.

analyzed: tena brahma śūnyayoḥ bhedaḥ bhaviṣyati iti atas āha anṛta ādi iti
translated: Therefore, there will be a difference between Brahman and the void. Therefore, it is said:

analyzed: anṛta ādi virodhi tvam ubhayoḥ ca sva lakṣaṇam
translated: The self-definition of both is being opposed to untruth, etc.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ satya jñāna ādi ātmaka tvam nāma anṛta jaḍa ādi virodhi tvam eva abhimatam māyā vādinaḥ nyasya asambhavāt
translated: The illusionists consider the nature of Brahman as consisting of truth, knowledge, etc. to be just the opposition to untruth, inertness, etc., because anything else is impossible.

analyzed: anṛta jaḍa virodhi rūpam anta traya mala bandhana duḥkha tā viruddham
translated: It is opposed to untruth, dullness, contradiction, the three forms, impurities, bondage, and suffering.

analyzed: iti tat vyākhyānāt ca
translated: And because it is explained thus:🔽The opposite of untruth, dullness, obstruction, form, mind, the three, impurity, bondage, and suffering.

original: anṛtādivirodhitvaṃ ca śūnyavādī śūnyasyāpi manyate /🔽jāḍyasaṃvṛtiduḥkhāntapūvardeṣavirodhi yat' /
analyzed: anṛta ādi virodhi tvam ca śūnyavādī śūnyasya api manyate
translated: And the proponent of emptiness considers the opposite of untruth, etc. to be true of emptiness as well.

analyzed: iti vacanāt
translated: As stated: 'The opposite of dullness, concealment, suffering, and previous faults.'

analyzed: tatas na etat api bhedakam iti yuktaḥ eva atideśaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is also not a distinguishing factor. Thus, the extension is indeed proper.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: prapañcamithyātvānumānanirāsārthaṃ vaidharmyācca na svapnādivaditi sūtram /🔽tatra yatbhrānteḥ saṃvṛvisatyasya' /
analyzed: prapañca mithyātva anumāna nirāsa artham vaidharmyāt ca na svapna ādi vat iti sūtram  tatra yat bhrānteḥ saṃvṛ visatyasya
translated: In order to refute the inference of the falsity of the world, the aphorism is And because of dissimilarity, it is not like a dream, etc.

analyzed: iti dūṣaṇam uktam
translated: There, the criticism is stated: Because of delusion, the truth of concealment is...

analyzed: tat eva vaidharmyāt iti sūtre pratīyate
translated: That very [criticism] is understood in the aphorism Because of dissimilarity.

original: yatpunaruktaṃ dṛśyatvasya satyatve tatraiva vyabhicāraprasaṅgāttasya mithyātvaṃ vācyam /
analyzed: yat punar uktam dṛśya tvasya satya tve tatra eva vyabhicāra prasaṅgāt tasya mithyātvam vācyam
translated: Again, it is said: If visibility is true, then the fallacy of inconstancy would apply to it alone, so its falsity must be stated.

analyzed: tathā ca asādhaka tvam iti tad sūtre na dṛśyate
translated: And thus, it is not a proof. That is not seen in the aphorism.

analyzed: tat katham etat vayākhyānam iti atas āha sva vākya iti
translated: How then is this explained? Therefore, it is said: By one's own statement...

analyzed: sva vākya abhāva saṃvādāt na kṛtyam prativādinaḥ
translated: Because of contradiction with one's own statement, there is no duty for the opponent.🔽...🔽That is his position. Because of dissimilarity, it is not like a dream, etc. Ajātaśatru said.

analyzed: tad pakṣaḥ iti vaidharmyāt na svapna ādi vat iti ajaḥ
translated: The non-Buddhist says, It is not like dreams and so on, because of the difference in that case.

analyzed: aprayatnāt nirācakre
translated: He refuted it without effort.

analyzed: atra vākyam iti hetu vākya arthaḥ dṛśya tvam lakṣyate
translated: Here, the word sentence indicates the meaning of the reason sentence, which is visibility.

analyzed: tad pakṣaḥ iti viṣaya saptamī
translated: In that case is the objective case.

analyzed: tad mithyātva sādhana viṣayaḥ iti yāvat
translated: That is, in the case of proving its falsity.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ hetau  a prayatnāt prayatnam a vidhāya
translated: The word iti (thus) is in the sense of reason.🔽Without effort means without making an effort.

analyzed: vaidharmyāt ca na svapna ādi vat
translated: And because of dissimilarity, it is not like in a dream, etc.

analyzed: iti anena nirācakre iti sambandhaḥ
translated: This is the connection with he refuted it.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: dṛśya tvasya mithyātvam śūnyavādinā eva abhyupagatam
translated: The falsity of visibility is accepted only by the proponent of emptiness.

analyzed: mithyā bhūtasya a cā
translated: The non-establishment of what is false

analyzed: sādhaka tvam su prasiddham eva
translated: is well-known.

original: ata evaitadviṣaye sadvādinaḥ kimapi kṛtyaṃ nāstyeva /
analyzed: atas eva etad viṣaye sadvādinaḥ kim api kṛtyam na asti eva
translated: For this very reason, the proponents of existence have nothing to do in this case.

analyzed: sphuṭa dūṇa vyutpādane sūtra tva vyāghātāt
translated: Because explaining the clear refutation contradicts the sutra.

analyzed: tasmāt etad dūṣaṇa vyutpādane sūtra kṛtā prayatnaḥ na vihitaḥ
translated: Therefore, the author of the sutra did not make an effort to explain the refutation of this.🔽But we have clarified his intention.

analyzed: asmābhiḥ tu tad abhiprāyaḥ sphuṭīkṛtaḥ iti  tathā api sattvam ca asya anubhūṣitaḥ
translated: And its existence is experienced

analyzed: iti yat prapañca mithyātvasya pratyakṣa viruddha tvam uktam
translated: This is what was said about the falsity of the world being contradicted by perception.🔽And If it were false, there would be no means of knowledge at all

analyzed: yat ca mithyātve mā na kācana
translated: And in the case of falsity, there is no such thing as 'not at all'.🔽

analyzed: iti niṣpramāṇa tvam
translated: Thus, it is unauthoritative.

original: tadubhayaṃ sūtre na dṛśyata ityata āha ceti //
analyzed: tat ubhayam sūtre na dṛśyate iti atas āha ca iti
translated: Since both of these are not seen in the sutra, he says ca (and).

analyzed: ca iti dṛṣṭi viruddha tām
translated: Ca (and) indicates contradiction with perception.

analyzed: niṣpramāṇa tvam api asya sūcayāmāsa viśvakṛt
translated: The creator of the universe has also indicated its lack of authority.

analyzed: asya mithyātvasya
translated: Of this falsity.

original: nanvanuktasamuccayārthena caśabdenedaṃ dūṣaṇadvayaṃ sūcitamiti yathā vyākhyāyate /
analyzed: nanu anukta samuccaya arthena caśabdena idam dūṣaṇa dvayam sūcitam iti yathā vyākhyāyate
translated: If it is explained that this pair of faults is indicated by the word ca (and) which has the meaning of including what is not mentioned,

analyzed: tathā tat api ca a śabda artha tayā vyākhyāyatām
translated: then let that also be explained as the meaning of the word ca.

analyzed: kim anukta tva aṅgīkāreṇa
translated: What is the use of accepting what is not mentioned?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: na kṛtyam prativādinaḥ iti uktvāt
translated: Because it has been said that the opponent has no function.

analyzed: sūtre hetu viśeṣasya anupādānāt niṣpramāṇaka tvam jñāpitam iti astu
translated: Let it be that the lack of authority is indicated by the omission of a specific reason in the sutra.

analyzed: kim ca āśabdasya ubhaya sūcaka tva grahaṇena na
translated: Moreover, what is the use of accepting that the word ca (and) indicates both? No.

analyzed: sati śabde sa avakāśa jñāpaka ādaraṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because when there is a word, it is not proper to accept an indication that has an opportunity.

analyzed: svapna ādi vat iti sūtram svapna vat iti vyākhyātam
translated: The sutra like a dream, etc. is explained as like a dream.

analyzed: kaḥ tra abhiprāyaḥ
translated: What is the intention here?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

original: bahusthaleṣu gṛhīteyaṃ vyāptirityato na vyabhicāramarhatīti pūrvapakṣiṇo 'bhimānaṃ sūcayituṃ sūtrakāreṇādipadaṃ prayuktam /
analyzed: bahu sthaleṣu gṛhītā iyam vyāptiḥ iti atas na vyabhicāram arhati iti pūrvapakṣiṇaḥ bhimānam sūcayitum sūtrakāreṇa ādi padam prayuktam
translated: The author of the sutra used the word ādi (etc.) to indicate the opponent's belief that this pervasion is grasped in many places and therefore does not deserve to be contradicted.

original: tathāpi prayogavelāyāmeka eva dṛṣṭānta upādeyo 'nyathā'dhikyaṃ prasajyatejyeteti /
analyzed: tathā api prayoga velāyām ekaḥ eva dṛṣṭāntaḥ upādeyaḥ nyathā ādhikyam
translated: Still, at the time of application, only one example should be used, otherwise excess would result.

analyzed: yathā āha
translated: As it is said:

analyzed: hetu udāharaṇa ādikam adhikam iti
translated: The reason, example, etc. are excessive.

analyzed: etad jñāpanāya bhāṣyakāreṇa svapna vat iti eva uktam iti sarvam sustham
translated: In order to make this known, the author of the commentary has said like a dream, so everything is well-established.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām asat adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Asat-adhyaya in the illustrious Nyaya-sudha.

analyzed: anupalabdhi adhikaraṇa
translated: IX. The Section on Non-apprehension

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām anupalabdhi adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the illustrious Nyaya-sudha, the section on non-apprehension.

analyzed: om na bhāvaḥ nupalabdheḥ om
translated: Om. There is no existence due to non-apprehension.

analyzed: atra yoga ācārāṇām matam apākriyate
translated: Here, the view of the Yogacarins is refuted.

analyzed: tad artham tat upanyasyati jñānam eva iti
translated: For that purpose, he presents their view with Knowledge alone...

analyzed: na bhāvaḥ n upalabdheḥ
translated: There is no existence due to non-apprehension.

analyzed: jñānam eva ekam akhila jñeya ākāram prabhāsate
translated: Knowledge alone shines with the forms of all knowable objects.

analyzed: vijñānam eva tattvam
translated: Consciousness alone is the truth.

analyzed: na rūpa ādayaḥ catvāraḥ skandhāḥ
translated: The four aggregates such as form do not exist.

analyzed: iti yoga ācārāḥ manyante iti atharḥ
translated: This is the view of the Yogacarins. This is the meaning.

analyzed: vijñāna aṅgīkāre pi viśeṣam āha ekam iti
translated: Even when consciousness is accepted, he states a distinction with one.

analyzed: advitīyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is without a second.

original: nanu jñeyamapi rūpādikaṃ pratyakṣādisiddhaṃ tatkathaṃ vijñānameva tattvamityata āha akhileti //
analyzed: nanu jñeyam api rūpa ādikam pratyakṣa ādi siddham tat katham vijñānam eva tattvam iti atas āha akhila iti
translated: But form etc., which are to be known, are also established by perception etc., so how can consciousness alone be the truth? To this he says all etc.

analyzed: jñānam eva jñeya kāram
translated: Knowledge alone is the object of knowledge.

analyzed: na jñeyam nāma jñānāt bhinnam asti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no object of knowledge apart from knowledge.

original: kuto jñeyasya jñānātmakatvamityata āha prabhāsata iti //
analyzed: kutas jñeyasya jñāna ātmaka tvam iti atas āha prabhāsate iti
translated: From where does the knowable have the nature of knowledge? To this he says it shines etc.

analyzed: jñānam hi prakāśate
translated: For knowledge shines.

original: tena prakāśamānatvasya jñānatvena vyāptau siddhāyāṃ nīlāderapi prakāśamānasya jñānatvaṃ siddhamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tena prakāśamāna tvasya jñāna tvena vyāptau siddhāyām nīla ādeḥ api prakāśamānasya jñāna tvam siddham iti arthaḥ
translated: When the pervasion of shining by knowledge is established, the knowledgehood of blue etc. which are shining is established. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yat vā prabhāsate nīla ādinā saha eva iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Or, the remainder is it shines along with blue etc.

analyzed: tena saha upalambha niyamāt abhedaḥ nīla tad dhiyoḥ
translated: Therefore, due to the rule of being apprehended together, there is non-difference between the blue and its cognition.

analyzed: iti uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: nanu ayuktaḥ jñāna jñeyayoḥ abhedaḥ
translated: But the non-difference of knowledge and the object of knowledge is improper.

analyzed: bhedasya pratibhāsanāt
translated: Because difference is manifested.

analyzed: ekam iti ca ayuktam
translated: And one is improper.

original: vijñānasantatīnāṃ bhedasya ekaikasyāpi santatau vijñānabhedasya ca vidyamānatvāt /
analyzed: vijñāna santatīnām bhedasya ekaikasya api santatau vijñāna bhedasya ca vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the difference of the series of cognitions, and the difference of each cognition within the series, exists.

analyzed: kiñca āstām anyaḥ bhedaḥ
translated: Moreover, let another difference be so.

analyzed: bheda abhāvaḥ tāvat abhyupagamyate
translated: The absence of difference is accepted.

original: tenaiva vijñānasya sadvitīyatvāprāpternaikatvamupapadyata ityata āha tatreti //
analyzed: tena eva vijñānasya sa dvitīya tva aprāpteḥ na ekatvam upapadyate iti atas āha tatra iti
translated: Therefore, since consciousness does not attain duality by that alone, singularity is not logically possible. Thus, he says tatra (in that case).

original: tatra santatibhedaśca svabhedo bheda eva ca /
analyzed: tatra santati bhedaḥ ca sva bhedaḥ bhedaḥ eva ca
translated: There, the difference in continuity, the difference in self, and the difference itself,

analyzed: kalpitāḥ pratibhāsante nānā saṃvṛti bhūmiṣu
translated: appear as imagined on the various levels of conventional reality.

analyzed: tatra jñāna jñeyayoḥ bhedaḥ iti sambandhaḥ
translated: There, the connection is between the difference of knowledge and the knowable.

analyzed: santati bhedaḥ santatīnām parasparam bhedaḥ
translated: The difference in continuity is the difference between the continuities themselves.

analyzed: sva bhedaḥ ekaikasyām api santatau pūrva uttara jñāna bhedaḥ
translated: The difference in self is the difference between the earlier and later cognitions even within each continuity.

analyzed: kalpitāḥ eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that they are imagined only.

analyzed: nānā saṃvṛti bhūmiṣu aneka ajñāna sthāneṣu antaḥkaraṇeṣu
translated: On the various levels of conventional reality, in the various places of ignorance, in the internal organs.

original: yadvā nānāsaṃvṛtikāraṇakāsu vāsanāsviti nimittasaptamī /🔽taduktambhedastu bhrantibuddhayaiva dṛdṛśya indā
analyzed: yat vā nānā saṃvṛti kāraṇakāsu vāsanāsu iti nimitta saptamī  tat uktam bhedaḥ tu bhranti buddhayā eva indā
translated: Or, in the imprints caused by various conventional realities, this is the locative case of the reason.

analyzed: iti  evam anūditam matam apākaroti iti etat api iti
translated: That has been said: But the difference is seen only by the deluded mind, as two moons are seen by one with diseased eyes.🔽Thus, he refutes the stated opinion with This is also not proper.

analyzed: iti etat api no yuktam
translated: This is also not proper.

analyzed: pūrva mata samuccaya arthaḥ pi śabdaḥ
translated: The word api (also) is for including the previous opinion.

analyzed: anenana bhāve
translated: By this, in the absence of existence.

analyzed: iti sūtra aṃśaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: This part of the sutra is explained.

analyzed: jagat bhāvaḥ jñānam na bhavati iti arthaḥ  bhavateḥ anubhava artha tvāt
translated: The meaning is that the existence of the world is not knowledge.🔽Because the root bhu means to experience.

analyzed: upasargāḥ hi dhātu līna asya arthasya vyañjakāḥ eva
translated: For prefixes merely reveal the meaning of a root that is already present.

original: kuto na yuktamiti cet /🔽kiṃ jñeyaṃ svarūpeṇāsadeva vijñāne samāropitaṃ vijñānātmakamityu
analyzed: kutas na yuktam iti ced  kim jñeyam sva rūpeṇa asat eva vijñāne samāropitam vijñāna ātmakam iti u
translated: If it is asked why it is not proper,🔽is it said that the object of knowledge, which is unreal in its own form, is superimposed on consciousness and is said to be of the nature of consciousness?

original: mucyate / kiṃ vā paramārthasata eva jñeyasya jagato vijñānātmakatvaṃ bhedamātraṃ tvasaditi /
analyzed: mucyate kim vā paramārtha sataḥ eva jñeyasya jagataḥ vijñāna ātmaka tvam bheda mātram tu asat iti
translated: Or is it that the world, which is ultimately real, is of the nature of consciousness, but the difference alone is unreal?

analyzed: ādyaḥ tu atīta adhikaraṇa rītyā nirastaḥ
translated: The first view has been refuted in the previous section.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

original: jagato jñānābhede pramāṇābhāvāt /🔽na tāvattatra pratyakṣamastītyāha na hīti //
analyzed: jagataḥ jñāna abhede pramāṇa abhāvāt  na tāvat tatra pratyakṣam asti iti āha na hi iti
translated: Because there is no means of valid knowledge for the non-difference of the world and knowledge.🔽First of all, there is no perception in that regard. He says: For the world does not appear as knowledge.

analyzed: na hi jñāna tayā jagat
translated: The world does not appear as knowledge.

analyzed: bhāsate
translated: It shines...

analyzed: anena anupalabdheḥ iti etat vayākhyātam bhavati
translated: By this, the statement because of non-apprehension is explained.

analyzed: mā bhūt pratyakṣeṇa jñāna arthayoḥ abheda siddhiḥ
translated: Let there be no establishment of non-difference of knowledge and object by perception.

analyzed: prakāśamāna tva ādi anumānāt tu  nena tu bhaviṣyati iti atas āha anubhavasya eva iti
translated: But it will be by inference from shining and so on.

analyzed: anubhavasya eva viruddha tvāt apeśalam
translated: But by this, it will be. Therefore he says: Because of the contradiction of experience itself, it is not proper.🔽That view...

analyzed: tat matam
translated: That is the opinion. . . .🔽. . . .

analyzed: sambandha mātre ṣaṣṭhī
translated: The genitive case is used in the sense of mere relation.

analyzed: eva śabdena anubhavasya anumānataḥ prābalyam sūcayati
translated: By the word eva (only), he indicates the superiority of experience over inference.

analyzed: tad matam tad abhimatam anumānam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the inference accepted by him is the one accepted by him.

analyzed: jñāna jñeyayoḥ aikyam iti ca vā
translated: Or, the oneness of knowledge and the object of knowledge.

analyzed: jñāna jñeyayoḥ sphuṭam bhedasya eva sākṣi siddha tvāt kāla atyaya apadiṣṭa tvam anumānasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that inference is contradicted by the passage of time, because the clear difference between knowledge and the object of knowledge is established by perception.

analyzed: anena anupalabdheḥ iti etat upalabdhi virodhāt iti ca vyākhyātam
translated: By this, because of non-apprehension is explained as because of contradiction with apprehension.

analyzed: nanu bheda grāhakam pratyakṣam bhrāntam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that perception which grasps difference is erroneous, it is not so.

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no sublating cognition.

analyzed: anumānam bādhakam iti tu na vācyam
translated: It cannot be said that inference is the sublating cognition.

analyzed: pratyakṣasya anumānataḥ balavat tvāt
translated: Because perception is stronger than inference.

analyzed: anyathā kāla atīta tā uccheda prasaṅgāt  pratyakṣasya bhrānti
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the sublation of inference by perception and the destruction of inference.

analyzed: nta tve numāna prāmāṇyam tasmin ca pratyakṣasya bhrānta tvam iti anyonya āśraya tvāt ca iti
translated: If perception were not true, inference would be valid, and if inference were valid, perception would be false. This would lead to mutual dependence.

original: anumānavirodhaṃ cānumānasya pratipādayituṃ sūtram oṃ kṣaṇikatvācca oṃ //
analyzed: anumāna virodham ca anumānasya pratipādayitum sūtram om kṣaṇika tvāt ca om
translated: To demonstrate the contradiction of inference with another inference, the aphorism is: And because of momentariness.

analyzed: iti  tat vayācaṣṭe kṣaṇika tvāt ca iti
translated: This is the aphorism.🔽He explains it as And because of momentariness.

analyzed: kṣaṇika tvāt ca
translated: And because of momentariness.

analyzed: kṣaṇika tvāt ca jñānasya sthira rūpataḥ  jñeyasya ukta prakāreṇa
translated: And because knowledge is momentary, and the object of knowledge is of a stable nature,🔽as stated earlier,

analyzed: āśutara vināśi tvāt iti arthaḥ  na ca jñānasya kṣaṇika tvam bhrāntam
translated: the meaning is that it perishes very quickly.🔽And the momentariness of knowledge is not a delusion.

analyzed: a bādhita prati iti  tyaya siddha tvāt
translated: Because the cognition is not contradicted,🔽it is well-established.

analyzed: sthira rūpataḥ
translated: From the absence of the nature of stability, i.e., from the absence of the quality of not perishing very quickly,

analyzed: anusmṛteḥ ca ityādi ukta prakāreṇa
translated: and from memory, etc., in the manner stated earlier.

original: atra kṣaṇikatvākṣaṇikatvalakṣaṇaviruddhadharmādhyāsaṃ bhedahetuṃ vadatā'ntarabāhyatvādiraneko viruddhadharmasaṃsarga upalakṣito boddhavyaḥ
analyzed: atra kṣaṇikatva akṣaṇikatva lakṣaṇa viruddha dharma adhyāsam bheda hetum vadatā antara bāhya tva ādiḥ anekaḥ viruddha dharma saṃsargaḥ upalakṣitaḥ boddhavyaḥ
translated: Here, by stating the superimposition of mutually contradictory properties characterized by momentariness and non-momentariness as the cause of difference, it should be understood that many other superimpositions of contradictory properties such as externality and internality are also implied.

original: evaṃ pratyekaṃ nirākṛtāni bauddhamatāni sādhāraṇadoṣeṇa dūṣayituṃ sūtram oṃ savarthānupapatteśca oṃ //
analyzed: evam pratyekam nirākṛtāni bauddha matāni sādhāraṇa doṣeṇa dūṣayitum sūtram om om
translated: In this way, having refuted the Buddhist doctrines individually, the aphorism And because of the impossibility of the meaning is stated to criticize them with a general fault.

analyzed: iti  tat vayākhyāti sarvā iti
translated: This is the aphorism.🔽He explains it as all

analyzed: sarvathā anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because of the impossibility in every way.

analyzed: sarva śruti virodhataḥ
translated: Because of the contradiction with all the scriptures.

analyzed: anubhūti viruddha tvāt api pakṣāḥ ime śivāḥ
translated: These positions are also inauspicious because they contradict experience.

analyzed: śruti prāmāṇyasya samarthita tvāt avaidikam prati api śruti virodha kathanam yuktam eva
translated: Since the authoritativeness of the Vedas has been established, it is indeed proper to state the contradiction with the scriptures even to one who is not Vedic.

analyzed: abhyupagata śruti prāmāṇyam śiṣyam prati vā
translated: Or to a disciple who has accepted the authoritativeness of the Vedas.

analyzed: teṣām pakṣāṇām aśiva tvam anena jñāpyate iti
translated: It is shown by this that those positions are inauspicious.

analyzed: nanu anubhūti virodhaḥ prāk uktaḥ eva punar kasmāt ucyate
translated: But isn't the contradiction with experience already stated? Why is it mentioned again?

analyzed: upasaṃhāra artham iti adoṣaḥ
translated: There is no fault, as it is for the purpose of conclusion.

analyzed: yat vā tadīya prameya antare pi iti
translated: Or, it is also in another matter of their doctrine.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām anupalabdhi adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on Non-apprehension in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: na ekasmin adhikaraṇe
translated: X. The chapter on Non-apprehension in One

analyzed: atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām na ekasmin adhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on Non-apprehension in One

analyzed: om na ekasmin asambhavāt om
translated: Om. Because it is not possible in one.

analyzed: jaina matam atra nirākriyate
translated: The Jain doctrine is refuted here.

analyzed: nirākārya aṃśa jñāpanāya tat upanyasyati āha iti
translated: In order to make known the part to be refuted, he presents it, saying he says.

analyzed: na ekasmin asaṃbhavāt  /
translated: Because it is not possible in one.

analyzed: āha kṣapaṇakaḥ viśvam sat asat dvayam advayam
translated: He says: The universe is existent, non-existent, both, and not both.

analyzed: sapta bhaṅgi sadātanam
translated: All that is eternal with seven modes.

analyzed: dvividham tāvat viśvam
translated: The universe is of two kinds.

analyzed: jīva ajīva ātmakam nirīśvaram
translated: It is without an overlord, consisting of jīvas (souls) and ajīvas (nonsouls).

analyzed: tat punar ṣaṣ dravya ātmakam
translated: It is again of the nature of six substances.

analyzed: tāni ca dravyāṇi jīva dharma adhama rpudgala kāla ākāśa nāmāni
translated: And those substances are named jīva (soul), dharma (merit), adharma (demerit), pudgala (individual), kāla (time), and ākāśa (space).

analyzed: tatra jīvāḥ trividhāḥ
translated: Among them, the jīvas are of three kinds.

analyzed: baddhāḥ yogasiddhāḥ muktāḥ ca iti  dharmaḥ gati hetuḥ jagat vayāpī
translated: Bound, liberated, and liberated through spiritual practice.🔽Dharma is the cause of motion and pervades the world.

analyzed: adharmaḥ sthiti hetuḥ vyāpakaḥ eva
translated: Adharma is the cause of stability and is all-pervading.

analyzed: pudgalaḥ rūpa rasa gandha sparśavat dravyam
translated: The soul is a substance like form, taste, smell, and touch.

analyzed: tat dvividham
translated: It is of two kinds.

analyzed: paramāṇu rūpam saṅghāta rūpam ca
translated: Atomic form and composite form.

analyzed: kālaḥ abhūt bhavati bhaviṣyati iti vyavahāra hetuḥ api aṇu rūpaḥ
translated: Time is the cause of the conventions was, is, and will be, and is also atomic in form.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ ekaḥ nanta pradeśaḥ ca
translated: Space is one and has infinite regions.

analyzed: sa dvividhaḥ loka ākāśaḥ loka ākāśaḥ ca iti
translated: It is of two kinds: worldly space and non-worldly space.

analyzed: eteṣu aṇu vyatiriktāni astikāya śabdāni
translated: Among these, the ones other than atoms are called aggregates.

analyzed: aneka deśa vartini dravye stikāya śabda pravṛtteḥ
translated: Because the word aggregate is used for a substance that exists in many places.

original: te ca jīvāstikāyo dharmāstikāyo 'dharmāstikāyaḥ pudgalāstikāya ākāśāstikāya iti pañca /
analyzed: te ca jīva astikāyaḥ dharma astikāyaḥ dharma astikāyaḥ pudgala astikāyaḥ ākāśa astikāyaḥ iti pañca
translated: And those are five: the aggregate of living beings, the aggregate of dharma, the aggregate of adharma, the aggregate of souls, and the aggregate of space.

original: atra ca mokṣopayoginaḥ sapta padārthā jīvājīvāsravabandhanirjarasaṃvaramokṣāḥ /
analyzed: atra ca mokṣa upayoginaḥ sapta padārthāḥ jīva ajīva āsrava bandha nirjara saṃvara mokṣāḥ
translated: And here, the seven categories that are useful for liberation are the soul, non-soul, influx, bondage, purification, restraint, and liberation.

analyzed: jīvaḥ jñāna darśana sukha vīrya guṇaḥ
translated: The soul is endowed with the qualities of knowledge, insight, happiness, and strength.

analyzed: ajīvaḥ jīva upabhogyam vastu jātam
translated: The non-soul is the collection of things to be enjoyed by the soul.

analyzed: asravaḥ tad bhoga upakaraṇam indriya ādikam
translated: Influx is the sense faculties and so on, which are the means for enjoying that.

analyzed: bandhaḥ dvividhaḥ
translated: Bondage is of two kinds.

analyzed: ghātika āghātika catuṣyaya bhedāt
translated: Due to the division into four: destroyer and non-destroyer.

analyzed: ādyam jīva guṇānām jñāna ānandā
translated: The first is an obstruction to the qualities of the soul, such as knowledge, bliss,

analyzed: dīnām pratibandhakam
translated: etc.

analyzed: dvitīyam śarīra saṃsthāna tad abhimāna tad sthiti tad prayukta sukha duḥkha hetu bhūtam
translated: The second is the cause of the form of the body, the pride in it, its maintenance, and the resulting pleasure and pain.
Nirjara is austerity, the means to liberation.
Samvara is the restraint of the senses, and nigraha is their control.
Moksha is the manifestation of the natural form of the self.

analyzed: mokṣa grahaṇena eva mokṣa mārgaḥ saṅgṛhītaḥ
translated: By mentioning moksha alone, the path to liberation is also included.

analyzed: sa ca samyak jñāna samyak darśana samyak cāritrī ākhya ratna traya ātmakaḥ
translated: And that consists of the triad of jewels called right knowledge, right insight, and right conduct.

analyzed: tat etat viśvam sapta bhaṅgi pratyekam sapta prakārakam āmityā  ha kṣapaṇakaḥ
translated: The Jaina monk says that this universe is sevenfold, each having seven aspects.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: sat iti eka prakāraḥ
translated: One aspect is existence.

analyzed: asat iti dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is non-existence.

analyzed: dvayam sat asat ātmakam iti tṛtīyaḥ
translated: The third is duality, which is the nature of both existence and non-existence.

analyzed: advayam a vaktavyam iti caturthaḥ
translated: The fourth is non-duality, which is inexpressible.

analyzed: dvayādvayam iti pañcama ṣaṣṭhau
translated: The fifth and sixth are duality and non-duality.

analyzed: tatra sat avaktavyam ca iti pañcamaḥ
translated: The fifth is existence and inexpressible.

analyzed: asat avaktavyam ca iti ṣaṣṭhaḥ
translated: The sixth is non-existence and inexpressible.

analyzed: a tat sarvam iti saptamaḥ
translated: The seventh is neither of those.

analyzed: sarvam iti sat asat ātmakam
translated: Sarvam, all means that which has the nature of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: a tat iti avaktavyam
translated: Atat,not that means inexpressible.

original: atra saptabhaṅgitvanirāsārthaṃ naikasminnasambhavāditi sūtraṃ vyācaṣṭe naitaditi //
analyzed: atra sapta bhaṅgi tva nirāsa artham na ekasmin asambhavāt iti sūtram vyācaṣṭe na etat iti
translated: Here, to refute the seven-fold nature, the sutra Naikasminnasambhavad is explained as Naitat (this is not possible).

analyzed: na etat padārthe ekasmin yuktam dṛṣṭi virodhataḥ
translated: This seven-fold nature is not proper in one thing, due to contradiction with perception.

analyzed: etat sapta prakāra tvam kutas
translated: Why is this seven-fold nature?

analyzed: asambhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible.

analyzed: saḥ pi katham
translated: How is that also?

analyzed: dṛṣṭi virodhataḥ
translated: Due to contradiction with perception.

analyzed: sarvam hi sva upādhau sat para upādhau asat
translated: For everything that exists in its own substrate does not exist in the substrate of others.

analyzed: svarūpeṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: An entity exists in its own form, but does not exist in the form of others.

analyzed: dravya rūpeṇa nityam avasthā bhedena anityam
translated: It is permanent in the form of substance, but impermanent in the different states.

analyzed: sva rūpa ādinā abhinnam sva guṇa ādinā bhinna abhinnam iti eva pratīyate
translated: It is non-different in its own form, but different and non-different in its own qualities. This is how it is perceived.

analyzed: na atas nyena prakāreṇa
translated: Not by any other way.

analyzed: atas vyavasthayā niyama grāhaka pratyakṣa ādi virodhena asambhavāt ayuktam eva anekāntamatam iti
translated: Therefore, due to the impossibility of contradiction with the perception etc. that grasps the restriction by the restriction, the doctrine of non-absolutism is not proper.

original: nanvekāntadarśanasya mithyādṛṣṭitvena na tadvirodho 'sambhavamāhavatītyata āha bhāveti //
analyzed: nanu ekānta darśanasya mithyādṛṣṭi tvena na tad virodhaḥ sambhavam āhavati iti atas āha bhāva iti
translated: But the false perception of absolutism does not cause the impossibility by contradicting it. Therefore, it is said Bhavat (existence).

analyzed: bhāva abhāva tayā viśvam yena rūpeṇa mīyate
translated: The universe is measured in the form of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: tad rūpam eva tat iti niyamaḥ kena vāryate
translated: By what is the restriction that it is of that very form prevented?

analyzed: yena rūpeṇa iti asya eva vivaraṇam bhāva abhāvatayā iti
translated: The explanation of by what form is by existence and non-existence.

original: tacca vyavasthitasadasattvādyupalakṣaṇaṃ boddhavyam /🔽yadvā bhāvābhāvatayānyena ca yena sattvādinā
analyzed: tat ca vyavasthita sat asat tva ādi upalakṣaṇam boddhavyam  yat vā bhāva abhāvatayā anyena ca yena sattva ādinā
translated: And that should be understood as an illustration of established existence and non-existence, etc.

original: rūpeṇeti yojanā /🔽athavā yena bhāvābhāvatayā rūpeṇeti sāmānādhikaraṇyena yojyam /
analyzed: rūpeṇa iti yojanā  athavā yena bhāva abhāva tayā rūpeṇa iti sāmānādhikaraṇyena yojyam
translated: Or the construction is: by existence and non-existence, and by another form, by existence, etc.🔽Or else, by what form of existence and non-existence should be construed in apposition.

analyzed: yadi vā bhāva abhāvatayā iti asya viśeṣaṇam etat
translated: Or this is a qualification of by existence and non-existence.

analyzed: yena vyavasthitena rūpeṇa iti
translated: By what established form.

analyzed: kena pramāṇena iti ākṣepaḥ
translated: The objection is: by what means of knowledge?

analyzed: bhavet etat niyama darśanasya mithyādṛṣṭi tvam
translated: This could be the falsity of the seen restriction,

original: yadi dṛṣṭasya niyamasya nivārakamanekāntasādhakaṃ prabalapramāṇaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi dṛṣṭasya niyamasya nivārakam anekānta sādhakam prabala pramāṇam syāt
translated: if there were a powerful means of knowledge that established non-restriction, which establishes non-one-sidedness.

analyzed: na ca etat asti
translated: But this is not the case.

original: naca bādhakena vinā pratyayānāṃ mithyātvaṃ kalpayituṃ yuktamatiprasaṅgāditi /
analyzed: na ca bādhakena vinā pratyayānām mithyātvam kalpayitum yuktam atiprasaṅgāt iti
translated: And without a contradiction, it is not proper to imagine the falsity of the conditions, due to over-extension.

analyzed: niyamasya bādhakam āśaṅkate tat tat iti
translated: He suspects a contradiction to the restriction with that and that, etc.

analyzed: tad tad doṣa nivṛtti artham svīkṛtā tad tad ātmanā
translated: For the purpose of removing that and that fault, that and that nature is accepted.🔽If...

analyzed: yadi

original: sadvādino hi sattvaṃ viśvasya pramāṇaiḥ prātiṣṭhipastadanaṅgīkāre doṣāṃśca nyarūpayan /
analyzed: sadvādinaḥ hi sattvam viśvasya pramāṇaiḥ prātiṣṭhipaḥ tad anaṅgīkāre doṣān ca nyarūpayan
translated: For the proponents of existence have established the existence of the universe by means of proofs and have stated the faults of not accepting it.

analyzed: evam asadvādinaḥ pi asattva sthāpanam tad anaṅgīkāre dūṣaṇam ca vyutpāditavantaḥ
translated: In the same way, the proponents of non-existence have also explained the establishment of non-existence and the refutation of not accepting it.

original: tathānye 'pi svapakṣasādhanaṃ tadanabhyupagame bādhanaṃ ca kṛtavantaḥ /🔽tathāca yadi satya
analyzed: tathā anye sva pakṣa sādhanam tad anabhyupagame bādhanam ca kṛtavantaḥ  tathā ca yadi
translated: Similarly, others have also established their own position and refuted the non-acceptance of it.

original: tvaṃ nāṅgīkriyate tadā tu tadupanyastaṃ pramāṇamuparudhyeta dūṣaṇaṃ cānuṣajyeta /
analyzed: tvam nā aṅgīkriyate tadā tu tat upanyastam pramāṇam uparudhyeta dūṣaṇam ca anuṣajyeta
translated: And so, if existence is not accepted, then the proofs presented would be obstructed and the refutations would be entailed.

analyzed: evam asattva ādi anaṅgīkāre pi
translated: In the same way, even if non-existence and so on are not accepted.

original: atastaddoṣaparihārārthaṃ tattatpramāṇānusaraṇārthaṃ ca tattadātmatā viśvasya mayā svīkṛtā /
analyzed: atas tad doṣa parihāra artham tad tad pramāṇa anusaraṇa artham ca tad tad ātma tā viśvasya mayā svīkṛtā
translated: Therefore, in order to avoid those faults and in order to follow those proofs, I have accepted the nature of the universe as such and such.

analyzed: tathā ca anekānte prabala pramāṇa sadbhāvāt katham niyame bādhaka abhāvaḥ iti
translated: And so, since there are strong proofs for non-absolutism, how can there be an absence of refutation by necessity?

analyzed: pariharati taiḥ iti
translated: He answers with by them.

analyzed: taiḥ akhilaiḥ deṣaiḥ lipyate cala darśanaḥ
translated: The one with a wavering view is smeared with all those faults.

analyzed: tarhi iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is then.

analyzed: idam atra vaktavyam
translated: This should be stated here.

analyzed: sat vādi mata anusaraṇa samaye sattva ādi bhaṅgīḥ aṅgīkaroṣi vā na vā iti
translated: When following the view of the proponents of existence, do you accept the positions of non-existence and so on or not?

analyzed: evam asat vādi caraṇa śaraṇa praveśa velāyām sattva ādi prakārān ūrīkaroṣi vā na vā iti
translated: In the same way, when you enter the feet of the proponents of non-existence, do you accept the modes of existence and so on, or not?

analyzed: evam anyeṣu api pakṣeṣu vikalpaḥ
translated: In the same way, there is an option in the other positions as well.

analyzed: yadi ādyaḥ tadā asau acala darśanaḥ sadā sakala pakṣa aṅgīkāravān taiḥ deṣaiḥ akhila etaiḥ akhilaiḥ deṣaiḥ lipyate
translated: If the first, then he, always accepting all positions, is smeared with all those faults.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

original: sadvādino hi na kevalaṃ sattve pramāṇaṃ tadanaṅgīkāre ca dūṣaṇaṃ ca vyutpādya nivṛttāḥ /
analyzed: sadvādinaḥ hi na kevalam sattve pramāṇam tad anaṅgīkāre ca dūṣaṇam ca vyutpādya nivṛttāḥ
translated: For the proponents of existence do not stop after just teaching the means of valid knowledge regarding existence and the refutation of not accepting it.

analyzed: kintu asattva ādi pakṣeṣu doṣān api vyutpāditavantaḥ
translated: But they also teach the faults regarding the positions of non-existence and so on.

original: evamasadvādino 'pi nāsattve pramāṇaṃ tadanabhyupagame bādhakaṃ cābhidhāyaivoparatā /
analyzed: evam asadvādinaḥ pi nā asattve pramāṇam tad anabhyupagame bādhakam ca abhidhāya evā uparatā
translated: In the same way, the proponents of non-existence do not stop after just stating the means of valid knowledge regarding non-existence and the refutation of not accepting it.

analyzed: kinnāma sattva ādi pakṣeṣu doṣān api upapāditavantaḥ
translated: But they also teach the faults regarding the positions of existence and so on.

analyzed: evam anye pi
translated: In the same way, the others also.

analyzed: tathā ca sakala pakṣa kakṣīkāre tu
translated: And in that case, if all positions are accepted,

analyzed: tad tad vādi ukta pakṣa antara doṣa lepaḥ katham na syāt
translated: how could one not be smeared with the faults of the other positions stated by the various proponents?

analyzed: atha manyase
translated: But if you think:

analyzed: na te doṣāḥ kintu ābhāsāḥ
translated: Those are not faults, but fallacies.

analyzed: te ca na anekāntavādam bādhante iti
translated: And those do not contradict the doctrine of non-absolutism.

analyzed: tadā katham tāni pramāṇāni
translated: Then how are those means of valid knowledge?

analyzed: anaṅgīkāre doṣāḥ ca na ābhāsāḥ
translated: And the faults in not accepting [a position] are not fallacious.

analyzed: ye na anumayena anusaraṇīyāḥ
translated: Those that should not be pursued by inference.

analyzed: sapta bhaṅgīḥ aṅgīkurvāṇena tad ukta vipakṣa doṣa anusāreṇa tad parityāgaḥ pi kāryaḥ syāt
translated: Accepting the seven modes as taught by various proponents, following the valid means of knowledge and so on as explained by them, one should also abandon them in accordance with the faults of the opposite position stated by them.

original: tathā cāṅgīkāraparityāgābhyāmubhayata ākṛṣṭo 'yaṃ kaṣṭāṃ daśāmāviṣyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca aṅgīkāra parityāgābhyām ubhayatas ākṛṣṭaḥ yam kaṣṭām daśām āviṣyaḥ syāt
translated: And thus, being drawn from both sides by acceptance and abandonment, he would enter into a difficult situation.

analyzed: nanu ekāntaḥ dvedhā
translated: But one-sidedness is twofold.

analyzed: kramākrama bhedāt
translated: By the distinction of sequence and non-sequence.

analyzed: tatra krama anekānte tāvat na aṅgīkāra parityāgau viruddhau
translated: Among them, in the case of sequential one-sidedness, acceptance and abandonment are not contradictory.

original: akramānekānte 'pi yena rūpeṇa nityatvaṃ tenaivānityatvamityādyanaṅgīkārānna virodhaḥ /
analyzed: akrama anekānte pi yena rūpeṇa nitya tvam tena eva anitya tvam ityādi anaṅgīkārāt na virodhaḥ
translated: Even in the case of non-sequential one-sidedness, there is no contradiction because eternality and non-eternality and so on are not accepted in the same form.

original: tathāca saptabhaṅgayaṅgīkāriṇā mayā tāni pramāṇāni dūṣaṇāni ca vyavasthāpitāni bhavantīti noktadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca sapta bhaṅgayaṅgīkāriṇā mayā tāni pramāṇāni dūṣaṇāni ca vyavasthāpitāni bhavanti iti na ukta doṣaḥ
translated: And thus, by me who accepts the seven modes, those means of knowledge and refutations are established. Therefore, there is no fault as stated.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: tad tad pramāṇa ādīnām vyavasthā anarha tvāt  na khalu tat tat pramāṇavā
translated: Because those various means of knowledge and so on are not worthy of being established.

analyzed: dvi ādibhiḥ tāni tāni pramāṇa ādīni sa avakāśāni upanyastāni
translated: Indeed, those various means of knowledge and so on are not presented by the proponents of those various means of knowledge and so on as having a basis.

analyzed: tasmāt sarveṣu api vādiṣu
translated: Therefore, in all the proponents,

analyzed: vādeṣu parama āstikasya kathitā eva gatiḥ
translated: The highest truth of the one who accepts the seven-fold doctrine has been stated in the debates.

analyzed: api ca evam api sapta bhaṅgayaṅgīkāraḥ nirmūlaḥ eva
translated: Moreover, even in this way, the acceptance of the seven-fold doctrine is baseless.

analyzed: na hi evaṃvādinaḥ vādinaḥ prasiddhāḥ
translated: For those who speak thus are not well-known.

analyzed: sambhāvanayā tad aṅgīkāre ca na saptatva pariniṣṭhā  sambhāvanā avaka akaḥ
translated: And if it is accepted on the basis of possibility, there is no limit to seven.

analyzed: śasya niḥsīma tvāt
translated: Because the possibility is limitless.

original: kiñca sarvāṅgīkārapakṣe syādasti ca nāsti ceti pakṣātsyādasti syānnāstīti pakṣadvayaṃ na bhidyate /
analyzed: kiñca sarva aṅgīkāra pakṣe syāt asti ca na asti ca iti pakṣāt syāt asti syāt na asti iti pakṣa dvayam na bhidyate
translated: Moreover, in the view that accepts everything, the two views it exists and does not exist and it may exist, it may not exist are not different.

analyzed: dvitīya pakṣe tu cala darśanaḥ iti eva dūṣaṇam
translated: But in the second view, the fault is only that it is a doctrine of fluctuating views.

analyzed: apasiddhāntī syāt iti
translated: He would be one who contradicts his own doctrine.

analyzed: tat evam sapta bhaṅgayaṅgīkāraḥ pramāṇa viruddhaḥ prāmāṇikaḥ ca iti uktam
translated: Thus it has been said that the acceptance of the seven-fold doctrine is contrary to valid knowledge and is not based on valid knowledge.

analyzed: akhilaiḥ deṣaiḥ lipyate iti anena paraspara vyāhatiḥ ca iti api sūcitam
translated: By saying is smeared with all faults, it is also indicated that there is mutual contradiction.

original: evambhūtasyāpi saptabhaṅginayasya svīkāre 'tiprasaṅgaṃ cāha atihāyeti //🔽atihāya pramāṇāptaṃ niyamaṃ sadasattayā /
analyzed: evambhūtasya api sapta bhaṅgi nayasya svīkāre tiprasaṅgam ca āha atihāya iti  atihāya pramāṇa āptam niyamam sat asat tayā
translated: Even accepting such a seven-fold doctrine, he says that there is an over-extension, by saying exceeding etc.🔽Exceeding the rule obtained through valid knowledge, as existent and non-existent,🔽all that is contradictory, and always without honor, is contradicted.🔽...

analyzed: aśeṣam ā viruddham ca nirmānam vyāhatam sadā
translated: It is free from all contradictions, devoid of pride, and always consistent.

analyzed: sarva prakāram vadataḥ dṛṣṭa hāniḥ amagrahaḥ
translated: If one speaks of all modes, there is the fault of contradiction, non-apprehension,

analyzed: sva vyāhata tvam ityādyāḥ doṣāḥ sarve bhavanti hi
translated: and self-contradiction, and so on, all the faults arise.

original: aśeṣamāviruddhaṃ vadata ityasyopapādanaṃ vyavasthitayā sadasattayā pramāṇāptaniyamamatihāyeti /
analyzed: aśeṣam ā viruddham vadataḥ iti asya upapādanam vyavasthitayā sat asat tayā pramāṇa āpta niyamam atihāya iti
translated: The explanation of this is that one speaks without contradiction of the entire [object], by abandoning the established true and false, and the restriction obtained through valid cognition.

analyzed: sarve prakārāḥ yasya viśvasya tat tathā uktam
translated: That which has all modes is said to be such.

analyzed: tatas ca asau prakāraḥ ca iti vā
translated: And from that, it is so and it has modes, thus.

analyzed: nanu krama anekānte tāvat kāla bhedena na vyāghātaḥ
translated: But when there is indeterminacy regarding sequence, there is no contradiction by the difference in time.

original: akramānekānte 'pi rūpabhedenetyata uktam sadā sarvaprakāraṃ vadata iti //
analyzed: akrama anekānte rūpa bhedena iti atas uktam sadā sarva prakāram vadate iti
translated: And even when there is indeterminacy regarding non-sequence, there is [no contradiction] by the difference in form. Therefore it is said: always speaking of all modes.

analyzed: sadā iti rūpa abhedasya api upalakṣaṇam
translated: Always is a reference to the non-difference in form.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ
translated: This is the intention:

original: yadi krameṇa vā rūpabhedena vāneprakāratvam tadā nāyamanekāntavādaḥ samarthanīyaḥ /
analyzed: yadi krameṇa vā rūpa bhedena vā aneprakāra tvam tadā na ayam anekāntavādaḥ samarthanīyaḥ
translated: If there is indeterminacy regarding sequence or by the difference in form, then this doctrine of indeterminacy should not be supported.

analyzed: sarvaiḥ api vādibhiḥ aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because it is accepted by all the proponents.

original: nahi ko 'pi vādī padārthānāṃ kālato rūpataścāvasthāvaicitryamanaṅgīkurvāṇo 'sti /
analyzed: nahi kaḥ pi vādī padārthānām kālataḥ rūpataḥ ca avasthā vaicitryam an aṅgīkurvāṇaḥ sti
translated: For there is no proponent who does not accept the variety of states of things in terms of time and form.

analyzed: yam prati anekāntavāda avatāraḥ saṅgaccheta
translated: To whom the introduction of the doctrine of indeterminacy would be appropriate.

original: kevalaṃ kṣaṇabhaṅgo vātyantasatkāryavādo vāvasthāvatoratyantabhedo vāpākaraṇīyaḥ /🔽ataḥ anekāntavādamavatārayatā kṣapaṇakena sadā rūpābhedenaiva ca sarvaprakāraka
analyzed: kevalam kṣaṇa bhaṅgaḥ vā atyanta satkārya vādaḥ vā avasthāvatoḥ atyanta bhedaḥ vā apākaraṇīyaḥ  atas anekāntavādam avatārayatā kṣapaṇakena sadā rūpa abhedena eva ca sarva prakāraka
translated: Only the doctrine of momentariness, the extreme doctrine of the effect being pre-existent in the cause, or the absolute difference between the state and the possessor of the state, should be rejected.

analyzed: tvam iti eva vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, by one who introduces the doctrine of non-absolutism, it should be said that there is always non-difference in form and that there is omniscience in all ways.

analyzed: tathā ca na vyāghāta nistāraḥ iti
translated: And thus there is no escape from contradiction.

original: aśeṣamāviruddhaṃ sadā sarvaprakāratvaṃ vadato dṛṣṭahāniḥ syāt /🔽nirmāna ca sadā sarvaprakāraṃ vadato amagraho aprāmāṇikasvīkāraḥ syāt /
analyzed: aśeṣam ā viruddham sadā sarva prakāra tvam vadataḥ dṛṣṭa hāniḥ syāt  ca sadā sarva prakāram vadataḥ aprāmāṇika svīkāraḥ syāt
translated: For one who always speaks of everything in an irreconcilable way, there would be the fault of abandoning what is seen.

original: vyāhataṃ sadā sarvaprakāraṃ vadataḥ svavyāhatatvaṃ syāditi yojanā /
analyzed: vyāhatam sadā sarva prakāram vadataḥ sva vyāhata tvam syāt iti yojanā
translated: For one who always speaks of everything in a self-contradictory way, there would be the fault of self-contradiction.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa hāna ādi anuṣaṅgi doṣa antara saṅgraha artham ityādyāḥ iti uktam
translated: The compound ādi is used to include other faults that follow from abandoning what is seen.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ sarvatra prasaṅga hetu sūcana arthaḥ
translated: The word hi is used everywhere to indicate the reason for the consequence.

original: ayamarthaḥ /🔽yadi pramāṇaviruddhamapi sarvaprakāratvaṃ viśvasya svīkriyate tadā dahanaśaityaṃ vā gavālambhanāderdharmasādhanatvādikaṃ vācā
