analyzed: ayam arthaḥ  yadi pramāṇa viruddham api sarva prakāra tvam viśvasya svīkriyate tadā dahana śaityam vā gavā ālambhana ādeḥ dharma sādhanatva ādikam vācā
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: ṅgīkāryam syāt
translated: If even what is contradicted by valid cognition, namely the all-pervasiveness of the universe, is accepted, then the coldness of fire or the means of accomplishing dharma such as killing cows would have to be accepted.

analyzed: pramāṇa virodhena pratipakṣa nirākaraṇam ca na syāt
translated: And the refutation of opponents by contradicting valid means of knowledge would not be possible.

analyzed: kintu pratyabhijñā ādi viruddham api kṣaṇikatva ādikam aṅgīkartavyam syāt
translated: But momentariness, etc., even though contradictory to recognition, etc., would have to be accepted.

analyzed: aviśeṣāt
translated: Because there is no distinction.

original: yadi cāprāmāṇikamapi sarvaprakāratvamurarīkriyate tadā kharaviṣāṇādikaṃ vā gomāṃsādibhakṣaṇasya dharmasādhanatvaṃ corarīkaraṇīyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca aprāmāṇikam api sarva prakāra tvam urarīkriyate tadā khara viṣāṇa ādikam vā go māṃsa ādi bhakṣaṇasya dharma sādhana tvam ca urarīkaraṇīyam syāt
translated: And if all kinds of [doctrines] are accepted even though not based on valid means of knowledge, then the eating of donkey's horn, etc., and the means of accomplishing Dharma by eating cow meat, etc., would have to be accepted.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvena para mata nirāsaḥ pi na kāryaḥ syāt
translated: The refutation of others' views by the absence of valid means of knowledge should also not be done.

analyzed: tat api abhyupagamanīyam eva bhavet aviśeṣāt
translated: That too would have to be accepted, because there is no distinction.

analyzed: tathā ca dūṣya upādeya hīnasya śāstra nirmāṇam api na syāt
translated: And thus, the composition of a treatise devoid of faults and virtues would also not be possible.

original: yadi ca vyāhatamapi sarvaprakāratvamaṅgīkuryāt tadā māturapi vandhyatvaṃ /
analyzed: yadi ca vyāhatam api sarva prakāra tvam aṅgīkuryāt tadā mātuḥ api vandhya tvam
translated: And if one were to accept all kinds of [doctrines] even though contradictory, then even one's mother would be barren.

analyzed: jina upadeśasya pramāṇa tayā abhyupagatasya api aprāmāṇyam  baddhasya api mukta tvam
translated: Even the Jina's teachings, which are accepted as valid means of knowledge, would be invalid.🔽Even one who is bound would be liberated.

analyzed: muktasya api baddha tvam
translated: Even one who is liberated would be bound.

analyzed: siddhasya api rāgi tvam
translated: Even one who is accomplished would be passionate.

analyzed: śvapacasya api siddha tvam ityādi sarvam api aṅgīkuryāt
translated: Even an outcaste would be accomplished, and so on - all of this would have to be accepted.

analyzed: kāryam syāt
translated: It would have to be done.

analyzed: anyathā anekānta bhaṅga prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the consequence of the destruction of non-absolutism.

analyzed: evam ca na śāstra praṇayana prayāsaḥ kāryaḥ
translated: And thus the effort to compose a treatise is not to be undertaken,

analyzed: matta unmatta ādibhiḥ eva asya kṛta tvāt iti
translated: since it has already been done by madmen and so on.

original: evaṃ viśvasya kṣapaṇakoktaṃ sarvaprakāratvaṃ nirākṛtya taduktamarthāntaramapi nirākartumanuvadati vaktīti //
analyzed: evam viśvasya kṣapaṇaka uktam sarva prakāra tvam nirākṛtya tad uktam artha antaram api nirākartum anuvadati vakti iti
translated: Having thus refuted the view expressed by Kṣapaṇaka that the universe is of all kinds, he quotes what was said by him as another meaning in order to refute that also, saying he says and so on.

analyzed: vakti sva prabham ātmānam deha mānam
translated: He says that the self is self-luminous and has the measure of the body.

analyzed: kṣapaṇakaḥ iti vartate
translated: Kṣapaṇaka is understood.

analyzed: sva prabham sva prakāśam
translated: Self-luminous means self-manifest.

original: dehasya mānaṃ parimāṇamiva mānaṃ yasyāsau tathoktaḥ /
analyzed: dehasya mānam parimāṇam iva mānam yasya asau tathā uktaḥ
translated: Having the measure of the body means having a size like the body.

analyzed: atra deha māna tvam eva vipratipannaḥ rthaḥ
translated: Here, having the measure of the body is the disputed meaning.

analyzed: sva prabha tvam tu sammatam eva asmākam  yat vā sva prabham iti kriyāviśeṣaṇam
translated: But self-luminosity is accepted by us.🔽Or self-luminous is an adverb.

analyzed: vinā pramāṇena svīyayā prabhayā utprekṣya eva vakti iti
translated: Without any means of knowledge, he says, having imagined it by his own light.

analyzed: athavā anena deha parimāṇa tve jaina uktam pramāṇa abhāvasam anuvadati
translated: Or by this he repeats the absence of means of knowledge stated by the Jainas in the case of having the measure of the body.

analyzed: tatra sva śabdena svīyaḥ dehaḥ ucyate
translated: There, by the word his own, one's own body is meant.

analyzed: tatra prabhā yasya asau tathā uktaḥ
translated: And that which has light in that is said to be so.

analyzed: tathā ca prayogaḥ
translated: And thus the argument is:

analyzed: devadatta ātmā
translated: The self of Devadatta

analyzed: tad dehe eva
translated: is just his body.

analyzed: tatra sarvatra eva ca vidyate
translated: And it exists everywhere there.

analyzed: tatra eva tatra sarvatra eva ca sva asādhāraṇa guṇa ādhāra tayā upalambhāt
translated: Because it is perceived as the substratum of its own uncommon qualities there and everywhere.

analyzed: yaḥ yatra eva
translated: Whoever is only there,

analyzed: yatra savartrā eva sva a sādhāraṇa guṇa ādhāra tayā upalabhyate
translated: wherever it is perceived as the substratum of its own uncommon qualities,

analyzed: sa tatra eva
translated: he is only there.

analyzed: tatra sarvatra ca vidyate
translated: And it exists there and everywhere.

original: yathā devadattagṛha eva tatra sarvatraiva copalabhyamānasvāsādhāraṇabhāsvaratvādiguṇaḥ pradīpaḥ /
analyzed: yathā devadatta gṛhe eva tatra sarvatra eva ca upalabhyamāna sva asādhāraṇa bhāsvara tva ādi guṇaḥ pradīpaḥ
translated: Just as a lamp, which is perceived as having its own uncommon qualities of brightness, etc., only in Devadatta's house and everywhere there,

analyzed: tathā ca ayam tasmāt tathā iti  anyathā kamanīya tanayā āliṅganena sarvatra āhlādā aka  da karasya sva
translated: and this is so, therefore it is so.

analyzed: sukhasya ananubhava prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the contingence of the non-experience of one's own happiness, which delights everywhere by the embrace of a beautiful woman.

analyzed: tathā ca sarvāṅgīṇa romāñca ādi kārya anudayaḥ syāt iti
translated: And thus there would be no arising of effects like horripilation all over the body.

original: yadvā pradīpasyeva svānapāyinī prabhā yasyāsau svaprabha iti / /
analyzed: yat vā pradīpasya iva sva anapāyinī prabhā yasya asau sva prabhaḥ iti
translated: Or, he who has his own light that does not depart from him like a lamp, is called svaprabha (having self-luminosity).

analyzed: atra ātmanaḥ kāya parimāṇa tva nirāsa artham sūtram
translated: Here, in order to refute the view that the self has the size of the body, there is a sutra:

analyzed: om evam ca ātmā akātsnaryam om  iti
translated: Om. Thus, the self is not partial. Om.

analyzed: tasya tātparyam āha tat api iti
translated: This is the meaning of that (sutra). He says: That also...

analyzed: evam ca ātma akārtsnyam
translated: Thus, the self is not partial.

original: na ca paryāyād apy avirodho vikārādibhyaḥ / / / /
analyzed: na ca paryāyāt api avirodhaḥ vikāra ādibhyaḥ
translated: And there is no non-contradiction even from the alternatives, due to modification, etc.

analyzed: tat api alam
translated: That too is enough.

analyzed: duṣyam nānā śarīreṣu praveśāt anyathābhavāt
translated: Due to entering into various bodies and becoming otherwise,

analyzed: kutas
translated: Wherefrom?

analyzed: akātsnarya ādi prasaṅgāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is due to the contingence of incompleteness, etc.

analyzed: pipīlikā ādi deha sthasya tad parimāṇasya ātmanaḥ karma vipāka vaśāt gaja gavaya ādi deha prāptau tatra akātsnaryam syāt
translated: For one whose self has the size of an ant's body, there would be incompleteness in attaining an elephant's or cow's body due to the ripening of karma.

original: gajādidehagatasya ca tatparimāṇasya pipīlikādidehe 'tirekaḥ syādityubhayathā kāyaparimāṇatvānupapattireveti /
analyzed: gaja ādi deha gatasya ca tad parimāṇasya pipīlika ādi dehe tirekaḥ syāt iti ubhayathā kāya parimāṇa tva anupapattiḥ eva iti
translated: And for one whose size is that of an elephant's body, there would be excess in an ant's body. Thus, in both cases, there is the non-establishment of the size of the body.

analyzed: etad artha tvena vā
translated: Or this is the meaning:

analyzed: ca nānā śarīreṣu iti vākyam yojyam
translated: The sentence in various bodies should be connected.

analyzed: tatra anyathābhāvāt iti kāya parimāṇa tva abhāva āpatteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: There, the meaning is that due to becoming otherwise means the contingence of the non-establishment of the size of the body.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: yaṃ yaṃ dehaṃ prāpnotyātmā tattatparimāṇo bhavatyato noktadoṣa ityāśaṅkānirāsārthaṃ sūtram oṃ naca paryāyādapyavirodho vikārādibhyaḥ oṃ //
analyzed: yam yam deham prāpnoti ātmā tad tad parimāṇaḥ bhavati atas na ukta doṣaḥ iti āśaṅkā nirāsa artham sūtram om na ca paryāyāt api avirodhaḥ vikāra ādibhyaḥ om
translated: The self becomes of that size when it attains any body. Therefore, there is no fault stated. To refute this doubt, the aphorism is: And there is no non-contradiction even from the alternatives, due to modification, etc.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tasya tātparyam āha tat api alam iti
translated: He states the purport of that: That too is enough.

analyzed: citta stham parimāṇa paryāyam tad śabdena parāmṛśati
translated: The word 'that' refers to the synonym 'size' which is located in the mind.

analyzed: nānā śarīreṣu praveśāt anyathābhāvāt
translated: Because of entering into various bodies, there is a change.

analyzed: iti sthūla sūkṣma śarīreṣu praveśāt sthūla sūkṣma parimāṇa upajana
translated: Thus, because of entering into gross and subtle bodies, when there is production of gross and subtle size,

analyzed: sati parimāṇa tadvatoḥ atyanta bheda anabhyupagamāt ātmanaḥ eva anyathābhāva prasaṅgāt iti arthaḥ
translated: since an absolute difference between size and its possessor is not accepted, it follows that the self itself undergoes a change. This is the meaning.

original: astvātmana evānyathābhāvāstataḥ ko doṣa ityata āha anyatheti //
analyzed: astu ātmanaḥ eva anyathābhāvāḥ tatas kaḥ doṣaḥ iti atas āha anyathā iti
translated: Let the self itself undergo a change. What is the fault in that? To this he says 'Otherwise,' etc.

analyzed: anyathābhāvi yat vastu tat anityam iti sthitiḥ
translated: The position is that an entity which undergoes a change is impermanent.

analyzed: tad mate
translated: In that view...

analyzed: sthitiḥ vyāptiḥ
translated: 'Position' means pervasion.

analyzed: tad mata jaina darśane
translated: In that view, in the Jaina doctrine.

analyzed: aṅgīkṛtā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: 'Is accepted' is understood.

analyzed: tatas pi kim iti atas āha tat iti
translated: What follows from that? To this he says 'That,' etc.

analyzed: tad anitya tvam
translated: That impermanence...

original: yata evaṃ vyāptiryataścānyathābhāvitvamaṅgīkṛtaṃ tat tasmādātmano 'nityatvamāpatatīti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yatas evam vyāptiḥ yatas ca anyathābhāvi tvam aṅgīkṛtam tat tasmāt ātmanaḥ nitya tvam āpatati iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Since this is the pervasion and since change is accepted, therefore it follows that the self is impermanent. This is the remainder.

analyzed: atra dṛṣṭāntaḥ pudgala iti
translated: Here the example is 'pudgala,' etc.

analyzed: pudgalasya anivāritam
translated: For the pudgala, there is no obstruction...

analyzed: iva śabdaḥ dhyā ahāryaḥ
translated: The word 'iva' (like) is to be supplied.

analyzed: pudgalasya dehasya iva iti
translated: Like the body of the pudgala.

analyzed: yat vā pudgala śabdaḥ jarat jainaiḥ ātma vāci tvena svīkṛtaḥ iti atra ātma vācī
translated: Or, the word pudgala is accepted by the Jains as denoting the self, so here it means self.

analyzed: yat vā yadi vā sva matena ayam ātmani prayuktaḥ
translated: Or, if it is used for the self according to their own doctrine.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ
translated: As they say:

analyzed: pudgalaḥ nirayayam giran iti  nanu avasthā paryāya rūpeṇa āpyā
translated: The pudgala is reborn in hell.

analyzed: tmanaḥ pi anitya tvam aṅgīkriyate eva
translated: But isn't impermanence of the self also accepted in the form of the change of states?

analyzed: tat katham anitya tva āpādanam iti atas vā pudgalasya dehasya iva iti uktam
translated: How then is impermanence being imposed? Therefore, it is said: of the pudgala, as of the body.

original: yathā dehasya dehākāranāmaparityāgena bhasmībhāvalakṣaṇānityatvaṃ tathāvidhamātamno 'pyāpādyata iti /
analyzed: yathā dehasya deha ākāra nāma parityāgena bhasmībhāva lakṣaṇa anitya tvam tathāvidham ātamnaḥ pi āpādyate iti
translated: Just as the impermanence characterized by being reduced to ashes by abandoning the form and name of the body, that kind of impermanence is imposed on the self also.

original: nanu anyathābhāvasyaivaṃ vidhānityatvena vyāptirnāsti paramāṇvādau vyabhicārāt /
analyzed: nanu anyathābhāvasya evaṃvidha anitya tvena vyāptiḥ nā asti paramāṇu ādau vyabhicārāt
translated: But the pervasion of the change in another way by such impermanence does not exist, because of inconstancy in the atom, etc.

analyzed: tat katham āpādanam
translated: How then is it imposed?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: parimāṇa vyatyaya lakṣaṇasya anyathābhāvasya evaṃvidha anitya tva vyāpta tvena deha ādau dṛṣṭatayā tadvataḥ pi ātmanaḥ tathāvidha anitya tvasya nivārayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: Since the change characterized by the reversal of dimension is seen in the body, etc. as pervaded by such impermanence, it is impossible to prevent the self, which possesses that, from having such impermanence.

analyzed: tat idam uktam anivāritam iti
translated: This is what is meant by saying it cannot be prevented.

analyzed: nanu asmad mata vat bhavat mate pi ātmanaḥ nyathābhāvaḥ sti eva sukha duḥkhābhyām ucca nīcatva abhyupagamāt
translated: But in your doctrine also, as in our doctrine, there is a change of the soul, because you admit that it is exalted and depressed by pleasure and pain.

analyzed: anyathābhāvinaḥ ca deha ādeḥ anitya tā upalabdhā
translated: And the body, etc., which are subject to change, are found to be non-eternal.

analyzed: tasmāt bhavat mate pi ātmanaḥ nitya tā durvārā iti atas āha na iti
translated: Therefore, even in your doctrine, the non-eternality of the soul is unavoidable. To this he says No.

analyzed: nā anityatā asmat pakṣe tu caitanya ādeḥ viśeṣiṇaḥ
translated: In our doctrine, there is no non-eternality of consciousness, etc., which are qualified.

original: lakṣaṇasya nivṛttau tu syānna taccetane kvacit // / / //
analyzed: lakṣaṇasya nivṛttau tu syāt na tat cetane kvacid
translated: But if the characteristic is removed, it would not exist anywhere in consciousness.

original: anyathābhāvavato 'pyātmanaḥ prasajyata iti śeṣaḥ /🔽tatkathamityata āha caitanyāderiti //
analyzed: anyathā bhāvavataḥ pi ātmanaḥ prasajyate iti śeṣaḥ  tat katham iti atas āha caitanya ādeḥ iti
translated: The rest is that even for the soul which is subject to change, it would follow.🔽How is that? To this he says of consciousness, etc.

analyzed: asmad mataḥ iti vartate
translated: In our doctrine is understood.

analyzed: anitya tā iti ca
translated: And non-eternality.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: The word tu (but) is for emphasis.

original: asmanmate caitanyāderlakṣaṇasya nivṛttāveva viśeṣiṇo lakṣaṇavato 'rthasyānityatā syāt /
analyzed: asmad mate caitanya ādeḥ lakṣaṇasya nivṛttau eva viśeṣiṇaḥ lakṣaṇavataḥ rthasya anitya tā syāt
translated: And in our doctrine, if the characteristic of consciousness, etc. is removed, the non-eternality of the qualified object, which has a characteristic, would occur.

analyzed: na tu jainānām iva anyathābhāva mātreṇa
translated: But not by mere change, as in the Jaina doctrine.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

original: yasya vastuno yallakṣaṇaṃ tannivṛttirūpo 'nyathābhāva eva tadanityatānibandhanaṃ nānyathābhāvamātramiti /
analyzed: yasya vastunaḥ yat lakṣaṇam tad nivṛtti rūpaḥ nyathābhāvaḥ eva tad anitya tā nibandhanam na anyathābhāva mātram iti
translated: The cause of non-eternality of a thing is only that change which consists in the removal of its characteristic, not mere change.

original: evaṃ tarhi śabdādilakṣaṇābhāvādgaganādīnāṃ mahāpralaye vināśaḥ syāt /
analyzed: evam tarhi śabda ādi lakṣaṇa abhāvāt gagana ādīnām mahāpralaye vināśaḥ syāt
translated: If it is so, then, due to the absence of characteristics like sound, etc., space, etc. would be destroyed at the time of the great dissolution.

original: ceṣyāśrayatvābhāvāccharīrasya suptyādau vilayo bhavedityata uktam viśeṣiṇo lakṣaṇasyeti //
analyzed: ceṣyā āśraya tva abhāvāt śarīrasya supti ādau vilayaḥ bhavet iti atas uktam viśeṣiṇaḥ lakṣaṇasya iti
translated: And due to the absence of a substratum for desire, the body would be dissolved during sleep, etc. Hence it is said: of the qualified characteristic.

analyzed: viśeṣavataḥ lakṣaṇasya na tu lakṣaṇa mātrasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: of the characteristic that has a particular, not of the characteristic alone.

analyzed: kim atas yadi evam iti atas āha na iti
translated: What follows from this if it is so? Hence it is said: No.

analyzed: tat iti sāmānyena vākya artham parāmṛśati
translated: He refers to the meaning of the sentence in general by saying that.

original: anityatvakāraṇatvenoktaṃ viśeṣiṇo lakṣaṇasya nivartanaṃ cetane kvacidapi na syāt /
analyzed: anitya tva kāraṇa tvena uktam viśeṣiṇaḥ lakṣaṇasya nivartanam cetane kvacid api na syāt
translated: The cessation of the qualified characteristic, which is stated as the cause of impermanence, would not occur anywhere in a conscious being.

analyzed: atas tasya anitya tā api na syāt
translated: Therefore, its impermanence would not occur either.

analyzed: yat vā tat iti
translated: Or, the word that refers to the characteristic.

original: cetane vartamānaṃ kvacinna nivartata iti śeṣaḥ / /🔽viśeṣiṇo lakṣaṇasya nivṛttau lakṣasyānityatā syādityuktam /
analyzed: cetane vartamānam kvacid na nivartate iti śeṣaḥ  viśeṣiṇaḥ lakṣaṇasya nivṛttau lakṣasya anitya tā syāt iti uktam
translated: The remainder is: It does not cease anywhere in a conscious being.🔽It has been said that if the qualified characteristic ceases, the characterized would be impermanent.

analyzed: tat viśadayati ota iti  ota prota ātmaka tvam tu paṭe dehe ṅga saṃsthitiḥ
translated: He clarifies that by saying But the cessation of the characteristic of being woven and unwoven, etc.🔽But the cessation of the characteristic of being woven and unwoven, etc.,

analyzed: ityādi lakṣaṇasya eva nivṛttau syāt anitya tā
translated: such as the arrangement of parts in a cloth or body, would result in impermanence.🔽The characteristic of being woven and unwoven, etc.,🔽such as the arrangement of parts in a cloth or body, would result in impermanence.

original: otaprotātmakatvaṃ nāma tantūnāṃ saṃyogaviśeṣaḥ paṭe lakṣaṇamiti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: otaprota ātmaka tvam nāma tantūnām saṃyoga viśeṣaḥ paṭe lakṣaṇam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The nature of being woven is a particular conjunction of threads in a cloth, this is the definition, the rest is understood.

analyzed: aṅga saṃsthitiḥ kara caraṇa ādi aṅgānām sanniveśa viśeṣaḥ
translated: The arrangement of limbs is the particular arrangement of limbs such as hands and feet.

analyzed: ādi śabdaḥ prakāra vacanaḥ
translated: The word ādi (etc.) means type.

analyzed: anitya tā lakṣyasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The impermanence is of the defined object, the rest is understood.

analyzed: yāvat lakṣya bhāvinām lakṣaṇānām nivṛttiḥ eva lakṣya anitya tva nimittam
translated: The cessation of definitions that exist as long as the defined object is the cause of the impermanence of the defined object.

analyzed: tādṛśam ca ātmanaḥ caitanyam
translated: And such is the sentience of the self.

original: tacca kadāpi na nivartate iti kathaṃ tasya vināśaprasaṅga iti /
analyzed: tat ca kadāpi na nivartate iti katham tasya vināśa prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: And that never ceases, so how can there be a possibility of its destruction?

analyzed: yat uktam ātmā sva prabhaḥ iti tat api asat
translated: What was said, that the self is self-luminous, that is also false.

analyzed: sva prabhāvataḥ pradīpa ādeḥ iva rūpa sparśa āpatteḥ
translated: Because of the attainment of form and touch like a lamp etc. by its own power.

analyzed: rūpa ādima tvāt ca vināśi tva āpatteḥ
translated: And because of having form etc., there is the consequence of impermanence.

analyzed: yat rūpa ādimat tat anitya tvam iti pareṇa eva vyāpteḥ aṅgīkṛta tvāt iti
translated: Because the pervasion that whatever has form etc. is impermanent is accepted by the opponent himself.

analyzed: nanu siddhānte pi ātmanaḥ rūpa ādimattvam aṅgīkriyate eva
translated: But even in the established doctrine, the self is accepted as having form etc.

analyzed: rūpa ādimataḥ nitya tvam iti vyāptiḥ ca
translated: And the pervasion that whatever has form etc. is impermanent.

analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvāt ca viparyayaḥ darśanāt
translated: And because of having form etc., there is the opposite seen.

analyzed: iti ukta tvāt
translated: Because it was said thus.

analyzed: tat katham anitya tva parihāraḥ iti atas āha bhautikam tu iti
translated: How then is the avoidance of impermanence? To this he says: But material form, etc.

original: bhautikaṃ tveva rūpādi vyāptaṃ nāśena no mate // / / // /
analyzed: bhautikam tu eva rūpa ādi vyāptam nāśena naḥ mate
translated: is indeed pervaded by destruction, not according to our opinion.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word but has the meaning of distinction.

analyzed: saḥ eva bhautikam iti vivṛtaḥ  na rūpa ādi mātram iti eva arthaḥ
translated: That itself is explained as material.🔽The meaning is not just form, etc.

analyzed: na ca bhautikam rūpa ādikam ātmani asti
translated: And material form, etc. do not exist in the self.

analyzed: tasmāt na anitya tā prasaṅgaḥ iti bhāvaḥ  yathā bhavadbhiḥ anyathābhāvaḥ viśeṣyate
translated: Therefore, there is no consequence of impermanence - this is the idea.🔽Just as you qualify otherness

analyzed: yāvat lakṣya bhāvi viśeṣa
translated: as the form of exclusion from the definition that occurs as long as the defined object exists,🔽otherness is pervaded by impermanence.

analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvam ca bhautika tvena
translated: And the possession of form, etc. is pervaded by being material.

original: tathāsmanmate 'pi viśeṣaṇaprakṣepe noktadoṣa ityata āha naivamiti //
analyzed: tathā asmad mate viśeṣaṇa prakṣepe na ukta doṣaḥ iti atas āha na evam iti
translated: Similarly, even in our opinion, when a qualifier is inserted, there is no fault stated. Therefore he says not so

analyzed: na evam tasya
translated: Not so, of that...

original: tasya kṣapaṇakasya mate naivamanyathābhāvo rūpādimattvaṃ ca viśeṣyate /
analyzed: tasya kṣapaṇakasya mate na evam anyathābhāvaḥ rūpa ādimattvam ca viśeṣyate
translated: In the opinion of that Jaina, otherness and the possession of form, etc. are not qualified in this way.

analyzed: kintu sāmānyam eva anitya tva vyāptatayā aṅgīkriyate tatas na ukta doṣa parihāraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But only the general is accepted as pervaded by impermanence. Therefore, the stated fault is not avoided - this is the meaning.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha anyathā iti
translated: How is that? To this he says otherwise...

analyzed: anyathābhāvaḥ yasya anitya tvam īritam
translated: The otherness of that which is said to be impermanent.

analyzed: rūpa ādi yuktasya tathā jagat nāśi tva siddhaye
translated: In the same way, for the establishment of the destruction of the world endowed with form etc.,

analyzed: nāśi tva siddhaye yasya anyathābhāvaḥ tasya anitya tvam īritam kṣapaṇakena
translated: For the establishment of the destructibility of the earth, mountains etc. due to their motion, the otherness of that which is said to be impermanent by the Jaina.

analyzed: tathāśabdaḥ samuccaye
translated: The word tathā (in the same way) is for inclusion.

analyzed: rūpa ādi yuktasya api anitya tvam īritam iti
translated: The impermanence of that which is endowed with form etc. is also said.

original: yadvā yat rūpādiyuktaṃ tatta🔽k tattathānityamīritamita yojanā /
analyzed: yat vā yat rūpa ādi yuktam tat ta  tat tathā anityam īritam ita yojanā
translated: Or, that which is endowed with form etc. is that.🔽It is construed as that is impermanent is said.

analyzed: tasya iti ata yasya iti anena anvayaḥ  anyathā tu yad śabda śravaṇāt tad śabda adhyāhāraḥ
translated: The word tasya (its) is connected with the word yasya (of which).🔽Otherwise, due to hearing the word yat, the word tat (that) is to be supplied.

analyzed: pūrva vākyāt tasya iti anuvartate vā
translated: Or, tasya (its) is to be supplied from the previous sentence.

analyzed: etat ca upapādayiṣyate
translated: And this will be explained.

analyzed: uktam upasaṃharati vyāptyā iti  vyāptyā tayā anyathā bhāvāt ātmanaḥ nitya tā bhavet
translated: He concludes what was said with by the pervasion.🔽By that pervasion, the impermanence of the self would be due to its otherness.

analyzed: yat anyathābhāvi tat anityam yat ca rūpa ādimat tat anityam iti vyāptyā
translated: Whatever is subject to change is impermanent, and whatever possesses form etc. is impermanent - by this pervasion.

analyzed: anyathābhāvāt iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: Due to its otherness is a synecdoche.

analyzed: rūpa ādimat tvāt ca iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: And due to possessing form etc. should also be seen.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: sampratipanna vyāptika vyāpya āropoṇa
translated: The superimposition of the pervaded on the basis of a commonly accepted pervasion,

analyzed: aniṣya vyāpaka āropaḥ
translated: The imputation of undesired pervasion

analyzed: paṇam tarkaḥ
translated: is a wager.

original: atra ca na cedvayāptiḥ sammatā kathaṃ tarhi tarkatvam /
analyzed: atra ca na ced vayāptiḥ sammatā katham tarhi tarka tvam
translated: And here, if pervasion is not accepted, then how can it be a wager?

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: vyāpya vat vayāpteḥ api para abhyupagata tve pi tarka tva avirodhāt
translated: Even when the pervasion of the pervaded is accepted by the opponent, it does not contradict being a wager.

analyzed: evam eva kvacid āśrayasya ubhaya asammatau api na doṣaḥ
translated: In the same way, even when the basis is not accepted by both in some cases, there is no fault.

analyzed: vakṣyati ca etat para nyāyaiḥ tu dūṣaṇam iti
translated: And he will say this: Refutation by the arguments of others.

original: kṣapaṇoktaṃ prameyāntaraṃ nirākartuṃ sūtram oṃ antyāvasthiteścobhayanityatvādaviśeṣāt oṃ //
analyzed: kṣapaṇa uktam prameya antaram nirākartum sūtram om antya avasthiteḥ ca ubhaya nitya tvāt aviśeṣāt om
translated: To refute another topic of discussion stated by the Jains, the aphorism begins: And because of the final state, because of the eternality of both, and because of the absence of distinction.

analyzed: iti
translated: This is it.

analyzed: tatra antya avasthiteḥ ca iti etāvat tāvat vayākhyāti nityā iti
translated: Here, he explains only up to And because of the final state. Eternality is it.

analyzed: antya avasthiteḥ ca ubhaya nitya tvāt aviśeṣaḥ
translated: And because of the final state, because of the eternality of both, there is no distinction.

analyzed: nitya ūrdhva gatiḥ api eṣā yā muktiḥ iti kathyate
translated: This upward movement to the eternal is also called liberation.

original: alokākāśamāptasya kathaṃ na vikṛtiśca sā // / / // /🔽apiśabdaḥ prameyāntaranirākaraṇasamuccayārthaḥ /
analyzed: a loka ākāśam āptasya katham na vikṛtiḥ ca sā  api śabdaḥ prameya antara nirākaraṇa samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: How can that which reaches the space of non-light be a modification?🔽The word also is for the purpose of including the refutation of another topic of discussion.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ parimāṇa paryāyeṇa saha samuccaye
translated: The word and is for the purpose of including along with the synonym size.

original: yā eṣā nityordhvagatirmuktiriti jainaiḥ kathyate sā ca kathamātmano vikṛtirno bhavet /
analyzed: yā eṣā nitya ūrdhva gatiḥ muktiḥ iti jainaiḥ kathyate sā ca katham ātmanaḥ vikṛtiḥ no bhavet
translated: And how could that which is called by the Jains 'liberation' - the eternal upward motion - not be a modification of the self?

analyzed: bhevedeva
translated: It must be a modification.

analyzed: tat katham
translated: How so?

analyzed: a loka ākāśam āptasya
translated: Of one who has attained the space beyond the world.

analyzed: prāk loka ākāśa sthaḥ hi ayam ātmā nirantara ūrdhva gatyā loka ākāśam āpnoti
translated: For this self, while residing in the space of the world, attains the space beyond the world through uninterrupted upward motion.

analyzed: tathāca anyathābhāvāt ātmanaḥ nitya tva āpattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, because of becoming otherwise, the self would be subject to impermanence - this is the idea.

analyzed: anena antyā yā
translated: By this, the last

analyzed: avasthitiḥ santata ūrdhva gati lakṣaṇā  tatas ca ātmanaḥ nitya tva āpattiḥ iti sūtrakhaṇḍasya arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: state, characterized by continuous upward motion,🔽and thus the self would be subject to impermanence - this is the meaning of the portion of the sutra that has been stated.

original: nanvanyathābhāvamātramanityatvasya prayojakamiti na tāvadbhavadīyaḥ pakṣa ityuktam /
analyzed: nanu anyathābhāva mātram anitya tvasya prayojakam iti na tāvat bhavadīyaḥ pakṣaḥ iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that mere becoming otherwise is not the cause of impermanence, so this is not your view.

analyzed: na api madīyaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: Nor is it my view.

original: tatkathaṃ pradeśaviśeṣasaṃyogamātrarūpānyathātvena muktātmano 'nityatvaprasañjanamityato jainapakṣo 'yamiti samarthayituṃ tāvatpṛcchati kīdṛśaśceti
analyzed: tat katham pradeśa viśeṣa saṃyoga mātra rūpa anyathātvena mukta ātmanaḥ nitya tva prasañjanam iti atas jaina pakṣaḥ yam iti samarthayitum tāvat pṛcchati kīdṛśaḥ ca iti
translated: Then how is it that the self in liberation, by the mere becoming otherwise in the form of contact with a particular region, is subject to impermanence? In order to establish this as the view of the Jains, he asks first of all, And what kind of becoming otherwise is accepted as the cause of destruction?

analyzed: kīdṛśaḥ ca anyathābhāvaḥ nāśa hetutayā iṣyate
translated: And what kind of becoming otherwise is accepted as the cause of destruction?

original: kṣapaṇakena hi kṣityādeḥ sarvasya nityatvādyanekāntaṃ samarthayamānena dravyaparyāyābhyāṃ nityatvamanityatvaṃ cetyuktam /
analyzed: kṣapaṇakena hi kṣiti ādeḥ sarvasya nitya tva ādi anekāntam samarthayamānena dravya paryāyābhyām nitya tvam anitya tvam ca iti uktam
translated: For the Jaina Kṣapaṇaka, while establishing the non-one-sidedness of the eternality etc. of earth and all else, has said that eternality and non-eternality are due to substance and modification.

analyzed: dravya ākārasya kadāpi anapāyāt nitya tvam
translated: Eternality is due to the form of substance never disappearing at any time.

analyzed: paryāyaḥ nyathābhāvaḥ tasmāt anitya tvam iti
translated: Modification is the state of being otherwise. Non-eternality is due to that.

analyzed: tatra vaktavyam  kīdṛśaḥ tra anyathābhāvaḥ nāśam prati hetutayā iṣyate
translated: Regarding that, it should be said:🔽What kind of state of being otherwise is accepted as the cause of destruction here?

analyzed: kim saṃsthāna ādi lakṣaṇa apagama rūpaḥ vā
translated: Is it in the form of the disappearance of the characteristics such as shape,

analyzed: sa dhāraṇaḥ vā iti bhāvaḥ  ādyam śaṅkate saṃsthāna iti
translated: or is it common? This is the idea.

analyzed: saṃsthāna apagamaḥ ced
translated: He doubts the first in If it is the disappearance of shape...🔽If it is the disappearance of shape...

analyzed: saṃsthāna grahaṇam lakṣaṇa upalakṣaṇam  nāśa hetutayā iṣyate iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The mention of shape is a metaphor for characteristics.🔽The connection is: is accepted as the cause of destruction.

analyzed: pratiṣedhati sa na iti
translated: He denies it with No, that cannot be said...

analyzed: sa nahi bhū sāgara ādiṣu
translated: No, that cannot be said of earth, water, etc.

analyzed: vaktum śakyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: can be said.

original: kuto netyata āha sa na hīti //
analyzed: kutas na iti atas āha sa na hi iti
translated: Why not? Therefore he says No, that cannot be said...

original: yāvallakṣyabhāvilakṣaṇāpagamalakṣaṇo 'nyathābhāvo bhūsāgarādiṣu pakṣaikadeśabhūteṣu na hīdānīṃ pramitastato hetoḥ sandigdhāsiddhatvaṃ syādityarthaḥ
analyzed: yāvat lakṣya bhāvi lakṣaṇa apagama lakṣaṇaḥ nyathābhāvaḥ bhū sāgara ādiṣu pakṣa eka deśa bhūteṣu na hi idānīm pramitaḥ tatas hetoḥ sandigdha asiddha tvam syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that as long as the transformation, which is the absence of the characteristic of having a visible form, is not ascertained in the case of the earth, ocean, etc., which are parts of the subject, then the reason would be uncertain due to being unestablished.

original: pramitatve tu tasyānityatve 'pi saṃśayo nāstītyanumānaṃ vyarthamāpadyate / /
analyzed: pramita tve tu tasya anitya tve pi saṃśayaḥ nā asti iti anumānam vyartham āpadyate
translated: But if it is ascertained, then there is no doubt even in its impermanence, so the inference would become pointless.

analyzed: tarhi dvitīyaḥ u stu iti śaṅkate yaḥ kaścid iti
translated: Then let the second one be accepted. This is suspected in if anyone.

analyzed: yaḥ kaścid anyathābhāvaḥ yadi
translated: If any transformation whatsoever...

analyzed: pūrvavat eva sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is as before.

original: avivakṣitaviśeṣa ityarthaḥ /🔽evaṃ tarhi muktātmano 'pyanityatvāpādanaṃ susthitamiti bhāvenāha muktiśceti //
analyzed: avivakṣita viśeṣaḥ iti arthaḥ  evam tarhi mukta ātmanaḥ pi anitya tva āpādanam susthitam iti bhāvena āha muktiḥ ca iti
translated: The meaning is that no particular [transformation] is intended.🔽If so, then the consequence of the impermanence of the liberated self is well-established. With this in mind, he says and liberation etc.

analyzed: muktiḥ ca tādṛśī
translated: And liberation is of that kind...
Of that kind, having the nature of transformation.

analyzed: evam api ātmanaḥ nitya tve bhū bhūdhara ādīnām api nitya tvam syāt
translated: Even so, if the self is permanent, the earth, mountains, etc. would also be permanent.

analyzed: anyathā hetoḥ anaikāntyāt
translated: Otherwise, the reason would be inconclusive.

analyzed: tat idam uktam sūtrakṛtā
translated: This is what the author of the aphorisms has said:

analyzed: ubhaya nitya tvāt iti
translated: Because of the permanence of both.

analyzed: avayava upacaya apacaya lakṣaṇaḥ nyathābhāvaḥ nitya tve hetuḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that transformation characterized by the increase and decrease of parts is the reason for impermanence, it is not so.

analyzed: sphaṭika ādau pakṣa eka deśe sandigdha tvāt
translated: Because in the case of crystal etc., which are part of the subject, [the reason] is doubtful.

original: rūpādimattvaṃ saviśeṣaṇamupādīyate cetko doṣa iti cenna /
analyzed: rūpa ādimattvam sa viśeṣaṇam upādīyate ced kaḥ doṣaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the presence of form etc. is stated with a qualification, what is the fault? It is not so.

analyzed: parasya vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of the opponent's [argument] being pointless.

analyzed: nahi paraḥ rūpa ādimat kiñcid nityam abhyupaiti  ātmanaḥ tu prabhayā rūpa ādimat tvam āpāditam eva
translated: For the opponent does not accept anything permanent that has form etc.🔽But the presence of form etc. in the self has already been established by [the opponent's] own light.

analyzed: yat vā ātmanaḥ rūpa ādimat tvam sva siddhānte eva
translated: Or, the presence of form etc. in the self is [already] accepted in [the opponent's] own doctrine.

analyzed: rūpa ādimataḥ nitya tvam iti vyāpti aṅgīkāre pūrvokta anitya tva prasaṅgaḥ vyākhyātavyaḥ
translated: If the pervasion that what has form etc. is impermanent is accepted, the consequence of the previously stated impermanence should be explained.

analyzed: kṣapaṇaka uktam artha antaram dūṣayitum anuvadati deha iti
translated: In order to refute the different meaning stated by the Jaina, he repeats [the Jaina's statement] with deha-mānaḥ.

analyzed: deha māne vikāraḥ syāt iti sthāsnūnanā ātmanaḥ
translated: If the size of the body is accepted, there would be change in the case of the immobile, which are not the self.

analyzed: āha
translated: He says:

analyzed: deha māne deha māna tve
translated: Deha-mānaḥ means the size of the body.

analyzed: pramite sati iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is understood as when it is known.

original: vikāraḥ syāt sthāvarāṇāṃ sātmakatvāṅgīkṛtāvātmana iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: vikāraḥ syāt sthāvarāṇām sātmaka tva aṅgīkṛtau ātmanaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: There would be change in the case of the immobile, if the presence of the self in them is accepted. The remainder is understood as in the case of the self.

analyzed: iti sa mā bhūt iti evamartham
translated: Let this not be so - with this meaning.

analyzed: sthāsnūn vṛkṣa ādīn
translated: The immobile refers to trees and so on.

analyzed: anātmanaḥ ātma anadhiṣṭhitān
translated: Which are not the self means which are not controlled by the self.

analyzed: āha kṣapaṇakaḥ
translated: The Jaina says:

original: atra kṣapaṇakaḥ sthāvarānanātmana āhetyetāvatyeva vaktavye yadātmano dehaparimāṇatvasya
analyzed: atra kṣapaṇakaḥ sthāvarānana ātmanaḥ āha iti etāvati eva vaktavye yat ātmanaḥ deha parimāṇa tvasya
translated: Here, when only this much should be said - the Jaina says that the soul is of the size of the body,

analyzed: pramita tvāt vṛkṣa ādīnām api sātmaka tve tad parimāṇa tva āpattau aṅkura avasthāyām aṇu mātrasya
translated: since the soul's being of the size of the body is well-established, if trees etc. also have souls, then their being of that size would lead to the absurdity of the soul being atomic in size when in the sprout stage,

original: mahāvṛkṣāvasthāyāṃ ca mahato vikāritvaṃ vikāritvādanityatvaṃ ca prasajyeta /🔽tanmā prāsāṅkṣīdityetadaprasañjītyevamar🔽thati hetukathanaṃ /
analyzed: mahā vṛkṣa avasthāyām ca mahataḥ vikāri tvam vikāri tvāt anitya tvam ca prasajyeta  tat mā prāsāṅkṣīt iti etat aprasañji iti evam ar  thati hetu kathanam
translated: and being large when in the large tree stage, and because of being mutable, impermanence would follow.🔽To prevent that, this is stated to prevent that.

analyzed: tat pūrva ukta prameya dṛḍhīkaraṇa artham
translated: This is stated as the reason to strengthen the previously stated thesis.

analyzed: yadi vikāri tva mātram anitya tve prayojakam jainaḥ na abhyupeyāt
translated: If the Jaina did not accept that mutability alone is the reason for impermanence,

original: tadā vikāritvenānityatvaprasaṅgādbibhyatā sthāvarāṇāmanātmatvaṃ yattenābhyupagataṃ tadanupapannaṃ syāt /🔽nahi sthāvarāṇāṃ sātmakatāyāmātmano lakṣaṇāpagamo bhavati /
analyzed: tadā vikāri tvena anitya tva prasaṅgāt bibhyatā sthāvarāṇām anātma tvam yat tena abhyupagatam tat anupapannam syāt  nahi sthāvarāṇām sātmaka tāyām ātmanaḥ lakṣaṇa apagamaḥ bhavati
translated: then the acceptance of the non-souledness of insentient beings out of fear of the absurdity of impermanence due to mutability would be illogical.🔽For when insentient beings have souls, the soul does not lose its characteristics.

analyzed: kintu anyathābhāva mātram iti
translated: But there is merely a change in form.

analyzed: yat vā dūṣaṇa saukarya artham hetu anuvādaḥ
translated: Or, the statement of the reason is for the sake of ease in refutation.

analyzed: tat idam vikāri tva āpatti bhayāt sthāvarāṇām anātma tva aṅgīkaraṇam ayuktam
translated: Therefore, it is not proper for the immobile things to be accepted as non-self out of fear of attaining changeability.

analyzed: tathā sati hasti ādi śarīrāṇām api anātmatvasya aṅgīkāyartva prasaṅgāt
translated: If it were so, then the bodies of elephants and others would also have to be accepted as non-self.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha hasti ādi iti
translated: How is that? Therefore it is said: elephant etc.

analyzed: hasti ādi deheṣu hi api syāt anyathābhāvaḥ
translated: For in the bodies of elephants and so on, there could be a change to another state.

original: pipīlikādidehasthasya tatparimāṇasya hastyādideheṣu prāpteṣvanyathābhāvaḥ syāt hi tasmāt iti /🔽athavā śarīramātrasyānātmaka
analyzed: pipīlikā ādi deha sthasya tad parimāṇasya hasti ādi deheṣu prāpteṣu anyathābhāvaḥ syāt hi tasmāt iti  athavā śarīra mātrasya anātmaka
translated: For the size of the one residing in the bodies of ants and so on, when attained in the bodies of elephants and so on, would be a change to another state. Indeed, because of that.

analyzed: tvam āpādya tad upapādanam idam kriyate
translated: Or else, having deduced that the body alone is non-self, this is done to establish that.

analyzed: hasti ādi sarva deheṣu api ātmanaḥ nyathābhāvaḥ syāt
translated: In all bodies of elephants and so on, there would be a change to another state of the self.

analyzed: utpatti samaye  dehānām hasta vitasti ādimā
translated: At the time of birth,

analyzed: sti mātra parimāṇa tvāt yauvane tu utkṛṣṭa parimāṇa tvāt iti
translated: because the bodies have only the size of a hand, a cubit, etc., but in youth they have an excellent size.

analyzed: anena aviśeṣāt iti sūtra khaṇḍasya arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: By this, the meaning of the phrase because of non-distinction is stated.

analyzed: nanu ca viṣamaḥ yam upanyāsaḥ
translated: But this presentation is unequal.

analyzed: alpā eva hi hasti ādi deheṣu ātmanaḥ vikṛtiḥ
translated: For the change of the self in the bodies of elephants and so on is small.

analyzed: vṛkṣa ādau tu mahatī
translated: But in a tree and so on it is great.

analyzed: tatas vṛkṣa ādīnām anātma tve hasti ādīnām api tat upa
translated: Then, it is not proper to adduce the example of elephants etc. to prove that trees etc. are not the self.

original: dāpādanamanucitamityata āha aṇudehasyeti //🔽aṇudehasya jīvasya gajatve vikṛtirhi yā /
analyzed: dāpādanam anucitam iti atas āha aṇu dehasya iti  aṇu dehasya jīvasya gaja tve vikṛtiḥ hi yā
translated: Therefore, he says of the atomic body etc.

original: dehavyāptyai viśeṣaḥ kastasyāḥ sthāsnutanau ca nuḥ // / /f //🔽aṇudehasya pipīlikādidehasya jīvasya gajatve prāpte /
analyzed: deha vyāptyai viśeṣaḥ kaḥ tasyāḥ sthāsnu tanau ca nuḥ  aṇu dehasya pipīlika ādi dehasya jīvasya gaja tve prāpte
translated: If the soul with an atomic body were to attain the state of an elephant, what would be the difference in its transformation? And what difference is there in the soul of a standing body?🔽If the soul with an atomic body, i.e., the body of an ant etc., were to attain the state of an elephant,

analyzed: yat vā utpatti samaye aṇu dehasya hasta vitasti ādi parimita dehasya
translated: or if at the time of birth, the soul with an atomic body, i.e., a body limited by a handspan etc.,

analyzed: mahāgaja tve prāpte deha vyāptau yā
translated: were to attain the state of a great elephant, what would be the difference

analyzed: yāvatī vikṛtiḥ
translated: in the transformation of its pervading the body?

analyzed: sthāsnu tanau ca nuḥ puruṣasya
translated: And what difference is there in the soul of a standing body, i.e., a man?

analyzed: yā vikṛtiḥ tasyāḥ tasyāḥ ca parasparam kaḥ viśeṣaḥ
translated: What difference is there between those transformations?

analyzed: na kaḥ pi
translated: None at all.

analyzed: ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ kim mahatī vikṛtiḥ anitya tva hetu tvāt anabhyupagantavyā
translated: Should the great transformation of the self be accepted as the cause of non-eternality,

analyzed: kiṃvā vikṛti mātram
translated: or should it be mere transformation?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so.

analyzed: mahattvasya apariniṣṭhita tvāt pariniṣṭhā kalpane keṣucid vṛkṣa ādiṣu tad abhāvāt
translated: Because greatness is not fixed, and if fixity is assumed, it is absent in some trees etc.

analyzed: tad anurodhena api pariniṣṭhā aṅgīkāre hasti ādau api tad bhāvāt
translated: Even if fixity is accepted in accordance with that, it is present in an elephant etc. as well.

analyzed: dvitīye tu ubhayoḥ vikāri tvena aviśeṣāt vṛkṣa ādi vat hasti ādau api anātmatvam aṅgīkāryam
translated: But in the second case, both being modifications, there is no difference, so even in the case of elephants etc., non-selfhood must be accepted, like in the case of trees etc.

analyzed: hasti ādi vat vṛkṣa ādīnām api sātmaka tvam na parityājyam iti
translated: The selfhood of trees etc. should not be abandoned, just as in the case of elephants etc.

analyzed: etena aviśeṣāt ityasya artha antaram uktam veditavyam
translated: By this, another meaning of because there is no difference should be understood.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: na vayam vikāri tva āpatti bhayāt vṛkṣa ādīnām anātmaka tvam ācakṣmahe
translated: We do not declare the non-selfhood of trees etc. out of fear of falling into the state of being a modification.

analyzed: kintu sātmaka tve pramāṇa abhāvāt bādhaka pramāṇa sadbhāvāt ca
translated: But because there is no evidence for their being self-possessed, and because there is evidence of contradiction.

analyzed: vṛkṣa ādīnām deha tve tad vayāpakam indriyavat tvam api syāt
translated: If trees etc. were bodies, they would also have sense organs, which are invariably concomitant with that.

analyzed: na ca tat asti
translated: But that is not so.

analyzed: tad kāryasya śravaṇa ādeḥ abhāvāt
translated: Because hearing etc., which are its effects, do not exist.

analyzed: tad jñāpakasya abhāvāt
translated: And that is also because there is no evidence of that.

original: adehatve ca na sātmakatvaṃ śilādivadityata āha gītāditi //
analyzed: adeha tve ca na sātmaka tvam śilā ādi vat iti atas āha gītāt iti
translated: And if they are not bodies, they are not self-possessed, like a stone etc. Therefore it is said from singing etc.

original: gītāt puṣpaphalāvāptiḥ sparśāt kārśyaṃ rasāt sthitiḥ /
analyzed: gītāt puṣpa phala avāptiḥ sparśāt kārśyam rasāt sthitiḥ
translated: From singing, the attainment of flowers and fruits is seen, from touch, emaciation, from taste, sustenance.

original: api vṛkṣasya dṛśyanta iti nānātmatā bhavet // / /d //
analyzed: api vṛkṣasya dṛśyante iti nānā ātma tā bhavet
translated: Even in the case of a tree, these are seen, so there would be non-selfhood.

analyzed: gītāt tāvat vṛkṣasya api puṣpa phala avāptiḥ dṛśyate
translated: To begin with, the attainment of flowers and fruits is seen even in the case of a tree from singing.

analyzed: tayā śravaṇam anumīyate
translated: From that, hearing is inferred.

analyzed: vimataḥ śravaṇavān gīta sānnidhye sati labdha vikāsa tvāt rāja ādi vat iti
translated: The one under dispute has hearing, because when singing is present, development is obtained, like a king, etc.

analyzed: na ca ayam svabhāvaḥ eva
translated: And this is not just the nature [of the soul].

analyzed: rāja ādeḥ api tad prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would follow for a king, etc. as well.

analyzed: śravaṇena ca śrotra sadbhāvaḥ numīyate
translated: And by hearing, the existence of the ear is inferred.

analyzed: evam śīta uṣṇa sparśa viśeṣāt kārśyam dṛśyate
translated: In the same way, emaciation is seen due to the specific contact of cold and heat.

analyzed: tena su kumāra śarīra vat sparśa jñānam anumīyate
translated: By that, the knowledge of touch is inferred, like in a delicate-bodied person.

analyzed: tena ca tvac indriya sattvam
translated: And by that, the existence of the skin sense organ.

analyzed: tathā udaka ādi rasāt sthitiḥ aśuṣyataḥ dṛśyate
translated: In the same way, stability, i.e. remaining in an unparched state, is seen due to the taste of water, etc.

analyzed: tena sammata deha vat rasa jñānam tatas rasanā indriya sadbhāvaḥ numīyate
translated: By that, the knowledge of taste is inferred, like in a person who agrees [to it], and from that, the existence of the tongue sense organ is inferred.

analyzed: evam kamanīya kāntā avalokanena utkoraka tvam tila vṛkṣasya upalabhyate
translated: In the same way, the swelling of a sesame plant is observed by looking at a beautiful woman.

analyzed: tena darśana kāmau
translated: By that, [the plant] desires to see [the woman].

analyzed: tatas nayana manasī siddhayataḥ
translated: From that, the eyes and mind are established.

analyzed: dhūpa upayāgena ca atiśaya darśanāt ghrāṇa siddhiḥ iti prasiddha śarīra aviśeṣāt sthāvarāṇām anātma tā na
translated: And by the observation of excess due to the offering of incense, the establishment of the nose is inferred. Thus, due to the lack of difference from a well-known body, the non-souledness of plants would not be established.

analyzed: kecid mūle niṣiktānām apām upari sarpaṇāt ādhyātmika vāyu sambandham anumāya sātmaka tvam anumiyate
translated: Some, inferring the connection with the internal wind by the upward movement of water sprinkled at the root, infer the souledness [of plants].

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not correct.

analyzed: bhasma gulikā ādau vyabhicārāt
translated: Because of inconstancy in ashes, balls, etc.

analyzed: etena aviśeṣāt iti etat prakāra antareṇa vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: By this, this [verse] Without distinction is explained in a different way.

analyzed: vakti svaprabham
translated: It speaks of its own light.

original: ityādikamutsūtritaṃ kasmādvarṇitamiti mandāśaṅkāṃ nivārayituṃ sūtrārūḍhaṃ karoti evañceti //
analyzed: ityādikam utsūtritam kasmāt varṇitam iti manda āśaṅkām nivārayitum sūtra ārūḍham karoti evam ca iti
translated: In order to ward off the feeble doubt Why is this and so on, which is not in the sutra, described?, he makes it fit into the sutra with And in this way.

analyzed: evam ca ātma akārtsnyam iti tatas eva āha veda vid
translated: And in this way, the self is not complete, therefore the knower of the Veda says so.

analyzed: iti tri sūtīm iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is in the three sutras.

analyzed: tatas eva tad artham eva
translated: From that itself, for that purpose itself.

analyzed: uktasya arthasya pratipādana artham eva
translated: For the purpose of teaching the meaning that has been stated.

analyzed: evam anyatra api sūtra anupanyāsena vyākhyāne na evam āśaṅkanīyam iti jñāpayitum idam abhihitam iti
translated: This is said in order to show that even in the explanation without citing the sutra elsewhere, one should not doubt in this way.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām na ekasmin adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Adhikarana on the non-completeness of the self in the glorious Nyaya Sudha.

analyzed: patyuḥ adhikaraṇa
translated: XI. The Adhikarana on the Lord

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām pati a r adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the Adhikarana on the Lord in the glorious Nyaya Sudha.

analyzed: om patyuḥ asāmañjasyāt om
translated: Om. Because the Lord's position is not coherent.

analyzed: iha mahādevam puraskṛtya pravartamānānām matam apākriyate
translated: Here, the doctrine of those who proceed with Mahadeva at the forefront is refuted.

original: te caturvidhāḥ śaivāḥ pāśupatāḥ kālāmukhā mahāvratāśceti /
analyzed: te caturvidhāḥ śaivāḥ pāśupatāḥ kālāmukhāḥ mahāvratāḥ ca iti
translated: And they are of four kinds: Shaivas, Pashupatas, Kalamukhas, and Mahavratas.

analyzed: teṣām sati api avāntarabhede sādhāraṇam eva prameyam veda vādasya ati viruddha tvāt apākartum anuvadati sarvajñatva ādikaiḥ iti
translated: Although they have internal divisions, he repeats the doctrine of the Vedas, which is extremely contradictory, in order to refute the common object of knowledge, saying with omniscience and other qualities.

analyzed: patyuḥ asāmañjasyāt  /
translated: Because the Lord is not reasonable.

analyzed: sarvajña tva ādikaiḥ sarvaiḥ guṇaiḥ yuktam sadāśivam
translated: Sadāśiva, endowed with all qualities such as omniscience,

analyzed: jagat vicitra racanā kartāram doṣa varjitam  āhuḥ pāśupatāḥ
translated: the creator of the wonderful arrangement of the world, free from faults,🔽the Pāśupatas say.

original: paśupaterime pāśupatā iti caturvidhā api gṛhyante /
analyzed: paśupateḥ ime pāśupatāḥ iti caturvidhāḥ api gṛhyante
translated: The Pāśupatas are included in all four types.

analyzed: te sadāśivam jagat vicitra racanā kartāram āhuḥ
translated: They say that Sadāśiva is the creator of the wonderful arrangement of the world.

analyzed: tatas janma ādyasya yatas iti uktam asat iti
translated: Therefore, what was said - from which arises birth, etc. - is not true.

original: ajñānādidoṣayuktaṃ kathaṃ jagatkartāramāhurityata uktam doṣavarjitamiti //🔽sārvajñādyabhāve 'jñānādivarjanaṃ cetanasya nopapadyata ityataḥ sarvajñatvādikaiḥ sarvairguṇairyuktamityuktam /
analyzed: ajñāna ādi doṣa yuktam katham jagat kartāram āhuḥ iti atas uktam doṣa varjitam iti  sārvajña ādi abhāve jñāna ādi varjanam cetanasya na upapadyate iti atas sarvajña tva ādikaiḥ sarvaiḥ guṇaiḥ yuktam iti uktam
translated: How can they say that he is the creator of the world, who is endowed with ignorance and other faults? Therefore, it is said that he is free from faults.🔽In the absence of omniscience and other qualities, the avoidance of ignorance and other faults is not possible for a conscious being. Hence, it is said that he is endowed with all qualities such as omniscience.

analyzed: yat vā sarvajñatva ādikaiḥ sarvaiḥ guṇaiḥ yuktam doṣa varjitam iti pradhāna lakṣaṇa viruddha artha upanyāsaḥ
translated: Or, the statement endowed with all qualities such as omniscience, free from faults is the presentation of an object contrary to the definition of Pradhāna.

analyzed: jagat vicitra racanā kartāram iti śrauta brahma lakṣaṇa viruddha artha uktiḥ iti avagantavyam
translated: It should be understood that it states a meaning contrary to the definition of Brahman in the Vedas, which is the creator of the wonderful arrangement of the universe.

analyzed: tat etat dūṣayitum patyuḥ asāmañjasyāt iti sūtra tātparyam āha tat ca iti  tat ca bahu śruti virodhataḥ
translated: To refute this, the purport of the sūtra because of the inconsistency of the Lord is stated as that and so on.🔽And that is not to be accepted due to contradiction with many scriptural statements.

analyzed: na upādeyam matam hi  caśabdaḥ pūrvatanaiḥ mataiḥ
translated: For it is the opinion...

analyzed: saha samuccaya arthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of including with the previous opinions.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word hi (for) is a reason.

analyzed: tat paśupateḥ sarva jagat kāṇa tva ādikam matam na upādeyam
translated: That opinion of Śiva being the cause of the world's blindness, etc. is not to be accepted.

analyzed: kutas  patyuḥ paśupateḥ  asāmañjasyāt doṣi tvāt
translated: Why?🔽Because of the inconsistency, i.e. faultiness, of the Lord, of Śiva.

analyzed: tad anaṅgīkāre ca bahu śruti virodhaḥ iti yojanā
translated: And in not accepting that, there is contradiction with many scriptural statements - this is the construction.

analyzed: kāḥ tāḥ śrutayaḥ iti atas tāḥ udāharati asya iti
translated: What are those scriptural statements? Therefore, to cite them, he says of this and so on.

original: asya devasya stuhi gartagam // / / //🔽utpipeṣa śirastasya gṛṇīṣe satpatiṃ padam /🔽yad viṣṇorupamaṃ hantuṃ rudramākṛṣṭate mayā // / / //
analyzed: asya devasya stuhi gartagam  utpipeṣa śiraḥ tasya gṛṇīṣe sat patim padam  yat viṣṇoḥ upamam hantum rudram ākṛṣṭate mayā
translated: Praise this god who dwells in the cave...🔽I praise the good lord, the place, which he, having crushed the head of that (demon),🔽is drawn by me to kill Rudra, who is equal to Viṣṇu...

original: dhanuryaṃ kāmaye taṃ tamugraṃ mā śiśnadevatāḥ /
analyzed: dhanuḥ yam kāmaye tam tam ugram mā śiśna devatāḥ
translated: I make that fierce one whom I desire, not the god of the penis.

analyzed: ghnan śiśnadevān ekaḥ saḥ āsīt nārāyaṇaḥ paraḥ
translated: He alone, Nārāyaṇa, the supreme one, killing the gods of the penis...🔽The one who is the lord of the gods, the one who is the lord of the universe, the one who is the lord of the world, the one who is the lord of all...

analyzed: tasmāt rudraḥ samprasādaḥ ca abhūtām vaiṣṇavam makham
translated: Therefore, Rudra and Prasada became the Vaishnava sacrifice.

analyzed: yajñena yajñam ayajanta abadhnan puruṣam paśum
translated: They worshipped the sacrifice with the sacrifice, and bound the Purusha as the animal.

analyzed: yaḥ bhūtānām adhipatiḥ rudraḥ tanti caraḥ vṛṣā
translated: He who is the lord of beings, Rudra, the bull who moves in the rays,

original: anenaasya devasya mīḷhuṣo vayā viṣṇoreṣasya prabhuthe havirbhiḥ /
analyzed: anena asya devasya mīḍhuṣaḥ vayāḥ viṣṇoḥ eṣasya prabhuthe havirbhiḥ
translated: By this, the life of this god, the rain-giver, the greatness of Vishnu, by the offerings,

original: vide hi rudro rudriyaṃ mahitvaṃ yāsiṣyaṃ vartiraścivāvirāvat' / iti /
analyzed: vide hi rudraḥ rudriyam mahi tvam yāsiṣyam iti
translated: Rudra knows his own greatness, which he will go to, as a favorable guest.

analyzed: śrutim upādatte
translated: He quotes the Shruti.

analyzed: stuhi garta gam
translated: Praise the one in the pit.

original: ityanenastuhi śrutaṃ gartamadaṃ yuvānaṃ mṛgaṃ na bhīmamupahatnumugram /
analyzed: iti anena stuhi śrutam garta madam yuvānam mṛgam na bhīmam upahatnum ugram
translated: By this, praise the one who is heard, the young one in the pit, terrible like a deer, fierce, striking down.

original: mṛḷā jaritre rudra stavāno 'nyaṃ te asmānnivapantu senā' / iti ṛ / /
analyzed: mṛḍa jaritre rudra stavānaḥ nyam te asmān nivapantu senāḥ iti
translated: Be gentle to the singer, O Rudra, when praised, let other armies fall upon us.

original: utpipeṣa' / ityanenarudrasya tveva dhanurārtniḥ ri utpipeṣa' / iti /
analyzed: utpipeṣa iti anena rudrasya tu eva dhanuḥ ārtniḥ utpipeṣa iti
translated: He rubbed. By this, The bow and the arm of Rudra were rubbed.

original: gṛṇīṣaḥ' / ityanenakumāraścitpitaraṃ vandamānaṃ prati nānāma rudropayantam /
analyzed: gṛṇīṣaḥ iti anena kumāraḥ cit pitaram vandamānam prati nānāma rudra upayantam
translated: We praise. By this, Rudra, when praised, did not accept the son who was bowing to his father, offering to Rudra.

original: bhūrerdātāraṃ satpatiṃ gṛṇīṣe stutastvaṃ bheṣajā rāsyasma' / iti ṛ / /
analyzed: bhūreḥ dātāram sat patim gṛṇīṣe stutaḥ tvam bheṣajā rāsyasmaḥ iti
translated: I praise the giver of ample wealth, the lord of the good, praised by you, give us medicines.

original: padam' / ityanenatava śriye maruto marjayanta rudra yatte janima cāru citram /
analyzed: padam iti anena tava śriye marutaḥ marjayanta rudra yat te janima cāru citram
translated: The foot. With this, For your glory, O Maruts, you adorn Rudra's beautiful and wondrous birth,

original: padaṃ yadviṣṇorupamaṃ nidhāyi tena pāsi guhyaṃ nāma gonām' / iti ṛ / /
analyzed: padam yat viṣṇoḥ upamam nidhāyi tena pāsi guhyam nāma gonām iti
translated: The foot that is placed as a match for Vishnu, with that you guard the secret name of the cows.

original: yaṃ kāmaye' / ityanenayaṃ kāmaye taṃ tamugraṃ kṛṇomi taṃ brahmāṇaṃ tamṛṣiṃ taṃ sumedhām' / iti ṛ / /
analyzed: yam kāmaye iti anena ayam kāmaye tam tam ugram kṛṇomi tam brahmāṇam tam ṛṣim tam su medhām iti
translated: With this, Whom I desire. With this, Whom I desire, him I make fierce, him a Brahman, him a sage, him of good understanding.

original: mā' / ityanenamā śiśnadevā api gurṛtaṃ na' / iti /
analyzed: mā śiśna devāḥ api naḥ iti
translated: With this, Do not. With this, Even the gods of the penis do not attain the ghee.

analyzed: ghnan iti anena ghnan śiśna devām abhivarpasā bhūt iti
translated: With this, Slaying. With this, Slaying the gods of the penis, he became prosperous.

original: ekosau' / ityanenaeko nārāyaṇa āsīnna brahmā naca śaṅkaraḥ' / iti /
analyzed: ekaḥ asau iti anena ekaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ āsīt na brahmā na ca śaṅkaraḥ iti
translated: With this, One. With this, One Narayana existed, not Brahma, not Shankara.

original: tasmāt' / ityanenasa ruṣyaḥ sa prasanno yadruṣyo yatprasannastasmādrudrasamprasādāvabhūtām' / iti /
analyzed: tasmāt iti anena sa ruṣyaḥ sa prasannaḥ yat ruṣyaḥ yat prasannaḥ tasmāt rudra samprasādau abhūtām iti
translated: With this, Therefore. With this, He is the angry one, he is the pleased one, in that he is the angry one, in that he is the pleased one, therefore they became Rudra and Prasada.

original: vaiṣṇavam' / ityanenateṣāṃ makhaṃ vaiṣṇavaṃ yaśa ārchat' / iti /
analyzed: vaiṣṇavam iti anena teṣām makham vaiṣṇavam yaśaḥ ārchat iti
translated: With this, The Vaishnava. With this, Their sacrifice attained the Vaishnava glory.

analyzed: yajñena iti abadhnan iti
translated: With the sacrifice. They bound.

analyzed: yaḥ bhūtānām iti prasiddham
translated: The one of beings is well-known.

original: kathametābhiḥ śrutibhiḥ paśupatenirrdeṣatvaṃ viruddhamityatastāsāṃ tātparyamāha ityādīti //
analyzed: katham etābhiḥ śrutibhiḥ paśupateḥ nirrdeṣa tvam viruddham iti atas tāsām tātparyam āha ityādi iti
translated: How is it that the statement of the Lord of beings is contradicted by these scriptural passages? Therefore, he states the purport of those [passages] with Thus, etc.

analyzed: ityādi śruti sāmarthyāt pāratantryam janiḥ mṛtiḥ
translated: By the power of these and other scriptural passages, dependence, birth, death,
Obtaining another through dependence, ignorance, and non-existence

analyzed: pratīyante
translated: Are understood...

analyzed: abhavaḥ abhāvaḥ
translated: Non-existence.

analyzed: pratīyante paśupateḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Are understood to belong to the Lord of beings, it is to be supplied.

analyzed: asya devasya
translated: Of this God

analyzed: iti anena para adhīna pada prāptiḥ pratīyate
translated: By this [verse], the attainment of a position dependent on another is understood.

analyzed: mīḷhuṣaḥ secakasya
translated: Of the one who sprinkles, the bestower.

analyzed: eṣasya icchā rūpasya
translated: Of this one, who is in the form of desire.

analyzed: asya viṣṇoḥ devasya  pramṛthe prabharaṇe pūjāyām iti yāvat
translated: Of this God Vishnu.

original: havirbhiḥ kṛte sati vayā bandhako rudro /
analyzed: havirbhiḥ kṛte sati vayāḥ bandhakaḥ
translated: When oblations are offered, the fetter, Rudra,

analyzed: rudriyam mahi tvam raudram padam
translated: The great power of Rudra, the position of Rudra,

analyzed: vide vivide lebhe
translated: Is known, is found.

original: hi yathā tathā he aśvinau yuvāmapi irāvat annavat /🔽varti vartanaṃ /
analyzed: hi yathā tathā he aśvinau yuvāmapi irāvat annavat  varti vartanam
translated: O Asvins, you two, by whatever means, with food,

analyzed: yāsiṣyam ayāsiṣya prāptavantau sthaḥ iti
translated: You two go, you two have gone, you two have attained.🔽Praise

analyzed: stuhi iti anena stāvaka tayā pāratantryam
translated: By this [verse], dependence as a praiser is stated.

analyzed: he rudra tvam śrutam prasiddham
translated: O Rudra, you, who are well-known,

analyzed: garta sadam hṛdaya guhā nivāsam
translated: The dweller in the cave, the abode of the heart's secret.

analyzed: yuvānam
translated: The young.

analyzed: mṛgam na bhīmam siṃham iva bhīṣaṇam
translated: The deer, the terrible one, like a lion, the frightening one.

analyzed: ugram ugrāṇām daityānām
translated: The fierce one of the fierce demons.

analyzed: upahantunam upahantāram
translated: The destroyer, the one who destroys.

analyzed: nṛharim
translated: The man-lion.

analyzed: stuhi stauṣi
translated: Praise, you praise.

analyzed: saḥ evam stavāna stuvan tvam
translated: You, praised in this way, praising.

analyzed: jaritre stotre
translated: To the singer, to the praise.

analyzed: tvām stuvantam mām
translated: You, praising me.

analyzed: mṛḷa mṛḍaya sukhasya
translated: Be gracious, be kind to me, to happiness.

analyzed: te senāḥ ca asmat anyam eva nivapantu ghnantu iti
translated: Let his armies throw down only others than us, let them kill, thus.

analyzed: rudrasya iti anena ajña tvam pāratantryam mṛtiḥ ca
translated: By this 'Rudra's', his ignorance, dependence, and death are mentioned.

original: āropitaṃ dhanurhanāvavaṣṭabhyāvasthitasya rudrasya śiro jyāyāṃ vabhrirū
analyzed: āropitam dhanuḥ hanau avaṣṭabhya avasthitasya rudrasya śiraḥ jyāyām vabhri rū
translated: The head of Rudra, who stood holding his bow drawn for shooting, was split by the string.

analyzed: kāmarūpeṇa indreṇa chinnāyām utkṣiptā dhanuḥ ārtniḥ utpipeṣa ciccheda iti
translated: The tip of the bow, cut off by Indra in the form of Kama, was thrown up and ground to pieces, it was cut off, thus.

analyzed: kumāraḥ iti anena api pāratantryam janiḥ ca
translated: By this 'Kumara' also, his dependence and birth are mentioned.

original: he rudra kumāraḥ putro bhavān jagadvayāmohanāya kailāsamupayantaṃ /
analyzed: he rudra kumāraḥ putraḥ bhavān jagat vayā mohanāya kailāsam upayantam
translated: O Rudra, you are the son, Kumara, for the delusion of the world, approaching Kailasa.

original: tvāṃ vandamānaṃ pitaraṃ kṛṣṇaṃ prati nanāma /
analyzed: tvām vandamānam pitaram kṛṣṇam prati nanāma
translated: You, bowing to your father Krishna, bowed to him.

original: tena stutastvaṃ bhūreḥ puruṣārthasya dātāraṃ satpatiṃ gṛṇīṣe stauṣi stutavānasi /
analyzed: tena stutaḥ tvam bhūreḥ puruṣa arthasya dātāram sat patim gṛṇīṣe stauṣi stutavān asi
translated: By that (hymn), you praise the giver of the four goals of life, the good lord, you praise, you have praised.

original: evambhūtastvamasmābhiḥ stutaḥ asme 'smabhyaṃ bheṣajā bheṣajāni saṃsāravyādhinirasanāni jñānāni rāsi dadāsi dehīti /
analyzed: evambhūtaḥ tvam asmābhiḥ stutaḥ asme smabhyam bheṣajā bheṣajāni saṃsāra vyādhi nirasanāni jñānāni rāsi dadāsi dehi iti
translated: Thus, you, praised by us, grant us medicines, remedies, knowledge for removing the disease of worldly existence.

analyzed: tava śriyaḥ
translated: 'Your glory.'

analyzed: iti anena para adhīna pada prāptiḥ janiḥ pāratantryam ca
translated: By this, birth is the attainment of a position dependent on another, and dependence.

original: he rudra yat yebhyaste janima janmābhūtte maruto brahmaṇo 'tītavartamānāstava śriye
analyzed: he rudra yat yebhyaḥ te janima janma abhūt te marutaḥ śriye
translated: O Rudra, those from whom you had birth, those Maruts, past and present, for your glory

original: sampade cāru sundaraṃ citramāścaryaṃ upamaṃ upa samīpe mā lakṣmīryasya saṃvahanakartrī tattathoktam /
analyzed: sampade cāru sundaram citram āścaryam upamam upa samīpe mā lakṣmīḥ yasya saṃvahana kartrī tat tathā uktam
translated: and prosperity, are beautiful, charming, wonderful, incomparable, near, Lakshmi, the carrier, is the one who has that.

analyzed: yat viṣṇoḥ padam marjayantaḥ śodhitavantaḥ kṣālitavantaḥ
translated: What is cleansed, purified, washed by them, the abode of Vishnu,

analyzed: tat tvayā hṛdi nidhāyi nyadhāyi
translated: that is placed in the heart by you.

original: tena kāraṇena tvaṃ gonāṃ gavāṃ vācāṃ
analyzed: tena kāraṇena tvam gonām gavām vācām
translated: For that reason, you, among the cows, or among the words,

original: madhye guhyaṃ nāma nārāyaṇādikaṃ pāsi japopadeśādinā pālayasīti /
analyzed: madhye guhyam nāma nārāyaṇa ādikam pāsi japa upadeśa ādinā pālayasi iti
translated: guard the secret name, Narayana and others, by teaching japa and so on.

analyzed: aham iti anena mṛtiḥ
translated: 'I.' By this, death.

original: ahaṃ brahmadviṣe brahmadviṣāṃ daityānāṃ śarave hiṃsakaṃ rudrāya rudraṃ hantavai hantumeva pralaye dhanurātanomi vistārayāmīti / /
analyzed: aham brahma dviṣe brahma dviṣām daityānām śarave hiṃsakam rudrāya rudram hantavai hantum eva pralaye dhanuḥ ātanomi vistārayāmi iti
translated: I, to Rudra, the destroyer, to Rudra for the destruction of the enemies of Brahman, to Rudra for the destruction of the demons who hate Brahman, I stretch out the bow for the destruction of Rudra at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: yam iti anena para adhīna pada prāptiḥ
translated: By the word 'yam' (I), he shows the attainment of a position dependent on another.

original: ahaṃ yaṃ yaṃ rudraṃ kartuṃ kāmaye taṃ tamugraṃ rudraṃ kṛṇomi karomi evaṃ taṃ brahmāṇaṃ tamṛṣiṃ taṃ sumedhāṃ sumedhasaṃ karomīti /
analyzed: aham yam yam rudram kartum kāmaye tam tam ugram rudram kṛṇomi karomi evam tam brahmāṇam tam ṛṣim tam sumedhām sumedhasam karomi iti
translated: I make him whom I wish to make Rudra, I make him a fierce Rudra. Thus I make him Brahman, I make him a sage, I make him a very wise one.

analyzed: mā iti anena ajña tvam
translated: By the word 'mā' (not), he shows ignorance.

original: atītānāgatavartamānā guhyābhimānino devā rudrā api no 'smākamupāsyamṛtaṃ jñānarūpaṃ brahma māgurna jñātavanta iti /
analyzed: atīta anāgata vartamānāḥ guhya abhimāninaḥ devāḥ rudrāḥ api no smākam upāsya mṛtam jñāna rūpam brahma mā aguḥ na jñātavantaḥ iti
translated: The gods who are the conceivers of the mysteries, past, future and present, the Rudras, have not known the Brahman which is to be worshipped by us, which is of the nature of knowledge and immortality.

analyzed: ghnan iti anena mṛtiḥ
translated: By the word 'ghna' (killing), he shows death.

analyzed: guhya abhimāni devān ghnan īśvaraḥ varpasā balena sarvam abhyabhūt abhibhūtavān iti
translated: The Lord, killing the gods who are the conceivers of the mysteries, has overcome everything with his power and strength.

analyzed: ekaḥ iti anena pralaye bhāvaḥ janiḥ ca
translated: By the word 'eka' (alone), he shows non-existence and birth at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: tasmāt iti anena janiḥ
translated: By the word 'tasmāt' (therefore), he shows birth.

analyzed: parameśvara roṣa jaḥ rudraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that Rudra is born from the anger of the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: samprasādaḥ brahmā
translated: Brahmā is the one who is pleased.

analyzed: teṣām ityādi vākyaiḥ pāratantryam
translated: By the sentences beginning with 'teṣām' (of them), he shows dependence.

analyzed: teṣām devānām yaśaḥ
translated: The glory of those gods.

original: vaiṣṇavaṃ makhaṃ viṣṇumakhe paśutvena niyuktaṃ rudramārchatprāptavaditi /
analyzed: vaiṣṇavam makham viṣṇu makhe paśu tvena niyuktam rudram ārchat prāpta vat iti
translated: Rudra, appointed as the animal in Vishnu's sacrifice, reached Vishnu.

original: devā yajñena rudreṇa paśunā yajñaṃ viṣṇumayajanteti /
analyzed: devāḥ yajñena rudreṇa paśunā yajñam viṣṇum ayajanta iti
translated: The gods, with Rudra as the animal, worshipped Vishnu with the sacrifice.

analyzed: devāḥ puruṣam rudram paśum abadhnan iti
translated: The gods bound Rudra, the man, as the animal.

original: yo bhūtānāmadhipatī rudraḥ sa viṣṇorājñārūpāyāṃ tantyāṃ carati vṛṣā prasiddhatantyāmiveti / /
analyzed: yaḥ bhūtānām adhipatiḥ rudraḥ sa viṣṇoḥ ājñā rūpāyām tantyām carati vṛṣā prasiddha tantyām iva iti
translated: Rudra, the lord of beings, moves as a bull on the string in the form of Vishnu's command, as if on a well-known string.

analyzed: etāsām śrutīnām etad artha tva upapādanam tu acāryeṇa eva anyatra udāhṛtebhyaḥ vākyebhyaḥ ṭīkātaḥ ca avagantavyam
translated: The explanation of the meaning of these Vedic passages should be understood from the other passages quoted by the teacher and from the commentary.

analyzed: atas eva sāmarthyāt iti uktam
translated: For this very reason, it is said by implication.

analyzed: sūtra artham upasaṃharati sa doṣa tvāt iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the sutra with because of having faults.

analyzed: sa doṣa tvāt na īśaḥ paśupatiḥ tatas
translated: Because of having faults, Pashupati is not the Lord.

original: tataḥ śrutibalena sadoṣatvātpaśupatiḥ īśo jagatkartā na bhavati /
analyzed: tatas śruti balena sa doṣa tvāt paśupatiḥ īśaḥ jagat kartā na bhavati
translated: Therefore, by the power of the Vedas, Pashupati is not the creator of the world because of having faults.

analyzed: doṣiṇaḥ yajñadattasya iva jagat kartṛ tva anupapatteḥ iti
translated: Because one who has faults, like Yajnadatta, cannot be the creator of the world.

original: yuktyantareṇa śivasya jagatkartṛtvamapākartuṃ sūtram oṃ sambandhānupapatteśca oṃ //
analyzed: yukti antareṇa śivasya jagatkartṛ tvam apākartum sūtram om sambandha anupapatteḥ ca om
translated: In order to refute Shiva's status as the creator of the world by another reasoning, the sutra begins: And because the relation is not possible.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tasya artham āha aśarīra tvataḥ iti
translated: The meaning of that is stated as because of being bodiless.

analyzed: saṃbandha anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And also because of the impossibility of relation.

analyzed: aśarīra tvataḥ tasya sambandhaḥ jagatā kvacid
translated: How can there be a relation of that with the world anywhere,

analyzed: kartṛ tvena na yujyeta
translated: as an agent, it is not proper.

analyzed: tasya śivasya
translated: Of that, of Śiva.

analyzed: aśarīrasya api gagana ādeḥ jagatā sambandha darśanāt katham etat iti atas vyākhyāti
translated: Since a relation of the bodiless with the world is seen, like that of space, how is this? Therefore, he explains the relation itself.

analyzed: kvacid kārye
translated: In some effect.

analyzed: kartṛ tvena iti
translated: As an agent.

analyzed: sambandhaḥ na yujyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The relation characterized by being the agent of bodily action is not proper. This is the meaning.

analyzed: kvacid iti anena kutas sarva kartṛ tvam iti sūcayati
translated: By in some he indicates from where the universal agency [comes].

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: śivaḥ na kartā aśarīra tvāt supta pralīna vat iti
translated: Śiva is not an agent because of being bodiless, like one who is asleep or merged.

analyzed: nanu śivaḥ siddhaḥ na vā
translated: But is Śiva established or not?

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: āśraya asiddheḥ
translated: Because of the non-establishment of the substratum.

original: ādye tu kartṛtvenaiva siddha iti dharmigrāhakamānavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: ādye tu kartṛ tvena eva siddhaḥ iti dharmi grāhaka māna virodhaḥ
translated: But in the first case, he is established as an agent itself, so there is contradiction with the means of knowing the subject.

analyzed: kiñca bhavat mate pi
translated: Moreover, even in your view,

analyzed: śivasya kartṛ tvam śarīri tvam ca aṅgīkriyate eva
translated: the agency and embodiment of Śiva are accepted.

analyzed: tathā ca apasiddhānta anyatara asiddhī syātām iti
translated: And in that case, there would be the fallacies of unestablished subject and unestablished reason.

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: idam atra ākūtam
translated: This is the intention here:

analyzed: paśupateḥ jagat kāraṇatvam vadan praṣṭavyaḥ  kim pāśupata ādi śāstrāṇi anumānāni
translated: One who asserts that Paśupati is the cause of the world should be asked:🔽Is this said relying on the Pāśupata and other scriptures and on inference,

analyzed: vā āśritya idam ucyate  uta śruti ādikam
translated: or on the Vedas and other sources?

analyzed: ādye tu atiprasaṅgaḥ yam ucyate
translated: In the first case, this is a great over-extension.

original: yadi pāśupatādyāśrityedamucyate tarhi tasyāśarīratvamapi tataḥ siddhamiti tadapyaṅgīkāryaṃ syāt /🔽tathāca kartṛtvānupapattiriti /
analyzed: yadi pāśupata ādi āśritya idam ucyate tarhi tasya aśarīra tvam api tatas siddham iti tat api aṅgīkāryam syāt  tathā ca kartṛ tva anupapattiḥ iti
translated: If this is said relying on the Pāśupata and others, then it follows that he is bodiless. Therefore, that too would have to be accepted.🔽And thus agency is not possible.

analyzed: atas eva na yujyate iti liṅ prayogaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the use of the word not proper is appropriate.

analyzed: dvitīye tu vakṣyate iti
translated: In the second case, it will be said.

analyzed: evañca na kaścid doṣaḥ
translated: And thus there is no fault at all.

analyzed: śiva svarūpasya asmākam śruti āditaḥ siddheḥ āśraya asiddhaya bhāvāt
translated: Since the nature of Śiva is established for us from the Vedas and other sources, there is no fallacy of the subject being unestablished.

analyzed: para siddhena aśarīra tvena kartṛ tva abhāva āpādanāt dharmi grāhaka virodha ādi abhāvāt
translated: Since the absence of agency is shown by the well-established bodilessness of others, there is no contradiction with the means of knowing the nature of things, etc.

original: etena pāśupatādivirodhāt śrutayo 'nyathā yojyā iti nirastam / /🔽nanvaśarīrasyāpi kartṛtve bādhakābhāvādvayāptividhuro 'yaṃ prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: etena pāśupata ādi virodhāt śrutayaḥ nyathā yojyāḥ iti nirastam  nanu aśarīrasya api kartṛ tve bādhaka abhāvāt vayāpti vidhuraḥ yam prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Thus, the objection that the Vedas should be interpreted differently because they contradict the Pāśupata and other scriptures is refuted.🔽If there is no contradiction in agency even for the bodiless, this reductio argument is devoid of pervasion.

original: kārakaprayoktṛtvaṃ hi kartṛtvaṃ na śarīritvamityata āha dehina iti //
analyzed: kāraka prayoktṛ tvam hi kartṛ tvam na śarīri tvam iti atas āha dehinaḥ iti
translated: For agency is the state of being an employer of instruments, not the state of having a body. Therefore, he says of the embodied one.

analyzed: dehinaḥ jñāna dṛṣṭitaḥ
translated: Of embodied beings, by the vision of knowledge.

original: satyaṃ kārakaprayoktṛtvameva kartṛtvaṃ na śarīritvamiti /🔽tacca na prayatnena vinā sambhavati /
analyzed: satyam kāraka prayoktṛ tvam eva kartṛ tvam na śarīri tvam iti  tat ca na prayatnena vinā sambhavati
translated: The truth is that agency is indeed the state of being an operator, not the state of having a body.🔽And that is not possible without effort.

analyzed: na ca icchām antareṇa prayatnaḥ
translated: And there is no effort without desire.

analyzed: na ca jñānāt vinā icchā
translated: And there is no desire without knowledge.

analyzed: na ca śarīrāt ṛte jñānam
translated: And there is no knowledge without a body.

analyzed: dehinām eva jāgratām jñāna darśanāt
translated: Because only embodied beings who are awake have the vision of knowledge.

analyzed: adehinām supta pralīnānām ca adarśanāt
translated: Because those without bodies, who are asleep or dissolved, are not seen.

original: tataḥ kartṛtvasya vyāpakaṃ śarīraṃ śivādvayāvartamānaṃ tadapi vyāvartayatīti / /
analyzed: tatas kartṛ tvasya vyāpakam śarīram śivāt vayāvartamānam tat api vyāvartayati iti
translated: Therefore, the body, which is the pervader of agency, is excluded from Śiva, and that too is excluded.
