analyzed: nanu jñāna janmani eva śarīrasya upayogaḥ
translated: But the body is useful only in the production of knowledge.

analyzed: jñānasya indriya janya tvāt
translated: Because knowledge is produced by the senses.

analyzed: indriyāṇām ca śarīra saṃyoga niyamāt
translated: And because the senses are restricted to contact with the body.

original: nityajñānaśca bhagavāñchiva iti kiṃ tasya śarīreṇeti /
analyzed: nitya jñānaḥ ca bhagavān śivaḥ iti kim tasya śarīreṇa iti
translated: And Lord Śiva has eternal knowledge. So what is the use of a body for him?

original: evaṃ tarhi prayatnajanmanyevecchopayoginīti nityaprayatnasyecchāpi na syāt /
analyzed: evam tarhi prayatna janmani evā icchā upayoginī iti nitya prayatnasya icchā api na syāt
translated: If that is so, then desire is useful only in the production of effort. So even desire would not exist for one who has eternal effort.

original: tathecchotpattāveva jñānamupayujyata iti nityecchasya jñānamapi na syāt /
analyzed: tathā icchā utpattau eva jñānam upayujyate iti nitya icchasya jñānam api na syāt
translated: Similarly, knowledge is useful only in the production of desire. So even knowledge would not exist for one who has eternal desire.

analyzed: atha na prayatna mātram kartṛ tvam
translated: Now, agency is not mere effort.

analyzed: api tarhi jñāna icche api
translated: Then, even in knowledge and desire.

original: paridṛṣṭasāmarthyakārakaprayoktṛtvaṃ kartṛtvamiti hi vṛddhā iti cet /
analyzed: paridṛṣṭa sāmarthya kāraka prayoktṛ tvam kartṛ tvam iti hi vṛddhāḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the elders say that agency is the employment of an agent whose capacity has been observed,

analyzed: tathā api icchā tyāge bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: even so, there is no reason to abandon desire.

analyzed: kutas ca evam kalpanīyam
translated: And why should it be imagined in this way?

analyzed: kulāla ādau tathā darśanāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is seen thus in the case of a potter and so on,

analyzed: kim tatra śarīram na dṛṣṭam
translated: why is the body not seen there?

analyzed: dṛṣṭam api anupayuktam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that even though seen, it is not useful,

analyzed: kiṃniyama abhāvāt evam āśrīyate
translated: why is it not accepted that it is so due to the absence of restriction?

analyzed: anyatra upakṣayāt vā
translated: Or because it is exhausted elsewhere.

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: The first is not so,

analyzed: vyabhicāra abhāvāt
translated: because there is no contradiction.

analyzed: śarīra preraṇe param śarīram na asti iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that there is no other body in the instigation of the body, it is not so.

analyzed: tena eva sa śarīra tvāt
translated: Because it itself is embodied.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ
translated: The second is not so.

analyzed: nirasta tvāt
translated: Because it has been refuted.

analyzed: anyathā jñāna ādīnām api anupayoga prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence that knowledge and so on would also not be useful.

analyzed: kutas ca asya nitya jñāna tva siddhiḥ
translated: And from where is the establishment of his eternal knowledge?

analyzed: āgamāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is from scripture, it is not so.

analyzed: paraspara āśraya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because there would be the undesirable consequence of mutual dependence.

original: siddhe hyāgamaprāmāṇye nityajñāneśvarasiddhistatsiddhau cāgamasya tatpraṇītatvena prāmāṇyasiddhiriti / /
analyzed: siddhe hi āgama prāmāṇye nitya jñāna īśvara siddhiḥ tad siddhau ca āgamasya tad praṇīta tvena prāmāṇya siddhiḥ iti
translated: For, when the validity of scripture is established, the establishment of the eternal knowing God is possible, and when that is established, the validity of scripture as composed by him is established.

original: uktadoṣaparihāramāśaṅkaya tannirāsāya sūtram oṃ karaṇavaccenna bhogādibhyaḥ oṃ //
analyzed: ukta doṣa parihāram āśaṅkaya tad nirāsāya sūtram om karaṇavat ced na bhoga ādibhyaḥ om
translated: Suspecting the avoidance of the stated faults, in order to refute that, the aphorism: If it is said like the instrument, not because of enjoyment etc.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: tannetyantaṃ tāvadvayācaṣṭe naceti //🔽karaṇavac cen na bhogādibhyaḥ / / / /
analyzed: tat na iti antam tāvat vayācaṣṭe na ca iti  karaṇavat ced na bhoga ādibhyaḥ
translated: Up to the end of not so he explains: Not so etc.🔽If it is said like the instrument, not because of enjoyment etc.

analyzed: na ca deha ādi vat viśvam asya syāt
translated: And the universe would not be his like the body etc.

analyzed: yat uktam aśarīra tvāt śivasya kartṛ tva anupapattiḥ iti
translated: What was said - that because Śiva is bodiless, agency is not possible for him -

analyzed: tat asat
translated: That is not so.

original: kulālādayo hi kartāro daṇḍādikaṃ sākṣātprayatnenādhiṣṭhātumanīśānāstadadhiṣṭhānāya sākṣātprayatnādhiṣṭheyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: kulāla ādayaḥ hi kartāraḥ daṇḍa ādikam sākṣāt prayatnena adhiṣṭhātum anīśānāḥ tad adhiṣṭhānāya sākṣāt prayatna adhiṣṭheyam syāt
translated: For potters and others, who are agents, are not able to directly control the stick etc. with effort. For the control of that, what is to be controlled by direct effort would be.

analyzed: tatas kim apareṇa śarīreṇa
translated: Then what else is there with a body?

analyzed: atas eva bhagavān viśvamūrtiḥ iti gīyate
translated: For this very reason, the Lord is sung as the universal form.

analyzed: na ca ādi sṛṣṭeḥ prāk kāraka abhāvaḥ
translated: And there is no absence of instruments prior to the primordial creation.

analyzed: māyā ādeḥ anādeḥ vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because Maya and others exist without beginning.

analyzed: anyathā sṛṣṭaya nupapatteḥ iti
translated: Otherwise, creation is not possible.

analyzed: ādi padena indriyāṇām vakṣyamāṇasya adhiṣṭhānasya ca saṅgrahaḥ
translated: By the word beginning, the senses and the mentioned substratum are included.

analyzed: tat idam na upapadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that this is not proper.

analyzed: kutas na iti atas sautra hetum vyākhyāti bhoga iti
translated: From where not so? Therefore, he explains the reason in the sutra: Because of enjoyment etc.

analyzed: bhoga sambhavāt
translated: Because of the possibility of enjoyment.

original: yadi śivasya kārakagrāmaḥ sākṣātprayatnādhiṣṭheyaḥ syāttadā sa tasya sukhaduḥkhānubhavalakṣaṇabhogahetuḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi śivasya kāraka grāmaḥ sākṣāt prayatna adhiṣṭheyaḥ syāt tadā sa tasya sukha duḥkha anubhava lakṣaṇa bhoga hetuḥ syāt
translated: If the group of agents of Śiva were directly controlled by effort, then he would be the cause of enjoyment characterized by the experience of pleasure and pain.

analyzed: sākṣāt prayatna adhiṣṭheye smat ādi śarīre tathā darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen that way in our own body, which is directly controlled by effort.

analyzed: karma arjitasya eva tathātvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is so only for what is earned by karma, that is not so.

analyzed: sākṣāt prayatna adhiṣṭheya tvena tathābhāvasya api āpatteḥ bhoga ādimataḥ ca na īśvara tvam
translated: Because even the state of being so is obtained by being directly controlled by effort, and one who has enjoyment etc. is not a lord.

analyzed: atas śivasya bhoga ādi prasaṅgāt na iyam kalpanā yuktā iti
translated: Therefore, this conception is not proper because of the possibility of enjoyment etc. for Śiva.

original: hetvantareṇa śivasya viśvakartṛtvaṃ nirākurvat oṃ adhiṣṭhānānupapatteśca oṃ //
analyzed: hetu antareṇa śivasya viśvakartṛ tvam nirākurvat om adhiṣṭhāna anupapatteḥ ca om
translated: Refuting Śiva's status as the creator of the universe with another reason, he states the aphorism: Om, and because of the impossibility of control. Om.

analyzed: iti sūtram vyācaṣṭe adhiṣṭhāne iti
translated: He explains this aphorism with adhiṣṭhāna etc.

analyzed: adhiṣṭhāna anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And because of the impossibility of control.

original: adhiṣṭhāne sthitaḥ kartā kāryaṃ kurvan pratīyate // / / //
analyzed: adhiṣṭhāne sthitaḥ kartā kāryam kurvan pratīyate
translated: The agent is seen to be performing the action while located in the substratum.

original: yaḥ kartā kulālādiḥ sa pṛthivyādāvadhiṣṭhāne sthita eva ghaṭādikāryaṃ kurvanpratīyate /
analyzed: yaḥ kartā kulāla ādiḥ sa pṛthivī ādau adhiṣṭhāne sthitaḥ eva ghaṭa ādi kāryam kurvan pratīyate
translated: The agent such as a potter is seen to be performing the action such as a pot while located in the substratum such as the ground, etc.

analyzed: na tu niradhiṣṭhānaḥ kaścid kiñcid kurvāṇaḥ
translated: But no one is seen to be performing anything without a substratum.

analyzed: anena vyatireka avinābhāvena niradhiṣṭhāna tvasya akartṛ tvena vyāptiḥ upapāditā bhavati
translated: By this [reasoning] through the absence of a counter-example, the pervasion of being without a substratum by being without an agent is established.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha na asya iti
translated: What follows from this? Therefore it is said: It does not have...

analyzed: na asya adhiṣṭhāna yogaḥ sti bhūtānām praḷaye tadā
translated: It does not have the connection of a substratum when the elements are dissolved at that time...

analyzed: asya śivasya
translated: Of this Śiva.

analyzed: tadā ādi sṛṣṭi samaye
translated: At that time, at the beginning of creation.

analyzed: kutas na asti
translated: Why does it not exist?

analyzed: prāk utpannānām pṛthivī ādīnām mahābhūtānām pralaye sati
translated: When the great elements such as earth, which were produced earlier, are dissolved.

analyzed: tasmāt kartṛ tvam api tasya na upapadyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is concluded that even his agency is not possible.

analyzed: nanu kārakāṇām eva adhiṣṭhāna tvam bhaviṣyati
translated: But the instruments themselves will be the substratum.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: sa adhiṣṭhānasya cetanasya bhoga ādi prasakteḥ ukta tvāt
translated: Because it has been said that for a conscious being with a substratum, there would be the undesirable consequence of enjoyment, etc.

analyzed: nanu ayam niradhiṣṭhāna tva hetuḥ kartuḥ vipakṣāt kulāla ādiḥ vā akartuḥ sapakṣāt ghaṭa ādeḥ api vyāvṛtta tvāt asādhāraṇaḥ
translated: But this reason of being without a substratum is inconclusive, because it is excluded from both the dissimilar class of the potter, etc. who are agents, and from the similar class of the pot, etc. which are not agents.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: gagana ādau sapakṣe vṛtteḥ
translated: Because it occurs in the similar instance of the sky, etc.

analyzed: nanu idam sūtra dvayam vyutkrameṇa kutas vyākhyātam
translated: But why are these two aphorisms explained out of order?

analyzed: sambandha anupapatti adhiṣṭhāna nānā anupapattyoḥ ubhayoḥ api parihāraḥ karaṇavat ced iti anena nirasyate iti jñāpana artham
translated: The refutation of both the non-apprehension of relation and the non-apprehension of the substratum is done by the argument If it is like the instrument, in order to show that.

analyzed: yadi khalu yathākramam eva vyākhyāyeta
translated: If it were explained in the proper sequence,

analyzed: tadā sannihita adhiṣṭhāna anupapatti parihāra nirāsakam evā idam jñāyeta
translated: then it would be understood as refuting only the non-apprehension of the substratum that is present.

original: vyutkrameṇa tu ubhayamadhye vyākhyāne satyubhayasambandhi vijñāyata iti /
analyzed: vyutkrameṇa tu ubhaya madhye vyākhyāne sati ubhaya sambandhi vijñāyate iti
translated: But when it is explained in the reverse order, in the middle of the two, it is understood to be related to both.

original: ata eva bhāṣye 'dhiṣṭhānādirūpamityuktamatra tu dehādivaditi / /🔽nanu yuktaṃ kulālasyādhiṣṭhānasāpekṣatvaṃ śarīritvam /
analyzed: atas eva bhāṣye dhiṣṭhāna ādi rūpam iti uktam atra tu deha ādi vat iti  nanu yuktam kulālasya adhiṣṭhāna sāpekṣa tvam śarīri tvam
translated: For this very reason, in the Bhāṣya it is said to be the form of the substratum, etc., but here it is said to be like the body, etc.🔽But it is proper that the potter, being embodied, should require a substratum, because he is dependent on it.

analyzed: śarīram hi guru tvāt prasakta patanam tad pratibandhāya sparśavat adhiṣṭhānam apekṣate
translated: For the body, being heavy, is prone to fall, and it requires a substratum that is tangible to prevent that.

analyzed: anavasthita śarīrasya kartṛ tva ayogāt
translated: Because one whose body is not steady is unfit to be an agent.

analyzed: īśvarasya tu śarīra vidhurasya kim adhiṣṭhānam eva
translated: But what is the substratum of God, who is devoid of a body?

original: ihedaṃ jātamityadivyavahārastu gaganādikamāśrityopapatsyata ityata āha adehaścediti //
analyzed: iha idam jātam iti adi vyavahāraḥ tu gagana ādikam āśritya upapatsyate iti atas āha adehaḥ ced iti
translated: The usage This is produced here and so on will be accounted for by taking recourse to space, etc. To this he says If he is bodiless.

analyzed: adehaḥ ced asārvajñaḥ śilā kāṣṭha ādi vat sadā
translated: If he were bodiless, he would be omniscient, like a stone or a piece of wood, always.

analyzed: sadā iti anena vyāptim upapādayati
translated: By the word always he explains the pervasion.

analyzed: atas eva śilā kāṣṭha ādi vat iti aneka dṛṣṭānta upādānam
translated: For this very reason, the use of multiple examples like a stone or a piece of wood is made.

analyzed: tathā ca kutas
translated: And how then can there be omniscience?

analyzed: kutas ca sarva kartṛ tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And how can there be omnipotence? This is the idea.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: na sarvathā sadāśivaḥ aśarīraḥ
translated: Sadasiva is not entirely bodiless.

analyzed: kintu līlayā śarīrāṇi api gṛhṇāti
translated: But he also assumes bodies playfully.

analyzed: tatas na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is not a fault.

analyzed: na ca bhoga ādi prāptiḥ
translated: And there is no attainment of enjoyment, etc.

original: līlayā gṛhītasya vigrahasya tadahetutvādityata āha dehī cediti //
analyzed: līlayā gṛhītasya vigrahasya tad ahetu tvāt iti atas āha dehī ced iti
translated: Because the body assumed playfully is not the cause of that. Hence he says If he has a body, etc.

analyzed: dehī ced antavān eva yajñadatta nidarśanāt
translated: If he has a body, he would have an end, like Yajnadatta.

analyzed: antavān maraṇavān syāt
translated: He would have an end, have death.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: And this is an indication.

analyzed: duḥkha ādimān ca syāt iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should be seen that he would also have suffering, etc.

analyzed: nanu asau vigrahaḥ na tad hetuḥ iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that that body is not the cause of that.

analyzed: mā evam  śarīram na bhoga āyatanam ca iti asya vyāhata tvāt
translated: This is not so.🔽Because it is contradictory to say that the body is not the abode of enjoyment.

analyzed: śarīra tvena eva tad anumānāt ca
translated: And because it is inferred to be a body itself.

analyzed: tat idam āha eva iti
translated: This is what he says with only.

analyzed: etena antavat ttma sarvajña tā vā
translated: By this, having an end or omniscience is refuted.

analyzed: iti sūtram vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: Thus the sutra is explained.

original: pāṭhakramādarthakramo garīyānityato vyutkrameṇa vyākhyānam / /🔽nanvevaṃ śivasya jagatkāraṇatvamapākurvatāṃ ko 'bhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: pāṭha kramāt artha kramaḥ garīyān iti atas vyutkrameṇa vyākhyānam  nanu evam śivasya jagat kāraṇatvam apākurvatām kaḥ bhiprāyaḥ
translated: The order of meaning is more important than the order of recitation. Therefore, the explanation is in reverse order.🔽If so, what is the intention of those who deny Shiva's status as the cause of the world?

analyzed: kim akartṛkam eva idam viśvam iti
translated: Is it that this universe is without a creator?

analyzed: kiṃvā viṣṇu kartṛkam iti
translated: Or is it that Vishnu is the creator?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ  kāryasya akartṛka tve virodhāt
translated: Not the first.🔽Because it is contradictory for an effect to be without a creator.

analyzed: apasiddhānta prasakteḥ ca
translated: And because it would lead to the fallacy of contradicting one's own doctrine.

original: na dvitīyaḥ /🔽viṣṇāvapi kartaryabhyupagamyamāne doṣāṇāmeṣāṃ samānatvena sva
analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ  viṣṇau api kartari abhyupagamyamāne doṣāṇām eṣām samāna tvena sva
translated: Not the second.

analyzed: vyāhata tvāt  tathā hi yat uktam asāmañjasyam śivasya tat tāvat viṣṇau api samam
translated: Because it would be self-contradictory for them, as the faults would be the same even if Vishnu were accepted as the creator.🔽To explain, the inconsistency that was stated regarding Shiva is the same even regarding Vishnu.

analyzed: janitā uta viṣṇoḥ
translated: For example, in passages such as Vishnu is born...

analyzed: ityādau janma ādi doṣa śravaṇāt
translated: Because faults such as birth are mentioned.

analyzed: sambandha anupapatti ādikam tu sphuṭam evā iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: But the lack of proper relationship and so on is clearly the same. Therefore, he says not so and so on.

analyzed: na ca etat akhilam viṣṇau
translated: And all this is not so regarding Vishnu.

analyzed: etat akhilam doṣa jātam
translated: This entire set of faults.

original: viṣṇāvapi viśvasya kartaryabhyupagate samānamiti na vācyam /
analyzed: viṣṇau api viśvasya kartari abhyupagate samānam iti na vācyam
translated: It should not be said that it is the same even if Vishnu is accepted as the creator of the universe.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: śrutyā eva sakala doṣa parihāreṇa viṣṇoḥ viśva kāraṇa tvasya pratipādita tvāt
translated: Because the fact that Viṣṇu is the cause of the universe has been established by the Vedas themselves, by the removal of all faults.

analyzed: nanu paśupateḥ api evam āgamaiḥ anumānaiḥ ca jagat kāraṇatā pratipāditā eva
translated: But the causality of the universe has been established by the scriptures and inferences in the same way for Paśupati (Śiva) also.

original: tataḥ ko viśeṣa ityata āha śrutīti //
analyzed: tatas kaḥ viśeṣaḥ iti atas āha śruti iti
translated: Then what is the difference? To this he says śruti etc.

analyzed: śruti prāmāṇya gauravāt
translated: Because of the weight of the authoritativeness of the Vedas etc.

analyzed: pāśupata āditaḥ pi śrutīnām prāmāṇyasya guru tvāt
translated: Even from the Pāśupata and other (scriptures), the authoritativeness of the Vedas is weighty.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: pāśupatādikaṃ hi śive jagatkartari sarvajñe siddhe tatpraṇītatvena pramāṇatvena niścīyeta /
analyzed: pāśupata ādikam hi śive jagatkartari sarvajñe siddhe tat praṇīta tvena pramāṇa tvena niścīyeta
translated: For, the Pāśupata and other (scriptures) would be ascertained as authoritative only if Śiva, the creator of the universe and the omniscient one, were established.

original: niścite ca tatprāmāṇye śivasyaivaṃvidhasya siddhirityanyonyāśrayatā duravadhāraṇaprāmāṇyam /
analyzed: niścite ca tad prāmāṇye śivasya evaṃvidhasya siddhiḥ iti anyonya āśraya tā duravadhāraṇa prāmāṇyam
translated: And if the authoritativeness of those (scriptures) were ascertained, then the establishment of Śiva of such a kind would be (established). Thus there would be mutual dependence, and the authoritativeness would be difficult to ascertain.

analyzed: anyatas śivasya evaṃvidha tā siddhau alam anena
translated: If Śiva of such a kind were established by other means, then this (scripture) would be sufficient.

analyzed: na ca anyat tādṛśam pramāṇam asti
translated: And there is no such authoritative means by other means.

analyzed: anumānānām dūṣita tvāt
translated: Because the inferences have been refuted.

analyzed: na ca evam śruti prāmāṇyam
translated: But the authoritativeness of the Vedas is not like this.

original: apauruṣeyatvena karaṇadoṣāṇāṃ bādhakapratyayasya cābhāve sati tasya niṣkampameva svato niścitatvāt /
analyzed: apauruṣeya tvena karaṇa doṣāṇām bādhaka pratyayasya ca abhāve sati tasya niṣkampam eva svatas niścita tvāt
translated: Because it is ascertained by itself without any doubt, in the absence of the faults of the means of knowledge and the absence of contradictory knowledge, due to its being not composed by an author.

original: ato niścitapramāṇabhāvayā śrutyā vidhūtāvadyagandhaṃ viṣṇorjagatkāraṇatvaṃ siddhayatyeveti /
analyzed: atas niścita pramāṇa bhāvayā śrutyā vidhūta avadya gandham viṣṇoḥ jagat kāraṇatvam siddhayati eva iti
translated: Therefore, by the scripture whose validity is certain, the cause of the world of Vishnu, whose bad smell has been removed, is established.

original: kāstāḥ śrutaya ityatastā udāharati mana iti //
analyzed: kāḥ tāḥ śrutayaḥ iti atas tāḥ udāharati manaḥ iti
translated: What are those scriptures? Therefore, he quotes them as mind and so on.

analyzed: manaḥ buddhaiḥ aṅgitām viṣṇoḥ lakṣayāmaḥ yaḥ eva saḥ
translated: We perceive the mind, intellect, and body of Vishnu, who is indeed He.

analyzed: saḥ eva dehaḥ vijñānam aiśvaryam śaktiḥ ūrjitā
translated: That very body is knowledge, lordship, and powerful ability.

original: deho viṣṇorna te viṣṇo vāsudevo 'grato 'bhavat // / / //🔽eko nārāyaṇastvāsīnna brahmā naca śaṅkaraḥ /
analyzed: dehaḥ viṣṇoḥ na te viṣṇo vāsudevaḥ gratas bhavat  ekaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ tu āsīt na brahmā na ca śaṅkaraḥ
translated: The body of Vishnu is not yours, O Vishnu. Vasudeva was in front of Vishnu.🔽Alone Narayana existed, not Brahma, nor Shankara.

analyzed: ajasya nābhau adhi ekam arpitam mātrayā paraḥ
translated: In the navel of the unborn, one is placed by measure, the other is supreme.

analyzed: sat dehaḥ sukha gandhaḥ ca jñāna bhās sat parākramaḥ
translated: He has a good body, the fragrance of happiness, the light of knowledge, and true valor.

analyzed: jñāna jñānaḥ sukha sukhaḥ sa viṣṇuḥ parama akṣaraḥ
translated: He who knows knowledge by knowledge, happiness by happiness, He is Vishnu, the supreme imperishable.

analyzed: ānandaḥ ekaḥ eva agre āsīt nārāyaṇaḥ prabhuḥ
translated: Bliss alone was in the beginning, the lord Narayana.

original: priyaṃ tasya śire modapramodau ca bhujau hareḥ // / / //🔽ānando madhyato brahma pucchaṃ nānyadabhūt kvacit /
analyzed: priyam tasya śire moda pramodau ca bhujau hareḥ  ānandaḥ madhyatas brahma puccham na anyat abhūt kvacid
translated: His head is Priyam, his arms are Moda and Pramoda of Hari.🔽Brahma is in the middle as bliss. The tail is not anything else anywhere.

analyzed: brahmā lalāṭāt api śaṅkaraḥ
translated: From his forehead, Brahma was born, and from his forehead, Shankara was born.

analyzed: pakṣayoḥ garuḍaḥ śeṣaḥ mukhāt āsa sarasvatī
translated: Garuda on the wings, Shesha from the mouth, Saraswati on the tongue,

analyzed: sahasra śīrṣā puruṣaḥ sahasra akṣaḥ sahasra pād
translated: The thousand-headed Purusha, with a thousand eyes, a thousand feet,

analyzed: anena buddhi manaḥ ṅga pratyaṅgavat tām bhagavataḥ
translated: With this, he observes the presence of intelligence, mind, limbs, and minor limbs in the Blessed One.

analyzed: buddhimān manovān aṅgavān pratyaṅgavān
translated: 'Intelligent, minded, having limbs, having minor limbs.'

analyzed: iti śrutim upādatte
translated: He cites this Vedic text.

original: ya eva' / ityanenayadātmako bhagavāṃstadātmikā vyaktiḥ kimātmako bhagavānjñānātmaka aiśvaryātmakaḥ śaktyātmakaḥ' / iti /
analyzed: yaḥ eva iti anena yad ātmakaḥ bhagavān tad ātmikā vyaktiḥ kimātmakaḥ bhagavān jñāna ātmakaḥ aiśvarya ātmakaḥ śakti ātmakaḥ iti
translated: With 'He who is...' he shows that the manifestation has the same nature as the Blessed One. What is the nature of the Blessed One? He is of the nature of knowledge, of the nature of lordship, of the nature of power.

analyzed: ūrjitā balavatī
translated: Vigorous means powerful.

analyzed: sarvatra apratibaddhā
translated: Unrestrained everywhere.

analyzed: etad ātamakaḥ bhagavān tatas tasya dehaḥ u pi etad ātmakaḥ iti śruti labdhaḥ rthaḥ
translated: The Blessed One has this nature, therefore his body also has this nature. This is the meaning obtained from the scriptures.

analyzed: na te viṣṇau
translated: 'Not in Vishnu...'

original: ityanenana te viṣṇo jāyamāno na jāto devamahimnaḥ paramantamāpa' / iti /
analyzed: iti anena na te viṣṇo jāyamānaḥ na jātaḥ deva mahimnaḥ param antam āpaḥ iti
translated: With this, 'Not in Vishnu, O god, is the highest greatness of the unborn or the born.'🔽'Vasudeva...'🔽With this, 'Vasudeva indeed was in the beginning.'

original: vāsudevaḥ' / ityanenavāsudevo vā idamagra āsīt' / iti /
analyzed: vāsudevaḥ iti anena vāsudevaḥ vai idam agre āsīt iti
translated: 'By measure...'

original: mātrayā' / ityanenaparo mātrayā tanvā vṛdhāna na te mahitvamanvaśnuvanti' / iti /
analyzed: mātrayā iti anena paraḥ mātrayā tanvā vṛdhāna na te mahitvam anvaśnuvanti iti
translated: With this, 'By measure, O thou that art grown by thy body, they do not attain thy greatness.'

analyzed: katham etābhiḥ śrutibhiḥ abhipreta artha siddhiḥ iti atas tāsām tātparyam āha ityādi iti
translated: How is the intended meaning established by these scriptural passages? To that, he states their purport with Thus, etc.

analyzed: ityādi śruti sandarbha balāt nitya guṇa ātmanaḥ
translated: By the power of the series of scriptural passages beginning with this,

analyzed: viṣṇoḥ dehāt jagat sarvam āvirāsīt iti iyate
translated: It is said that the entire universe arose from the body of Vishnu, who is eternal and has the nature of qualities.

analyzed: nityaḥ ca asau guṇa ātmā ca iti tathā uktaḥ
translated: He is said to be so because he is eternal and has the nature of qualities.

analyzed: tasmāt
translated: Therefore.

analyzed: tatrabuddhiḥ
translated: There, the intellect.

analyzed: iti śrutyā viṣṇoḥ dehavat tvam avagamyate
translated: By this scriptural passage, the fact that Vishnu has a body is understood.

analyzed: aṅgam dehaḥ
translated: A limb is a body.

analyzed: pratyaṅgāni hasta ādīni
translated: The minor limbs are the hands and so on.

analyzed: lakṣayāmahe jñāpayāmaḥ
translated: We perceive, we make known.

analyzed: katham buddhimān ityādi
translated: How is he intelligent, etc.?

analyzed: yad ātmakaḥ bhagavān
translated: In what form the Lord is.

analyzed: iti anayā bhagavataḥ dehasya jñāna ādi guṇa ātmaka tvāt
translated: By this, because the body of the Lord has the nature of qualities such as knowledge,

analyzed: vyaktiḥ dehaḥ
translated: The manifestation is the body.

analyzed: na te viṣṇau
translated: They are not in Vishnu.

analyzed: iti anā bhagavaḥ dehasya jñāna ādi guṇa ātmaka tvam anādi nitya tvam
translated: By this, the body of the Lord has the nature of qualities such as knowledge and is beginningless and eternal.

analyzed: jāta ādibhiḥ a prāpya mahitvasya anyathā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the existence of the body cannot be otherwise explained by being born, etc.

analyzed: vāsudevaḥ iti śruti dvayena anādi nitya deha tvam
translated: By the two scriptural passages Vasudeva and The unborn, the body is beginningless and eternal.

analyzed: ajasya iti anayā dehavat tvam tasya api aja tvam
translated: By this Of the unborn, the fact that he has a body and is unborn is understood.

analyzed: paras mātrayā
translated: Beyond measure.

analyzed: iti anayā deśa kāla guṇaiḥ aparicchinna tanu tvam
translated: Thus, by this (verse), (the Lord) is said to have a body that is not limited by space, time, and qualities.

analyzed: sat dehaḥ ityādi śruti dvayena janma ādi doṣa rahita guṇa ātma dehavattvam
translated: By the two scriptural passages beginning with He who has a real body, (the Lord) is said to have a body consisting of qualities free from the faults of birth, etc.

analyzed: sat dehaḥ janma ādi doṣa rahita dehaḥ
translated: He who has a real body has a body free from the faults of birth, etc.

analyzed: sukha gandhaḥ su gandhaḥ
translated: Having the fragrance of bliss has a pleasant fragrance.

analyzed: jñāna bhās na tu taijasa bhās
translated: (He is) the light of knowledge, not the light of the elements.

analyzed: jñāna jñāne ityādeḥ atiśayita jñāne ityādiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The knower of knowledge etc. means the one with superior knowledge etc.

analyzed: priya ādi śabdāḥ sukha viśeṣa vācinaḥ
translated: Words like priya (dear) denote a particular kind of bliss.

analyzed: anyat prākṛta ādikam
translated: Other refers to the natural and so on.

original: manasaḥ' / ityādiśrutidvayena dehavattvaṃ tato jagato janma ca /
analyzed: manasaḥ ityādi śruti dvayena dehavat tvam tatas jagataḥ janma ca
translated: By the two scriptural passages beginning with of the mind, (the Lord) is said to have a body and from that the birth of the world.

analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ sya
translated: The Brahmana of this

analyzed: ityādi vākya śeṣāt
translated: from the remaining part of the sentence.

analyzed: pakṣayoḥ pārśvayoḥ
translated: On the two wings means on the two sides.

original: atra kāsucit śrutiṣu vivakṣitārtho na sphuṭaṃ pratīyate /🔽kintūpapattisādhya ityāśayavatoktam balāditi //
analyzed: atra kāsucid śrutiṣu vivakṣita arthaḥ na sphuṭam pratīyate  kintu upapatti sādhyaḥ iti āśayavatā uktam balāt iti
translated: Here, in some scriptural passages, the intended meaning is not clearly understood.🔽But it is to be accomplished by reasoning, with this intention it is said by force.

analyzed: āvirāsīt iti anena satkārya vādam sūcayati
translated: By appeared he indicates the doctrine of sat-kārya (effect pre-exists in the cause).

analyzed: īyate jñāyate
translated: Is known means is understood.

analyzed: atra sakala jagat kāraṇatvasya eva śruti siddha tve sarva doṣa parihāraḥ sidhyati eva
translated: Here, if the fact of being the cause of the entire world is established by scripture, the avoidance of all faults is certainly accomplished.

analyzed: nahi doṣeṣu satsu tat sambhavati
translated: For that is not possible when faults are present.

analyzed: tathā api deha abhāva prayuktāni dūṣaṇāni prayuktāni
translated: Still, objections based on the absence of a body have been raised.

original: tasya ca dehasya jñānānandādiguṇātmakatvena jananādidoṣaparihāro 'pi siddhaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca dehasya jñāna ānanda ādi guṇa ātmaka tvena janana ādi doṣa parihāraḥ api siddhaḥ
translated: And the avoidance of faults like birth has also been established by the fact that that body consists of qualities like knowledge, bliss, etc.

analyzed: janitā uta ityādi vākyam tu bahvībhiḥ niravakāśa ādibhiḥ śrutibhiḥ viruddham anyathā vyākhyeyam
translated: But the statement beginning with He who is born is contradicted by many non-conclusive and other Vedic statements and should be explained otherwise.

analyzed: tat idam uktam sandarbha balāt iti
translated: This is what is meant by by the force of the context.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: dehaḥ jñāna ānanda ādi guṇa ātmā anādi nityaḥ ca iti etat śaśaḥ viṣāṇavān iti vat viruddham
translated: That the body consists of qualities like knowledge, bliss, etc., and is beginningless and eternal, is contradictory like saying the hare has horns.

original: yo dehaḥ sa bhautiko janmādimāniti niyamadarśanāt /
analyzed: yaḥ dehaḥ sa bhautikaḥ janma ādimān iti niyama darśanāt
translated: Because it is observed that whatever is a body is necessarily composed of elements and subject to birth, etc.

original: tato viṣṇordehamaṅgīkṛtya tasyābhautikatvādyaṅgīkāre śaśasyāpi viṣāṇitvamaṅgīkāryamityato dehasyābhautikatvādinā virodhaṃ tāvadapākaroti mānasattvāditi🔽mānavattvād virodhaḥ ko / / / // / / //
analyzed: tatas viṣṇoḥ deham aṅgīkṛtya tasya abhautika tva ādi aṅgīkāre śaśasya api viṣāṇi tvam aṅgīkāryam iti atas dehasya abhautika tva ādinā virodham tāvat apākaroti māna sattvāt iti  mānavat tvāt virodhaḥ kaḥ
translated: Therefore, having accepted Vishnu's body, if His being non-material, etc. is accepted, then the hare's having horns must also be accepted. Thus, he first removes the contradiction of the body being non-material, etc. with because of having a mind.🔽What contradiction is there in having a mind?

analyzed: kaḥ iti ākṣepe
translated: What is used in the sense of objection.

analyzed: na asti virodhaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no contradiction.

analyzed: idānīm śaśaviṣāṇa pratibandīm mocayati na iti
translated: Now he releases the counter-argument of the hare's horns with no.

analyzed: nāmānam kvacid iṣyate
translated: A name is accepted in some cases.

analyzed: aṅgīkurmaḥ śaśaviṣāṇam api
translated: We accept even the horn of a hare.

analyzed: yadi parameśvara vigrahasya ānanda ādi ātmaka tvam asti prāmāṇikam syāt
translated: If the blissfulness etc. of the body of the Supreme Lord were to exist, it would be authoritative.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

original: nahyaprāmāṇikaṃ kenāpi kadāpi kvacidapyeṣyuṃ śakyata iti /🔽nanu prāmāṇikatve 'pi virodhābhāvaḥ kathamityata āha avirodha iti //
analyzed: na hi aprāmāṇikam kena api kadāpi kvacid api eṣyum śakyate iti  nanu prāmāṇika tve pi virodha abhāvaḥ katham iti atas āha avirodhaḥ iti
translated: For what is not authoritative cannot be accepted by anyone at any time anywhere.🔽But even if it is authoritative, how can there be absence of contradiction? To this he says: Absence of contradiction etc.

analyzed: avirodhaḥ virodhaḥ ca mānena eva hi gamyate
translated: Absence of contradiction and contradiction are indeed understood only through valid cognition.

original: yayoḥ kvacitsahadarśanaṃ tayoravirodhaḥ /🔽yayostu niyamena vyadhikaraṇatayaiva daśarnaṃ tayoḥ virodha ityevaṃ sahadarśanāsahadarśanalakṣaṇena mānena hi
analyzed: yayoḥ kvacid saha darśanam tayoḥ avirodhaḥ  yayoḥ tu niyamena vyadhikaraṇa tayā eva tayoḥ virodhaḥ iti evam sahadarśana asahadarśana lakṣaṇena mānena hi
translated: That which is seen together somewhere, there is absence of contradiction between them.

analyzed: vastūnām avirodha virodhau avagantavyau
translated: But that which is seen invariably only as having different substrata, there is contradiction between them. Thus, absence of contradiction and contradiction of entities should be understood through valid cognition characterized by seeing together and not seeing together.

analyzed: tad niyamākasya anyasya abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no other rule than that.

original: ataḥ pramāṇena sahadṛṣṭe 'rthe virodhaḥ kathaṃ syādvayāghātāditi /
analyzed: atas pramāṇena saha dṛṣṭe rthe virodhaḥ katham syāt vayāghātāt iti
translated: Therefore, how can there be contradiction in an object seen together with valid cognition, because of the absence of inconsistency?

analyzed: upasaṃharati atas iti
translated: He concludes with Therefore etc.

original: ata uktaṃ samastaṃ ca vāsudevasya yujyate // / / //
analyzed: atas uktam samastam ca vāsudevasya yujyate
translated: Therefore, all that has been said is proper for Vāsudeva.

analyzed: pramāṇaiḥ saha dṛṣṭe rthe virodhasya an āśaṅkanīya tvāt
translated: Because contradiction is not to be suspected in an object seen together with valid cognition.

analyzed: uktam udāhṛtābhiḥ śrutibhiḥ
translated: It has been stated by the quoted scriptures.

analyzed: samastam cit ānanda ādi ātmaka niravadya vigraheṇa jagat kāraṇatvam
translated: The cause of the world with a faultless body consisting of consciousness, bliss, etc.

analyzed: etat ca arūpa vat eva ityādinā vakṣyamāṇam śiṣya hita eṣiṇā ācāryeṇa atra uktam iti jñātavyam
translated: And this, which will be stated later with It is like the formless, etc., should be understood to have been stated here by the teacher who is desirous of the welfare of the disciples.

analyzed: nanu etat asmākam api samānam
translated: But this is the same for us also.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus:

analyzed: yadi api pāśupata ādikam aśakya avadhāraṇa pramāṇa bhāvam
translated: Although the Pāśupata and other [scriptures] are of doubtful validity,

analyzed: tathā api jñātvā śivam śāntim atyantam eti
translated: nevertheless, having known Śiva, one attains peace forever.

analyzed: ekaḥ rudraḥ na dvitīyāya tasthe
translated: Rudra is one, he does not stand as a second.

analyzed: saḥ imān lokān īśate īśanībhiḥ
translated: He rules over these worlds with his powers.

analyzed: ityādyāḥ śrutayaḥ tāvat śivasya jagat janma ādi hetutām ācakṣate
translated: These and other scriptures declare that Śiva is the cause of the creation, etc. of the world.

analyzed: śiva ādi nāma upeta tvāt
translated: Because they are endowed with the names Śiva and so on.

original: naca tathāvidhasyāsamañjasatvaṃ sambhavatītyudāhṛtāḥ śrutayo 'nyathā yojyāḥ /🔽ataḥ sambandhānupapattyādikaṃ śrutirevābhāsayiṣyati /
analyzed: na ca tathāvidhasya asamañjasa tvam sambhavati iti udāhṛtāḥ śrutayaḥ nyathā yojyāḥ  atas sambandha anupapatti ādikam śrutiḥ evā ābhāsayiṣyati
translated: And it is not possible for such [a scripture] to be incoherent. Therefore, the quoted scriptures should be interpreted otherwise.

original: tadghaṭakaṃ vā kimapi kalpayiṣyatītyata āha śivādīti //
analyzed: tad ghaṭakam vā kim api kalpayiṣyati iti atas āha śiva ādi iti
translated: Therefore, the scriptures themselves will reveal the impossibility of the relation, etc., or will imagine something that is a part of that. In response to this, he says Śiva and so on.

analyzed: śiva ādi nāma yuktāḥ ca śrutayaḥ viṣṇu vācakāḥ
translated: And the scriptures endowed with the names Śiva and so on are the words of Viṣṇu.

analyzed: bhavet evam yadi etāḥ śrutayaḥ śiva parāḥ syuḥ
translated: This would be so if these scriptures were about Shiva.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: kintu śiva ādi nāma yuktāḥ api viṣṇu viṣayāḥ eva
translated: Rather, even those with names like Shiva are about Vishnu alone.

analyzed: nanu etat kutas  evam sati asmābhiḥ api vaktum śakyate eva
translated: But how is this known?

original: eko nārāyaṇa ityādyā api śrutayaḥ śivaparā iti /
analyzed: ekaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ ityādyāḥ api śrutayaḥ śiva parāḥ iti
translated: If this is so, then we can also say: Even scriptures like Nārāyaṇa alone are about Shiva.

analyzed: mā evam
translated: No, that is not so.

analyzed: śiva ādi nāmnām viṣṇau śaktimat tvāt
translated: Because the names like Shiva have power in Vishnu.

analyzed: nārāyaṇa ādi nāmnām śive śakti abhavāt
translated: Because the names like Nārāyaṇa do not have power in Shiva.

analyzed: atra api kim mānam iti atas āha nāmāni iti
translated: Here also, what is the proof? Therefore it is said: The names, etc.

original: nāmāni sarvāṇi ca yameko yo devanāmadhāḥ /
analyzed: nāmāni sarvāṇi ca yam ekaḥ yaḥ deva nāma dhāḥ
translated: The one in whom all names are united, who is the bestower of the names of gods,

analyzed: viṣṇu nāmāni na anyasya sarva nāmā hariḥ svayam
translated: The names of Vishnu are not of any other, Hari himself is all names.

analyzed: na nārāyaṇa nāmāni tad anyeṣu apare harau
translated: The names of Nārāyaṇa are not in other Hrishikeshas.🔽Such scriptures are the proof there, and the conclusion is stated.

original: ityādiśrutayastatra mānaṃ coktaḥ samanvayaḥ // / / //🔽anenanāmāni viśvābhi na santi loke' /🔽ityādikāṃ śrutimupādatte /
analyzed: ityādi śrutayaḥ tatra mānam ca uktaḥ samanvayaḥ  anenanāmāni viśvā abhi na santi loke  ityādikām śrutim upādatte
translated: By this, the scripture beginning with The names of all things are in Him is referred to.

analyzed: ekaḥ iti anena
translated: By one,

analyzed: yaḥ devānām nāmadhāḥ ekaḥ eva iti
translated: He who is the one bestower of the names of gods

analyzed: nāmāni dhatte iti nāmadhāḥ  na anyasya vācakāni
translated: Name-bestower means one who bears the names.🔽They are not the denotators of any other.

analyzed: na tad anyeṣu vartante
translated: They do not occur in others.

analyzed: apare śiva ādi śabdāḥ
translated: The other words like Shiva are also [used in the same way].

analyzed: uktaḥ samanvayaḥ ca tatra mānam iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is that the proof for that has been stated.

analyzed: samanvaya grahaṇena etat api parihṛtam  etāḥ api śrutīḥ aham
translated: By mentioning the agreement, this is also avoided.

analyzed: vyākhyāsyāmi iti
translated: I will explain these scriptures as having Shiva and others as their subject matter.

analyzed: upakrama ādibhiḥ liṅga ādibhiḥ ca bhagavat para tayā niścita tvāt iti
translated: Because it has been ascertained by the agreements such as the introductory statement and the indications that they refer to the Lord.

original: mā bhūcchatibhiḥ śivasya jagatkāraṇatvāvadhāraṇaṃ śaivapurāṇaistu bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: mā bhūt śatibhiḥ śivasya jagat kāraṇatva avadhāraṇam śaiva purāṇaiḥ tu bhaviṣyati
translated: Let there be no ascertainment of Shiva's status as the cause of the world by the scriptures, but it will be by the Shiva Puranas.

analyzed: na ca tāni api viṣṇu parāṇi
translated: And those are not devoted to Vishnu.

analyzed: upakrama ādi balena śiva viṣaya tayā niścita tvāt iti atas āha purāṇāni iti
translated: Because they have been ascertained as referring to Shiva by the power of the introductory statement and other indications. Therefore it is said:

analyzed: purāṇāni purāṇa ādyaiḥ viruddha tvāt na tat pramā
translated: The Puranas are not a valid means of knowledge regarding that, due to contradicting the Puranas and other [texts].

analyzed: purāṇa ādyaiḥ vaiṣṇavaiḥ  viruddha tvāt prāk prābalya cintāyāḥ sat pratipakṣa tvāt
translated: The Puranas and other [texts] are Vaishnava.

analyzed: tat uttaram bādhita tvāt ca
translated: Because of contradicting, because of being a true counter-argument before the consideration of superiority, and because of being contradicted afterwards.

analyzed: tat tatra śivasya jagat kāraṇa tve
translated: That is there. In the case of Shiva being the cause of the world.

analyzed: na kevalam vaiṣṇava ādi purāṇa ādi viruddha tvāt apramāṇam śaiva purāṇam
translated: Not only is the Shiva Purana not a valid means of knowledge due to contradicting the Vaishnava Puranas and other [texts],

analyzed: kintu
translated: But the Shiva Purana is a valid means of knowledge for the Shaivas.

analyzed: viruddha tvāt api iti āha tat iti
translated: He says that it is also because of contradiction: that.

analyzed: tad viruddheṣu no mānam pūrva apara virodhataḥ
translated: There is no authority in what contradicts that, due to contradiction between earlier and later.

analyzed: tad viruddheṣu śaiva purāṇa ādi viruddheṣu śiva jagat kāraṇa ādiṣu no mānam
translated: There is no authority in what contradicts that, in what contradicts the Śaiva Purāṇa etc., in what contradicts Śiva being the cause of the world etc.

analyzed: śaiva purāṇam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The Śaiva Purāṇa is implied.

original: kathaṃ śaivapurāṇasya śaivapurāṇavirodha ityata āha pūrveti //
analyzed: katham śaiva purāṇasya śaiva purāṇa virodhaḥ iti atas āha pūrva iti
translated: How can the Śaiva Purāṇa contradict the Śaiva Purāṇa? Therefore he says earlier and later.

analyzed: etat ca anyatra darśitam
translated: And this has been shown elsewhere.

original: kiñca śaivavaiṣṇavapakṣapātaśūnyabrāhmapurāṇaviruddhatvācca śaivapurāṇaṃ vimate 'rthe na mānamityāha sameti //
analyzed: kiñca śaiva vaiṣṇava pakṣapāta śūnya brāhma purāṇa viruddha tvāt ca śaiva purāṇam vimate rthe na mānam iti āha sama iti
translated: Moreover, because it contradicts the Brahma Purāṇa, which is free from partiality towards Śaivas and Vaiṣṇavas, the Śaiva Purāṇa is not authoritative in a disputed matter. He says equally.

analyzed: sama brāhma virodhāt ca
translated: And because of the contradiction with the equal Brahma.

analyzed: idam api anyatra darśitam
translated: This too has been shown elsewhere.

analyzed: evam tarhi vaiṣṇavānām api purāṇa ādīnām aprāmāṇyam syāt
translated: If so, then the Purāṇas etc. of the Vaiṣṇavas would also be unauthoritative.

analyzed: teṣām api śaiva brāhma purāṇa viruddha tvāt pūrva apara virodhāt ca iti atas āha niyamāt iti
translated: Because they also contradict the Śaiva and Brahma Purāṇas and due to contradiction between earlier and later. Therefore he says by rule.

analyzed: niyamāt vaiṣṇaveṣu api
translated: By rule, even in the Vaiṣṇava.

analyzed: eka prakāra tvāt
translated: Because of being of one kind.

analyzed: pūrva apara virodha abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction between earlier and later.

analyzed: śaiva ādi purāṇānām etad pratibandhaka tva ādi asāmarthyāt iti apeḥ arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word api is that the Śaiva and other Purāṇas are not capable of being a counteragent to this.

analyzed: teṣām na aprāmāṇyam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is that they are not unauthoritative.

original: nanu vaiṣṇaveṣvapi purāṇādiṣu śivādīnāṃ jagatkāraṇatvādikaṃ viṣṇunā tadīyastutyādikāraṇaṃ ca pratīyata eva /
analyzed: nanu vaiṣṇaveṣu api purāṇa ādiṣu śiva ādīnām jagat kāraṇatva ādikam viṣṇunā tadīya stutya ādi kāraṇam ca pratīyate eva
translated: But in the Vaishnava Puranas and other texts, it is indeed understood that Shiva and others are the cause of the world, and Vishnu is the cause of praising them and so on.

original: tatkathaṃ niyama ucyata ityata āha mohārthamiti //
analyzed: tat katham niyamaḥ ucyate iti atas āha moha artham iti
translated: How then is the rule stated? To this he says for the purpose of delusion and so on.

analyzed: moha artha muktitaḥ ca eva
translated: And because it is stated for the purpose of delusion, etc.

analyzed: śiva ādīnām jagat kāraṇa tva ādeḥ ayogya jana vyāmohana artham eva uktiḥ
translated: The statement of Shiva and others being the cause of the world, etc. is only for the purpose of deluding those who are not qualified.

original: caśabdādviṣṇunā śivastutyādermohārthaṃ kṛtasyānuvādataśca niyamo na viruddha iti /
analyzed: caśabdāt viṣṇunā śiva stuti ādeḥ moha artham kṛtasya anuvādataḥ ca niyamaḥ na viruddhaḥ iti
translated: And because Vishnu's praise of Shiva, etc. is stated as done for the purpose of delusion, the rule is not contradicted.

analyzed: katham śaiva purāṇa ādīnām pratirodhaka tva ādi asāmathyarm iti atas āha moha artham iti
translated: How is it that the Shaiva Puranas, etc. are not capable of countering, etc.? To this he says for the purpose of delusion.

analyzed: śaiva purāṇa ādīnām moha artham eva uktitaḥ kṛta tvāt
translated: Because the Shaiva Puranas, etc. are stated as being done only for the purpose of delusion.

analyzed: caśabdena vaiṣṇavānām kṛta tvāt
translated: The word and indicates that the Vaishnavas are done only for the purpose of knowing the truth.

analyzed: atra ca arthe pramāṇāni uktāni
translated: And in this matter, other proofs are stated elsewhere.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa artham upasaṃharati viṣṇuḥ iti
translated: He concludes the meaning of the section with Vishnu and so on.

analyzed: viṣṇuḥ ekaḥ guṇa arṇavaḥ
translated: Vishnu alone is an ocean of qualities.

analyzed: tasmāt iti siddham iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the remainder is established.

original: nanu skandādimatānyapyuktārthavirodhīni santi tāni kuto 'tra na nirākriyanta ityata āha skandeti //
analyzed: nanu skanda ādi matāni api ukta artha virodhīni santi tāni kutas na nirākriyante iti atas āha skanda iti
translated: But are not the doctrines of Skanda and others also contrary to the meaning stated? Why are they not refuted here? To this he says Skanda etc.

analyzed: skanda sūrya gaṇeśa ādi matāni nyāyataḥ mutaḥ
translated: The doctrines of Skanda, Surya, Ganesha and others are refuted by reasoning from that.

analyzed: nirākṛtāni
translated: They are refuted by reasoning from that.

analyzed: amutas nyāyataḥ pāśupata mata nirākaraṇa nyāyataḥ
translated: From that, by the reasoning of refuting the doctrine of Pasupata.

analyzed: atas na nirākriyante iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore they are not refuted - this is the remainder.

analyzed: katham anena nyāyena tad nirākaraṇam iti atas āha aśeṣeṇa iti
translated: How is their refutation by this reasoning? To this he says completely etc.

analyzed: aśeṣeṇa siddhāntasya aviśeṣataḥ  kātsnaryena tadīya siddhāntānām pāśupata siddhāntasya ca aviśeṣataḥ
translated: Completely, without distinction from the established conclusion.🔽Completely, without distinction from their established conclusions and the established conclusion of Pasupata.

analyzed: kevala devatā antara parigraheṇa eva siddhānta bhedaḥ
translated: The difference in established conclusions is only by accepting a different deity.

analyzed: prakriyā tu sarvatra samānā eva
translated: But the procedure is the same everywhere.

analyzed: atas pūrva nirākaraṇa nyāyena eva tad nirākaraṇam yuktam eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the refutation of them is indeed proper by the reasoning of the previous refutation - this is the idea.

analyzed: iti śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām patyuḥ adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the Lord in the glorious Nyāyasudhā.

analyzed: adhikaraṇa  atha śrīmat nyāyasudhāyām utpatti aśaktya
translated: XI. The chapter on the impossibility of origination.

analyzed: dhikaraṇam
translated: Now, in the glorious Nyāyasudhā, the chapter on the impossibility of origination.

analyzed: om utpatti asambhavāt om
translated: Om. Because origination is impossible.

analyzed: śāktam matam atra apākriyate
translated: The Shakta doctrine is refuted here.

analyzed: na nirākartavyam eva etat
translated: This should not be refuted at all.

analyzed: skānda ādi mata vat asya api pūrva nyāyena eva nirasta tvāt
translated: Because this too has been refuted by the same reasoning as before, like the doctrine of Skanda and others.

analyzed: yathā hi
translated: For just as,

original: patyurityasya sthāne skandasyetyādi paṭhitvāsāmañjasye tadanusāriṇyaḥ śrutaya udāhriyante /
analyzed: patyuḥ ityasya sthāne skandasya ityādi paṭhitvā asāmañjasye tad anusāriṇyaḥ śrutayaḥ udāhriyante
translated: having read of the Lord as of Skanda and so on, the scriptures that follow that are cited.

analyzed: sambandha anupapatti ādikam ca tad viṣayam yojyate
translated: And the topic of the impossibility of relation and so on is applied to that.

analyzed: tathā śaktau api vaktum
translated: In the same way, it can be said of Shakti too.

analyzed: anyathā skanda ādi śarnam api pṛthak apākaraṇīyam syāt
translated: Otherwise, the worship of Skanda and others would also have to be refuted separately.

analyzed: atha ucyeta
translated: Now, if it is said:

analyzed: śākta mate pāśupatāt ācāra bheda ādeḥ vidyamāna tvāt tad siddhānta aviśeṣaḥ na asti iti
translated: In the Shakta doctrine, there is no difference in the conclusions because of the existence of differences in conduct and so on from the Pashupata doctrine,

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: saura ādi mateṣu api tasya vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because that exists even in the doctrines of Surya and others.

original: atha kiṃ tena /🔽devatāviśeṣaparigrahamantareṇoktārthaviruddho dūṣyo 'tharḥ sarvatra samāna eveti brūṣe /
analyzed: atha kim tena  devatā viśeṣa parigraham antareṇa ukta artha viruddhaḥ sarvatra samānaḥ eva iti brūṣe
translated: Now, what is the use of that?

original: tacchākte 'pi samānamityato naitadapi pṛthagapākaraṇīyamityata āha nirākṛtāviti //
analyzed: tat śākte samānam iti atas na etat api pṛthak apākaraṇīyam iti atas āha nirākṛtau iti
translated: If you say that the doctrine that is contradictory to the stated meaning without the acceptance of a particular deity is to be refuted everywhere, it is the same in Shakta too. Therefore, this also should not be refuted separately. Hence he says in the refutation and so on.

analyzed: utpatti asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because of the impossibility of origination.

analyzed: nirākṛtau viśeṣasya bhāvāt śakti matam pṛthak  dūṣyate
translated: The doctrine of Śaktimat is refuted separately because there is a difference in the refutation of the particular [view].🔽[The opponent says:] The doctrine of Śaktimat is not refuted separately, because it is not different from the Pāśupata doctrine.

analyzed: satyam
translated: [Reply:] True,

analyzed: skanda ādi vat śāktasya api matasya na pāśupatāt viśeṣaḥ
translated: but the doctrine of Śaktimat is also not different from the Pāśupata doctrine.

analyzed: atas eva ukta doṣa grāma viṣaya tvam api  tathā api tatra asādhāraṇasya dūṣaṇasya api vi
translated: For this very reason, it is also subject to the multitude of faults mentioned.

original: sya vidyamānatvāttadvivakṣayā śaktimataṃ pṛthagbhaṅgayā dūṣyate sūtrakāreṇa /
analyzed: vidyamāna tvāt tad vivakṣayā śakti matam pṛthak bhaṅgayā dūṣyate sūtrakāreṇa
translated: Nevertheless, because there is also a unique fault there, the author of the aphorisms refutes the doctrine of Śaktimat separately, intending that [unique fault].

original: utpattyasambhavo hi śāktasyaivāsādhāraṇadoṣo na tu puruṣadaivatānām /
analyzed: utpatti asambhavaḥ hi śāktasya eva asādhāraṇa doṣaḥ na tu puruṣa daivatānām
translated: For the impossibility of origination is a unique fault only of the doctrine of Śaktimat, but not of those who have Puruṣa as the deity.

analyzed: etat ca vakṣyāmaḥ iti
translated: And this we will explain.

analyzed: evam adhikaraṇa ārambham upapādya idānīm śākta mata sthiti
translated: Having thus explained the beginning of the section, he now presents the position of the doctrine of Śaktimat

analyzed: m upanyasyati mahatī iti
translated: with the words great and so on.
The great goddess, the bestower of hrīṃ, is the cause of all.

analyzed: tripurā bhairavī ityādi nāmabhiḥ sā abhidhīyate
translated: She is designated by names such as Tripurabhairavī and so on.

analyzed: śaktimatam iti vartate
translated: The doctrine of Śaktimat continues.

analyzed: sarvasya āgāminā iti śabdena sambandhaḥ
translated: The word all is connected with the following word coming.

analyzed: devī mahatī sarva utkṛṣṭā iti śakti matam iti
translated: The goddess is great, the most excellent of all, according to the doctrine of Śaktimat.

analyzed: katham mahatī iti atas uktam sarva kāraṇam iti
translated: How is she great? To this it is said: she is the cause of all.

analyzed: sakala jagat sṛṣṭayā ādikāraṇa tvāt sārvajña ādi sarva guṇavatī samasta doṣa dūrā bhaga
translated: Because she is the cause of the creation etc. of the entire world, and is endowed with all qualities such as omniscience, and is far from all faults, the Blessed

analyzed: vatī iti atas sarva utkṛṣṭā iti
translated: Goddess is therefore the most excellent of all.

analyzed: nanu idam śāstram anyonya vyāhatam katham pramāṇam syāt
translated: But how can this scripture be a valid means of knowledge when it contradicts itself?

original: bhuvaneśvarītantre hi saiva mahatī sarvakāraṇamiti cocyate /
analyzed: bhuvaneśvarītantre hi sā eva mahatī sarva kāraṇam iti ca ucyate
translated: For in the Bhuvaneśvarī Tantra, she alone is said to be the great cause of everything.

analyzed: tripurātantre tu tripurā eva
translated: But in the Tripurā Tantra, it is Tripura.

analyzed: tathā bhaivarītantre bhairavī
translated: Similarly, in the Bhairava Tantra, it is Bhairavī.

analyzed: evam kubjikā ādi tantreṣu anyā ca anyā ca
translated: Thus in the Kubjikā and other Tantras, it is different and different.

analyzed: na ca bahvīnām sarva uttama tvam upapadyate iti atas uktam
translated: And it is not possible for many to be the most excellent of all. Therefore it is said:

analyzed: hrīṅkārī tripurā bhairavī ityādi nāmabhiḥ sā bhagavatī ekā evā abhidhīyate
translated: That Blessed Goddess is called by the names Hrīṃkāri, Tripurā, Bhairavī, and so on.

analyzed: atas na na anyonya
translated: Therefore there is no mutual

analyzed: vyāghātaḥ iti
translated: contradiction.

analyzed: śāktāḥ ca trividhāḥ
translated: And the Śāktas are of three kinds.

analyzed: mahā vāmāḥ madhya vāmāḥ aṇu vāmāḥ ca iti
translated: They are the Mahāvāmas, Madhyavāmas, and Aṇuvāmas.

analyzed: ete eva kvacid śākta śāmbhavāṇa śabdaiḥ ucyante
translated: These same are sometimes called Śākta, Śāmbhava, and Aṇa.

analyzed: tatra ādyānām mata viśeṣam darśayati tasyāḥ iti
translated: There, he shows the special opinion of the first ones:

analyzed: tasyāḥ sadāśiva ādyāḥ ca jāyante deva mānuṣāḥ
translated: From her are born Sadāśiva and others, gods and humans.

analyzed: bhūta bhautikam api etat iti
translated: And this is the elemental and the derived.

analyzed: tasyāḥ kevalāyāḥ eva śakteḥ
translated: Of that very power alone.

analyzed: sadāśiva grahaṇena mata antarāt bhedaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: By mentioning Sadasiva, the difference from other doctrines is shown.

analyzed: tatra sadāśivasya śaktitaḥ janma an abhyupagamāt
translated: There, because the birth of Sadasiva is not accepted as being from power.

analyzed: evam upanyastam mahāvāma matam tāvat ayuktam iti āha tat iti
translated: Thus, the Mahavama doctrine, which has been presented, is, for the time being, said to be incorrect.

analyzed: tat na upapadyate
translated: That is not logically possible.

analyzed: nirantara upanyastam mahā vāma matam tat iti parāmṛśati
translated: The Mahavama doctrine, which has been presented continuously, is referred to by the word that.

analyzed: kutas iti ākāṅkṣāyām sūtram utpatti asambhavāt iti
translated: When there is a desire to know the reason, the aphorism is stated: Because of the impossibility of origination.

analyzed: tat vayākhyātum tāvat vayāptim upapādayati dṛṣṭā iti
translated: In order to explain that, he first establishes the pervasion by saying It is seen.

original: dṛṣṭā pumbhyaḥ sadā sṛṣṭiḥ strīpumbhyo vā viśeṣataḥ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭā pumbhyaḥ sadā sṛṣṭiḥ strī pumbhyaḥ vā viśeṣataḥ
translated: The creation is always seen from males, or especially from females and males.

analyzed: kevalābhyaḥ nahi strībhyaḥ tatas utpatti asambhavāt
translated: Not from females alone, because of the impossibility of origination.

analyzed: na arcyam mahā vāma matam
translated: The Mahavama doctrine is not to be worshipped.

analyzed: atra sṛṣṭi śabdena āpattyā utpattiḥ vivakṣitā na sṛṣṭi mātram
translated: Here, by the word creation, birth by transformation is intended, not just creation.

analyzed: tasya kevalābhyaḥ pi strībhyaḥ darśanāt
translated: Because that is seen even from females alone.

analyzed: sadā iti vyabhicāra abhāvam sūcayati
translated: Always indicates the absence of contradiction.

analyzed: vā śabdaḥ tuśabda arthaḥ
translated: The word or has the meaning of but.

analyzed: viśeṣataḥ prācuryeṇa
translated: Especially means predominantly.

original: keṣāñcideva hi droṇādīnāṃ sṛṣṭiḥ kevalebhyaḥ puruṣebhyo dṛṣṭā /
analyzed: keṣāñcid eva hi droṇa ādīnām sṛṣṭiḥ kevalebhyaḥ puruṣebhyaḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: The creation of only some, like Drona and others, is seen to be from mere males.

analyzed: nanu a catur ādi sūtreṇa strīpuṃsebhyaḥ iti bhavitavyam
translated: But in the sutra beginning with acatura, it should be from women and men.

analyzed: strī puṃbhyaḥ iti katham
translated: How is it from women and men?

analyzed: samāsa antaḥ vidhiḥ anityaḥ
translated: The ending of a compound is optional.

analyzed: iti bhaviṣyati
translated: It will be so.

analyzed: yat vā dvandvāt paraḥ samāsa antaḥ sau nipātitaḥ
translated: Or, that ending of a compound after a dvandva is prescribed.

original: atra tu strībhiḥ sahitāḥ pumāṃsaḥ strīmumāṃsaste
analyzed: atra tu strībhiḥ sahitāḥ pumāṃsaḥ strīm umāṃsaḥ te
translated: But here, the men together with women are the women and men.

original: tebhya iti na dvandva iti na bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: tebhyaḥ iti na dvandve iti na bhaviṣyati
translated: From them, it will not be a dvandva.🔽From mere women, devoid of the grace of men,

analyzed: kevalābhyaḥ puruṣa anugraha hīnābhyaḥ  ṣa an anugṛhītābhyaḥ
translated: not favored by men.

original: tataḥ kimityataḥ sūtraṃ vyākhyāti tata iti //
analyzed: tatas kim iti atas sūtram vyākhyāti tatas iti
translated: What then? Therefore, the sutra is explained as tataḥ (from that).

analyzed: yatas evam vyāptiḥ yatas ca prakṛtā atiḥ kevalā
translated: Since the pervasion is thus, and since the grace of mere women is not the cause,

analyzed: śiva ādīnām tatas janma aṅgīkārāt
translated: because the birth of Śiva and others is accepted from that.

analyzed: tatas kāraṇāt tatas śakteḥ apatya utpatti asambhavāt iti arthaḥ
translated: From that cause, from the impossibility of the birth of a child from that Śakti, this is the meaning.

analyzed: ayam atra prayogaḥ
translated: Here is the argument:

analyzed: ādi kālīna āpattyā utpattiḥ na kevala strī kṛta akartṛkā
translated: The birth of a child in primordial times is not only done by women, it is not done by women alone,

analyzed: apatya utpatti tvāt
translated: because it is the birth of a child.

analyzed: yā āpattyā utpattiḥ sā na kevala strī kartṛkā
translated: That birth of a child is not done by women alone,

analyzed: yathā sampratipannā
translated: like what is commonly accepted.

original: sā hi kadācit puruṣamātrātkvacitpuruṣānugṛhītābhyaḥ strībhyo dṛṣṭā /
analyzed: sā hi kadācid puruṣa mātrāt kvacid puruṣa anugṛhītābhyaḥ strībhyaḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: For it is sometimes seen in men alone, and sometimes in women favored by men.

original: na punaḥ kvāpi kevalābhyaḥ strībhyo dṛṣṭā /
analyzed: na punar kvāpi kevalābhyaḥ strībhyaḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: But it is never seen in women alone anywhere.

analyzed: yena ukta vyāpteḥ vyabhicāraḥ syāt iti
translated: So there would be no invalidation of the established pervasion.

analyzed: yat vā śaktiḥ na āpatti aprasavitrī kevala strī tvāt sampratipanna kevala strī vat
translated: Or, potency is not the cause of conception, because of being mere womanhood, like a woman agreed upon as mere.

original: atra kevalābhyo na hi strībhya ityanvayakathanaṃ dṛṣṭetyādi tadvayabhicāraparihārārthamiti jñātavyam /🔽yadi vā kevalastrītvānnāpatyaprasavitrī cecchaktiḥ syāttadā kevalapulātpu
analyzed: atra kevalābhyaḥ na hi strībhyaḥ iti anvaya kathanam dṛṣṭa ityādi tad vayabhicāra parihāra artham iti jñātavyam  yadi vā kevala strī tvāt na apatya prasavitrī ced śaktiḥ syāt tadā kevala pulāt pu
translated: Here, it should be understood that the statement not from women alone and so on is for the sake of avoiding invalidation by the example.

original: ruṣatvāt puruṣottamo 'pi tathā na syādityākṣepamapākartuṃ prāgeva dṛṣṭetyādyuktam /
analyzed: ruṣa tvāt tathā na syāt iti ākṣepam apākartum prāk eva dṛṣṭā ityādi uktam
translated: Or, if potency were not the cause of conception because of being mere womanhood, then even the best of men would not be so because of mere manhood. To remove this objection, seen before and so on was stated earlier.

original: asiddhaṃ ca kevalatvaṃ tasya lakṣmīpaterityāśayena strīpuṃbhya ityuktam /
analyzed: asiddham ca kevala tvam tasya lakṣmīpateḥ iti āśayena strī puṃbhyaḥ iti uktam
translated: And the mere nature of that lord of Lakshmi is unestablished. With this idea, from women and men is stated.

analyzed: kevalābhyaḥ iti tu vyāpti upapādakam
translated: From mere is for establishing the pervasion.

analyzed: athavā yad nirākṛtau viśeṣasya bhāvāt
translated: Or, because a particular is present when it is negated.

original: ityanenāsya doṣasyāsādhāraṇatvamuktam tadupapādanāya dṛṣṭetyādyupanyāsaḥ / /🔽idānīmadhikāśaṅkayā matāntaramutthāpayati vāmairiti //
analyzed: iti anena asya doṣasya asādhāraṇa tvam uktam tad upapādanāya dṛṣṭa ityādi upanyāsaḥ  idānīm adhika āśaṅkayā mata antaram utthāpayati vāmaiḥ iti
translated: By this, its being a fault peculiar to the opponent is stated. For the establishment of that, the statement beginning with seen is made.

analyzed: vāmaiḥ anyat udīryate
translated: Now, with an additional doubt, he raises another view with Vāma.🔽The Vāmas say something else...

analyzed: madhya vāmaiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is the middle Vāmas.

analyzed: anyat mahāvāmasiddhāntāt
translated: Other than the doctrine of the Mahāvāmas.

analyzed: kim tat iti atas āha śiva iti
translated: What is that? Therefore he says Śiva etc.

analyzed: śiva upasarjanā śaktiḥ sasarja idam samantataḥ
translated: Śakti, with Śiva as a subordinate factor, created this everywhere...

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus...

analyzed: śivaḥ upasarjanam yasyāḥ sā śivopasarjanā
translated: She who has Śiva as a subordinate factor is Śivopa-sarjanā.

original: idamityasyaiva vyākhyānaṃ samantato deśe kāle ca vartamānaṃ kāryamiti /
analyzed: idam iti asya eva vyākhyānam samantataḥ deśe kāle ca vartamānam kāryam iti
translated: This is the explanation of this. It means the effect that exists in space and time everywhere.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: na utpatti asambhavaḥ smad mate sti  asmābhiḥ śiva sahitāyāḥ śakteḥ viśva prasabha
translated: The impossibility of origination does not exist in our view.

analyzed: vasya aṅgīkṛta tvāt
translated: Because we accept Śakti, along with Śiva, as the cause of the creation of the universe.

analyzed: na ca evam te
translated: And thus,

analyzed: dvayoḥ sarva utkṛṣṭa tvam viruddham āpadyate
translated: the contradiction of the highest excellence of both does not arise.

analyzed: śivasya śaktim pati upasarjana tva aṅgīkārāt iti  etat pratiṣedhati tat ca iti
translated: Because Śiva is accepted as having Śakti as a subordinate factor.🔽This is refuted by That etc.🔽And that is reasonable, not...

analyzed: tat ca upapannam na
translated: And that is not reasonable. . . .🔽. . . .

analyzed: atra api utpatti asambhavasya aparihārāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that even here, the impossibility of origination is not avoided.

analyzed: na ca kartuḥ karaṇam  /
translated: And the instrument is not of the agent.

analyzed: śivasya akaraṇa tvataḥ  a deha tvāt
translated: Because Śiva is not an instrument.🔽Because he is bodiless.

analyzed: akaraṇa tvataḥ iti asya eva sva padasya varṇanam adeha tvāt iti
translated: The explanation of the very same word because he is not an instrument is because he is bodiless.

analyzed: yat vā akaraṇa tvataḥ jñāna ādi kāraṇa abhāvāt iti arthaḥ  tat eva katham ityatas karaṇa tvataḥ nirindriya tvāt iti uktam
translated: Or the meaning is: because there is no cause of knowledge etc.🔽That itself is said how? Therefore it is said because he is not an instrument, because he is without senses.

analyzed: tat api kutas iti atas uktam adeha tvāt iti
translated: That too is said how? Therefore it is said because he is bodiless.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

analyzed: dehavatā hi śivena apatya utpattau śakteḥ sācivyam ācaraṇīyam
translated: For Śiva who has a body, he should perform the office of assisting Śakti in the production of offspring.

analyzed: na videhena  tasya pravi
translated: Not for one without a body.

analyzed: līna vat indriya ādi vijñāna ādi vikalasya tad anupapatteḥ
translated: Because that is not possible for him, who is like one merged, deficient in the consciousness of senses etc.

analyzed: na ca śiva deha utpattau kevalāyāḥ śakteḥ śaktiḥ asti
translated: And mere Śakti does not have the power to produce Śiva's body.

analyzed: prāk ukta doṣāt
translated: Because of the previously stated fault.

analyzed: anyathā atra api tathā upapattau śiva aṅgīkāra vaiyarthya āpatteḥ ca
translated: Otherwise, if it were possible here too in that way, it would follow that the acceptance of Śiva is pointless.

analyzed: na ca śiva sahitāyāḥ
translated: And not of Śakti together with Śiva.

analyzed: videhasya sāhāyya karaṇa anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for one without a body to assist.

analyzed: atas aṅgīkṛtasya api śivasya ajāgala stanāyita tvena atra api utpatti asambhavaḥ eva iti  mata antaram utthāpayati api hi iti
translated: Therefore, even if Śiva is accepted, due to being like the barren woman's son, there is still impossibility of origination here.🔽He raises another view, saying Moreover, others may say that God is omniscient...

analyzed: api hi anye brūyuḥ sarvajñam īśvaram  aṇu vāmā
translated: Moreover, others may say that God is omniscient, etc.

analyzed: anye pi iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that others also.

analyzed: tān eva viśeṣa nāmnā āha aṇu vāmāḥ iti
translated: He mentions those very [views] by their specific names, saying the Atomists, the Followers of the Left-handed Goddess, etc.

original: asya matasya loke pracuratāṃ sūcayituṃ hiśabdaḥ /
analyzed: asya matasya loke pracura tām sūcayitum hi śabdaḥ
translated: The word indeed is used to indicate the abundance of this view in the world.

analyzed: sarvajñam iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: Omniscient is a mere illustration.

analyzed: jagat sṛṣṭayā ādi upayukta sakala kāraṇa upetam
translated: [He is] endowed with all the causes necessary for the creation of the world, etc.

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is being said:

analyzed: śiva sahitā śaktiḥ jagat jananī iti abhyupacchataḥ mama nā ukta doṣaḥ
translated: For me who accepts that Śakti, along with Śiva, is the mother of the world, the stated fault does not arise.

analyzed: līlā vigraha grahaṇena śakti sāhāyya karaṇasya a sambhogasya
translated: Because Śiva, being naturally omniscient, etc., does not depend on a body and senses.

analyzed: pi upapatteḥ iti  tat idam dūṣayati na tat iti
translated: And because it is possible that by taking up a playful form, [Śiva] assists Śakti, even without enjoyment.🔽He refutes this, saying That is not proper...

analyzed: na tat yuktam
translated: That is not proper...

original: kuta ityatra sūtram oṃ vijñānādibhāve vā tadapratiṣedhaḥ oṃ //🔽iti /
analyzed: kutas iti atra sūtram om vijñāna ādi bhāve vā tad apratiṣedhaḥ om  iti
translated: Why? On this point, the aphorism is: Or, in the state of consciousness, etc., there is no prohibition of that.

analyzed: tasya arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of that [aphorism].

original: śivasya vijñānādibhāve aṅgīkṛte tasya matasya pratiṣedho na kriyata iti /
analyzed: śivasya vijñāna ādi bhāve aṅgīkṛte tasya matasya pratiṣedhaḥ na kriyate iti
translated: When the existence of Śiva as consciousness etc. is accepted, the denial of that view is not made.

analyzed: nanu idam matam anumānam na vā
translated: But is this view an inference or not?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: ukta artha viruddha tvāt
translated: Because it contradicts the stated meaning.

analyzed: na tat yuktam iti asya ca ayogāt
translated: And because this is not appropriate.

analyzed: dvitīye katham tad apratiṣedhaḥ iti uktam
translated: In the second case, how is that non-denial stated?

original: kathaṃ ca na tadyuktamityatrāsya hetutvamityatastadapratiṣedha iti niveśayitumutsūtraṃ tāvaddhetumāha īśeti //
analyzed: katham ca na tat yuktam iti atra asya hetutvam iti atas tad apratiṣedhaḥ iti niveśayitum utsūtram tāvat hetum āha īśa iti
translated: And how is this the reason here in that is not appropriate? Therefore, in order to insert that non-denial, he first gives the reason in the sutra, saying Īśa etc.

analyzed: vijñāna ādi bhāve vā tad apratiṣedhaḥ
translated: Or, in the existence of consciousness etc., that non-denial is

analyzed: īśa vāda praveśanāt
translated: because of the entry into the doctrine of Īśa.

analyzed: śaiva mata praveśa āpatteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is because of the consequence of entering the Śaiva doctrine.

analyzed: nanu śaivāḥ sārvajña ādi guṇa upetam śivam ekam eva abhyupayanti
translated: But the Śaivas accept only one Śiva endowed with the qualities of omniscience etc.

analyzed: śāktāḥ tu śivam śaktim ca iti asti mahān siddhānta bhedaḥ
translated: But the Śāktas accept both Śiva and Śakti. This is a great difference in the final doctrines.

original: tatkathaṃ śāktānāṃ śaivamatānupraveśa ityata āpāditadoṣo 'yamityāśayavānāha sārvajñādīti //🔽sārvajñyādiguṇairyuktaṃ gurukalpanayā dvayam // / / //
analyzed: tat katham śāktānām śaiva mata anupraveśaḥ iti atas āpādita doṣaḥ yam iti āśayavān āha sārvajña ādi iti  sārvajñya ādi guṇaiḥ yuktam guru kalpanayā dvayam
translated: How then is there entry into the Śaiva doctrine for the Śāktas? With this intention, he says sarvajñya etc., indicating the fault that has been deduced.🔽The two endowed with the qualities of omniscience etc. are not appropriate

analyzed: na yujyate
translated: to be imagined as the teacher.

analyzed: satyam śāktaiḥ sārvajña ādi guṇaiḥ yuktam śiva śakti ākhyam dvayam abhyupagatam iti
translated: It is true that the Śaivas accept two things endowed with the qualities of omniscience and so on, namely Śiva and Śakti.

analyzed: tat tu na yujyate
translated: But that is not correct.

analyzed: kalpanā gauravāt
translated: Because of the great burden of assumptions.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: To explain:

analyzed: na tāvat sārvajña ādi upetam pratyakṣeṇa siddham
translated: First, that which is endowed with omniscience and so on is not established by perception.

analyzed: para cittavṛttīnām param prati atīndriya tvāt
translated: Because the operations of another's mind are imperceptible to another.

analyzed: na api āgamena
translated: Nor is it by scripture.

analyzed: śakta āgamasya prāmāṇya sandehāt
translated: Because the authority of the Śaiva scriptures is doubted.

analyzed: apauruṣeya āgamasya pareṇa prāmāṇya an ādaraṇāt
translated: Because the opponent does not accept the authority of the non-human scriptures.

analyzed: ādaraṇe vā tatas eva sva mata hāneḥ
translated: Or if he does accept it, then he would lose his own position on that basis alone.

analyzed: tatas prapañca racanā anupapattyā eva tathāvidham vastu kalpanīyam
translated: Therefore, such a thing must be assumed only because of the impossibility of the creation of the world.

original: ekenaiva sārvajñādimatā sarvaṃ nirvahatyeva /🔽tathāca vṛthā tathābhūtavastu
analyzed: ekena eva sārvajña ādimatā sarvam nirvahati eva  tathā ca vṛthā tathābhūta vastu
translated: Everything is accomplished by only one who is omniscient and so on.

original: dvayakalpane kalpanāgauravameva /🔽ata ekameva tādṛśaṃ vastvaṅgīkāryamiti /🔽tataḥ kimityata āha tata iti /
analyzed: dvaya kalpane kalpanā gauravam eva  atas ekam eva tādṛśam vastu aṅgīkāryam iti  tatas kim iti atas āha tatas iti
translated: And so, the assumption of two such things is pointless.🔽Therefore, only one such thing should be accepted.

analyzed: tatas tu īśaḥ ekaḥ eva prayojakaḥ
translated: What follows from that? Therefore, he says: Therefore, only one Lord is the employer...🔽...

original: uktahetorekasyaiva sārvajñādimato 'ṅgīkāryatve kevalaśakteraṅgīkṛtāvutpattyasambhavaprasaṅgādīśa eva sārvajñādyupetaḥ prapañcaracanāyāḥ prayojakaḥ
analyzed: ukta hetoḥ ekasya eva sārvajña ādimataḥ ṅgīkārya tve kevala śakteḥ aṅgīkṛtau utpatti asambhava prasaṅgāt īśaḥ eva sārvajña ādi upetaḥ prapañca racanāyāḥ prayojakaḥ  /
translated: For the above reason, if only one omniscient being is to be accepted, then in the acceptance of mere power, the absurdity of non-production would arise, and the Lord alone, endowed with omniscience, would be the cause of the creation of the world.

analyzed: śāktaiḥ aṅgīkartavyaḥ syāt
translated: He would have to be accepted by the Shaktas.

analyzed: evam ca katham na śaiva mata praveśaḥ śākta matasya iti
translated: And in this way, how can the Shakta doctrine not be subsumed within the Shaiva doctrine?

analyzed: kim atas yadi evam
translated: What follows from this, if this is so?

analyzed: śāktasya apasiddhāntena parājayaḥ syāt iti ced satyam
translated: If it is argued that the Shakta doctrine would be defeated by the contradiction of its own tenets, that is true.

analyzed: tāvatā api bhagavat siddhānta anavakṷptiḥ eva
translated: But even so, there would be no establishment of the doctrine of the Lord.

original: śaivamatasyāpi bhavatsiddhāntavirodhitvena nirākatarvyatvādityatastadapratiṣedha iti sūtrāṃśaṃ sopapattikaṃ niveśayati ukteti //
analyzed: śaiva matasya api bhavat siddhānta virodhi tvena nirākatarvya tvāt iti atas tad apratiṣedhaḥ iti sūtra aṃśam sopapattikam niveśayati uktā iti
translated: Because the Shaiva doctrine also would have to be refuted as being contradictory to your doctrine. Therefore, the part of the sutra it is not to be refuted is to be inserted along with the reasoning.

analyzed: ukta doṣaḥ ca tad pakṣaḥ iti nā evā atra dūṣyate
translated: And the fault stated in that doctrine is not to be refuted here at all.

original: yataḥ śaivapakṣo nirantarātītādhikaraṇa evoktadoṣo 'to 'tra na punardūṣyate punaruktidoṣabhayāditi /
analyzed: yatas śaiva pakṣaḥ nirantara atīta adhikaraṇaḥ na punar dūṣyate punarukti doṣa bhayāt iti
translated: Because the fault stated in the Shaiva doctrine in the immediately preceding section, therefore it is not refuted again here, out of fear of the fault of repetition.

original: evaṃ pratyekamapākṛtāni trīṇyapi matāni sādhāraṇadūṣaṇena nirākartuṃ sūtram /
analyzed: evam pratyekam apākṛtāni trīṇi api matāni sādhāraṇa dūṣaṇena nirākartum sūtram
translated: In this way, having refuted each of the three doctrines individually, in order to refute them with a general criticism, the sutra is:

analyzed: om vipratiṣedhāt ca om iti
translated: Om. And because of the contradiction. Om.

analyzed: tat vyācaṣṭe śruti iti
translated: He explains that with the scriptures etc.

analyzed: vipratiṣedhāt ca
translated: And because of the contradiction.

analyzed: śruti smṛti itihāsānām sāmastyena virodhataḥ
translated: Because of the contradiction of the scriptures, Smritis and Itihasas as a whole,

analyzed: satām jugupsita tvāt ca nā aṅgīkāryam hi tat matam
translated: and because it is despised by the good, that view should not be accepted.

analyzed: satām madhye jugupsita tvāt goptum iṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because it is desired to be concealed by the good.

analyzed: yat vā kartṛ karmaṇoḥ kṛti iti kartari ṣaṣṭhī  sadbhiḥ nindita tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the genitive case in of the doer and the object is in the sense of the doer.🔽The meaning is because it is condemned by the good.

analyzed: hi śabdena śruti ādīnām prasiddha tām dyotayati
translated: The word hi (in fact) indicates the well-known nature of the scriptures etc.

analyzed: kecid imām catur sūtrīm bhāgavata mata nirākaraṇa para tayā vyācakṣate
translated: Some explain this set of four sutras as being aimed at refuting the doctrine of the Bhagavata.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus it is.

original: pāñcarātrikā vāsudevātsaṅkarṣaṇo nāma jīvo jāyate saṅkarṣaṇātpradyumnasaṃjñakaṃ mano jāyate /
analyzed: pāñcarātrikāḥ vāsudevāt saṅkarṣaṇaḥ nāma jīvaḥ jāyate saṅkarṣaṇāt pradyumna saṃjñakam manaḥ jāyate
translated: The Pancharatrika (followers of the Pancharatra) say that from Vasudeva, the individual soul named Samkarshana is born, from Samkarshana, the mind called Pradyumna is born,

analyzed: pradyumnāt aniruddha saṃjñakaḥ haṅkāraḥ jāyate iti prakriyām āhuḥ
translated: and from Pradyumna, the ego called Aniruddha is born. This is their theory.

analyzed: tatra sūtram utpatti asambhavāt iti
translated: Regarding that, the sutra is because of the impossibility of origination.

original: vāsudevātsaṅkarṣaṇo nāma jīvo jāyata iti tāvadayuktam /
analyzed: vāsudevāt saṅkarṣaṇaḥ nāma jīvaḥ jāyate iti tāvat ayuktam
translated: It is not proper to say that from Vasudeva, the individual soul named Samkarshana is born.

analyzed: jīvabhyaḥ utpatti asambhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible for the individual soul to originate.

analyzed: utpattimataḥ hi jīvasya anitya tva ādayaḥ doṣāḥ prasajyeran
translated: For if the individual soul, which is produced, were noneternal, many faults would follow.

analyzed: tatas ca nā eva asya bhagavat prāptiḥ mokṣaḥ syāt  na jāyatena
