analyzed: tad dharme sārvajña ādi dharma vaiśiṣyayā ākāre katham na mānam bhavet
translated: How can it not be a means of knowing its attributes such as omniscience?

analyzed: ayam abhisandhiḥ
translated: This is the intention.

original: śuktirajatādijñānaṃ hīdamaṃśe pramāṇaṃ rajatavaiśiṣyayāṃśe tvapramāṇamiti yuktam /
analyzed: śukti rajata ādi jñānam hi idam aṃśe pramāṇam rajata vaiśiṣyayā aṃśe tu apramāṇam iti yuktam
translated: It is proper that the cognition of silver in a shell is a means of valid knowledge regarding the part that is this, but not a means of valid knowledge regarding the part that is the qualification of silver.

analyzed: vaiśiṣyayā aṃśasya bādhaka pramāṇa viruddha tvāt
translated: Because the part that is the qualification is contradicted by the means of valid knowledge that negates it.

analyzed: idam ākārasya uttaratra api anuvṛtteḥ
translated: Because the form of this continues even later.

original: idaṃ na rajatamiti bādhakajñānamutpadyate na punarnedaṃ rajataṃ ceti /
analyzed: idam na rajatam iti bādhaka jñānam utpadyate na punar na idam rajatam ca iti
translated: The negating cognition arises as this is not silver, not as this is not silver.

analyzed: na ca ayam atra nyāyaḥ
translated: And this is not the right principle here.

analyzed: sva rūpa vat viśiṣya aṃśe pi bādhaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no negation even regarding the part that is the qualification, just as regarding the nature.

analyzed: na ca abheda anumāna āgamau bādhakau
translated: And the inference and scripture that prove non-difference are not negating.

analyzed: anyonya āśraya tvāt
translated: Because of mutual dependence.

original: bādhitatvena śruteraprāmāṇye satyupajīvyavirodharahitasyānumānāderbādhakatvaṃ sati ca tasmiṃstadvirodhinyāḥ śruteraprāmāṇyamiti /
analyzed: bādhita tvena śruteḥ aprāmāṇye sati upajīvya virodha rahitasya anumāna ādeḥ bādhaka tvam sati ca tasmin tad virodhinyāḥ śruteḥ aprāmāṇyam iti
translated: When the scripture is invalidated as contradicted by what is negated, then the inference etc. which are devoid of contradiction by what is experienced are negating, and when that exists, the scripture which is contradicted by that is invalid.

analyzed: katham ca anumāna ādeḥ śruti bādhaka tvam
translated: And how can inference, etc., contradict the Veda?

analyzed: na tāvat virodhi tva mātreṇa
translated: Not merely by contradiction.

analyzed: vaiparītyasya api suvaca tvāt
translated: Because the opposite can also be easily stated.

original: nāpi virodhyuttarajñānatvena śuktirūpyamiti jñānānantaraṃ rajatamidamiti jñānasya darśanāt /
analyzed: nā api virodhi uttara jñāna tvena śukti rūpyam iti jñāna anantaram rajatam idam iti jñānasya darśanāt
translated: Nor by being the subsequent cognition that contradicts, because the cognition this is silver is seen after the cognition this is mother-of-pearl.

analyzed: anuttara virodhi jñānam bādhakam idam tu sottaram iti api na
translated: Nor can it be said that the contradicting cognition that does not have a subsequent [cognition] is the contradictor, but this [cognition] has a subsequent [cognition].

analyzed: kadācid anuttarasya api rajata jñānasya sambhavāt
translated: Because the non-subsequent cognition of silver is sometimes possible.

original: kintu yāvacchakti parīkṣitamuttaraṃ virodhyaparīkṣitasya pūrvasya bādhakaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: kintu yāvacchakti parīkṣitam uttaram virodhya parīkṣitasya pūrvasya bādhakam bhavati
translated: But the subsequent [cognition] that is examined to the best of one's ability is the contradictor of the prior [cognition] that is unexamined and contradicted.

analyzed: na ca evam atra asti iti
translated: And this is not so in this case.

original: na kevalaṃ bādhakābhāvasāmyādayaṃ vibhāgo na yuktaḥ kiṃ tarhītyata āha eketi //
analyzed: na kevalam bādhaka abhāva sāmyāt ayam vibhāgaḥ na yuktaḥ kim tarhi iti atas āha eka iti
translated: And not only is this distinction not proper due to the equality of the absence of contradictors, but what else? To this he says one etc.

analyzed: eka vijñāna vijñaptyāḥ dvayam mānam bhaviṣyati
translated: By the manifestation of one cognition, both [means of valid knowledge] will be means of valid knowledge.

original: na cedekamamānaṃ tad dvayamapyatra no bhavet // / / //
analyzed: na ced ekam amānam tat dvayam api atra no bhavet
translated: If one is not a means of valid knowledge, then both will not be here.

analyzed: ekavidham eva idam yaḥ sarvajñaḥ ityādi śruti janitam vijñānam
translated: This is indeed of one kind, the cognition produced by the Vedic statement He who is omniscient etc.

original: na punaḥ śuktirajatādijñānamiva svarūpamātre pramāṇaṃ viśiṣyākāre tvapramāṇamityanekavidhamityevaṃ🔽parīkṣāsahakṛtasākṣirūpavijñaptyāpīdaṃ jñānadvayaṃ dharmadharmidvayagarbhaṃ viśiṣyākāraṃ
analyzed: na punar śukti rajata ādi jñānam iva svarūpa mātre pramāṇam viśiṣya ākāre tu apramāṇam iti anekavidham iti evam  parīkṣā sahakṛta sākṣi rūpa vijñaptyā api idam jñāna dvayam dharma dharmi dvaya garbham viśiṣya ākāram
translated: But it is not so that, like the cognition of silver in a shell, it is a valid cognition only with regard to the form of its own nature, but with regard to the qualified form it is not a valid cognition. Thus,

analyzed: prati api mānam bhavati eva
translated: even by the cognition in the form of the witness, which is assisted by examination, this pair of cognitions is a valid cognition even with regard to the qualified form containing the pair of the property and the property-possessor.

analyzed: vakṣyate ca ayam arthaḥ prapañcena
translated: And this matter will be stated elaborately.

analyzed: yat vā dvayam pratīti dvayam sva rūpavat dharme pi iti yojyam
translated: Or, the pair should be construed as the pair of cognitions with regard to the property as well as the form of its own nature.

original: athavā yaḥ sarvajña ityādiśruterbrahmasvarūpamātre prāmāṇyamaprāmāṇyaṃ tu sārvajñādiviśiṣyākāra iti vadataḥ ko 'bhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: athavā yaḥ sarvajñaḥ ityādi śruteḥ brahma svarūpa mātre prāmāṇyam aprāmāṇyam tu sārvajña ādi viśiṣya ākāre iti vadataḥ kaḥ bhiprāyaḥ
translated: Or, what is the intention of one who says that the cognition of the form He who is omniscient... is a valid cognition only with regard to the mere nature of Brahman, but with regard to the qualified form such as omniscience it is not a valid cognition?

original: kiṃ śuktirajatādijñānamivaikamevedaṃ jñānaṃ viṣayabhedena pramāṇamapramāṇaṃ ceti /
analyzed: kim śukti rajata ādi jñānam iva ekam eva idam jñānam viṣaya bhedena pramāṇam apramāṇam ca iti
translated: Is it that, like the cognition of silver in a shell, this cognition is a valid cognition as well as not a valid cognition with regard to the difference of objects?

analyzed: kiṃvā jñāna dvayam etat tatra ekam pramāṇam aparam ca apramāṇam iti
translated: Or, is this a pair of cognitions, one of which is a valid cognition and the other is not a valid cognition?

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati yat iti
translated: He refutes the first [view] with What...

analyzed: pūrvaḥ eva abhiprāyaḥ
translated: [The intention is] the same as before.

analyzed: dvitīyam nirākaroti eka iti
translated: He refutes the second [view] with One...

original: ekamevedaṃ vijñānamiti sākṣivijñaptyā nānekatvaṃ kalpyamiti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: ekam eva idam vijñānam iti sākṣi vijñaptyā na aneka tvam kalpyam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is: the non-duality should not be imagined by the cognition of the witness that this is only one cognition.

analyzed: anyathā stambhaḥ yam ityādau api jñāna dvaya kalpanā āpattiḥ
translated: Otherwise, even in the case of 'this is a pillar', the postulation of two cognitions would be a consequence.

analyzed: tathā ca sāmānādhikaraṇyam na kena api jñāyeta
translated: And thus, the co-reference would not be known by anyone.

original: astu vedaṃ jñānadvayaṃ tathāpi naikasyāprāmāṇyaṃ vaktuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: astu vā idam jñāna dvayam tathā api nā ekasya aprāmāṇyam vaktum śakyate
translated: Or let there be these two cognitions, even then the non-authoritativeness of one cannot be said.

analyzed: svarūpa jñānasya iva dharma jñānasya api abādhita tvāt iti āha dvayam iti
translated: Because the knowledge of the form, like the knowledge of dharma, is not contradicted. Thus he says 'two' etc.

analyzed: jñāna dvayam api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: even two cognitions.

analyzed: dharma jñānam api iti ca
translated: And the knowledge of dharma.

analyzed: vaktavye dvayam iti vacanam nyāya sāmya sūcana artham
translated: When it should be said, the statement 'two' is for the purpose of indicating the similarity of reasoning.

original: evaṃ bādhābhāvaparīkṣitatvasāmye 'pi śrautamekaṃ jñānadvayaṃ vāṅgīkṛtyāṃśataḥ prāmāṇyaprāmāṇye vadato 'tiprasaṅgamāha nacediti //
analyzed: evam bādhā abhāva parīkṣita tva sāmye śrautam ekam jñāna dvayam vā aṅgīkṛtya aṃśataḥ prāmāṇya prāmāṇye vadataḥ tiprasaṅgam āha na ced iti
translated: Thus, even when there is similarity in the examination of the absence of contradiction, he who accepts the two cognitions as heard and speaks of partial authoritativeness and non-authoritativeness, he incurs the following absurdity. He says 'if not' etc.

original: tacchrautaṃ jñānaṃ dvayaṃ viśiṣyākāraṃ prati pramāṇaṃ na cettadātra viṣaye ekaṃ svarūpāṃśaṃ pratyapi pramāṇaṃ na bhavet /
analyzed: tat śrautam jñānam dvayam viśiṣya ākāram prati pramāṇam na ced tadā atra viṣaye ekam svarūpa aṃśam prati api pramāṇam na bhavet
translated: If that heard cognition, or the two cognitions, are not authoritative with regard to the specific form, then in that case, with regard to this object, it would not be authoritative even with regard to the single part of the form.

analyzed: aviśeṣāt
translated: Because there is no distinction.

analyzed: tathā ca punar anāśrayayoḥ anumāna āgāmayoḥ anutthānam eva
translated: And thus again, inference and verbal testimony, which have no basis, do not arise at all.

original: yadvā tadvijñānamatra viṣaye ekaṃ viśiṣyākāraṃ prati pramāṇaṃ cettadā dvayaṃ pratyapi no bhavet /
analyzed: yat vā tat vijñānam atra viṣaye ekam viśiṣya ākāram prati pramāṇam ced tadā dvayam prati api no bhavet
translated: Or, if that cognition is a means of valid knowledge with regard to a particular form in this object, then it would not be so with regard to the two [forms].

analyzed: viśiṣya ākāravat sva rūpe pramāṇam na bhavet
translated: It would not be a means of valid knowledge even with regard to its own form, which has a particular form.

analyzed: aviśeṣāt iti yāvat
translated: Because there is no difference, that is the meaning.

original: jñānadvayāṅgīkāravāde tvatra jñānadvaye tadviśiṣyaviṣayaṃ jñānaṃ pramāṇaṃ na cettarhi jñānadvayamapi pramāṇaṃ na bhavet /
analyzed: jñāna dvaya aṅgīkāra vāde tu atra jñāna dvaye tad viśiṣya viṣayam jñānam pramāṇam na ced tarhi jñāna dvayam api pramāṇam na bhavet
translated: But in the doctrine of accepting two cognitions, if that cognition with a particular object is not a means of valid knowledge in these two cognitions, then even the two cognitions would not be a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: viśiṣya jñānam iva svarūpa jñānam api apramāṇam syāt aviśeṣāt iti
translated: Just as the particular cognition, the cognition of the form would also be a means of valid knowledge because there is no difference.

original: evamabhedānumānāgamau prati yaḥ sarvajña iti śruterniṣedhyasamarpakatvenopajīvyatvaṃ pratyuktam /
analyzed: evam abheda anumāna āgamau prati yaḥ sarvajñaḥ iti śruteḥ niṣedhya samarpaka tvena upajīvya tvam pratyuktam
translated: Thus, the objection that the Vedic text He who is omniscient is to be relied upon as presenting what is to be negated in the case of the inference and verbal testimony of non-difference is answered.

analyzed: tathā api na anumāna āgamayoḥ upajīvya pramāṇa virodhaḥ sti
translated: Nevertheless, there is no contradiction with the means of valid knowledge that is to be relied upon in the case of inference and verbal testimony.

analyzed: yaḥ sarvajñaḥ ityādi śruti siddha brahma sva rūpa mātra āśrayaṇena pravṛtta tvāt
translated: Because they operate by relying only on the form of Brahman established by the Vedic text beginning with He who is omniscient, etc.

analyzed: nahi sārvajña ādi viśiṣya ākāram avalambya anumāna ādinā pravartitavyam iti atra niyāmakam asti
translated: For there is no rule that one should proceed by inference etc. taking as the object an aspect qualified by omniscience etc.

analyzed: tatas viruddha ākārasya anupayogi tayā anupajīvanāt upajīvyasya ca svarūpa mātrasya avirodhi tvāt na upajīvya pramāṇa virodhaḥ
translated: Therefore, since an aspect that is contradictory is not useful and is not the basis, and since the mere form of the basis is not contradictory, there is no contradiction with the basis.

analyzed: numāna ādeḥ pramāṇa virodhaḥ tu kathañcid syāt iti āśaṅkām pariharan upasaṃharati dharmī iti
translated: But there may be contradiction with a means of valid knowledge such as inference in some way. To remove this doubt, he concludes with the word dharmin.

analyzed: dharmi grāhi virodhaḥ tu tasmāt mānasya dūṣaṇam
translated: But contradiction with what apprehends the subject is the fault of that means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ
translated: The word tu (but) has the meaning of distinction.

analyzed: pramāṇa mātra virodhāt vayavacchinatti
translated: It distinguishes from contradiction with mere means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: dharmi grāhiṇyā śrutyā virodhaḥ
translated: There is contradiction with the scripture that apprehends the subject.

analyzed: mānasya abheda pramāṇasya anumāna āgama rūpasya
translated: Of the means of valid knowledge, which is in the form of inference and scripture, and which establishes non-difference.

analyzed: ayam āśayaḥ
translated: This is the intention.

original: paramāṇavaḥ sāvayavā ityāderanumānasya vākyasya ca kathamupajīvyavirodhaḥ iti vaktavyam /
analyzed: paramāṇavaḥ sa avayavāḥ ityādeḥ anumānasya vākyasya ca katham upajīvya virodhaḥ iti vaktavyam
translated: It should be said how the inference and statement such as atoms have parts contradict the basis.

analyzed: paramāṇu tvasya anupayoginaḥ nupajīvya tvam kintu svarūpa mātrasya iti vaktum śakya tvāt
translated: Because it is possible to say that atomhood, which is not useful, is not the basis, but the mere form is.

analyzed: na evam yuktam
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: niravayatva ādinā vinā paramāṇoḥ dharmīkaraṇa asambhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible to make an atom the subject without [properties] such as being partless.

analyzed: svarūpa mātra dharmīkaraṇe siddhārtha tā āpattiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that if the subject is made to be mere intrinsic nature, the [proponent's] thesis is established,

analyzed: samam prakṛte pi
translated: [we reply:] the same [applies] to the present case as well.

original: nahi brahmāpi sārvajñādinā vinā śakyaṃ dharmīkartum /
analyzed: nahi brahma api sārvajña ādinā vinā śakyam dharmīkartum
translated: For Brahman also cannot be made the subject without [properties] such as omniscience.

analyzed: svarūpa mātra dharmīkaraṇe siddhasādhanāt
translated: Because if the subject is made to be mere intrinsic nature, the [proponent's] thesis is established.

original: āropitena sārvajñādinā vyāvṛttasya dharmīkaraṇe ko doṣaḥ /
analyzed: āropitena sārvajña ādinā vyāvṛttasya dharmīkaraṇe kaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: What is the fault in making the subject [Brahman] distinct by means of superimposed omniscience and so on?

original: yo 'yaṃ sthāṇuḥ sa puruṣa itivaditi cenna /🔽āropitena niravayavatvādinā vyāvṛttasya tatrāpi dharmīkaraṇasambhavāt /
analyzed: yaḥ yam sthāṇuḥ sa puruṣaḥ itivat iti ced na  āropitena niravayava tva ādinā vyāvṛttasya tatra api dharmīkaraṇa sambhavāt
translated: If it is argued that it is like [saying] this post is a man, no.🔽Because even there, it is possible to make the subject distinct by means of superimposed partlessness and so on.
If it is argued that the means of knowledge that apprehends partlessness and so on is ascertained to be valid,

analyzed: na āropitam iti ced
translated: and that [partlessness and so on] are not superimposed,

analyzed: tulyam atra api
translated: [we reply:] the same [applies] here as well.

analyzed: śruteḥ api prāmāṇya niścayāt
translated: Because the validity of the Veda is also ascertained.

original: tadevaṃ pramāṇasiddhena niravayavatvādinā viśiṣyasyaiva yathā dharmīkaraṇaṃ tathātrāpi
analyzed: tat evam pramāṇa siddhena niravayava tva ādinā viśiṣyasya eva yathā dharmīkaraṇam tathā atra api
translated: Thus, just as the subject is made to be qualified by partlessness and so on, which are established by means of valid knowledge, in the same way here as well,

original: sāvarjñādinā pāramārthikenaiva viśiṣyasyaiva dharmīkaraṇamityato dharmigrāhakavirodho duṣparihara iti /
analyzed: pāramārthikena eva viśiṣyasya eva dharmīkaraṇam iti atas dharmi grāhaka virodhaḥ duṣpariharaḥ iti
translated: the subject is made to be qualified by means of only the real omniscience and so on. Therefore, the contradiction with the means of knowing the subject is difficult to overcome.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be so.

analyzed: yathā khalu abheda pramāṇayoḥ anumāna āgamayoḥ upajīvya virodhāt na abheda sādhaka tvam tathā udāhṛtāyāḥ cintyaḥ ityādi bheda śruteḥ api upajīvya virodhāt na
translated: Just as inference and scripture, which are means of knowing non-difference, do not establish non-difference due to contradiction with what is relied upon, so also the statement of difference quoted, different, inconceivable, etc., does not establish difference due to contradiction with what is relied upon.

Just as inference and scripture, which are the means of knowing non-difference, cannot establish non-difference because they are contradicted by what is to be relied upon, so also the statement of difference, such as different and inconceivable, cannot establish difference because it is contradicted by what is to be relied upon.🔽It is not possible.

analyzed: tādātmya pratiyogikaḥ pratiṣedhaḥ hi bhedaḥ nāma
translated: For difference is a negation that has identity as its counter-correlate.

original: nacāprāpte tādātmye tatpratiṣedhabodhanaṃ yuktamityabhedaprāpakaṃ pramāṇamupajīvya pravṛttā bhedaśrutiḥ kathaṃ nopajīvyaviruddhā /
analyzed: na ca aprāpte tādātmye tad pratiṣedha bodhanam yuktam iti abheda prāpakam pramāṇam upajīvya pravṛttā bheda śrutiḥ katham nā upajīvya viruddhā
translated: And it is not proper to teach the negation of that when identity is not already known. Thus, how can the statement of difference, which operates relying on the means of knowing non-difference, not be contradicted by what is to be relied upon?

original: kiñca nirbhedaṃ svarūpamāśritya tasya bhedo bodhanīyaḥ /
analyzed: kiñca nirbhedam svarūpam āśritya tasya bhedaḥ bodhanīyaḥ
translated: Moreover, the difference of that [identity] must be taught relying on a nature that is without difference.

original: tathāca kathaṃ nopajīvyavirodhaḥ /🔽yathoktamabhedaṃ nollikhantī dhīrna bhedollekhanakṣamā /
analyzed: tathā ca katham na upajīvya virodhaḥ  yathā uktam abhedam nā ullikhantī dhīḥ na bheda ullekhana kṣamā
translated: And so, how is there not contradiction with what is to be relied upon?🔽As it has been said: A cognition that does not indicate non-difference is not capable of indicating difference.

analyzed: tathā ca ādye pramā sā syāt na antye sva apekṣya vaiśasāt
translated: And so, the former would be valid knowledge, not the latter, due to the destruction of its own object.

analyzed: iti atas āha na iti
translated: To this he says No.

analyzed: na upajīvyaḥ hi abhedaḥ kvacid bheda śruteḥ balāt
translated: For the non-difference is not to be relied upon here, because of the force of the statement of difference somewhere.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ yukti sūcakaḥ
translated: The word indeed indicates reasoning.

analyzed: abhedaḥ iti tad grāhakam
translated: Non-difference refers to the means of knowing it.🔽Here somewhere means

analyzed: atra kvacid iti
translated: Here, 'in some cases' means:

analyzed: dharmi tva ādau iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of being the substratum.

analyzed: tat ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: bheda śruteḥ hi na dharmi samarpaka tvena abheda jñāna upajīvaka tvam tāvat
translated: For the statement of difference cannot be the basis of the knowledge of non-difference by indicating the substratum,

analyzed: jīva īśvara svarūpasya eva dharmi tvāt
translated: because the nature of the individual soul and the Lord itself is the substratum.

analyzed: nā api svarūpa prāmāṇya grāhaka tvena
translated: Nor can it be by indicating the validity of the nature [of Brahman].

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa eva tad siddheḥ
translated: Because that is established by perception itself.

analyzed: atas niṣedhya prāpaka tayā eva iti vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be said that it is only by indicating what is to be negated.

analyzed: na ca tad virodhaḥ prāmāṇyam āvahati
translated: And contradiction of that does not bring about invalidity.

analyzed: niṣedha śāstra apalāpa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because then it would lead to the rejection of the scriptures of negation.

analyzed: na ca pramāṇa prāptasya ayam pratiṣedhaḥ
translated: And this negation is not of what is obtained by valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: kintu tattvamasi ādi śruti tātparya a parijñāna prāptasya eva
translated: But rather of what is obtained by the ignorance of the meaning of the scriptures beginning with That art thou.

original: yadapi nirbhedaṃ svarūpamādāya bhedo boddhavya iti tatrāpi na yayorbhedo bodhanīyastayorabheda āśrayaṇīyaḥ /
analyzed: yat api nirbhedam svarūpam ādāya bhedaḥ boddhavyaḥ iti tatra api na yayoḥ bhedaḥ bodhanīyaḥ tayoḥ abhedaḥ āśrayaṇīyaḥ
translated: And even in the case where difference is to be understood taking the nature [of Brahman] as without difference, even there, the non-difference of those two [Brahman and the individual soul] should not be accepted, of which the difference is to be understood.

original: kintu svagatabhedaṃ vastu dharmitayopādāya tasyāntato bhedo bodhyate /
analyzed: kintu svagata bhedam vastu dharmitayā upādāya tasya antatas bhedaḥ bodhyate
translated: But rather, taking the difference belonging to itself as the substratum, the difference of that [Brahman] is finally to be understood.

analyzed: atas jīva īśa bheda śruteḥ tad abheda upajīvana abhāvāt anapekṣa tva lakṣaṇāt balāt yuktam bheda sādhaka tvam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, because the statement of the difference of the individual soul and the Lord is not based on the non-difference [of Brahman and the individual soul], it is proper that it should establish difference by the power of its own independent nature. This is the remainder [of the sentence].

analyzed: kiñca tiṣṭhatu tāvat yaḥ sarvajñaḥ ityādi śruteḥ upajīvya tvam
translated: Moreover, let alone the fact that the statement he who is omniscient etc. is to be relied upon.

analyzed: tathā api abheda anumāna āgama bādhaka tvam bhavet eva
translated: Even so, the contradiction of the inference and scripture of non-difference would certainly be there.

original: iyaṃ khalu śrutiḥ sārvajñādiviśiṣyamīśvaraṃ pratipādayantī na kiñcidapekṣate /
analyzed: iyam khalu śrutiḥ sārvajña ādi viśiṣyam īśvaram pratipādayantī na kiñcid apekṣate
translated: For this scripture, while teaching God who is distinguished by omniscience etc., does not depend on anything.

analyzed: anumāna āgamau tu sa apekṣau
translated: But inference and scripture depend on something.

analyzed: sāpekṣa nirapekṣayoḥ ca nirapekṣasya prābalyāt iti āśayavān āha na upajīvyaḥ hi iti
translated: And between that which depends and that which does not depend, the one that does not depend is stronger. With this intention he says not being relied upon.

analyzed: atra bheda abheda pramāṇayoḥ madhye
translated: Here, between the means of knowing difference and non-difference.

analyzed: bheda śruteḥ bhedaka dharma viśiṣya dharmi śruteḥ  abhedaḥ iti abheda pramāṇam
translated: The statement of difference is the statement of the possessor of attributes distinguished by the attributes of difference.🔽Non-difference is the means of knowing non-difference.

analyzed: anapekṣa tva upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a metaphor for not depending.

analyzed: atas balāt abheda pramāṇa bādhaka tvam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the remainder is that it contradicts the means of knowing non-difference by force.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

original: yaḥ sarvajña ityādiśrutirna jīvabhedakadharmaviśiṣyaṃ brahma pratipādayati /
analyzed: yaḥ sarvajñaḥ ityādi śrutiḥ na jīva bhedaka dharma viśiṣyam brahma pratipādayati
translated: The scripture beginning with he who is omniscient does not teach Brahman distinguished by the attributes that differ from the individual soul.

analyzed: kintu anuvadati eva
translated: But it merely repeats.

analyzed: atas na anumāna ādeḥ tad bādhaḥ iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: Therefore, there is no contradiction of that by inference etc. Hence he says not etc.

original: na ca mānāntaropeyaṃ brahma tad bhavati kvacit // / / //
analyzed: na ca māna antara upeyam brahma tat bhavati kvacid
translated: And Brahman is never to be attained by another means of knowledge.

analyzed: upeyam jñeyam
translated: To be attained is to be known.

analyzed: tat iti sārvajña ādi upetam
translated: 'That' means endowed with omniscience and so on.

analyzed: kvacid iti bhrānti pratipannam api na bhavati iti sūcayati
translated: 'In some cases' indicates that it is not even mistakenly apprehended.

analyzed: na tāvat sārvajña ādi viśiṣyam brahma śrīti vyatirikta pramāṇa gamyam
translated: To begin with, Brahman qualified by omniscience and so on is not known by any means of knowledge other than the Veda.

analyzed: śāstra eka yoni tvasya samarthita tvāt
translated: Because it has been established that the Veda is its only source.

analyzed: na api bhrānti pratipannam
translated: Nor is it mistakenly apprehended.

analyzed: kvacid pramitasya eva anyatra āropāt
translated: Because what is known in one place is superimposed elsewhere.

analyzed: na ca pramāṇena bhrāntyā vā aprāptasya anuvādaḥ sambhavati
translated: And it is not possible to describe by means of a means of knowledge or by mistake what has not been obtained.

analyzed: atas na iyam śrutiḥ anuvādinī
translated: Therefore this Vedic text is not descriptive.

analyzed: kinnāma pratipādayati eva ukta rūpam brahma iti
translated: But rather it does teach Brahman of the described nature.

analyzed: nanu tathā api nā upajīvya pramāṇa virodhaḥ numāna ādeḥ
translated: But even so, there is no contradiction with a means of knowledge that is used, such as inference.

analyzed: śruti upajīvane hi saḥ syāt
translated: For that would be the case if it depended on the Veda.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But it is not so.

original: tadvayatiriktapramāṇopajīvanādityata āha naceti //🔽vastuvyavahito vahniradhūmasthale pratyakṣādyavedyo 'pi kvaciddeśe pratyakṣeṇānumānena vāvagamyate /
analyzed: tad vayatirikta pramāṇa upajīvanāt iti atas āha na ca iti  vastu vyavahitaḥ vahniḥ adhūma sthale pratyakṣa ādi avedyaḥ kvacid deśe pratyakṣeṇa anumānena vā avagamyate
translated: Because it depends on a means of knowledge other than that. Therefore he says 'and it is not' and so on.🔽Fire, which is obstructed by an intervening substance, is not known by perception or other means in a place without smoke, but is known by perception or inference in some place.

analyzed: prāk patana utpatteḥ agamyam api guru tvam kvacid kāle numānena gamyate
translated: Gravity, which is not known before falling or arising, is known by inference at some time.

analyzed: na ca evam brahma kvacid māna antara upeyam
translated: And Brahman is not to be known by any other means of knowledge anywhere.

analyzed: yena tat upajīvya anumāna ādi pravṛttiḥ syāt
translated: By which there would be the operation of inference etc. which depend on that.

analyzed: astu vā brahma pramāṇa antara vedyam
translated: Or let Brahman be knowable by another means of knowledge.

analyzed: tathā api abheda anumāna ādeḥ upajīvya pramāṇa virodhaḥ duṣpariharaḥ  śruti vat tasya api pramāṇasya bheda pratyāyaka tvāt iti abhiprāyavān āha yena iti
translated: Even so, the contradiction of the inference etc. of non-difference with the means of knowledge which is depended on is difficult to avoid.🔽With the intention that like the Veda, that means of knowledge also conveys the knowledge of difference, he says 'by which' etc.

analyzed: yena mānena ca apeyam bhedaḥ tena avagamyate
translated: And the difference is understood by that very means of knowledge by which Brahman is to be known.

analyzed: upeyam brahma iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Brahman is to be known is the remainder.

analyzed: tat katham iti atas āha sa sārvajña iti
translated: How is that? Therefore he says 'by which' etc.

analyzed: sarva jñāna maya evā īśaḥ yadi upeyaḥ kathañcana
translated: If the Lord, who consists of all knowledge, is somehow to be known,

analyzed: sarva jñathva guṇena eva tayā bhedaḥ vagamyate
translated: the difference is understood by that very quality of omniscience.

analyzed: dharma ādikam kasyacid pratyakṣam prameya tvāt ghaṭa vat iti ādikayā  vajña sādhaka tayā anumayā
translated: This is an inference which proves the existence of the all-knowing one, like the inference 'the dharma etc. are perceptible to someone, because of being an object of knowledge, like a pot' etc.

analyzed: sarva kartṛ tva ādi anumāna upalakṣaṇam ca etat
translated: This also illustrates the inference of being the creator of all etc.

analyzed: eva iti pratyakṣam vyāvartayati
translated: The word 'only' excludes perception.

analyzed: kathañcana iti abhyupagama vādaḥ yam iti sūcayati
translated: 'Somehow' indicates that this is a statement of acceptance.

analyzed: sarvajña tva iti upalakṣaṇam
translated: 'Omniscience' is an illustration.

analyzed: tayā eva iti anvayaḥ
translated: 'By that very' is to be construed.

analyzed: īśvare tāvat pratyakṣam śaṅkā arham eva na bhavati
translated: As for God, perception is not even worthy of suspicion.

analyzed: atas numānam eva vaktavyam  pratipakṣa ādinā parāhatasya api tasya kathañcid śaṅkā arha tvāt
translated: Therefore, inference alone must be stated.🔽Because even that [perception], which is refuted by the opponent, etc., is somehow worthy of suspicion.

analyzed: anumānam ca kiñcid kenacid viśiṣyam eva pratipādayati
translated: And inference establishes only a particular thing as distinguished from something else.

analyzed: na tu niṣkṛṣṭam vastu
translated: But not an isolated entity.

analyzed: naca jīva ādi sādhāraṇa dharma viśiṣya athar siddhau īśvaraḥ sidhyati
translated: And God is not established by establishing a thing distinguished by attributes common to the individual soul, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt bhedaka dharma vaiśiṣyayena eva tad siddhiḥ varktavyā
translated: Therefore, His establishment must be stated only by the distinction of attributes that distinguish Him.

analyzed: tathā ca anumāna ādeḥ upajīvya virodhaḥ vajralepāyitaḥ
translated: And thus the contradiction with what is relied upon by inference, etc., is made firm.

original: yadyapyanumānaṃ svataḥ śrutito durbalaṃ tathāpi upajīvyatayā bādhakaṃ bhavatyeveti / /🔽tadaneneśvaragrāhikāyāḥ śruterbhedakadharmaviśṭi tasminprāmāṇyamupapāditam /🔽idānīṃ jīvagrāhakasya pratyakṣasyeśvarabhedakavi
analyzed: yadi api anumānam svatas śrutitaḥ durbalam tathā api upajīvya tayā bādhakam bhavati eva iti  tat anena īśvara grāhikāyāḥ śruteḥ bhedaka dharma viśṭi tasmin prāmāṇyam upapāditam  idānīm jīva grāhakasya pratyakṣasya īśvara bheda kavi
translated: Even though inference is weaker than scripture by itself, still it becomes a refutation by being what is relied upon.🔽By this, the validity of scripture, which apprehends God, is established in Him as distinguished by attributes that distinguish Him.

analyzed: dharmiṇi jīve prāmāṇyam samarthyate
translated: Now, the validity of perception, which apprehends the individual soul, is established in the individual soul, which is distinguished by attributes that distinguish God.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is as follows.

analyzed: bhavatu śrutiḥ aduḥkhi tva sārvajña ādimat īśvare pramāṇam
translated: Let scripture be a valid means of knowledge regarding God, who possesses non-suffering, omniscience, and so on.

analyzed: tathā api na abheda anumāna āgamayoḥ upajīvya pramāṇa virodhena aprāmāṇyam
translated: Still, the inference and the scripture of non-difference do not become invalid due to contradiction with the authoritative means of knowledge that are relied upon.

original: duḥkhitvādirūpe hi jīvasya tāttvike sati tathā syānna caivam /
analyzed: duḥkhi tva ādi rūpe hi jīvasya tāttvike sati tathā syāt na ca evam
translated: For, if the nature of the individual soul as miserable, etc. were real, it would be so, but it is not so.

analyzed: aham duḥkhī ityādeḥ anubhavasya mithyā anubhava tvāt
translated: Because the experience I am miserable, etc. is a false experience.

original: antaḥkaraṇagato hi duḥkhādiranarthaḥ svarūpato mithyābhūto japākusumāruṇimeva sphaṭike caitanye cakāsti /🔽naca bhrāntipratipannenannabhe
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa gataḥ hi duḥkha ādiḥ anarthaḥ svarūpataḥ mithyā bhūtaḥ japā kusuma aruṇima iva sphaṭike caitanye cakāsti  na ca bhrānti pratipannena na anna bhe
translated: For, the evil such as misery, etc. residing in the internal organ, which is false in its own nature, shines in consciousness like a crystal reddened by a China rose.

original: bhedakena vastu bhidyata iti ata āha neti //
analyzed: bhedakena vastu bhidyate iti atas āha na iti
translated: And an existent thing is not differentiated by a difference apprehended by error, nor by a differentiator. Therefore he says no.

analyzed: na duḥkha anubhavaḥ kvāpi mithyā anubhava tām vrajet  kvāpi iti
translated: The experience of misery never becomes a false experience anywhere.🔽Anywhere means

analyzed: sarvathā iti arthaḥ
translated: in every way.

original: bhavedetadyadyahaṃ duḥkhītyādyanubhavo mithyānubhavaḥ syānna ca tathā /
analyzed: bhavet etat yadi aham duḥkhī ityādi anubhavaḥ mithyā anubhavaḥ syāt na ca tathā
translated: This would be so if the experience I am miserable, etc. were a false experience, but it is not so.

analyzed: api tu pramāṇam eva
translated: On the contrary, it is a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: yadi api duḥkha ādikam antaḥkaraṇa gatam  tathā api sva rūpeṇa sat eva
translated: Even though misery, etc. reside in the internal organ,🔽still they exist in their own nature.

analyzed: jīvātmanaḥ ca tad bhoktṛ tvena tadvat tvam tāttvikam eva
translated: And the individual soul's being the experiencer of that is indeed real.

analyzed: alpa śaktitva pāratantrya ādikam tu svarūpa gatam eva iti āśayaḥ
translated: The idea is that weakness of power, dependence, etc. are only a part of the nature of the self.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha nahi iti
translated: Why is this so? He says: For, etc.

original: na hi bādhaḥ kvacid dṛṣṭo duḥkhādyanubhavasya tu // / / //
analyzed: na hi bādhaḥ kvacid dṛṣṭaḥ duḥkha ādi anubhavasya tu
translated: For, nowhere is there seen any contradiction of the experience of pain, etc.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ na eva iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The word tu (but) is for emphasis, connected with naiva (not at all).

analyzed: asañjāta bādha bhrameṣu vyabhicāra parihārāya kvacid iti uktam
translated: Kvacit (nowhere) is said to avoid the fallacy of contradiction in non-arisen delusions.

original: nahi kadācitkutracitkaścinnāhaṃ duḥkhī kintvantaḥkaraṇagatenaiva mithyāduḥkhena duḥkhitayā'tmānamamaniṣī🔽ṣamiti bādhakapratyayavāndṛśyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: nahi kadācid kutracid kaścid na aham duḥkhī kintu antaḥkaraṇa gatena eva mithyāduḥkhena duḥkhi tayā ātmānam amaniṣī  ṣam iti bādhaka pratyayavān dṛśyate iti arthaḥ
translated: For, no one is ever seen anywhere who has the contradictory idea, I am not in pain, but am identifying myself with the false pain residing in the internal organ. This is the meaning.

analyzed: nanu vimuktaḥ ca vimucyate tat tvam asi
translated: And he who is liberated is liberated (Ch. 6.14.2), That thou art (Ch. 6.8.7), etc.

analyzed: ityādi śrutiḥ eva asya anubhavasya bādhikā asti iti katham na duḥkha anubhūtiḥ bhrāntiḥ
translated: This very scripture is the contradictor of this experience. How then is the experience of pain not a delusion?

original: atra hi duḥkhādyupaplavarahitamevāsyātmanastāttvikaṃ rūpamiti pratipādyata ityata āha yadīti //
analyzed: atra hi duḥkha ādi upaplava rahitam eva asya ātmanaḥ tāttvikam rūpam iti pratipādyate iti atas āha yadi iti
translated: For, it is taught here that the true nature of the self is free from the affliction of pain, etc. Therefore, he says: If, etc.🔽If it is concluded that the experience of pain is also a delusion,🔽by what is it understood that the scripture of the non-suffering one is not a delusion?

analyzed: yadi duḥkha anubhūtiḥ ca bhrāntiḥ iti avasīyate
translated: If it is concluded that the experience of pain is also a delusion,

analyzed: aduḥkhita aśrutiḥ kena na bhrāntiḥ iti gamyate
translated: by what is it understood that the scripture of the non-suffering one is not a delusion?

analyzed: avasīyate śrutim āśritya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is understood: “on the basis of scripture.”

analyzed: kena kāraṇena
translated: By what reason?

analyzed: bhrāntiḥ svarūpataḥ rthataḥ ca
translated: Delusion is in regard to form and meaning.

analyzed: gamyate abhyupagamyate
translated: It is accepted.

analyzed: anubhavam āśritya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is understood: “on the basis of experience.”

analyzed: idam uktam bhavati  bhavet eṣā śrutiḥ asya anubhavasya bādhikā
translated: This is what is said.🔽This scripture could be the sublater of this experience,

analyzed: yadi niścita pramāṇa bhāvā bhavet
translated: if it were ascertained to be a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: na ca tathā
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: dharmi grāhaka anubhava virodhena asmābhiḥ tad aprāmāṇyasya pratipādyamāna tvāt
translated: Because by us its invalidity is being established by contradiction with the experience which apprehends the subject.

analyzed: parasya ca tad parihārāya adya api samudyata tvāt
translated: And because the opponent is still engaged in the attempt to defend it.

original: tathāca sati śrutiprāmāṇyaniścaye 'nubhavasya bhrāntitvaṃ tasmiṃśca sati śrutiprāmāṇyaniścaya iti parasparāśrayatvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca sati śruti prāmāṇya niścaye nubhavasya bhrānti tvam tasmin ca sati śruti prāmāṇya niścayaḥ iti paraspara āśraya tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And if that is so, then there would be the contingence of mutual dependence, in that the validity of scripture is ascertained when the experience is illusory, and that is so when the validity of scripture is ascertained.

analyzed: nanu anubhava virodhena śruti aprāmāṇya abhidhāne samānam etat
translated: But even when the invalidity of scripture is stated by contradiction with experience, the same is true.

analyzed: na samānam
translated: It is not the same.

analyzed: anubhavasya anapekṣa tvāt śruteḥ tad apekṣa tvāt
translated: Because experience is independent, and scripture is dependent on it.

analyzed: anyathā sarvatra dharmi grāhaka virodha uccheda āpattiḥ ittiḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be the contingence of the destruction of contradiction with the apprehender of the subject in every case, because of the absence of dependence on it.

original: nanu tarhi nedaṃ rajatamityasyāpi rajatamidamiti jñānaṃ prati bādhakatvamayuktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: nanu tarhi na idam rajatam ityasya api rajatam idam iti jñānam prati bādhaka tvam ayuktam syāt
translated: But then it would be improper for the cognition 'this is not silver' also to be a sublater of the cognition 'this is silver'.

analyzed: na syāt
translated: It would not be so.

original: nedaṃ rajatamiti jñānaprāmāṇyasya sākṣiṇā parīkṣayā niścitatvāt /
analyzed: na idam rajatam iti jñāna prāmāṇyasya sākṣiṇā parīkṣayā niścita tvāt
translated: Because the validity of the cognition 'this is not silver' is ascertained by the examination of the witness.

analyzed: idam rajatam iti jñānasya tad abhāvāt  parīkṣita prāmāṇyena upajīvakena upajīvyasya atathābhūtasya bādha upagamāt
translated: Because there is no such thing for the cognition 'this is silver'.🔽Because the sublation of that which is not so by the sublater which is examined as to its validity is accepted.

analyzed: upajīvya upajīvaka nyāyasya tad anya viṣaya tvāt  prāmāṇya sandehe khalu nyāya anusaraṇam
translated: Because the principle of the sublater and the sublated applies to something other than that.🔽For when there is doubt about validity, one follows reasoning.

analyzed: niścite tu prāmāṇye kim anena
translated: But when validity is ascertained, what is the use of this?

original: vakṣyati caitadācāryaḥ /🔽evaṃ tarhi śruterapi prāmāṇyaṃ parīkṣāsahakṛtena sākṣiṇā niścitamityanubhavabādhakatvamupapatsyata ityāśayavānāśaṅkate śrutīti // /
analyzed: vakṣyati ca etat ācāryaḥ  evam tarhi śruteḥ api prāmāṇyam parīkṣā sahakṛtena sākṣiṇā niścitam iti anubhava bādhaka tvam upapatsyate iti āśayavān āśaṅkate śruti iti
translated: And the teacher will say this.🔽If that is so, then the sublation of experience will be proper, since the validity of the Veda also is ascertained by the witness cooperating with examination. With this idea he raises the objection with 'the Veda'.

original: evaṃ tarhi śruterapi prāmāṇyaṃ parīkṣāsahakṛtena sākṣiṇā niścitamityanubhavabādhakatvamupapatsyata ityāśayavānāśaṅkate śrutīti / /
analyzed: evam tarhi śruteḥ api prāmāṇyam parīkṣā sahakṛtena sākṣiṇā niścitam iti anubhava bādhaka tvam upapatsyate iti āśayavān āśaṅkate śruti iti
translated: If that is so, then the sublation of experience will be proper, since the validity of the Veda also is ascertained by the witness cooperating with examination. With this idea he raises the objection with 'the Veda'.

analyzed: śruti svarūpam arthaḥ ca mānena eva avasīyate
translated: The form of the Veda and its meaning are ascertained only by valid cognition.

analyzed: svarūpam arthaḥ ca iti vivakṣā bhedena prāmāṇyam eva uktam
translated: The form and the meaning, due to the difference in intention, are said to be the very validity.

analyzed: jīvasya nirduḥkha brahma ātmatā pratipādaka śruti svarūpam asyāḥ śruteḥ saḥ rthaḥ iti ubhayatra phalataḥ rtha bheda abhāvāt
translated: The form of the Veda that teaches the Jiva's identity with Brahman devoid of sorrow is the meaning of this Veda. Thus, there is no difference in meaning in both cases.

analyzed: etat eva hi prāmāṇyam api  mānena sākṣiṇā
translated: This alone is the validity.

analyzed: pariharati tat ced iti
translated: By valid cognition, by the witness.

original: taccenmānaṃ gṛhītaṃ te kiṃ duḥkhānubhave bhramaḥ // / / //
analyzed: tat ced mānam gṛhītam te kim duḥkha anubhave bhramaḥ
translated: He answers this with If that is the valid cognition grasped by you, why the delusion in the experience of sorrow?

analyzed: te iti avyayam tṛtīyā arthe
translated: That is an indeclinable in the sense of the third case.

analyzed: te mataḥ iti adhyāhāraḥ vā
translated: Or there is the implication they are considered.

analyzed: kim kinnimittam  duḥkha anubhave bhramaḥ iti
translated: Why means for what reason.🔽In the experience of sorrow means.

analyzed: duḥkha anubhavasya bhrama tvam iti iti yāvat
translated: It means the delusion of the experience of sorrow.

analyzed: aṅgīkriyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is is accepted.

original: tat sākṣilakṣaṇaṃ mānaṃ duḥkhānubhavaviṣaye bhramaḥ kuto 'ṅgīkriyata iti vā /
analyzed: tat sākṣi lakṣaṇam mānam duḥkha anubhava viṣaye bhramaḥ kutas ṅgīkriyate iti vā
translated: Or why is the valid cognition characterized by the witness accepted as a delusion regarding the object of the experience of sorrow?

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: sākṣiṇā śrutiprāmāṇyaṃ niścitamiti na pareṇāṅgīkartuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: sākṣiṇā śruti prāmāṇyam niścitam iti na pareṇa aṅgīkartum śakyate
translated: It cannot be accepted by the opponent that the validity of the Veda is ascertained by the witness.

analyzed: tathā sati tad prāmāṇyasya aṅgīkartavya tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if that were so, then its validity would have to be accepted.

analyzed: iṣyate tat iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is accepted, it is not so.

original: tathā satyahaṃ duḥkhīti duḥkhādiviṣayo 'pi sa eveti tatrāpi tasya prāmāṇyameva grāhyaṃ syānna bhramatvam /
analyzed: tathā sati aham duḥkhī iti duḥkha ādi viṣayaḥ saḥ eva iti tatra api tasya prāmāṇyam eva grāhyam syāt na bhrama tvam
translated: Because if that were so, then even in the case of the object of suffering etc., such as I am suffering, it would be the same, so its validity would have to be accepted there also, not its being a delusion.

analyzed: na ced śruti prāmāṇya grahaṇe bhramaḥ syāt iti
translated: And if not, then even in accepting the validity of the Veda, it would be a delusion.

original: nanvekatra prāmāṇye viṣayāntare 'pi prāmāṇyena bhāvyaṃ tatrāprāmāṇye cānyatrāpi aprāmāṇyena bhavitavyamiti kuta etat /
analyzed: nanu ekatra prāmāṇye viṣaya antare prāmāṇyena bhāvyam tatra aprāmāṇye ca anyatra api aprāmāṇyena bhavitavyam iti kutas etat
translated: But if there is validity in one case, then there must be validity in another object also, and if there is no validity there, then there must be no validity in another case also - how is this so?

original: mā hi bhūdekasya cakṣurāderayaṃ niyama ityata āha naceti //
analyzed: mā hi bhūt ekasya cakṣuḥ ādeḥ ayam niyamaḥ iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: Because it should not be that this restriction applies to the eye etc. alone. Therefore he says: And there is no particular contradiction etc.

analyzed: na ca bādha viśeṣaḥ u sti yat abādhitam eva tat
translated: And there is no particular contradiction, by which only that which is not contradicted would be valid.

analyzed: bhede deva ekasya api kvacid prāmāṇye paratra aprāmāṇyam
translated: Even in the case of difference, if one thing is valid in one place, it is not valid elsewhere.

analyzed: kāraṇa viśeṣāt
translated: Because of the particular cause.

analyzed: sa ca utpattau doṣaḥ jñaptau bādhaḥ
translated: And that is a fault in the origination, a contradiction in the cognition.

analyzed: doṣaḥ pi bādhā unneyaḥ eva
translated: The fault also is to be inferred only from the contradiction.

analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it has been said:

original: balavatpramāṇataścaiva jñeyā doṣā na cānyathā' / iti /
analyzed: balavat pramāṇataḥ ca eva jñeyāḥ doṣāḥ na ca anyathā iti
translated: And the faults are to be known only by strong means of knowledge, not otherwise.

analyzed: tatas bādhaḥ eva viśeṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, contradiction alone is the distinction.

analyzed: na ca duḥkha ādi viṣayasya sākṣi anubhavasya bādha rūpaḥ viśeṣaḥ sti
translated: And there is no peculiarity in the form of contradiction in the case of the direct experience which has pain etc. for its object.

original: yenāsau śrutiprāmāṇye pramāṇabhūto 'pi duḥkhādau bhramaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yena asau śruti prāmāṇye pramāṇa bhūtaḥ duḥkha ādau bhramaḥ syāt
translated: By which, even though it is a means of valid knowledge in regard to the authoritativeness of the Veda, it would be an illusion in regard to pain etc.

original: yat yasmādevaṃ tat tasmāt śrutiprāmāṇyamiva tat ātmano duḥkhitvādikamapyabādhitameva satyamevāṅgīkāyarmiti /🔽yadvā yadyasmādevaṃ tatta🔽smātkiṃ duḥkhānubhave bhrama iti pūrveṇaiva
analyzed: yat yasmāt evam tat tasmāt śruti prāmāṇyam iva tat ātmanaḥ duḥkhi tva ādikam api abādhitam eva satyam eva aṅgīkāyarm iti  yat vā yat yasmāt evam tat te  smāt kim duḥkha anubhave bhramaḥ iti pūrveṇa eva
translated: Since this is so, therefore, like the authoritativeness of the Veda, its being the self, and its being painful etc. are also unobstructed, and are to be accepted as true only.

analyzed: ṇaḥ sambandhaḥ
translated: Or, since this is so, therefore, what? In the experience of pain, it is an illusion. The connection is with the preceding sentence only.

analyzed: nanu etat śruti prāmāṇyam duḥkha ādikam ca sākṣi gṛhītam eva
translated: But this authoritativeness of the Veda and the pain etc. are apprehended by the self-luminous self alone.

analyzed: na ca ubhayatra prāmāṇyam sākṣiṇaḥ yuktam
translated: And it is not proper that the self-luminous self should be a means of valid knowledge in both cases.

analyzed: paraspara virodhāt
translated: Because of mutual contradiction.

analyzed: tatas ekatra aprāmāṇya avaśyambhāve duḥkha ādau eva tat iti grāhyam
translated: Therefore, when the absence of being a means of valid knowledge in one case is inevitable, it should be accepted in the case of pain etc. alone.

analyzed: śruti prāmāṇyasya apauruṣeya tva ādi parīkṣā sahakṛtena gṛhīta tvāt
translated: Because the authoritativeness of the Veda is apprehended by the self-luminous self in association with the examination of its being not a product etc.

analyzed: atas mithyā eva duḥkhi tva ādikam ita ced na
translated: Therefore, being painful etc. are false. If this is said, it is not so.

analyzed: duḥkha ādau api sajātīya vijātīya saṃvāda rūpa parīkṣā sadbhāvāt
translated: Because in the case of pain etc. also, there is the presence of examination in the form of agreement with the homogeneous and the heterogeneous.

original: evaṃ tarhi sandehānna duḥkhādisatyatāniścayo bhavatāṃ yukta iti na śruteranubhavabādho vaktuṃ śakyata ityata āha abādhitameveti //
analyzed: evam tarhi sandehāt na duḥkha ādi satya tā niścayaḥ bhavatām yuktaḥ iti na śruteḥ anubhava bādhaḥ vaktum śakyate iti atas āha abādhitam eva iti
translated: If it is so, then, since there is doubt, it is not proper for you to be certain of the truth of the reality of pain, etc. Therefore, it cannot be said that the testimony of the scriptures is contradicted by experience. To this he says: It is not contradicted.

analyzed: tat duḥkham satyam eva iti avadhārayataḥ yam abhisandhiḥ
translated: The idea of one who determines that that pain is the truth is this.

analyzed: satyam
translated: It is true.

analyzed: śruti prāmāṇyam duḥkha ādikam ca sākṣi gṛhītam eva
translated: The authority of the scriptures and the fact of pain, etc. are both apprehended by the witness.

analyzed: na ca ekatra api bādhakam asti iti ubhayam api pramāṇam sākṣī
translated: And there is no contradiction even in one case. Therefore, both are valid means of knowledge, and the witness is not contradicted.

analyzed: na ca virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction.

analyzed: advaita sattām antareṇa api śruti prāmāṇya sattāyāḥ sambhavāt
translated: Even without the reality of non-duality, the reality of the authority of the scriptures is possible.

analyzed: na hi apauruṣeya tva ādi yuktayaḥ viṣaya viśeṣa niyata prāmāṇya niścaye sākṣiṇaḥ
translated: For the arguments based on being not of human origin, etc. do not assist the witness in determining the validity which is restricted to a particular object.

analyzed: sācivyam ācaranti  kintu prāmāṇya mātra niścaye
translated: But they assist in determining validity in general.

original: upakramādyāstu tatra tatrābhāsīkṛtā eva /🔽naca duḥkhasattāmantareṇa tatra prāmāṇyasya sambhavo 'sti /
analyzed: upakrama ādyāḥ tu tatra tatra ābhāsīkṛtāḥ eva  na ca duḥkha sattām antareṇa tatra prāmāṇyasya sambhavaḥ sti
translated: But the arguments from the subject-matter, etc. have been refuted in various places.🔽And there is no possibility of the validity of the scriptures in the absence of the reality of pain.

analyzed: na ca duḥkha sattayā śruti prāmāṇya mātrasya virodhaḥ sti
translated: And there is no contradiction between the reality of pain and the mere validity of the scriptures.

analyzed: viṣaya antare pi tasya sambhavāt
translated: For it is possible even in a different object.

analyzed: atas satyam eva duḥkha ādikam iti
translated: Therefore, suffering etc. are indeed real.

analyzed: śrutiḥ anubhavasya bādhikā na bhavati
translated: Śruti is not a sublater of experience.

analyzed: kintu dharmi grāhaka tayā prabalena anubhavena eva bādhyate iti uktam
translated: But it is said that it is sublated only by experience which is stronger as the apprehender of the subject.

analyzed: na kevalam dhamiḥ grāhaka tayā anubhavasya prābalyam
translated: Not only is experience stronger as the apprehender of the subject,

analyzed: kinnāma śruti svarūpa prāmāṇya grāhaka tvena api iti āśayavān āha śruti iti
translated: but also as the apprehender of the validity of the form of Śruti. With this intention he says: Śruti etc.

analyzed: arthaḥ iti arthavat tvam prāmāṇyam iti yāvat
translated: Artha means having an object, that is, validity.

original: svarūpataḥ prāmāṇyataścāvasitā hi śrutirabhipretasiddhaye prayoktavyā nānyathā /🔽śratisvarūpaṃ tatprāmāṇyaṃ ca mānenaiva sākṣilakṣaṇenāvasīyate nānyena /
analyzed: svarūpataḥ prāmāṇyataḥ ca avasitā hi śrutiḥ abhipreta siddhaye prayoktavyā nā anyathā  śrati svarūpam tad prāmāṇyam ca mānena eva sākṣi lakṣaṇena avasīyate na anyena
translated: For, Śruti which is ascertained as to its form and validity should be employed for the accomplishment of the intended purpose, not otherwise.🔽The form of Śruti and its validity are ascertained only by the valid means of knowledge called perception, not by anything else.

original: yadyapi śratisvarūpaṃ śrotravedyaṃ tathāpi śrotrajanitatadvṛttiprāmāṇyaṃ yāvanna sākṣiṇā gṛhyate tāvanna tat siddhayatītyataḥ śrutisvarūpāvasāyo
analyzed: yadi api śrati svarūpam śrotra vedyam tathā api śrotra janita tad vṛtti prāmāṇyam yāvat na sākṣiṇā gṛhyate tāvat na tat siddhayati iti atas śruti svarūpa avasāyaḥ
translated: Although the form of Śruti is to be known by the ear, still it is not established until the validity of the cognition produced by the ear is grasped by the witness. Therefore, the ascertainment of the form of Śruti

analyzed: pi sākṣiṇī eva āyatate
translated: also depends on the witness itself.

analyzed: yat vā śruti śabdenai
translated: Or, by the word Śruti

analyzed: na tad janitam jñānam ucyate
translated: the cognition produced by it is meant.

analyzed: tatra pṛcchāmaḥ
translated: There we ask:

original: tasya sākṣiṇaḥ prāmāṇyaṃ bhavatāpyabhyupagataṃ na veti /
analyzed: tasya sākṣiṇaḥ prāmāṇyam bhavatā api abhyupagatam na vā iti
translated: Whether the validity of the witnesses is accepted by you or not.

original: neti pakṣe śrutisvarūpādyasiddherna tadvirodhena duḥkhādyanubhavasya bhramatvaṃ vaktuṃ yuktam /
analyzed: na iti pakṣe śruti svarūpa ādi asiddheḥ na tad virodhena duḥkha ādi anubhavasya bhrama tvam vaktum yuktam
translated: If you say it is not, then, because the nature etc. of the Vedas are not established, it is not proper to say that the experience of suffering etc. is an error due to contradiction with them.

analyzed: ādyam dūṣayati tat ced iti  tat sākṣisva
translated: He refutes the first view by saying If that...🔽If that, the nature of the witness,

original: rūpaṃ pramāṇaṃ tvayā gṛhītaṃ cettadā duḥkhānubhavasya bhramatvaṃ kiṃ kathaṃ
analyzed: rūpam pramāṇam tvayā gṛhītam ced tadā duḥkha anubhavasya bhrama tvam kim katham
translated: is accepted by you as valid, then how can the experience of suffering be said to be an error?

analyzed: na kathañcid
translated: Not in any way.

analyzed: śruti virodhena khalu tat ucyate
translated: For it is said due to contradiction with the Vedas.

original: sā tu svarūpaprāmāṇyagrāhakatayopajīvyenānubhavena bādhitā kathaṃ tadbādhanāya prabhavatīti /
analyzed: sā tu svarūpa prāmāṇya grāhaka tayā upajīvyena anubhavena bādhitā katham tad bādhanāya prabhavati iti
translated: But how can that, which is contradicted by the experience that is relied upon as the valid means of knowing the nature and validity of the Vedas, be able to contradict that?

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: śruti svarūpa prāmāṇyayoḥ sākṣiṇaḥ prāmāṇyam aṅgīkriyate
translated: The validity of the witness regarding the nature and validity of the Vedas is accepted.

analyzed: duḥkha ādau tu viṣaya antare śruti virodhena aprāmāṇyam āśrīyate
translated: But in the case of suffering etc., which are different objects, invalidity is accepted due to contradiction with the Vedas.

analyzed: tat katham ukta doṣaḥ iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: How then is the stated fault? To this he says And...

original: bādhasya bādhakatvena abhimatāyāḥ śruteḥ viśeṣo bādhyatayābhimatātsākṣiṇo 'tiśayo nāsti /
analyzed: bādhasya bādhaka tvena abhimatāyāḥ śruteḥ viśeṣaḥ bādhya tayā abhimatāt sākṣiṇaḥ atiśayaḥ na asti
translated: There is no difference between the Veda, which is considered to be the contradictor of the contradicted, and the witness, which is considered to be the contradicted.

original: asti coktavakṣyamāṇarītyā sākṣiṇa eva viśeṣa iti /
analyzed: asti ca ukta vakṣyamāṇa rītyā sākṣiṇaḥ eva viśeṣaḥ iti
translated: And there is a special feature of the witness itself in the manner stated and to be stated.

analyzed: śiṣyam spaṣṭam
translated: The meaning is clear.

analyzed: kiñca aham duḥkhī ityādi sākṣiṇaḥ bhrama tvam vadan praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: Moreover, one who says that the witness I am unhappy etc. is deluded should be asked:

analyzed: kim sarvatra api sākṣiṇaḥ bhrama tvam aṅgīkriyate
translated: Is the delusion of the witness accepted everywhere?

analyzed: uta kvacid prāmāṇyam api
translated: Or is there even validity somewhere?

analyzed: ādye doṣam āha śruti svarūpam iti  mānena sākṣiṇā eva
translated: In the first case, he states the fault with The form of the Veda etc.🔽By the means of valid knowledge, by the witness itself.

original: tathāca tasya bhrāntitve tanna siddhayediti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathāca tasya bhrānti tve tat na siddhayet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, if that were deluded, it would not be established. This is the meaning.

original: paramārthato mā saitsīditi ca na vācyam /
analyzed: paramārthataḥ mā saitsīt iti ca na vācyam
translated: And it should not be said Let it not be so in reality.
Because the nature of revealing the truth is accepted.

original: atha śrutisvarūpādiviṣaye tanmānatvaṃ svīkriyata iti dvitīyamanūdyottaramāha taccediti //
analyzed: atha śruti svarūpa ādi viṣaye tad māna tvam svīkriyate iti dvitīyam anūdya uttaram āha tat ced iti
translated: Now, if the validity of that is accepted in the case of the form of the Veda etc., then the second is stated and the answer is given with If that etc.

original: ekatra prāmāṇye paratrāpi prāmāṇyamaṅgīkartavyamityetatkuta ityato 'viśeṣādityāha naceti //
analyzed: ekatra prāmāṇye paratra api prāmāṇyam aṅgīkartavyam iti etat kutas iti atas viśeṣāt iti āha na ca iti
translated: If there is validity in one place, then validity must be accepted in another place also. Where is this from? Therefore, it is said And that is not so due to non-distinction.

analyzed: pūrvavat vayākhyānam  evam sākṣiṇaḥ
translated: The explanation is as before.

analyzed: m upetya bādhaka abhāvena aham duḥkhī ityādeḥ bhraṃma tvam na upapadyate iti uktam
translated: Thus, accepting the common nature of the witness with other means of valid knowledge, it is said that the delusion of I am unhappy etc. is not possible due to the absence of contradiction.

original: idānīṃ sākṣiṇo yathārthatvaniyamācca na duḥkhādiviṣaye bhramatvaśaṅkopapadyate /🔽kiṃ bādhakagaveṣaṇādinetyāśayavānsākṣiṇo yathārthatvaniyamaṃ vipakṣe bādhakena samarthayate bādha iti // /
analyzed: idānīm sākṣiṇaḥ yathārtha tva niyamāt ca na duḥkha ādi viṣaye bhrama tva śaṅkā upapadyate  kim bādhaka gaveṣaṇa ādinā iti āśayavān sākṣiṇaḥ yathārtha tva niyamam vipakṣe bādhakena samarthayate bādhaḥ iti
translated: Now, because of the restriction of the truthfulness of the witness, doubt of error regarding pain etc. is not possible.🔽With the intention that what is the use of searching for a sublating cognition etc.? he establishes the restriction of truthfulness of the witness in the contrary by a sublating cognition, saying if there were a sublation etc.

original: anubhūte sākṣipratīte 'rthe yadi bādhaḥ pravarteta sākṣī yadi kutracidayathārthaḥ syāditi yāvat /
analyzed: anubhūte sākṣi pratīte rthe yadi bādhaḥ pravarteta sākṣī yadi kutracid ayathārthaḥ syāt iti yāvat
translated: If there were a sublation of the object experienced, i.e. known by the witness, i.e. if the witness were false in some case.

analyzed: a yathātu arthasya bādhā unneya tvāt evam uktam
translated: Because the falsity of the object is to be inferred from the sublation, it is said thus.

original: tadā kathaṃ stambho 'yaṃ kumbho 'yamiti padārthānāṃ nirṇaya īyate upeyate /
analyzed: tadā katham stambhaḥ yam kumbhaḥ yam iti padārthānām nirṇayaḥ īyate upeyate
translated: Then how is the determination of objects such as this is a pillar, this is a pot obtained, i.e. reached?

analyzed: etat eva prapañcayati kaḥ pi iti
translated: He elaborates on this, saying whoever etc.

original: ko 'pi hy artho na niścetuṃ śakyate bhramavādinā // / / //
analyzed: kaḥ pi hi arthaḥ na niścetum śakyate bhrama vādinā
translated: Whoever cannot ascertain any object, the one who asserts error, i.e.

analyzed: bhrama vādinā sākṣiṇaḥ kvacid bhrama tvam vadatā
translated: the one who asserts that the witness is false in some case.

original: yadi sākṣī kvacidayathārthaḥ syāttadā padārthanirṇayo na syādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yadi sākṣī kvacid ayathārthaḥ syāt tadā padārtha nirṇayaḥ na syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: If the witness were false in some case, then there would be no determination of objects. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ anye pi
translated: As others also say:

analyzed: jñānasya vyabhicāri tve viśvāsaḥ kinnibandhanaḥ iti
translated: If knowledge is deceptive, on what basis is there confidence?

original: nanu ca nirṇayo niścaya iti cāvadhāraṇātmakaṃ jñānamucyate /
analyzed: nanu ca nirṇayaḥ niścayaḥ iti ca avadhāraṇa ātmakam jñānam ucyate
translated: But it is said that ascertainment is a cognition that has the nature of determination.

analyzed: tat ca stambha kumbha ādiṣu artheṣu tad tad kāraṇa sāmagrī vaśāt eva utpadyate
translated: And that arises just from the collection of causes and conditions regarding objects like a pillar, a pot, etc.

analyzed: nirṇāyaka abhāva sahakṛta samāna dharma darśana ādinā hi anavadhāraṇa ātmakam jñānam saṃśaya pada vedanīyam janyate
translated: For by seeing similar properties assisted by the absence of a determiner, a cognition having the nature of non-ascertainment is produced, which is to be experienced by the word doubt.

analyzed: tad vilakṣaṇayā ca sāmagṣā avadhāraṇa jñānam
translated: And by a collection that is different from that, a cognition of determination arises.

analyzed: tatra kaḥ sākṣiṇaḥ yāthārthya niyamasya upayogaḥ
translated: What use is there there for the witness to be restricted to being in accordance with reality?

analyzed: kiñca tad abhāvena apaneṣyate
translated: And what is to be removed by its absence?

analyzed: ucyate
translated: It is said:

analyzed: na stambhaḥ yam iti eka ākāra pratiniyatam jñānam iha hi
translated: This is a pillar is not a cognition that is restricted to a single form.

analyzed: nirṇaya ādi śabdaiḥ abhidhīyate
translated: For here, it is indeed expressed by words like ascertainment, etc.

analyzed: api tarhi tad anantara bhāvī vastu tathātva āśvāsaḥ
translated: But then, the confidence in the true nature of the object that arises after that.

analyzed: tathā hi
translated: It is like this.

analyzed: vaktāraḥ bhavanti  stambhaḥ iti ca
translated: The speakers say:🔽It is cognized as a pillar,

original: pratīyate bhavati cāyaṃ stambha iti vā vastutattvaṃ tu na vidma iti veti /
analyzed: pratīyate bhavati ca ayam stambhaḥ iti vā vastu tattvam tu na vidmaḥ iti vā iti
translated: and it is a pillar, but we do not know the true nature of the object.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: What is the reason for that?

original: ekākārapratiniyateṣvapi jñāneṣa keṣāñcidbhramatvasya keṣāñcidabhramatvasya bahulamupalabdhatvenedānīṃ jāyamānepyeṣve
analyzed: eka ākāra pratiniyateṣu api keṣāñcid bhrama tvasya keṣāñcid abhrama tvasya bahulam upalabdha tvena idānīm jāyamāna ipi eṣu
translated: Even in cognitions restricted to one form, it is often observed that some are erroneous and some are non-erroneous. Therefore, even when these are produced now,

analyzed: ka ākāra niyate jñāne vastu tathātva viśvāsa ayogāt
translated: it is not possible to have confidence in the true nature of the object in cognitions restricted to one form.

analyzed: bhavatu vastu tathātva āśvāsaḥ vastu darśana pṛṣṭhabhāvī nirṇayaḥ
translated: Let there be confidence in the true nature of the object, the ascertainment that arises after the perception of the object.

original: so 'pi tasya daśarnasya bhramatvābhramatvanirṇayamevāpekṣate /🔽yadi jñānaṃ bhramaḥ syāttadā vastvatathābhūtamityavasīyate /
analyzed: saḥ u pi tasya daśarnasya bhrama tva abhrama tva nirṇayam eva apekṣate  yadi jñānam bhramaḥ syāt tadā vastu atathābhūtam iti avasīyate
translated: That also depends on the ascertainment of whether that perception is erroneous or non-erroneous.🔽If the cognition is erroneous, then the object is ascertained to be not as it appears.

analyzed: yadi tu abhramaḥ tadā tathābhūtam iti
translated: But if it is non-erroneous, then it is ascertained to be as it appears.

analyzed: evam ca kim sākṣiṇaḥ yāthārthya niyamena upanīyate
translated: In this way, what is being presented is the restriction of the truthfulness of the witness?

original: kiṃca tasya bhramatvenāpanīyata ityata āha bhramatvamiti //
analyzed: kiṃca tasya bhrama tvena apanīyate iti atas āha bhrama tvam iti
translated: Or is it being presented as erroneous? To this he says:

analyzed: bhrama tvam abhrama tvam ca yadā eva anubhava upagam
translated: Erroneousness and non-erroneousness are accepted only when experienced.

analyzed: ekasya bhramatā tatra parasya a bhramatā kutas
translated: How can one be erroneous and the other non-erroneous in the same case?

analyzed: satyam pratyayānām bhrama tva abhrama tva nirṇaya āyattaḥ vastu nirṇayaḥ iti
translated: It is true that the ascertainment of the object depends on the ascertainment of whether the means of knowledge are erroneous or non-erroneous.

original: saiva tatra pratyayeṣvekasya stambhādau puruṣādipratyayasya bhramatāparasya stambhādipratyayasyābhramatā ca kuto nirṇetavyā na kuto 'pi /
analyzed: sā eva tatra pratyayeṣu ekasya stambha ādau puruṣa ādi pratyayasya bhrama tā aparasya stambha ādi pratyayasya abhrama tā ca kutas nirṇetavyā na
translated: How can the correctness of one cognition, such as the cognition of a post in a post, and the error of another cognition, such as the cognition of a man in a post, be determined? From nowhere.

analyzed: kutas yadā yatas
translated: From where? When?

analyzed: pratyayānām ca anubhava upagam sākṣiṇā eva adhyavaseyam iti
translated: The correctness and error of cognitions must be ascertained by the witness itself, based on experience.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be argued:

original: karaṇadoṣabādhakapratyayādhīnaṃ pratyayānāṃ bhramatvamabhramatvaṃ ca saṃvādāyattaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: karaṇa doṣa bādhaka pratyaya adhīnam pratyayānām bhrama tvam abhrama tvam ca saṃvāda āyattam bhaviṣyati
translated: The correctness and error of cognitions depend on the defects of the sense organs and counteracting cognitions, and will be determined by agreement.

analyzed: tat katham tad anavadhāraṇam iti āśaṅkām pariharan uktam artham spaṣṭam ācaṣṭe bhrama tvam iti
translated: How then can that be undetermined? To remove this doubt, he clearly states the intended meaning, saying error and so on.

original: bhramatvamabhramatvaṃ ca sarvaṃ vedyaṃ hi sākṣiṇā /
analyzed: bhrama tvam abhrama tvam ca sarvam vedyam hi sākṣiṇā
translated: All error and non-error are indeed to be known by the witness.

original: sa cet sākṣī kvacid duṣyaḥ kathaṃ nirṇaya īyate // / / //
analyzed: sa ced sākṣī kvacid duṣyaḥ katham nirṇayaḥ īyate
translated: If that witness is defective in some way, how can a determination be reached?

original: pratyayānāṃ bhramatvamabhramatvaṃ tadavadhāraṇopayuktaṃ ca sarvaṃ karaṇadoṣādikaṃ sākṣiṇā niśceyam /
analyzed: pratyayānām bhrama tvam abhrama tvam tad avadhāraṇa upayuktam ca sarvam karaṇa doṣa ādikam sākṣiṇā niśceyam
translated: All error and non-error of cognitions, and everything useful for determining them, such as the defects of the sense organs, must be ascertained by the witness.

analyzed: aniścitasya bhrama tva ādi avadhāraṇa aprasaṅgāt
translated: Because that which is not ascertained cannot lead to the determination of error and so on.

original: sa cetsākṣī kvacit duṣyaḥ ayathārthaḥ syāttadā kathaṃ kāraṇadoṣāderbhramatvādervastutathātvādervā niṇarya īyate /
analyzed: sa ced sākṣī kvacid duṣyaḥ ayathārthaḥ syāt tadā katham kāraṇa doṣa ādeḥ bhrama tva ādeḥ vastu tathātva ādeḥ vā niṇaryaḥ īyate
translated: If that witness is somehow corrupted, and is not in accordance with reality, then how is the error of the fault of the cause, etc., or the reality of that state, etc., ascertained?

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati  pratyayānām bhrama tva avadhāraṇam kāka
translated: This is what is said.

original: raṇadoṣādyāyattaṃ tathāpi sākṣiṇo yāthārthyaniyamābhāve na siddhayet /
analyzed: raṇa doṣa ādi āyattam tathā api sākṣiṇaḥ yāthārthya niyama abhāve na
translated: The ascertainment of the error of the conditions, even though dependent on the fault of the cause, etc., would not be established in the absence of the restriction of the truthfulness of the witness.

analyzed: nahi tad svarūpeṇa upayuktam
translated: For that is not useful by its own nature.

original: atiprasaṅgāt /🔽kintu niścitameva tanniścayaśca sākṣātkāraparamparayā vā sākṣiṇyāyatate /
analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt  kintu niścitam eva tad niścayaḥ ca sākṣātkāra paramparayā vā sākṣiṇi āyatate
translated: Because of the absurdity of the consequence.🔽But that ascertainment extends either directly or indirectly through the witness itself.

analyzed: sa hi kā karaṇa doṣa ādikam svayam eva vā
translated: For he ascertains the error either by himself ascertaining the fault of the cause, etc.,

analyzed: tad grāhaka prāmāṇya grahaṇena vā niścitya bhrama tvam niścinoti
translated: or by the apprehension of the validity of the apprehender of that.

original: tataśca tasya kvacidayathārthatve 'viśvasanīyatvāpattyā na nirṇayaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tatas ca tasya kvacid ayathārtha tve viśvasanīya tva āpattyā na nirṇayaḥ syāt
translated: And then, if that [witness] is not in accordance with reality in some case, there would be no ascertainment due to the consequence of unreliability.

analyzed: abhrama tva niścayaḥ tu na saṃvāda adhīnaḥ
translated: But the ascertainment of non-error is not dependent on agreement.

analyzed: tathā sati anavasthā ādi doṣāḥ prāduṣyuḥ iti uktam
translated: For if it were so, the faults of infinite regress, etc., would arise. This has been said.

analyzed: kintu kevala sākṣiṇi āyattaḥ
translated: But it is dependent solely on the witness itself.

analyzed: viparyaya śaṅkā nirāse tu saṃvādasya anupraveśaḥ
translated: But in the negation of the suspicion of error, there is the entry of agreement.

analyzed: na ca saṃvādaḥ pi aniścitaḥ ṅgam
translated: And agreement is not an uncertain factor.

analyzed: tad niścayaḥ ca sākṣi adhīnaḥ eva
translated: And the ascertainment of that depends on the witness alone.

original: tasya ca kvacidayathārthatve tadubhayanirṇayo 'pi na bhavediti / /
analyzed: tasya ca kvacid ayathārtha tve tad ubhaya nirṇayaḥ na bhavet iti
translated: And if that is false in some cases, then the determination of both would not be possible.

original: nanu sākṣiṇo yathārthatvaniyame 'pi pratyayānāṃ bhramatvābhramatvanirṇayo nopapadyate /
analyzed: nanu sākṣiṇaḥ yathārtha tva niyame pi pratyayānām bhrama tva abhrama tva nirṇayaḥ nā upapadyate
translated: But even if the truth of the witness is certain, the determination of the error or non-error of the cognitions is not possible.

analyzed: nahi yāthārthyam svarūpeṇa eva upayuktam
translated: For truthfulness is not useful by itself.

analyzed: atiprasaṅgāt
translated: Because of over-extension.

analyzed: kintu niścitam eva
translated: But only when certain.

analyzed: na ca tad niścaya upāyaḥ sti  atas tad aniścayāt kāka
translated: And there is no means of ascertaining that.

original: raṇadoṣāderbhramatvādeḥ stambhatvāderaniścaya evetyata āha viśeṣā iti //
analyzed: raṇa doṣa ādeḥ bhrama tva ādeḥ stambha tva ādeḥ aniścayaḥ eva iti atas āha viśeṣāḥ iti
translated: Therefore, because that is uncertain, the uncertainty of the error etc. of the crow's cawing defect etc. and the uncertainty of the pillar etc.

original: viśeṣā sarva evaite sākṣipratyayagocarāḥ // / / //🔽viśiṣyante etairiti viśeṣāḥ kāka
analyzed: viśeṣā sarve eva ete sākṣi pratyaya gocarāḥ  viśiṣyante etaiḥ iti viśeṣāḥ
translated: He says: All these distinctions are the domain of the witness's cognition.

analyzed: raṇa doṣa upa ādayaḥ
translated: They are distinguished by these, therefore they are distinctions, the crow's cawing defect etc.

analyzed: sākṣi pratyakṣa gocarāḥ eva iti sambandhaḥ  sākṣi yāthārthyasya sākṣiṇā eva u niścaya upapatteḥ
translated: They are only the domain of the witness's perception. This is the connection.🔽Because the truth of the witness is possible only by the ascertainment of the witness itself.

analyzed: asya arthasya ca vakṣyamāṇa vyavahāra anyathā anupapatti siddha tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And because this meaning is established by the impossibility of any other usage of what is going to be said, this is the idea.

analyzed: yadi sākṣī kvacid vayabhicaret tadā tena aviśvasanīyena kāka
translated: If the witness were to err somewhere, then by that untrustworthy person, the determination of the faults of the crow

analyzed: raṇa doṣa ādi niścayaḥ na syāt
translated: fight, etc. would not be possible.

original: tadabhāve ca pratyayānāṃ bhramatvādi na niścīyeta /
analyzed: tad abhāve ca pratyayānām bhrama tva ādi na niścīyeta
translated: And in the absence of that, the error, etc. of the conditions could not be ascertained.

analyzed: tathā ca vastu nirṇayaḥ na syāt
translated: And thus there would be no determination of the object.

analyzed: kāraṇa abhāve kārya akārya udayā
translated: It has been said that in the absence of a cause, the effect cannot arise,

analyzed: yogāt iti uktam
translated: because of incompatibility.

analyzed: tatra mā bhūt etat sarvam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that let all this not be so, it is not so.

analyzed: tathā sati hāna upādāna ādi sarva vyavahā vilopa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because in that case, there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of all worldly transactions such as abandonment, acceptance, etc.

analyzed: katham  sarva vyavahārāṇām atatkārya tvāt iti āha ūrīkṛtya ca iti
translated: How?

original: ūrīkṛtya ca tān sarvān vyavahāraḥ pravartate // / / //
analyzed: ūrīkṛtya ca tān sarvān vyavahāraḥ pravartate
translated: Because all worldly transactions are not the effects of that. It is said: And all those being taken into account, worldly transactions proceed.🔽...

analyzed: niścitya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: having ascertained.

analyzed: caḥ va dhāraṇe  tān sarvān kāka
translated: The word ca (and) is for emphasis.

analyzed: raṇa doṣa ādī
translated: And all those, the faults of the crow fight, etc.,

original: n ūrīkṛtya vyavahāra pravartata iti gauṇaṃ samānakartṛkatvam /
analyzed: ūrīkṛtya pravartate iti gauṇam samāna kartṛka tvam
translated: being taken into account, worldly transactions proceed. The secondary sameness of agent is [to be understood].

analyzed: yat vā urīkṛtya kāraṇatayā upādāya kāraṇīkṛtvā iti vyākhyeyam
translated: Or, alternatively, it should be explained as having taken into account, having made the cause, having made the cause.

analyzed: tathā hi  idam rajatam iti bhrāntyā pravṛttaḥ kāka
translated: It is like this.

analyzed: raṇa doṣam bādhaka pratyayam ca
translated: Engaged through the error this is silver, the fault of the crow fight, and the contradictory cognition,🔽...

original: vāvadhārya tasya jñānasya bhramatvaṃ niścitya nedaṃ rajataṃ kintu śuktireveti vastu vyavasthāpya jahāti /
analyzed: vā avadhārya tasya jñānasya bhrama tvam niścitya na idam rajatam kintu śuktiḥ eva iti vastu vyavasthāpya jahāti
translated: Having ascertained the error of that cognition, having determined that this is not silver but merely a shell, he abandons it.

original: tathā jalamedaditi pratītya tasya pratyayasyāpātata evānyathātvaśaṅkāyāṃ saṃvādaṃ niveśya tatsvarūpaprāmāṇye gṛhītvāca
analyzed: tathā jalam edat iti pratītya tasya pratyayasya āpātataḥ eva anyathātva śaṅkāyām saṃvādam niveśya tad svarūpa prāmāṇye gṛhītvā āca
translated: Similarly, having cognized this as water, when there is doubt about its being otherwise, having ascertained its nature and validity,

analyzed: abhrama tvam niścitya jalam etat bhavati eva iti avadhārya tat upādatte iti
translated: having ascertained its non-erroneousness, having determined that this is indeed water, he accepts it.

original: nanu nāyamasti niyamo yaduktarītyār'thatathātvādhyavasāyapūrvaka eva vyavahāra iti /🔽tatsandehādināpidapi🔽vyavahāradarśanādityata āha sākṣiṇa iti //
analyzed: nanu nā ayam asti niyamaḥ yat ukta rītyā artha tathātva adhyavasāya pūrvakaḥ eva vyavahāraḥ iti  tad sandeha ādinā apidapi  vyavahāra darśanāt iti atas āha sākṣiṇaḥ iti
translated: Now, this is not the rule that practical activity is preceded by the ascertainment of the reality of the object in the manner stated.🔽Because practical activity is seen even with doubt about it. To this he says: The practical activity of the witness is said to be...

analyzed: sākṣiṇaḥ vyavasāyī tu vyavahāraḥ bhidhīyate  vyavasāyī niraśaṅkaḥ
translated: The practical activity of the witness is said to be...

original: dī ca vyavahāro 'smābhiruktarītyā sākṣiṇaḥ kāryo 'bhidhīyate na tu vyavahāramātram /
analyzed: ca smābhiḥ ukta rītyā sākṣiṇaḥ kāryaḥ abhidhīyate na tu vyavahāra mātram
translated: The practical activity that is free from doubt, free from contradiction, and free from error is said to be the practical activity of the witness in the manner stated by us, not mere practical activity.

analyzed: na ca viśiṣyaḥ vyavahāraḥ rtha tathātva adhyavasāya pūrvakatām vyabhicarati iti
translated: And the qualified practical activity does not deviate from being preceded by the ascertainment of the reality of the object.

original: astu vyavahāravilopaḥ kinnaśchinnamityāśaṅkāṃ pariharannuktāprasaṅgānāṃ viparyayaparyavasānamāha tasmāditi //
analyzed: astu vyavahāra vilopaḥ kinnaḥ chinnam iti āśaṅkām pariharan ukta aprasaṅgānām viparyaya paryavasānam āha tasmāt iti
translated: To remove the doubt that the abandonment of worldly usage is not a fault, he states the conclusion opposite to the undesirable consequences mentioned: Therefore, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt sarva prasiddhasya vyavahārasya siddhaye
translated: Therefore, for the establishment of worldly usage, which is well-known to all,

original: sākṣī nirdoṣa evaikaḥ sadāṅgīkārya eva naḥ // / / //🔽yasmātsākṣiṇaḥ kvacidayathārthatve 'viśvasanīyatvāpattyā kāka
analyzed: sākṣī nirdoṣaḥ eva ekaḥ sadā aṅgīkāryaḥ eva naḥ  yasmāt sākṣiṇaḥ kvacid ayathārtha tve viśvasanīya tva āpattyā kāka
translated: the faultless witness alone should always be accepted by us.
